children.value: Neb had raised himself a little and gazed without seeing. Despair had completely changed his countenance. He could scarcely be recognized, exhausted with fatigue, broken with grief. He believed his master was dead.
children.prevalue: Neb had raised himself a little and gazed without seeing Despair had completely changed his countenance He could scarcely be recognized exhausted with fatigue broken with grief He believed his master was dead

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Gideon Spilett at last rose, after a long and attentive examination.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett at last rose after a long and attentive examination

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: He lives! said he.
children.prevalue: He lives said he

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Pencroft knelt in his turn beside the engineer, he also heard a throbbing, and even felt a slight breath on his cheek.
children.prevalue: Pencroft knelt in his turn beside the engineer he also heard a throbbing and even felt a slight breath on his cheek

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Herbert at a word from the reporter ran out to look for water. He found, a hundred feet off, a limpid stream, which seemed to have been greatly increased by the rains, and which filtered through the sand; but nothing in which to put the water, not even a shell among the downs. The lad was obliged to content himself with dipping his handkerchief in the stream, and with it hastened back to the grotto.
children.prevalue: Herbert at a word from the reporter ran out to look for water He found a hundred feet off a limpid stream which seemed to have been greatly increased by the rains and which filtered through the sand but nothing in which to put the water not even a shell among the downs The lad was obliged to content himself with dipping his handkerchief in the stream and with it hastened back to the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Happily the wet handkerchief was enough for Gideon Spilett, who only wished to wet the engineer's lips. The cold water produced an almost immediate effect. His chest heaved and he seemed to try to speak.
children.prevalue: Happily the wet handkerchief was enough for Gideon Spilett who only wished to wet the engineer s lips The cold water produced an almost immediate effect His chest heaved and he seemed to try to speak

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: We will save him! exclaimed the reporter.
children.prevalue: We will save him exclaimed the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: At these words hope revived in Neb's heart. He undressed his master to see if he was wounded, but not so much as a bruise was to be found, either on the head, body, or limbs, which was surprising, as he must have been dashed against the rocks; even the hands were uninjured, and it was difficult to explain how the engineer showed no traces of the efforts which he must have made to get out of reach of the breakers.
children.prevalue: At these words hope revived in Neb s heart He undressed his master to see if he was wounded but not so much as a bruise was to be found either on the head body or limbs which was surprising as he must have been dashed against the rocks even the hands were uninjured and it was difficult to explain how the engineer showed no traces of the efforts which he must have made to get out of reach of the breakers

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But the explanation would come later. When Cyrus was able to speak he would say what had happened. For the present the question was, how to recall him to life, and it appeared likely that rubbing would bring this about; so they set to work with the sailor's jersey.
children.prevalue: But the explanation would come later When Cyrus was able to speak he would say what had happened For the present the question was how to recall him to life and it appeared likely that rubbing would bring this about so they set to work with the sailor s jersey

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The engineer, revived by this rude shampooing, moved his arm slightly and began to breathe more regularly. He was sinking from exhaustion, and certainly, had not the reporter and his companions arrived, it would have been all over with Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: The engineer revived by this rude shampooing moved his arm slightly and began to breathe more regularly He was sinking from exhaustion and certainly had not the reporter and his companions arrived it would have been all over with Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You thought your master was dead, didn't you? said the seaman to Neb.
children.prevalue: You thought your master was dead didn t you said the seaman to Neb

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes! quite dead! replied Neb, and if Top had not found you, and brought you here, I should have buried my master, and then have lain down on his grave to die!
children.prevalue: Yes quite dead replied Neb and if Top had not found you and brought you here I should have buried my master and then have lain down on his grave to die

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It had indeed been a narrow escape for Cyrus Harding!
children.prevalue: It had indeed been a narrow escape for Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Neb then recounted what had happened. The day before, after having left the Chimneys at daybreak, he had ascended the coast in a northerly direction, and had reached that part of the shore which he had already visited.
children.prevalue: Neb then recounted what had happened The day before after having left the Chimneys at daybreak he had ascended the coast in a northerly direction and had reached that part of the shore which he had already visited

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: There, without any hope he acknowledged, Neb had searched the beach, among the rocks, on the sand, for the smallest trace to guide him. He examined particularly that part of the beach which was not covered by the high tide, for near the sea the water would have obliterated all marks. Neb did not expect to find his master living. It was for a corpse that he searched, a corpse which he wished to bury with his own hands!
children.prevalue: There without any hope he acknowledged Neb had searched the beach among the rocks on the sand for the smallest trace to guide him He examined particularly that part of the beach which was not covered by the high tide for near the sea the water would have obliterated all marks Neb did not expect to find his master living It was for a corpse that he searched a corpse which he wished to bury with his own hands

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: He sought long in vain. This desert coast appeared never to have been visited by a human creature. The shells, those which the sea had not reached, and which might be met with by millions above high-water mark, were untouched. Not a shell was broken.
children.prevalue: He sought long in vain This desert coast appeared never to have been visited by a human creature The shells those which the sea had not reached and which might be met with by millions above high water mark were untouched Not a shell was broken

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Neb then resolved to walk along the beach for some miles. It was possible that the waves had carried the body to quite a distant point. When a corpse floats a little distance from a low shore, it rarely happens that the tide does not throw it up, sooner or later. This Neb knew, and he wished to see his master again for the last time.
children.prevalue: Neb then resolved to walk along the beach for some miles It was possible that the waves had carried the body to quite a distant point When a corpse floats a little distance from a low shore it rarely happens that the tide does not throw it up sooner or later This Neb knew and he wished to see his master again for the last time

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I went along the coast for another two miles, carefully examining the beach, both at high and low water, and I had despaired of finding anything, when yesterday, above five in the evening, I saw footprints on the sand.
children.prevalue: I went along the coast for another two miles carefully examining the beach both at high and low water and I had despaired of finding anything when yesterday above five in the evening I saw footprints on the sand

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Footprints? exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Footprints exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes! replied Neb.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Neb

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Did these footprints begin at the water's edge? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: Did these footprints begin at the water s edge asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: No, replied Neb, only above high-water mark, for the others must have been washed out by the tide.
children.prevalue: No replied Neb only above high water mark for the others must have been washed out by the tide

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Go on, Neb, said Spilett.
children.prevalue: Go on Neb said Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I went half crazy when I saw these footprints. They were very clear and went towards the downs. I followed them for a quarter of a mile, running, but taking care not to destroy them. Five minutes after, as it was getting dark, I heard the barking of a dog. It was Top, and Top brought me here, to my master!
children.prevalue: I went half crazy when I saw these footprints They were very clear and went towards the downs I followed them for a quarter of a mile running but taking care not to destroy them Five minutes after as it was getting dark I heard the barking of a dog It was Top and Top brought me here to my master

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Neb ended his account by saying what had been his grief at finding the inanimate body, in which he vainly sought for the least sign of life. Now that he had found him dead he longed for him to be alive. All his efforts were useless! Nothing remained to be done but to render the last duties to the one whom he had loved so much! Neb then thought of his companions. They, no doubt, would wish to see the unfortunate man again. Top was there. Could he not rely on the sagacity of the faithful animal? Neb several times pronounced the name of the reporter, the one among his companions whom Top knew best.
children.prevalue: Neb ended his account by saying what had been his grief at finding the inanimate body in which he vainly sought for the least sign of life Now that he had found him dead he longed for him to be alive All his efforts were useless Nothing remained to be done but to render the last duties to the one whom he had loved so much Neb then thought of his companions They no doubt would wish to see the unfortunate man again Top was there Could he not rely on the sagacity of the faithful animal Neb several times pronounced the name of the reporter the one among his companions whom Top knew best

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Then he pointed to the south, and the dog bounded off in the direction indicated to him.
children.prevalue: Then he pointed to the south and the dog bounded off in the direction indicated to him

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: We have heard how, guided by an instinct which might be looked upon almost as supernatural, Top had found them.
children.prevalue: We have heard how guided by an instinct which might be looked upon almost as supernatural Top had found them

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Neb's companions had listened with great attention to this account.
children.prevalue: Neb s companions had listened with great attention to this account

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It was unaccountable to them how Cyrus Harding, after the efforts which he must have made to escape from the waves by crossing the rocks, had not received even a scratch. And what could not be explained either was how the engineer had managed to get to this cave in the downs, more than a mile from the shore.
children.prevalue: It was unaccountable to them how Cyrus Harding after the efforts which he must have made to escape from the waves by crossing the rocks had not received even a scratch And what could not be explained either was how the engineer had managed to get to this cave in the downs more than a mile from the shore

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: So, Neb, said the reporter, it was not you who brought your master to this place.
children.prevalue: So Neb said the reporter it was not you who brought your master to this place

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: No, it was not I, replied the Negro.
children.prevalue: No it was not I replied the Negro

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: It's very clear that the captain came here by himself, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It s very clear that the captain came here by himself said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It is clear in reality, observed Spilett, but it is not credible!
children.prevalue: It is clear in reality observed Spilett but it is not credible

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The explanation of this fact could only be produced from the engineer's own lips, and they must wait for that till speech returned. Rubbing had re-established the circulation of the blood. Cyrus Harding moved his arm again, then his head, and a few incomprehensible words escaped him.
children.prevalue: The explanation of this fact could only be produced from the engineer s own lips and they must wait for that till speech returned Rubbing had re established the circulation of the blood Cyrus Harding moved his arm again then his head and a few incomprehensible words escaped him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Neb, who was bending over him, spoke, but the engineer did not appear to hear, and his eyes remained closed. Life was only exhibited in him by movement, his senses had not as yet been restored.
children.prevalue: Neb who was bending over him spoke but the engineer did not appear to hear and his eyes remained closed Life was only exhibited in him by movement his senses had not as yet been restored

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Pencroft much regretted not having either fire, or the means of procuring it, for he had, unfortunately, forgotten to bring the burnt linen, which would easily have ignited from the sparks produced by striking together two flints. As to the engineer's pockets, they were entirely empty, except that of his waistcoat, which contained his watch. It was necessary to carry Harding to the Chimneys, and that as soon as possible. This was the opinion of all.
children.prevalue: Pencroft much regretted not having either fire or the means of procuring it for he had unfortunately forgotten to bring the burnt linen which would easily have ignited from the sparks produced by striking together two flints As to the engineer s pockets they were entirely empty except that of his waistcoat which contained his watch It was necessary to carry Harding to the Chimneys and that as soon as possible This was the opinion of all

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Meanwhile, the care which was lavished on the engineer brought him back to consciousness sooner than they could have expected. The water with which they wetted his lips revived him gradually. Pencroft also thought of mixing with the water some moisture from the titra's flesh which he had brought. Herbert ran to the beach and returned with two large bivalve shells. The sailor concocted something which he introduced between the lips of the engineer, who eagerly drinking it opened his eyes.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile the care which was lavished on the engineer brought him back to consciousness sooner than they could have expected The water with which they wetted his lips revived him gradually Pencroft also thought of mixing with the water some moisture from the titra s flesh which he had brought Herbert ran to the beach and returned with two large bivalve shells The sailor concocted something which he introduced between the lips of the engineer who eagerly drinking it opened his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Neb and the reporter were leaning over him.
children.prevalue: Neb and the reporter were leaning over him

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: My master! my master! cried Neb.
children.prevalue: My master my master cried Neb

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The engineer heard him. He recognized Neb and Spilett, then his other two companions, and his hand slightly pressed theirs.
children.prevalue: The engineer heard him He recognized Neb and Spilett then his other two companions and his hand slightly pressed theirs

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: A few words again escaped him, which showed what thoughts were, even then, troubling his brain. This time he was understood. Undoubtedly they were the same words he had before attempted to utter.
children.prevalue: A few words again escaped him which showed what thoughts were even then troubling his brain This time he was understood Undoubtedly they were the same words he had before attempted to utter

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Island or continent? he murmured.
children.prevalue: Island or continent he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Bother the continent, cried Pencroft hastily; there is time enough to see about that, captain! we don't care for anything, provided you are living.
children.prevalue: Bother the continent cried Pencroft hastily there is time enough to see about that captain we don t care for anything provided you are living

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The engineer nodded faintly, and then appeared to sleep.
children.prevalue: The engineer nodded faintly and then appeared to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: They respected this sleep, and the reporter began immediately to make arrangements for transporting Harding to a more comfortable place. Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft left the cave and directed their steps towards a high mound crowned with a few distorted trees. On the way the sailor could not help repeating,--
children.prevalue: They respected this sleep and the reporter began immediately to make arrangements for transporting Harding to a more comfortable place Neb Herbert and Pencroft left the cave and directed their steps towards a high mound crowned with a few distorted trees On the way the sailor could not help repeating

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Island or continent! To think of that, when at one's last gasp! What a man!
children.prevalue: Island or continent To think of that when at one s last gasp What a man

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Arrived at the summit of the mound, Pencroft and his two companions set to work, with no other tools than their hands, to despoil of its principal branches a rather sickly tree, a sort of marine fir; with these branches they made a litter, on which, covered with grass and leaves, they could carry the engineer.
children.prevalue: Arrived at the summit of the mound Pencroft and his two companions set to work with no other tools than their hands to despoil of its principal branches a rather sickly tree a sort of marine fir with these branches they made a litter on which covered with grass and leaves they could carry the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: This occupied them nearly forty minutes, and it was ten o'clock when they returned to Cyrus Harding whom Spilett had not left.
children.prevalue: This occupied them nearly forty minutes and it was ten o clock when they returned to Cyrus Harding whom Spilett had not left

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The engineer was just awaking from the sleep, or rather from the drowsiness, in which they had found him. The color was returning to his cheeks, which till now had been as pale as death. He raised himself a little, looked around him, and appeared to ask where he was.
children.prevalue: The engineer was just awaking from the sleep or rather from the drowsiness in which they had found him The color was returning to his cheeks which till now had been as pale as death He raised himself a little looked around him and appeared to ask where he was

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Can you listen to me without fatigue, Cyrus? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: Can you listen to me without fatigue Cyrus asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: It's my opinion, said the sailor, that Captain Harding will be able to listen to you still better, if he will have some more grouse jelly,--for we have grouse, captain, added he, presenting him with a little of this jelly, to which he this time added some of the flesh.
children.prevalue: It s my opinion said the sailor that Captain Harding will be able to listen to you still better if he will have some more grouse jelly for we have grouse captain added he presenting him with a little of this jelly to which he this time added some of the flesh

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Cyrus Harding ate a little of the grouse, and the rest was divided among his companions, who found it but a meager breakfast, for they were suffering extremely from hunger.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding ate a little of the grouse and the rest was divided among his companions who found it but a meager breakfast for they were suffering extremely from hunger

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Well! said the sailor, there is plenty of food at the Chimneys, for you must know, captain, that down there, in the south, we have a house, with rooms, beds, and fireplace, and in the pantry, several dozen of birds, which our Herbert calls couroucous. Your litter is ready, and as soon as you feel strong enough we will carry you home.
children.prevalue: Well said the sailor there is plenty of food at the Chimneys for you must know captain that down there in the south we have a house with rooms beds and fireplace and in the pantry several dozen of birds which our Herbert calls couroucous Your litter is ready and as soon as you feel strong enough we will carry you home

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Thanks, my friend, replied the engineer; wait another hour or two, and then we will set out. And now speak, Spilett.
children.prevalue: Thanks my friend replied the engineer wait another hour or two and then we will set out And now speak Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The reporter then told him all that had occurred. He recounted all the events with which Cyrus was unacquainted, the last fall of the balloon, the landing on this unknown land, which appeared a desert (whatever it was, whether island or continent), the discovery of the Chimneys, the search for him, not forgetting of course Neb's devotion, the intelligence exhibited by the faithful Top, as well as many other matters.
children.prevalue: The reporter then told him all that had occurred He recounted all the events with which Cyrus was unacquainted the last fall of the balloon the landing on this unknown land which appeared a desert whatever it was whether island or continent the discovery of the Chimneys the search for him not forgetting of course Neb s devotion the intelligence exhibited by the faithful Top as well as many other matters

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: But, asked Harding, in a still feeble voice, you did not, then, pick me up on the beach?
children.prevalue: But asked Harding in a still feeble voice you did not then pick me up on the beach

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: No, replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: No replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And did you not bring me to this cave?
children.prevalue: And did you not bring me to this cave

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: At what distance is this cave from the sea?
children.prevalue: At what distance is this cave from the sea

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: About a mile, replied Pencroft; and if you are astonished, captain, we are not less surprised ourselves at seeing you in this place!
children.prevalue: About a mile replied Pencroft and if you are astonished captain we are not less surprised ourselves at seeing you in this place

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Indeed, said the engineer, who was recovering gradually, and who took great interest in these details, indeed it is very singular!
children.prevalue: Indeed said the engineer who was recovering gradually and who took great interest in these details indeed it is very singular

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But, resumed the sailor, can you tell us what happened after you were carried off by the sea?
children.prevalue: But resumed the sailor can you tell us what happened after you were carried off by the sea

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Cyrus Harding considered. He knew very little. The wave had torn him from the balloon net. He sank at first several fathoms. On returning to the surface, in the half light, he felt a living creature struggling near him. It was Top, who had sprung to his help. He saw nothing of the balloon, which, lightened both of his weight and that of the dog, had darted away like an arrow.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding considered He knew very little The wave had torn him from the balloon net He sank at first several fathoms On returning to the surface in the half light he felt a living creature struggling near him It was Top who had sprung to his help He saw nothing of the balloon which lightened both of his weight and that of the dog had darted away like an arrow

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: There he was, in the midst of the angry sea, at a distance which could not be less than half a mile from the shore. He attempted to struggle against the billows by swimming vigorously. Top held him up by his clothes; but a strong current seized him and drove him towards the north, and after half an hour of exertion, he sank, dragging Top with him into the depths. From that moment to the moment in which he recovered to find himself in the arms of his friends he remembered nothing.
children.prevalue: There he was in the midst of the angry sea at a distance which could not be less than half a mile from the shore He attempted to struggle against the billows by swimming vigorously Top held him up by his clothes but a strong current seized him and drove him towards the north and after half an hour of exertion he sank dragging Top with him into the depths From that moment to the moment in which he recovered to find himself in the arms of his friends he remembered nothing

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: However, remarked Pencroft, you must have been thrown on to the beach, and you must have had strength to walk here, since Neb found your footmarks!
children.prevalue: However remarked Pencroft you must have been thrown on to the beach and you must have had strength to walk here since Neb found your footmarks

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes... of course, replied the engineer, thoughtfully; and you found no traces of human beings on this coast?
children.prevalue: Yes of course replied the engineer thoughtfully and you found no traces of human beings on this coast

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Not a trace, replied the reporter; besides, if by chance you had met with some deliverer there, just in the nick of time, why should he have abandoned you after having saved you from the waves?
children.prevalue: Not a trace replied the reporter besides if by chance you had met with some deliverer there just in the nick of time why should he have abandoned you after having saved you from the waves

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: You are right, my dear Spilett. Tell me, Neb, added the engineer, turning to his servant, it was not you who... you can't have had a moment of unconsciousness... during which no, that's absurd.... Do any of the footsteps still remain? asked Harding.
children.prevalue: You are right my dear Spilett Tell me Neb added the engineer turning to his servant it was not you who you can t have had a moment of unconsciousness during which no that s absurd Do any of the footsteps still remain asked Harding

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Yes, master, replied Neb; here, at the entrance, at the back of the mound, in a place sheltered from the rain and wind. The storm has destroyed the others.
children.prevalue: Yes master replied Neb here at the entrance at the back of the mound in a place sheltered from the rain and wind The storm has destroyed the others

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Pencroft, said Cyrus Harding, will you take my shoe and see if it fits exactly to the footprints?
children.prevalue: Pencroft said Cyrus Harding will you take my shoe and see if it fits exactly to the footprints

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The sailor did as the engineer requested. While he and Herbert, guided by Neb, went to the place where the footprints were to be found, Cyrus remarked to the reporter,--
children.prevalue: The sailor did as the engineer requested While he and Herbert guided by Neb went to the place where the footprints were to be found Cyrus remarked to the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: It is a most extraordinary thing!
children.prevalue: It is a most extraordinary thing

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Perfectly inexplicable! replied Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Perfectly inexplicable replied Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: But do not dwell upon it just now, my dear Spilett, we will talk about it by-and-by.
children.prevalue: But do not dwell upon it just now my dear Spilett we will talk about it by and by

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: A moment after the others entered.
children.prevalue: A moment after the others entered

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: There was no doubt about it. The engineer's shoe fitted exactly to the footmarks. It was therefore Cyrus Harding who had left them on the sand.
children.prevalue: There was no doubt about it The engineer s shoe fitted exactly to the footmarks It was therefore Cyrus Harding who had left them on the sand

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Come, said he, I must have experienced this unconsciousness which I attributed to Neb. I must have walked like a somnambulist, without any knowledge of my steps, and Top must have guided me here, after having dragged me from the waves... Come, Top! Come, old dog!
children.prevalue: Come said he I must have experienced this unconsciousness which I attributed to Neb I must have walked like a somnambulist without any knowledge of my steps and Top must have guided me here after having dragged me from the waves Come Top Come old dog

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The magnificent animal bounded barking to his master, and caresses were lavished on him. It was agreed that there was no other way of accounting for the rescue of Cyrus Harding, and that Top deserved all the honor of the affair.
children.prevalue: The magnificent animal bounded barking to his master and caresses were lavished on him It was agreed that there was no other way of accounting for the rescue of Cyrus Harding and that Top deserved all the honor of the affair

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Towards twelve o'clock, Pencroft having asked the engineer if they could now remove him, Harding, instead of replying, and by an effort which exhibited the most energetic will, got up. But he was obliged to lean on the sailor, or he would have fallen.
children.prevalue: Towards twelve o clock Pencroft having asked the engineer if they could now remove him Harding instead of replying and by an effort which exhibited the most energetic will got up But he was obliged to lean on the sailor or he would have fallen

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Well done! cried Pencroft; bring the captain's litter.
children.prevalue: Well done cried Pencroft bring the captain s litter

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The litter was brought; the transverse branches had been covered with leaves and long grass. Harding was laid on it, and Pencroft, having taken his place at one end and Neb at the other, they started towards the coast. There was a distance of eight miles to be accomplished; but, as they could not go fast, and it would perhaps be necessary to stop frequently, they reckoned that it would take at least six hours to reach the Chimneys. The wind was still strong, but fortunately it did not rain. Although lying down, the engineer, leaning on his elbow, observed the coast, particularly inland. He did not speak, but he gazed; and, no doubt, the appearance of the country, with its inequalities of ground, its forests, its various productions, were impressed on his mind. However, after traveling for two hours, fatigue overcame him, and he slept.
children.prevalue: The litter was brought the transverse branches had been covered with leaves and long grass Harding was laid on it and Pencroft having taken his place at one end and Neb at the other they started towards the coast There was a distance of eight miles to be accomplished but as they could not go fast and it would perhaps be necessary to stop frequently they reckoned that it would take at least six hours to reach the Chimneys The wind was still strong but fortunately it did not rain Although lying down the engineer leaning on his elbow observed the coast particularly inland He did not speak but he gazed and no doubt the appearance of the country with its inequalities of ground its forests its various productions were impressed on his mind However after traveling for two hours fatigue overcame him and he slept

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: At half-past five the little band arrived at the precipice, and a short time after at the Chimneys.
children.prevalue: At half past five the little band arrived at the precipice and a short time after at the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: They stopped, and the litter was placed on the sand; Cyrus Harding was sleeping profoundly, and did not awake.
children.prevalue: They stopped and the litter was placed on the sand Cyrus Harding was sleeping profoundly and did not awake

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Pencroft, to his extreme surprise, found that the terrible storm had quite altered the aspect of the place. Important changes had occurred; great blocks of stone lay on the beach, which was also covered with a thick carpet of sea-weed, algae, and wrack. Evidently the sea, passing over the islet, had been carried right up to the foot of the enormous curtain of granite. The soil in front of the cave had been torn away by the violence of the waves. A horrid presentiment flashed across Pencroft's mind. He rushed into the passage, but returned almost immediately, and stood motionless, staring at his companions.... The fire was out; the drowned cinders were nothing but mud; the burnt linen, which was to have served as tinder, had disappeared! The sea had penetrated to the end of the passages, and everything was overthrown and destroyed in the interior of the Chimneys!
children.prevalue: Pencroft to his extreme surprise found that the terrible storm had quite altered the aspect of the place Important changes had occurred great blocks of stone lay on the beach which was also covered with a thick carpet of sea weed algae and wrack Evidently the sea passing over the islet had been carried right up to the foot of the enormous curtain of granite The soil in front of the cave had been torn away by the violence of the waves A horrid presentiment flashed across Pencroft s mind He rushed into the passage but returned almost immediately and stood motionless staring at his companions The fire was out the drowned cinders were nothing but mud the burnt linen which was to have served as tinder had disappeared The sea had penetrated to the end of the passages and everything was overthrown and destroyed in the interior of the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In a few words, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Neb were made acquainted with what had happened. This accident, which appeared so very serious to Pencroft, produced different effects on the companions of the honest sailor.
children.prevalue: In a few words Gideon Spilett Herbert and Neb were made acquainted with what had happened This accident which appeared so very serious to Pencroft produced different effects on the companions of the honest sailor

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Neb, in his delight at having found his master, did not listen, or rather, did not care to trouble himself with what Pencroft was saying.
children.prevalue: Neb in his delight at having found his master did not listen or rather did not care to trouble himself with what Pencroft was saying

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Herbert shared in some degree the sailor's feelings.
children.prevalue: Herbert shared in some degree the sailor s feelings

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As to the reporter, he simply replied,--
children.prevalue: As to the reporter he simply replied

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Upon my word, Pencroft, it's perfectly indifferent to me!
children.prevalue: Upon my word Pencroft it s perfectly indifferent to me

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But, I repeat, that we haven't any fire!
children.prevalue: But I repeat that we haven t any fire

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Pooh!
children.prevalue: Pooh

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Nor any means of relighting it!
children.prevalue: Nor any means of relighting it

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Nonsense!
children.prevalue: Nonsense

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: But I say, Mr. Spilett--
children.prevalue: But I say Mr Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Isn't Cyrus here? replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: Isn t Cyrus here replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Is not our engineer alive? He will soon find some way of making fire for us!
children.prevalue: Is not our engineer alive He will soon find some way of making fire for us

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: With what?
children.prevalue: With what

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: With nothing.
children.prevalue: With nothing

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: What had Pencroft to say? He could say nothing, for, in the bottom of his heart he shared the confidence which his companions had in Cyrus Harding. The engineer was to them a microcosm, a compound of every science, a possessor of all human knowledge. It was better to be with Cyrus in a desert island, than without him in the most flourishing town in the United States. With him they could want nothing; with him they would never despair. If these brave men had been told that a volcanic eruption would destroy the land, that this land would be engulfed in the depths of the Pacific, they would have imperturbably replied,--
children.prevalue: What had Pencroft to say He could say nothing for in the bottom of his heart he shared the confidence which his companions had in Cyrus Harding The engineer was to them a microcosm a compound of every science a possessor of all human knowledge It was better to be with Cyrus in a desert island than without him in the most flourishing town in the United States With him they could want nothing with him they would never despair If these brave men had been told that a volcanic eruption would destroy the land that this land would be engulfed in the depths of the Pacific they would have imperturbably replied

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Cyrus is here!
children.prevalue: Cyrus is here

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: While in the palanquin, however, the engineer had again relapsed into unconsciousness, which the jolting to which he had been subjected during his journey had brought on, so that they could not now appeal to his ingenuity. The supper must necessarily be very meager. In fact, all the grouse flesh had been consumed, and there no longer existed any means of cooking more game. Besides, the couroucous which had been reserved had disappeared. They must consider what was to be done.
children.prevalue: While in the palanquin however the engineer had again relapsed into unconsciousness which the jolting to which he had been subjected during his journey had brought on so that they could not now appeal to his ingenuity The supper must necessarily be very meager In fact all the grouse flesh had been consumed and there no longer existed any means of cooking more game Besides the couroucous which had been reserved had disappeared They must consider what was to be done

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: First of all, Cyrus Harding was carried into the central passage. There they managed to arrange for him a couch of sea-weed which still remained almost dry. The deep sleep which had overpowered him would no doubt be more beneficial to him than any nourishment.
children.prevalue: First of all Cyrus Harding was carried into the central passage There they managed to arrange for him a couch of sea weed which still remained almost dry The deep sleep which had overpowered him would no doubt be more beneficial to him than any nourishment

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Night had closed in, and the temperature, which had modified when the wind shifted to the northwest, again became extremely cold. Also, the sea having destroyed the partitions which Pencroft had put up in certain places in the passages, the Chimneys, on account of the draughts, had become scarcely habitable. The engineer's condition would, therefore, have been bad enough, if his companions had not carefully covered him with their coats and waistcoats.
children.prevalue: Night had closed in and the temperature which had modified when the wind shifted to the northwest again became extremely cold Also the sea having destroyed the partitions which Pencroft had put up in certain places in the passages the Chimneys on account of the draughts had become scarcely habitable The engineer s condition would therefore have been bad enough if his companions had not carefully covered him with their coats and waistcoats

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Supper, this evening, was of course composed of the inevitable lithodomes, of which Herbert and Neb picked up a plentiful supply on the beach. However, to these molluscs, the lad added some edible sea-weed, which he gathered on high rocks, whose sides were only washed by the sea at the time of high tides. This sea-weed, which belongs to the order of Fucacae, of the genus Sargassum, produces, when dry, a gelatinous matter, rich and nutritious. The reporter and his companions, after having eaten a quantity of lithodomes, sucked the sargassum, of which the taste was very tolerable. It is used in parts of the East very considerably by the natives. Never mind! said the sailor, the captain will help us soon. Meanwhile the cold became very severe, and unhappily they had no means of defending themselves from it.
children.prevalue: Supper this evening was of course composed of the inevitable lithodomes of which Herbert and Neb picked up a plentiful supply on the beach However to these molluscs the lad added some edible sea weed which he gathered on high rocks whose sides were only washed by the sea at the time of high tides This sea weed which belongs to the order of Fucacae of the genus Sargassum produces when dry a gelatinous matter rich and nutritious The reporter and his companions after having eaten a quantity of lithodomes sucked the sargassum of which the taste was very tolerable It is used in parts of the East very considerably by the natives Never mind said the sailor the captain will help us soon Meanwhile the cold became very severe and unhappily they had no means of defending themselves from it

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The sailor, extremely vexed, tried in all sorts of ways to procure fire. Neb helped him in this work. He found some dry moss, and by striking together two pebbles he obtained some sparks, but the moss, not being inflammable enough, did not take fire, for the sparks were really only incandescent, and not at all of the same consistency as those which are emitted from flint when struck in the same manner. The experiment, therefore, did not succeed.
children.prevalue: The sailor extremely vexed tried in all sorts of ways to procure fire Neb helped him in this work He found some dry moss and by striking together two pebbles he obtained some sparks but the moss not being inflammable enough did not take fire for the sparks were really only incandescent and not at all of the same consistency as those which are emitted from flint when struck in the same manner The experiment therefore did not succeed

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Pencroft, although he had no confidence in the proceeding, then tried rubbing two pieces of dry wood together, as savages do. Certainly, the movement which he and Neb exhibited, if it had been transformed into heat, according to the new theory, would have been enough to heat the boiler of a steamer! It came to nothing. The bits of wood became hot, to be sure, but much less so than the operators themselves.
children.prevalue: Pencroft although he had no confidence in the proceeding then tried rubbing two pieces of dry wood together as savages do Certainly the movement which he and Neb exhibited if it had been transformed into heat according to the new theory would have been enough to heat the boiler of a steamer It came to nothing The bits of wood became hot to be sure but much less so than the operators themselves

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: After working an hour, Pencroft, who was in a complete state of perspiration, threw down the pieces of wood in disgust.
children.prevalue: After working an hour Pencroft who was in a complete state of perspiration threw down the pieces of wood in disgust

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I can never be made to believe that savages light their fires in this way, let them say what they will, he exclaimed. I could sooner light my arms by rubbing them against each other!
children.prevalue: I can never be made to believe that savages light their fires in this way let them say what they will he exclaimed I could sooner light my arms by rubbing them against each other

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The sailor was wrong to despise the proceeding. Savages often kindle wood by means of rapid rubbing. But every sort of wood does not answer for the purpose, and besides, there is the knack, following the usual expression, and it is probable that Pencroft had not the knack.
children.prevalue: The sailor was wrong to despise the proceeding Savages often kindle wood by means of rapid rubbing But every sort of wood does not answer for the purpose and besides there is the knack following the usual expression and it is probable that Pencroft had not the knack

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Pencroft's ill humor did not last long. Herbert had taken the bits of wood which he had turned down, and was exerting himself to rub them. The hardy sailor could not restrain a burst of laughter on seeing the efforts of the lad to succeed where he had failed.
children.prevalue: Pencroft s ill humor did not last long Herbert had taken the bits of wood which he had turned down and was exerting himself to rub them The hardy sailor could not restrain a burst of laughter on seeing the efforts of the lad to succeed where he had failed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Rub, my boy, rub! said he.
children.prevalue: Rub my boy rub said he

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I am rubbing, replied Herbert, laughing, but I don't pretend to do anything else but warm myself instead of shivering, and soon I shall be as hot as you are, my good Pencroft!
children.prevalue: I am rubbing replied Herbert laughing but I don t pretend to do anything else but warm myself instead of shivering and soon I shall be as hot as you are my good Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: This soon happened. However, they were obliged to give up, for this night at least, the attempt to procure fire. Gideon Spilett repeated, for the twentieth time, that Cyrus Harding would not have been troubled for so small a difficulty. And, in the meantime, he stretched himself in one of the passages on his bed of sand. Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft did the same, while Top slept at his master's feet.
children.prevalue: This soon happened However they were obliged to give up for this night at least the attempt to procure fire Gideon Spilett repeated for the twentieth time that Cyrus Harding would not have been troubled for so small a difficulty And in the meantime he stretched himself in one of the passages on his bed of sand Herbert Neb and Pencroft did the same while Top slept at his master s feet

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Next day, the 28th of March, when the engineer awoke, about eight in the morning, he saw his companions around him watching his sleep, and, as on the day before, his first words were:--
children.prevalue: Next day the 28th of March when the engineer awoke about eight in the morning he saw his companions around him watching his sleep and as on the day before his first words were

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Island or continent? This was his uppermost thought.
children.prevalue: Island or continent This was his uppermost thought

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well! replied Pencroft, we don't know anything about it, captain!
children.prevalue: Well replied Pencroft we don t know anything about it captain

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You don't know yet?
children.prevalue: You don t know yet

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: But we shall know, rejoined Pencroft, when you have guided us into the country.
children.prevalue: But we shall know rejoined Pencroft when you have guided us into the country

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I think I am able to try it, replied the engineer, who, without much effort, rose and stood upright.
children.prevalue: I think I am able to try it replied the engineer who without much effort rose and stood upright

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: That's capital! cried the sailor.
children.prevalue: That s capital cried the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I feel dreadfully weak, replied Harding. Give me something to eat, my friends, and it will soon go off. You have fire, haven't you?
children.prevalue: I feel dreadfully weak replied Harding Give me something to eat my friends and it will soon go off You have fire haven t you

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: This question was not immediately replied to. But, in a few seconds--
children.prevalue: This question was not immediately replied to But in a few seconds

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Alas! we have no fire, said Pencroft, or rather, captain, we have it no longer!
children.prevalue: Alas we have no fire said Pencroft or rather captain we have it no longer

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And the sailor recounted all that had passed the day before. He amused the engineer by the history of the single match, then his abortive attempt to procure fire in the savages' way.
children.prevalue: And the sailor recounted all that had passed the day before He amused the engineer by the history of the single match then his abortive attempt to procure fire in the savages way

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: We shall consider, replied the engineer, and if we do not find some substance similar to tinder--
children.prevalue: We shall consider replied the engineer and if we do not find some substance similar to tinder

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Well? asked the sailor.
children.prevalue: Well asked the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Well, we will make matches.
children.prevalue: Well we will make matches

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Chemicals?
children.prevalue: Chemicals

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Chemicals!
children.prevalue: Chemicals

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It is not more difficult than that, cried the reporter, striking the sailor on the shoulder.
children.prevalue: It is not more difficult than that cried the reporter striking the sailor on the shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The latter did not think it so simple, but he did not protest. All went out. The weather had become very fine. The sun was rising from the sea's horizon, and touched with golden spangles the prismatic rugosities of the huge precipice.
children.prevalue: The latter did not think it so simple but he did not protest All went out The weather had become very fine The sun was rising from the sea s horizon and touched with golden spangles the prismatic rugosities of the huge precipice

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Having thrown a rapid glance around him, the engineer seated himself on a block of stone. Herbert offered him a few handfuls of shell-fish and sargassum, saying,--
children.prevalue: Having thrown a rapid glance around him the engineer seated himself on a block of stone Herbert offered him a few handfuls of shell fish and sargassum saying

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It is all that we have, Captain Harding.
children.prevalue: It is all that we have Captain Harding

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Thanks, my boy, replied Harding; it will do--for this morning at least.
children.prevalue: Thanks my boy replied Harding it will do for this morning at least

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He ate the wretched food with appetite, and washed it down with a little fresh water, drawn from the river in an immense shell.
children.prevalue: He ate the wretched food with appetite and washed it down with a little fresh water drawn from the river in an immense shell

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: His companions looked at him without speaking. Then, feeling somewhat refreshed, Cyrus Harding crossed his arms, and said,--
children.prevalue: His companions looked at him without speaking Then feeling somewhat refreshed Cyrus Harding crossed his arms and said

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: So, my friends, you do not know yet whether fate has thrown us on an island, or on a continent?
children.prevalue: So my friends you do not know yet whether fate has thrown us on an island or on a continent

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: No, captain, replied the boy.
children.prevalue: No captain replied the boy

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: We shall know to-morrow, said the engineer; till then, there is nothing to be done.
children.prevalue: We shall know to morrow said the engineer till then there is nothing to be done

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Fire, said the sailor, who, also, had a fixed idea.
children.prevalue: Fire said the sailor who also had a fixed idea

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: We will make it, Pencroft, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: We will make it Pencroft replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: While you were carrying me yesterday, did I not see in the west a mountain which commands the country?
children.prevalue: While you were carrying me yesterday did I not see in the west a mountain which commands the country

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, replied Spilett, a mountain which must be rather high--
children.prevalue: Yes replied Spilett a mountain which must be rather high

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Well, replied the engineer, we will climb to the summit to-morrow, and then we shall see if this land is an island or a continent. Till then, I repeat, there is nothing to be done.
children.prevalue: Well replied the engineer we will climb to the summit to morrow and then we shall see if this land is an island or a continent Till then I repeat there is nothing to be done

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Yes, fire! said the obstinate sailor again.
children.prevalue: Yes fire said the obstinate sailor again

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But he will make us a fire! replied Gideon Spilett, only have a little patience, Pencroft!
children.prevalue: But he will make us a fire replied Gideon Spilett only have a little patience Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The seaman looked at Spilett in a way which seemed to say, If it depended upon you to do it, we wouldn't taste roast meat very soon; but he was silent.
children.prevalue: The seaman looked at Spilett in a way which seemed to say If it depended upon you to do it we wouldn t taste roast meat very soon but he was silent

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Meanwhile Captain Harding had made no reply. He appeared to be very little troubled by the question of fire. For a few minutes he remained absorbed in thought; then again speaking,--
children.prevalue: Meanwhile Captain Harding had made no reply He appeared to be very little troubled by the question of fire For a few minutes he remained absorbed in thought then again speaking

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: My friends, said he, our situation is, perhaps, deplorable; but, at any rate, it is very plain. Either we are on a continent, and then, at the expense of greater or less fatigue, we shall reach some inhabited place, or we are on an island. In the latter case, if the island is inhabited, we will try to get out of the scrape with the help of its inhabitants; if it is desert, we will try to get out of the scrape by ourselves.
children.prevalue: My friends said he our situation is perhaps deplorable but at any rate it is very plain Either we are on a continent and then at the expense of greater or less fatigue we shall reach some inhabited place or we are on an island In the latter case if the island is inhabited we will try to get out of the scrape with the help of its inhabitants if it is desert we will try to get out of the scrape by ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Certainly, nothing could be plainer, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Certainly nothing could be plainer replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But, whether it is an island or a continent, asked Gideon Spilett, whereabouts do you think, Cyrus, this storm has thrown us?
children.prevalue: But whether it is an island or a continent asked Gideon Spilett whereabouts do you think Cyrus this storm has thrown us

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I cannot say exactly, replied the engineer, but I presume it is some land in the Pacific. In fact, when we left Richmond, the wind was blowing from the northeast, and its very violence greatly proves that it could not have varied. If the direction has been maintained from the northeast to the southwest, we have traversed the States of North Carolina, of South Carolina, of Georgia, the Gulf of Mexico, Mexico, itself, in its narrow part, then a part of the Pacific Ocean. I cannot estimate the distance traversed by the balloon at less than six to seven thousand miles, and, even supposing that the wind had varied half a quarter, it must have brought us either to the archipelago of Mendava, either on the Pomotous, or even, if it had a greater strength than I suppose, to the land of New Zealand. If the last hypothesis is correct, it will be easy enough to get home again. English or Maoris, we shall always find some one to whom we can speak. If, on the contrary, this is the coast of a desert island in some tiny archipelago, perhaps we shall be able to reconnoiter it from the summit of that peak which overlooks the country, and then we shall see how best to establish ourselves here as if we are never to go away.
children.prevalue: I cannot say exactly replied the engineer but I presume it is some land in the Pacific In fact when we left Richmond the wind was blowing from the northeast and its very violence greatly proves that it could not have varied If the direction has been maintained from the northeast to the southwest we have traversed the States of North Carolina of South Carolina of Georgia the Gulf of Mexico Mexico itself in its narrow part then a part of the Pacific Ocean I cannot estimate the distance traversed by the balloon at less than six to seven thousand miles and even supposing that the wind had varied half a quarter it must have brought us either to the archipelago of Mendava either on the Pomotous or even if it had a greater strength than I suppose to the land of New Zealand If the last hypothesis is correct it will be easy enough to get home again English or Maoris we shall always find some one to whom we can speak If on the contrary this is the coast of a desert island in some tiny archipelago perhaps we shall be able to reconnoiter it from the summit of that peak which overlooks the country and then we shall see how best to establish ourselves here as if we are never to go away

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Never? cried the reporter. You say 'Never,' my dear Cyrus?
children.prevalue: Never cried the reporter You say Never my dear Cyrus

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Better to put things at the worst at first, replied the engineer, and reserve the best for a surprise.
children.prevalue: Better to put things at the worst at first replied the engineer and reserve the best for a surprise

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Well said, remarked Pencroft. It is to be hoped, too, that this island, if it be one, is not situated just out of the course of ships; that would be really unlucky!
children.prevalue: Well said remarked Pencroft It is to be hoped too that this island if it be one is not situated just out of the course of ships that would be really unlucky

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: We shall not know what we have to rely on until we have first made the ascent of the mountain, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: We shall not know what we have to rely on until we have first made the ascent of the mountain replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: But to-morrow, captain, asked Herbert, shall you be in a state to bear the fatigue of the ascent?
children.prevalue: But to morrow captain asked Herbert shall you be in a state to bear the fatigue of the ascent

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I hope so, replied the engineer, provided you and Pencroft, my boy, show yourselves quick and clever hunters.
children.prevalue: I hope so replied the engineer provided you and Pencroft my boy show yourselves quick and clever hunters

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Captain, said the sailor, since you are speaking of game, if on my return, I was as certain of roasting it as I am of bringing it back--
children.prevalue: Captain said the sailor since you are speaking of game if on my return I was as certain of roasting it as I am of bringing it back

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Bring it back all the same, Pencroft, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: Bring it back all the same Pencroft replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: It was then agreed that the engineer and the reporter were to pass the day at the Chimneys, so as to examine the shore and the upper plateau. Neb, Herbert, and the sailor were to return to the forest, renew their store of wood, and lay violent hands on every creature, feathered or hairy, which might come within their reach.
children.prevalue: It was then agreed that the engineer and the reporter were to pass the day at the Chimneys so as to examine the shore and the upper plateau Neb Herbert and the sailor were to return to the forest renew their store of wood and lay violent hands on every creature feathered or hairy which might come within their reach

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: They set out accordingly about ten o'clock in the morning, Herbert confident, Neb joyous, Pencroft murmuring aside,--
children.prevalue: They set out accordingly about ten o clock in the morning Herbert confident Neb joyous Pencroft murmuring aside

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: If, on my return, I find a fire at the house, I shall believe that the thunder itself came to light it. All three climbed the bank; and arrived at the angle made by the river, the sailor, stopping, said to his two companions,--
children.prevalue: If on my return I find a fire at the house I shall believe that the thunder itself came to light it All three climbed the bank and arrived at the angle made by the river the sailor stopping said to his two companions

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Shall we begin by being hunters or wood-men?
children.prevalue: Shall we begin by being hunters or wood men

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Hunters, replied Herbert. There is Top already in quest.
children.prevalue: Hunters replied Herbert There is Top already in quest

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: We will hunt, then, said the sailor, and afterwards we can come back and collect our wood.
children.prevalue: We will hunt then said the sailor and afterwards we can come back and collect our wood

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: This agreed to, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, after having torn three sticks from the trunk of a young fir, followed Top, who was bounding about among the long grass.
children.prevalue: This agreed to Herbert Neb and Pencroft after having torn three sticks from the trunk of a young fir followed Top who was bounding about among the long grass

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: This time, the hunters, instead of following the course of the river, plunged straight into the heart of the forest. There were still the same trees, belonging, for the most part, to the pine family. In certain places, less crowded, growing in clumps, these pines exhibited considerable dimensions, and appeared to indicate, by their development, that the country was situated in a higher latitude than the engineer had supposed. Glades, bristling with stumps worn away by time, were covered with dry wood, which formed an inexhaustible store of fuel. Then, the glade passed, the underwood thickened again, and became almost impenetrable.
children.prevalue: This time the hunters instead of following the course of the river plunged straight into the heart of the forest There were still the same trees belonging for the most part to the pine family In certain places less crowded growing in clumps these pines exhibited considerable dimensions and appeared to indicate by their development that the country was situated in a higher latitude than the engineer had supposed Glades bristling with stumps worn away by time were covered with dry wood which formed an inexhaustible store of fuel Then the glade passed the underwood thickened again and became almost impenetrable

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: It was difficult enough to find the way among the groups of trees, without any beaten track. So the sailor from time to time broke off branches which might be easily recognized. But, perhaps, he was wrong not to follow the watercourse, as he and Herbert had done on their first excursion, for after walking an hour not a creature had shown itself. Top, running under the branches, only roused birds which could not be approached. Even the couroucous were invisible, and it was probable that the sailor would be obliged to return to the marshy part of the forest, in which he had so happily performed his grouse fishing.
children.prevalue: It was difficult enough to find the way among the groups of trees without any beaten track So the sailor from time to time broke off branches which might be easily recognized But perhaps he was wrong not to follow the watercourse as he and Herbert had done on their first excursion for after walking an hour not a creature had shown itself Top running under the branches only roused birds which could not be approached Even the couroucous were invisible and it was probable that the sailor would be obliged to return to the marshy part of the forest in which he had so happily performed his grouse fishing

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Well, Pencroft, said Neb, in a slightly sarcastic tone, if this is all the game which you promised to bring back to my master, it won't need a large fire to roast it!
children.prevalue: Well Pencroft said Neb in a slightly sarcastic tone if this is all the game which you promised to bring back to my master it won t need a large fire to roast it

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Have patience, replied the sailor, it isn't the game which will be wanting on our return.
children.prevalue: Have patience replied the sailor it isn t the game which will be wanting on our return

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Have you not confidence in Captain Harding?
children.prevalue: Have you not confidence in Captain Harding

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: But you don't believe that he will make fire?
children.prevalue: But you don t believe that he will make fire

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: I shall believe it when the wood is blazing in the fireplace.
children.prevalue: I shall believe it when the wood is blazing in the fireplace

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: It will blaze, since my master has said so.
children.prevalue: It will blaze since my master has said so

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: We shall see!
children.prevalue: We shall see

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Meanwhile, the sun had not reached the highest point in its course above the horizon. The exploration, therefore, continued, and was usefully marked by a discovery which Herbert made of a tree whose fruit was edible. This was the stone-pine, which produces an excellent almond, very much esteemed in the temperate regions of America and Europe. These almonds were in a perfect state of maturity, and Herbert described them to his companions, who feasted on them.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile the sun had not reached the highest point in its course above the horizon The exploration therefore continued and was usefully marked by a discovery which Herbert made of a tree whose fruit was edible This was the stone pine which produces an excellent almond very much esteemed in the temperate regions of America and Europe These almonds were in a perfect state of maturity and Herbert described them to his companions who feasted on them

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Come, said Pencroft, sea-weed by way of bread, raw mussels for meat, and almonds for dessert, that's certainly a good dinner for those who have not a single match in their pocket!
children.prevalue: Come said Pencroft sea weed by way of bread raw mussels for meat and almonds for dessert that s certainly a good dinner for those who have not a single match in their pocket

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: We mustn't complain, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: We mustn t complain said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I am not complaining, my boy, replied Pencroft, only I repeat, that meat is a little too much economized in this sort of meal.
children.prevalue: I am not complaining my boy replied Pencroft only I repeat that meat is a little too much economized in this sort of meal

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Top has found something! cried Neb, who ran towards a thicket, in the midst of which the dog had disappeared, barking. With Top's barking were mingled curious gruntings.
children.prevalue: Top has found something cried Neb who ran towards a thicket in the midst of which the dog had disappeared barking With Top s barking were mingled curious gruntings

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The sailor and Herbert had followed Neb. If there was game there this was not the time to discuss how it was to be cooked, but rather, how they were to get hold of it.
children.prevalue: The sailor and Herbert had followed Neb If there was game there this was not the time to discuss how it was to be cooked but rather how they were to get hold of it

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: The hunters had scarcely entered the bushes when they saw Top engaged in a struggle with an animal which he was holding by the ear. This quadruped was a sort of pig nearly two feet and a half long, of a blackish brown color, lighter below, having hard scanty hair; its toes, then strongly fixed in the ground, seemed to be united by a membrane. Herbert recognized in this animal the capybara, that is to say, one of the largest members of the rodent order.
children.prevalue: The hunters had scarcely entered the bushes when they saw Top engaged in a struggle with an animal which he was holding by the ear This quadruped was a sort of pig nearly two feet and a half long of a blackish brown color lighter below having hard scanty hair its toes then strongly fixed in the ground seemed to be united by a membrane Herbert recognized in this animal the capybara that is to say one of the largest members of the rodent order

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Meanwhile, the capybara did not struggle against the dog. It stupidly rolled its eyes, deeply buried in a thick bed of fat. Perhaps it saw men for the first time.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile the capybara did not struggle against the dog It stupidly rolled its eyes deeply buried in a thick bed of fat Perhaps it saw men for the first time

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: However, Neb having tightened his grasp on his stick, was just going to fell the pig, when the latter, tearing itself from Top's teeth, by which it was only held by the tip of its ear, uttered a vigorous grunt, rushed upon Herbert, almost overthrew him, and disappeared in the wood.
children.prevalue: However Neb having tightened his grasp on his stick was just going to fell the pig when the latter tearing itself from Top s teeth by which it was only held by the tip of its ear uttered a vigorous grunt rushed upon Herbert almost overthrew him and disappeared in the wood

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: The rascal! cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: The rascal cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: All three directly darted after Top, but at the moment when they joined him the animal had disappeared under the waters of a large pond shaded by venerable pines.
children.prevalue: All three directly darted after Top but at the moment when they joined him the animal had disappeared under the waters of a large pond shaded by venerable pines

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft stopped, motionless. Top plunged into the water, but the capybara, hidden at the bottom of the pond, did not appear.
children.prevalue: Neb Herbert and Pencroft stopped motionless Top plunged into the water but the capybara hidden at the bottom of the pond did not appear

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Let us wait, said the boy, for he will soon come to the surface to breathe.
children.prevalue: Let us wait said the boy for he will soon come to the surface to breathe

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Won't he drown? asked Neb.
children.prevalue: Won t he drown asked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: No, replied Herbert, since he has webbed feet, and is almost an amphibious animal. But watch him.
children.prevalue: No replied Herbert since he has webbed feet and is almost an amphibious animal But watch him

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Top remained in the water. Pencroft and his two companions went to different parts of the bank, so as to cut off the retreat of the capybara, which the dog was looking for beneath the water.
children.prevalue: Top remained in the water Pencroft and his two companions went to different parts of the bank so as to cut off the retreat of the capybara which the dog was looking for beneath the water

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Herbert was not mistaken. In a few minutes the animal appeared on the surface of the water. Top was upon it in a bound, and kept it from plunging again. An instant later the capybara, dragged to the bank, was killed by a blow from Neb's stick.
children.prevalue: Herbert was not mistaken In a few minutes the animal appeared on the surface of the water Top was upon it in a bound and kept it from plunging again An instant later the capybara dragged to the bank was killed by a blow from Neb s stick

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Hurrah! cried Pencroft, who was always ready with this cry of triumph.
children.prevalue: Hurrah cried Pencroft who was always ready with this cry of triumph

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Give me but a good fire, and this pig shall be gnawed to the bones!
children.prevalue: Give me but a good fire and this pig shall be gnawed to the bones

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Pencroft hoisted the capybara on his shoulders, and judging by the height of the sun that it was about two o'clock, he gave the signal to return.
children.prevalue: Pencroft hoisted the capybara on his shoulders and judging by the height of the sun that it was about two o clock he gave the signal to return

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Top's instinct was useful to the hunters, who, thanks to the intelligent animal, were enabled to discover the road by which they had come. Half an hour later they arrived at the river.
children.prevalue: Top s instinct was useful to the hunters who thanks to the intelligent animal were enabled to discover the road by which they had come Half an hour later they arrived at the river

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Pencroft soon made a raft of wood, as he had done before, though if there was no fire it would be a useless task, and the raft following the current, they returned towards the Chimneys.
children.prevalue: Pencroft soon made a raft of wood as he had done before though if there was no fire it would be a useless task and the raft following the current they returned towards the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: But the sailor had not gone fifty paces when he stopped, and again uttering a tremendous hurrah, pointed towards the angle of the cliff,--
