They first broke the ore into little pieces, and cleansed them with the hand from the impurities which soiled their surface. Then coal and ore were arranged in heaps and in successive layers, as the charcoal-burner does with the wood which he wishes to carbonize. In this way, under the influence of the air projected by the blowing-machine, the coal would be transformed into carbonic acid, then into oxide of carbon, its use being to reduce the oxide of iron, that is to say, to rid it of the oxygen.
children.prevalue: The coal as well as the ore was collected without trouble on the surface of the ground They first broke the ore into little pieces and cleansed them with the hand from the impurities which soiled their surface Then coal and ore were arranged in heaps and in successive layers as the charcoal burner does with the wood which he wishes to carbonize In this way under the influence of the air projected by the blowing machine the coal would be transformed into carbonic acid then into oxide of carbon its use being to reduce the oxide of iron that is to say to rid it of the oxygen

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Thus the engineer proceeded. The bellows of sealskin, furnished at its extremity with a nozzle of clay, which had been previously fabricated in the pottery kiln, was established near the heap of ore. Using the mechanism which consisted of a frame, cords of fiber and counterpoise, he threw into the mass an abundance of air, which by raising the temperature also concurred with the chemical transformation to produce in time pure iron.
children.prevalue: Thus the engineer proceeded The bellows of sealskin furnished at its extremity with a nozzle of clay which had been previously fabricated in the pottery kiln was established near the heap of ore Using the mechanism which consisted of a frame cords of fiber and counterpoise he threw into the mass an abundance of air which by raising the temperature also concurred with the chemical transformation to produce in time pure iron

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The operation was difficult. All the patience, all the ingenuity of the settlers was needed; but at last it succeeded, and the result was a lump of iron, reduced to a spongy state, which it was necessary to shingle and fagot, that is to say, to forge so as to expel from it the liquefied veinstone. These amateur smiths had, of course, no hammer; but they were in no worse a situation than the first metallurgist, and therefore did what, no doubt, he had to do.
children.prevalue: The operation was difficult All the patience all the ingenuity of the settlers was needed but at last it succeeded and the result was a lump of iron reduced to a spongy state which it was necessary to shingle and fagot that is to say to forge so as to expel from it the liquefied veinstone These amateur smiths had of course no hammer but they were in no worse a situation than the first metallurgist and therefore did what no doubt he had to do

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: A handle was fixed to the first lump, and was used as a hammer to forge the second on a granite anvil, and thus they obtained a coarse but useful metal. At length, after many trials and much fatigue, on the 25th of April several bars of iron were forged, and transformed into tools, crowbars, pincers, pickaxes, spades, etc., which Pencroft and Neb declared to be real jewels. But the metal was not yet in its most serviceable state, that is, of steel. Now steel is a combination of iron and coal, which is extracted, either from the liquid ore, by taking from it the excess of coal, or from the iron by adding to it the coal which was wanting. The first, obtained by the decarburation of the metal, gives natural or puddled steel; the second, produced by the carburation of the iron, gives steel of cementation.
children.prevalue: A handle was fixed to the first lump and was used as a hammer to forge the second on a granite anvil and thus they obtained a coarse but useful metal At length after many trials and much fatigue on the 25th of April several bars of iron were forged and transformed into tools crowbars pincers pickaxes spades etc which Pencroft and Neb declared to be real jewels But the metal was not yet in its most serviceable state that is of steel Now steel is a combination of iron and coal which is extracted either from the liquid ore by taking from it the excess of coal or from the iron by adding to it the coal which was wanting The first obtained by the decarburation of the metal gives natural or puddled steel the second produced by the carburation of the iron gives steel of cementation

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It was the last which Cyrus Harding intended to forge, as he possessed iron in a pure state. He succeeded by heating the metal with powdered coal in a crucible which had previously been manufactured from clay suitable for the purpose.
children.prevalue: It was the last which Cyrus Harding intended to forge as he possessed iron in a pure state He succeeded by heating the metal with powdered coal in a crucible which had previously been manufactured from clay suitable for the purpose

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: He then worked this steel, which is malleable both when hot or cold, with the hammer. Neb and Pencroft, cleverly directed, made hatchets, which, heated red-hot, and plunged suddenly into cold water, acquired an excellent temper.
children.prevalue: He then worked this steel which is malleable both when hot or cold with the hammer Neb and Pencroft cleverly directed made hatchets which heated red hot and plunged suddenly into cold water acquired an excellent temper

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Other instruments, of course roughly fashioned, were also manufactured; blades for planes, axes, hatchets, pieces of steel to be transformed into saws, chisels; then iron for spades, pickaxes, hammers, nails, etc. At last, on the 5th of May, the metallic period ended, the smiths returned to the Chimneys, and new work would soon authorize them to take a fresh title.
children.prevalue: Other instruments of course roughly fashioned were also manufactured blades for planes axes hatchets pieces of steel to be transformed into saws chisels then iron for spades pickaxes hammers nails etc At last on the 5th of May the metallic period ended the smiths returned to the Chimneys and new work would soon authorize them to take a fresh title

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was the 6th of May, a day which corresponds to the 6th of November in the countries of the Northern Hemisphere. The sky had been obscured for some days, and it was of importance to make preparations for the winter. However, the temperature was not as yet much lower, and a centigrade thermometer, transported to Lincoln Island, would still have marked an average of ten to twelve degrees above zero. This was not surprising, since Lincoln Island, probably situated between the thirty-fifth and fortieth parallel, would be subject, in the Southern Hemisphere, to the same climate as Sicily or Greece in the Northern Hemisphere. But as Greece and Sicily have severe cold, producing snow and ice, so doubtless would Lincoln Island in the severest part of the winter and it was advisable to provide against it.
children.prevalue: It was the 6th of May a day which corresponds to the 6th of November in the countries of the Northern Hemisphere The sky had been obscured for some days and it was of importance to make preparations for the winter However the temperature was not as yet much lower and a centigrade thermometer transported to Lincoln Island would still have marked an average of ten to twelve degrees above zero This was not surprising since Lincoln Island probably situated between the thirty fifth and fortieth parallel would be subject in the Southern Hemisphere to the same climate as Sicily or Greece in the Northern Hemisphere But as Greece and Sicily have severe cold producing snow and ice so doubtless would Lincoln Island in the severest part of the winter and it was advisable to provide against it

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: In any case if cold did not yet threaten them, the rainy season would begin, and on this lonely island, exposed to all the fury of the elements, in mid-ocean, bad weather would be frequent, and probably terrible. The question of a more comfortable dwelling than the Chimneys must therefore be seriously considered and promptly resolved on.
children.prevalue: In any case if cold did not yet threaten them the rainy season would begin and on this lonely island exposed to all the fury of the elements in mid ocean bad weather would be frequent and probably terrible The question of a more comfortable dwelling than the Chimneys must therefore be seriously considered and promptly resolved on

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Pencroft, naturally, had some predilection for the retreat which he had discovered, but he well understood that another must be found. The Chimneys had been already visited by the sea, under circumstances which are known, and it would not do to be exposed again to a similar accident.
children.prevalue: Pencroft naturally had some predilection for the retreat which he had discovered but he well understood that another must be found The Chimneys had been already visited by the sea under circumstances which are known and it would not do to be exposed again to a similar accident

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Besides, added Cyrus Harding, who this day was talking of these things with his companions, we have some precautions to take.
children.prevalue: Besides added Cyrus Harding who this day was talking of these things with his companions we have some precautions to take

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Why? The island is not inhabited, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: Why The island is not inhabited said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: That is probable, replied the engineer, although we have not yet explored the interior; but if no human beings are found, I fear that dangerous animals may abound. It is necessary to guard against a possible attack, so that we shall not be obliged to watch every night, or to keep up a fire. And then, my friends, we must foresee everything. We are here in a part of the Pacific often frequented by Malay pirates--
children.prevalue: That is probable replied the engineer although we have not yet explored the interior but if no human beings are found I fear that dangerous animals may abound It is necessary to guard against a possible attack so that we shall not be obliged to watch every night or to keep up a fire And then my friends we must foresee everything We are here in a part of the Pacific often frequented by Malay pirates

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What! said Herbert, at such a distance from land?
children.prevalue: What said Herbert at such a distance from land

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes, my boy, replied the engineer. These pirates are bold sailors as well as formidable enemies, and we must take measures accordingly.
children.prevalue: Yes my boy replied the engineer These pirates are bold sailors as well as formidable enemies and we must take measures accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Well, replied Pencroft, we will fortify ourselves against savages with two legs as well as against savages with four. But, captain, will it not be best to explore every part of the island before undertaking anything else?
children.prevalue: Well replied Pencroft we will fortify ourselves against savages with two legs as well as against savages with four But captain will it not be best to explore every part of the island before undertaking anything else

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: That would be best, added Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: That would be best added Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Who knows if we might not find on the opposite side one of the caverns which we have searched for in vain here?
children.prevalue: Who knows if we might not find on the opposite side one of the caverns which we have searched for in vain here

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That is true, replied the engineer, but you forget, my friends, that it will be necessary to establish ourselves in the neighborhood of a watercourse, and that, from the summit of Mount Franklin, we could not see towards the west, either stream or river. Here, on the contrary, we are placed between the Mercy and Lake Grant, an advantage which must not be neglected. And, besides, this side, looking towards the east, is not exposed as the other is to the trade-winds, which in this hemisphere blow from the northwest.
children.prevalue: That is true replied the engineer but you forget my friends that it will be necessary to establish ourselves in the neighborhood of a watercourse and that from the summit of Mount Franklin we could not see towards the west either stream or river Here on the contrary we are placed between the Mercy and Lake Grant an advantage which must not be neglected And besides this side looking towards the east is not exposed as the other is to the trade winds which in this hemisphere blow from the northwest

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Then, captain, replied the sailor, let us build a house on the edge of the lake. Neither bricks nor tools are wanting now. After having been brickmakers, potters, smelters, and smiths, we shall surely know how to be masons!
children.prevalue: Then captain replied the sailor let us build a house on the edge of the lake Neither bricks nor tools are wanting now After having been brickmakers potters smelters and smiths we shall surely know how to be masons

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, my friend; but before coming to any decision we must consider the matter thoroughly. A natural dwelling would spare us much work, and would be a surer retreat, for it would be as well defended against enemies from the interior as those from outside.
children.prevalue: Yes my friend but before coming to any decision we must consider the matter thoroughly A natural dwelling would spare us much work and would be a surer retreat for it would be as well defended against enemies from the interior as those from outside

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: That is true, Cyrus, replied the reporter, but we have already examined all that mass of granite, and there is not a hole, not a cranny!
children.prevalue: That is true Cyrus replied the reporter but we have already examined all that mass of granite and there is not a hole not a cranny

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: No, not one! added Pencroft. Ah, if we were able to dig out a dwelling in that cliff, at a good height, so as to be out of the reach of harm, that would be capital! I can see that on the front which looks seaward, five or six rooms--
children.prevalue: No not one added Pencroft Ah if we were able to dig out a dwelling in that cliff at a good height so as to be out of the reach of harm that would be capital I can see that on the front which looks seaward five or six rooms

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: With windows to light them! said Herbert, laughing.
children.prevalue: With windows to light them said Herbert laughing

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And a staircase to climb up to them! added Neb.
children.prevalue: And a staircase to climb up to them added Neb

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You are laughing, cried the sailor, and why? What is there impossible in what I propose? Haven't we got pickaxes and spades? Won't Captain Harding be able to make powder to blow up the mine? Isn't it true, captain, that you will make powder the very day we want it?
children.prevalue: You are laughing cried the sailor and why What is there impossible in what I propose Haven t we got pickaxes and spades Won t Captain Harding be able to make powder to blow up the mine Isn t it true captain that you will make powder the very day we want it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Cyrus Harding listened to the enthusiastic Pencroft developing his fanciful projects. To attack this mass of granite, even by a mine, was Herculean work, and it was really vexing that nature could not help them at their need. But the engineer did not reply to the sailor except by proposing to examine the cliff more attentively, from the mouth of the river to the angle which terminated it on the north.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding listened to the enthusiastic Pencroft developing his fanciful projects To attack this mass of granite even by a mine was Herculean work and it was really vexing that nature could not help them at their need But the engineer did not reply to the sailor except by proposing to examine the cliff more attentively from the mouth of the river to the angle which terminated it on the north

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: They went out, therefore, and the exploration was made with extreme care, over an extent of nearly two miles. But in no place in the bare, straight cliff, could any cavity be found. The nests of the rock pigeons which fluttered at its summit were only, in reality, holes bored at the very top, and on the irregular edge of the granite.
children.prevalue: They went out therefore and the exploration was made with extreme care over an extent of nearly two miles But in no place in the bare straight cliff could any cavity be found The nests of the rock pigeons which fluttered at its summit were only in reality holes bored at the very top and on the irregular edge of the granite

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It was a provoking circumstance, and as to attacking this cliff, either with pickaxe or with powder, so as to effect a sufficient excavation, it was not to be thought of. It so happened that, on all this part of the shore, Pencroft had discovered the only habitable shelter, that is to say, the Chimneys, which now had to be abandoned.
children.prevalue: It was a provoking circumstance and as to attacking this cliff either with pickaxe or with powder so as to effect a sufficient excavation it was not to be thought of It so happened that on all this part of the shore Pencroft had discovered the only habitable shelter that is to say the Chimneys which now had to be abandoned

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The exploration ended, the colonists found themselves at the north angle of the cliff, where it terminated in long slopes which died away on the shore. From this place, to its extreme limit in the west, it only formed a sort of declivity, a thick mass of stones, earth, and sand, bound together by plants, bushes, and grass inclined at an angle of only forty-five degrees. Clumps of trees grew on these slopes, which were also carpeted with thick grass. But the vegetation did not extend far, and a long, sandy plain, which began at the foot of these slopes, reached to the beach.
children.prevalue: The exploration ended the colonists found themselves at the north angle of the cliff where it terminated in long slopes which died away on the shore From this place to its extreme limit in the west it only formed a sort of declivity a thick mass of stones earth and sand bound together by plants bushes and grass inclined at an angle of only forty five degrees Clumps of trees grew on these slopes which were also carpeted with thick grass But the vegetation did not extend far and a long sandy plain which began at the foot of these slopes reached to the beach

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Cyrus Harding thought, not without reason, that the overplus of the lake must overflow on this side. The excess of water furnished by the Red Creek must also escape by some channel or other. Now the engineer had not yet found this channel on any part of the shore already explored, that is to say, from the mouth of the stream on the west of Prospect Heights.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding thought not without reason that the overplus of the lake must overflow on this side The excess of water furnished by the Red Creek must also escape by some channel or other Now the engineer had not yet found this channel on any part of the shore already explored that is to say from the mouth of the stream on the west of Prospect Heights

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The engineer now proposed to his companions to climb the slope, and to return to the Chimneys by the heights, while exploring the northern and eastern shores of the lake. The proposal was accepted, and in a few minutes Herbert and Neb were on the upper plateau. Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft followed with more sedate steps.
children.prevalue: The engineer now proposed to his companions to climb the slope and to return to the Chimneys by the heights while exploring the northern and eastern shores of the lake The proposal was accepted and in a few minutes Herbert and Neb were on the upper plateau Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett and Pencroft followed with more sedate steps

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The beautiful sheet of water glittered through the trees under the rays of the sun. In this direction the country was charming. The eye feasted on the groups of trees. Some old trunks, bent with age, showed black against the verdant grass which covered the ground. Crowds of brilliant cockatoos screamed among the branches, moving prisms, hopping from one bough to another.
children.prevalue: The beautiful sheet of water glittered through the trees under the rays of the sun In this direction the country was charming The eye feasted on the groups of trees Some old trunks bent with age showed black against the verdant grass which covered the ground Crowds of brilliant cockatoos screamed among the branches moving prisms hopping from one bough to another

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The settlers instead of going directly to the north bank of the lake, made a circuit round the edge of the plateau, so as to join the mouth of the creek on its left bank. It was a detour of more than a mile and a half. Walking was easy, for the trees widely spread, left a considerable space between them. The fertile zone evidently stopped at this point, and vegetation would be less vigorous in the part between the course of the Creek and the Mercy.
children.prevalue: The settlers instead of going directly to the north bank of the lake made a circuit round the edge of the plateau so as to join the mouth of the creek on its left bank It was a detour of more than a mile and a half Walking was easy for the trees widely spread left a considerable space between them The fertile zone evidently stopped at this point and vegetation would be less vigorous in the part between the course of the Creek and the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions walked over this new ground with great care. Bows, arrows, and sticks with sharp iron points were their only weapons. However, no wild beast showed itself, and it was probable that these animals frequented rather the thick forests in the south; but the settlers had the disagreeable surprise of seeing Top stop before a snake of great size, measuring from fourteen to fifteen feet in length. Neb killed it by a blow from his stick. Cyrus Harding examined the reptile, and declared it not venomous, for it belonged to that species of diamond serpents which the natives of New South Wales rear. But it was possible that others existed whose bite was mortal such as the deaf vipers with forked tails, which rise up under the feet, or those winged snakes, furnished with two ears, which enable them to proceed with great rapidity. Top, the first moment of surprise over, began a reptile chase with such eagerness, that they feared for his safety. His master called him back directly.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions walked over this new ground with great care Bows arrows and sticks with sharp iron points were their only weapons However no wild beast showed itself and it was probable that these animals frequented rather the thick forests in the south but the settlers had the disagreeable surprise of seeing Top stop before a snake of great size measuring from fourteen to fifteen feet in length Neb killed it by a blow from his stick Cyrus Harding examined the reptile and declared it not venomous for it belonged to that species of diamond serpents which the natives of New South Wales rear But it was possible that others existed whose bite was mortal such as the deaf vipers with forked tails which rise up under the feet or those winged snakes furnished with two ears which enable them to proceed with great rapidity Top the first moment of surprise over began a reptile chase with such eagerness that they feared for his safety His master called him back directly

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The mouth of the Red Creek, at the place where it entered into the lake, was soon reached. The explorers recognized on the opposite shore the point which they had visited on their descent from Mount Franklin. Cyrus Harding ascertained that the flow of water into it from the creek was considerable. Nature must therefore have provided some place for the escape of the overplus. This doubtless formed a fall, which, if it could be discovered, would be of great use.
children.prevalue: The mouth of the Red Creek at the place where it entered into the lake was soon reached The explorers recognized on the opposite shore the point which they had visited on their descent from Mount Franklin Cyrus Harding ascertained that the flow of water into it from the creek was considerable Nature must therefore have provided some place for the escape of the overplus This doubtless formed a fall which if it could be discovered would be of great use

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The colonists, walking apart, but not straying far from each other, began to skirt the edge of the lake, which was very steep. The water appeared to be full of fish, and Pencroft resolved to make some fishing-rods, so as to try and catch some.
children.prevalue: The colonists walking apart but not straying far from each other began to skirt the edge of the lake which was very steep The water appeared to be full of fish and Pencroft resolved to make some fishing rods so as to try and catch some

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The northeast point was first to be doubled. It might have been supposed that the discharge of water was at this place, for the extremity of the lake was almost on a level with the edge of the plateau. But no signs of this were discovered, and the colonists continued to explore the bank, which, after a slight bend, descended parallel to the shore.
children.prevalue: The northeast point was first to be doubled It might have been supposed that the discharge of water was at this place for the extremity of the lake was almost on a level with the edge of the plateau But no signs of this were discovered and the colonists continued to explore the bank which after a slight bend descended parallel to the shore

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: On this side the banks were less woody, but clumps of trees, here and there, added to the picturesqueness of the country. Lake Grant was viewed from thence in all its extent, and no breath disturbed the surface of its waters. Top, in beating the bushes, put up flocks of birds of different kinds, which Gideon Spilett and Herbert saluted with arrows. One was hit by the lad, and fell into some marshy grass. Top rushed forward, and brought a beautiful swimming bird, of a slate color, short beak, very developed frontal plate, and wings edged with white. It was a coot, the size of a large partridge, belonging to the group of macrodactyls which form the transition between the order of wading birds and that of palmipeds. Sorry game, in truth, and its flavor is far from pleasant. But Top was not so particular in these things as his masters, and it was agreed that the coot should be for his supper.
children.prevalue: On this side the banks were less woody but clumps of trees here and there added to the picturesqueness of the country Lake Grant was viewed from thence in all its extent and no breath disturbed the surface of its waters Top in beating the bushes put up flocks of birds of different kinds which Gideon Spilett and Herbert saluted with arrows One was hit by the lad and fell into some marshy grass Top rushed forward and brought a beautiful swimming bird of a slate color short beak very developed frontal plate and wings edged with white It was a coot the size of a large partridge belonging to the group of macrodactyls which form the transition between the order of wading birds and that of palmipeds Sorry game in truth and its flavor is far from pleasant But Top was not so particular in these things as his masters and it was agreed that the coot should be for his supper

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The settlers were now following the eastern bank of the lake, and they would not be long in reaching the part which they already knew. The engineer was much surprised at not seeing any indication of the discharge of water. The reporter and the sailor talked with him, and he could not conceal his astonishment.
children.prevalue: The settlers were now following the eastern bank of the lake and they would not be long in reaching the part which they already knew The engineer was much surprised at not seeing any indication of the discharge of water The reporter and the sailor talked with him and he could not conceal his astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: At this moment Top, who had been very quiet till then, gave signs of agitation. The intelligent animal went backwards and forwards on the shore, stopped suddenly, and looked at the water, one paw raised, as if he was pointing at some invisible game; then he barked furiously, and was suddenly silent.
children.prevalue: At this moment Top who had been very quiet till then gave signs of agitation The intelligent animal went backwards and forwards on the shore stopped suddenly and looked at the water one paw raised as if he was pointing at some invisible game then he barked furiously and was suddenly silent

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions had at first paid any attention to Top's behavior; but the dog's barking soon became so frequent that the engineer noticed it.
children.prevalue: Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions had at first paid any attention to Top s behavior but the dog s barking soon became so frequent that the engineer noticed it

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What is there, Top? he asked.
children.prevalue: What is there Top he asked

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The dog bounded towards his master, seeming to be very uneasy, and then rushed again towards the bank. Then, all at once, he plunged into the lake.
children.prevalue: The dog bounded towards his master seeming to be very uneasy and then rushed again towards the bank Then all at once he plunged into the lake

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Here, Top! cried Cyrus Harding, who did not like his dog to venture into the treacherous water.
children.prevalue: Here Top cried Cyrus Harding who did not like his dog to venture into the treacherous water

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: What's happening down there? asked Pencroft, examining the surface of the lake.
children.prevalue: What s happening down there asked Pencroft examining the surface of the lake

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Top smells some amphibious creature, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: Top smells some amphibious creature replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: An alligator, perhaps, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: An alligator perhaps said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I do not think so, replied Harding. Alligators are only met with in regions less elevated in latitude.
children.prevalue: I do not think so replied Harding Alligators are only met with in regions less elevated in latitude

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Meanwhile Top had returned at his master's call, and had regained the shore: but he could not stay quiet; he plunged in among the tall grass, and guided by instinct, he appeared to follow some invisible being which was slipping along under the surface of the water. However the water was calm; not a ripple disturbed its surface. Several times the settlers stopped on the bank, and observed it attentively. Nothing appeared. There was some mystery there.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile Top had returned at his master s call and had regained the shore but he could not stay quiet he plunged in among the tall grass and guided by instinct he appeared to follow some invisible being which was slipping along under the surface of the water However the water was calm not a ripple disturbed its surface Several times the settlers stopped on the bank and observed it attentively Nothing appeared There was some mystery there

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The engineer was puzzled.
children.prevalue: The engineer was puzzled

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Let us pursue this exploration to the end, said he.
children.prevalue: Let us pursue this exploration to the end said he

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Half an hour after they had all arrived at the southeast angle of the lake, on Prospect Heights. At this point the examination of the banks of the lake was considered finished, and yet the engineer had not been able to discover how and where the waters were discharged. There is no doubt this overflow exists, he repeated, and since it is not visible it must go through the granite cliff at the west!
children.prevalue: Half an hour after they had all arrived at the southeast angle of the lake on Prospect Heights At this point the examination of the banks of the lake was considered finished and yet the engineer had not been able to discover how and where the waters were discharged There is no doubt this overflow exists he repeated and since it is not visible it must go through the granite cliff at the west

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But what importance do you attach to knowing that, my dear Cyrus? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: But what importance do you attach to knowing that my dear Cyrus asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Considerable importance, replied the engineer; for if it flows through the cliff there is probably some cavity, which it would be easy to render habitable after turning away the water.
children.prevalue: Considerable importance replied the engineer for if it flows through the cliff there is probably some cavity which it would be easy to render habitable after turning away the water

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: But is it not possible, captain, that the water flows away at the bottom of the lake, said Herbert, and that it reaches the sea by some subterranean passage?
children.prevalue: But is it not possible captain that the water flows away at the bottom of the lake said Herbert and that it reaches the sea by some subterranean passage

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: That might be, replied the engineer, and should it be so we shall be obliged to build our house ourselves, since nature has not done it for us.
children.prevalue: That might be replied the engineer and should it be so we shall be obliged to build our house ourselves since nature has not done it for us

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The colonists were about to begin to traverse the plateau to return to the Chimneys, when Top gave new signs of agitation. He barked with fury, and before his master could restrain him, he had plunged a second time into the lake.
children.prevalue: The colonists were about to begin to traverse the plateau to return to the Chimneys when Top gave new signs of agitation He barked with fury and before his master could restrain him he had plunged a second time into the lake

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: All ran towards the bank. The dog was already more than twenty feet off, and Cyrus was calling him back, when an enormous head emerged from the water, which did not appear to be deep in that place.
children.prevalue: All ran towards the bank The dog was already more than twenty feet off and Cyrus was calling him back when an enormous head emerged from the water which did not appear to be deep in that place

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Herbert recognized directly the species of amphibian to which the tapering head, with large eyes, and adorned with long silky mustaches, belonged.
children.prevalue: Herbert recognized directly the species of amphibian to which the tapering head with large eyes and adorned with long silky mustaches belonged

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: A lamantin! he cried.
children.prevalue: A lamantin he cried

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: It was not a lamantin, but one of that species of the order of cetaceans, which bear the name of the dugong, for its nostrils were open at the upper part of its snout. The enormous animal rushed on the dog, who tried to escape by returning towards the shore. His master could do nothing to save him, and before Gideon Spilett or Herbert thought of bending their bows, Top, seized by the dugong, had disappeared beneath the water.
children.prevalue: It was not a lamantin but one of that species of the order of cetaceans which bear the name of the dugong for its nostrils were open at the upper part of its snout The enormous animal rushed on the dog who tried to escape by returning towards the shore His master could do nothing to save him and before Gideon Spilett or Herbert thought of bending their bows Top seized by the dugong had disappeared beneath the water

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Neb, his iron-tipped spear in his hand, wished to go to Top's help, and attack the dangerous animal in its own element.
children.prevalue: Neb his iron tipped spear in his hand wished to go to Top s help and attack the dangerous animal in its own element

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No, Neb, said the engineer, restraining his courageous servant.
children.prevalue: No Neb said the engineer restraining his courageous servant

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Meanwhile, a struggle was going on beneath the water, an inexplicable struggle, for in his situation Top could not possibly resist; and judging by the bubbling of the surface it must be also a terrible struggle, and could not but terminate in the death of the dog! But suddenly, in the middle of a foaming circle, Top reappeared. Thrown in the air by some unknown power, he rose ten feet above the surface of the lake, fell again into the midst of the agitated waters, and then soon gained the shore, without any severe wounds, miraculously saved.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile a struggle was going on beneath the water an inexplicable struggle for in his situation Top could not possibly resist and judging by the bubbling of the surface it must be also a terrible struggle and could not but terminate in the death of the dog But suddenly in the middle of a foaming circle Top reappeared Thrown in the air by some unknown power he rose ten feet above the surface of the lake fell again into the midst of the agitated waters and then soon gained the shore without any severe wounds miraculously saved

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions could not understand it. What was not less inexplicable was that the struggle still appeared to be going on. Doubtless, the dugong, attacked by some powerful animal, after having released the dog, was fighting on its own account. But it did not last long. The water became red with blood, and the body of the dugong, emerging from the sheet of scarlet which spread around, soon stranded on a little beach at the south angle of the lake. The colonists ran towards it. The dugong was dead. It was an enormous animal, fifteen or sixteen feet long, and must have weighed from three to four thousand pounds. At its neck was a wound, which appeared to have been produced by a sharp blade.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions could not understand it What was not less inexplicable was that the struggle still appeared to be going on Doubtless the dugong attacked by some powerful animal after having released the dog was fighting on its own account But it did not last long The water became red with blood and the body of the dugong emerging from the sheet of scarlet which spread around soon stranded on a little beach at the south angle of the lake The colonists ran towards it The dugong was dead It was an enormous animal fifteen or sixteen feet long and must have weighed from three to four thousand pounds At its neck was a wound which appeared to have been produced by a sharp blade

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What could the amphibious creature have been, who, by this terrible blow had destroyed the formidable dugong? No one could tell, and much interested in this incident, Harding and his companions returned to the Chimneys.
children.prevalue: What could the amphibious creature have been who by this terrible blow had destroyed the formidable dugong No one could tell and much interested in this incident Harding and his companions returned to the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next day, the 7th of May, Harding and Gideon Spilett, leaving Neb to prepare breakfast, climbed Prospect Heights, while Herbert and Pencroft ascended by the river, to renew their store of wood.
children.prevalue: The next day the 7th of May Harding and Gideon Spilett leaving Neb to prepare breakfast climbed Prospect Heights while Herbert and Pencroft ascended by the river to renew their store of wood

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The engineer and the reporter soon reached the little beach on which the dugong had been stranded. Already flocks of birds had attacked the mass of flesh, and had to be driven away with stones, for Cyrus wished to keep the fat for the use of the colony. As to the animal's flesh it would furnish excellent food, for in the islands of the Malay Archipelago and elsewhere, it is especially reserved for the table of the native princes. But that was Neb's affair.
children.prevalue: The engineer and the reporter soon reached the little beach on which the dugong had been stranded Already flocks of birds had attacked the mass of flesh and had to be driven away with stones for Cyrus wished to keep the fat for the use of the colony As to the animal s flesh it would furnish excellent food for in the islands of the Malay Archipelago and elsewhere it is especially reserved for the table of the native princes But that was Neb s affair

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At this moment Cyrus Harding had other thoughts. He was much interested in the incident of the day before. He wished to penetrate the mystery of that submarine combat, and to ascertain what monster could have given the dugong so strange a wound. He remained at the edge of the lake, looking, observing; but nothing appeared under the tranquil waters, which sparkled in the first rays of the rising sun.
children.prevalue: At this moment Cyrus Harding had other thoughts He was much interested in the incident of the day before He wished to penetrate the mystery of that submarine combat and to ascertain what monster could have given the dugong so strange a wound He remained at the edge of the lake looking observing but nothing appeared under the tranquil waters which sparkled in the first rays of the rising sun

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: At the beach, on which lay the body of the dugong, the water was tolerably shallow, but from this point the bottom of the lake sloped gradually, and it was probable that the depth was considerable in the center. The lake might be considered as a large center basin, which was filled by the water from the Red Creek.
children.prevalue: At the beach on which lay the body of the dugong the water was tolerably shallow but from this point the bottom of the lake sloped gradually and it was probable that the depth was considerable in the center The lake might be considered as a large center basin which was filled by the water from the Red Creek

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Well, Cyrus, said the reporter, there seems to be nothing suspicious in this water.
children.prevalue: Well Cyrus said the reporter there seems to be nothing suspicious in this water

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: No, my dear Spilett, replied the engineer, and I really do not know how to account for the incident of yesterday.
children.prevalue: No my dear Spilett replied the engineer and I really do not know how to account for the incident of yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I acknowledge, returned Spilett, that the wound given this creature is, at least, very strange, and I cannot explain either how Top was so vigorously cast up out of the water. One could have thought that a powerful arm hurled him up, and that the same arm with a dagger killed the dugong!
children.prevalue: I acknowledge returned Spilett that the wound given this creature is at least very strange and I cannot explain either how Top was so vigorously cast up out of the water One could have thought that a powerful arm hurled him up and that the same arm with a dagger killed the dugong

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes, replied the engineer, who had become thoughtful; there is something there that I cannot understand. But do you better understand either, my dear Spilett, in what way I was saved myself--how I was drawn from the waves, and carried to the downs? No! Is it not true? Now, I feel sure that there is some mystery there, which, doubtless, we shall discover some day. Let us observe, but do not dwell on these singular incidents before our companions. Let us keep our remarks to ourselves, and continue our work.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the engineer who had become thoughtful there is something there that I cannot understand But do you better understand either my dear Spilett in what way I was saved myself how I was drawn from the waves and carried to the downs No Is it not true Now I feel sure that there is some mystery there which doubtless we shall discover some day Let us observe but do not dwell on these singular incidents before our companions Let us keep our remarks to ourselves and continue our work

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: It will be remembered that the engineer had not as yet been able to discover the place where the surplus water escaped, but he knew it must exist somewhere. He was much surprised to see a strong current at this place. By throwing in some bits of wood he found that it set towards the southern angle. He followed the current, and arrived at the south point of the lake.
children.prevalue: It will be remembered that the engineer had not as yet been able to discover the place where the surplus water escaped but he knew it must exist somewhere He was much surprised to see a strong current at this place By throwing in some bits of wood he found that it set towards the southern angle He followed the current and arrived at the south point of the lake

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: There was there a sort of depression in the water, as if it was suddenly lost in some fissure in the ground.
children.prevalue: There was there a sort of depression in the water as if it was suddenly lost in some fissure in the ground

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Harding listened; placing his ear to the level of the lake, he very distinctly heard the noise of a subterranean fall.
children.prevalue: Harding listened placing his ear to the level of the lake he very distinctly heard the noise of a subterranean fall

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: There, said he, rising, is the discharge of the water; there, doubtless, by a passage in the granite cliff, it joins the sea, through cavities which we can use to our profit. Well, I can find it!
children.prevalue: There said he rising is the discharge of the water there doubtless by a passage in the granite cliff it joins the sea through cavities which we can use to our profit Well I can find it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The engineer cut a long branch, stripped it of its leaves, and plunging it into the angle between the two banks, he found that there was a large hole one foot only beneath the surface of the water. This hole was the opening so long looked for in vain, and the force of the current was such that the branch was torn from the engineer's hands and disappeared.
children.prevalue: The engineer cut a long branch stripped it of its leaves and plunging it into the angle between the two banks he found that there was a large hole one foot only beneath the surface of the water This hole was the opening so long looked for in vain and the force of the current was such that the branch was torn from the engineer s hands and disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: There is no doubt about it now, repeated Harding. There is the outlet, and I will lay it open to view!
children.prevalue: There is no doubt about it now repeated Harding There is the outlet and I will lay it open to view

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: How? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: How asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: By lowering the level of the water of the lake three feet.
children.prevalue: By lowering the level of the water of the lake three feet

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And how will you lower the level?
children.prevalue: And how will you lower the level

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: By opening another outlet larger than this.
children.prevalue: By opening another outlet larger than this

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: At what place, Cyrus?
children.prevalue: At what place Cyrus

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: At the part of the bank nearest the coast.
children.prevalue: At the part of the bank nearest the coast

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But it is a mass of granite! observed Spilett.
children.prevalue: But it is a mass of granite observed Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Well, replied Cyrus Harding, I will blow up the granite, and the water escaping, will subside, so as to lay bare this opening--
children.prevalue: Well replied Cyrus Harding I will blow up the granite and the water escaping will subside so as to lay bare this opening

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And make a waterfall, by falling on to the beach, added the reporter.
children.prevalue: And make a waterfall by falling on to the beach added the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: A fall that we shall make use of! replied Cyrus. Come, come!
children.prevalue: A fall that we shall make use of replied Cyrus Come come

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The engineer hurried away his companion, whose confidence in Harding was such that he did not doubt the enterprise would succeed. And yet, how was this granite wall to be opened without powder, and with imperfect instruments? Was not this work upon which the engineer was so bent above their strength?
children.prevalue: The engineer hurried away his companion whose confidence in Harding was such that he did not doubt the enterprise would succeed And yet how was this granite wall to be opened without powder and with imperfect instruments Was not this work upon which the engineer was so bent above their strength

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: When Harding and the reporter entered the Chimneys, they found Herbert and Pencroft unloading their raft of wood.
children.prevalue: When Harding and the reporter entered the Chimneys they found Herbert and Pencroft unloading their raft of wood

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The woodmen have just finished, captain. said the sailor, laughing, and when you want masons--
children.prevalue: The woodmen have just finished captain said the sailor laughing and when you want masons

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Masons,--no, but chemists, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Masons no but chemists replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes, added the reporter, we are going to blow up the island--
children.prevalue: Yes added the reporter we are going to blow up the island

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Blow up the island? cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Blow up the island cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Part of it, at least, replied Spilett.
children.prevalue: Part of it at least replied Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Listen to me, my friends, said the engineer. And he made known to them the result of his observations.
children.prevalue: Listen to me my friends said the engineer And he made known to them the result of his observations

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: According to him, a cavity, more or less considerable, must exist in the mass of granite which supported Prospect Heights, and he intended to penetrate into it. To do this, the opening through which the water rushed must first be cleared, and the level lowered by making a larger outlet. Therefore an explosive substance must be manufactured, which would make a deep trench in some other part of the shore. This was what Harding was going to attempt with the minerals which nature placed at his disposal.
children.prevalue: According to him a cavity more or less considerable must exist in the mass of granite which supported Prospect Heights and he intended to penetrate into it To do this the opening through which the water rushed must first be cleared and the level lowered by making a larger outlet Therefore an explosive substance must be manufactured which would make a deep trench in some other part of the shore This was what Harding was going to attempt with the minerals which nature placed at his disposal

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It is useless to say with what enthusiasm all, especially Pencroft, received this project. To employ great means, open the granite, create a cascade, that suited the sailor. And he would just as soon be a chemist as a mason or bootmaker, since the engineer wanted chemicals. He would be all that they liked, even a professor of dancing and deportment, said he to Neb, if that was ever necessary.
children.prevalue: It is useless to say with what enthusiasm all especially Pencroft received this project To employ great means open the granite create a cascade that suited the sailor And he would just as soon be a chemist as a mason or bootmaker since the engineer wanted chemicals He would be all that they liked even a professor of dancing and deportment said he to Neb if that was ever necessary

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Neb and Pencroft were first of all told to extract the grease from the dugong, and to keep the flesh, which was destined for food. Such perfect confidence had they in the engineer, that they set out directly, without even asking a question. A few minutes after them, Cyrus Harding, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett, dragging the hurdle, went towards the vein of coals, where those shistose pyrites abound which are met with in the most recent transition soil, and of which Harding had already found a specimen. All the day being employed in carrying a quantity of these stones to the Chimneys, by evening they had several tons.
children.prevalue: Neb and Pencroft were first of all told to extract the grease from the dugong and to keep the flesh which was destined for food Such perfect confidence had they in the engineer that they set out directly without even asking a question A few minutes after them Cyrus Harding Herbert and Gideon Spilett dragging the hurdle went towards the vein of coals where those shistose pyrites abound which are met with in the most recent transition soil and of which Harding had already found a specimen All the day being employed in carrying a quantity of these stones to the Chimneys by evening they had several tons

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The next day, the 8th of May, the engineer began his manipulations. These shistose pyrites being composed principally of coal, flint, alumina, and sulphuret of iron--the latter in excess--it was necessary to separate the sulphuret of iron, and transform it into sulphate as rapidly as possible. The sulphate obtained, the sulphuric acid could then be extracted.
children.prevalue: The next day the 8th of May the engineer began his manipulations These shistose pyrites being composed principally of coal flint alumina and sulphuret of iron the latter in excess it was necessary to separate the sulphuret of iron and transform it into sulphate as rapidly as possible The sulphate obtained the sulphuric acid could then be extracted

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: This was the object to be attained. Sulphuric acid is one of the agents the most frequently employed, and the manufacturing importance of a nation can be measured by the consumption which is made of it. This acid would later be of great use to the settlers, in the manufacturing of candles, tanning skins, etc., but this time the engineer reserved it for another use.
children.prevalue: This was the object to be attained Sulphuric acid is one of the agents the most frequently employed and the manufacturing importance of a nation can be measured by the consumption which is made of it This acid would later be of great use to the settlers in the manufacturing of candles tanning skins etc but this time the engineer reserved it for another use

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Cyrus Harding chose, behind the Chimneys, a site where the ground was perfectly level. On this ground he placed a layer of branches and chopped wood, on which were piled some pieces of shistose pyrites, buttressed one against the other, the whole being covered with a thin layer of pyrites, previously reduced to the size of a nut.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding chose behind the Chimneys a site where the ground was perfectly level On this ground he placed a layer of branches and chopped wood on which were piled some pieces of shistose pyrites buttressed one against the other the whole being covered with a thin layer of pyrites previously reduced to the size of a nut

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: This done, they set fire to the wood, the heat was communicated to the shist, which soon kindled, since it contains coal and sulphur. Then new layers of bruised pyrites were arranged so as to form an immense heap, the exterior of which was covered with earth and grass, several air-holes being left, as if it was a stack of wood which was to be carbonized to make charcoal.
children.prevalue: This done they set fire to the wood the heat was communicated to the shist which soon kindled since it contains coal and sulphur Then new layers of bruised pyrites were arranged so as to form an immense heap the exterior of which was covered with earth and grass several air holes being left as if it was a stack of wood which was to be carbonized to make charcoal

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: They then left the transformation to complete itself, and it would not take less than ten or twelve days for the sulphuret of iron to be changed to sulphate of iron and the alumina into sulphate of alumina, two equally soluble substances, the others, flint, burnt coal, and cinders, not being so.
children.prevalue: They then left the transformation to complete itself and it would not take less than ten or twelve days for the sulphuret of iron to be changed to sulphate of iron and the alumina into sulphate of alumina two equally soluble substances the others flint burnt coal and cinders not being so

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: While this chemical work was going on, Cyrus Harding proceeded with other operations, which were pursued with more than zeal,--it was eagerness.
children.prevalue: While this chemical work was going on Cyrus Harding proceeded with other operations which were pursued with more than zeal it was eagerness

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Neb and Pencroft had taken away the fat from the dugong, and placed it in large earthen pots. It was then necessary to separate the glycerine from the fat by saponifying it. Now, to obtain this result, it had to be treated either with soda or lime. In fact, one or other of these substances, after having attacked the fat, would form a soap by separating the glycerine, and it was just this glycerine which the engineer wished to obtain. There was no want of lime, only treatment by lime would give calcareous soap, insoluble, and consequently useless, while treatment by soda would furnish, on the contrary, a soluble soap, which could be put to domestic use. Now, a practical man, like Cyrus Harding, would rather try to obtain soda. Was this difficult? No; for marine plants abounded on the shore, glass-wort, ficoides, and all those fucaceae which form wrack. A large quantity of these plants was collected, first dried, then burnt in holes in the open air. The combustion of these plants was kept up for several days, and the result was a compact gray mass, which has been long known under the name of natural soda.
children.prevalue: Neb and Pencroft had taken away the fat from the dugong and placed it in large earthen pots It was then necessary to separate the glycerine from the fat by saponifying it Now to obtain this result it had to be treated either with soda or lime In fact one or other of these substances after having attacked the fat would form a soap by separating the glycerine and it was just this glycerine which the engineer wished to obtain There was no want of lime only treatment by lime would give calcareous soap insoluble and consequently useless while treatment by soda would furnish on the contrary a soluble soap which could be put to domestic use Now a practical man like Cyrus Harding would rather try to obtain soda Was this difficult No for marine plants abounded on the shore glass wort ficoides and all those fucaceae which form wrack A large quantity of these plants was collected first dried then burnt in holes in the open air The combustion of these plants was kept up for several days and the result was a compact gray mass which has been long known under the name of natural soda

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This obtained, the engineer treated the fat with soda, which gave both a soluble soap and that neutral substance, glycerine.
children.prevalue: This obtained the engineer treated the fat with soda which gave both a soluble soap and that neutral substance glycerine

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But this was not all. Cyrus Harding still needed, in view of his future preparation, another substance, nitrate of potash, which is better known under the name of salt niter, or of saltpeter.
children.prevalue: But this was not all Cyrus Harding still needed in view of his future preparation another substance nitrate of potash which is better known under the name of salt niter or of saltpeter

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Cyrus Harding could have manufactured this substance by treating the carbonate of potash, which would be easily extracted from the cinders of the vegetables, by azotic acid. But this acid was wanting, and he would have been in some difficulty, if nature had not happily furnished the saltpeter, without giving them any other trouble than that of picking it up. Herbert found a vein of it at the foot of Mount Franklin, and they had nothing to do but purify this salt.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding could have manufactured this substance by treating the carbonate of potash which would be easily extracted from the cinders of the vegetables by azotic acid But this acid was wanting and he would have been in some difficulty if nature had not happily furnished the saltpeter without giving them any other trouble than that of picking it up Herbert found a vein of it at the foot of Mount Franklin and they had nothing to do but purify this salt

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: These different works lasted a week. They were finished before the transformation of the sulphuret into sulphate of iron had been accomplished. During the following days the settlers had time to construct a furnace of bricks of a particular arrangement, to serve for the distillation of the sulphate or iron when it had been obtained. All this was finished about the 18th of May, nearly at the time when the chemical transformation terminated. Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, skillfully directed by the engineer, had become most clever workmen. Before all masters, necessity is the one most listened to, and who teaches the best.
children.prevalue: These different works lasted a week They were finished before the transformation of the sulphuret into sulphate of iron had been accomplished During the following days the settlers had time to construct a furnace of bricks of a particular arrangement to serve for the distillation of the sulphate or iron when it had been obtained All this was finished about the 18th of May nearly at the time when the chemical transformation terminated Gideon Spilett Herbert Neb and Pencroft skillfully directed by the engineer had become most clever workmen Before all masters necessity is the one most listened to and who teaches the best

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: When the heap of pyrites had been entirely reduced by fire, the result of the operation, consisting of sulphate of iron, sulphate of alumina, flint, remains of coal, and cinders was placed in a basinful of water. They stirred this mixture, let it settle, then decanted it, and obtained a clear liquid containing in solution sulphate of iron and sulphate of alumina, the other matters remaining solid, since they are insoluble. Lastly, this liquid being partly evaporated, crystals of sulphate of iron were deposited, and the not evaporated liquid, which contained the sulphate of alumina, was thrown away.
children.prevalue: When the heap of pyrites had been entirely reduced by fire the result of the operation consisting of sulphate of iron sulphate of alumina flint remains of coal and cinders was placed in a basinful of water They stirred this mixture let it settle then decanted it and obtained a clear liquid containing in solution sulphate of iron and sulphate of alumina the other matters remaining solid since they are insoluble Lastly this liquid being partly evaporated crystals of sulphate of iron were deposited and the not evaporated liquid which contained the sulphate of alumina was thrown away

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Cyrus Harding had now at his disposal a large quantity of these sulphate of iron crystals, from which the sulphuric acid had to be extracted. The making of sulphuric acid is a very expensive manufacture. Considerable works are necessary--a special set of tools, an apparatus of platina, leaden chambers, unassailable by the acid, and in which the transformation is performed, etc. The engineer had none of these at his disposal, but he knew that, in Bohemia especially, sulphuric acid is manufactured by very simple means, which have also the advantage of producing it to a superior degree of concentration. It is thus that the acid known under the name of Nordhausen acid is made.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding had now at his disposal a large quantity of these sulphate of iron crystals from which the sulphuric acid had to be extracted The making of sulphuric acid is a very expensive manufacture Considerable works are necessary a special set of tools an apparatus of platina leaden chambers unassailable by the acid and in which the transformation is performed etc The engineer had none of these at his disposal but he knew that in Bohemia especially sulphuric acid is manufactured by very simple means which have also the advantage of producing it to a superior degree of concentration It is thus that the acid known under the name of Nordhausen acid is made

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: To obtain sulphuric acid, Cyrus Harding had only one operation to make, to calcine the sulphate of iron crystals in a closed vase, so that the sulphuric acid should distil in vapor, which vapor, by condensation, would produce the acid.
children.prevalue: To obtain sulphuric acid Cyrus Harding had only one operation to make to calcine the sulphate of iron crystals in a closed vase so that the sulphuric acid should distil in vapor which vapor by condensation would produce the acid

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The crystals were placed in pots, and the heat from the furnace would distil the sulphuric acid. The operation was successfully completed, and on the 20th of May, twelve days after commencing it, the engineer was the possessor of the agent which later he hoped to use in so many different ways.
children.prevalue: The crystals were placed in pots and the heat from the furnace would distil the sulphuric acid The operation was successfully completed and on the 20th of May twelve days after commencing it the engineer was the possessor of the agent which later he hoped to use in so many different ways

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Now, why did he wish for this agent? Simply to produce azotic acid; and that was easy, since saltpeter, attacked by sulphuric acid, gives azotic, or nitric, acid by distillation.
children.prevalue: Now why did he wish for this agent Simply to produce azotic acid and that was easy since saltpeter attacked by sulphuric acid gives azotic or nitric acid by distillation

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But, after all, how was he going to employ this azotic acid? His companions were still ignorant of this, for he had not informed them of the result at which he aimed.
children.prevalue: But after all how was he going to employ this azotic acid His companions were still ignorant of this for he had not informed them of the result at which he aimed

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: However, the engineer had nearly accomplished his purpose, and by a last operation he would procure the substance which had given so much trouble.
children.prevalue: However the engineer had nearly accomplished his purpose and by a last operation he would procure the substance which had given so much trouble

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Taking some azotic acid, he mixed it with glycerine, which had been previously concentrated by evaporation, subjected to the water-bath, and he obtained, without even employing a refrigerant mixture, several pints of an oily yellow mixture.
children.prevalue: Taking some azotic acid he mixed it with glycerine which had been previously concentrated by evaporation subjected to the water bath and he obtained without even employing a refrigerant mixture several pints of an oily yellow mixture

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: This last operation Cyrus Harding had made alone, in a retired place, at a distance from the Chimneys, for he feared the danger of an explosion, and when he showed a bottle of this liquid to his friends, he contented himself with saying,--
children.prevalue: This last operation Cyrus Harding had made alone in a retired place at a distance from the Chimneys for he feared the danger of an explosion and when he showed a bottle of this liquid to his friends he contented himself with saying

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Here is nitro-glycerine!
children.prevalue: Here is nitro glycerine

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: It was really this terrible production, of which the explosive power is perhaps tenfold that of ordinary powder, and which has already caused so many accidents. However, since a way has been found to transform it into dynamite, that is to say, to mix with it some solid substance, clay or sugar, porous enough to hold it, the dangerous liquid has been used with some security. But dynamite was not yet known at the time when the settlers worked on Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: It was really this terrible production of which the explosive power is perhaps tenfold that of ordinary powder and which has already caused so many accidents However since a way has been found to transform it into dynamite that is to say to mix with it some solid substance clay or sugar porous enough to hold it the dangerous liquid has been used with some security But dynamite was not yet known at the time when the settlers worked on Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And is it that liquid that is going to blow up our rocks? said Pencroft incredulously.
children.prevalue: And is it that liquid that is going to blow up our rocks said Pencroft incredulously

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Yes, my friend, replied the engineer, and this nitro-glycerine will produce so much the more effect, as the granite is extremely hard, and will oppose a greater resistance to the explosion.
children.prevalue: Yes my friend replied the engineer and this nitro glycerine will produce so much the more effect as the granite is extremely hard and will oppose a greater resistance to the explosion

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And when shall we see this, captain?
children.prevalue: And when shall we see this captain

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: To-morrow, as soon as we have dug a hole for the mine, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: To morrow as soon as we have dug a hole for the mine replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The next day, the 21st of May, at daybreak, the miners went to the point which formed the eastern shore of Lake Grant, and was only five hundred feet from the coast. At this place, the plateau inclined downwards from the waters, which were only restrained by their granite case. Therefore, if this case was broken, the water would escape by the opening and form a stream, which, flowing over the inclined surface of the plateau, would rush on to the beach. Consequently, the level of the lake would be greatly lowered, and the opening where the water escaped would be exposed, which was their final aim.
children.prevalue: The next day the 21st of May at daybreak the miners went to the point which formed the eastern shore of Lake Grant and was only five hundred feet from the coast At this place the plateau inclined downwards from the waters which were only restrained by their granite case Therefore if this case was broken the water would escape by the opening and form a stream which flowing over the inclined surface of the plateau would rush on to the beach Consequently the level of the lake would be greatly lowered and the opening where the water escaped would be exposed which was their final aim

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Under the engineer's directions, Pencroft, armed with a pickaxe, which he handled skillfully and vigorously, attacked the granite. The hole was made on the point of the shore, slanting, so that it should meet a much lower level than that of the water of the lake. In this way the explosive force, by scattering the rock, would open a large place for the water to rush out.
children.prevalue: Under the engineer s directions Pencroft armed with a pickaxe which he handled skillfully and vigorously attacked the granite The hole was made on the point of the shore slanting so that it should meet a much lower level than that of the water of the lake In this way the explosive force by scattering the rock would open a large place for the water to rush out

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The work took some time, for the engineer, wishing to produce a great effect, intended to devote not less than seven quarts of nitro-glycerine to the operation. But Pencroft, relieved by Neb, did so well, that towards four o'clock in the evening, the mine was finished.
children.prevalue: The work took some time for the engineer wishing to produce a great effect intended to devote not less than seven quarts of nitro glycerine to the operation But Pencroft relieved by Neb did so well that towards four o clock in the evening the mine was finished

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Now the question of setting fire to the explosive substance was raised. Generally, nitro-glycerine is ignited by caps of fulminate, which in bursting cause the explosion. A shock is therefore needed to produce the explosion, for, simply lighted, this substance would burn without exploding.
children.prevalue: Now the question of setting fire to the explosive substance was raised Generally nitro glycerine is ignited by caps of fulminate which in bursting cause the explosion A shock is therefore needed to produce the explosion for simply lighted this substance would burn without exploding

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Cyrus Harding could certainly have fabricated a percussion cap. In default of fulminate, he could easily obtain a substance similar to guncotton, since he had azotic acid at his disposal. This substance, pressed in a cartridge, and introduced among the nitro-glycerine, would burst by means of a fuse, and cause the explosion.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding could certainly have fabricated a percussion cap In default of fulminate he could easily obtain a substance similar to guncotton since he had azotic acid at his disposal This substance pressed in a cartridge and introduced among the nitro glycerine would burst by means of a fuse and cause the explosion

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: But Cyrus Harding knew that nitro-glycerine would explode by a shock. He resolved to employ this means, and try another way, if this did not succeed.
children.prevalue: But Cyrus Harding knew that nitro glycerine would explode by a shock He resolved to employ this means and try another way if this did not succeed

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: In fact, the blow of a hammer on a few drops of nitro-glycerine, spread out on a hard surface, was enough to create an explosion. But the operator could not be there to give the blow, without becoming a victim to the operation. Harding, therefore, thought of suspending a mass of iron, weighing several pounds, by means of a fiber, to an upright just above the mine. Another long fiber, previously impregnated with sulphur, was attached to the middle of the first, by one end, while the other lay on the ground several feet distant from the mine. The second fiber being set on fire, it would burn till it reached the first. This catching fire in its turn, would break, and the mass of iron would fall on the nitro-glycerine. This apparatus being then arranged, the engineer, after having sent his companions to a distance, filled the hole, so that the nitro-glycerine was on a level with the opening; then he threw a few drops of it on the surface of the rock, above which the mass of iron was already suspended.
