children.value: Well, we are free to roast ourselves at Granite House! said Pencroft. There are heaps of fuel, and no reason for sparing it.
children.prevalue: Well we are free to roast ourselves at Granite House said Pencroft There are heaps of fuel and no reason for sparing it

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Besides, added Gideon Spilett, Lincoln Island is not situated under a very high latitude, and probably the winters here are not severe. Did you not say, Cyrus, that this thirty-fifth parallel corresponded to that of Spain in the other hemisphere?
children.prevalue: Besides added Gideon Spilett Lincoln Island is not situated under a very high latitude and probably the winters here are not severe Did you not say Cyrus that this thirty fifth parallel corresponded to that of Spain in the other hemisphere

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Doubtless, replied the engineer, but some winters in Spain are very cold! No want of snow and ice; and perhaps Lincoln Island is just as rigorously tried. However, it is an island, and as such, I hope that the temperature will be more moderate.
children.prevalue: Doubtless replied the engineer but some winters in Spain are very cold No want of snow and ice and perhaps Lincoln Island is just as rigorously tried However it is an island and as such I hope that the temperature will be more moderate

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Why, captain? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: Why captain asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Because the sea, my boy, may be considered as an immense reservoir, in which is stored the heat of the summer. When winter comes, it restores this heat, which insures for the regions near the ocean a medium temperature, less high in summer, but less low in winter.
children.prevalue: Because the sea my boy may be considered as an immense reservoir in which is stored the heat of the summer When winter comes it restores this heat which insures for the regions near the ocean a medium temperature less high in summer but less low in winter

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: We shall prove that, replied Pencroft. But I don't want to bother myself about whether it will be cold or not. One thing is certain, that is that the days are already short, and the evenings long. Suppose we talk about the question of light.
children.prevalue: We shall prove that replied Pencroft But I don t want to bother myself about whether it will be cold or not One thing is certain that is that the days are already short and the evenings long Suppose we talk about the question of light

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Nothing is easier, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: Nothing is easier replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: To talk about? asked the sailor.
children.prevalue: To talk about asked the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: To settle.
children.prevalue: To settle

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And when shall we begin?
children.prevalue: And when shall we begin

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: To-morrow, by having a seal hunt.
children.prevalue: To morrow by having a seal hunt

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: To make candles?
children.prevalue: To make candles

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Such was the engineer's project; and it was quite feasible, since he had lime and sulphuric acid, while the amphibians of the islet would furnish the fat necessary for the manufacture.
children.prevalue: Such was the engineer s project and it was quite feasible since he had lime and sulphuric acid while the amphibians of the islet would furnish the fat necessary for the manufacture

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: They were now at the 4th of June. It was Whit Sunday and they agreed to observe this feast. All work was suspended, and prayers were offered to Heaven. But these prayers were now thanksgivings. The settlers in Lincoln Island were no longer the miserable castaways thrown on the islet. They asked for nothing more--they gave thanks. The next day, the 5th of June, in rather uncertain weather, they set out for the islet. They had to profit by the low tide to cross the Channel, and it was agreed that they would construct, for this purpose, as well as they could, a boat which would render communication so much easier, and would also permit them to ascend the Mercy, at the time of their grand exploration of the southwest of the island, which was put off till the first fine days.
children.prevalue: They were now at the 4th of June It was Whit Sunday and they agreed to observe this feast All work was suspended and prayers were offered to Heaven But these prayers were now thanksgivings The settlers in Lincoln Island were no longer the miserable castaways thrown on the islet They asked for nothing more they gave thanks The next day the 5th of June in rather uncertain weather they set out for the islet They had to profit by the low tide to cross the Channel and it was agreed that they would construct for this purpose as well as they could a boat which would render communication so much easier and would also permit them to ascend the Mercy at the time of their grand exploration of the southwest of the island which was put off till the first fine days

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The seals were numerous, and the hunters, armed with their iron-tipped spears, easily killed half-a-dozen. Neb and Pencroft skinned them, and only brought back to Granite House their fat and skin, this skin being intended for the manufacture of boots.
children.prevalue: The seals were numerous and the hunters armed with their iron tipped spears easily killed half a dozen Neb and Pencroft skinned them and only brought back to Granite House their fat and skin this skin being intended for the manufacture of boots

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The result of the hunt was this: nearly three hundred pounds of fat, all to be employed in the fabrication of candles.
children.prevalue: The result of the hunt was this nearly three hundred pounds of fat all to be employed in the fabrication of candles

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The operation was extremely simple, and if it did not yield absolutely perfect results, they were at least very useful. Cyrus Harding would only have had at his disposal sulphuric acid, but by heating this acid with the neutral fatty bodies he could separate the glycerine; then from this new combination, he easily separated the olein, the margarin, and the stearin, by employing boiling water. But to simplify the operation, he preferred to saponify the fat by means of lime. By this he obtained a calcareous soap, easy to decompose by sulphuric acid, which precipitated the lime into the state of sulphate, and liberated the fatty acids.
children.prevalue: The operation was extremely simple and if it did not yield absolutely perfect results they were at least very useful Cyrus Harding would only have had at his disposal sulphuric acid but by heating this acid with the neutral fatty bodies he could separate the glycerine then from this new combination he easily separated the olein the margarin and the stearin by employing boiling water But to simplify the operation he preferred to saponify the fat by means of lime By this he obtained a calcareous soap easy to decompose by sulphuric acid which precipitated the lime into the state of sulphate and liberated the fatty acids

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: From these three acids-oleic, margaric, and stearic-the first, being liquid, was driven out by a sufficient pressure. As to the two others, they formed the very substance of which the candles were to be molded.
children.prevalue: From these three acids oleic margaric and stearic the first being liquid was driven out by a sufficient pressure As to the two others they formed the very substance of which the candles were to be molded

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: This operation did not last more than four and twenty hours. The wicks, after several trials, were made of vegetable fibers, and dipped in the liquefied substance, they formed regular stearic candles, molded by the hand, which only wanted whiteness and polish. They would not doubtless have the advantages of the wicks which are impregnated with boracic acid, and which vitrify as they burn and are entirely consumed, but Cyrus Harding having manufactured a beautiful pair of snuffers, these candles would be greatly appreciated during the long evenings in Granite House.
children.prevalue: This operation did not last more than four and twenty hours The wicks after several trials were made of vegetable fibers and dipped in the liquefied substance they formed regular stearic candles molded by the hand which only wanted whiteness and polish They would not doubtless have the advantages of the wicks which are impregnated with boracic acid and which vitrify as they burn and are entirely consumed but Cyrus Harding having manufactured a beautiful pair of snuffers these candles would be greatly appreciated during the long evenings in Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: During this month there was no want of work in the interior of their new dwelling. The joiners had plenty to do. They improved their tools, which were very rough, and added others also.
children.prevalue: During this month there was no want of work in the interior of their new dwelling The joiners had plenty to do They improved their tools which were very rough and added others also

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Scissors were made among other things, and the settlers were at last able to cut their hair, and also to shave, or at least trim their beards. Herbert had none, Neb but little, but their companions were bristling in a way which justified the making of the said scissors.
children.prevalue: Scissors were made among other things and the settlers were at last able to cut their hair and also to shave or at least trim their beards Herbert had none Neb but little but their companions were bristling in a way which justified the making of the said scissors

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The manufacture of a hand-saw cost infinite trouble, but at last an instrument was obtained which, when vigorously handled, could divide the ligneous fibers of the wood. They then made tables, seats, cupboards, to furnish the principal rooms, and bedsteads, of which all the bedding consisted of grass mattresses. The kitchen, with its shelves, on which rested the cooking utensils, its brick stove, looked very well, and Neb worked away there as earnestly as if he was in a chemist's laboratory.
children.prevalue: The manufacture of a hand saw cost infinite trouble but at last an instrument was obtained which when vigorously handled could divide the ligneous fibers of the wood They then made tables seats cupboards to furnish the principal rooms and bedsteads of which all the bedding consisted of grass mattresses The kitchen with its shelves on which rested the cooking utensils its brick stove looked very well and Neb worked away there as earnestly as if he was in a chemist s laboratory

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: But the joiners had soon to be replaced by carpenters. In fact, the waterfall created by the explosion rendered the construction of two bridges necessary, one on Prospect Heights, the other on the shore. Now the plateau and the shore were transversely divided by a watercourse, which had to be crossed to reach the northern part of the island. To avoid it the colonists had been obliged to make a considerable detour, by climbing up to the source of the Red Creek. The simplest thing was to establish on the plateau, and on the shore, two bridges from twenty to five and twenty feet in length. All the carpenter's work that was needed was to clear some trees of their branches: this was a business of some days. Directly the bridges were established, Neb and Pencroft profited by them to go to the oyster-bed which had been discovered near the downs. They dragged with them a sort of rough cart, which replaced the former inconvenient hurdle, and brought back some thousands of oysters, which soon increased among the rocks and formed a bed at the mouth of the Mercy. These molluscs were of excellent quality, and the colonists consumed some daily.
children.prevalue: But the joiners had soon to be replaced by carpenters In fact the waterfall created by the explosion rendered the construction of two bridges necessary one on Prospect Heights the other on the shore Now the plateau and the shore were transversely divided by a watercourse which had to be crossed to reach the northern part of the island To avoid it the colonists had been obliged to make a considerable detour by climbing up to the source of the Red Creek The simplest thing was to establish on the plateau and on the shore two bridges from twenty to five and twenty feet in length All the carpenter s work that was needed was to clear some trees of their branches this was a business of some days Directly the bridges were established Neb and Pencroft profited by them to go to the oyster bed which had been discovered near the downs They dragged with them a sort of rough cart which replaced the former inconvenient hurdle and brought back some thousands of oysters which soon increased among the rocks and formed a bed at the mouth of the Mercy These molluscs were of excellent quality and the colonists consumed some daily

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It has been seen that Lincoln Island, although its inhabitants had as yet only explored a small portion of it, already contributed to almost all their wants. It was probable that if they hunted into its most secret recesses, in all the wooded part between the Mercy and Reptile Point, they would find new treasures.
children.prevalue: It has been seen that Lincoln Island although its inhabitants had as yet only explored a small portion of it already contributed to almost all their wants It was probable that if they hunted into its most secret recesses in all the wooded part between the Mercy and Reptile Point they would find new treasures

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The settlers in Lincoln Island had still one privation. There was no want of meat, nor of vegetable products; those ligneous roots which they had found, when subjected to fermentation, gave them an acid drink, which was preferable to cold water; they also made sugar, without canes or beet-roots, by collecting the liquor which distils from the acer saceharinum, a sort of maple-tree, which flourishes in all the temperate zones, and of which the island possessed a great number; they made a very agreeable tea by employing the herbs brought from the warren; lastly, they had an abundance of salt, the only mineral which is used in food... but bread was wanting.
children.prevalue: The settlers in Lincoln Island had still one privation There was no want of meat nor of vegetable products those ligneous roots which they had found when subjected to fermentation gave them an acid drink which was preferable to cold water they also made sugar without canes or beet roots by collecting the liquor which distils from the acer saceharinum a sort of maple tree which flourishes in all the temperate zones and of which the island possessed a great number they made a very agreeable tea by employing the herbs brought from the warren lastly they had an abundance of salt the only mineral which is used in food but bread was wanting

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Perhaps in time the settlers could replace this want by some equivalent, it was possible that they might find the sago or the breadfruit tree among the forests of the south, but they had not as yet met with these precious trees. However, Providence came directly to their aid, in an infinitesimal proportion it is true, but Cyrus Harding, with all his intelligence, all his ingenuity, would never have been able to produce that which, by the greatest chance, Herbert one day found in the lining of his waistcoat, which he was occupied in setting to rights.
children.prevalue: Perhaps in time the settlers could replace this want by some equivalent it was possible that they might find the sago or the breadfruit tree among the forests of the south but they had not as yet met with these precious trees However Providence came directly to their aid in an infinitesimal proportion it is true but Cyrus Harding with all his intelligence all his ingenuity would never have been able to produce that which by the greatest chance Herbert one day found in the lining of his waistcoat which he was occupied in setting to rights

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: On this day, as it was raining in torrents, the settlers were assembled in the great hall in Granite House, when the lad cried out all at once,--
children.prevalue: On this day as it was raining in torrents the settlers were assembled in the great hall in Granite House when the lad cried out all at once

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Look here, captain--A grain of corn!
children.prevalue: Look here captain A grain of corn

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: And he showed his companions a grain--a single grain--which from a hole in his pocket had got into the lining of his waistcoat.
children.prevalue: And he showed his companions a grain a single grain which from a hole in his pocket had got into the lining of his waistcoat

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The presence of this grain was explained by the fact that Herbert, when at Richmond, used to feed some pigeons, of which Pencroft had made him a present.
children.prevalue: The presence of this grain was explained by the fact that Herbert when at Richmond used to feed some pigeons of which Pencroft had made him a present

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: A grain of corn? said the engineer quickly.
children.prevalue: A grain of corn said the engineer quickly

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, captain; but one, only one!
children.prevalue: Yes captain but one only one

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well, my boy, said Pencroft, laughing, we're getting on capitally, upon my word! What shall we make with one grain of corn?
children.prevalue: Well my boy said Pencroft laughing we re getting on capitally upon my word What shall we make with one grain of corn

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: We will make bread of it, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: We will make bread of it replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Bread, cakes, tarts! replied the sailor. Come, the bread that this grain of corn will make won't choke us very soon!
children.prevalue: Bread cakes tarts replied the sailor Come the bread that this grain of corn will make won t choke us very soon

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Herbert, not attaching much importance to his discovery, was going to throw away the grain in question; but Harding took it, examined it, found that it was in good condition, and looking the sailor full in the face--Pencroft, he asked quietly, do you know how many ears one grain of corn can produce?
children.prevalue: Herbert not attaching much importance to his discovery was going to throw away the grain in question but Harding took it examined it found that it was in good condition and looking the sailor full in the face Pencroft he asked quietly do you know how many ears one grain of corn can produce

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: One, I suppose! replied the sailor, surprised at the question.
children.prevalue: One I suppose replied the sailor surprised at the question

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Ten, Pencroft! And do you know how many grains one ear bears?
children.prevalue: Ten Pencroft And do you know how many grains one ear bears

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No, upon my word.
children.prevalue: No upon my word

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: About eighty! said Cyrus Harding. Then, if we plant this grain, at the first crop we shall reap eight hundred grains which at the second will produce six hundred and forty thousand; at the third, five hundred and twelve millions; at the fourth, more than four hundred thousands of millions! There is the proportion.
children.prevalue: About eighty said Cyrus Harding Then if we plant this grain at the first crop we shall reap eight hundred grains which at the second will produce six hundred and forty thousand at the third five hundred and twelve millions at the fourth more than four hundred thousands of millions There is the proportion

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Harding's companions listened without answering. These numbers astonished them. They were exact, however.
children.prevalue: Harding s companions listened without answering These numbers astonished them They were exact however

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, my friends, continued the engineer, such are the arithmetical progressions of prolific nature; and yet what is this multiplication of the grain of corn, of which the ear only bears eight hundred grains, compared to the poppy-plant, which bears thirty-two thousand seeds; to the tobacco-plant, which produces three hundred and sixty thousand? In a few years, without the numerous causes of destruction, which arrests their fecundity, these plants would overrun the earth.
children.prevalue: Yes my friends continued the engineer such are the arithmetical progressions of prolific nature and yet what is this multiplication of the grain of corn of which the ear only bears eight hundred grains compared to the poppy plant which bears thirty two thousand seeds to the tobacco plant which produces three hundred and sixty thousand In a few years without the numerous causes of destruction which arrests their fecundity these plants would overrun the earth

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But the engineer had not finished his lecture.
children.prevalue: But the engineer had not finished his lecture

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And now, Pencroft, he continued, do you know how many bushels four hundred thousand millions of grains would make?
children.prevalue: And now Pencroft he continued do you know how many bushels four hundred thousand millions of grains would make

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, replied the sailor; but what I do know is, that I am nothing better than a fool!
children.prevalue: No replied the sailor but what I do know is that I am nothing better than a fool

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Well, they would make more than three millions, at a hundred and thirty thousand a bushel, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Well they would make more than three millions at a hundred and thirty thousand a bushel Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Three millions! cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Three millions cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Three millions.
children.prevalue: Three millions

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: In four years?
children.prevalue: In four years

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: In four years, replied Cyrus Harding, and even in two years, if, as I hope, in this latitude we can obtain two crops a year.
children.prevalue: In four years replied Cyrus Harding and even in two years if as I hope in this latitude we can obtain two crops a year

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: At that, according to his usual custom, Pencroft could not reply otherwise than by a tremendous hurrah.
children.prevalue: At that according to his usual custom Pencroft could not reply otherwise than by a tremendous hurrah

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: So, Herbert, added the engineer, you have made a discovery of great importance to us. Everything, my friends, everything can serve us in the condition in which we are. Do not forget that, I beg of you.
children.prevalue: So Herbert added the engineer you have made a discovery of great importance to us Everything my friends everything can serve us in the condition in which we are Do not forget that I beg of you

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No, captain, no, we shan't forget it, replied Pencroft; and if ever I find one of those tobacco-seeds, which multiply by three hundred and sixty thousand, I assure you I won't throw it away! And now, what must we do?
children.prevalue: No captain no we shan t forget it replied Pencroft and if ever I find one of those tobacco seeds which multiply by three hundred and sixty thousand I assure you I won t throw it away And now what must we do

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: We must plant this grain, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: We must plant this grain replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Yes, added Gideon Spilett, and with every possible care, for it bears in itself our future harvests.
children.prevalue: Yes added Gideon Spilett and with every possible care for it bears in itself our future harvests

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Provided it grows! cried the sailor.
children.prevalue: Provided it grows cried the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: It will grow, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: It will grow replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: This was the 20th of June. The time was then propitious for sowing this single precious grain of corn. It was first proposed to plant it in a pot, but upon reflection it was decided to leave it to nature, and confide it to the earth. This was done that very day, and it is needless to add, that every precaution was taken that the experiment might succeed.
children.prevalue: This was the 20th of June The time was then propitious for sowing this single precious grain of corn It was first proposed to plant it in a pot but upon reflection it was decided to leave it to nature and confide it to the earth This was done that very day and it is needless to add that every precaution was taken that the experiment might succeed

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The weather having cleared, the settlers climbed the height above Granite House. There, on the plateau, they chose a spot, well sheltered from the wind, and exposed to all the heat of the midday sun. The place was cleared, carefully weeded, and searched for insects and worms; then a bed of good earth, improved with a little lime, was made; it was surrounded by a railing; and the grain was buried in the damp earth.
children.prevalue: The weather having cleared the settlers climbed the height above Granite House There on the plateau they chose a spot well sheltered from the wind and exposed to all the heat of the midday sun The place was cleared carefully weeded and searched for insects and worms then a bed of good earth improved with a little lime was made it was surrounded by a railing and the grain was buried in the damp earth

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Did it not seem as if the settlers were laying the first stone of some edifice? It recalled to Pencroft the day on which he lighted his only match, and all the anxiety of the operation. But this time the thing was more serious. In fact, the castaways would have been always able to procure fire, in some mode or other, but no human power could supply another grain of corn, if unfortunately this should be lost!
children.prevalue: Did it not seem as if the settlers were laying the first stone of some edifice It recalled to Pencroft the day on which he lighted his only match and all the anxiety of the operation But this time the thing was more serious In fact the castaways would have been always able to procure fire in some mode or other but no human power could supply another grain of corn if unfortunately this should be lost

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: From this time Pencroft did not let a single day pass without going to visit what he gravely called his corn-field. And woe to the insects which dared to venture there! No mercy was shown them.
children.prevalue: From this time Pencroft did not let a single day pass without going to visit what he gravely called his corn field And woe to the insects which dared to venture there No mercy was shown them

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Towards the end of the month of June, after incessant rain, the weather became decidedly colder, and on the 29th a Fahrenheit thermometer would certainly have announced only twenty degrees above zero, that is considerably below the freezing-point. The next day, the 30th of June, the day which corresponds to the 31st of December in the northern year, was a Friday. Neb remarked that the year finished on a bad day, but Pencroft replied that naturally the next would begin on a good one, which was better.
children.prevalue: Towards the end of the month of June after incessant rain the weather became decidedly colder and on the 29th a Fahrenheit thermometer would certainly have announced only twenty degrees above zero that is considerably below the freezing point The next day the 30th of June the day which corresponds to the 31st of December in the northern year was a Friday Neb remarked that the year finished on a bad day but Pencroft replied that naturally the next would begin on a good one which was better

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At any rate it commenced by very severe cold. Ice accumulated at the mouth of the Mercy, and it was not long before the whole expanse of the lake was frozen.
children.prevalue: At any rate it commenced by very severe cold Ice accumulated at the mouth of the Mercy and it was not long before the whole expanse of the lake was frozen

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The settlers had frequently been obliged to renew their store of wood. Pencroft also had wisely not waited till the river was frozen, but had brought enormous rafts of wood to their destination. The current was an indefatigable moving power, and it was employed in conveying the floating wood to the moment when the frost enchained it. To the fuel which was so abundantly supplied by the forest, they added several cartloads of coal, which had to be brought from the foot of the spurs of Mount Franklin. The powerful heat of the coal was greatly appreciated in the low temperature, which on the 4th of July fell to eight degrees of Fahrenheit, that is, thirteen degrees below zero. A second fireplace had been established in the dining-room, where they all worked together at their different avocations. During this period of cold, Cyrus Harding had great cause to congratulate himself on having brought to Granite House the little stream of water from Lake Grant. Taken below the frozen surface, and conducted through the passage, it preserved its fluidity, and arrived at an interior reservoir which had been hollowed out at the back part of the storeroom, while the overflow ran through the well to the sea.
children.prevalue: The settlers had frequently been obliged to renew their store of wood Pencroft also had wisely not waited till the river was frozen but had brought enormous rafts of wood to their destination The current was an indefatigable moving power and it was employed in conveying the floating wood to the moment when the frost enchained it To the fuel which was so abundantly supplied by the forest they added several cartloads of coal which had to be brought from the foot of the spurs of Mount Franklin The powerful heat of the coal was greatly appreciated in the low temperature which on the 4th of July fell to eight degrees of Fahrenheit that is thirteen degrees below zero A second fireplace had been established in the dining room where they all worked together at their different avocations During this period of cold Cyrus Harding had great cause to congratulate himself on having brought to Granite House the little stream of water from Lake Grant Taken below the frozen surface and conducted through the passage it preserved its fluidity and arrived at an interior reservoir which had been hollowed out at the back part of the storeroom while the overflow ran through the well to the sea

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: About this time, the weather being extremely dry, the colonists, clothed as warmly as possible, resolved to devote a day to the exploration of that part of the island between the Mercy and Claw Cape. It was a wide extent of marshy land, and they would probably find good sport, for water-birds ought to swarm there.
children.prevalue: About this time the weather being extremely dry the colonists clothed as warmly as possible resolved to devote a day to the exploration of that part of the island between the Mercy and Claw Cape It was a wide extent of marshy land and they would probably find good sport for water birds ought to swarm there

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: They reckoned that it would be about eight or nine miles to go there, and as much to return, so that the whole of the day would be occupied. As an unknown part of the island was about to be explored, the whole colony took part in the expedition. Accordingly, on the 5th of July, at six o'clock in the morning, when day had scarcely broken, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, armed with spears, snares, bows and arrows, and provided with provisions, left Granite House, preceded by Top, who bounded before them.
children.prevalue: They reckoned that it would be about eight or nine miles to go there and as much to return so that the whole of the day would be occupied As an unknown part of the island was about to be explored the whole colony took part in the expedition Accordingly on the 5th of July at six o clock in the morning when day had scarcely broken Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett Herbert Neb and Pencroft armed with spears snares bows and arrows and provided with provisions left Granite House preceded by Top who bounded before them

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Their shortest way was to cross the Mercy on the ice, which then covered it.
children.prevalue: Their shortest way was to cross the Mercy on the ice which then covered it

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But, as the engineer justly observed, that could not take the place of a regular bridge! So, the construction of a regular bridge was noted in the list of future works.
children.prevalue: But as the engineer justly observed that could not take the place of a regular bridge So the construction of a regular bridge was noted in the list of future works

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: It was the first time that the settlers had set foot on the right bank of the Mercy, and ventured into the midst of those gigantic and superb coniferae now sprinkled over with snow.
children.prevalue: It was the first time that the settlers had set foot on the right bank of the Mercy and ventured into the midst of those gigantic and superb coniferae now sprinkled over with snow

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: But they had not gone half a mile when from a thicket a whole family of quadrupeds, who had made a home there, disturbed by Top, rushed forth into the open country.
children.prevalue: But they had not gone half a mile when from a thicket a whole family of quadrupeds who had made a home there disturbed by Top rushed forth into the open country

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ah! I should say those are foxes! cried Herbert, when he saw the troop rapidly decamping.
children.prevalue: Ah I should say those are foxes cried Herbert when he saw the troop rapidly decamping

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: They were foxes, but of a very large size, who uttered a sort of barking, at which Top seemed to be very much astonished, for he stopped short in the chase, and gave the swift animals time to disappear.
children.prevalue: They were foxes but of a very large size who uttered a sort of barking at which Top seemed to be very much astonished for he stopped short in the chase and gave the swift animals time to disappear

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The dog had reason to be surprised, as he did not know Natural History. But, by their barking, these foxes, with reddish-gray hair, black tails terminating in a white tuft, had betrayed their origin. So Herbert was able, without hesitating, to give them their real name of Arctic foxes. They are frequently met with in Chile, in the Falkland Islands, and in all parts of America traversed by the thirtieth and fortieth parallels. Herbert much regretted that Top had not been able to catch one of these carnivora.
children.prevalue: The dog had reason to be surprised as he did not know Natural History But by their barking these foxes with reddish gray hair black tails terminating in a white tuft had betrayed their origin So Herbert was able without hesitating to give them their real name of Arctic foxes They are frequently met with in Chile in the Falkland Islands and in all parts of America traversed by the thirtieth and fortieth parallels Herbert much regretted that Top had not been able to catch one of these carnivora

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Are they good to eat? asked Pencroft, who only regarded the representatives of the fauna in the island from one special point of view.
children.prevalue: Are they good to eat asked Pencroft who only regarded the representatives of the fauna in the island from one special point of view

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: No, replied Herbert; but zoologists have not yet found out if the eye of these foxes is diurnal or nocturnal, or whether it is correct to class them in the genus dog, properly so called.
children.prevalue: No replied Herbert but zoologists have not yet found out if the eye of these foxes is diurnal or nocturnal or whether it is correct to class them in the genus dog properly so called

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Harding could not help smiling on hearing the lad's reflection, which showed a thoughtful mind. As to the sailor, from the moment when he found that the foxes were not classed in the genus eatable, they were nothing to him. However, when a poultry-yard was established at Granite House, he observed that it would be best to take some precautions against a probable visit from these four-legged plunderers, and no one disputed this.
children.prevalue: Harding could not help smiling on hearing the lad s reflection which showed a thoughtful mind As to the sailor from the moment when he found that the foxes were not classed in the genus eatable they were nothing to him However when a poultry yard was established at Granite House he observed that it would be best to take some precautions against a probable visit from these four legged plunderers and no one disputed this

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: After having turned the point, the settlers saw a long beach washed by the open sea. It was then eight o'clock in the morning. The sky was very clear, as it often is after prolonged cold; but warmed by their walk, neither Harding nor his companions felt the sharpness of the atmosphere too severely. Besides there was no wind, which made it much more bearable. A brilliant sun, but without any calorific action, was just issuing from the ocean. The sea was as tranquil and blue as that of a Mediterranean gulf, when the sky is clear. Claw Cape, bent in the form of a yataghan, tapered away nearly four miles to the southeast. To the left the edge of the marsh was abruptly ended by a little point. Certainly, in this part of Union Bay, which nothing sheltered from the open sea, not even a sandbank, ships beaten by the east winds would have found no shelter. They perceived by the tranquillity of the sea, in which no shallows troubled the waters, by its uniform color, which was stained by no yellow shades, by the absence of even a reef, that the coast was steep and that the ocean there covered a deep abyss. Behind in the west, but at a distance of four miles, rose the first trees of the forests of the Far West. They might have believed themselves to be on the desolate coast of some island in the Antarctic regions which the ice had invaded. The colonists halted at this place for breakfast. A fire of brushwood and dried seaweed was lighted, and Neb prepared the breakfast of cold meat, to which he added some cups of Oswego tea.
children.prevalue: After having turned the point the settlers saw a long beach washed by the open sea It was then eight o clock in the morning The sky was very clear as it often is after prolonged cold but warmed by their walk neither Harding nor his companions felt the sharpness of the atmosphere too severely Besides there was no wind which made it much more bearable A brilliant sun but without any calorific action was just issuing from the ocean The sea was as tranquil and blue as that of a Mediterranean gulf when the sky is clear Claw Cape bent in the form of a yataghan tapered away nearly four miles to the southeast To the left the edge of the marsh was abruptly ended by a little point Certainly in this part of Union Bay which nothing sheltered from the open sea not even a sandbank ships beaten by the east winds would have found no shelter They perceived by the tranquillity of the sea in which no shallows troubled the waters by its uniform color which was stained by no yellow shades by the absence of even a reef that the coast was steep and that the ocean there covered a deep abyss Behind in the west but at a distance of four miles rose the first trees of the forests of the Far West They might have believed themselves to be on the desolate coast of some island in the Antarctic regions which the ice had invaded The colonists halted at this place for breakfast A fire of brushwood and dried seaweed was lighted and Neb prepared the breakfast of cold meat to which he added some cups of Oswego tea

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: While eating they looked around them. This part of Lincoln Island was very sterile, and contrasted with all the western part. The reporter was thus led to observe that if chance had thrown them at first on the shore, they would have had but a deplorable idea of their future domain.
children.prevalue: While eating they looked around them This part of Lincoln Island was very sterile and contrasted with all the western part The reporter was thus led to observe that if chance had thrown them at first on the shore they would have had but a deplorable idea of their future domain

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I believe that we should not have been able to reach it, replied the engineer, for the sea is deep, and there is not a rock on which we could have taken refuge. Before Granite House, at least, there were sandbanks, an islet, which multiplied our chances of safety. Here, nothing but the depths!
children.prevalue: I believe that we should not have been able to reach it replied the engineer for the sea is deep and there is not a rock on which we could have taken refuge Before Granite House at least there were sandbanks an islet which multiplied our chances of safety Here nothing but the depths

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It is singular enough, remarked Spilett, that this comparatively small island should present such varied ground. This diversity of aspect, logically only belongs to continents of a certain extent. One would really say, that the western part of Lincoln Island, so rich and so fertile, is washed by the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico, and that its shores to the north and the southeast extend over a sort of Arctic sea.
children.prevalue: It is singular enough remarked Spilett that this comparatively small island should present such varied ground This diversity of aspect logically only belongs to continents of a certain extent One would really say that the western part of Lincoln Island so rich and so fertile is washed by the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico and that its shores to the north and the southeast extend over a sort of Arctic sea

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: You are right, my dear Spilett, replied Cyrus Harding, I have also observed this. I think the form and also the nature of this island strange. It is a summary of all the aspects which a continent presents, and I should not be surprised if it was a continent formerly.
children.prevalue: You are right my dear Spilett replied Cyrus Harding I have also observed this I think the form and also the nature of this island strange It is a summary of all the aspects which a continent presents and I should not be surprised if it was a continent formerly

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What! a continent in the middle of the Pacific? cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: What a continent in the middle of the Pacific cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Why not? replied Cyrus Harding. Why should not Australia, New Ireland, Australasia, united to the archipelagoes of the Pacific, have once formed a sixth part of the world, as important as Europe or Asia, as Africa or the two Americas? To my mind, it is quite possible that all these islands, emerging from this vast ocean, are but the summits of a continent, now submerged, but which was above the waters at a prehistoric period.
children.prevalue: Why not replied Cyrus Harding Why should not Australia New Ireland Australasia united to the archipelagoes of the Pacific have once formed a sixth part of the world as important as Europe or Asia as Africa or the two Americas To my mind it is quite possible that all these islands emerging from this vast ocean are but the summits of a continent now submerged but which was above the waters at a prehistoric period

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: As the Atlantis was formerly, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: As the Atlantis was formerly replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes, my boy... if, however, it existed.
children.prevalue: Yes my boy if however it existed

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And would Lincoln Island have been a part of that continent? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: And would Lincoln Island have been a part of that continent asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: It is probable, replied Cyrus Harding, and that would sufficiently, explain the variety of productions which are seen on its surface.
children.prevalue: It is probable replied Cyrus Harding and that would sufficiently explain the variety of productions which are seen on its surface

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And the great number of animals which still inhabit it, added Herbert.
children.prevalue: And the great number of animals which still inhabit it added Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes, my boy, replied the engineer, and you furnish me with an argument to support my theory. It is certain, after what we have seen, that animals are numerous in this island, and what is more strange, that the species are extremely varied. There is a reason for that, and to me it is that Lincoln Island may have formerly been a part of some vast continent which had gradually sunk below the Pacific.
children.prevalue: Yes my boy replied the engineer and you furnish me with an argument to support my theory It is certain after what we have seen that animals are numerous in this island and what is more strange that the species are extremely varied There is a reason for that and to me it is that Lincoln Island may have formerly been a part of some vast continent which had gradually sunk below the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Then, some fine day, said Pencroft, who did not appear to be entirely convinced, the rest of this ancient continent may disappear in its turn, and there will be nothing between America and Asia.
children.prevalue: Then some fine day said Pencroft who did not appear to be entirely convinced the rest of this ancient continent may disappear in its turn and there will be nothing between America and Asia

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, replied Harding, there will be new continents which millions and millions of animalculae are building at this moment.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Harding there will be new continents which millions and millions of animalculae are building at this moment

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And what are these masons? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: And what are these masons asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Coral insects, replied Cyrus Harding. By constant work they made the island of Clermont-Tonnerre, and numerous other coral islands in the Pacific Ocean. Forty-seven millions of these insects are needed to weigh a grain, and yet, with the sea-salt they absorb, the solid elements of water which they assimilate, these animalculae produce limestone, and this limestone forms enormous submarine erections, of which the hardness and solidity equal granite. Formerly, at the first periods of creation, nature employing fire, heaved up the land, but now she entrusts to these microscopic creatures the task of replacing this agent, of which the dynamic power in the interior of the globe has evidently diminished--which is proved by the number of volcanoes on the surface of the earth, now actually extinct. And I believe that centuries succeeding to centuries, and insects to insects, this Pacific may one day be changed into a vast continent, which new generations will inhabit and civilize in their turn.
children.prevalue: Coral insects replied Cyrus Harding By constant work they made the island of Clermont Tonnerre and numerous other coral islands in the Pacific Ocean Forty seven millions of these insects are needed to weigh a grain and yet with the sea salt they absorb the solid elements of water which they assimilate these animalculae produce limestone and this limestone forms enormous submarine erections of which the hardness and solidity equal granite Formerly at the first periods of creation nature employing fire heaved up the land but now she entrusts to these microscopic creatures the task of replacing this agent of which the dynamic power in the interior of the globe has evidently diminished which is proved by the number of volcanoes on the surface of the earth now actually extinct And I believe that centuries succeeding to centuries and insects to insects this Pacific may one day be changed into a vast continent which new generations will inhabit and civilize in their turn

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: That will take a long time, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: That will take a long time said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Nature has time for it, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Nature has time for it replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: But what would be the use of new continents? asked Herbert. It appears to me that the present extent of habitable countries is sufficient for humanity. Yet nature does nothing uselessly.
children.prevalue: But what would be the use of new continents asked Herbert It appears to me that the present extent of habitable countries is sufficient for humanity Yet nature does nothing uselessly

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Nothing uselessly, certainly, replied the engineer, but this is how the necessity of new continents for the future, and exactly on the tropical zone occupied by the coral islands, may be explained. At least to me this explanation appears plausible.
children.prevalue: Nothing uselessly certainly replied the engineer but this is how the necessity of new continents for the future and exactly on the tropical zone occupied by the coral islands may be explained At least to me this explanation appears plausible

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: We are listening, captain, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: We are listening captain said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: This is my idea: philosophers generally admit that some day our globe will end, or rather that animal and vegetable life will no longer be possible, because of the intense cold to which it will be subjected. What they are not agreed upon, is the cause of this cold. Some think that it will arise from the falling of the temperature, which the sun will experience after millions of years; others, from the gradual extinction of the fires in the interior of our globe, which have a greater influence on it than is generally supposed. I hold to this last hypothesis, grounding it on the fact that the moon is really a cold star, which is no longer habitable, although the sun continues to throw on its surface the same amount of heat. If, then, the moon has become cold, it is because the interior fires to which, as do all the stars of the stellar world, it owes its origin, are completely extinct. Lastly, whatever may be the cause, our globe will become cold some day, but this cold will only operate gradually. What will happen, then? The temperate zones, at a more or less distant period, will not be more habitable than the polar regions now are. Then the population of men, as well as the animals, will flow towards the latitudes which are more directly under the solar influence. An immense emigration will take place. Europe, Central Asia, North America, will gradually be abandoned, as well as Australasia and the lower parts of South America. The vegetation will follow the human emigration. The flora will retreat towards the Equator at the same time as the fauna. The central parts of South America and Africa will be the continents chiefly inhabited. The Laplanders and the Samoides will find the climate of the polar regions on the shores of the Mediterranean. Who can say, that at this period, the equatorial regions will not be too small, to contain and nourish terrestrial humanity? Now, may not provident nature, so as to give refuge to all the vegetable and animal emigration, be at present laying the foundation of a new continent under the Equator, and may she not have entrusted these insects with the construction of it? I have often thought of all these things, my friends, and I seriously believe that the aspect of our globe will some day be completely changed; that by the raising of new continents the sea will cover the old, and that, in future ages, a Columbus will go to discover the islands of Chimborazo, of the Himalayas, or of Mont Blanc, remains of a submerged America, Asia, and Europe. Then these new continents will become, in their turn, uninhabitable; heat will die away, as does the heat from a body when the soul has left it; and life will disappear from the globe, if not for ever, at least for a period. Perhaps then, our spheroid will rest--will be left to death--to revive some day under superior conditions! But all that, my friends, is the secret of the Author of all things; and beginning by the work of the insects, I have perhaps let myself be carried too far, in investigating the secrets of the future.
children.prevalue: This is my idea philosophers generally admit that some day our globe will end or rather that animal and vegetable life will no longer be possible because of the intense cold to which it will be subjected What they are not agreed upon is the cause of this cold Some think that it will arise from the falling of the temperature which the sun will experience after millions of years others from the gradual extinction of the fires in the interior of our globe which have a greater influence on it than is generally supposed I hold to this last hypothesis grounding it on the fact that the moon is really a cold star which is no longer habitable although the sun continues to throw on its surface the same amount of heat If then the moon has become cold it is because the interior fires to which as do all the stars of the stellar world it owes its origin are completely extinct Lastly whatever may be the cause our globe will become cold some day but this cold will only operate gradually What will happen then The temperate zones at a more or less distant period will not be more habitable than the polar regions now are Then the population of men as well as the animals will flow towards the latitudes which are more directly under the solar influence An immense emigration will take place Europe Central Asia North America will gradually be abandoned as well as Australasia and the lower parts of South America The vegetation will follow the human emigration The flora will retreat towards the Equator at the same time as the fauna The central parts of South America and Africa will be the continents chiefly inhabited The Laplanders and the Samoides will find the climate of the polar regions on the shores of the Mediterranean Who can say that at this present laying the foundation of a new continent under the Equator and may she not have entrusted these insects with the construction of it I have often thought of all these things my friends and I discover the islands of Chimborazo of the Himalayas or of Mont Blanc remains of a submerged America Asia and Europe Then these new continents will become in their turn uninhabitable heat will die away children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: My dear Cyrus, replied Spilett, these theories are prophecies to me, and they will be accomplished some day.
children.prevalue: My dear Cyrus replied Spilett these theories are prophecies to me and they will be accomplished some day

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: That is the secret of God, said the engineer.
children.prevalue: That is the secret of God said the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: All that is well and good, then said Pencroft, who had listened with all his might, but will you tell me, captain, if Lincoln Island has been made by your insects?
children.prevalue: All that is well and good then said Pencroft who had listened with all his might but will you tell me captain if Lincoln Island has been made by your insects

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No, replied Harding; it is of a purely volcanic origin.
children.prevalue: No replied Harding it is of a purely volcanic origin

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Then it will disappear some day?
children.prevalue: Then it will disappear some day

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: That is probable.
children.prevalue: That is probable

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I hope we won't be here then.
children.prevalue: I hope we won t be here then

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: No, don't be uneasy, Pencroft; we shall not be here then, as we have no wish to die here, and hope to get away some time.
children.prevalue: No don t be uneasy Pencroft we shall not be here then as we have no wish to die here and hope to get away some time

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: In the meantime, replied Gideon Spilett, let us establish ourselves here as if forever. There is no use in doing things by halves.
children.prevalue: In the meantime replied Gideon Spilett let us establish ourselves here as if forever There is no use in doing things by halves

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: This ended the conversation. Breakfast was finished, the exploration was continued, and the settlers arrived at the border of the marshy region. It was a marsh of which the extent, to the rounded coast which terminated the island at the southeast, was about twenty square miles. The soil was formed of clayey flint-earth, mingled with vegetable matter, such as the remains of rushes, reeds, grass, etc. Here and there beds of grass, thick as a carpet, covered it. In many places icy pools sparkled in the sun. Neither rain nor any river, increased by a sudden swelling, could supply these ponds. They therefore naturally concluded that the marsh was fed by the infiltrations of the soil and it was really so. It was also to be feared that during the heat miasmas would arise, which might produce fevers.
children.prevalue: This ended the conversation Breakfast was finished the exploration was continued and the settlers arrived at the border of the marshy region It was a marsh of which the extent to the rounded coast which terminated the island at the southeast was about twenty square miles The soil was formed of clayey flint earth mingled with vegetable matter such as the remains of rushes reeds grass etc Here and there beds of grass thick as a carpet covered it In many places icy pools sparkled in the sun Neither rain nor any river increased by a sudden swelling could supply these ponds They therefore naturally concluded that the marsh was fed by the infiltrations of the soil and it was really so It was also to be feared that during the heat miasmas would arise which might produce fevers

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Above the aquatic plants, on the surface of the stagnant water, fluttered numbers of birds. Wild duck, teal, snipe lived there in flocks, and those fearless birds allowed themselves to be easily approached.
children.prevalue: Above the aquatic plants on the surface of the stagnant water fluttered numbers of birds Wild duck teal snipe lived there in flocks and those fearless birds allowed themselves to be easily approached

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: One shot from a gun would certainly have brought down some dozen of the birds, they were so close together. The explorers were, however, obliged to content themselves with bows and arrows. The result was less, but the silent arrow had the advantage of not frightening the birds, while the noise of firearms would have dispersed them to all parts of the marsh. The hunters were satisfied, for this time, with a dozen ducks, which had white bodies with a band of cinnamon, a green head, wings black, white, and red, and flattened beak. Herbert called them tadorns. Top helped in the capture of these birds, whose name was given to this marshy part of the island. The settlers had here an abundant reserve of aquatic game. At some future time they meant to explore it more carefully, and it was probable that some of the birds there might be domesticated, or at least brought to the shores of the lake, so that they would be more within their reach.

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: About five o'clock in the evening Cyrus Harding and his companions retraced their steps to their dwelling by traversing Tadorn's Fens, and crossed the Mercy on the ice-bridge.
children.prevalue: About five o clock in the evening Cyrus Harding and his companions retraced their steps to their dwelling by traversing Tadorn s Fens and crossed the Mercy on the ice bridge

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: At eight in the evening they all entered Granite House.
children.prevalue: At eight in the evening they all entered Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: This intense cold lasted till the 15th of August, without, however, passing the degree of Fahrenheit already mentioned. When the atmosphere was calm, the low temperature was easily borne, but when the wind blew, the poor settlers, insufficiently clothed, felt it severely. Pencroft regretted that Lincoln Island was not the home of a few families of bears rather than of so many foxes and seals.
children.prevalue: This intense cold lasted till the 15th of August without however passing the degree of Fahrenheit already mentioned When the atmosphere was calm the low temperature was easily borne but when the wind blew the poor settlers insufficiently clothed felt it severely Pencroft regretted that Lincoln Island was not the home of a few families of bears rather than of so many foxes and seals

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Bears, said he, are generally very well dressed, and I ask no more than to borrow for the winter the warm cloaks which they have on their backs.
children.prevalue: Bears said he are generally very well dressed and I ask no more than to borrow for the winter the warm cloaks which they have on their backs

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But, replied Neb, laughing, perhaps the bears would not consent to give you their cloaks, Pencroft. These beasts are not St. Martins.
children.prevalue: But replied Neb laughing perhaps the bears would not consent to give you their cloaks Pencroft These beasts are not St Martins

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: We would make them do it, Neb, we would make them, replied Pencroft, in quite an authoritative tone.
children.prevalue: We would make them do it Neb we would make them replied Pencroft in quite an authoritative tone

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But these formidable carnivora did not exist in the island, or at any rate they had not yet shown themselves.
children.prevalue: But these formidable carnivora did not exist in the island or at any rate they had not yet shown themselves

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: In the meanwhile, Herbert, Pencroft, and the reporter occupied themselves with making traps on Prospect Heights and at the border of the forest.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile Herbert Pencroft and the reporter occupied themselves with making traps on Prospect Heights and at the border of the forest

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: According to the sailor, any animal, whatever it was, would be a lawful prize, and the rodents or carnivora which might get into the new snares would be well received at Granite House.
children.prevalue: According to the sailor any animal whatever it was would be a lawful prize and the rodents or carnivora which might get into the new snares would be well received at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The traps were besides extremely simple; being pits dug in the ground, a platform of branches and grass above, which concealed the opening, and at the bottom some bait, the scent of which would attract animals. It must be mentioned also, that they had not been dug at random, but at certain places where numerous footprints showed that quadrupeds frequented the ground. They were visited every day, and at three different times, during the first days, specimens of those Antarctic foxes which they had already seen on the right bank of the Mercy were found in them.
children.prevalue: The traps were besides extremely simple being pits dug in the ground a platform of branches and grass above which concealed the opening and at the bottom some bait the scent of which would attract animals It must be mentioned also that they had not been dug at random but at certain places where numerous footprints showed that quadrupeds frequented the ground They were visited every day and at three different times during the first days specimens of those Antarctic foxes which they had already seen on the right bank of the Mercy were found in them

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Why, there are nothing but foxes in this country! cried Pencroft, when for the third time he drew one of the animals out of the pit. Looking at it in great disgust, he added, beasts which are good for nothing!
children.prevalue: Why there are nothing but foxes in this country cried Pencroft when for the third time he drew one of the animals out of the pit Looking at it in great disgust he added beasts which are good for nothing

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes, said Gideon Spilett, they are good for something!
children.prevalue: Yes said Gideon Spilett they are good for something

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: And what is that?
children.prevalue: And what is that

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: To make bait to attract other creatures!
children.prevalue: To make bait to attract other creatures

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The reporter was right, and the traps were henceforward baited with the foxes carcasses.
children.prevalue: The reporter was right and the traps were henceforward baited with the foxes carcasses

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The sailor had also made snares from the long tough fibers of a certain plant, and they were even more successful than the traps. Rarely a day passed without some rabbits from the warren being caught. It was always rabbit, but Neb knew how to vary his sauces and the settlers did not think of complaining.
children.prevalue: The sailor had also made snares from the long tough fibers of a certain plant and they were even more successful than the traps Rarely a day passed without some rabbits from the warren being caught It was always rabbit but Neb knew how to vary his sauces and the settlers did not think of complaining

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: However, once or twice in the second week of August, the traps supplied the hunters with other animals more useful than foxes, namely, several of those small wild boars which had already been seen to the north of the lake. Pencroft had no need to ask if these beasts were eatable. He could see that by their resemblance to the pig of America and Europe.
children.prevalue: However once or twice in the second week of August the traps supplied the hunters with other animals more useful than foxes namely several of those small wild boars which had already been seen to the north of the lake Pencroft had no need to ask if these beasts were eatable He could see that by their resemblance to the pig of America and Europe

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But these are not pigs, said Herbert to him, I warn you of that, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: But these are not pigs said Herbert to him I warn you of that Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: My boy, replied the sailor, bending over the trap and drawing out one of these representatives of the family of sus by the little appendage which served it as a tail. Let me believe that these are pigs.
children.prevalue: My boy replied the sailor bending over the trap and drawing out one of these representatives of the family of sus by the little appendage which served it as a tail Let me believe that these are pigs

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Because that pleases me!
children.prevalue: Because that pleases me

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Are you very fond of pig then, Pencroft?
children.prevalue: Are you very fond of pig then Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I am very fond of pig, replied the sailor, particularly of its feet, and if it had eight instead of four, I should like it twice as much!
children.prevalue: I am very fond of pig replied the sailor particularly of its feet and if it had eight instead of four I should like it twice as much

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: As to the animals in question, they were peccaries belonging to one of the four species which are included in the family, and they were also of the species of Tajacu, recognizable by their deep color and the absence of those long teeth with which the mouths of their congeners are armed. These peccaries generally live in herds, and it was probable that they abounded in the woody parts of the island.
children.prevalue: As to the animals in question they were peccaries belonging to one of the four species which are included in the family and they were also of the species of Tajacu recognizable by their deep color and the absence of those long teeth with which the mouths of their congeners are armed These peccaries generally live in herds and it was probable that they abounded in the woody parts of the island

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: At any rate, they were eatable from head to foot, and Pencroft did not ask more from them.
children.prevalue: At any rate they were eatable from head to foot and Pencroft did not ask more from them

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Towards the 15th of August, the state of the atmosphere was suddenly moderated by the wind shifting to the northwest. The temperature rose some degrees, and the accumulated vapor in the air was not long in resolving into snow. All the island was covered with a sheet of white, and showed itself to its inhabitants under a new aspect. The snow fell abundantly for several days, and it soon reached a thickness of two feet.
children.prevalue: Towards the 15th of August the state of the atmosphere was suddenly moderated by the wind shifting to the northwest The temperature rose some degrees and the accumulated vapor in the air was not long in resolving into snow All the island was covered with a sheet of white and showed itself to its inhabitants under a new aspect The snow fell abundantly for several days and it soon reached a thickness of two feet

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The wind also blew with great violence, and at the height of Granite House the sea could be heard thundering against the reefs. In some places, the wind, eddying round the corners, formed the snow into tall whirling columns, resembling those waterspouts which turn round on their base, and which vessels attack with a shot from a gun. However, the storm, coming from the northwest, blew across the island, and the position of Granite House preserved it from a direct attack.
children.prevalue: The wind also blew with great violence and at the height of Granite House the sea could be heard thundering against the reefs In some places the wind eddying round the corners formed the snow into tall whirling columns resembling those waterspouts which turn round on their base and which vessels attack with a shot from a gun However the storm coming from the northwest blew across the island and the position of Granite House preserved it from a direct attack

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But in the midst of this snow-storm, as terrible as if it had been produced in some polar country, neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions could, notwithstanding their wish for it, venture forth, and they remained shut up for five days, from the 20th to the 25th of August. They could hear the tempest raging in Jacamar Wood, which would surely suffer from it. Many of the trees would no doubt be torn up by the roots, but Pencroft consoled himself by thinking that he would not have the trouble of cutting them down.
children.prevalue: But in the midst of this snow storm as terrible as if it had been produced in some polar country neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions could notwithstanding their wish for it venture forth and they remained shut up for five days from the 20th to the 25th of August They could hear the tempest raging in Jacamar Wood which would surely suffer from it Many of the trees would no doubt be torn up by the roots but Pencroft consoled himself by thinking that he would not have the trouble of cutting them down

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The wind is turning woodman, let it alone, he repeated.
children.prevalue: The wind is turning woodman let it alone he repeated

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Besides, there was no way of stopping it, if they had wished to do so.
children.prevalue: Besides there was no way of stopping it if they had wished to do so

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: How grateful the inhabitants of Granite House then were to Heaven for having prepared for them this solid and immovable retreat! Cyrus Harding had also his legitimate share of thanks, but after all, it was Nature who had hollowed out this vast cavern, and he had only discovered it. There all were in safety, and the tempest could not reach them. If they had constructed a house of bricks and wood on Prospect Heights, it certainly would not have resisted the fury of this storm. As to the Chimneys, it must have been absolutely uninhabitable, for the sea, passing over the islet, would beat furiously against it. But here, in Granite House, in the middle of a solid mass, over which neither the sea nor air had any influence, there was nothing to fear.

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: During these days of seclusion the settlers did not remain inactive.
children.prevalue: During these days of seclusion the settlers did not remain inactive

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: There was no want of wood, cut up into planks, in the storeroom, and little by little they completed their furnishing; constructing the most solid of tables and chairs, for material was not spared. Neb and Pencroft were very proud of this rather heavy furniture, which they would not have changed on any account.
children.prevalue: There was no want of wood cut up into planks in the storeroom and little by little they completed their furnishing constructing the most solid of tables and chairs for material was not spared Neb and Pencroft were very proud of this rather heavy furniture which they would not have changed on any account

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Then the carpenters became basket-makers, and they did not succeed badly in this new manufacture. At the point of the lake which projected to the north, they had discovered an osier-bed in which grew a large number of purple osiers. Before the rainy season, Pencroft and Herbert had cut down these useful shrubs, and their branches, well prepared, could now be effectively employed. The first attempts were somewhat crude, but in consequence of the cleverness and intelligence of the workmen, by consulting, and recalling the models which they had seen, and by emulating each other, the possessions of the colony were soon increased by several baskets of different sizes. The storeroom was provided with them, and in special baskets Neb placed his collection of rhizomes, stone-pine almonds, etc.
