children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: During the last week of the month of August the weather moderated again. The temperature fell a little, and the tempest abated. The colonists sallied out directly. There was certainly two feet of snow on the shore, but they were able to walk without much difficulty on the hardened surface. Cyrus Harding and his companions climbed Prospect Heights.
children.prevalue: During the last week of the month of August the weather moderated again The temperature fell a little and the tempest abated The colonists sallied out directly There was certainly two feet of snow on the shore but they were able to walk without much difficulty on the hardened surface Cyrus Harding and his companions climbed Prospect Heights

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What a change! The woods, which they had left green, especially in the part at which the firs predominated, had disappeared under a uniform color. All was white, from the summit of Mount Franklin to the shore, the forests, the plains, the lake, the river. The waters of the Mercy flowed under a roof of ice, which, at each rising and ebbing of the tide, broke up with loud crashes. Numerous birds fluttered over the frozen surface of the lake. Ducks and snipe, teal and guillemots were assembled in thousands. The rocks among which the cascade flowed were bristling with icicles. One might have said that the water escaped by a monstrous gargoyle, shaped with all the imagination of an artist of the Renaissance. As to the damage caused by the storm in the forest, that could not as yet be ascertained; they would have to wait till the snowy covering was dissipated.
children.prevalue: What a change The woods which they had left green especially in the part at which the firs predominated had disappeared under a uniform color All was white from the summit of Mount Franklin to the shore the forests the plains the lake the river The waters of the Mercy flowed under a roof of ice which at each rising and ebbing of the tide broke up with loud crashes Numerous birds fluttered over the frozen surface of the lake Ducks and snipe teal and guillemots were assembled in thousands The rocks among which the cascade flowed were bristling with icicles One might have said that the water escaped by a monstrous gargoyle shaped with all the imagination of an artist of the Renaissance As to the damage caused by the storm in the forest that could not as yet be ascertained they would have to wait till the snowy covering was dissipated

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Herbert did not miss this opportunity of going to visit their traps. They did not find them easily, under the snow with which they were covered. They had also to be careful not to fall into one or other of them, which would have been both dangerous and humiliating; to be taken in their own snares! But happily they avoided this unpleasantness, and found their traps perfectly intact. No animal had fallen into them, and yet the footprints in the neighborhood were very numerous, among others, certain very clear marks of claws. Herbert did not hesitate to affirm that some animal of the feline species had passed there, which justified the engineer's opinion that dangerous beasts existed in Lincoln Island. These animals doubtless generally lived in the forests of the Far West, but pressed by hunger, they had ventured as far as Prospect Heights. Perhaps they had smelled out the inhabitants of Granite House. Now, what are these feline creatures? asked Pencroft. They are tigers, replied Herbert. I thought those beasts were only found in hot countries?

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: On the new continent, replied the lad, they are found from Mexico to the Pampas of Buenos Aires. Now, as Lincoln Island is nearly under the same latitude as the provinces of La Plata, it is not surprising that tigers are to be met with in it.
children.prevalue: On the new continent replied the lad they are found from Mexico to the Pampas of Buenos Aires Now as Lincoln Island is nearly under the same latitude as the provinces of La Plata it is not surprising that tigers are to be met with in it

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well, we must look out for them, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Well we must look out for them replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: However, the snow soon disappeared, quickly dissolving under the influence of the rising temperature. Rain fell, and the sheet of white soon vanished. Notwithstanding the bad weather, the settlers renewed their stores of different things, stone-pine almonds, rhizomes, syrup from the maple-tree, for the vegetable part; rabbits from the warren, agouties, and kangaroos for the animal part. This necessitated several excursions into the forest, and they found that a great number of trees had been blown down by the last hurricane. Pencroft and Neb also pushed with the cart as far as the vein of coal, and brought back several tons of fuel. They saw in passing that the pottery kiln had been severely damaged by the wind, at least six feet of it having been blown off.
children.prevalue: However the snow soon disappeared quickly dissolving under the influence of the rising temperature Rain fell and the sheet of white soon vanished Notwithstanding the bad weather the settlers renewed their stores of different things stone pine almonds rhizomes syrup from the maple tree for the vegetable part rabbits from the warren agouties and kangaroos for the animal part This necessitated several excursions into the forest and they found that a great number of trees had been blown down by the last hurricane Pencroft and Neb also pushed with the cart as far as the vein of coal and brought back several tons of fuel They saw in passing that the pottery kiln had been severely damaged by the wind at least six feet of it having been blown off

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: At the same time as the coal, the store of wood was renewed at Granite House, and they profited by the current of the Mercy having again become free, to float down several rafts. They could see that the cold period was not ended.
children.prevalue: At the same time as the coal the store of wood was renewed at Granite House and they profited by the current of the Mercy having again become free to float down several rafts They could see that the cold period was not ended

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: A visit was also paid to the Chimneys, and the settlers could not but congratulate themselves on not having been living there during the hurricane. The sea had left unquestionable traces of its ravages. Sweeping over the islet, it had furiously assailed the passages, half filling them with sand, while thick beds of seaweed covered the rocks. While Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft hunted or collected wood, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett busied themselves in putting the Chimneys to rights, and they found the forge and the bellows almost unhurt, protected as they had been from the first by the heaps of sand.
children.prevalue: A visit was also paid to the Chimneys and the settlers could not but congratulate themselves on not having been living there during the hurricane The sea had left unquestionable traces of its ravages Sweeping over the islet it had furiously assailed the passages half filling them with sand while thick beds of seaweed covered the rocks While Neb Herbert and Pencroft hunted or collected wood Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett busied themselves in putting the Chimneys to rights and they found the forge and the bellows almost unhurt protected as they had been from the first by the heaps of sand

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The store of fuel had not been made uselessly. The settlers had not done with the rigorous cold. It is known that, in the Northern Hemisphere, the month of February is principally distinguished by rapid fallings of the temperature. It is the same in the Southern Hemisphere, and the end of the month of August, which is the February of North America, does not escape this climatic law.
children.prevalue: The store of fuel had not been made uselessly The settlers had not done with the rigorous cold It is known that in the Northern Hemisphere the month of February is principally distinguished by rapid fallings of the temperature It is the same in the Southern Hemisphere and the end of the month of August which is the February of North America does not escape this climatic law

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: About the 25th, after another change from snow to rain, the wind shifted to the southeast, and the cold became, suddenly, very severe. According to the engineer's calculation, the mercurial column of a Fahrenheit thermometer would not have marked less than eight degrees below zero, and this intense cold, rendered still more painful by a sharp gale, lasted for several days. The colonists were again shut up in Granite House, and as it was necessary to hermetically seal all the openings of the facade, only leaving a narrow passage for renewing the air, the consumption of candles was considerable. To economize them, the cavern was often only lighted by the blazing hearths, on which fuel was not spared. Several times, one or other of the settlers descended to the beach in the midst of ice which the waves heaped up at each tide, but they soon climbed up again to Granite House, and it was not without pain and difficulty that their hands could hold to the rounds of the ladder. In consequence of the intense cold, their fingers felt as if burned when they touched the rounds. To occupy the leisure hours, which the tenants of Granite House now had at their disposal, Cyrus Harding undertook an operation which could be performed indoors.

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: We know that the settlers had no other sugar at their disposal than the liquid substance which they drew from the maple, by making deep incisions in the tree. They contented themselves with collecting this liquor in jars and employing it in this state for different culinary purposes, and the more so, as on growing old, this liquid began to become white and to be of a syrupy consistence.
children.prevalue: We know that the settlers had no other sugar at their disposal than the liquid substance which they drew from the maple by making deep incisions in the tree They contented themselves with collecting this liquor in jars and employing it in this state for different culinary purposes and the more so as on growing old this liquid began to become white and to be of a syrupy consistence

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But there was something better to be made of it, and one day Cyrus Harding announced that they were going to turn into refiners.
children.prevalue: But there was something better to be made of it and one day Cyrus Harding announced that they were going to turn into refiners

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Refiners! replied Pencroft. That is rather a warm trade, I think.
children.prevalue: Refiners replied Pencroft That is rather a warm trade I think

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Very warm, answered the engineer.
children.prevalue: Very warm answered the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Then it will be seasonable! said the sailor.
children.prevalue: Then it will be seasonable said the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: This word refining need not awake in the mind thoughts of an elaborate manufactory with apparatus and numerous workmen. No! to crystallize this liquor, only an extremely easy operation is required. Placed on the fire in large earthen pots, it was simply subjected to evaporation, and soon a scum arose to its surface. As soon as this began to thicken, Neb carefully removed it with a wooden spatula; this accelerated the evaporation, and at the same time prevented it from contracting an empyreumatic flavor.
children.prevalue: This word refining need not awake in the mind thoughts of an elaborate manufactory with apparatus and numerous workmen No to crystallize this liquor only an extremely easy operation is required Placed on the fire in large earthen pots it was simply subjected to evaporation and soon a scum arose to its surface As soon as this began to thicken Neb carefully removed it with a wooden spatula this accelerated the evaporation and at the same time prevented it from contracting an empyreumatic flavor

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: After boiling for several hours on a hot fire, which did as much good to the operators as the substance operated upon, the latter was transformed into a thick syrup. This syrup was poured into clay molds, previously fabricated in the kitchen stove, and to which they had given various shapes. The next day this syrup had become cold, and formed cakes and tablets. This was sugar of rather a reddish color, but nearly transparent and of a delicious taste.
children.prevalue: After boiling for several hours on a hot fire which did as much good to the operators as the substance operated upon the latter was transformed into a thick syrup This syrup was poured into clay molds previously fabricated in the kitchen stove and to which they had given various shapes The next day this syrup had become cold and formed cakes and tablets This was sugar of rather a reddish color but nearly transparent and of a delicious taste

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The cold continued to the middle of September, and the prisoners in Granite House began to find their captivity rather tedious. Nearly every day they attempted sorties which they could not prolong. They constantly worked at the improvement of their dwelling. They talked while working. Harding instructed his companions in many things, principally explaining to them the practical applications of science. The colonists had no library at their disposal; but the engineer was a book which was always at hand, always open at the page which one wanted, a book which answered all their questions, and which they often consulted. The time thus passed away pleasantly, these brave men not appearing to have any fears for the future.
children.prevalue: The cold continued to the middle of September and the prisoners in Granite House began to find their captivity rather tedious Nearly every day they attempted sorties which they could not prolong They constantly worked at the improvement of their dwelling They talked while working Harding instructed his companions in many things principally explaining to them the practical applications of science The colonists had no library at their disposal but the engineer was a book which was always at hand always open at the page which one wanted a book which answered all their questions and which they often consulted The time thus passed away pleasantly these brave men not appearing to have any fears for the future

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: However, all were anxious to see, if not the fine season, at least the cessation of the insupportable cold. If only they had been clothed in a way to meet it, how many excursions they would have attempted, either to the downs or to Tadorn's Fens! Game would have been easily approached, and the chase would certainly have been most productive. But Cyrus Harding considered it of importance that no one should injure his health, for he had need of all his hands, and his advice was followed.
children.prevalue: However all were anxious to see if not the fine season at least the cessation of the insupportable cold If only they had been clothed in a way to meet it how many excursions they would have attempted either to the downs or to Tadorn s Fens Game would have been easily approached and the chase would certainly have been most productive But Cyrus Harding considered it of importance that no one should injure his health for he had need of all his hands and his advice was followed

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But it must be said, that the one who was most impatient of this imprisonment, after Pencroft perhaps, was Top. The faithful dog found Granite House very narrow. He ran backwards and forwards from one room to another, showing in his way how weary he was of being shut up. Harding often remarked that when he approached the dark well which communicated with the sea, and of which the orifice opened at the back of the storeroom, Top uttered singular growlings. He ran round and round this hole, which had been covered with a wooden lid. Sometimes even he tried to put his paws under the lid, as if he wished to raise it. He then yelped in a peculiar way, which showed at once anger and uneasiness.
children.prevalue: But it must be said that the one who was most impatient of this imprisonment after Pencroft perhaps was Top The faithful dog found Granite House very narrow He ran backwards and forwards from one room to another showing in his way how weary he was of being shut up Harding often remarked that when he approached the dark well which communicated with the sea and of which the orifice opened at the back of the storeroom Top uttered singular growlings He ran round and round this hole which had been covered with a wooden lid Sometimes even he tried to put his paws under the lid as if he wished to raise it He then yelped in a peculiar way which showed at once anger and uneasiness

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The engineer observed this maneuver several times.
children.prevalue: The engineer observed this maneuver several times

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What could there be in this abyss to make such an impression on the intelligent animal? The well led to the sea, that was certain. Could narrow passages spread from it through the foundations of the island? Did some marine monster come from time to time, to breathe at the bottom of this well? The engineer did not know what to think, and could not refrain from dreaming of many strange improbabilities. Accustomed to go far into the regions of scientific reality, he would not allow himself to be drawn into the regions of the strange and almost of the supernatural; but yet how to explain why Top, one of those sensible dogs who never waste their time in barking at the moon, should persist in trying with scent and hearing to fathom this abyss, if there was nothing there to cause his uneasiness? Top's conduct puzzled Cyrus Harding even more than he cared to acknowledge to himself.
children.prevalue: What could there be in this abyss to make such an impression on the intelligent animal The well led to the sea that was certain Could narrow passages spread from it through the foundations of the island Did some marine monster come from time to time to breathe at the bottom of this well The engineer did not know what to think and could not refrain from dreaming of many strange improbabilities Accustomed to go far into the regions of scientific reality he would not allow himself to be drawn into the regions of the strange and almost of the supernatural but yet how to explain why Top one of those sensible dogs who never waste their time in barking at the moon should persist in trying with scent and hearing to fathom this abyss if there was nothing there to cause his uneasiness Top s conduct puzzled Cyrus Harding even more than he cared to acknowledge to himself

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: At all events, the engineer only communicated his impressions to Gideon Spilett, for he thought it useless to explain to his companions the suspicions which arose from what perhaps was only Top's fancy.
children.prevalue: At all events the engineer only communicated his impressions to Gideon Spilett for he thought it useless to explain to his companions the suspicions which arose from what perhaps was only Top s fancy

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: At last the cold ceased. There had been rain, squalls mingled with snow, hailstorms, gusts of wind, but these inclemencies did not last. The ice melted, the snow disappeared; the shore, the plateau, the banks of the Mercy, the forest, again became practicable. This return of spring delighted the tenants of Granite House, and they soon only passed in it the hours necessary for eating and sleeping.
children.prevalue: At last the cold ceased There had been rain squalls mingled with snow hailstorms gusts of wind but these inclemencies did not last The ice melted the snow disappeared the shore the plateau the banks of the Mercy the forest again became practicable This return of spring delighted the tenants of Granite House and they soon only passed in it the hours necessary for eating and sleeping

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: They hunted much in the second part of September, which led Pencroft to again entreat for the firearms, which he asserted had been promised by Cyrus Harding. The latter, knowing well that without special tools it would be nearly impossible for him to manufacture a gun which would be of any use, still drew back and put off the operation to some future time, observing in his usual dry way, that Herbert and Spilett had become very skilful archers, so that many sorts of excellent animals, agouties, kangaroos, capybaras, pigeons, bustards, wild ducks, snipes, in short, game both with fur and feathers, fell victims to their arrows, and that, consequently, they could wait. But the obstinate sailor would listen to nothing of this, and he would give the engineer no peace till he promised to satisfy his desire. Gideon Spilett, however, supported Pencroft.
children.prevalue: They hunted much in the second part of September which led Pencroft to again entreat for the firearms which he asserted had been promised by Cyrus Harding The latter knowing well that without special tools it would be nearly impossible for him to manufacture a gun which would be of any use still drew back and put off the operation to some future time observing in his usual dry way that Herbert and Spilett had become very skilful archers so that many sorts of excellent animals agouties kangaroos capybaras pigeons bustards wild ducks snipes in short game both with fur and feathers fell victims to their arrows and that consequently they could wait But the obstinate sailor would listen to nothing of this and he would give the engineer no peace till he promised to satisfy his desire Gideon Spilett however supported Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: If, which may be doubted, said he, the island is inhabited by wild beasts, we must think how to fight with and exterminate them. A time may come when this will be our first duty.
children.prevalue: If which may be doubted said he the island is inhabited by wild beasts we must think how to fight with and exterminate them A time may come when this will be our first duty

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: But at this period, it was not the question of firearms which occupied Harding, but that of clothes. Those which the settlers wore had passed this winter, but they would not last until next winter. Skins of carnivora or the wool of ruminants must be procured at any price, and since there were plenty of musmons, it was agreed to consult on the means of forming a flock which might be brought up for the use of the colony. An enclosure for the domestic animals, a poultry-yard for the birds, in a word to establish a sort of farm in the island, such were the two important projects for the fine season.
children.prevalue: But at this period it was not the question of firearms which occupied Harding but that of clothes Those which the settlers wore had passed this winter but they would not last until next winter Skins of carnivora or the wool of ruminants must be procured at any price and since there were plenty of musmons it was agreed to consult on the means of forming a flock which might be brought up for the use of the colony An enclosure for the domestic animals a poultry yard for the birds in a word to establish a sort of farm in the island such were the two important projects for the fine season

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: In consequence and in view of these future establishments, it became of much importance that they should penetrate into all the yet unknown parts of Lincoln Island, that is to say, through that thick forest which extended on the right bank of the Mercy, from its mouth to the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula, as well as on the whole of its western side. But this needed settled weather, and a month must pass before this exploration could be profitably undertaken.

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: They therefore waited with some impatience, when an incident occurred which increased the desire the settlers had to visit the whole of their domain.
children.prevalue: They therefore waited with some impatience when an incident occurred which increased the desire the settlers had to visit the whole of their domain

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: It was the 24th of October. On this day, Pencroft had gone to visit his traps, which he always kept properly baited. In one of them he found three animals which would be very welcome for the larder. They were a female peccary and her two young ones.
children.prevalue: It was the 24th of October On this day Pencroft had gone to visit his traps which he always kept properly baited In one of them he found three animals which would be very welcome for the larder They were a female peccary and her two young ones

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Pencroft then returned to Granite House, enchanted with his capture, and, as usual, he made a great show of his game.
children.prevalue: Pencroft then returned to Granite House enchanted with his capture and as usual he made a great show of his game

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Come, we shall have a grand feast, captain! he exclaimed. And you too, Mr. Spilett, you will eat some!
children.prevalue: Come we shall have a grand feast captain he exclaimed And you too Mr Spilett you will eat some

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I shall be very happy, replied the reporter; but what is it that I am going to eat?
children.prevalue: I shall be very happy replied the reporter but what is it that I am going to eat

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Suckling-pig.
children.prevalue: Suckling pig

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oh, indeed, suckling-pig, Pencroft? To hear you, I thought that you were bringing back a young partridge stuffed with truffles!
children.prevalue: Oh indeed suckling pig Pencroft To hear you I thought that you were bringing back a young partridge stuffed with truffles

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: What? cried Pencroft. Do you mean to say that you turn up your nose at suckling-pig?'
children.prevalue: What cried Pencroft Do you mean to say that you turn up your nose at suckling pig

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: No, replied Gideon Spilett, without showing any enthusiasm; provided one doesn't eat too much.
children.prevalue: No replied Gideon Spilett without showing any enthusiasm provided one doesn t eat too much

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: That's right, that's right, returned the sailor, who was not pleased whenever he heard his chase made light of. You like to make objections. Seven months ago, when we landed on the island, you would have been only too glad to have met with such game!
children.prevalue: That s right that s right returned the sailor who was not pleased whenever he heard his chase made light of You like to make objections Seven months ago when we landed on the island you would have been only too glad to have met with such game

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Well, well, replied the reporter, man is never perfect, nor contented.
children.prevalue: Well well replied the reporter man is never perfect nor contented

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Now, said Pencroft, I hope that Neb will distinguish himself. Look here! These two little peccaries are not more than three months old! They will be as tender as quails! Come along, Neb, come! I will look after the cooking myself.
children.prevalue: Now said Pencroft I hope that Neb will distinguish himself Look here These two little peccaries are not more than three months old They will be as tender as quails Come along Neb come I will look after the cooking myself

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And the sailor, followed by Neb, entered the kitchen, where they were soon absorbed in their culinary labors.
children.prevalue: And the sailor followed by Neb entered the kitchen where they were soon absorbed in their culinary labors

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: They were allowed to do it in their own way. Neb, therefore, prepared a magnificent repast--the two little peccaries, kangaroo soup, a smoked ham, stone-pine almonds, Oswego tea; in fact, all the best that they had, but among all the dishes figured in the first rank the savory peccaries.
children.prevalue: They were allowed to do it in their own way Neb therefore prepared a magnificent repast the two little peccaries kangaroo soup a smoked ham stone pine almonds Oswego tea in fact all the best that they had but among all the dishes figured in the first rank the savory peccaries

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: At five o'clock dinner was served in the dining-room of Granite House. The kangaroo soup was smoking on the table. They found it excellent.
children.prevalue: At five o clock dinner was served in the dining room of Granite House The kangaroo soup was smoking on the table They found it excellent

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: To the soup succeeded the peccaries, which Pencroft insisted on carving himself, and of which he served out monstrous portions to each of the guests.
children.prevalue: To the soup succeeded the peccaries which Pencroft insisted on carving himself and of which he served out monstrous portions to each of the guests

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: These suckling-pigs were really delicious, and Pencroft was devouring his share with great gusto, when all at once a cry and an oath escaped him.
children.prevalue: These suckling pigs were really delicious and Pencroft was devouring his share with great gusto when all at once a cry and an oath escaped him

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: What's the matter? asked Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: What s the matter asked Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The matter? the matter is that I have just broken a tooth! replied the sailor.
children.prevalue: The matter the matter is that I have just broken a tooth replied the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: What, are there pebbles in your peccaries? said Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: What are there pebbles in your peccaries said Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: I suppose so, replied Pencroft, drawing from his lips the object which had cost him a grinder--!
children.prevalue: I suppose so replied Pencroft drawing from his lips the object which had cost him a grinder

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: It was not a pebble--it was a leaden bullet.
children.prevalue: It was not a pebble it was a leaden bullet

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: PART 2
children.prevalue: PART 2

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: ABANDONED
children.prevalue: ABANDONED

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was now exactly seven months since the balloon voyagers had been thrown on Lincoln Island. During that time, notwithstanding the researches they had made, no human being had been discovered. No smoke even had betrayed the presence of man on the surface of the island. No vestiges of his handiwork showed that either at an early or at a late period had man lived there. Not only did it now appear to be uninhabited by any but themselves, but the colonists were compelled to believe that it never had been inhabited. And now, all this scaffolding of reasonings fell before a simple ball of metal, found in the body of an inoffensive rodent! In fact, this bullet must have issued from a firearm, and who but a human being could have used such a weapon?
children.prevalue: It was now exactly seven months since the balloon voyagers had been thrown on Lincoln Island During that time notwithstanding the researches they had made no human being had been discovered No smoke even had betrayed the presence of man on the surface of the island No vestiges of his handiwork showed that either at an early or at a late period had man lived there Not only did it now appear to be uninhabited by any but themselves but the colonists were compelled to believe that it never had been inhabited And now all this scaffolding of reasonings fell before a simple ball of metal found in the body of an inoffensive rodent In fact this bullet must have issued from a firearm and who but a human being could have used such a weapon

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When Pencroft had placed the bullet on the table, his companions looked at it with intense astonishment. All the consequences likely to result from this incident, notwithstanding its apparent insignificance, immediately took possession of their minds. The sudden apparition of a supernatural being could not have startled them more completely.
children.prevalue: When Pencroft had placed the bullet on the table his companions looked at it with intense astonishment All the consequences likely to result from this incident notwithstanding its apparent insignificance immediately took possession of their minds The sudden apparition of a supernatural being could not have startled them more completely

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Cyrus Harding did not hesitate to give utterance to the suggestions which this fact, at once surprising and unexpected, could not fail to raise in his mind. He took the bullet, turned it over and over, rolled it between his finger and thumb; then, turning to Pencroft, he asked,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding did not hesitate to give utterance to the suggestions which this fact at once surprising and unexpected could not fail to raise in his mind He took the bullet turned it over and over rolled it between his finger and thumb then turning to Pencroft he asked

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Are you sure that the peccary wounded by this bullet was not more than three months old?
children.prevalue: Are you sure that the peccary wounded by this bullet was not more than three months old

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Not more, captain, replied Pencroft. It was still sucking its mother when I found it in the trap.
children.prevalue: Not more captain replied Pencroft It was still sucking its mother when I found it in the trap

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Well, said the engineer, that proves that within three months a gun-shot was fired in Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: Well said the engineer that proves that within three months a gun shot was fired in Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And that a bullet, added Gideon Spilett, wounded, though not mortally, this little animal.
children.prevalue: And that a bullet added Gideon Spilett wounded though not mortally this little animal

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: That is unquestionable, said Cyrus Harding, and these are the deductions which must be drawn from this incident: that the island was inhabited before our arrival, or that men have landed here within three months. Did these men arrive here voluntarily or involuntarily, by disembarking on the shore or by being wrecked? This point can only be cleared up later. As to what they were, Europeans or Malays, enemies or friends of our race, we cannot possibly guess; and if they still inhabit the island, or if they have left it, we know not. But these questions are of too much importance to be allowed to remain long unsettled.
children.prevalue: That is unquestionable said Cyrus Harding and these are the deductions which must be drawn from this incident that the island was inhabited before our arrival or that men have landed here within three months Did these men arrive here voluntarily or involuntarily by disembarking on the shore or by being wrecked This point can only be cleared up later As to what they were Europeans or Malays enemies or friends of our race we cannot possibly guess and if they still inhabit the island or if they have left it we know not But these questions are of too much importance to be allowed to remain long unsettled

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No! a hundred times no! a thousand times no! cried the sailor, springing up from the table. There are no other men than ourselves on Lincoln Island! By my faith! The island isn't large and if it had been inhabited, we should have seen some of the inhabitants long before this!
children.prevalue: No a hundred times no a thousand times no cried the sailor springing up from the table There are no other men than ourselves on Lincoln Island By my faith The island isn t large and if it had been inhabited we should have seen some of the inhabitants long before this

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In fact, the contrary would be very astonishing, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: In fact the contrary would be very astonishing said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But it would be much more astonishing, I should think, observed the reporter, if this peccary had been born with a bullet in its inside!
children.prevalue: But it would be much more astonishing I should think observed the reporter if this peccary had been born with a bullet in its inside

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: At least, said Neb seriously, if Pencroft has not had--
children.prevalue: At least said Neb seriously if Pencroft has not had

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Look here, Neb, burst out Pencroft. Do you think I could have a bullet in my jaw for five or six months without finding it out? Where could it be hidden? he asked, opening his mouth to show the two-and-thirty teeth with which it was furnished. Look well, Neb, and if you find one hollow tooth in this set, I will let you pull out half a dozen!
children.prevalue: Look here Neb burst out Pencroft Do you think I could have a bullet in my jaw for five or six months without finding it out Where could it be hidden he asked opening his mouth to show the two and thirty teeth with which it was furnished Look well Neb and if you find one hollow tooth in this set I will let you pull out half a dozen

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Neb's supposition is certainly inadmissible, replied Harding, who, notwithstanding the gravity of his thoughts, could not restrain a smile. It is certain that a gun has been fired in the island, within three months at most. But I am inclined to think that the people who landed on this coast were only here a very short time ago, or that they just touched here; for if, when we surveyed the island from the summit of Mount Franklin, it had been inhabited, we should have seen them or we should have been seen ourselves. It is therefore, probable that within only a few weeks castaways have been thrown by a storm on some part of the coast. However that may be, it is of consequence to us to have this point settled.
children.prevalue: Neb s supposition is certainly inadmissible replied Harding who notwithstanding the gravity of his thoughts could not restrain a smile It is certain that a gun has been fired in the island within three months at most But I am inclined to think that the people who landed on this coast were only here a very short time ago or that they just touched here for if when we surveyed the island from the summit of Mount Franklin it had been inhabited we should have seen them or we should have been seen ourselves It is therefore probable that within only a few weeks castaways have been thrown by a storm on some part of the coast However that may be it is of consequence to us to have this point settled

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I think that we should act with caution, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: I think that we should act with caution said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Such is my advice, replied Cyrus Harding, for it is to be feared that Malay pirates have landed on the island!
children.prevalue: Such is my advice replied Cyrus Harding for it is to be feared that Malay pirates have landed on the island

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Captain, asked the sailor, would it not be a good plan, before setting out, to build a canoe in which we could either ascend the river, or, if we liked, coast round the inland? It will not do to be unprovided.
children.prevalue: Captain asked the sailor would it not be a good plan before setting out to build a canoe in which we could either ascend the river or if we liked coast round the inland It will not do to be unprovided

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Your idea is good, Pencroft, replied the engineer, but we cannot wait for that. It would take at least a month to build a boat.
children.prevalue: Your idea is good Pencroft replied the engineer but we cannot wait for that It would take at least a month to build a boat

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes, a real boat, replied the sailor; but we do not want one for a sea voyage, and in five days at the most, I will undertake to construct a canoe fit to navigate the Mercy.
children.prevalue: Yes a real boat replied the sailor but we do not want one for a sea voyage and in five days at the most I will undertake to construct a canoe fit to navigate the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Five days, cried Neb, to build a boat?
children.prevalue: Five days cried Neb to build a boat

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, Neb; a boat in the Indian fashion.
children.prevalue: Yes Neb a boat in the Indian fashion

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Of wood? asked the Negro, looking still unconvinced.
children.prevalue: Of wood asked the Negro looking still unconvinced

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Of wood, replied Pencroft, or rather of bark. I repeat, captain, that in five days the work will be finished!
children.prevalue: Of wood replied Pencroft or rather of bark I repeat captain that in five days the work will be finished

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: In five days, then, be it, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: In five days then be it replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But till that time we must be very watchful, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: But till that time we must be very watchful said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Very watchful indeed, my friends, replied Harding; and I beg you to confine your hunting excursions to the neighborhood of Granite House.
children.prevalue: Very watchful indeed my friends replied Harding and I beg you to confine your hunting excursions to the neighborhood of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The dinner ended less gaily than Pencroft had hoped.
children.prevalue: The dinner ended less gaily than Pencroft had hoped

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: So, then, the island was, or had been, inhabited by others than the settlers. Proved as it was by the incident of the bullet, it was hereafter an unquestionable fact, and such a discovery could not but cause great uneasiness among the colonists.
children.prevalue: So then the island was or had been inhabited by others than the settlers Proved as it was by the incident of the bullet it was hereafter an unquestionable fact and such a discovery could not but cause great uneasiness among the colonists

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett, before sleeping, conversed long about the matter. They asked themselves if by chance this incident might not have some connection with the inexplicable way in which the engineer had been saved, and the other peculiar circumstances which had struck them at different times. However, Cyrus Harding, after having discussed the pros and cons of the question, ended by saying,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett before sleeping conversed long about the matter They asked themselves if by chance this incident might not have some connection with the inexplicable way in which the engineer had been saved and the other peculiar circumstances which had struck them at different times However Cyrus Harding after having discussed the pros and cons of the question ended by saying

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: In short, would you like to know my opinion, my dear Spilett?
children.prevalue: In short would you like to know my opinion my dear Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, Cyrus.
children.prevalue: Yes Cyrus

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well, then, it is this: however minutely we explore the island, we shall find nothing.
children.prevalue: Well then it is this however minutely we explore the island we shall find nothing

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The next day Pencroft set to work. He did not mean to build a boat with boards and planking, but simply a flat-bottomed canoe, which would be well suited for navigating the Mercy--above all, for approaching its source, where the water would naturally be shallow. Pieces of bark, fastened one to the other, would form a light boat; and in case of natural obstacles, which would render a portage necessary, it would be easily carried. Pencroft intended to secure the pieces of bark by means of nails, to insure the canoe being water-tight.
children.prevalue: The next day Pencroft set to work He did not mean to build a boat with boards and planking but simply a flat bottomed canoe which would be well suited for navigating the Mercy above all for approaching its source where the water would naturally be shallow Pieces of bark fastened one to the other would form a light boat and in case of natural obstacles which would render a portage necessary it would be easily carried Pencroft intended to secure the pieces of bark by means of nails to insure the canoe being water tight

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It was first necessary to select the trees which would afford a strong and supple bark for the work. Now the last storm had brought down a number of large birch-trees, the bark of which would be perfectly suited for their purpose. Some of these trees lay on the ground, and they had only to be barked, which was the most difficult thing of all, owing to the imperfect tools which the settlers possessed. However, they overcame all difficulties.
children.prevalue: It was first necessary to select the trees which would afford a strong and supple bark for the work Now the last storm had brought down a number of large birch trees the bark of which would be perfectly suited for their purpose Some of these trees lay on the ground and they had only to be barked which was the most difficult thing of all owing to the imperfect tools which the settlers possessed However they overcame all difficulties

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: While the sailor, seconded by the engineer, thus occupied himself without losing an hour, Gideon Spilett and Herbert were not idle.
children.prevalue: While the sailor seconded by the engineer thus occupied himself without losing an hour Gideon Spilett and Herbert were not idle

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: They were made purveyors to the colony. The reporter could not but admire the boy, who had acquired great skill in handling the bow and spear. Herbert also showed great courage and much of that presence of mind which may justly be called the reasoning of bravery. These two companions of the chase, remembering Cyrus Harding's recommendations, did not go beyond a radius of two miles round Granite House; but the borders of the forest furnished a sufficient tribute of agoutis, capybaras, kangaroos, peccaries, etc.; and if the result from the traps was less than during the cold, still the warren yielded its accustomed quota, which might have fed all the colony in Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: They were made purveyors to the colony The reporter could not but admire the boy who had acquired great skill in handling the bow and spear Herbert also showed great courage and much of that presence of mind which may justly be called the reasoning of bravery These two companions of the chase remembering Cyrus Harding s recommendations did not go beyond a radius of two miles round Granite House but the borders of the forest furnished a sufficient tribute of agoutis capybaras kangaroos peccaries etc and if the result from the traps was less than during the cold still the warren yielded its accustomed quota which might have fed all the colony in Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Often during these excursions, Herbert talked with Gideon Spilett on the incident of the bullet, and the deductions which the engineer drew from it, and one day--it was the 26th of October--he said--But, Mr. Spilett, do you not think it very extraordinary that, if any castaways have landed on the island, they have not yet shown themselves near Granite House?
children.prevalue: Often during these excursions Herbert talked with Gideon Spilett on the incident of the bullet and the deductions which the engineer drew from it and one day it was the 26th of October he said But Mr Spilett do you not think it very extraordinary that if any castaways have landed on the island they have not yet shown themselves near Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Very astonishing if they are still here, replied the reporter, but not astonishing at all if they are here no longer!
children.prevalue: Very astonishing if they are still here replied the reporter but not astonishing at all if they are here no longer

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: So you think that these people have already quitted the island? returned Herbert.
children.prevalue: So you think that these people have already quitted the island returned Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It is more than probable, my boy; for if their stay was prolonged, and above all, if they were still here, some accident would have at last betrayed their presence.
children.prevalue: It is more than probable my boy for if their stay was prolonged and above all if they were still here some accident would have at last betrayed their presence

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But if they were able to go away, observed the lad, they could not have been castaways.
children.prevalue: But if they were able to go away observed the lad they could not have been castaways

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: No, Herbert; or, at least, they were what might be called provisional castaways. It is very possible that a storm may have driven them to the island without destroying their vessel, and that, the storm over, they went away again.
children.prevalue: No Herbert or at least they were what might be called provisional castaways It is very possible that a storm may have driven them to the island without destroying their vessel and that the storm over they went away again

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I must acknowledge one thing, said Herbert, it is that Captain Harding appears rather to fear than desire the presence of human beings on our island.
children.prevalue: I must acknowledge one thing said Herbert it is that Captain Harding appears rather to fear than desire the presence of human beings on our island

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: In short, responded the reporter, there are only Malays who frequent these seas, and those fellows are ruffians which it is best to avoid.
children.prevalue: In short responded the reporter there are only Malays who frequent these seas and those fellows are ruffians which it is best to avoid

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: It is not impossible, Mr. Spilett, said Herbert, that some day or other we may find traces of their landing.
children.prevalue: It is not impossible Mr Spilett said Herbert that some day or other we may find traces of their landing

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I do not say no, my boy. A deserted camp, the ashes of a fire, would put us on the track, and this is what we will look for in our next expedition.
children.prevalue: I do not say no my boy A deserted camp the ashes of a fire would put us on the track and this is what we will look for in our next expedition

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The day on which the hunters spoke thus, they were in a part of the forest near the Mercy, remarkable for its beautiful trees. There, among others, rose, to a height of nearly 200 feet above the ground, some of those superb coniferae, to which, in New Zealand, the natives give the name of Kauris.
children.prevalue: The day on which the hunters spoke thus they were in a part of the forest near the Mercy remarkable for its beautiful trees There among others rose to a height of nearly 200 feet above the ground some of those superb coniferae to which in New Zealand the natives give the name of Kauris

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I have an idea, Mr. Spilett, said Herbert. If I were to climb to the top of one of these kauris, I could survey the country for an immense distance round.
children.prevalue: I have an idea Mr Spilett said Herbert If I were to climb to the top of one of these kauris I could survey the country for an immense distance round

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The idea is good, replied the reporter; but could you climb to the top of those giants?
children.prevalue: The idea is good replied the reporter but could you climb to the top of those giants

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I can at least try, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: I can at least try replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The light and active boy then sprang on the first branches, the arrangement of which made the ascent of the kauri easy, and in a few minutes he arrived at the summit, which emerged from the immense plain of verdure.
children.prevalue: The light and active boy then sprang on the first branches the arrangement of which made the ascent of the kauri easy and in a few minutes he arrived at the summit which emerged from the immense plain of verdure

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: From this elevated situation his gaze extended over all the southern portion of the island, from Claw Cape on the southeast, to Reptile End on the southwest. To the northwest rose Mount Franklin, which concealed a great part of the horizon.
children.prevalue: From this elevated situation his gaze extended over all the southern portion of the island from Claw Cape on the southeast to Reptile End on the southwest To the northwest rose Mount Franklin which concealed a great part of the horizon

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But Herbert, from the height of his observatory, could examine all the yet unknown portion of the island, which might have given shelter to the strangers whose presence they suspected.
children.prevalue: But Herbert from the height of his observatory could examine all the yet unknown portion of the island which might have given shelter to the strangers whose presence they suspected

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The lad looked attentively. There was nothing in sight on the sea, not a sail, neither on the horizon nor near the island. However, as the bank of trees hid the shore, it was possible that a vessel, especially if deprived of her masts, might lie close to the land and thus be invisible to Herbert.
children.prevalue: The lad looked attentively There was nothing in sight on the sea not a sail neither on the horizon nor near the island However as the bank of trees hid the shore it was possible that a vessel especially if deprived of her masts might lie close to the land and thus be invisible to Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Neither in the forests of the Far West was anything to be seen. The wood formed an impenetrable screen, measuring several square miles, without a break or an opening. It was impossible even to follow the course of the Mercy, or to ascertain in what part of the mountain it took its source. Perhaps other creeks also ran towards the west, but they could not be seen.
children.prevalue: Neither in the forests of the Far West was anything to be seen The wood formed an impenetrable screen measuring several square miles without a break or an opening It was impossible even to follow the course of the Mercy or to ascertain in what part of the mountain it took its source Perhaps other creeks also ran towards the west but they could not be seen

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: But at last, if all indication of an encampment escaped Herbert's sight could he not even catch a glimpse of smoke, the faintest trace of which would be easily discernible in the pure atmosphere?
children.prevalue: But at last if all indication of an encampment escaped Herbert s sight could he not even catch a glimpse of smoke the faintest trace of which would be easily discernible in the pure atmosphere

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: For an instant Herbert thought he could perceive a slight smoke in the west, but a more attentive examination showed that he was mistaken. He strained his eyes in every direction, and his sight was excellent. No, decidedly there was nothing there.
children.prevalue: For an instant Herbert thought he could perceive a slight smoke in the west but a more attentive examination showed that he was mistaken He strained his eyes in every direction and his sight was excellent No decidedly there was nothing there

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Herbert descended to the foot of the kauri, and the two sportsmen returned to Granite House. There Cyrus Harding listened to the lad's account, shook his head and said nothing. It was very evident that no decided opinion could be pronounced on this question until after a complete exploration of the island.
children.prevalue: Herbert descended to the foot of the kauri and the two sportsmen returned to Granite House There Cyrus Harding listened to the lad s account shook his head and said nothing It was very evident that no decided opinion could be pronounced on this question until after a complete exploration of the island

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Two days after--the 28th of October--another incident occurred, for which an explanation was again required.
children.prevalue: Two days after the 28th of October another incident occurred for which an explanation was again required

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: While strolling along the shore about two miles from Granite House, Herbert and Neb were fortunate enough to capture a magnificent specimen of the order of chelonia. It was a turtle of the species Midas, the edible green turtle, so called from the color both of its shell and fat.
children.prevalue: While strolling along the shore about two miles from Granite House Herbert and Neb were fortunate enough to capture a magnificent specimen of the order of chelonia It was a turtle of the species Midas the edible green turtle so called from the color both of its shell and fat

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Herbert caught sight of this turtle as it was crawling among the rocks to reach the sea.
children.prevalue: Herbert caught sight of this turtle as it was crawling among the rocks to reach the sea

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Help, Neb, help! he cried.
children.prevalue: Help Neb help he cried

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Neb ran up.
children.prevalue: Neb ran up

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: What a fine animal! said Neb; but how are we to catch it?
children.prevalue: What a fine animal said Neb but how are we to catch it

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Nothing is easier, Neb, replied Herbert. We have only to turn the turtle on its back, and it cannot possibly get away. Take your spear and do as I do.
children.prevalue: Nothing is easier Neb replied Herbert We have only to turn the turtle on its back and it cannot possibly get away Take your spear and do as I do

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The reptile, aware of danger, had retired between its carapace and plastron. They no longer saw its head or feet, and it was motionless as a rock.
children.prevalue: The reptile aware of danger had retired between its carapace and plastron They no longer saw its head or feet and it was motionless as a rock

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Herbert and Neb then drove their sticks underneath the animal, and by their united efforts managed without difficulty to turn it on its back. The turtle, which was three feet in length, would have weighed at least four hundred pounds.
children.prevalue: Herbert and Neb then drove their sticks underneath the animal and by their united efforts managed without difficulty to turn it on its back The turtle which was three feet in length would have weighed at least four hundred pounds

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Capital! cried Neb; this is something which will rejoice friend Pencroft's heart.
children.prevalue: Capital cried Neb this is something which will rejoice friend Pencroft s heart

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: In fact, the heart of friend Pencroft could not fail to be rejoiced, for the flesh of the turtle, which feeds on wrack-grass, is extremely savory. At this moment the creature's head could be seen, which was small, flat, but widened behind by the large temporal fossae hidden under the long roof.
children.prevalue: In fact the heart of friend Pencroft could not fail to be rejoiced for the flesh of the turtle which feeds on wrack grass is extremely savory At this moment the creature s head could be seen which was small flat but widened behind by the large temporal fossae hidden under the long roof

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And now, what shall we do with our prize? said Neb. We can't drag it to Granite House!
children.prevalue: And now what shall we do with our prize said Neb We can t drag it to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Leave it here, since it cannot turn over, replied Herbert, and we will come back with the cart to fetch it.
children.prevalue: Leave it here since it cannot turn over replied Herbert and we will come back with the cart to fetch it

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: That is the best plan.
children.prevalue: That is the best plan

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: However, for greater precaution, Herbert took the trouble, which Neb deemed superfluous, to wedge up the animal with great stones; after which the two hunters returned to Granite House, following the beach, which the tide had left uncovered. Herbert, wishing to surprise Pencroft, said nothing about the superb specimen of a chelonian which they had turned over on the sand; but, two hours later, he and Neb returned with the cart to the place where they had left it. The superb specimen of a chelonian was no longer there!
children.prevalue: However for greater precaution Herbert took the trouble which Neb deemed superfluous to wedge up the animal with great stones after which the two hunters returned to Granite House following the beach which the tide had left uncovered Herbert wishing to surprise Pencroft said nothing about the superb specimen of a chelonian which they had turned over on the sand but two hours later he and Neb returned with the cart to the place where they had left it The superb specimen of a chelonian was no longer there

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Neb and Herbert stared at each other first; then they stared about them. It was just at this spot that the turtle had been left. The lad even found the stones which he had used, and therefore he was certain of not being mistaken.
children.prevalue: Neb and Herbert stared at each other first then they stared about them It was just at this spot that the turtle had been left The lad even found the stones which he had used and therefore he was certain of not being mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Well! said Neb, these beasts can turn themselves over, then?''
children.prevalue: Well said Neb these beasts can turn themselves over then

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: It appears so, replied Herbert, who could not understand it at all, and was gazing at the stones scattered on the sand.
children.prevalue: It appears so replied Herbert who could not understand it at all and was gazing at the stones scattered on the sand

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Well, Pencroft will be disgusted!
children.prevalue: Well Pencroft will be disgusted

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: And Captain Harding will perhaps be very perplexed how to explain this disappearance, thought Herbert.
children.prevalue: And Captain Harding will perhaps be very perplexed how to explain this disappearance thought Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Look here, said Neb, who wished to hide his ill-luck, we won't speak about it.
children.prevalue: Look here said Neb who wished to hide his ill luck we won t speak about it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: On the contrary, Neb, we must speak about it, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: On the contrary Neb we must speak about it replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: And the two, taking the cart, which there was now no use for, returned to Granite House.
children.prevalue: And the two taking the cart which there was now no use for returned to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Arrived at the dockyard, where the engineer and the sailor were working together, Herbert recounted what had happened.
children.prevalue: Arrived at the dockyard where the engineer and the sailor were working together Herbert recounted what had happened

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh! the stupids! cried the sailor, to have let at least fifty meals escape!
children.prevalue: Oh the stupids cried the sailor to have let at least fifty meals escape

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: But, Pencroft, replied Neb, it wasn't our fault that the beast got away; as I tell you, we had turned it over on its back!
children.prevalue: But Pencroft replied Neb it wasn t our fault that the beast got away as I tell you we had turned it over on its back

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Then you didn't turn it over enough! returned the obstinate sailor.
children.prevalue: Then you didn t turn it over enough returned the obstinate sailor

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Not enough! cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: Not enough cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And he told how he had taken care to wedge up the turtle with stones.
children.prevalue: And he told how he had taken care to wedge up the turtle with stones

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: It is a miracle, then! replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It is a miracle then replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I thought, captain, said Herbert, that turtles, once placed on their backs, could not regain their feet, especially when they are of a large size?'
children.prevalue: I thought captain said Herbert that turtles once placed on their backs could not regain their feet especially when they are of a large size

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: That is true, my boy, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: That is true my boy replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Then how did it manage?
children.prevalue: Then how did it manage

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: At what distance from the sea did you leave this turtle? asked the engineer, who, having suspended his work, was reflecting on this incident.
children.prevalue: At what distance from the sea did you leave this turtle asked the engineer who having suspended his work was reflecting on this incident

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Fifteen feet at the most, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: Fifteen feet at the most replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: And the tide was low at the time?
children.prevalue: And the tide was low at the time

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Yes, captain.
children.prevalue: Yes captain

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Well, replied the engineer, what the turtle could not do on the sand it might have been able to do in the water. It turned over when the tide overtook it, and then quietly returned to the deep sea.
children.prevalue: Well replied the engineer what the turtle could not do on the sand it might have been able to do in the water It turned over when the tide overtook it and then quietly returned to the deep sea

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Oh! what stupids we were! cried Neb.
children.prevalue: Oh what stupids we were cried Neb

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: That is precisely what I had the honor of telling you before! returned the sailor.
children.prevalue: That is precisely what I had the honor of telling you before returned the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Cyrus Harding had given this explanation, which, no doubt, was admissible. But was he himself convinced of the accuracy of this explanation? It cannot be said that he was.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding had given this explanation which no doubt was admissible But was he himself convinced of the accuracy of this explanation It cannot be said that he was

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On the 9th of October the bark canoe was entirely finished. Pencroft had kept his promise, and a light boat, the shell of which was joined together by the flexible twigs of the crejimba, had been constructed in five days. A seat in the stern, a second seat in the middle to preserve the equilibrium, a third seat in the bows, rowlocks for the two oars, a scull to steer with, completed the little craft, which was twelve feet long, and did not weigh more than two hundred pounds. The operation of launching it was extremely simple. The canoe was carried to the beach and laid on the sand before Granite House, and the rising tide floated it. Pencroft, who leaped in directly, maneuvered it with the scull and declared it to be just the thing for the purpose to which they wished to put it.
children.prevalue: On the 9th of October the bark canoe was entirely finished Pencroft had kept his promise and a light boat the shell of which was joined together by the flexible twigs of the crejimba had been constructed in five days A seat in the stern a second seat in the middle to preserve the equilibrium a third seat in the bows rowlocks for the two oars a scull to steer with completed the little craft which was twelve feet long and did not weigh more than two hundred pounds The operation of launching it was extremely simple The canoe was carried to the beach and laid on the sand before Granite House and the rising tide floated it Pencroft who leaped in directly maneuvered it with the scull and declared it to be just the thing for the purpose to which they wished to put it

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Hurrah! cried the sailor, who did not disdain to celebrate thus his own triumph. With this we could go round--
children.prevalue: Hurrah cried the sailor who did not disdain to celebrate thus his own triumph With this we could go round

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The world? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: The world asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: No, the island. Some stones for ballast, a mast and a sail, which the captain will make for us some day, and we shall go splendidly! Well, captain--and you, Mr. Spilett; and you, Herbert; and you, Neb--aren't you coming to try our new vessel? Come along! we must see if it will carry all five of us!
children.prevalue: No the island Some stones for ballast a mast and a sail which the captain will make for us some day and we shall go splendidly Well captain and you Mr Spilett and you Herbert and you Neb aren t you coming to try our new vessel Come along we must see if it will carry all five of us

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This was certainly a trial which ought to be made. Pencroft soon brought the canoe to the shore by a narrow passage among the rocks, and it was agreed that they should make a trial of the boat that day by following the shore as far as the first point at which the rocks of the south ended.
children.prevalue: This was certainly a trial which ought to be made Pencroft soon brought the canoe to the shore by a narrow passage among the rocks and it was agreed that they should make a trial of the boat that day by following the shore as far as the first point at which the rocks of the south ended

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: As they embarked, Neb cried,--
children.prevalue: As they embarked Neb cried

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But your boat leaks rather, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: But your boat leaks rather Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: That's nothing, Neb, replied the sailor; the wood will get seasoned. In two days there won't be a single leak, and our boat will have no more water in her than there is in the stomach of a drunkard. Jump in!
children.prevalue: That s nothing Neb replied the sailor the wood will get seasoned In two days there won t be a single leak and our boat will have no more water in her than there is in the stomach of a drunkard Jump in

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: They were soon all seated, and Pencroft shoved off. The weather was magnificent, the sea as calm as if its waters were contained within the narrow limits of a lake. Thus the boat could proceed with as much security as if it was ascending the tranquil current of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: They were soon all seated and Pencroft shoved off The weather was magnificent the sea as calm as if its waters were contained within the narrow limits of a lake Thus the boat could proceed with as much security as if it was ascending the tranquil current of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Neb took one of the oars, Herbert the other, and Pencroft remained in the stern in order to use the scull.
children.prevalue: Neb took one of the oars Herbert the other and Pencroft remained in the stern in order to use the scull

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The sailor first crossed the channel, and steered close to the southern point of the islet. A light breeze blew from the south. No roughness was found either in the channel or the green sea. A long swell, which the canoe scarcely felt, as it was heavily laden, rolled regularly over the surface of the water. They pulled out about half a mile distant from the shore, that they might have a good view of Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: The sailor first crossed the channel and steered close to the southern point of the islet A light breeze blew from the south No roughness was found either in the channel or the green sea A long swell which the canoe scarcely felt as it was heavily laden rolled regularly over the surface of the water They pulled out about half a mile distant from the shore that they might have a good view of Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Pencroft afterwards returned towards the mouth of the river. The boat then skirted the shore, which, extending to the extreme point, hid all Tadorn's Fens.
children.prevalue: Pencroft afterwards returned towards the mouth of the river The boat then skirted the shore which extending to the extreme point hid all Tadorn s Fens

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: This point, of which the distance was increased by the irregularity of the coast, was nearly three miles from the Mercy. The settlers resolved to go to its extremity, and only go beyond it as much as was necessary to take a rapid survey of the coast as far as Claw Cape.
children.prevalue: This point of which the distance was increased by the irregularity of the coast was nearly three miles from the Mercy The settlers resolved to go to its extremity and only go beyond it as much as was necessary to take a rapid survey of the coast as far as Claw Cape

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The canoe followed the windings of the shore, avoiding the rocks which fringed it, and which the rising tide began to cover. The cliff gradually sloped away from the mouth of the river to the point. This was formed of granite rocks, capriciously distributed, very different from the cliff at Prospect Heights, and of an extremely wild aspect. It might have been said that an immense cartload of rocks had been emptied out there. There was no vegetation on this sharp promontory, which projected two miles from the forest, and it thus represented a giant's arm stretched out from a leafy sleeve.
children.prevalue: The canoe followed the windings of the shore avoiding the rocks which fringed it and which the rising tide began to cover The cliff gradually sloped away from the mouth of the river to the point This was formed of granite rocks capriciously distributed very different from the cliff at Prospect Heights and of an extremely wild aspect It might have been said that an immense cartload of rocks had been emptied out there There was no vegetation on this sharp promontory which projected two miles from the forest and it thus represented a giant s arm stretched out from a leafy sleeve

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The canoe, impelled by the two oars, advanced without difficulty. Gideon Spilett, pencil in one hand and notebook in the other, sketched the coast in bold strokes. Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft chatted, while examining this part of their domain, which was new to them, and, in proportion as the canoe proceeded towards the south, the two Mandible Capes appeared to move, and surround Union Bay more closely.
children.prevalue: The canoe impelled by the two oars advanced without difficulty Gideon Spilett pencil in one hand and notebook in the other sketched the coast in bold strokes Neb Herbert and Pencroft chatted while examining this part of their domain which was new to them and in proportion as the canoe proceeded towards the south the two Mandible Capes appeared to move and surround Union Bay more closely

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: As to Cyrus Harding, he did not speak; he simply gazed, and by the mistrust which his look expressed, it appeared that he was examining some strange country.
children.prevalue: As to Cyrus Harding he did not speak he simply gazed and by the mistrust which his look expressed it appeared that he was examining some strange country

children.name: Paragraph_17
