children.value: In the meantime, after a voyage of three-quarters of an hour, the canoe reached the extremity of the point, and Pencroft was preparing to return, when Herbert, rising, pointed to a black object, saying,--
children.prevalue: In the meantime after a voyage of three quarters of an hour the canoe reached the extremity of the point and Pencroft was preparing to return when Herbert rising pointed to a black object saying

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: What do I see down there on the beach?
children.prevalue: What do I see down there on the beach

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: All eyes turned towards the point indicated.
children.prevalue: All eyes turned towards the point indicated

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Why, said the reporter, there is something. It looks like part of a wreck half buried in the sand.
children.prevalue: Why said the reporter there is something It looks like part of a wreck half buried in the sand

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Ah! cried Pencroft, I see what it is!
children.prevalue: Ah cried Pencroft I see what it is

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What? asked Neb.
children.prevalue: What asked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Barrels, barrels, which perhaps are full, replied the sailor.
children.prevalue: Barrels barrels which perhaps are full replied the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Pull to the shore, Pencroft! said Cyrus.
children.prevalue: Pull to the shore Pencroft said Cyrus

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: A few strokes of the oar brought the canoe into a little creek, and its passengers leaped on shore.
children.prevalue: A few strokes of the oar brought the canoe into a little creek and its passengers leaped on shore

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Pencroft was not mistaken. Two barrels were there, half buried in the sand, but still firmly attached to a large chest, which, sustained by them, had floated to the moment when it stranded on the beach.
children.prevalue: Pencroft was not mistaken Two barrels were there half buried in the sand but still firmly attached to a large chest which sustained by them had floated to the moment when it stranded on the beach

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: There has been a wreck, then, in some part of the island, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: There has been a wreck then in some part of the island said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Evidently, replied Spilett.
children.prevalue: Evidently replied Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But what's in this chest? cried Pencroft, with very natural impatience. What's in this chest? It is shut up, and nothing to open it with! Well, perhaps a stone--
children.prevalue: But what s in this chest cried Pencroft with very natural impatience What s in this chest It is shut up and nothing to open it with Well perhaps a stone

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And the sailor, raising a heavy block, was about to break in one of the sides of the chest, when the engineer arrested his hand.
children.prevalue: And the sailor raising a heavy block was about to break in one of the sides of the chest when the engineer arrested his hand

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Pencroft, said he, can you restrain your impatience for one hour only?
children.prevalue: Pencroft said he can you restrain your impatience for one hour only

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But, captain, just think! Perhaps there is everything we want in there!
children.prevalue: But captain just think Perhaps there is everything we want in there

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: We shall find that out, Pencroft, replied the engineer; but trust to me, and do not break the chest, which may be useful to us. We must convey it to Granite House, where we can open it easily, and without breaking it. It is quite prepared for a voyage; and since it has floated here, it may just as well float to the mouth of the river.
children.prevalue: We shall find that out Pencroft replied the engineer but trust to me and do not break the chest which may be useful to us We must convey it to Granite House where we can open it easily and without breaking it It is quite prepared for a voyage and since it has floated here it may just as well float to the mouth of the river

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You are right, captain, and I was wrong, as usual, replied the sailor.
children.prevalue: You are right captain and I was wrong as usual replied the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The engineer's advice was good. In fact, the canoe probably would not have been able to contain the articles possibly enclosed in the chest, which doubtless was heavy, since two empty barrels were required to buoy it up. It was, therefore, much better to tow it to the beach at Granite House.
children.prevalue: The engineer s advice was good In fact the canoe probably would not have been able to contain the articles possibly enclosed in the chest which doubtless was heavy since two empty barrels were required to buoy it up It was therefore much better to tow it to the beach at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And now, whence had this chest come? That was the important question. Cyrus Harding and his companions looked attentively around them, and examined the shore for several hundred steps. No other articles or pieces of wreck could be found. Herbert and Neb climbed a high rock to survey the sea, but there was nothing in sight--neither a dismasted vessel nor a ship under sail.
children.prevalue: And now whence had this chest come That was the important question Cyrus Harding and his companions looked attentively around them and examined the shore for several hundred steps No other articles or pieces of wreck could be found Herbert and Neb climbed a high rock to survey the sea but there was nothing in sight neither a dismasted vessel nor a ship under sail

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: However, there was no doubt that there had been a wreck. Perhaps this incident was connected with that of the bullet? Perhaps strangers had landed on another part of the island? Perhaps they were still there? But the thought which came naturally to the settlers was, that these strangers could not be Malay pirates, for the chest was evidently of American or European make.
children.prevalue: However there was no doubt that there had been a wreck Perhaps this incident was connected with that of the bullet Perhaps strangers had landed on another part of the island Perhaps they were still there But the thought which came naturally to the settlers was that these strangers could not be Malay pirates for the chest was evidently of American or European make

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: All the party returned to the chest, which was of an unusually large size. It was made of oak wood, very carefully closed and covered with a thick hide, which was secured by copper nails. The two great barrels, hermetically sealed, but which sounded hollow and empty, were fastened to its sides by strong ropes, knotted with a skill which Pencroft directly pronounced sailors alone could exhibit. It appeared to be in a perfect state of preservation, which was explained by the fact that it had stranded on a sandy beach, and not among rocks. They had no doubt whatever, on examining it carefully, that it had not been long in the water, and that its arrival on this coast was recent. The water did not appear to have penetrated to the inside, and the articles which it contained were no doubt uninjured.
children.prevalue: All the party returned to the chest which was of an unusually large size It was made of oak wood very carefully closed and covered with a thick hide which was secured by copper nails The two great barrels hermetically sealed but which sounded hollow and empty were fastened to its sides by strong ropes knotted with a skill which Pencroft directly pronounced sailors alone could exhibit It appeared to be in a perfect state of preservation which was explained by the fact that it had stranded on a sandy beach and not among rocks They had no doubt whatever on examining it carefully that it had not been long in the water and that its arrival on this coast was recent The water did not appear to have penetrated to the inside and the articles which it contained were no doubt uninjured

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: It was evident that this chest had been thrown overboard from some dismasted vessel driven towards the island, and that, in the hope that it would reach the land, where they might afterwards find it, the passengers had taken the precaution to buoy it up by means of this floating apparatus.
children.prevalue: It was evident that this chest had been thrown overboard from some dismasted vessel driven towards the island and that in the hope that it would reach the land where they might afterwards find it the passengers had taken the precaution to buoy it up by means of this floating apparatus

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: We will tow this chest to Granite House, said the engineer, where we can make an inventory of its contents; then, if we discover any of the survivors from the supposed wreck, we can return it to those to whom it belongs. If we find no one--
children.prevalue: We will tow this chest to Granite House said the engineer where we can make an inventory of its contents then if we discover any of the survivors from the supposed wreck we can return it to those to whom it belongs If we find no one

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: We will keep it for ourselves! cried Pencroft. But what in the world can there be in it?
children.prevalue: We will keep it for ourselves cried Pencroft But what in the world can there be in it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The sea was already approaching the chest, and the high tide would evidently float it. One of the ropes which fastened the barrels was partly unlashed and used as a cable to unite the floating apparatus with the canoe. Pencroft and Neb then dug away the sand with their oars, so as to facilitate the moving of the chest, towing which the boat soon began to double the point, to which the name of Flotsam Point was given.
children.prevalue: The sea was already approaching the chest and the high tide would evidently float it One of the ropes which fastened the barrels was partly unlashed and used as a cable to unite the floating apparatus with the canoe Pencroft and Neb then dug away the sand with their oars so as to facilitate the moving of the chest towing which the boat soon began to double the point to which the name of Flotsam Point was given

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The chest was heavy, and the barrels were scarcely sufficient to keep it above water. The sailor also feared every instant that it would get loose and sink to the bottom of the sea. But happily his fears were not realized, and an hour and a half after they set out--all that time had been taken up in going a distance of three miles--the boat touched the beach below Granite House.
children.prevalue: The chest was heavy and the barrels were scarcely sufficient to keep it above water The sailor also feared every instant that it would get loose and sink to the bottom of the sea But happily his fears were not realized and an hour and a half after they set out all that time had been taken up in going a distance of three miles the boat touched the beach below Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Canoe and chest were then hauled up on the sands; and as the tide was then going out, they were soon left high and dry. Neb, hurrying home, brought back some tools with which to open the chest in such a way that it might be injured as little as possible, and they proceeded to its inventory. Pencroft did not try to hide that he was greatly excited.
children.prevalue: Canoe and chest were then hauled up on the sands and as the tide was then going out they were soon left high and dry Neb hurrying home brought back some tools with which to open the chest in such a way that it might be injured as little as possible and they proceeded to its inventory Pencroft did not try to hide that he was greatly excited

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The sailor began by detaching the two barrels, which, being in good condition, would of course be of use. Then the locks were forced with a cold chisel and hammer, and the lid thrown back. A second casing of zinc lined the interior of the chest, which had been evidently arranged that the articles which it enclosed might under any circumstances be sheltered from damp.
children.prevalue: The sailor began by detaching the two barrels which being in good condition would of course be of use Then the locks were forced with a cold chisel and hammer and the lid thrown back A second casing of zinc lined the interior of the chest which had been evidently arranged that the articles which it enclosed might under any circumstances be sheltered from damp

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Oh! cried Neb, suppose it's jam!
children.prevalue: Oh cried Neb suppose it s jam

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I hope not, replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: I hope not replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: If only there was-- said the sailor in a low voice.
children.prevalue: If only there was said the sailor in a low voice

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: What? asked Neb, who overheard him.
children.prevalue: What asked Neb who overheard him

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Nothing!
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The covering of zinc was torn off and thrown back over the sides of the chest, and by degrees numerous articles of very varied character were produced and strewn about on the sand. At each new object Pencroft uttered fresh hurrahs, Herbert clapped his hands, and Neb danced up and down. There were books which made Herbert wild with joy, and cooking utensils which Neb covered with kisses!
children.prevalue: The covering of zinc was torn off and thrown back over the sides of the chest and by degrees numerous articles of very varied character were produced and strewn about on the sand At each new object Pencroft uttered fresh hurrahs Herbert clapped his hands and Neb danced up and down There were books which made Herbert wild with joy and cooking utensils which Neb covered with kisses

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: In short, the colonists had reason to be extremely satisfied, for this chest contained tools, weapons, instruments, clothes, books; and this is the exact list of them as stated in Gideon Spilett's note-book: --Tools:--3 knives with several blades, 2 woodmen's axes, 2 carpenter's hatchets, 3 planes, 2 adzes, 1 twibil or mattock, 6 chisels, 2 files, 3 hammers, 3 gimlets, 2 augers, 10 bags of nails and screws, 3 saws of different sizes, 2 boxes of needles.
children.prevalue: In short the colonists had reason to be extremely satisfied for this chest contained tools weapons instruments clothes books and this is the exact list of them as stated in Gideon Spilett s note book Tools 3 knives with several blades 2 woodmen s axes 2 carpenter s hatchets 3 planes 2 adzes 1 twibil or mattock 6 chisels 2 files 3 hammers 3 gimlets 2 augers 10 bags of nails and screws 3 saws of different sizes 2 boxes of needles

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Weapons:--2 flint-lock guns, 2 for percussion caps, 2 breach-loader carbines, 5 boarding cutlasses, 4 sabers, 2 barrels of powder, each containing twenty-five pounds; 12 boxes of percussion caps.
children.prevalue: Weapons 2 flint lock guns 2 for percussion caps 2 breach loader carbines 5 boarding cutlasses 4 sabers 2 barrels of powder each containing twenty five pounds 12 boxes of percussion caps

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Instruments:--1 sextant, 1 double opera-glass, 1 telescope, 1 box of mathematical instruments, 1 mariner's compass, 1 Fahrenheit thermometer, 1 aneroid barometer, 1 box containing a photographic apparatus, object-glass, plates, chemicals, etc.
children.prevalue: Instruments 1 sextant 1 double opera glass 1 telescope 1 box of mathematical instruments 1 mariner s compass 1 Fahrenheit thermometer 1 aneroid barometer 1 box containing a photographic apparatus object glass plates chemicals etc

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Clothes:--2 dozen shirts of a peculiar material resembling wool, but evidently of a vegetable origin; 3 dozen stockings of the same material.
children.prevalue: Clothes 2 dozen shirts of a peculiar material resembling wool but evidently of a vegetable origin 3 dozen stockings of the same material

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Utensils:--1 iron pot, 6 copper saucepans, 3 iron dishes, 10 metal plates, 2 kettles, 1 portable stove, 6 table-knives.
children.prevalue: Utensils 1 iron pot 6 copper saucepans 3 iron dishes 10 metal plates 2 kettles 1 portable stove 6 table knives

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Books:--1 Bible, 1 atlas, 1 dictionary of the different Polynesian idioms, 1 dictionary of natural science, in six volumes; 3 reams of white paper, 2 books with blank pages.
children.prevalue: Books 1 Bible 1 atlas 1 dictionary of the different Polynesian idioms 1 dictionary of natural science in six volumes 3 reams of white paper 2 books with blank pages

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: It must be allowed, said the reporter, after the inventory had been made, that the owner of this chest was a practical man! Tools, weapons, instruments, clothes, utensils, books--nothing is wanting! It might really be said that he expected to be wrecked, and had prepared for it beforehand.
children.prevalue: It must be allowed said the reporter after the inventory had been made that the owner of this chest was a practical man Tools weapons instruments clothes utensils books nothing is wanting It might really be said that he expected to be wrecked and had prepared for it beforehand

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Nothing is wanting, indeed, murmured Cyrus Harding thoughtfully.
children.prevalue: Nothing is wanting indeed murmured Cyrus Harding thoughtfully

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And for a certainty, added Herbert, the vessel which carried this chest and its owner was not a Malay pirate!
children.prevalue: And for a certainty added Herbert the vessel which carried this chest and its owner was not a Malay pirate

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Unless, said Pencroft, the owner had been taken prisoner by pirates--
children.prevalue: Unless said Pencroft the owner had been taken prisoner by pirates

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: That is not admissible, replied the reporter. It is more probable that an American or European vessel has been driven into this quarter, and that her passengers, wishing to save necessaries at least, prepared this chest and threw it overboard.
children.prevalue: That is not admissible replied the reporter It is more probable that an American or European vessel has been driven into this quarter and that her passengers wishing to save necessaries at least prepared this chest and threw it overboard

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Is that your opinion, captain? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: Is that your opinion captain asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Yes, my boy, replied the engineer, that may have been the case. It is possible that at the moment, or in expectation of a wreck, they collected into this chest different articles of the greatest use in hopes of finding it again on the coast--
children.prevalue: Yes my boy replied the engineer that may have been the case It is possible that at the moment or in expectation of a wreck they collected into this chest different articles of the greatest use in hopes of finding it again on the coast

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Even the photographic box! exclaimed the sailor incredulously.
children.prevalue: Even the photographic box exclaimed the sailor incredulously

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: As to that apparatus, replied Harding, I do not quite see the use of it; and a more complete supply of clothes or more abundant ammunition would have been more valuable to us as well as to any other castaways!
children.prevalue: As to that apparatus replied Harding I do not quite see the use of it and a more complete supply of clothes or more abundant ammunition would have been more valuable to us as well as to any other castaways

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: But isn't there any mark or direction on these instruments, tools, or books, which would tell us something about them? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: But isn t there any mark or direction on these instruments tools or books which would tell us something about them asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: That might be ascertained. Each article was carefully examined, especially the books, instruments and weapons. Neither the weapons nor the instruments, contrary to the usual custom, bore the name of the maker; they were, besides, in a perfect state, and did not appear to have been used. The same peculiarity marked the tools and utensils; all were new, which proved that the articles had not been taken by chance and thrown into the chest, but, on the contrary, that the choice of things had been well considered and arranged with care. This was also indicated by the second case of metal which had preserved them from damp, and which could not have been soldered in a moment of haste.
children.prevalue: That might be ascertained Each article was carefully examined especially the books instruments and weapons Neither the weapons nor the instruments contrary to the usual custom bore the name of the maker they were besides in a perfect state and did not appear to have been used The same peculiarity marked the tools and utensils all were new which proved that the articles had not been taken by chance and thrown into the chest but on the contrary that the choice of things had been well considered and arranged with care This was also indicated by the second case of metal which had preserved them from damp and which could not have been soldered in a moment of haste

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: As to the dictionaries of natural science and Polynesian idioms, both were English; but they neither bore the name of the publisher nor the date of publication.
children.prevalue: As to the dictionaries of natural science and Polynesian idioms both were English but they neither bore the name of the publisher nor the date of publication

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The same with the Bible printed in English, in quarto, remarkable from a typographic point of view, and which appeared to have been often used.
children.prevalue: The same with the Bible printed in English in quarto remarkable from a typographic point of view and which appeared to have been often used

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The atlas was a magnificent work, comprising maps of every country in the world, and several planispheres arranged upon Mercator's projection, and of which the nomenclature was in French--but which also bore neither date nor name of publisher.
children.prevalue: The atlas was a magnificent work comprising maps of every country in the world and several planispheres arranged upon Mercator s projection and of which the nomenclature was in French but which also bore neither date nor name of publisher

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: There was nothing, therefore, on these different articles by which they could be traced, and nothing consequently of a nature to show the nationality of the vessel which must have recently passed these shores.
children.prevalue: There was nothing therefore on these different articles by which they could be traced and nothing consequently of a nature to show the nationality of the vessel which must have recently passed these shores

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: But, wherever the chest might have come from, it was a treasure to the settlers on Lincoln Island. Till then, by making use of the productions of nature, they had created everything for themselves, and, thanks to their intelligence, they had managed without difficulty. But did it not appear as if Providence had wished to reward them by sending them these productions of human industry? Their thanks rose unanimously to Heaven.
children.prevalue: But wherever the chest might have come from it was a treasure to the settlers on Lincoln Island Till then by making use of the productions of nature they had created everything for themselves and thanks to their intelligence they had managed without difficulty But did it not appear as if Providence had wished to reward them by sending them these productions of human industry Their thanks rose unanimously to Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: However, one of them was not quite satisfied: it was Pencroft. It appeared that the chest did not contain something which he evidently held in great esteem, for in proportion as they approached the bottom of the box, his hurrahs diminished in heartiness, and, the inventory finished, he was heard to mutter these words:--That's all very fine, but you can see that there is nothing for me in that box!
children.prevalue: However one of them was not quite satisfied it was Pencroft It appeared that the chest did not contain something which he evidently held in great esteem for in proportion as they approached the bottom of the box his hurrahs diminished in heartiness and the inventory finished he was heard to mutter these words That s all very fine but you can see that there is nothing for me in that box

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: This led Neb to say,--
children.prevalue: This led Neb to say

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Why, friend Pencroft, what more do you expect?
children.prevalue: Why friend Pencroft what more do you expect

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Half a pound of tobacco, replied Pencroft seriously, and nothing would have been wanting to complete my happiness!
children.prevalue: Half a pound of tobacco replied Pencroft seriously and nothing would have been wanting to complete my happiness

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: No one could help laughing at this speech of the sailor's.
children.prevalue: No one could help laughing at this speech of the sailor s

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: But the result of this discovery of the chest was, that it was now more than ever necessary to explore the island thoroughly. It was therefore agreed that the next morning at break of day, they should set out, by ascending the Mercy so as to reach the western shore. If any castaways had landed on the coast, it was to be feared they were without resources, and it was therefore the more necessary to carry help to them without delay.
children.prevalue: But the result of this discovery of the chest was that it was now more than ever necessary to explore the island thoroughly It was therefore agreed that the next morning at break of day they should set out by ascending the Mercy so as to reach the western shore If any castaways had landed on the coast it was to be feared they were without resources and it was therefore the more necessary to carry help to them without delay

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: During the day the different articles were carried to Granite House, where they were methodically arranged in the great hall. This day--the 29th of October--happened to be a Sunday, and, before going to bed, Herbert asked the engineer if he would not read them something from the Gospel.
children.prevalue: During the day the different articles were carried to Granite House where they were methodically arranged in the great hall This day the 29th of October happened to be a Sunday and before going to bed Herbert asked the engineer if he would not read them something from the Gospel

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Willingly, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Willingly replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: He took the sacred volume, and was about to open it, when Pencroft stopped him, saying,--Captain, I am superstitious. Open at random and read the first verse which, your eye falls upon. We will see if it applies to our situation.
children.prevalue: He took the sacred volume and was about to open it when Pencroft stopped him saying Captain I am superstitious Open at random and read the first verse which your eye falls upon We will see if it applies to our situation

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Cyrus Harding smiled at the sailor's idea, and, yielding to his wish, he opened exactly at a place where the leaves were separated by a marker.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding smiled at the sailor s idea and yielding to his wish he opened exactly at a place where the leaves were separated by a marker

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Immediately his eyes were attracted by a cross which, made with a pencil, was placed against the eighth verse of the seventh chapter of the Gospel of St. Matthew. He read the verse, which was this:--
children.prevalue: Immediately his eyes were attracted by a cross which made with a pencil was placed against the eighth verse of the seventh chapter of the Gospel of St Matthew He read the verse which was this

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth.
children.prevalue: For every one that asketh receiveth and he that seeketh findeth

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next day, the 30th of October, all was ready for the proposed exploring expedition, which recent events had rendered so necessary. In fact, things had so come about that the settlers in Lincoln Island no longer needed help for themselves, but were even able to carry it to others.
children.prevalue: The next day the 30th of October all was ready for the proposed exploring expedition which recent events had rendered so necessary In fact things had so come about that the settlers in Lincoln Island no longer needed help for themselves but were even able to carry it to others

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was therefore agreed that they should ascend the Mercy as far as the river was navigable. A great part of the distance would thus be traversed without fatigue, and the explorers could transport their provisions and arms to an advanced point in the west of the island.
children.prevalue: It was therefore agreed that they should ascend the Mercy as far as the river was navigable A great part of the distance would thus be traversed without fatigue and the explorers could transport their provisions and arms to an advanced point in the west of the island

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It was necessary to think not only of the things which they should take with them, but also of those which they might have by chance to bring back to Granite House. If there had been a wreck on the coast, as was supposed, there would be many things cast up, which would be lawfully their prizes. In the event of this, the cart would have been of more use than the light canoe, but it was heavy and clumsy to drag, and therefore more difficult to use; this led Pencroft to express his regret that the chest had not contained, besides his halfpound of tobacco, a pair of strong New Jersey horses, which would have been very useful to the colony!
children.prevalue: It was necessary to think not only of the things which they should take with them but also of those which they might have by chance to bring back to Granite House If there had been a wreck on the coast as was supposed there would be many things cast up which would be lawfully their prizes In the event of this the cart would have been of more use than the light canoe but it was heavy and clumsy to drag and therefore more difficult to use this led Pencroft to express his regret that the chest had not contained besides his halfpound of tobacco a pair of strong New Jersey horses which would have been very useful to the colony

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The provisions, which Neb had already packed up, consisted of a store of meat and of several gallons of beer, that is to say enough to sustain them for three days, the time which Harding assigned for the expedition. They hoped besides to supply themselves on the road, and Neb took care not to forget the portable stove.
children.prevalue: The provisions which Neb had already packed up consisted of a store of meat and of several gallons of beer that is to say enough to sustain them for three days the time which Harding assigned for the expedition They hoped besides to supply themselves on the road and Neb took care not to forget the portable stove

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The only tools the settlers took were the two woodmen's axes, which they could use to cut a path through the thick forests, as also the instruments, the telescope and pocket-compass.
children.prevalue: The only tools the settlers took were the two woodmen s axes which they could use to cut a path through the thick forests as also the instruments the telescope and pocket compass

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: For weapons they selected the two flint-lock guns, which were likely to be more useful to them than the percussion fowling-pieces, the first only requiring flints which could be easily replaced, and the latter needing fulminating caps, a frequent use of which would soon exhaust their limited stock. However, they took also one of the carbines and some cartridges. As to the powder, of which there was about fifty pounds in the barrel, a small supply of it had to be taken, but the engineer hoped to manufacture an explosive substance which would allow them to husband it. To the firearms were added the five cutlasses well sheathed in leather, and, thus supplied, the settlers could venture into the vast forest with some chance of success.
children.prevalue: For weapons they selected the two flint lock guns which were likely to be more useful to them than the percussion fowling pieces the first only requiring flints which could be easily replaced and the latter needing fulminating caps a frequent use of which would soon exhaust their limited stock However they took also one of the carbines and some cartridges As to the powder of which there was about fifty pounds in the barrel a small supply of it had to be taken but the engineer hoped to manufacture an explosive substance which would allow them to husband it To the firearms were added the five cutlasses well sheathed in leather and thus supplied the settlers could venture into the vast forest with some chance of success

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It is useless to add that Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb, thus armed, were at the summit of their happiness, although Cyrus Harding made them promise not to fire a shot unless it was necessary.
children.prevalue: It is useless to add that Pencroft Herbert and Neb thus armed were at the summit of their happiness although Cyrus Harding made them promise not to fire a shot unless it was necessary

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: At six in the morning the canoe put off from the shore; all had embarked, including Top, and they proceeded to the mouth of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: At six in the morning the canoe put off from the shore all had embarked including Top and they proceeded to the mouth of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The tide had begun to come up half an hour before. For several hours, therefore, there would be a current, which it was well to profit by, for later the ebb would make it difficult to ascend the river. The tide was already strong, for in three days the moon would be full, and it was enough to keep the boat in the center of the current, where it floated swiftly along between the high banks without its being necessary to increase its speed by the aid of the oars. In a few minutes the explorers arrived at the angle formed by the Mercy and exactly at the place where, seven months before, Pencroft had made his first raft of wood.
children.prevalue: The tide had begun to come up half an hour before For several hours therefore there would be a current which it was well to profit by for later the ebb would make it difficult to ascend the river The tide was already strong for in three days the moon would be full and it was enough to keep the boat in the center of the current where it floated swiftly along between the high banks without its being necessary to increase its speed by the aid of the oars In a few minutes the explorers arrived at the angle formed by the Mercy and exactly at the place where seven months before Pencroft had made his first raft of wood

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: After this sudden angle the river widened and flowed under the shade of great evergreen firs.
children.prevalue: After this sudden angle the river widened and flowed under the shade of great evergreen firs

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The aspect of the banks was magnificent. Cyrus Harding and his companions could not but admire the lovely effects so easily produced by nature with water and trees. As they advanced the forest element diminished. On the right bank of the river grew magnificent specimens of the ulmaceae tribe, the precious elm, so valuable to builders, and which withstands well the action of water. Then there were numerous groups belonging to the same family, among others one in particular, the fruit of which produces a very useful oil. Further on, Herbert remarked the lardizabala, a twining shrub which, when bruised in water, furnishes excellent cordage; and two or three ebony trees of a beautiful black, crossed with capricious veins.
children.prevalue: The aspect of the banks was magnificent Cyrus Harding and his companions could not but admire the lovely effects so easily produced by nature with water and trees As they advanced the forest element diminished On the right bank of the river grew magnificent specimens of the ulmaceae tribe the precious elm so valuable to builders and which withstands well the action of water Then there were numerous groups belonging to the same family among others one in particular the fruit of which produces a very useful oil Further on Herbert remarked the lardizabala a twining shrub which when bruised in water furnishes excellent cordage and two or three ebony trees of a beautiful black crossed with capricious veins

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: From time to time, in certain places where the landing was easy, the canoe was stopped, when Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft, their guns in their hands, and preceded by Top, jumped on shore. Without expecting game, some useful plant might be met with, and the young naturalist was delighted with discovering a sort of wild spinach, belonging to the order of chenopodiaceae, and numerous specimens of cruciferae, belonging to the cabbage tribe, which it would certainly be possible to cultivate by transplanting. There were cresses, horseradish, turnips, and lastly, little branching hairy stalks, scarcely more than three feet high, which produced brownish grains.
children.prevalue: From time to time in certain places where the landing was easy the canoe was stopped when Gideon Spilett Herbert and Pencroft their guns in their hands and preceded by Top jumped on shore Without expecting game some useful plant might be met with and the young naturalist was delighted with discovering a sort of wild spinach belonging to the order of chenopodiaceae and numerous specimens of cruciferae belonging to the cabbage tribe which it would certainly be possible to cultivate by transplanting There were cresses horseradish turnips and lastly little branching hairy stalks scarcely more than three feet high which produced brownish grains

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Do you know what this plant is? asked Herbert of the sailor.
children.prevalue: Do you know what this plant is asked Herbert of the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Tobacco! cried Pencroft, who evidently had never seen his favorite plant except in the bowl of his pipe.
children.prevalue: Tobacco cried Pencroft who evidently had never seen his favorite plant except in the bowl of his pipe

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: No, Pencroft, replied Herbert; this is not tobacco, it is mustard.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft replied Herbert this is not tobacco it is mustard

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Mustard be hanged! returned the sailor; but if by chance you happen to come across a tobacco-plant, my boy, pray don't scorn that!
children.prevalue: Mustard be hanged returned the sailor but if by chance you happen to come across a tobacco plant my boy pray don t scorn that

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: We shall find it some day! said Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: We shall find it some day said Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well! exclaimed Pencroft, when that day comes, I do not know what more will be wanting in our island!
children.prevalue: Well exclaimed Pencroft when that day comes I do not know what more will be wanting in our island

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: These different plants, which had been carefully rooted up, were carried to the canoe, where Cyrus Harding had remained buried in thought.
children.prevalue: These different plants which had been carefully rooted up were carried to the canoe where Cyrus Harding had remained buried in thought

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft in this manner frequently disembarked, sometimes on the right bank, sometimes on the left bank of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: The reporter Herbert and Pencroft in this manner frequently disembarked sometimes on the right bank sometimes on the left bank of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The latter was less abrupt, but the former more wooded. The engineer ascertained by consulting his pocket-compass that the direction of the river from the first turn was obviously southwest and northeast, and nearly straight for a length of about three miles. But it was to be supposed that this direction changed beyond that point, and that the Mercy continued to the north-west, towards the spurs of Mount Franklin, among which the river rose.
children.prevalue: The latter was less abrupt but the former more wooded The engineer ascertained by consulting his pocket compass that the direction of the river from the first turn was obviously southwest and northeast and nearly straight for a length of about three miles But it was to be supposed that this direction changed beyond that point and that the Mercy continued to the north west towards the spurs of Mount Franklin among which the river rose

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: During one of these excursions, Gideon Spilett managed to get hold of two couples of living gallinaceae. They were birds with long, thin beaks, lengthened necks, short wings, and without any appearance of a tail. Herbert rightly gave them the name of tinamous, and it was resolved that they should be the first tenants of their future poultry-yard.
children.prevalue: During one of these excursions Gideon Spilett managed to get hold of two couples of living gallinaceae They were birds with long thin beaks lengthened necks short wings and without any appearance of a tail Herbert rightly gave them the name of tinamous and it was resolved that they should be the first tenants of their future poultry yard

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But till then the guns had not spoken, and the first report which awoke the echoes of the forest of the Far West was provoked by the appearance of a beautiful bird, resembling the kingfisher.
children.prevalue: But till then the guns had not spoken and the first report which awoke the echoes of the forest of the Far West was provoked by the appearance of a beautiful bird resembling the kingfisher

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I recognize him! cried Pencroft, and it seemed as if his gun went off by itself.
children.prevalue: I recognize him cried Pencroft and it seemed as if his gun went off by itself

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What do you recognize? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What do you recognize asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The bird which escaped us on our first excursion, and from which we gave the name to that part of the forest.
children.prevalue: The bird which escaped us on our first excursion and from which we gave the name to that part of the forest

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A jacamar! cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: A jacamar cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It was indeed a jacamar, of which the plumage shines with a metallic luster. A shot brought it to the ground, and Top carried it to the canoe. At the same time half a dozen lories were brought down. The lory is of the size of a pigeon, the plumage dashed with green, part of the wings crimson, and its crest bordered with white. To the young boy belonged the honor of this shot, and he was proud enough of it. Lories are better food than the jacamar, the flesh of which is rather tough, but it was difficult to persuade Pencroft that he had not killed the king of eatable birds. It was ten o'clock in the morning when the canoe reached a second angle of the Mercy, nearly five miles from its mouth. Here a halt was made for breakfast under the shade of some splendid trees. The river still measured from sixty to seventy feet in breadth, and its bed from five to six feet in depth. The engineer had observed that it was increased by numerous affluents, but they were unnavigable, being simply little streams. As to the forest, including Jacamar Wood, as well as the forests of the Far West, it extended as far as the eye could reach. In no place, either in the depths of the forests or under the trees on the banks of the Mercy, was the presence of man revealed. The explorers could not discover one suspicious trace. It was evident that the woodman's axe had never touched these trees, that the pioneer's knife had never severed the creepers hanging from one trunk to another in the midst of tangled brushwood and long grass. If castaways had landed on the island, they could not have yet quitted the shore, and it was not in the woods that the survivors of the supposed shipwreck should be sought.
children.prevalue: It was indeed a jacamar of which the plumage shines with a metallic luster A shot brought it to the ground and Top carried it to the canoe At the same time half a dozen lories were brought down The lory is of the size of a pigeon the plumage dashed with green part of the wings crimson and its crest bordered with white To the young boy belonged the honor of this shot and he was proud enough of it Lories are better food than the jacamar the flesh of which is rather tough but it was difficult to persuade Pencroft that he had not killed the king of eatable birds It was ten o clock in the morning when the canoe reached a second angle of the Mercy nearly five miles from its mouth Here a halt was made for breakfast under the shade of some splendid trees The river still measured from sixty to seventy feet in breadth and its bed from five to six feet in depth The engineer had observed that it was increased by numerous affluents but they were unnavigable being simply little streams As to the forest including Jacamar Wood as well as the forests of the Far West it extended as far as the eye could reach In no place either in the depths of the forests or under the trees on the banks of the Mercy was the presence of man revealed The explorers could not discover one suspicious trace It was evident that the woodman s axe had never touched these trees that the pioneer s knife had never severed the creepers hanging from one trunk to another in the midst of tangled brushwood and long grass If castaways had landed on the island they could not have yet quitted the shore and it was not in the woods that the survivors of the supposed shipwreck should be sought

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The engineer therefore manifested some impatience to reach the western coast of Lincoln Island, which was at least five miles distant according to his estimation.
children.prevalue: The engineer therefore manifested some impatience to reach the western coast of Lincoln Island which was at least five miles distant according to his estimation

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The voyage was continued, and as the Mercy appeared to flow not towards the shore, but rather towards Mount Franklin, it was decided that they should use the boat as long as there was enough water under its keel to float it. It was both fatigue spared and time gained, for they would have been obliged to cut a path through the thick wood with their axes. But soon the flow completely failed them, either the tide was going down, and it was about the hour, or it could no longer be felt at this distance from the mouth of the Mercy. They had therefore to make use of the oars. Herbert and Neb each took one, and Pencroft took the scull. The forest soon became less dense, the trees grew further apart and often quite isolated. But the further they were from each other the more magnificent they appeared, profiting, as they did, by the free, pure air which circulated around them.
children.prevalue: The voyage was continued and as the Mercy appeared to flow not towards the shore but rather towards Mount Franklin it was decided that they should use the boat as long as there was enough water under its keel to float it It was both fatigue spared and time gained for they would have been obliged to cut a path through the thick wood with their axes But soon the flow completely failed them either the tide was going down and it was about the hour or it could no longer be felt at this distance from the mouth of the Mercy They had therefore to make use of the oars Herbert and Neb each took one and Pencroft took the scull The forest soon became less dense the trees grew further apart and often quite isolated But the further they were from each other the more magnificent they appeared profiting as they did by the free pure air which circulated around them

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What splendid specimens of the flora of this latitude! Certainly their presence would have been enough for a botanist to name without hesitation the parallel which traversed Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: What splendid specimens of the flora of this latitude Certainly their presence would have been enough for a botanist to name without hesitation the parallel which traversed Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Eucalypti! cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: Eucalypti cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: They were, in fact, those splendid trees, the giants of the extratropical zone, the congeners of the Australian and New Zealand eucalyptus, both situated under the same latitude as Lincoln Island. Some rose to a height of two hundred feet. Their trunks at the base measured twenty feet in circumference, and their bark was covered by a network of farrows containing a red, sweet-smelling gum. Nothing is more wonderful or more singular than those enormous specimens of the order of the myrtaceae, with their leaves placed vertically and not horizontally, so that an edge and not a surface looks upwards, the effect being that the sun's rays penetrate more freely among the trees.
children.prevalue: They were in fact those splendid trees the giants of the extratropical zone the congeners of the Australian and New Zealand eucalyptus both situated under the same latitude as Lincoln Island Some rose to a height of two hundred feet Their trunks at the base measured twenty feet in circumference and their bark was covered by a network of farrows containing a red sweet smelling gum Nothing is more wonderful or more singular than those enormous specimens of the order of the myrtaceae with their leaves placed vertically and not horizontally so that an edge and not a surface looks upwards the effect being that the sun s rays penetrate more freely among the trees

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The ground at the foot of the eucalypti was carpeted with grass, and from the bushes escaped flights of little birds, which glittered in the sunlight like winged rubies.
children.prevalue: The ground at the foot of the eucalypti was carpeted with grass and from the bushes escaped flights of little birds which glittered in the sunlight like winged rubies

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: These are something like trees! cried Neb; but are they good for anything?
children.prevalue: These are something like trees cried Neb but are they good for anything

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Pooh! replied Pencroft. Of course there are vegetable giants as well as human giants, and they are no good, except to show themselves at fairs!
children.prevalue: Pooh replied Pencroft Of course there are vegetable giants as well as human giants and they are no good except to show themselves at fairs

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I think that you are mistaken, Pencroft, replied Gideon Spilett, and that the wood of the eucalyptus has begun to be very advantageously employed in cabinet-making.
children.prevalue: I think that you are mistaken Pencroft replied Gideon Spilett and that the wood of the eucalyptus has begun to be very advantageously employed in cabinet making

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And I may add, said Herbert, that the eucalyptus belongs to a family which comprises many useful members; the guava-tree, from whose fruit guava jelly is made; the clove-tree, which produces the spice; the pomegranate-tree, which bears pomegranates; the Eugeacia Cauliflora, the fruit of which is used in making a tolerable wine; the Ugui myrtle, which contains an excellent alcoholic liquor; the Caryophyllus myrtle, of which the bark forms an esteemed cinnamon; the Eugenia Pimenta, from whence comes Jamaica pepper; the common myrtle, from whose buds and berries spice is sometimes made; the Eucalyptus manifera, which yields a sweet sort of manna; the Guinea Eucalyptus, the sap of which is transformed into beer by fermentation; in short, all those trees known under the name of gum-trees or iron-bark trees in Australia, belong to this family of the myrtaceae, which contains forty-six genera and thirteen hundred species!
children.prevalue: And I may add said Herbert that the eucalyptus belongs to a family which comprises many useful members the guava tree from whose fruit guava jelly is made the clove tree which produces the spice the pomegranate tree which bears pomegranates the Eugeacia Cauliflora the fruit of which is used in making a tolerable wine the Ugui myrtle which contains an excellent alcoholic liquor the Caryophyllus myrtle of which the bark forms an esteemed cinnamon the Eugenia Pimenta from whence comes Jamaica pepper the common myrtle from whose buds and berries spice is sometimes made the Eucalyptus manifera which yields a sweet sort of manna the Guinea Eucalyptus the sap of which is transformed into beer by fermentation in short all those trees known under the name of gum trees or iron bark trees in Australia belong to this family of the myrtaceae which contains forty six genera and thirteen hundred species

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The lad was allowed to run on, and he delivered his little botanical lecture with great animation. Cyrus Harding listened smiling, and Pencroft with an indescribable feeling of pride.
children.prevalue: The lad was allowed to run on and he delivered his little botanical lecture with great animation Cyrus Harding listened smiling and Pencroft with an indescribable feeling of pride

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Very good, Herbert, replied Pencroft, but I could swear that all those useful specimens you have just told us about are none of them giants like these!
children.prevalue: Very good Herbert replied Pencroft but I could swear that all those useful specimens you have just told us about are none of them giants like these

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: That is true, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: That is true Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That supports what I said, returned the sailor, namely, that these giants are good for nothing!
children.prevalue: That supports what I said returned the sailor namely that these giants are good for nothing

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: There you are wrong, Pencroft, said the engineer; these gigantic eucalypti, which shelter us, are good for something.
children.prevalue: There you are wrong Pencroft said the engineer these gigantic eucalypti which shelter us are good for something

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And what is that?
children.prevalue: And what is that

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: To render the countries which they inhabit healthy. Do you know what they are called in Australia and New Zealand?
children.prevalue: To render the countries which they inhabit healthy Do you know what they are called in Australia and New Zealand

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: No, captain.
children.prevalue: No captain

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: They are called 'fever trees.'
children.prevalue: They are called fever trees

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Because they give fevers?
children.prevalue: Because they give fevers

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, because they prevent them!
children.prevalue: No because they prevent them

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Good. I must note that, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: Good I must note that said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Note it then, my dear Spilett; for it appears proved that the presence of the eucalyptus is enough to neutralize miasmas. This natural antidote has been tried in certain countries in the middle of Europe and the north of Africa where the soil was absolutely unhealthy, and the sanitary condition of the inhabitants has been gradually ameliorated. No more intermittent fevers prevail in the regions now covered with forests of the myrtaceae. This fact is now beyond doubt, and it is a happy circumstance for us settlers in Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: Note it then my dear Spilett for it appears proved that the presence of the eucalyptus is enough to neutralize miasmas This natural antidote has been tried in certain countries in the middle of Europe and the north of Africa where the soil was absolutely unhealthy and the sanitary condition of the inhabitants has been gradually ameliorated No more intermittent fevers prevail in the regions now covered with forests of the myrtaceae This fact is now beyond doubt and it is a happy circumstance for us settlers in Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Ah! what an island! What a blessed island! cried Pencroft. I tell you, it wants nothing--unless it is--
children.prevalue: Ah what an island What a blessed island cried Pencroft I tell you it wants nothing unless it is

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: That will come, Pencroft, that will be found, replied the engineer; but now we must continue our voyage and push on as far as the river will carry our boat!
children.prevalue: That will come Pencroft that will be found replied the engineer but now we must continue our voyage and push on as far as the river will carry our boat

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The exploration was therefore continued for another two miles in the midst of country covered with eucalypti, which predominated in the woods of this portion of the island. The space which they occupied extended as far as the eye could reach on each side of the Mercy, which wound along between high green banks. The bed was often obstructed by long weeds, and even by pointed rocks, which rendered the navigation very difficult. The action of the oars was prevented, and Pencroft was obliged to push with a pole. They found also that the water was becoming shallower and shallower, and that the canoe must soon stop. The sun was already sinking towards the horizon, and the trees threw long shadows on the ground. Cyrus Harding, seeing that he could not hope to reach the western coast of the island in one journey, resolved to camp at the place where any further navigation was prevented by want of water. He calculated that they were still five or six miles from the coast, and this distance was too great for them to attempt during the night in the midst of unknown woods.
children.prevalue: The exploration was therefore continued for another two miles in the midst of country covered with eucalypti which predominated in the woods of this portion of the island The space which they occupied extended as far as the eye could reach on each side of the Mercy which wound along between high green banks The bed was often obstructed by long weeds and even by pointed rocks which rendered the navigation very difficult The action of the oars was prevented and Pencroft was obliged to push with a pole They found also that the water was becoming shallower and shallower and that the canoe must soon stop The sun was already sinking towards the horizon and the trees threw long shadows on the ground Cyrus Harding seeing that he could not hope to reach the western coast of the island in one journey resolved to camp at the place where any further navigation was prevented by want of water He calculated that they were still five or six miles from the coast and this distance was too great for them to attempt during the night in the midst of unknown woods

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The boat was pushed on through the forest, which gradually became thicker again, and appeared also to have more inhabitants; for if the eyes of the sailor did not deceive him, he thought he saw bands of monkeys springing among the trees. Sometimes even two or three of these animals stopped at a little distance from the canoe and gazed at the settlers without manifesting any terror, as if, seeing men for the first time, they had not yet learned to fear them. It would have been easy to bring down one of these quadramani with a gunshot, and Pencroft was greatly tempted to fire, but Harding opposed so useless a massacre. This was prudent, for the monkeys, or apes rather, appearing to be very powerful and extremely active, it was useless to provoke an unnecessary aggression, and the creatures might, ignorant of the power of the explorers' firearms, have attacked them. It is true that the sailor considered the monkeys from a purely alimentary point of view, for those animals which are herbivorous make very excellent game; but since they had an abundant supply of provisions, it was a pity to waste their ammunition.
children.prevalue: The boat was pushed on through the forest which gradually became thicker again and appeared also to have more inhabitants for if the eyes of the sailor did not deceive him he thought he saw bands of monkeys springing among the trees Sometimes even two or three of these animals stopped at a little distance from the canoe and gazed at the settlers without manifesting any terror as if seeing men for the first time they had not yet learned to fear them It would have been easy to bring down one of these quadramani with a gunshot and Pencroft was greatly tempted to fire but Harding opposed so useless a massacre This was prudent for the monkeys or apes rather appearing to be very powerful and extremely active it was useless to provoke an unnecessary aggression and the creatures might ignorant of the power of the explorers firearms have attacked them It is true that the sailor considered the monkeys from a purely alimentary point of view for those animals which are herbivorous make very excellent game but since they had an abundant supply of provisions it was a pity to waste their ammunition

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Towards four o'clock, the navigation of the Mercy became exceedingly difficult, for its course was obstructed by aquatic plants and rocks. The banks rose higher and higher, and already they were approaching the spurs of Mount Franklin. The source could not be far off, since it was fed by the water from the southern slopes of the mountain.
children.prevalue: Towards four o clock the navigation of the Mercy became exceedingly difficult for its course was obstructed by aquatic plants and rocks The banks rose higher and higher and already they were approaching the spurs of Mount Franklin The source could not be far off since it was fed by the water from the southern slopes of the mountain

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: In a quarter of an hour, said the sailor, we shall be obliged to stop, captain.
children.prevalue: In a quarter of an hour said the sailor we shall be obliged to stop captain

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Very well, we will stop, Pencroft, and we will make our encampment for the night.
children.prevalue: Very well we will stop Pencroft and we will make our encampment for the night

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At what distance are we from Granite House? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: At what distance are we from Granite House asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: About seven miles, replied the engineer, taking into calculation, however, the detours of the river, which has carried us to the northwest.
children.prevalue: About seven miles replied the engineer taking into calculation however the detours of the river which has carried us to the northwest

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Shall we go on? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: Shall we go on asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, as long as we can, replied Cyrus Harding. To-morrow, at break of day, we will leave the canoe, and in two hours I hope we shall cross the distance which separates us from the coast, and then we shall have the whole day in which to explore the shore.
children.prevalue: Yes as long as we can replied Cyrus Harding To morrow at break of day we will leave the canoe and in two hours I hope we shall cross the distance which separates us from the coast and then we shall have the whole day in which to explore the shore

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Go ahead! replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Go ahead replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But soon the boat grated on the stony bottom of the river, which was now not more than twenty feet in breadth. The trees met like a bower overhead, and caused a half-darkness. They also heard the noise of a waterfall, which showed that a few hundred feet up the river there was a natural barrier.
children.prevalue: But soon the boat grated on the stony bottom of the river which was now not more than twenty feet in breadth The trees met like a bower overhead and caused a half darkness They also heard the noise of a waterfall which showed that a few hundred feet up the river there was a natural barrier

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Presently, after a sudden turn of the river, a cascade appeared through the trees. The canoe again touched the bottom, and in a few minutes it was moored to a trunk near the right bank.
children.prevalue: Presently after a sudden turn of the river a cascade appeared through the trees The canoe again touched the bottom and in a few minutes it was moored to a trunk near the right bank

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: It was nearly five o'clock. The last rays of the sun gleamed through the thick foliage and glanced on the little waterfall, making the spray sparkle with all the colors of the rainbow. Beyond that, the Mercy was lost in the bushwood, where it was fed from some hidden source. The different streams which flowed into it increased it to a regular river further down, but here it was simply a shallow, limpid brook.
children.prevalue: It was nearly five o clock The last rays of the sun gleamed through the thick foliage and glanced on the little waterfall making the spray sparkle with all the colors of the rainbow Beyond that the Mercy was lost in the bushwood where it was fed from some hidden source The different streams which flowed into it increased it to a regular river further down but here it was simply a shallow limpid brook

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: It was agreed to camp here, as the place was charming. The colonists disembarked, and a fire was soon lighted under a clump of trees, among the branches of which Cyrus Harding and his companions could, if it was necessary, take refuge for the night.
children.prevalue: It was agreed to camp here as the place was charming The colonists disembarked and a fire was soon lighted under a clump of trees among the branches of which Cyrus Harding and his companions could if it was necessary take refuge for the night

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Supper was quickly devoured, for they were very hungry, and then there was only sleeping to think of. But, as roarings of rather a suspicious nature had been heard during the evening, a good fire was made up for the night, so as to protect the sleepers with its crackling flames. Neb and Pencroft also watched by turns, and did not spare fuel. They thought they saw the dark forms of some wild animals prowling round the camp among the bushes, but the night passed without incident, and the next day, the 31st of October, at five o'clock in the morning, all were on foot, ready for a start.
children.prevalue: Supper was quickly devoured for they were very hungry and then there was only sleeping to think of But as roarings of rather a suspicious nature had been heard during the evening a good fire was made up for the night so as to protect the sleepers with its crackling flames Neb and Pencroft also watched by turns and did not spare fuel They thought they saw the dark forms of some wild animals prowling round the camp among the bushes but the night passed without incident and the next day the 31st of October at five o clock in the morning all were on foot ready for a start

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was six o' clock in the morning when the settlers, after a hasty breakfast, set out to reach by the shortest way, the western coast of the island. And how long would it take to do this? Cyrus Harding had said two hours, but of course that depended on the nature of the obstacles they might meet with. As it was probable that they would have to cut a path through the grass, shrubs, and creepers, they marched axe in hand, and with guns also ready, wisely taking warning from the cries of the wild beasts heard in the night.
children.prevalue: It was six o clock in the morning when the settlers after a hasty breakfast set out to reach by the shortest way the western coast of the island And how long would it take to do this Cyrus Harding had said two hours but of course that depended on the nature of the obstacles they might meet with As it was probable that they would have to cut a path through the grass shrubs and creepers they marched axe in hand and with guns also ready wisely taking warning from the cries of the wild beasts heard in the night

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The exact position of the encampment could be determined by the bearing of Mount Franklin, and as the volcano arose in the north at a distance of less than three miles, they had only to go straight towards the southwest to reach the western coast. They set out, having first carefully secured the canoe. Pencroft and Neb carried sufficient provision for the little band for at least two days. It would not thus be necessary to hunt. The engineer advised his companions to refrain from firing, that their presence might not be betrayed to any one near the shore. The first hatchet blows were given among the brushwood in the midst of some mastic-trees, a little above the cascade; and his compass in his hand, Cyrus Harding led the way.
children.prevalue: The exact position of the encampment could be determined by the bearing of Mount Franklin and as the volcano arose in the north at a distance of less than three miles they had only to go straight towards the southwest to reach the western coast They set out having first carefully secured the canoe Pencroft and Neb carried sufficient provision for the little band for at least two days It would not thus be necessary to hunt The engineer advised his companions to refrain from firing that their presence might not be betrayed to any one near the shore The first hatchet blows were given among the brushwood in the midst of some mastic trees a little above the cascade and his compass in his hand Cyrus Harding led the way

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The forest here was composed for the most part of trees which had already been met with near the lake and on Prospect Heights. There were deodars, Douglas firs, casuarinas, gum trees, eucalypti, hibiscus, cedars, and other trees, generally of a moderate size, for their number prevented their growth.
children.prevalue: The forest here was composed for the most part of trees which had already been met with near the lake and on Prospect Heights There were deodars Douglas firs casuarinas gum trees eucalypti hibiscus cedars and other trees generally of a moderate size for their number prevented their growth

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Since their departure, the settlers had descended the slopes which constituted the mountain system of the island, on to a dry soil, but the luxuriant vegetation of which indicated it to be watered either by some subterranean marsh or by some stream. However, Cyrus Harding did not remember having seen, at the time of his excursion to the crater, any other watercourses but the Red Creek and the Mercy.
children.prevalue: Since their departure the settlers had descended the slopes which constituted the mountain system of the island on to a dry soil but the luxuriant vegetation of which indicated it to be watered either by some subterranean marsh or by some stream However Cyrus Harding did not remember having seen at the time of his excursion to the crater any other watercourses but the Red Creek and the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: During the first part of their excursion, they saw numerous troops of monkeys who exhibited great astonishment at the sight of men, whose appearance was so new to them. Gideon Spilett jokingly asked whether these active and merry quadrupeds did not consider him and his companions as degenerate brothers.
children.prevalue: During the first part of their excursion they saw numerous troops of monkeys who exhibited great astonishment at the sight of men whose appearance was so new to them Gideon Spilett jokingly asked whether these active and merry quadrupeds did not consider him and his companions as degenerate brothers

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And certainly, pedestrians, hindered at each step by bushes, caught by creepers, barred by trunks of trees, did not shine beside those supple animals, who, bounding from branch to branch, were hindered by nothing on their course. The monkeys were numerous, but happily they did not manifest any hostile disposition.
children.prevalue: And certainly pedestrians hindered at each step by bushes caught by creepers barred by trunks of trees did not shine beside those supple animals who bounding from branch to branch were hindered by nothing on their course The monkeys were numerous but happily they did not manifest any hostile disposition

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Several pigs, agoutis, kangaroos, and other rodents were seen, also two or three koalas, at which Pencroft longed to have a shot.
children.prevalue: Several pigs agoutis kangaroos and other rodents were seen also two or three koalas at which Pencroft longed to have a shot

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But, said he, you may jump and play just now; we shall have one or two words to say to you on our way back!
children.prevalue: But said he you may jump and play just now we shall have one or two words to say to you on our way back

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: At half-past nine the way was suddenly found to be barred by an unknown stream, from thirty to forty feet broad, whose rapid current dashed foaming over the numerous rocks which interrupted its course. This creek was deep and clear, but it was absolutely unnavigable.
children.prevalue: At half past nine the way was suddenly found to be barred by an unknown stream from thirty to forty feet broad whose rapid current dashed foaming over the numerous rocks which interrupted its course This creek was deep and clear but it was absolutely unnavigable

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: We are cut off! cried Neb.
children.prevalue: We are cut off cried Neb

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: No, replied Herbert, it is only a stream, and we can easily swim over.
children.prevalue: No replied Herbert it is only a stream and we can easily swim over

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: What would be the use of that? returned Harding. This creek evidently runs to the sea. Let us remain on this side and follow the bank, and I shall be much astonished if it does not lead us very quickly to the coast. Forward!
children.prevalue: What would be the use of that returned Harding This creek evidently runs to the sea Let us remain on this side and follow the bank and I shall be much astonished if it does not lead us very quickly to the coast Forward

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: One minute, said the reporter. The name of this creek, my friends? Do not let us leave our geography incomplete.
children.prevalue: One minute said the reporter The name of this creek my friends Do not let us leave our geography incomplete

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: All right! said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: All right said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Name it, my boy, said the engineer, addressing the lad.
children.prevalue: Name it my boy said the engineer addressing the lad

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Will it not be better to wait until we have explored it to its mouth? answered Herbert.
children.prevalue: Will it not be better to wait until we have explored it to its mouth answered Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Very well, replied Cyrus Harding. Let us follow it as fast as we can without stopping.
children.prevalue: Very well replied Cyrus Harding Let us follow it as fast as we can without stopping

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Still another minute! said Pencroft.
