children.prevalue: Still another minute said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: What's the matter? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What s the matter asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Though hunting is forbidden, fishing is allowed, I suppose, said the sailor.
children.prevalue: Though hunting is forbidden fishing is allowed I suppose said the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We have no time to lose, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: We have no time to lose replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh! five minutes! replied Pencroft, I only ask for five minutes to use in the interest of our breakfast!
children.prevalue: Oh five minutes replied Pencroft I only ask for five minutes to use in the interest of our breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And Pencroft, lying down on the bank, plunged his arm into the water, and soon pulled up several dozen of fine crayfish from among the stones.
children.prevalue: And Pencroft lying down on the bank plunged his arm into the water and soon pulled up several dozen of fine crayfish from among the stones

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: These will be good! cried Neb, going to the sailor's aid.
children.prevalue: These will be good cried Neb going to the sailor s aid

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: As I said, there is everything in this island, except tobacco! muttered Pencroft with a sigh.
children.prevalue: As I said there is everything in this island except tobacco muttered Pencroft with a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The fishing did not take five minutes, for the crayfish were swarming in the creek. A bag was filled with the crustaceae, whose shells were of a cobalt blue. The settlers then pushed on.
children.prevalue: The fishing did not take five minutes for the crayfish were swarming in the creek A bag was filled with the crustaceae whose shells were of a cobalt blue The settlers then pushed on

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: They advanced more rapidly and easily along the bank of the river than in the forest. From time to time they came upon the traces of animals of a large size who had come to quench their thirst at the stream, but none were actually seen, and it was evidently not in this part of the forest that the peccary had received the bullet which had cost Pencroft a grinder.
children.prevalue: They advanced more rapidly and easily along the bank of the river than in the forest From time to time they came upon the traces of animals of a large size who had come to quench their thirst at the stream but none were actually seen and it was evidently not in this part of the forest that the peccary had received the bullet which had cost Pencroft a grinder

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: In the meanwhile, considering the rapid current, Harding was led to suppose that he and his companions were much farther from the western coast than they had at first supposed. In fact, at this hour, the rising tide would have turned back the current of the creek, if its mouth had only been a few miles distant. Now, this effect was not produced, and the water pursued its natural course. The engineer was much astonished at this, and frequently consulted his compass, to assure himself that some turn of the river was not leading them again into the Far West.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile considering the rapid current Harding was led to suppose that he and his companions were much farther from the western coast than they had at first supposed In fact at this hour the rising tide would have turned back the current of the creek if its mouth had only been a few miles distant Now this effect was not produced and the water pursued its natural course The engineer was much astonished at this and frequently consulted his compass to assure himself that some turn of the river was not leading them again into the Far West

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: However, the creek gradually widened and its waters became less tumultuous. The trees on the right bank were as close together as on the left bank, and it was impossible to distinguish anything beyond them; but these masses of wood were evidently uninhabited, for Top did not bark, and the intelligent animal would not have failed to signal the presence of any stranger in the neighborhood.
children.prevalue: However the creek gradually widened and its waters became less tumultuous The trees on the right bank were as close together as on the left bank and it was impossible to distinguish anything beyond them but these masses of wood were evidently uninhabited for Top did not bark and the intelligent animal would not have failed to signal the presence of any stranger in the neighborhood

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: At half-past ten, to the great surprise of Cyrus Harding, Herbert, who was a little in front, suddenly stopped and exclaimed,--
children.prevalue: At half past ten to the great surprise of Cyrus Harding Herbert who was a little in front suddenly stopped and exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The sea!
children.prevalue: The sea

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: In a few minutes more, the whole western shore of the island lay extended before the eyes of the settlers.
children.prevalue: In a few minutes more the whole western shore of the island lay extended before the eyes of the settlers

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But what a contrast between this and the eastern coast, upon which chance had first thrown them. No granite cliff, no rocks, not even a sandy beach. The forest reached the shore, and the tall trees bending over the water were beaten by the waves. It was not such a shore as is usually formed by nature, either by extending a vast carpet of sand, or by grouping masses of rock, but a beautiful border consisting of the most splendid trees. The bank was raised a little above the level of the sea, and on this luxuriant soil, supported by a granite base, the fine forest trees seemed to be as firmly planted as in the interior of the island.
children.prevalue: But what a contrast between this and the eastern coast upon which chance had first thrown them No granite cliff no rocks not even a sandy beach The forest reached the shore and the tall trees bending over the water were beaten by the waves It was not such a shore as is usually formed by nature either by extending a vast carpet of sand or by grouping masses of rock but a beautiful border consisting of the most splendid trees The bank was raised a little above the level of the sea and on this luxuriant soil supported by a granite base the fine forest trees seemed to be as firmly planted as in the interior of the island

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The colonists were then on the shore of an unimportant little harbor, which would scarcely have contained even two or three fishing-boats. It served as a neck to the new creek, of which the curious thing was that its waters, instead of joining the sea by a gentle slope, fell from a height of more than forty feet, which explained why the rising tide was not felt up the stream. In fact, the tides of the Pacific, even at their maximum elevation, could never reach the level of the river, and, doubtless, millions of years would pass before the water would have worn away the granite and hollowed a practicable mouth.
children.prevalue: The colonists were then on the shore of an unimportant little harbor which would scarcely have contained even two or three fishing boats It served as a neck to the new creek of which the curious thing was that its waters instead of joining the sea by a gentle slope fell from a height of more than forty feet which explained why the rising tide was not felt up the stream In fact the tides of the Pacific even at their maximum elevation could never reach the level of the river and doubtless millions of years would pass before the water would have worn away the granite and hollowed a practicable mouth

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It was settled that the name of Falls River should be given to this stream. Beyond, towards the north, the forest border was prolonged for a space of nearly two miles; then the trees became scarcer, and beyond that again the picturesque heights described a nearly straight line, which ran north and south. On the contrary, all the part of the shore between Falls River and Reptile End was a mass of wood, magnificent trees, some straight, others bent, so that the long sea-swell bathed their roots. Now, it was this coast, that is, all the Serpentine Peninsula, that was to be explored, for this part of the shore offered a refuge to castaways, which the other wild and barren side must have refused.
children.prevalue: It was settled that the name of Falls River should be given to this stream Beyond towards the north the forest border was prolonged for a space of nearly two miles then the trees became scarcer and beyond that again the picturesque heights described a nearly straight line which ran north and south On the contrary all the part of the shore between Falls River and Reptile End was a mass of wood magnificent trees some straight others bent so that the long sea swell bathed their roots Now it was this coast that is all the Serpentine Peninsula that was to be explored for this part of the shore offered a refuge to castaways which the other wild and barren side must have refused

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The weather was fine and clear, and from a height of a hillock on which Neb and Pencroft had arranged breakfast, a wide view was obtained. There was, however, not a sail in sight; nothing could be seen along the shore as far as the eye could reach. But the engineer would take nothing for granted until he had explored the coast to the very extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula.
children.prevalue: The weather was fine and clear and from a height of a hillock on which Neb and Pencroft had arranged breakfast a wide view was obtained There was however not a sail in sight nothing could be seen along the shore as far as the eye could reach But the engineer would take nothing for granted until he had explored the coast to the very extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Breakfast was soon despatched, and at half-past eleven the captain gave the signal for departure. Instead of proceeding over the summit of a cliff or along a sandy beach, the settlers were obliged to remain under cover of the trees so that they might continue on the shore.
children.prevalue: Breakfast was soon despatched and at half past eleven the captain gave the signal for departure Instead of proceeding over the summit of a cliff or along a sandy beach the settlers were obliged to remain under cover of the trees so that they might continue on the shore

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The distance which separated Falls River from Reptile End was about twelve miles. It would have taken the settlers four hours to do this, on a clear ground and without hurrying themselves; but as it was they needed double the time, for what with trees to go round, bushes to cut down, and creepers to chop away, they were impeded at every step, these obstacles greatly lengthening their journey.
children.prevalue: The distance which separated Falls River from Reptile End was about twelve miles It would have taken the settlers four hours to do this on a clear ground and without hurrying themselves but as it was they needed double the time for what with trees to go round bushes to cut down and creepers to chop away they were impeded at every step these obstacles greatly lengthening their journey

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: There was, however, nothing to show that a shipwreck had taken place recently. It is true that, as Gideon Spilett observed, any remains of it might have drifted out to sea, and they must not take it for granted that because they could find no traces of it, a ship had not been castaway on the coast.
children.prevalue: There was however nothing to show that a shipwreck had taken place recently It is true that as Gideon Spilett observed any remains of it might have drifted out to sea and they must not take it for granted that because they could find no traces of it a ship had not been castaway on the coast

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The reporter's argument was just, and besides, the incident of the bullet proved that a shot must have been fired in Lincoln Island within three months.
children.prevalue: The reporter s argument was just and besides the incident of the bullet proved that a shot must have been fired in Lincoln Island within three months

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: It was already five o'clock, and there were still two miles between the settlers and the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula. It was evident that after having reached Reptile End, Harding and his companions would not have time to return before dark to their encampment near the source of the Mercy. It would therefore be necessary to pass the night on the promontory. But they had no lack of provisions, which was lucky, for there were no animals on the shore, though birds, on the contrary, abound--jacamars, couroucous, tragopans, grouse, lories, parrots, cockatoos, pheasants, pigeons, and a hundred others. There was not a tree without a nest, and not a nest which was not full of flapping wings.
children.prevalue: It was already five o clock and there were still two miles between the settlers and the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula It was evident that after having reached Reptile End Harding and his companions would not have time to return before dark to their encampment near the source of the Mercy It would therefore be necessary to pass the night on the promontory But they had no lack of provisions which was lucky for there were no animals on the shore though birds on the contrary abound jacamars couroucous tragopans grouse lories parrots cockatoos pheasants pigeons and a hundred others There was not a tree without a nest and not a nest which was not full of flapping wings

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Towards seven o'clock the weary explorers arrived at Reptile End. Here the seaside forest ended, and the shore resumed the customary appearance of a coast, with rocks, reefs, and sands. It was possible that something might be found here, but darkness came on, and the further exploration had to be put off to the next day.
children.prevalue: Towards seven o clock the weary explorers arrived at Reptile End Here the seaside forest ended and the shore resumed the customary appearance of a coast with rocks reefs and sands It was possible that something might be found here but darkness came on and the further exploration had to be put off to the next day

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Pencroft and Herbert hastened on to find a suitable place for their camp. Among the last trees of the forest of the Far West, the boy found several thick clumps of bamboos.
children.prevalue: Pencroft and Herbert hastened on to find a suitable place for their camp Among the last trees of the forest of the Far West the boy found several thick clumps of bamboos

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Good, said he; this is a valuable discovery.
children.prevalue: Good said he this is a valuable discovery

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Valuable? returned Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Valuable returned Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Certainly, replied Herbert. I may say, Pencroft, that the bark of the bamboo, cut into flexible laths, is used for making baskets; that this bark, mashed into a paste, is used for the manufacture of Chinese paper; that the stalks furnish, according to their size, canes and pipes and are used for conducting water; that large bamboos make excellent material for building, being light and strong, and being never attacked by insects. I will add that by sawing the bamboo in two at the joint, keeping for the bottom the part of the transverse film which forms the joint, useful cups are obtained, which are much in use among the Chinese. No! you don't care for that. But--
children.prevalue: Certainly replied Herbert I may say Pencroft that the bark of the bamboo cut into flexible laths is used for making baskets that this bark mashed into a paste is used for the manufacture of Chinese paper that the stalks furnish according to their size canes and pipes and are used for conducting water that large bamboos make excellent material for building being light and strong and being never attacked by insects I will add that by sawing the bamboo in two at the joint keeping for the bottom the part of the transverse film which forms the joint useful cups are obtained which are much in use among the Chinese No you don t care for that But

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But what?
children.prevalue: But what

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: But I can tell you, if you are ignorant of it, that in India these bamboos are eaten like asparagus.
children.prevalue: But I can tell you if you are ignorant of it that in India these bamboos are eaten like asparagus

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Asparagus thirty feet high! exclaimed the sailor. And are they good?
children.prevalue: Asparagus thirty feet high exclaimed the sailor And are they good

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Excellent, replied Herbert. Only it is not the stems of thirty feet high which are eaten, but the young shoots.
children.prevalue: Excellent replied Herbert Only it is not the stems of thirty feet high which are eaten but the young shoots

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Perfect, my boy, perfect! replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Perfect my boy perfect replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: I will also add that the pith of the young stalks, preserved in vinegar, makes a good pickle.
children.prevalue: I will also add that the pith of the young stalks preserved in vinegar makes a good pickle

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Better and better, Herbert!
children.prevalue: Better and better Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And lastly, that the bamboos exude a sweet liquor which can be made into a very agreeable drink.
children.prevalue: And lastly that the bamboos exude a sweet liquor which can be made into a very agreeable drink

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Is that all? asked the sailor.
children.prevalue: Is that all asked the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: That is all!
children.prevalue: That is all

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: And they don't happen to do for smoking?
children.prevalue: And they don t happen to do for smoking

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: No, my poor Pencroft.
children.prevalue: No my poor Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Herbert and the sailor had not to look long for a place in which to pass the night. The rocks, which must have been violently beaten by the sea under the influence of the winds of the southwest, presented many cavities in which shelter could be found against the night air. But just as they were about to enter one of these caves a loud roaring arrested them.
children.prevalue: Herbert and the sailor had not to look long for a place in which to pass the night The rocks which must have been violently beaten by the sea under the influence of the winds of the southwest presented many cavities in which shelter could be found against the night air But just as they were about to enter one of these caves a loud roaring arrested them

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Back! cried Pencroft. Our guns are only loaded with small shot, and beasts which can roar as loud as that would care no more for it than for grains of salt! And the sailor, seizing Herbert by the arm, dragged him behind a rock, just as a magnificent animal showed itself at the entrance of the cavern.
children.prevalue: Back cried Pencroft Our guns are only loaded with small shot and beasts which can roar as loud as that would care no more for it than for grains of salt And the sailor seizing Herbert by the arm dragged him behind a rock just as a magnificent animal showed itself at the entrance of the cavern

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: It was a jaguar of a size at least equal to its Asiatic congeners, that is to say, it measured five feet from the extremity of its head to the beginning of its tail. The yellow color of its hair was relieved by streaks and regular oblong spots of black, which contrasted with the white of its chest. Herbert recognized it as the ferocious rival of the tiger, as formidable as the puma, which is the rival of the largest wolf!
children.prevalue: It was a jaguar of a size at least equal to its Asiatic congeners that is to say it measured five feet from the extremity of its head to the beginning of its tail The yellow color of its hair was relieved by streaks and regular oblong spots of black which contrasted with the white of its chest Herbert recognized it as the ferocious rival of the tiger as formidable as the puma which is the rival of the largest wolf

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The jaguar advanced and gazed around him with blazing eyes, his hair bristling as if this was not the first time he had scented men.
children.prevalue: The jaguar advanced and gazed around him with blazing eyes his hair bristling as if this was not the first time he had scented men

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: At this moment the reporter appeared round a rock, and Herbert, thinking that he had not seen the jaguar, was about to rush towards him, when Gideon Spilett signed to him to remain where he was. This was not his first tiger, and advancing to within ten feet of the animal he remained motionless, his gun to his shoulder, without moving a muscle. The jaguar collected itself for a spring, but at that moment a shot struck it in the eyes, and it fell dead.
children.prevalue: At this moment the reporter appeared round a rock and Herbert thinking that he had not seen the jaguar was about to rush towards him when Gideon Spilett signed to him to remain where he was This was not his first tiger and advancing to within ten feet of the animal he remained motionless his gun to his shoulder without moving a muscle The jaguar collected itself for a spring but at that moment a shot struck it in the eyes and it fell dead

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Herbert and Pencroft rushed towards the jaguar. Neb and Harding also ran up, and they remained for some instants contemplating the animal as it lay stretched on the ground, thinking that its magnificent skin would be a great ornament to the hall at Granite House.
children.prevalue: Herbert and Pencroft rushed towards the jaguar Neb and Harding also ran up and they remained for some instants contemplating the animal as it lay stretched on the ground thinking that its magnificent skin would be a great ornament to the hall at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh, Mr. Spilett, how I admire and envy you! cried Herbert, in a fit of very natural enthusiasm.
children.prevalue: Oh Mr Spilett how I admire and envy you cried Herbert in a fit of very natural enthusiasm

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Well, my boy, replied the reporter, you could have done the same.
children.prevalue: Well my boy replied the reporter you could have done the same

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I! with such coolness!--
children.prevalue: I with such coolness

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Imagine to yourself, Herbert, that the jaguar is only a hare, and you would fire as quietly as possible.
children.prevalue: Imagine to yourself Herbert that the jaguar is only a hare and you would fire as quietly as possible

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: That is, rejoined Pencroft, that it is not more dangerous than a hare!
children.prevalue: That is rejoined Pencroft that it is not more dangerous than a hare

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And now, said Gideon Spilett, since the jaguar has left its abode, I do not see, my friends, why we should not take possession of it for the night.
children.prevalue: And now said Gideon Spilett since the jaguar has left its abode I do not see my friends why we should not take possession of it for the night

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But others may come, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: But others may come said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: It will be enough to light a fire at the entrance of the cavern, said the reporter, and no wild beasts will dare to cross the threshold.
children.prevalue: It will be enough to light a fire at the entrance of the cavern said the reporter and no wild beasts will dare to cross the threshold

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Into the jaguar's house, then! replied the sailor, dragging after him the body of the animal.
children.prevalue: Into the jaguar s house then replied the sailor dragging after him the body of the animal

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: While Neb skinned the jaguar, his companions collected an abundant supply of dry wood from the forest, which they heaped up at the cave.
children.prevalue: While Neb skinned the jaguar his companions collected an abundant supply of dry wood from the forest which they heaped up at the cave

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Cyrus Harding, seeing the clump of bamboos, cut a quantity, which he mingled with the other fuel.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding seeing the clump of bamboos cut a quantity which he mingled with the other fuel

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: This done, they entered the grotto, of which the floor was strewn with bones, the guns were carefully loaded, in case of a sudden attack, they had supper, and then just before they lay down to rest, the heap of wood piled at the entrance was set fire to. Immediately, a regular explosion, or rather a series of reports, broke the silence! The noise was caused by the bamboos, which, as the flames reached them, exploded like fireworks. The noise was enough to terrify even the boldest of wild beasts.
children.prevalue: This done they entered the grotto of which the floor was strewn with bones the guns were carefully loaded in case of a sudden attack they had supper and then just before they lay down to rest the heap of wood piled at the entrance was set fire to Immediately a regular explosion or rather a series of reports broke the silence The noise was caused by the bamboos which as the flames reached them exploded like fireworks The noise was enough to terrify even the boldest of wild beasts

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: It was not the engineer who had invented this way of causing loud explosions, for, according to Marco Polo, the Tartars have employed it for many centuries to drive away from their encampments the formidable wild beasts of Central Asia.
children.prevalue: It was not the engineer who had invented this way of causing loud explosions for according to Marco Polo the Tartars have employed it for many centuries to drive away from their encampments the formidable wild beasts of Central Asia

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions slept like innocent marmots in the cave which the jaguar had so politely left at their disposal.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions slept like innocent marmots in the cave which the jaguar had so politely left at their disposal

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: At sunrise all were on the shore at the extremity of the promontory, and their gaze was directed towards the horizon, of which two-thirds of the circumference were visible. For the last time the engineer could ascertain that not a sail nor the wreck of a ship was on the sea, and even with the telescope nothing suspicious could be discovered.
children.prevalue: At sunrise all were on the shore at the extremity of the promontory and their gaze was directed towards the horizon of which two thirds of the circumference were visible For the last time the engineer could ascertain that not a sail nor the wreck of a ship was on the sea and even with the telescope nothing suspicious could be discovered

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: There was nothing either on the shore, at least, in the straight line of three miles which formed the south side of the promontory, for beyond that, rising ground had the rest of the coast, and even from the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula Claw Cape could not be seen.
children.prevalue: There was nothing either on the shore at least in the straight line of three miles which formed the south side of the promontory for beyond that rising ground had the rest of the coast and even from the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula Claw Cape could not be seen

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The southern coast of the island still remained to be explored. Now should they undertake it immediately, and devote this day to it?
children.prevalue: The southern coast of the island still remained to be explored Now should they undertake it immediately and devote this day to it

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This was not included in their first plan. In fact, when the boat was abandoned at the sources of the Mercy, it had been agreed that after having surveyed the west coast, they should go back to it, and return to Granite House by the Mercy. Harding then thought that the western coast would have offered refuge, either to a ship in distress, or to a vessel in her regular course; but now, as he saw that this coast presented no good anchorage, he wished to seek on the south what they had not been able to find on the west.
children.prevalue: This was not included in their first plan In fact when the boat was abandoned at the sources of the Mercy it had been agreed that after having surveyed the west coast they should go back to it and return to Granite House by the Mercy Harding then thought that the western coast would have offered refuge either to a ship in distress or to a vessel in her regular course but now as he saw that this coast presented no good anchorage he wished to seek on the south what they had not been able to find on the west

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Gideon Spilett proposed to continue the exploration, that the question of the supposed wreck might be completely settled, and he asked at what distance Claw Cape might be from the extremity of the peninsula.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett proposed to continue the exploration that the question of the supposed wreck might be completely settled and he asked at what distance Claw Cape might be from the extremity of the peninsula

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: About thirty miles, replied the engineer, if we take into consideration the curvings of the coast.
children.prevalue: About thirty miles replied the engineer if we take into consideration the curvings of the coast

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Thirty miles! returned Spilett. That would be a long day's march. Nevertheless, I think that we should return to Granite House by the south coast.
children.prevalue: Thirty miles returned Spilett That would be a long day s march Nevertheless I think that we should return to Granite House by the south coast

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: But, observed Herbert, from Claw Cape to Granite House there must be at least another ten miles.
children.prevalue: But observed Herbert from Claw Cape to Granite House there must be at least another ten miles

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Make it forty miles in all, replied the engineer, and do not hesitate to do it. At least we should survey the unknown shore, and then we shall not have to begin the exploration again.
children.prevalue: Make it forty miles in all replied the engineer and do not hesitate to do it At least we should survey the unknown shore and then we shall not have to begin the exploration again

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Very good, said Pencroft. But the boat?
children.prevalue: Very good said Pencroft But the boat

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The boat has remained by itself for one day at the sources of the Mercy, replied Gideon Spilett; it may just as well stay there two days! As yet, we have had no reason to think that the island is infested by thieves!
children.prevalue: The boat has remained by itself for one day at the sources of the Mercy replied Gideon Spilett it may just as well stay there two days As yet we have had no reason to think that the island is infested by thieves

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yet, said the sailor, when I remember the history of the turtle, I am far from confident of that.
children.prevalue: Yet said the sailor when I remember the history of the turtle I am far from confident of that

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The turtle! the turtle! replied the reporter. Don't you know that the sea turned it over?
children.prevalue: The turtle the turtle replied the reporter Don t you know that the sea turned it over

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Who knows? murmured the engineer.
children.prevalue: Who knows murmured the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But,-- said Neb.
children.prevalue: But said Neb

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Neb had evidently something to say, for he opened his mouth to speak and yet said nothing.
children.prevalue: Neb had evidently something to say for he opened his mouth to speak and yet said nothing

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: What do you want to say, Neb? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: What do you want to say Neb asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: If we return by the shore to Claw Cape, replied Neb, after having doubled the Cape, we shall be stopped--
children.prevalue: If we return by the shore to Claw Cape replied Neb after having doubled the Cape we shall be stopped

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: By the Mercy! of course, replied Herbert, and we shall have neither bridge nor boat by which to cross.
children.prevalue: By the Mercy of course replied Herbert and we shall have neither bridge nor boat by which to cross

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But, captain, added Pencroft, with a few floating trunks we shall have no difficulty in crossing the river.
children.prevalue: But captain added Pencroft with a few floating trunks we shall have no difficulty in crossing the river

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Never mind, said Spilett, it will be useful to construct a bridge if we wish to have an easy access to the Far West!
children.prevalue: Never mind said Spilett it will be useful to construct a bridge if we wish to have an easy access to the Far West

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: A bridge! cried Pencroft. Well, is not the captain the best engineer in his profession? He will make us a bridge when we want one. As to transporting you this evening to the other side of the Mercy, and that without wetting one thread of your clothes, I will take care of that. We have provisions for another day, and besides we can get plenty of game. Forward!
children.prevalue: A bridge cried Pencroft Well is not the captain the best engineer in his profession He will make us a bridge when we want one As to transporting you this evening to the other side of the Mercy and that without wetting one thread of your clothes I will take care of that We have provisions for another day and besides we can get plenty of game Forward

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The reporter's proposal, so strongly seconded by the sailor, received general approbation, for each wished to have their doubts set at rest, and by returning by Claw Cape the exploration would be ended. But there was not an hour to lose, for forty miles was a long march, and they could not hope to reach Granite House before night.
children.prevalue: The reporter s proposal so strongly seconded by the sailor received general approbation for each wished to have their doubts set at rest and by returning by Claw Cape the exploration would be ended But there was not an hour to lose for forty miles was a long march and they could not hope to reach Granite House before night

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: At six o'clock in the morning the little band set out. As a precaution the guns were loaded with ball, and Top, who led the van, received orders to beat about the edge of the forest.
children.prevalue: At six o clock in the morning the little band set out As a precaution the guns were loaded with ball and Top who led the van received orders to beat about the edge of the forest

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: From the extremity of the promontory which formed the tail of the peninsula the coast was rounded for a distance of five miles, which was rapidly passed over, without even the most minute investigations bringing to light the least trace of any old or recent landings; no debris, no mark of an encampment, no cinders of a fire, nor even a footprint!
children.prevalue: From the extremity of the promontory which formed the tail of the peninsula the coast was rounded for a distance of five miles which was rapidly passed over without even the most minute investigations bringing to light the least trace of any old or recent landings no debris no mark of an encampment no cinders of a fire nor even a footprint

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: From the point of the peninsula on which the settlers now were their gaze could extend along the southwest. Twenty-five miles off the coast terminated in the Claw Cape, which loomed dimly through the morning mists, and which, by the phenomenon of the mirage, appeared as if suspended between land and water.
children.prevalue: From the point of the peninsula on which the settlers now were their gaze could extend along the southwest Twenty five miles off the coast terminated in the Claw Cape which loomed dimly through the morning mists and which by the phenomenon of the mirage appeared as if suspended between land and water

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Between the place occupied by the colonists and the other side of the immense bay, the shore was composed, first, of a tract of low land, bordered in the background by trees; then the shore became more irregular, projecting sharp points into the sea, and finally ended in the black rocks which, accumulated in picturesque disorder, formed Claw Cape.
children.prevalue: Between the place occupied by the colonists and the other side of the immense bay the shore was composed first of a tract of low land bordered in the background by trees then the shore became more irregular projecting sharp points into the sea and finally ended in the black rocks which accumulated in picturesque disorder formed Claw Cape

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Such was the development of this part of the island, which the settlers took in at a glance, while stopping for an instant.
children.prevalue: Such was the development of this part of the island which the settlers took in at a glance while stopping for an instant

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: If a vessel ran in here, said Pencroft, she would certainly be lost. Sandbanks and reefs everywhere! Bad quarters!
children.prevalue: If a vessel ran in here said Pencroft she would certainly be lost Sandbanks and reefs everywhere Bad quarters

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But at least something would be left of the ship, observed the reporter.
children.prevalue: But at least something would be left of the ship observed the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: There might be pieces of wood on the rocks, but nothing on the sands, replied the sailor.
children.prevalue: There might be pieces of wood on the rocks but nothing on the sands replied the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Because the sands are still more dangerous than the rocks, for they swallow up everything that is thrown on them. In a few days the hull of a ship of several hundred tons would disappear entirely in there!
children.prevalue: Because the sands are still more dangerous than the rocks for they swallow up everything that is thrown on them In a few days the hull of a ship of several hundred tons would disappear entirely in there

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: So, Pencroft, asked the engineer, if a ship has been wrecked on these banks, is it not astonishing that there is now no trace of her remaining?
children.prevalue: So Pencroft asked the engineer if a ship has been wrecked on these banks is it not astonishing that there is now no trace of her remaining

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: No, captain, with the aid of time and tempest. However, it would be surprising, even in this case, that some of the masts or spars should not have been thrown on the beach, out of reach of the waves.
children.prevalue: No captain with the aid of time and tempest However it would be surprising even in this case that some of the masts or spars should not have been thrown on the beach out of reach of the waves

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Let us go on with our search, then, returned Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Let us go on with our search then returned Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: At one o'clock the colonists arrived at the other side of Washington Bay, they having now gone a distance of twenty miles.
children.prevalue: At one o clock the colonists arrived at the other side of Washington Bay they having now gone a distance of twenty miles

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: They then halted for breakfast.
children.prevalue: They then halted for breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Here began the irregular coast, covered with lines of rocks and sandbanks. The long sea-swell could be seen breaking over the rocks in the bay, forming a foamy fringe. From this point to Claw Cape the beach was very narrow between the edge of the forest and the reefs.
children.prevalue: Here began the irregular coast covered with lines of rocks and sandbanks The long sea swell could be seen breaking over the rocks in the bay forming a foamy fringe From this point to Claw Cape the beach was very narrow between the edge of the forest and the reefs

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Walking was now more difficult, on account of the numerous rocks which encumbered the beach. The granite cliff also gradually increased in height, and only the green tops of the trees which crowned it could be seen.
children.prevalue: Walking was now more difficult on account of the numerous rocks which encumbered the beach The granite cliff also gradually increased in height and only the green tops of the trees which crowned it could be seen

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: After half an hour's rest, the settlers resumed their journey, and not a spot among the rocks was left unexamined. Pencroft and Neb even rushed into the surf whenever any object attracted their attention. But they found nothing, some curious formations of the rocks having deceived them. They ascertained, however, that eatable shellfish abounded there, but these could not be of any great advantage to them until some easy means of communication had been established between the two banks of the Mercy, and until the means of transport had been perfected.
children.prevalue: After half an hour s rest the settlers resumed their journey and not a spot among the rocks was left unexamined Pencroft and Neb even rushed into the surf whenever any object attracted their attention But they found nothing some curious formations of the rocks having deceived them They ascertained however that eatable shellfish abounded there but these could not be of any great advantage to them until some easy means of communication had been established between the two banks of the Mercy and until the means of transport had been perfected

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Nothing therefore which threw any light on the supposed wreck could be found on this shore, yet an object of any importance, such as the hull of a ship, would have been seen directly, or any of her masts and spars would have been washed on shore, just as the chest had been, which was found twenty miles from here. But there was nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing therefore which threw any light on the supposed wreck could be found on this shore yet an object of any importance such as the hull of a ship would have been seen directly or any of her masts and spars would have been washed on shore just as the chest had been which was found twenty miles from here But there was nothing

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Towards three o'clock Harding and his companions arrived at a snug little creek. It formed quite a natural harbor, invisible from the sea, and was entered by a narrow channel.
children.prevalue: Towards three o clock Harding and his companions arrived at a snug little creek It formed quite a natural harbor invisible from the sea and was entered by a narrow channel

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: At the back of this creek some violent convulsion had torn up the rocky border, and a cutting, by a gentle slope, gave access to an upper plateau, which might be situated at least ten miles from Claw Cape, and consequently four miles in a straight line from Prospect Heights. Gideon Spilett proposed to his companions that they should make a halt here. They agreed readily, for their walk had sharpened their appetites; and although it was not their usual dinner-hour, no one refused to strengthen himself with a piece of venison. This luncheon would sustain them until their supper, which they intended to take at Granite House. In a few minutes the settlers, seated under a clump of fine sea-pines, were devouring the provisions which Neb produced from his bag.
children.prevalue: At the back of this creek some violent convulsion had torn up the rocky border and a cutting by a gentle slope gave access to an upper plateau which might be situated at least ten miles from Claw Cape and consequently four miles in a straight line from Prospect Heights Gideon Spilett proposed to his companions that they should make a halt here They agreed readily for their walk had sharpened their appetites and although it was not their usual dinner hour no one refused to strengthen himself with a piece of venison This luncheon would sustain them until their supper which they intended to take at Granite House In a few minutes the settlers seated under a clump of fine sea pines were devouring the provisions which Neb produced from his bag

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: This spot was raised from fifty to sixty feet above the level of the sea. The view was very extensive, but beyond the cape it ended in Union Bay. Neither the islet nor Prospect Heights was visible, and could not be from thence, for the rising ground and the curtain of trees closed the northern horizon.
children.prevalue: This spot was raised from fifty to sixty feet above the level of the sea The view was very extensive but beyond the cape it ended in Union Bay Neither the islet nor Prospect Heights was visible and could not be from thence for the rising ground and the curtain of trees closed the northern horizon

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It is useless to add that notwithstanding the wide extent of sea which the explorers could survey, and though the engineer swept the horizon with his glass, no vessel could be found.
children.prevalue: It is useless to add that notwithstanding the wide extent of sea which the explorers could survey and though the engineer swept the horizon with his glass no vessel could be found

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The shore was of course examined with the same care from the edge of the water to the cliff, and nothing could be discovered even with the aid of the instrument.
children.prevalue: The shore was of course examined with the same care from the edge of the water to the cliff and nothing could be discovered even with the aid of the instrument

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Well, said Gideon Spilett, it seems we must make up our minds to console ourselves with thinking that no one will come to dispute with us the possession of Lincoln Island!
children.prevalue: Well said Gideon Spilett it seems we must make up our minds to console ourselves with thinking that no one will come to dispute with us the possession of Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: But the bullet, cried Herbert. That was not imaginary, I suppose!
children.prevalue: But the bullet cried Herbert That was not imaginary I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Hang it, no! exclaimed Pencroft, thinking of his absent tooth.
children.prevalue: Hang it no exclaimed Pencroft thinking of his absent tooth

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Then what conclusion may be drawn? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: Then what conclusion may be drawn asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: This, replied the engineer, that three months or more ago, a vessel, either voluntarily or not, came here.
children.prevalue: This replied the engineer that three months or more ago a vessel either voluntarily or not came here

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What! then you admit, Cyrus, that she was swallowed up without leaving any trace? cried the reporter.
children.prevalue: What then you admit Cyrus that she was swallowed up without leaving any trace cried the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: No, my dear Spilett; but you see that if it is certain that a human being set foot on the island, it appears no less certain that he has now left it.
children.prevalue: No my dear Spilett but you see that if it is certain that a human being set foot on the island it appears no less certain that he has now left it

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Then, if I understand you right, captain, said Herbert, the vessel has left again?
children.prevalue: Then if I understand you right captain said Herbert the vessel has left again

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Evidently.
children.prevalue: Evidently

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And we have lost an opportunity to get back to our country? said Neb.
children.prevalue: And we have lost an opportunity to get back to our country said Neb

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I fear so.
children.prevalue: I fear so

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Very well, since the opportunity is lost, let us go on; it can't be helped, said Pencroft, who felt home-sickness for Granite House.
children.prevalue: Very well since the opportunity is lost let us go on it can t be helped said Pencroft who felt home sickness for Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: But just as they were rising, Top was heard loudly barking; and the dog issued from the wood, holding in his mouth a rag soiled with mud.
children.prevalue: But just as they were rising Top was heard loudly barking and the dog issued from the wood holding in his mouth a rag soiled with mud

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Neb seized it. It was a piece of strong cloth!
children.prevalue: Neb seized it It was a piece of strong cloth

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Top still barked, and by his going and coming, seemed to invite his master to follow him into the forest.
children.prevalue: Top still barked and by his going and coming seemed to invite his master to follow him into the forest

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Now there's something to explain the bullet! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Now there s something to explain the bullet exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: A castaway! replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: A castaway replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Wounded, perhaps! said Neb.
children.prevalue: Wounded perhaps said Neb

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Or dead! added the reporter.
children.prevalue: Or dead added the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: All ran after the dog, among the tall pines on the border of the forest. Harding and his companions made ready their firearms, in case of an emergency.
children.prevalue: All ran after the dog among the tall pines on the border of the forest Harding and his companions made ready their firearms in case of an emergency

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: They advanced some way into the wood, but to their great disappointment, they as yet saw no signs of any human being having passed that way. Shrubs and creepers were uninjured, and they had even to cut them away with the axe, as they had done in the deepest recesses of the forest. It was difficult to fancy that any human creature had ever passed there, but yet Top went backward and forward, not like a dog who searches at random, but like a dog being endowed with a mind, who is following up an idea.
children.prevalue: They advanced some way into the wood but to their great disappointment they as yet saw no signs of any human being having passed that way Shrubs and creepers were uninjured and they had even to cut them away with the axe as they had done in the deepest recesses of the forest It was difficult to fancy that any human creature had ever passed there but yet Top went backward and forward not like a dog who searches at random but like a dog being endowed with a mind who is following up an idea

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: In about seven or eight minutes Top stopped in a glade surrounded with tall trees. The settlers gazed around them, but saw nothing, neither under the bushes nor among the trees.
children.prevalue: In about seven or eight minutes Top stopped in a glade surrounded with tall trees The settlers gazed around them but saw nothing neither under the bushes nor among the trees

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: What is the matter, Top? said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: What is the matter Top said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Top barked louder, bounding about at the foot of a gigantic pine. All at once Pencroft shouted,--Ho, splendid! capital!
children.prevalue: Top barked louder bounding about at the foot of a gigantic pine All at once Pencroft shouted Ho splendid capital

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: What is it? asked Spilett.
children.prevalue: What is it asked Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: We have been looking for a wreck at sea or on land!
children.prevalue: We have been looking for a wreck at sea or on land

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Well; and here we've found one in the air!
children.prevalue: Well and here we ve found one in the air

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: And the sailor pointed to a great white rag, caught in the top of the pine, a fallen scrap of which the dog had brought to them.
children.prevalue: And the sailor pointed to a great white rag caught in the top of the pine a fallen scrap of which the dog had brought to them

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But that is not a wreck! cried Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: But that is not a wreck cried Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I beg your pardon! returned Pencroft.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon returned Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Why? is it--?
children.prevalue: Why is it

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: It is all that remains of our airy boat, of our balloon, which has been caught up aloft there, at the top of that tree!
children.prevalue: It is all that remains of our airy boat of our balloon which has been caught up aloft there at the top of that tree

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Pencroft was not mistaken, and he gave vent to his feelings in a tremendous hurrah, adding,--
children.prevalue: Pencroft was not mistaken and he gave vent to his feelings in a tremendous hurrah adding

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: There is good cloth! There is what will furnish us with linen for years. There is what will make us handkerchiefs and shirts! Ha, ha, Mr. Spilett, what do you say to an island where shirts grow on the trees?
children.prevalue: There is good cloth There is what will furnish us with linen for years There is what will make us handkerchiefs and shirts Ha ha Mr Spilett what do you say to an island where shirts grow on the trees

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: It was certainly a lucky circumstance for the settlers in Lincoln Island that the balloon, after having made its last bound into the air, had fallen on the island and thus given them the opportunity of finding it again, whether they kept the case under its present form, or whether they wished to attempt another escape by it, or whether they usefully employed the several hundred yards of cotton, which was of fine quality. Pencroft's joy was therefore shared by all.
children.prevalue: It was certainly a lucky circumstance for the settlers in Lincoln Island that the balloon after having made its last bound into the air had fallen on the island and thus given them the opportunity of finding it again whether they kept the case under its present form or whether they wished to attempt another escape by it or whether they usefully employed the several hundred yards of cotton which was of fine quality Pencroft s joy was therefore shared by all

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: But it was necessary to bring down the remains of the balloon from the tree, to place it in security, and this was no slight task. Neb, Herbert, and the sailor, climbing to the summit of the tree, used all their skill to disengage the now reduced balloon.
children.prevalue: But it was necessary to bring down the remains of the balloon from the tree to place it in security and this was no slight task Neb Herbert and the sailor climbing to the summit of the tree used all their skill to disengage the now reduced balloon

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The operation lasted two hours, and then not only the case, with its valve, its springs, its brasswork, lay on the ground, but the net, that is to say a considerable quantity of ropes and cordage, and the circle and the anchor. The case, except for the fracture, was in good condition, only the lower portion being torn.
children.prevalue: The operation lasted two hours and then not only the case with its valve its springs its brasswork lay on the ground but the net that is to say a considerable quantity of ropes and cordage and the circle and the anchor The case except for the fracture was in good condition only the lower portion being torn

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: It was a fortune which had fallen from the sky.
children.prevalue: It was a fortune which had fallen from the sky

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: All the same, captain, said the sailor, if we ever decide to leave the island, it won't be in a balloon, will it? These airboats won't go where we want them to go, and we have had some experience in that way! Look here, we will build a craft of some twenty tons, and then we can make a main-sail, a foresail, and a jib out of that cloth. As to the rest of it, that will help to dress us.
children.prevalue: All the same captain said the sailor if we ever decide to leave the island it won t be in a balloon will it These airboats won t go where we want them to go and we have had some experience in that way Look here we will build a craft of some twenty tons and then we can make a main sail a foresail and a jib out of that cloth As to the rest of it that will help to dress us

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: We shall see, Pencroft, replied Cyrus Harding; we shall see.
children.prevalue: We shall see Pencroft replied Cyrus Harding we shall see

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: In the meantime, we must put it in a safe place, said Neb.
children.prevalue: In the meantime we must put it in a safe place said Neb

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: They certainly could not think of carrying this load of cloth, ropes, and cordage, to Granite House, for the weight of it was very considerable, and while waiting for a suitable vehicle in which to convey it, it was of importance that this treasure should not be left longer exposed to the mercies of the first storm. The settlers, uniting their efforts, managed to drag it as far as the shore, where they discovered a large rocky cavity, which owing to its position could not be visited either by the wind or rain.
children.prevalue: They certainly could not think of carrying this load of cloth ropes and cordage to Granite House for the weight of it was very considerable and while waiting for a suitable vehicle in which to convey it it was of importance that this treasure should not be left longer exposed to the mercies of the first storm The settlers uniting their efforts managed to drag it as far as the shore where they discovered a large rocky cavity which owing to its position could not be visited either by the wind or rain

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: We needed a locker, and now we have one, said Pencroft; but as we cannot lock it up, it will be prudent to hide the opening. I don't mean from two-legged thieves, but from those with four paws!
children.prevalue: We needed a locker and now we have one said Pencroft but as we cannot lock it up it will be prudent to hide the opening I don t mean from two legged thieves but from those with four paws

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: At six o'clock, all was stowed away, and after having given the creek the very suitable name of Port Balloon, the settlers pursued their way along Claw Cape. Pencroft and the engineer talked of the different projects which it was agreed to put into execution with the briefest possible delay. It was necessary first of all to throw a bridge over the Mercy, so as to establish an easy communication with the south of the island; then the cart must be taken to bring back the balloon, for the canoe alone could not carry it, then they would build a decked boat, and Pencroft would rig it as a cutter, and they would be able to undertake voyages of circumnavigation round the island, etc.
children.prevalue: At six o clock all was stowed away and after having given the creek the very suitable name of Port Balloon the settlers pursued their way along Claw Cape Pencroft and the engineer talked of the different projects which it was agreed to put into execution with the briefest possible delay It was necessary first of all to throw a bridge over the Mercy so as to establish an easy communication with the south of the island then the cart must be taken to bring back the balloon for the canoe alone could not carry it then they would build a decked boat and Pencroft would rig it as a cutter and they would be able to undertake voyages of circumnavigation round the island etc

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: In the meanwhile night came on, and it was already dark when the settlers reached Flotsam Point, where they had found the precious chest.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile night came on and it was already dark when the settlers reached Flotsam Point where they had found the precious chest

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The distance between Flotsam Point and Granite House was another four miles, and it was midnight when, after having followed the shore to the mouth of the Mercy, the settlers arrived at the first angle formed by the Mercy.
children.prevalue: The distance between Flotsam Point and Granite House was another four miles and it was midnight when after having followed the shore to the mouth of the Mercy the settlers arrived at the first angle formed by the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: There the river was eighty feet in breadth, which was awkward to cross, but as Pencroft had taken upon himself to conquer this difficulty, he was compelled to do it. The settlers certainly had reason to be pretty tired. The journey had been long, and the task of getting down the balloon had not rested either their arms or legs. They were anxious to reach Granite House to eat and sleep, and if the bridge had been constructed, in a quarter of an hour they would have been at home.
children.prevalue: There the river was eighty feet in breadth which was awkward to cross but as Pencroft had taken upon himself to conquer this difficulty he was compelled to do it The settlers certainly had reason to be pretty tired The journey had been long and the task of getting down the balloon had not rested either their arms or legs They were anxious to reach Granite House to eat and sleep and if the bridge had been constructed in a quarter of an hour they would have been at home

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: The night was very dark. Pencroft prepared to keep his promise by constructing a sort of raft, on which to make the passage of the Mercy. He and Neb, armed with axes, chose two trees near the water, and began to attack them at the base.
children.prevalue: The night was very dark Pencroft prepared to keep his promise by constructing a sort of raft on which to make the passage of the Mercy He and Neb armed with axes chose two trees near the water and began to attack them at the base

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Spilett, seated on the bank, waited till their companions were ready for their help, while Herbert roamed about, though without going to any distance. All at once, the lad, who had strolled by the river, came running back, and, pointing up the Mercy, exclaimed,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Spilett seated on the bank waited till their companions were ready for their help while Herbert roamed about though without going to any distance All at once the lad who had strolled by the river came running back and pointing up the Mercy exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: What is floating there?
children.prevalue: What is floating there

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Pencroft stopped working, and seeing an indistinct object moving through the gloom,--
children.prevalue: Pencroft stopped working and seeing an indistinct object moving through the gloom

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: A canoe! cried he.
children.prevalue: A canoe cried he

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: All approached, and saw to their extreme surprise, a boat floating down the current.
children.prevalue: All approached and saw to their extreme surprise a boat floating down the current

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Boat ahoy! shouted the sailor, without thinking that perhaps it would be best to keep silence.
children.prevalue: Boat ahoy shouted the sailor without thinking that perhaps it would be best to keep silence

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: No reply. The boat still drifted onward, and it was not more than twelve feet off, when the sailor exclaimed,--
children.prevalue: No reply The boat still drifted onward and it was not more than twelve feet off when the sailor exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: But it is our own boat! she has broken her moorings, and floated down the current. I must say she has arrived very opportunely.
children.prevalue: But it is our own boat she has broken her moorings and floated down the current I must say she has arrived very opportunely

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Our boat? murmured the engineer.
children.prevalue: Our boat murmured the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Pencroft was right. It was indeed the canoe, of which the rope had undoubtedly broken, and which had come alone from the sources of the Mercy. It was very important to seize it before the rapid current should have swept it away out of the mouth of the river, but Neb and Pencroft cleverly managed this by means of a long pole.
children.prevalue: Pencroft was right It was indeed the canoe of which the rope had undoubtedly broken and which had come alone from the sources of the Mercy It was very important to seize it before the rapid current should have swept it away out of the mouth of the river but Neb and Pencroft cleverly managed this by means of a long pole

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: The canoe touched the shore. The engineer leaped in first, and found, on examining the rope, that it had been really worn through by rubbing against the rocks.
children.prevalue: The canoe touched the shore The engineer leaped in first and found on examining the rope that it had been really worn through by rubbing against the rocks

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Well, said the reporter to him, in a low voice, this is a strange thing.
children.prevalue: Well said the reporter to him in a low voice this is a strange thing

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Strange indeed! returned Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Strange indeed returned Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Strange or not, it was very fortunate. Herbert, the reporter, Neb, and Pencroft, embarked in turn. There was no doubt about the rope having been worn through, but the astonishing part of the affair was, that the boat should arrive just at the moment when the settlers were there to seize it on its way, for a quarter of an hour earlier or later it would have been lost in the sea.
children.prevalue: Strange or not it was very fortunate Herbert the reporter Neb and Pencroft embarked in turn There was no doubt about the rope having been worn through but the astonishing part of the affair was that the boat should arrive just at the moment when the settlers were there to seize it on its way for a quarter of an hour earlier or later it would have been lost in the sea

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: If they had been living in the time of genii, this incident would have given them the right to think that the island was haunted by some supernatural being, who used his power in the service of the castaways!
children.prevalue: If they had been living in the time of genii this incident would have given them the right to think that the island was haunted by some supernatural being who used his power in the service of the castaways

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: A few strokes of the oar brought the settlers to the mouth of the Mercy. The canoe was hauled up on the beach near the Chimneys, and all proceeded towards the ladder of Granite House.
children.prevalue: A few strokes of the oar brought the settlers to the mouth of the Mercy The canoe was hauled up on the beach near the Chimneys and all proceeded towards the ladder of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: But at that moment, Top barked angrily, and Neb, who was looking for the first steps, uttered a cry.
children.prevalue: But at that moment Top barked angrily and Neb who was looking for the first steps uttered a cry

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: There was no longer a ladder!
children.prevalue: There was no longer a ladder

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Cyrus Harding stood still, without saying a word. His companions searched in the darkness on the wall, in case the wind should have moved the ladder, and on the ground, thinking that it might have fallen down.... But the ladder had quite disappeared. As to ascertaining if a squall had blown it on the landing-place, half way up, that was impossible in the dark.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding stood still without saying a word His companions searched in the darkness on the wall in case the wind should have moved the ladder and on the ground thinking that it might have fallen down But the ladder had quite disappeared As to ascertaining if a squall had blown it on the landing place half way up that was impossible in the dark

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: If it is a joke, cried Pencroft, it is a very stupid one! To come home and find no staircase to go up to your room by--that's nothing for weary men to laugh at.
children.prevalue: If it is a joke cried Pencroft it is a very stupid one To come home and find no staircase to go up to your room by that s nothing for weary men to laugh at

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Neb could do nothing but cry out Oh! oh! oh!
children.prevalue: Neb could do nothing but cry out Oh oh oh

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I begin to think that very curious things happen in Lincoln Island! said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: I begin to think that very curious things happen in Lincoln Island said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Curious? replied Gideon Spilett, not at all, Pencroft, nothing can be more natural. Some one has come during our absence, taken possession of our dwelling and drawn up the ladder.
children.prevalue: Curious replied Gideon Spilett not at all Pencroft nothing can be more natural Some one has come during our absence taken possession of our dwelling and drawn up the ladder

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Some one, cried the sailor. But who?
children.prevalue: Some one cried the sailor But who

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Who but the hunter who fired the bullet? replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: Who but the hunter who fired the bullet replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well, if there is any one up there, replied Pencroft, who began to lose patience, I will give them a hail, and they must answer.
children.prevalue: Well if there is any one up there replied Pencroft who began to lose patience I will give them a hail and they must answer

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And in a stentorian voice the sailor gave a prolonged Halloo! which was echoed again and again from the cliff and rocks.
children.prevalue: And in a stentorian voice the sailor gave a prolonged Halloo which was echoed again and again from the cliff and rocks

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The settlers listened and they thought they heard a sort of chuckling laugh, of which they could not guess the origin. But no voice replied to Pencroft, who in vain repeated his vigorous shouts.
children.prevalue: The settlers listened and they thought they heard a sort of chuckling laugh of which they could not guess the origin But no voice replied to Pencroft who in vain repeated his vigorous shouts

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: There was something indeed in this to astonish the most apathetic of men, and the settlers were not men of that description. In their situation every incident had its importance, and, certainly, during the seven months which they had spent on the island, they had not before met with anything of so surprising a character.
children.prevalue: There was something indeed in this to astonish the most apathetic of men and the settlers were not men of that description In their situation every incident had its importance and certainly during the seven months which they had spent on the island they had not before met with anything of so surprising a character

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Be that as it may, forgetting their fatigue in the singularity of the event, they remained below Granite House, not knowing what to think, not knowing what to do, questioning each other without any hope of a satisfactory reply, every one starting some supposition each more unlikely than the last. Neb bewailed himself, much disappointed at not being able to get into his kitchen, for the provisions which they had had on their expedition were exhausted, and they had no means of renewing them.
children.prevalue: Be that as it may forgetting their fatigue in the singularity of the event they remained below Granite House not knowing what to think not knowing what to do questioning each other without any hope of a satisfactory reply every one starting some supposition each more unlikely than the last Neb bewailed himself much disappointed at not being able to get into his kitchen for the provisions which they had had on their expedition were exhausted and they had no means of renewing them

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: My friends, at last said Cyrus Harding, there is only one thing to be done at present; wait for day, and then act according to circumstances. But let us go to the Chimneys. There we shall be under shelter, and if we cannot eat, we can at least sleep.
children.prevalue: My friends at last said Cyrus Harding there is only one thing to be done at present wait for day and then act according to circumstances But let us go to the Chimneys There we shall be under shelter and if we cannot eat we can at least sleep

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But who is it that has played us this cool trick? again asked Pencroft, unable to make up his mind to retire from the spot.
children.prevalue: But who is it that has played us this cool trick again asked Pencroft unable to make up his mind to retire from the spot

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Whoever it was, the only thing practicable was to do as the engineer proposed, to go to the Chimneys and there wait for day. In the meanwhile Top was ordered to mount guard below the windows of Granite House, and when Top received an order he obeyed it without any questioning. The brave dog therefore remained at the foot of the cliff while his master with his companions sought a refuge among the rocks.
children.prevalue: Whoever it was the only thing practicable was to do as the engineer proposed to go to the Chimneys and there wait for day In the meanwhile Top was ordered to mount guard below the windows of Granite House and when Top received an order he obeyed it without any questioning The brave dog therefore remained at the foot of the cliff while his master with his companions sought a refuge among the rocks

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: To say that the settlers, notwithstanding their fatigue, slept well on the sandy floor of the Chimneys would not be true. It was not only that they were extremely anxious to find out the cause of what had happened, whether it was the result of an accident which would be discovered at the return of day, or whether on the contrary it was the work of a human being; but they also had very uncomfortable beds. That could not be helped, however, for in some way or other at that moment their dwelling was occupied, and they could not possibly enter it.
