children.prevalue: To say that the settlers notwithstanding their fatigue slept well on the sandy floor of the Chimneys would not be true It was not only that they were extremely anxious to find out the cause of what had happened whether it was the result of an accident which would be discovered at the return of day or whether on the contrary it was the work of a human being but they also had very uncomfortable beds That could not be helped however for in some way or other at that moment their dwelling was occupied and they could not possibly enter it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Now Granite House was more than their dwelling, it was their warehouse. There were all the stores belonging to the colony, weapons, instruments, tools, ammunition, provisions, etc. To think that all that might be pillaged and that the settlers would have all their work to do over again, fresh weapons and tools to make, was a serious matter. Their uneasiness led one or other of them also to go out every few minutes to see if Top was keeping good watch. Cyrus Harding alone waited with his habitual patience, although his strong mind was exasperated at being confronted with such an inexplicable fact, and he was provoked at himself for allowing a feeling to which he could not give a name, to gain an influence over him. Gideon Spilett shared his feelings in this respect, and the two conversed together in whispers of the inexplicable circumstance which baffled even their intelligence and experience.
children.prevalue: Now Granite House was more than their dwelling it was their warehouse There were all the stores belonging to the colony weapons instruments tools ammunition provisions etc To think that all that might be pillaged and that the settlers would have all their work to do over again fresh weapons and tools to make was a serious matter Their uneasiness led one or other of them also to go out every few minutes to see if Top was keeping good watch Cyrus Harding alone waited with his habitual patience although his strong mind was exasperated at being confronted with such an inexplicable fact and he was provoked at himself for allowing a feeling to which he could not give a name to gain an influence over him Gideon Spilett shared his feelings in this respect and the two conversed together in whispers of the inexplicable circumstance which baffled even their intelligence and experience

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It is a joke, said Pencroft; it is a trick some one has played us. Well, I don't like such jokes, and the joker had better look out for himself, if he falls into my hands, I can tell him.
children.prevalue: It is a joke said Pencroft it is a trick some one has played us Well I don t like such jokes and the joker had better look out for himself if he falls into my hands I can tell him

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: As soon as the first gleam of light appeared in the east, the colonists, suitably armed, repaired to the beach under Granite House. The rising sun now shone on the cliff and they could see the windows, the shutters of which were closed, through the curtains of foliage.
children.prevalue: As soon as the first gleam of light appeared in the east the colonists suitably armed repaired to the beach under Granite House The rising sun now shone on the cliff and they could see the windows the shutters of which were closed through the curtains of foliage

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: All here was in order; but a cry escaped the colonists when they saw that the door, which they had closed on their departure, was now wide open.
children.prevalue: All here was in order but a cry escaped the colonists when they saw that the door which they had closed on their departure was now wide open

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Some one had entered Granite House--there could be no more doubt about that.
children.prevalue: Some one had entered Granite House there could be no more doubt about that

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The upper ladder, which generally hung from the door to the landing, was in its place, but the lower ladder was drawn up and raised to the threshold. It was evident that the intruders had wished to guard themselves against a surprise.
children.prevalue: The upper ladder which generally hung from the door to the landing was in its place but the lower ladder was drawn up and raised to the threshold It was evident that the intruders had wished to guard themselves against a surprise

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Pencroft hailed again.
children.prevalue: Pencroft hailed again

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: No reply.
children.prevalue: No reply

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The beggars, exclaimed the sailor. There they are sleeping quietly as if they were in their own house. Hallo there, you pirates, brigands, robbers, sons of John Bull!
children.prevalue: The beggars exclaimed the sailor There they are sleeping quietly as if they were in their own house Hallo there you pirates brigands robbers sons of John Bull

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: When Pencroft, being a Yankee, treated any one to the epithet of son of John Bull, he considered he had reached the last limits of insult.
children.prevalue: When Pencroft being a Yankee treated any one to the epithet of son of John Bull he considered he had reached the last limits of insult

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The sun had now completely risen, and the whole facade of Granite House became illuminated by its rays; but in the interior as well as on the exterior all was quiet and calm.
children.prevalue: The sun had now completely risen and the whole facade of Granite House became illuminated by its rays but in the interior as well as on the exterior all was quiet and calm

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The settlers asked if Granite House was inhabited or not, and yet the position of the ladder was sufficient to show that it was; it was also certain that the inhabitants, whoever they might be, had not been able to escape. But how were they to be got at?
children.prevalue: The settlers asked if Granite House was inhabited or not and yet the position of the ladder was sufficient to show that it was it was also certain that the inhabitants whoever they might be had not been able to escape But how were they to be got at

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Herbert then thought of fastening a cord to an arrow, and shooting the arrow so that it should pass between the first rounds of the ladder which hung from the threshold. By means of the cord they would then be able to draw down the ladder to the ground, and so re-establish the communication between the beach and Granite House. There was evidently nothing else to be done, and, with a little skill, this method might succeed. Very fortunately bows and arrows had been left at the Chimneys, where they also found a quantity of light hibiscus cord. Pencroft fastened this to a well-feathered arrow. Then Herbert fixing it to his bow, took a careful aim for the lower part of the ladder.
children.prevalue: Herbert then thought of fastening a cord to an arrow and shooting the arrow so that it should pass between the first rounds of the ladder which hung from the threshold By means of the cord they would then be able to draw down the ladder to the ground and so re establish the communication between the beach and Granite House There was evidently nothing else to be done and with a little skill this method might succeed Very fortunately bows and arrows had been left at the Chimneys where they also found a quantity of light hibiscus cord Pencroft fastened this to a well feathered arrow Then Herbert fixing it to his bow took a careful aim for the lower part of the ladder

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Neb drew back, so as to see if anything appeared at the windows. The reporter lifted his gun to his shoulder and covered the door.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett Pencroft and Neb drew back so as to see if anything appeared at the windows The reporter lifted his gun to his shoulder and covered the door

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The bow was bent, the arrow flew, taking the cord with it, and passed between the two last rounds.
children.prevalue: The bow was bent the arrow flew taking the cord with it and passed between the two last rounds

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The operation had succeeded.
children.prevalue: The operation had succeeded

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Herbert immediately seized the end of the cord, but, at that moment when he gave it a pull to bring down the ladder, an arm, thrust suddenly out between the wall and the door, grasped it and dragged it inside Granite House.
children.prevalue: Herbert immediately seized the end of the cord but at that moment when he gave it a pull to bring down the ladder an arm thrust suddenly out between the wall and the door grasped it and dragged it inside Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The rascals! shouted the sailor. If a ball can do anything for you, you shall not have long to wait for it.
children.prevalue: The rascals shouted the sailor If a ball can do anything for you you shall not have long to wait for it

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: But who was it? asked Neb.
children.prevalue: But who was it asked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Who was it? Didn't you see?
children.prevalue: Who was it Didn t you see

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It was a monkey, a sapajou, an orangoutang, a baboon, a gorilla, a sagoin. Our dwelling has been invaded by monkeys, who climbed up the ladder during our absence.
children.prevalue: It was a monkey a sapajou an orangoutang a baboon a gorilla a sagoin Our dwelling has been invaded by monkeys who climbed up the ladder during our absence

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And, at this moment, as if to bear witness to the truth of the sailor's words, two or three quadrumana showed themselves at the windows, from which they had pushed back the shutters, and saluted the real proprietors of the place with a thousand hideous grimaces.
children.prevalue: And at this moment as if to bear witness to the truth of the sailor s words two or three quadrumana showed themselves at the windows from which they had pushed back the shutters and saluted the real proprietors of the place with a thousand hideous grimaces

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I knew that it was only a joke, cried Pencroft; but one of the jokers shall pay the penalty for the rest.
children.prevalue: I knew that it was only a joke cried Pencroft but one of the jokers shall pay the penalty for the rest

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: So saying, the sailor, raising his piece, took a rapid aim at one of the monkeys and fired. All disappeared, except one who fell mortally wounded on the beach. This monkey, which was of a large size, evidently belonged to the first order of the quadrumana. Whether this was a chimpanzee, an orangoutang, or a gorilla, he took rank among the anthropoid apes, who are so called from their resemblance to the human race. However, Herbert declared it to be an orangoutang.
children.prevalue: So saying the sailor raising his piece took a rapid aim at one of the monkeys and fired All disappeared except one who fell mortally wounded on the beach This monkey which was of a large size evidently belonged to the first order of the quadrumana Whether this was a chimpanzee an orangoutang or a gorilla he took rank among the anthropoid apes who are so called from their resemblance to the human race However Herbert declared it to be an orangoutang

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: What a magnificent beast! cried Neb.
children.prevalue: What a magnificent beast cried Neb

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Magnificent, if you like, replied Pencroft; but still I do not see how we are to get into our house.
children.prevalue: Magnificent if you like replied Pencroft but still I do not see how we are to get into our house

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Herbert is a good marksman, said the reporter, and his bow is here. He can try again.
children.prevalue: Herbert is a good marksman said the reporter and his bow is here He can try again

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Why, these apes are so cunning, returned Pencroft; they won't show themselves again at the windows and so we can't kill them; and when I think of the mischief they may do in the rooms and storehouse--
children.prevalue: Why these apes are so cunning returned Pencroft they won t show themselves again at the windows and so we can t kill them and when I think of the mischief they may do in the rooms and storehouse

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Have patience, replied Harding; these creatures cannot keep us long at bay.
children.prevalue: Have patience replied Harding these creatures cannot keep us long at bay

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I shall not be sure of that till I see them down here, replied the sailor. And now, captain, do you know how many dozens of these fellows are up there?
children.prevalue: I shall not be sure of that till I see them down here replied the sailor And now captain do you know how many dozens of these fellows are up there

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It was difficult to reply to Pencroft, and as for the young boy making another attempt, that was not easy; for the lower part of the ladder had been drawn again into the door, and when another pull was given, the line broke and the ladder remained firm. The case was really perplexing. Pencroft stormed. There was a comic side to the situation, but he did not think it funny at all. It was certain that the settlers would end by reinstating themselves in their domicile and driving out the intruders, but when and how? this is what they were not able to say.
children.prevalue: It was difficult to reply to Pencroft and as for the young boy making another attempt that was not easy for the lower part of the ladder had been drawn again into the door and when another pull was given the line broke and the ladder remained firm The case was really perplexing Pencroft stormed There was a comic side to the situation but he did not think it funny at all It was certain that the settlers would end by reinstating themselves in their domicile and driving out the intruders but when and how this is what they were not able to say

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Two hours passed, during which the apes took care not to show themselves, but they were still there, and three or four times a nose or a paw was poked out at the door or windows, and was immediately saluted by a gun-shot.
children.prevalue: Two hours passed during which the apes took care not to show themselves but they were still there and three or four times a nose or a paw was poked out at the door or windows and was immediately saluted by a gun shot

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Let us hide ourselves, at last said the engineer. Perhaps the apes will think we have gone quite away and will show themselves again. Let Spilett and Herbert conceal themselves behind those rocks and fire on all that may appear.
children.prevalue: Let us hide ourselves at last said the engineer Perhaps the apes will think we have gone quite away and will show themselves again Let Spilett and Herbert conceal themselves behind those rocks and fire on all that may appear

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The engineer's orders were obeyed, and while the reporter and the lad, the best marksmen in the colony, posted themselves in a good position, but out of the monkeys' sight, Neb, Pencroft, and Cyrus climbed the plateau and entered the forest in order to kill some game, for it was now time for breakfast and they had no provisions remaining.
children.prevalue: The engineer s orders were obeyed and while the reporter and the lad the best marksmen in the colony posted themselves in a good position but out of the monkeys sight Neb Pencroft and Cyrus climbed the plateau and entered the forest in order to kill some game for it was now time for breakfast and they had no provisions remaining

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: In half an hour the hunters returned with a few rock pigeons, which they roasted as well as they could. Not an ape had appeared. Gideon Spilett and Herbert went to take their share of the breakfast, leaving Top to watch under the windows. They then, having eaten, returned to their post.
children.prevalue: In half an hour the hunters returned with a few rock pigeons which they roasted as well as they could Not an ape had appeared Gideon Spilett and Herbert went to take their share of the breakfast leaving Top to watch under the windows They then having eaten returned to their post

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Two hours later, their situation was in no degree improved. The quadrumana gave no sign of existence, and it might have been supposed that they had disappeared; but what seemed more probable was that, terrified by the death of one of their companions, and frightened by the noise of the firearms, they had retreated to the back part of the house or probably even into the store-room. And when they thought of the valuables which this storeroom contained, the patience so much recommended by the engineer, fast changed into great irritation, and there certainly was room for it.
children.prevalue: Two hours later their situation was in no degree improved The quadrumana gave no sign of existence and it might have been supposed that they had disappeared but what seemed more probable was that terrified by the death of one of their companions and frightened by the noise of the firearms they had retreated to the back part of the house or probably even into the store room And when they thought of the valuables which this storeroom contained the patience so much recommended by the engineer fast changed into great irritation and there certainly was room for it

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Decidedly it is too bad, said the reporter; and the worst of it is, there is no way of putting an end to it.
children.prevalue: Decidedly it is too bad said the reporter and the worst of it is there is no way of putting an end to it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But we must drive these vagabonds out somehow, cried the sailor. We could soon get the better of them, even if there are twenty of the rascals; but for that, we must meet them hand to hand. Come now, is there no way of getting at them?
children.prevalue: But we must drive these vagabonds out somehow cried the sailor We could soon get the better of them even if there are twenty of the rascals but for that we must meet them hand to hand Come now is there no way of getting at them

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Let us try to enter Granite House by the old opening at the lake, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Let us try to enter Granite House by the old opening at the lake replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Oh! shouted the sailor, and I never thought of that.
children.prevalue: Oh shouted the sailor and I never thought of that

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: This was in reality the only way by which to penetrate into Granite House so as to fight with and drive out the intruders. The opening was, it is true, closed up with a wall of cemented stones, which it would be necessary to sacrifice, but that could easily be rebuilt. Fortunately, Cyrus Harding had not as yet effected his project of hiding this opening by raising the waters of the lake, for the operation would then have taken some time.
children.prevalue: This was in reality the only way by which to penetrate into Granite House so as to fight with and drive out the intruders The opening was it is true closed up with a wall of cemented stones which it would be necessary to sacrifice but that could easily be rebuilt Fortunately Cyrus Harding had not as yet effected his project of hiding this opening by raising the waters of the lake for the operation would then have taken some time

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: It was already past twelve o'clock, when the colonists, well armed and provided with picks and spades, left the Chimneys, passed beneath the windows of Granite House, after telling Top to remain at his post, and began to ascend the left bank of the Mercy, so as to reach Prospect Heights.
children.prevalue: It was already past twelve o clock when the colonists well armed and provided with picks and spades left the Chimneys passed beneath the windows of Granite House after telling Top to remain at his post and began to ascend the left bank of the Mercy so as to reach Prospect Heights

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: But they had not made fifty steps in this direction, when they heard the dog barking furiously.
children.prevalue: But they had not made fifty steps in this direction when they heard the dog barking furiously

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: And all rushed down the bank again.
children.prevalue: And all rushed down the bank again

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Arrived at the turning, they saw that the situation had changed.
children.prevalue: Arrived at the turning they saw that the situation had changed

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: In fact, the apes, seized with a sudden panic, from some unknown cause, were trying to escape. Two or three ran and clambered from one window to another with the agility of acrobats. They were not even trying to replace the ladder, by which it would have been easy to descend; perhaps in their terror they had forgotten this way of escape. The colonists, now being able to take aim without difficulty, fired. Some, wounded or killed, fell back into the rooms, uttering piercing cries. The rest, throwing themselves out, were dashed to pieces in their fall, and in a few minutes, so far as they knew, there was not a living quadrumana in Granite House.
children.prevalue: In fact the apes seized with a sudden panic from some unknown cause were trying to escape Two or three ran and clambered from one window to another with the agility of acrobats They were not even trying to replace the ladder by which it would have been easy to descend perhaps in their terror they had forgotten this way of escape The colonists now being able to take aim without difficulty fired Some wounded or killed fell back into the rooms uttering piercing cries The rest throwing themselves out were dashed to pieces in their fall and in a few minutes so far as they knew there was not a living quadrumana in Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: At this moment the ladder was seen to slip over the threshold, then unroll and fall to the ground.
children.prevalue: At this moment the ladder was seen to slip over the threshold then unroll and fall to the ground

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Hullo! cried the sailor, this is queer!
children.prevalue: Hullo cried the sailor this is queer

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Very strange! murmured the engineer, leaping first up the ladder.
children.prevalue: Very strange murmured the engineer leaping first up the ladder

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Take care, captain! cried Pencroft, perhaps there are still some of these rascals.
children.prevalue: Take care captain cried Pencroft perhaps there are still some of these rascals

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: We shall soon see, replied the engineer, without stopping however.
children.prevalue: We shall soon see replied the engineer without stopping however

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: All his companions followed him, and in a minute they had arrived at the threshold. They searched everywhere. There was no one in the rooms nor in the storehouse, which had been respected by the band of quadrumana.
children.prevalue: All his companions followed him and in a minute they had arrived at the threshold They searched everywhere There was no one in the rooms nor in the storehouse which had been respected by the band of quadrumana

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well now, and the ladder, cried the sailor; who can the gentleman have been who sent us that down?
children.prevalue: Well now and the ladder cried the sailor who can the gentleman have been who sent us that down

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But at that moment a cry was heard, and a great orang, who had hidden himself in the passage, rushed into the room, pursued by Neb.
children.prevalue: But at that moment a cry was heard and a great orang who had hidden himself in the passage rushed into the room pursued by Neb

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Ah, the robber! cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Ah the robber cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And hatchet in hand, he was about to cleave the head of the animal, when Cyrus Harding seized his arm, saying,--
children.prevalue: And hatchet in hand he was about to cleave the head of the animal when Cyrus Harding seized his arm saying

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Spare him, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Spare him Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Pardon this rascal?
children.prevalue: Pardon this rascal

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Yes! it was he who threw us the ladder!
children.prevalue: Yes it was he who threw us the ladder

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: And the engineer said this in such a peculiar voice that it was difficult to know whether he spoke seriously or not.
children.prevalue: And the engineer said this in such a peculiar voice that it was difficult to know whether he spoke seriously or not

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Nevertheless, they threw themselves on the orang, who defended himself gallantly, but was soon overpowered and bound.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless they threw themselves on the orang who defended himself gallantly but was soon overpowered and bound

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: There! said Pencroft. And what shall we make of him, now we've got him?
children.prevalue: There said Pencroft And what shall we make of him now we ve got him

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: A servant! replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: A servant replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The lad was not joking in saying this, for he knew how this intelligent race could be turned to account.
children.prevalue: The lad was not joking in saying this for he knew how this intelligent race could be turned to account

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: The settlers then approached the ape and gazed at it attentively. He belonged to the family of anthropoid apes, of which the facial angle is not much inferior to that of the Australians and Hottentots. It was an orangoutang, and as such, had neither the ferocity of the gorilla, nor the stupidity of the baboon. It is to this family of the anthropoid apes that so many characteristics belong which prove them to be possessed of an almost human intelligence. Employed in houses, they can wait at table, sweep rooms, brush clothes, clean boots, handle a knife, fork, and spoon properly, and even drink wine... doing everything as well as the best servant that ever walked upon two legs. Buffon possessed one of these apes, who served him for a long time as a faithful and zealous servant.
children.prevalue: The settlers then approached the ape and gazed at it attentively He belonged to the family of anthropoid apes of which the facial angle is not much inferior to that of the Australians and Hottentots It was an orangoutang and as such had neither the ferocity of the gorilla nor the stupidity of the baboon It is to this family of the anthropoid apes that so many characteristics belong which prove them to be possessed of an almost human intelligence Employed in houses they can wait at table sweep rooms brush clothes clean boots handle a knife fork and spoon properly and even drink wine doing everything as well as the best servant that ever walked upon two legs Buffon possessed one of these apes who served him for a long time as a faithful and zealous servant

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: The one which had been seized in the hall of Granite House was a great fellow, six feet high, with an admirably poportioned frame, a broad chest, head of a moderate size, the facial angle reaching sixty-five degrees, round skull, projecting nose, skin covered with soft glossy hair, in short, a fine specimen of the anthropoids. His eyes, rather smaller than human eyes, sparkled with intelligence; his white teeth glittered under his mustache, and he wore a little curly brown beard.
children.prevalue: The one which had been seized in the hall of Granite House was a great fellow six feet high with an admirably poportioned frame a broad chest head of a moderate size the facial angle reaching sixty five degrees round skull projecting nose skin covered with soft glossy hair in short a fine specimen of the anthropoids His eyes rather smaller than human eyes sparkled with intelligence his white teeth glittered under his mustache and he wore a little curly brown beard

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: A handsome fellow! said Pencroft; if we only knew his language, we could talk to him.
children.prevalue: A handsome fellow said Pencroft if we only knew his language we could talk to him

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: But, master, said Neb, are you serious? Are we going to take him as a servant?
children.prevalue: But master said Neb are you serious Are we going to take him as a servant

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes, Neb, replied the engineer, smiling. But you must not be jealous.
children.prevalue: Yes Neb replied the engineer smiling But you must not be jealous

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And I hope he will make an excellent servant, added Herbert. He appears young, and will be easy to educate, and we shall not be obliged to use force to subdue him, nor draw his teeth, as is sometimes done. He will soon grow fond of his masters if they are kind to him.
children.prevalue: And I hope he will make an excellent servant added Herbert He appears young and will be easy to educate and we shall not be obliged to use force to subdue him nor draw his teeth as is sometimes done He will soon grow fond of his masters if they are kind to him

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And they will be, replied Pencroft, who had forgotten all his rancor against the jokers.
children.prevalue: And they will be replied Pencroft who had forgotten all his rancor against the jokers

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Then, approaching the orang,--
children.prevalue: Then approaching the orang

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Well, old boy! he asked, how are you?
children.prevalue: Well old boy he asked how are you

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: The orang replied by a little grunt which did not show any anger.
children.prevalue: The orang replied by a little grunt which did not show any anger

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: You wish to join the colony? again asked the sailor. You are going to enter the service of Captain Cyrus Harding?
children.prevalue: You wish to join the colony again asked the sailor You are going to enter the service of Captain Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Another respondent grunt was uttered by the ape.
children.prevalue: Another respondent grunt was uttered by the ape

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: And you will be satisfied with no other wages than your food?
children.prevalue: And you will be satisfied with no other wages than your food

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Third affirmative grunt.
children.prevalue: Third affirmative grunt

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: This conversation is slightly monotonous, observed Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: This conversation is slightly monotonous observed Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: So much the better, replied Pencroft; the best servants are those who talk the least. And then, no wages, do you hear, my boy? We will give you no wages at first, but we will double them afterwards if we are pleased with you.
children.prevalue: So much the better replied Pencroft the best servants are those who talk the least And then no wages do you hear my boy We will give you no wages at first but we will double them afterwards if we are pleased with you

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Thus the colony was increased by a new member. As to his name the sailor begged that in memory of another ape which he had known, he might be called Jupiter, and Jup for short.
children.prevalue: Thus the colony was increased by a new member As to his name the sailor begged that in memory of another ape which he had known he might be called Jupiter and Jup for short

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: And so, without more ceremony, Master Jup was installed in Granite House.
children.prevalue: And so without more ceremony Master Jup was installed in Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The settlers in Lincoln Island had now regained their dwelling, without having been obliged to reach it by the old opening, and were therefore spared the trouble of mason's work. It was certainly lucky, that at the moment they were about to set out to do so, the apes had been seized with that terror, no less sudden than inexplicable, which had driven them out of Granite House. Had the animals discovered that they were about to be attacked from another direction? This was the only explanation of their sudden retreat.
children.prevalue: The settlers in Lincoln Island had now regained their dwelling without having been obliged to reach it by the old opening and were therefore spared the trouble of mason s work It was certainly lucky that at the moment they were about to set out to do so the apes had been seized with that terror no less sudden than inexplicable which had driven them out of Granite House Had the animals discovered that they were about to be attacked from another direction This was the only explanation of their sudden retreat

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: During the day the bodies of the apes were carried into the wood, where they were buried; then the settlers busied themselves in repairing the disorder caused by the intruders, disorder but not damage, for although they had turned everything in the rooms topsy-turvy, yet they had broken nothing. Neb relighted his stove, and the stores in the larder furnished a substantial repast, to which all did ample justice.
children.prevalue: During the day the bodies of the apes were carried into the wood where they were buried then the settlers busied themselves in repairing the disorder caused by the intruders disorder but not damage for although they had turned everything in the rooms topsy turvy yet they had broken nothing Neb relighted his stove and the stores in the larder furnished a substantial repast to which all did ample justice

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Jup was not forgotten, and he ate with relish some stonepine almonds and rhizome roots, with which he was abundantly supplied. Pencroft had unfastened his arms, but judged it best to have his legs tied until they were more sure of his submission.
children.prevalue: Jup was not forgotten and he ate with relish some stonepine almonds and rhizome roots with which he was abundantly supplied Pencroft had unfastened his arms but judged it best to have his legs tied until they were more sure of his submission

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Then, before retiring to rest, Harding and his companions seated round their table, discussed those plans, the execution of which was most pressing. The most important and most urgent was the establishment of a bridge over the Mercy, so as to form a communication with the southern part of the island and Granite House; then the making of an enclosure for the musmons or other woolly animals which they wished to capture.
children.prevalue: Then before retiring to rest Harding and his companions seated round their table discussed those plans the execution of which was most pressing The most important and most urgent was the establishment of a bridge over the Mercy so as to form a communication with the southern part of the island and Granite House then the making of an enclosure for the musmons or other woolly animals which they wished to capture

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: These two projects would help to solve the difficulty as to their clothing, which was now serious. The bridge would render easy the transport of the balloon case, which would furnish them with linen, and the inhabitants of the enclosure would yield wool which would supply them with winter clothes.
children.prevalue: These two projects would help to solve the difficulty as to their clothing which was now serious The bridge would render easy the transport of the balloon case which would furnish them with linen and the inhabitants of the enclosure would yield wool which would supply them with winter clothes

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: As to the enclosure, it was Cyrus Harding's intention to establish it at the sources of the Red Creek, where the ruminants would find fresh and abundant pasture. The road between Prospect Heights and the sources of the stream was already partly beaten, and with a better cart than the first, the material could be easily conveyed to the spot, especially if they could manage to capture some animals to draw it.
children.prevalue: As to the enclosure it was Cyrus Harding s intention to establish it at the sources of the Red Creek where the ruminants would find fresh and abundant pasture The road between Prospect Heights and the sources of the stream was already partly beaten and with a better cart than the first the material could be easily conveyed to the spot especially if they could manage to capture some animals to draw it

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But though there might be no inconvenience in the enclosure being so far from Granite House, it would not be the same with the poultry-yard, to which Neb called the attention of the colonists. It was indeed necessary that the birds should be close within reach of the cook, and no place appeared more favorable for the establishment of the said poultry-yard than that portion of the banks of the lake which was close to the old opening.
children.prevalue: But though there might be no inconvenience in the enclosure being so far from Granite House it would not be the same with the poultry yard to which Neb called the attention of the colonists It was indeed necessary that the birds should be close within reach of the cook and no place appeared more favorable for the establishment of the said poultry yard than that portion of the banks of the lake which was close to the old opening

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Water-birds would prosper there as well as others, and the couple of tinamous taken in their last excursion would be the first to be domesticated.
children.prevalue: Water birds would prosper there as well as others and the couple of tinamous taken in their last excursion would be the first to be domesticated

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The next day, the 3rd of November, the new works were begun by the construction of the bridge, and all hands were required for this important task. Saws, hatchets, and hammers were shouldered by the settlers, who, now transformed into carpenters, descended to the shore.
children.prevalue: The next day the 3rd of November the new works were begun by the construction of the bridge and all hands were required for this important task Saws hatchets and hammers were shouldered by the settlers who now transformed into carpenters descended to the shore

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: There Pencroft observed,--
children.prevalue: There Pencroft observed

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Suppose, that during our absence, Master Jup takes it into his head to draw up the ladder which he so politely returned to us yesterday?
children.prevalue: Suppose that during our absence Master Jup takes it into his head to draw up the ladder which he so politely returned to us yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Let us tie its lower end down firmly, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Let us tie its lower end down firmly replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: This was done by means of two stakes securely fixed in the sand. Then the settlers, ascending the left bank of the Mercy, soon arrived at the angle formed by the river.
children.prevalue: This was done by means of two stakes securely fixed in the sand Then the settlers ascending the left bank of the Mercy soon arrived at the angle formed by the river

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: There they halted, in order to ascertain if the bridge could be thrown across. The place appeared suitable.
children.prevalue: There they halted in order to ascertain if the bridge could be thrown across The place appeared suitable

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In fact, from this spot, to Port Balloon, discovered the day before on the southern coast, there was only a distance of three miles and a half, and from the bridge to the Port, it would be easy to make a good cart-road which would render the communication between Granite House and the south of the island extremely easy.
children.prevalue: In fact from this spot to Port Balloon discovered the day before on the southern coast there was only a distance of three miles and a half and from the bridge to the Port it would be easy to make a good cart road which would render the communication between Granite House and the south of the island extremely easy

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Cyrus Harding now imparted to his companions a scheme for completely isolating Prospect Heights so as to shelter it from the attacks both of quadrupeds and quadrumana. In this way, Granite House, the Chimneys, the poultry-yard, and all the upper part of the plateau which was to be used for cultivation, would be protected against the depredations of animals. Nothing could be easier than to execute this project, and this is how the engineer intended to set to work.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding now imparted to his companions a scheme for completely isolating Prospect Heights so as to shelter it from the attacks both of quadrupeds and quadrumana In this way Granite House the Chimneys the poultry yard and all the upper part of the plateau which was to be used for cultivation would be protected against the depredations of animals Nothing could be easier than to execute this project and this is how the engineer intended to set to work

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The plateau was already defended on three sides by water-courses, either artificial or natural. On the northwest, by the shores of Lake Grant, from the entrance of the passage to the breach made in the banks of the lake for the escape of the water.
children.prevalue: The plateau was already defended on three sides by water courses either artificial or natural On the northwest by the shores of Lake Grant from the entrance of the passage to the breach made in the banks of the lake for the escape of the water

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: On the north, from this breach to the sea, by the new water-course which had hollowed out a bed for itself across the plateau and shore, above and below the fall, and it would be enough to dig the bed of this creek a little deeper to make it impracticable for animals, on all the eastern border by the sea itself, from the mouth of the aforesaid creek to the mouth of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: On the north from this breach to the sea by the new water course which had hollowed out a bed for itself across the plateau and shore above and below the fall and it would be enough to dig the bed of this creek a little deeper to make it impracticable for animals on all the eastern border by the sea itself from the mouth of the aforesaid creek to the mouth of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Lastly, on the south, from the mouth to the turn of the Mercy where the bridge was to be established.
children.prevalue: Lastly on the south from the mouth to the turn of the Mercy where the bridge was to be established

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The western border of the plateau now remained between the turn of the river and the southern angle of the lake, a distance of about a mile, which was open to all comers. But nothing could be easier than to dig a broad deep ditch, which could be filled from the lake, and the overflow of which would throw itself by a rapid fall into the bed of the Mercy. The level of the lake would, no doubt, be somewhat lowered by this fresh discharge of its waters, but Cyrus Harding had ascertained that the volume of water in the Red Creek was considerable enough to allow of the execution of this project.
children.prevalue: The western border of the plateau now remained between the turn of the river and the southern angle of the lake a distance of about a mile which was open to all comers But nothing could be easier than to dig a broad deep ditch which could be filled from the lake and the overflow of which would throw itself by a rapid fall into the bed of the Mercy The level of the lake would no doubt be somewhat lowered by this fresh discharge of its waters but Cyrus Harding had ascertained that the volume of water in the Red Creek was considerable enough to allow of the execution of this project

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: So then, added the engineer, Prospect Heights will become a regular island, being surrounded with water on all sides, and only communicating with the rest of our domain by the bridge which we are about to throw across the Mercy, the two little bridges already established above and below the fall; and, lastly, two other little bridges which must be constructed, one over the canal which I propose to dig, the other across to the left bank of the Mercy. Now, if these bridges can be raised at will, Prospect Heights will be guarded from any surprise.
children.prevalue: So then added the engineer Prospect Heights will become a regular island being surrounded with water on all sides and only communicating with the rest of our domain by the bridge which we are about to throw across the Mercy the two little bridges already established above and below the fall and lastly two other little bridges which must be constructed one over the canal which I propose to dig the other across to the left bank of the Mercy Now if these bridges can be raised at will Prospect Heights will be guarded from any surprise

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The bridge was the most urgent work. Trees were selected, cut down, stripped of their branches, and cut into beams, joists, and planks. The end of the bridge which rested on the right bank of the Mercy was to be firm, but the other end on the left bank was to be movable, so that it might be raised by means of a counterpoise, as some canal bridges are managed.
children.prevalue: The bridge was the most urgent work Trees were selected cut down stripped of their branches and cut into beams joists and planks The end of the bridge which rested on the right bank of the Mercy was to be firm but the other end on the left bank was to be movable so that it might be raised by means of a counterpoise as some canal bridges are managed

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: This was certainly a considerable work, and though it was skillfully conducted, it took some time, for the Mercy at this place was eighty feet wide. It was therefore necessary to fix piles in the bed of the river so as to sustain the floor of the bridge and establish a pile-driver to act on the tops of these piles, which would thus form two arches and allow the bridge to support heavy loads.
children.prevalue: This was certainly a considerable work and though it was skillfully conducted it took some time for the Mercy at this place was eighty feet wide It was therefore necessary to fix piles in the bed of the river so as to sustain the floor of the bridge and establish a pile driver to act on the tops of these piles which would thus form two arches and allow the bridge to support heavy loads

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Happily there was no want of tools with which to shape the wood, nor of iron-work to make it firm, nor of the ingenuity of a man who had a marvelous knowledge of the work, nor lastly, the zeal of his companions, who in seven months had necessarily acquired great skill in the use of their tools; and it must be said that not the least skilful was Gideon Spilett, who in dexterity almost equaled the sailor himself. Who would ever have expected so much from a newspaper man! thought Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Happily there was no want of tools with which to shape the wood nor of iron work to make it firm nor of the ingenuity of a man who had a marvelous knowledge of the work nor lastly the zeal of his companions who in seven months had necessarily acquired great skill in the use of their tools and it must be said that not the least skilful was Gideon Spilett who in dexterity almost equaled the sailor himself Who would ever have expected so much from a newspaper man thought Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The construction of the Mercy bridge lasted three weeks of regular hard work. They even breakfasted on the scene of their labors, and the weather being magnificent, they only returned to Granite House to sleep.
children.prevalue: The construction of the Mercy bridge lasted three weeks of regular hard work They even breakfasted on the scene of their labors and the weather being magnificent they only returned to Granite House to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: During this period it may be stated that Master Jup grew more accustomed to his new masters, whose movements he always watched with very inquisitive eyes. However, as a precautionary measure, Pencroft did not as yet allow him complete liberty, rightly wishing to wait until the limits of the plateau should be settled by the projected works. Top and Jup were good friends and played willingly together, but Jup did everything solemnly.
children.prevalue: During this period it may be stated that Master Jup grew more accustomed to his new masters whose movements he always watched with very inquisitive eyes However as a precautionary measure Pencroft did not as yet allow him complete liberty rightly wishing to wait until the limits of the plateau should be settled by the projected works Top and Jup were good friends and played willingly together but Jup did everything solemnly

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: On the 20th of November the bridge was finished. The movable part, balanced by the counterpoise, swung easily, and only a slight effort was needed to raise it; between its hinge and the last cross-bar on which it rested when closed, there existed a space of twenty feet, which was sufficiently wide to prevent any animals from crossing.
children.prevalue: On the 20th of November the bridge was finished The movable part balanced by the counterpoise swung easily and only a slight effort was needed to raise it between its hinge and the last cross bar on which it rested when closed there existed a space of twenty feet which was sufficiently wide to prevent any animals from crossing

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The settlers now began to talk of fetching the balloon-case, which they were anxious to place in perfect security; but to bring it, it would be necessary to take a cart to Port Balloon, and consequently, necessary to beat a road through the dense forests of the Far West. This would take some time. Also, Neb and Pencroft having gone to examine into the state of things at Port Balloon, and reported that the stock of cloth would suffer no damage in the grotto where it was stored, it was decided that the work at Prospect Heights should not be discontinued.
children.prevalue: The settlers now began to talk of fetching the balloon case which they were anxious to place in perfect security but to bring it it would be necessary to take a cart to Port Balloon and consequently necessary to beat a road through the dense forests of the Far West This would take some time Also Neb and Pencroft having gone to examine into the state of things at Port Balloon and reported that the stock of cloth would suffer no damage in the grotto where it was stored it was decided that the work at Prospect Heights should not be discontinued

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: That, observed Pencroft, will enable us to establish our poultry-yard under better conditions, since we need have no fear of visits from foxes nor the attacks of other beasts.
children.prevalue: That observed Pencroft will enable us to establish our poultry yard under better conditions since we need have no fear of visits from foxes nor the attacks of other beasts

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Then, added Neb, we can clear the plateau, and transplant wild plants to it.
children.prevalue: Then added Neb we can clear the plateau and transplant wild plants to it

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And prepare our second corn-field! cried the sailor with a triumphant air.
children.prevalue: And prepare our second corn field cried the sailor with a triumphant air

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: In fact, the first corn-field sown with a single grain had prospered admirably, thanks to Pencroft's care. It had produced the ten ears foretold by the engineer, and each ear containing eighty grains, the colony found itself in possession of eight hundred grains, in six months, which promised a double harvest each year.
children.prevalue: In fact the first corn field sown with a single grain had prospered admirably thanks to Pencroft s care It had produced the ten ears foretold by the engineer and each ear containing eighty grains the colony found itself in possession of eight hundred grains in six months which promised a double harvest each year

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: These eight hundred grains, except fifty, which were prudently reserved, were to be sown in a new field, but with no less care than was bestowed on the single grain.
children.prevalue: These eight hundred grains except fifty which were prudently reserved were to be sown in a new field but with no less care than was bestowed on the single grain

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The field was prepared, then surrounded with a strong palisade, high and pointed, which quadrupeds would have found difficulty in leaping. As to birds, some scarecrows, due to Pencroft's ingenious brain, were enough to frighten them. The seven hundred and fifty grains deposited in very regular furrows were then left for nature to do the rest.
children.prevalue: The field was prepared then surrounded with a strong palisade high and pointed which quadrupeds would have found difficulty in leaping As to birds some scarecrows due to Pencroft s ingenious brain were enough to frighten them The seven hundred and fifty grains deposited in very regular furrows were then left for nature to do the rest

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: On the 21st of November, Cyrus Harding began to plan the canal which was to close the plateau on the west, from the south angle of Lake Grant to the angle of the Mercy. There was there two or three feet of vegetable earth, and below that granite. It was therefore necessary to manufacture some more nitro-glycerine, and the nitro-glycerine did its accustomed work. In less than a fortnight a ditch, twelve feet wide and six deep, was dug out in the hard ground of the plateau. A new trench was made by the same means in the rocky border of the lake, forming a small stream, to which they gave the name of Creek Glycerine, and which was thus an affluent of the Mercy. As the engineer had predicted, the level of the lake was lowered, though very slightly. To complete the enclosure the bed of the stream on the beach was considerably enlarged, and the sand supported by means of stakes.
children.prevalue: On the 21st of November Cyrus Harding began to plan the canal which was to close the plateau on the west from the south angle of Lake Grant to the angle of the Mercy There was there two or three feet of vegetable earth and below that granite It was therefore necessary to manufacture some more nitro glycerine and the nitro glycerine did its accustomed work In less than a fortnight a ditch twelve feet wide and six deep was dug out in the hard ground of the plateau A new trench was made by the same means in the rocky border of the lake forming a small stream to which they gave the name of Creek Glycerine and which was thus an affluent of the Mercy As the engineer had predicted the level of the lake was lowered though very slightly To complete the enclosure the bed of the stream on the beach was considerably enlarged and the sand supported by means of stakes

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: By the end of the first fortnight of December these works were finished, and Prospect Heights--that is to say, a sort of irregular pentagon, having a perimeter of nearly four miles, surrounded by a liquid belt--was completely protected from depredators of every description.
children.prevalue: By the end of the first fortnight of December these works were finished and Prospect Heights that is to say a sort of irregular pentagon having a perimeter of nearly four miles surrounded by a liquid belt was completely protected from depredators of every description

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: During the month of December, the heat was very great. In spite of it, however, the settlers continued their work, and as they were anxious to possess a poultry-yard they forthwith commenced it.
children.prevalue: During the month of December the heat was very great In spite of it however the settlers continued their work and as they were anxious to possess a poultry yard they forthwith commenced it

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It is useless to say that since the enclosing of the plateau had been completed, Master Jup had been set at liberty. He did not leave his masters, and evinced no wish to escape. He was a gentle animal, though very powerful and wonderfully active. He was already taught to make himself useful by drawing loads of wood and carting away the stones which were extracted from the bed of Creek Glycerine.
children.prevalue: It is useless to say that since the enclosing of the plateau had been completed Master Jup had been set at liberty He did not leave his masters and evinced no wish to escape He was a gentle animal though very powerful and wonderfully active He was already taught to make himself useful by drawing loads of wood and carting away the stones which were extracted from the bed of Creek Glycerine

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The poultry-yard occupied an area of two hundred square yards, on the southeastern bank of the lake. It was surrounded by a palisade, and in it were constructed various shelters for the birds which were to populate it. These were simply built of branches and divided into compartments, made ready for the expected guests.
children.prevalue: The poultry yard occupied an area of two hundred square yards on the southeastern bank of the lake It was surrounded by a palisade and in it were constructed various shelters for the birds which were to populate it These were simply built of branches and divided into compartments made ready for the expected guests

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The first were the two tinamous, which were not long in having a number of young ones; they had for companions half a dozen ducks, accustomed to the borders of the lake. Some belonged to the Chinese species, of which the wings open like a fan, and which by the brilliancy of their plumage rival the golden pheasants. A few days afterwards, Herbert snared a couple of gallinaceae, with spreading tails composed of long feathers, magnificent alectors, which soon became tame. As to pelicans, kingfishers, water-hens, they came of themselves to the shores of the poultry-yard, and this little community, after some disputes, cooing, screaming, clucking, ended by settling down peacefully, and increased in encouraging proportion for the future use of the colony.
children.prevalue: The first were the two tinamous which were not long in having a number of young ones they had for companions half a dozen ducks accustomed to the borders of the lake Some belonged to the Chinese species of which the wings open like a fan and which by the brilliancy of their plumage rival the golden pheasants A few days afterwards Herbert snared a couple of gallinaceae with spreading tails composed of long feathers magnificent alectors which soon became tame As to pelicans kingfishers water hens they came of themselves to the shores of the poultry yard and this little community after some disputes cooing screaming clucking ended by settling down peacefully and increased in encouraging proportion for the future use of the colony

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Cyrus Harding, wishing to complete his performance, established a pigeon-house in a corner of the poultry-yard. There he lodged a dozen of those pigeons which frequented the rocks of the plateau. These birds soon became accustomed to returning every evening to their new dwelling, and showed more disposition to domesticate themselves than their congeners, the wood-pigeons.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding wishing to complete his performance established a pigeon house in a corner of the poultry yard There he lodged a dozen of those pigeons which frequented the rocks of the plateau These birds soon became accustomed to returning every evening to their new dwelling and showed more disposition to domesticate themselves than their congeners the wood pigeons

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Lastly, the time had come for turning the balloon-case to use, by cutting it up to make shirts and other articles; for as to keeping it in its present form, and risking themselves in a balloon filled with gas, above a sea of the limits of which they had no idea, it was not to be thought of.
children.prevalue: Lastly the time had come for turning the balloon case to use by cutting it up to make shirts and other articles for as to keeping it in its present form and risking themselves in a balloon filled with gas above a sea of the limits of which they had no idea it was not to be thought of

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It was necessary to bring the case to Granite House, and the colonists employed themselves in rendering their heavy cart lighter and more manageable. But though they had a vehicle, the moving power was yet to be found.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to bring the case to Granite House and the colonists employed themselves in rendering their heavy cart lighter and more manageable But though they had a vehicle the moving power was yet to be found

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But did there not exist in the island some animal which might supply the place of the horse, ass, or ox? That was the question.
children.prevalue: But did there not exist in the island some animal which might supply the place of the horse ass or ox That was the question

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Certainly, said Pencroft, a beast of burden would be very useful to us until the captain has made a steam cart, or even an engine, for some day we shall have a railroad from Granite House to Port Balloon, with a branch line to Mount Franklin!
children.prevalue: Certainly said Pencroft a beast of burden would be very useful to us until the captain has made a steam cart or even an engine for some day we shall have a railroad from Granite House to Port Balloon with a branch line to Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: One day, the 23rd of December, Neb and Top were heard shouting and barking, each apparently trying to see who could make the most noise. The settlers, who were busy at the Chimneys, ran, fearing some vexatious incident.
children.prevalue: One day the 23rd of December Neb and Top were heard shouting and barking each apparently trying to see who could make the most noise The settlers who were busy at the Chimneys ran fearing some vexatious incident

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What did they see? Two fine animals of a large size that had imprudently ventured on the plateau, when the bridges were open. One would have said they were horses, or at least donkeys, male and female, of a fine shape, dove-colored, the legs and tail white, striped with black on the head and neck. They advanced quietly without showing any uneasiness, and gazed at the men, in whom they could not as yet recognize their future masters.
children.prevalue: What did they see Two fine animals of a large size that had imprudently ventured on the plateau when the bridges were open One would have said they were horses or at least donkeys male and female of a fine shape dove colored the legs and tail white striped with black on the head and neck They advanced quietly without showing any uneasiness and gazed at the men in whom they could not as yet recognize their future masters

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: These are onagers! cried Herbert, animals something between the zebra and the quagga!
children.prevalue: These are onagers cried Herbert animals something between the zebra and the quagga

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Why not donkeys? asked Neb.
children.prevalue: Why not donkeys asked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Because they have not long ears, and their shape is more graceful!
children.prevalue: Because they have not long ears and their shape is more graceful

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Donkeys or horses, interrupted Pencroft, they are 'moving powers,' as the captain would say, and as such must be captured!
children.prevalue: Donkeys or horses interrupted Pencroft they are moving powers as the captain would say and as such must be captured

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The sailor, without frightening the animals, crept through the grass to the bridge over Creek Glycerine, lowered it, and the onagers were prisoners.
children.prevalue: The sailor without frightening the animals crept through the grass to the bridge over Creek Glycerine lowered it and the onagers were prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Now, should they seize them with violence and master them by force? No. It was decided that for a few days they should be allowed to roam freely about the plateau, where there was an abundance of grass, and the engineer immediately began to prepare a stable near the poultry-yard, in which the onagers might find food, with a good litter, and shelter during the night.
children.prevalue: Now should they seize them with violence and master them by force No It was decided that for a few days they should be allowed to roam freely about the plateau where there was an abundance of grass and the engineer immediately began to prepare a stable near the poultry yard in which the onagers might find food with a good litter and shelter during the night

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: This done, the movements of the two magnificent creatures were left entirely free, and the settlers avoided even approaching them so as to terrify them. Several times, however, the onagers appeared to wish to leave the plateau, too confined for animals accustomed to the plains and forests. They were then seen following the water-barrier which everywhere presented itself before them, uttering short neighs, then galloping through the grass, and becoming calmer, they would remain entire hours gazing at the woods, from which they were cut off for ever!
children.prevalue: This done the movements of the two magnificent creatures were left entirely free and the settlers avoided even approaching them so as to terrify them Several times however the onagers appeared to wish to leave the plateau too confined for animals accustomed to the plains and forests They were then seen following the water barrier which everywhere presented itself before them uttering short neighs then galloping through the grass and becoming calmer they would remain entire hours gazing at the woods from which they were cut off for ever

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: In the meantime harness of vegetable fiber had been manufactured, and some days after the capture of the onagers, not only the cart was ready, but a straight road, or rather a cutting, had been made through the forests of the Far West, from the angle of the Mercy to Port Balloon. The cart might then be driven there, and towards the end of December they tried the onagers for the first time.
children.prevalue: In the meantime harness of vegetable fiber had been manufactured and some days after the capture of the onagers not only the cart was ready but a straight road or rather a cutting had been made through the forests of the Far West from the angle of the Mercy to Port Balloon The cart might then be driven there and towards the end of December they tried the onagers for the first time

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Pencroft had already coaxed the animals to come and eat out of his hand, and they allowed him to approach without making any difficulty, but once harnessed they reared and could with difficulty be held in. However, it was not long before they submitted to this new service, for the onager, being less refractory than the zebra, is frequently put in harness in the mountainous regions of Southern Africa, and it has even been acclimatized in Europe, under zones of a relative coolness.
children.prevalue: Pencroft had already coaxed the animals to come and eat out of his hand and they allowed him to approach without making any difficulty but once harnessed they reared and could with difficulty be held in However it was not long before they submitted to this new service for the onager being less refractory than the zebra is frequently put in harness in the mountainous regions of Southern Africa and it has even been acclimatized in Europe under zones of a relative coolness

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: On this day all the colony, except Pencroft who walked at the animals' heads, mounted the cart, and set out on the road to Port Balloon.
children.prevalue: On this day all the colony except Pencroft who walked at the animals heads mounted the cart and set out on the road to Port Balloon

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Of course they were jolted over the somewhat rough road, but the vehicle arrived without any accident, and was soon loaded with the case and rigging of the balloon.
children.prevalue: Of course they were jolted over the somewhat rough road but the vehicle arrived without any accident and was soon loaded with the case and rigging of the balloon

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At eight o'clock that evening the cart, after passing over the Mercy bridge, descended the left bank of the river, and stopped on the beach. The onagers being unharnessed, were thence led to their stable, and Pencroft before going to sleep gave vent to his feelings in a deep sigh of satisfaction that awoke all the echoes of Granite House.
children.prevalue: At eight o clock that evening the cart after passing over the Mercy bridge descended the left bank of the river and stopped on the beach The onagers being unharnessed were thence led to their stable and Pencroft before going to sleep gave vent to his feelings in a deep sigh of satisfaction that awoke all the echoes of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The first week of January was devoted to the manufacture of the linen garments required by the colony. The needles found in the box were used by sturdy if not delicate fingers, and we may be sure that what was sewn was sewn firmly.
children.prevalue: The first week of January was devoted to the manufacture of the linen garments required by the colony The needles found in the box were used by sturdy if not delicate fingers and we may be sure that what was sewn was sewn firmly

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There was no lack of thread, thanks to Cyrus Harding's idea of re-employing that which had been already used in the covering of the balloon. This with admirable patience was all unpicked by Gideon Spilett and Herbert, for Pencroft had been obliged to give this work up, as it irritated him beyond measure; but he had no equal in the sewing part of the business. Indeed, everybody knows that sailors have a remarkable aptitude for tailoring.
children.prevalue: There was no lack of thread thanks to Cyrus Harding s idea of re employing that which had been already used in the covering of the balloon This with admirable patience was all unpicked by Gideon Spilett and Herbert for Pencroft had been obliged to give this work up as it irritated him beyond measure but he had no equal in the sewing part of the business Indeed everybody knows that sailors have a remarkable aptitude for tailoring

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The cloth of which the balloon-case was made was then cleaned by means of soda and potash, obtained by the incineration of plants, in such a way that the cotton, having got rid of the varnish, resumed its natural softness and elasticity; then, exposed to the action of the atmosphere, it soon became perfectly white. Some dozen shirts and sock--the latter not knitted, of course, but made of cotton--were thus manufactured. What a comfort it was to the settlers to clothe themselves again in clean linen, which was doubtless rather rough, but they were not troubled about that! and then to go to sleep between sheets, which made the couches at Granite House into quite comfortable beds!
children.prevalue: The cloth of which the balloon case was made was then cleaned by means of soda and potash obtained by the incineration of plants in such a way that the cotton having got rid of the varnish resumed its natural softness and elasticity then exposed to the action of the atmosphere it soon became perfectly white Some dozen shirts and sock the latter not knitted of course but made of cotton were thus manufactured What a comfort it was to the settlers to clothe themselves again in clean linen which was doubtless rather rough but they were not troubled about that and then to go to sleep between sheets which made the couches at Granite House into quite comfortable beds

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: It was about this time also that they made boots of seal-leather, which were greatly needed to replace the shoes and boots brought from America. We may be sure that these new shoes were large enough and never pinched the feet of the wearers.
children.prevalue: It was about this time also that they made boots of seal leather which were greatly needed to replace the shoes and boots brought from America We may be sure that these new shoes were large enough and never pinched the feet of the wearers

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: With the beginning of the year 1866 the heat was very great, but the hunting in the forests did not stand still. Agouties, peccaries, capybaras, kangaroos, game of all sorts, actually swarmed there, and Spilett and Herbert were too good marksmen ever to throw away their shot uselessly.
children.prevalue: With the beginning of the year 1866 the heat was very great but the hunting in the forests did not stand still Agouties peccaries capybaras kangaroos game of all sorts actually swarmed there and Spilett and Herbert were too good marksmen ever to throw away their shot uselessly

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Cyrus Harding still recommended them to husband the ammunition, and he took measures to replace the powder and shot which had been found in the box, and which he wished to reserve for the future. How did he know where chance might one day cast his companions and himself in the event of their leaving their domain? They should, then, prepare for the unknown future by husbanding their ammunition and by substituting for it some easily renewable substance.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding still recommended them to husband the ammunition and he took measures to replace the powder and shot which had been found in the box and which he wished to reserve for the future How did he know where chance might one day cast his companions and himself in the event of their leaving their domain They should then prepare for the unknown future by husbanding their ammunition and by substituting for it some easily renewable substance

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: To replace lead, of which Harding had found no traces in the island, he employed granulated iron, which was easy to manufacture. These bullets, not having the weight of leaden bullets, were made larger, and each charge contained less, but the skill of the sportsmen made up this deficiency. As to powder, Cyrus Harding would have been able to make that also, for he had at his disposal saltpeter, sulphur, and coal; but this preparation requires extreme care, and without special tools it is difficult to produce it of a good quality. Harding preferred, therefore, to manufacture pyroxyle, that is to say gun-cotton, a substance in which cotton is not indispensable, as the elementary tissue of vegetables may be used, and this is found in an almost pure state, not only in cotton, but in the textile fiber of hemp and flax, in paper, the pith of the elder, etc. Now, the elder abounded in the island towards the mouth of Red Creek, and the colonists had already made coffee of the berries of these shrubs, which belong to the family of the caprifoliaceae.
