children.prevalue: To replace lead of which Harding had found no traces in the island he employed granulated iron which was easy to manufacture These bullets not having the weight of leaden bullets were made larger and each charge contained less but the skill of the sportsmen made up this deficiency As to powder Cyrus Harding would have been able to make that also for he had at his disposal saltpeter sulphur and coal but this preparation requires extreme care and without special tools it is difficult to produce it of a good quality Harding preferred therefore to manufacture pyroxyle that is to say gun cotton a substance in which cotton is not indispensable as the elementary tissue of vegetables may be used and this is found in an almost pure state not only in cotton but in the textile fiber of hemp and flax in paper the pith of the elder etc Now the elder abounded in the island towards the mouth of Red Creek and the colonists had already made coffee of the berries of these shrubs which belong to the family of the caprifoliaceae

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The only thing to be collected, therefore, was elder-pith, for as to the other substance necessary for the manufacture of pyroxyle, it was only fuming azotic acid. Now, Harding having sulphuric acid at his disposal, had already been easily able to produce azotic acid by attacking the saltpeter with which nature supplied him. He accordingly resolved to manufacture and employ pyroxyle, although it has some inconveniences, that is to say, a great inequality of effect, an excessive inflammability, since it takes fire at one hundred and seventy degrees instead of two hundred and forty, and lastly, an instantaneous deflagration which might damage the firearms. On the other hand, the advantages of pyroxyle consist in this, that it is not injured by damp, that it does not make the gun-barrels dirty, and that its force is four times that of ordinary powder.
children.prevalue: The only thing to be collected therefore was elder pith for as to the other substance necessary for the manufacture of pyroxyle it was only fuming azotic acid Now Harding having sulphuric acid at his disposal had already been easily able to produce azotic acid by attacking the saltpeter with which nature supplied him He accordingly resolved to manufacture and employ pyroxyle although it has some inconveniences that is to say a great inequality of effect an excessive inflammability since it takes fire at one hundred and seventy degrees instead of two hundred and forty and lastly an instantaneous deflagration which might damage the firearms On the other hand the advantages of pyroxyle consist in this that it is not injured by damp that it does not make the gun barrels dirty and that its force is four times that of ordinary powder

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: To make pyroxyle, the cotton must be immersed in the fuming azotic acid for a quarter of an hour, then washed in cold water and dried. Nothing could be more simple.
children.prevalue: To make pyroxyle the cotton must be immersed in the fuming azotic acid for a quarter of an hour then washed in cold water and dried Nothing could be more simple

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Cyrus Harding had only at his disposal the ordinary azotic acid and not the fuming or monohydrate azotic acid, that is to say, acid which emits white vapors when it comes in contact with damp air; but by substituting for the latter ordinary azotic acid, mixed, in the proportion of from three to five volumes of concentrated sulphuric acid, the engineer obtained the same result. The sportsmen of the island therefore soon had a perfectly prepared substance, which, employed discreetly, produced admirable results.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding had only at his disposal the ordinary azotic acid and not the fuming or monohydrate azotic acid that is to say acid which emits white vapors when it comes in contact with damp air but by substituting for the latter ordinary azotic acid mixed in the proportion of from three to five volumes of concentrated sulphuric acid the engineer obtained the same result The sportsmen of the island therefore soon had a perfectly prepared substance which employed discreetly produced admirable results

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: About this time the settlers cleared three acres of the plateau, and the rest was preserved in a wild state, for the benefit of the onagers. Several excursions were made into the Jacamar Wood and the forests of the Far West, and they brought back from thence a large collection of wild vegetables, spinach, cress, radishes, and turnips, which careful culture would soon improve, and which would temper the regimen on which the settlers had till then subsisted. Supplies of wood and coal were also carted. Each excursion was at the same time a means of improving the roads, which gradually became smoother under the wheels of the cart.
children.prevalue: About this time the settlers cleared three acres of the plateau and the rest was preserved in a wild state for the benefit of the onagers Several excursions were made into the Jacamar Wood and the forests of the Far West and they brought back from thence a large collection of wild vegetables spinach cress radishes and turnips which careful culture would soon improve and which would temper the regimen on which the settlers had till then subsisted Supplies of wood and coal were also carted Each excursion was at the same time a means of improving the roads which gradually became smoother under the wheels of the cart

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The rabbit-warren still continued to supply the larder of Granite House. As fortunately it was situated on the other side of Creek Glycerine, its inhabitants could not reach the plateau nor ravage the newly-made plantation. The oyster-bed among the rocks was frequently renewed and furnished excellent molluscs. Besides that, the fishing, either in the lake or the Mercy, was very profitable, for Pencroft had made some lines, armed with iron hooks, with which they frequently caught fine trout, and a species of fish whose silvery sides were speckled with yellow, and which were also extremely savory. Master Neb, who was skilled in the culinary art, knew how to vary agreeably the bill of fare. Bread alone was wanting at the table of the settlers, and as has been said, they felt this privation greatly.
children.prevalue: The rabbit warren still continued to supply the larder of Granite House As fortunately it was situated on the other side of Creek Glycerine its inhabitants could not reach the plateau nor ravage the newly made plantation The oyster bed among the rocks was frequently renewed and furnished excellent molluscs Besides that the fishing either in the lake or the Mercy was very profitable for Pencroft had made some lines armed with iron hooks with which they frequently caught fine trout and a species of fish whose silvery sides were speckled with yellow and which were also extremely savory Master Neb who was skilled in the culinary art knew how to vary agreeably the bill of fare Bread alone was wanting at the table of the settlers and as has been said they felt this privation greatly

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The settlers hunted too the turtles which frequented the shores of Cape Mandible. At this place the beach was covered with little mounds, concealing perfectly spherical turtles' eggs, with white hard shells, the albumen of which does not coagulate as that of birds' eggs. They were hatched by the sun, and their number was naturally considerable, as each turtle can lay annually two hundred and fifty.
children.prevalue: The settlers hunted too the turtles which frequented the shores of Cape Mandible At this place the beach was covered with little mounds concealing perfectly spherical turtles eggs with white hard shells the albumen of which does not coagulate as that of birds eggs They were hatched by the sun and their number was naturally considerable as each turtle can lay annually two hundred and fifty

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: A regular egg-field, observed Gideon Spilett, and we have nothing to do but to pick them up.
children.prevalue: A regular egg field observed Gideon Spilett and we have nothing to do but to pick them up

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But not being contented with simply the produce, they made chase after the producers, the result of which was that they were able to bring back to Granite House a dozen of these chelonians, which were really valuable from an alimentary point of view. The turtle soup, flavored with aromatic herbs, often gained well-merited praises for its preparer, Neb.
children.prevalue: But not being contented with simply the produce they made chase after the producers the result of which was that they were able to bring back to Granite House a dozen of these chelonians which were really valuable from an alimentary point of view The turtle soup flavored with aromatic herbs often gained well merited praises for its preparer Neb

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: We must here mention another fortunate circumstance by which new stores for the winter were laid in. Shoals of salmon entered the Mercy, and ascended the country for several miles. It was the time at which the females, going to find suitable places in which to spawn, precede the males and make a great noise through the fresh water. A thousand of these fish, which measured about two feet and a half in length, came up the river, and a large quantity were retained by fixing dams across the stream. More than a hundred were thus taken, which were salted and stored for the time when winter, freezing up the streams, would render fishing impracticable. By this time the intelligent Jup was raised to the duty of valet. He had been dressed in a jacket, white linen breeches, and an apron, the pockets of which were his delight. The clever orang had been marvelously trained by Neb, and any one would have said that the Negro and the ape understood each other when they talked together. Jup had besides a real affection for Neb, and Neb returned it. When his services were not required, either for carrying wood or for climbing to the top of some tree, Jup passed the greatest part of his time in the kitchen, where he endeavored to imitate Neb in all that he saw him do. The black showed the greatest patience and even extreme zeal in instructing his pupil, and the pupil exhibited remarkable intelligence in profiting by the lessons he received from his master.

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Judge then of the pleasure Master Jup gave to the inhabitants of Granite House when, without their having had any idea of it, he appeared one day, napkin on his arm, ready to wait at table. Quick, attentive, he acquitted himself perfectly, changing the plates, bringing dishes, pouring out water, all with a gravity which gave intense amusement to the settlers, and which enraptured Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Judge then of the pleasure Master Jup gave to the inhabitants of Granite House when without their having had any idea of it he appeared one day napkin on his arm ready to wait at table Quick attentive he acquitted himself perfectly changing the plates bringing dishes pouring out water all with a gravity which gave intense amusement to the settlers and which enraptured Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Jup, some soup!
children.prevalue: Jup some soup

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Jup, a little agouti!
children.prevalue: Jup a little agouti

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Jup, a plate!
children.prevalue: Jup a plate

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Jup! Good Jup! Honest Jup!
children.prevalue: Jup Good Jup Honest Jup

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Nothing was heard but that, and Jup without ever being disconcerted, replied to every one, watched for everything, and he shook his head in a knowing way when Pencroft, referring to his joke of the first day, said to him,--
children.prevalue: Nothing was heard but that and Jup without ever being disconcerted replied to every one watched for everything and he shook his head in a knowing way when Pencroft referring to his joke of the first day said to him

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Decidedly, Jup, your wages must be doubled.
children.prevalue: Decidedly Jup your wages must be doubled

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It is useless to say that the orang was now thoroughly domesticated at Granite House, and that he often accompanied his masters to the forest without showing any wish to leave them. It was most amusing to see him walking with a stick which Pencroft had given him, and which he carried on his shoulder like a gun. If they wished to gather some fruit from the summit of a tree, how quickly he climbed for it. If the wheel of the cart stuck in the mud, with what energy did Jup with a single heave of his shoulder put it right again.
children.prevalue: It is useless to say that the orang was now thoroughly domesticated at Granite House and that he often accompanied his masters to the forest without showing any wish to leave them It was most amusing to see him walking with a stick which Pencroft had given him and which he carried on his shoulder like a gun If they wished to gather some fruit from the summit of a tree how quickly he climbed for it If the wheel of the cart stuck in the mud with what energy did Jup with a single heave of his shoulder put it right again

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What a jolly fellow he is! cried Pencroft often. If he was as mischievous as he is good, there would be no doing anything with him!
children.prevalue: What a jolly fellow he is cried Pencroft often If he was as mischievous as he is good there would be no doing anything with him

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It was towards the end of January the colonists began their labors in the center of the island. It had been decided that a corral should be established near the sources of the Red Creek, at the foot of Mount Franklin, destined to contain the ruminants, whose presence would have been troublesome at Granite House, and especially for the musmons, who were to supply the wool for the settlers' winter garments.
children.prevalue: It was towards the end of January the colonists began their labors in the center of the island It had been decided that a corral should be established near the sources of the Red Creek at the foot of Mount Franklin destined to contain the ruminants whose presence would have been troublesome at Granite House and especially for the musmons who were to supply the wool for the settlers winter garments

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Each morning, the colony, sometimes entire, but more often represented only by Harding, Herbert, and Pencroft, proceeded to the sources of the Creek, a distance of not more than five miles, by the newly beaten road to which the name of Corral Road had been given.
children.prevalue: Each morning the colony sometimes entire but more often represented only by Harding Herbert and Pencroft proceeded to the sources of the Creek a distance of not more than five miles by the newly beaten road to which the name of Corral Road had been given

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: There a site was chosen, at the back of the southern ridge of the mountain. It was a meadow land, dotted here and there with clumps of trees, and watered by a little stream, which sprung from the slopes which closed it in on one side. The grass was fresh, and it was not too much shaded by the trees which grew about it. This meadow was to be surrounded by a palisade, high enough to prevent even the most agile animals from leaping over. This enclosure would be large enough to contain a hundred musmons and wild goats, with all the young ones they might produce.
children.prevalue: There a site was chosen at the back of the southern ridge of the mountain It was a meadow land dotted here and there with clumps of trees and watered by a little stream which sprung from the slopes which closed it in on one side The grass was fresh and it was not too much shaded by the trees which grew about it This meadow was to be surrounded by a palisade high enough to prevent even the most agile animals from leaping over This enclosure would be large enough to contain a hundred musmons and wild goats with all the young ones they might produce

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The perimeter of the corral was then traced by the engineer, and they would then have proceeded to fell the trees necessary for the construction of the palisade, but as the opening up of the road had already necessitated the sacrifice of a considerable number, those were brought and supplied a hundred stakes, which were firmly fixed in the ground.
children.prevalue: The perimeter of the corral was then traced by the engineer and they would then have proceeded to fell the trees necessary for the construction of the palisade but as the opening up of the road had already necessitated the sacrifice of a considerable number those were brought and supplied a hundred stakes which were firmly fixed in the ground

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The construction of this corral did not take less than three weeks, for besides the palisade, Cyrus Harding built large sheds, in which the animals could take shelter. These buildings had also to be made very strong, for musmons are powerful animals, and their first fury was to be feared. The stakes, sharpened at their upper end and hardened by fire, had been fixed by means of cross-bars, and at regular distances props assured the solidity of the whole.
children.prevalue: The construction of this corral did not take less than three weeks for besides the palisade Cyrus Harding built large sheds in which the animals could take shelter These buildings had also to be made very strong for musmons are powerful animals and their first fury was to be feared The stakes sharpened at their upper end and hardened by fire had been fixed by means of cross bars and at regular distances props assured the solidity of the whole

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The corral finished, a raid had to be made on the pastures frequented by the ruminants. This was done on the 7th of February, on a beautiful summer's day, and every one took part in it. The onagers, already well trained, were ridden by Spilett and Herbert, and were of great use.
children.prevalue: The corral finished a raid had to be made on the pastures frequented by the ruminants This was done on the 7th of February on a beautiful summer s day and every one took part in it The onagers already well trained were ridden by Spilett and Herbert and were of great use

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The maneuver consisted simply in surrounding the musmons and goats, and gradually narrowing the circle around them. Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, Neb, and Jup, posted themselves in different parts of the wood, while the two cavaliers and Top galloped in a radius of half a mile round the corral.
children.prevalue: The maneuver consisted simply in surrounding the musmons and goats and gradually narrowing the circle around them Cyrus Harding Pencroft Neb and Jup posted themselves in different parts of the wood while the two cavaliers and Top galloped in a radius of half a mile round the corral

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The musmons were very numerous in this part of the island. These fine animals were as large as deer; their horns were stronger than those of the ram, and their gray-colored fleece was mixed with long hair.
children.prevalue: The musmons were very numerous in this part of the island These fine animals were as large as deer their horns were stronger than those of the ram and their gray colored fleece was mixed with long hair

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: This hunting day was very fatiguing. Such going and coming, and running and riding and shouting! Of a hundred musmons which had been surrounded, more than two-thirds escaped, but at last, thirty of these animals and ten wild goats were gradually driven back towards the corral, the open door of which appearing to offer a means of escape, they rushed in and were prisoners.
children.prevalue: This hunting day was very fatiguing Such going and coming and running and riding and shouting Of a hundred musmons which had been surrounded more than two thirds escaped but at last thirty of these animals and ten wild goats were gradually driven back towards the corral the open door of which appearing to offer a means of escape they rushed in and were prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: In short, the result was satisfactory, and the settlers had no reason to complain. There was no doubt that the flock would prosper, and that at no distant time not only wool but hides would be abundant.
children.prevalue: In short the result was satisfactory and the settlers had no reason to complain There was no doubt that the flock would prosper and that at no distant time not only wool but hides would be abundant

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: That evening the hunters returned to Granite House quite exhausted. However, notwithstanding their fatigue, they returned the next day to visit the corral. The prisoners had been trying to overthrow the palisade, but of course had not succeeded, and were not long in becoming more tranquil.
children.prevalue: That evening the hunters returned to Granite House quite exhausted However notwithstanding their fatigue they returned the next day to visit the corral The prisoners had been trying to overthrow the palisade but of course had not succeeded and were not long in becoming more tranquil

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: During the month of February, no event of any importance occurred. The daily labors were pursued methodically, and, as well as improving the roads to the corral and to Port Balloon, a third was commenced, which, starting from the enclosure, proceeded towards the western coast. The yet unknown portion of Lincoln Island was that of the wood-covered Serpentine Peninsula, which sheltered the wild beasts, from which Gideon Spilett was so anxious to clear their domain.
children.prevalue: During the month of February no event of any importance occurred The daily labors were pursued methodically and as well as improving the roads to the corral and to Port Balloon a third was commenced which starting from the enclosure proceeded towards the western coast The yet unknown portion of Lincoln Island was that of the wood covered Serpentine Peninsula which sheltered the wild beasts from which Gideon Spilett was so anxious to clear their domain

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Before the cold season should appear the most assiduous care was given to the cultivation of the wild plants which had been transplanted from the forest to Prospect Heights. Herbert never returned from an excursion without bringing home some useful vegetable. One day, it was some specimens of the chicory tribe, the seeds of which by pressure yield an excellent oil; another, it was some common sorrel, whose antiscorbutic qualities were not to be despised; then, some of those precious tubers, which have at all times been cultivated in South America, potatoes, of which more than two hundred species are now known. The kitchen garden, now well stocked and carefully defended from the birds, was divided into small beds, where grew lettuces, kidney potatoes, sorrel, turnips, radishes, and other coneiferae. The soil on the plateau was particularly fertile, and it was hoped that the harvests would be abundant.
children.prevalue: Before the cold season should appear the most assiduous care was given to the cultivation of the wild plants which had been transplanted from the forest to Prospect Heights Herbert never returned from an excursion without bringing home some useful vegetable One day it was some specimens of the chicory tribe the seeds of which by pressure yield an excellent oil another it was some common sorrel whose antiscorbutic qualities were not to be despised then some of those precious tubers which have at all times been cultivated in South America potatoes of which more than two hundred species are now known The kitchen garden now well stocked and carefully defended from the birds was divided into small beds where grew lettuces kidney potatoes sorrel turnips radishes and other coneiferae The soil on the plateau was particularly fertile and it was hoped that the harvests would be abundant

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: They had also a variety of different beverages, and so long as they did not demand wine, the most hard to please would have had no reason to complain. To the Oswego tea, and the fermented liquor extracted from the roots of the dragonnier, Harding had added a regular beer, made from the young shoots of the spruce-fir, which, after having been boiled and fermented, made that agreeable drink called by the Anglo-Americans spring-beer.
children.prevalue: They had also a variety of different beverages and so long as they did not demand wine the most hard to please would have had no reason to complain To the Oswego tea and the fermented liquor extracted from the roots of the dragonnier Harding had added a regular beer made from the young shoots of the spruce fir which after having been boiled and fermented made that agreeable drink called by the Anglo Americans spring beer

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Towards the end of the summer, the poultry-yard was possessed of a couple of fine bustards, which belonged to the houbara species, characterized by a sort of feathery mantle; a dozen shovelers, whose upper mandible was prolonged on each side by a membraneous appendage; and also some magnificent cocks, similar to the Mozambique cocks, the comb, caruncle, and epidermis being black. So far, everything had succeeded, thanks to the activity of these courageous and intelligent men. Nature did much for them, doubtless; but faithful to the great precept, they made a right use of what a bountiful Providence gave them.
children.prevalue: Towards the end of the summer the poultry yard was possessed of a couple of fine bustards which belonged to the houbara species characterized by a sort of feathery mantle a dozen shovelers whose upper mandible was prolonged on each side by a membraneous appendage and also some magnificent cocks similar to the Mozambique cocks the comb caruncle and epidermis being black So far everything had succeeded thanks to the activity of these courageous and intelligent men Nature did much for them doubtless but faithful to the great precept they made a right use of what a bountiful Providence gave them

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: After the heat of these warm summer days, in the evening when their work was finished and the sea-breeze began to blow, they liked to sit on the edge of Prospect Heights, in a sort of veranda, covered with creepers, which Neb had made with his own hands. There they talked, they instructed each other, they made plans, and the rough good-humor of the sailor always amused this little world, in which the most perfect harmony had never ceased to reign.
children.prevalue: After the heat of these warm summer days in the evening when their work was finished and the sea breeze began to blow they liked to sit on the edge of Prospect Heights in a sort of veranda covered with creepers which Neb had made with his own hands There they talked they instructed each other they made plans and the rough good humor of the sailor always amused this little world in which the most perfect harmony had never ceased to reign

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: They often spoke of their country, of their dear and great America. What was the result of the War of Secession? It could not have been greatly prolonged. Richmond had doubtless soon fallen into the hands of General Grant. The taking of the capital of the Confederates must have been the last action of this terrible struggle. Now the North had triumphed in the good cause, how welcome would have been a newspaper to the exiles in Lincoln Island! For eleven months all communication between them and the rest of their fellow-creatures had been interrupted, and in a short time the 24th of March would arrive, the anniversary of the day on which the balloon had thrown them on this unknown coast. They were then mere castaways, not even knowing how they should preserve their miserable lives from the fury of the elements! And now, thanks to the knowledge of their captain, and their own intelligence, they were regular colonists, furnished with arms, tools, and instruments; they had been able to turn to their profit the animals, plants, and minerals of the island, that is to say, the three kingdoms of Nature.
children.prevalue: They often spoke of their country of their dear and great America What was the result of the War of Secession It could not have been greatly prolonged Richmond had doubtless soon fallen into the hands of General Grant The taking of the capital of the Confederates must have been the last action of this terrible struggle Now the North had triumphed in the good cause how welcome would have been a newspaper to the exiles in Lincoln Island For eleven months all communication between them and the rest of their fellow creatures had been interrupted and in a short time the 24th of March would arrive the anniversary of the day on which the balloon had thrown them on this unknown coast They were then mere castaways not even knowing how they should preserve their miserable lives from the fury of the elements And now thanks to the knowledge of their captain and their own intelligence they were regular colonists furnished with arms tools and instruments they had been able to turn to their profit the animals plants and minerals of the island that is to say the three kingdoms of Nature

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes; they often talked of all these things and formed still more plans.
children.prevalue: Yes they often talked of all these things and formed still more plans

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: As to Cyrus Harding he was for the most part silent, and listened to his companions more often than he spoke to them. Sometimes he smiled at Herbert's ideas or Pencroft's nonsense, but always and everywhere he pondered over those inexplicable facts, that strange enigma, of which the secret still escaped him!
children.prevalue: As to Cyrus Harding he was for the most part silent and listened to his companions more often than he spoke to them Sometimes he smiled at Herbert s ideas or Pencroft s nonsense but always and everywhere he pondered over those inexplicable facts that strange enigma of which the secret still escaped him

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The weather changed during the first week of March. There had been a full moon at the commencement of the month, and the heat was excessive. The atmosphere was felt to be full of electricity, and a period of some length of tempestuous weather was to be feared.
children.prevalue: The weather changed during the first week of March There had been a full moon at the commencement of the month and the heat was excessive The atmosphere was felt to be full of electricity and a period of some length of tempestuous weather was to be feared

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Indeed, on the 2nd, peals of thunder were heard, the wind blew from the east, and hail rattled against the facade of Granite House like volleys of grape-shot. The door and windows were immediately closed, or everything in the rooms would have been drenched. On seeing these hailstones, some of which were the size of a pigeon's egg, Pencroft's first thought was that his cornfield was in serious danger.
children.prevalue: Indeed on the 2nd peals of thunder were heard the wind blew from the east and hail rattled against the facade of Granite House like volleys of grape shot The door and windows were immediately closed or everything in the rooms would have been drenched On seeing these hailstones some of which were the size of a pigeon s egg Pencroft s first thought was that his cornfield was in serious danger

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: He directly rushed to his field, where little green heads were already appearing, and by means of a great cloth, he managed to protect his crop.
children.prevalue: He directly rushed to his field where little green heads were already appearing and by means of a great cloth he managed to protect his crop

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: This bad weather lasted a week, during which time the thunder rolled without cessation in the depths of the sky.
children.prevalue: This bad weather lasted a week during which time the thunder rolled without cessation in the depths of the sky

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The colonists, not having any pressing work out of doors, profited by the bad weather to work at the interior of Granite House, the arrangement of which was becoming more complete from day to day. The engineer made a turning-lathe, with which he turned several articles both for the toilet and the kitchen, particularly buttons, the want of which was greatly felt. A gunrack had been made for the firearms, which were kept with extreme care, and neither tables nor cupboards were left incomplete. They sawed, they planed, they filed, they turned; and during the whole of this bad season, nothing was heard but the grinding of tools or the humming of the turning-lathe which responded to the growling of the thunder.
children.prevalue: The colonists not having any pressing work out of doors profited by the bad weather to work at the interior of Granite House the arrangement of which was becoming more complete from day to day The engineer made a turning lathe with which he turned several articles both for the toilet and the kitchen particularly buttons the want of which was greatly felt A gunrack had been made for the firearms which were kept with extreme care and neither tables nor cupboards were left incomplete They sawed they planed they filed they turned and during the whole of this bad season nothing was heard but the grinding of tools or the humming of the turning lathe which responded to the growling of the thunder

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Master Jup had not been forgotten, and he occupied a room at the back, near the storeroom, a sort of cabin with a cot always full of good litter, which perfectly suited his taste.
children.prevalue: Master Jup had not been forgotten and he occupied a room at the back near the storeroom a sort of cabin with a cot always full of good litter which perfectly suited his taste

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: With good old Jup there is never any quarreling, often repeated Pencroft, never any improper reply. What a servant, Neb, what a servant!
children.prevalue: With good old Jup there is never any quarreling often repeated Pencroft never any improper reply What a servant Neb what a servant

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Of course Jup was now well used to service. He brushed their clothes, he turned the spit, he waited at table, he swept the rooms, he gathered wood, and he performed another admirable piece of service which delighted Pencroft--he never went to sleep without first coming to tuck up the worthy sailor in his bed.
children.prevalue: Of course Jup was now well used to service He brushed their clothes he turned the spit he waited at table he swept the rooms he gathered wood and he performed another admirable piece of service which delighted Pencroft he never went to sleep without first coming to tuck up the worthy sailor in his bed

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: As to the health of the members of the colony, bipeds or bimana, quadrumana or quadrupeds, it left nothing to be desired. With their life in the open air, on this salubrious soil, under that temperate zone, working both with head and hands, they could not suppose that illness would ever attack them.
children.prevalue: As to the health of the members of the colony bipeds or bimana quadrumana or quadrupeds it left nothing to be desired With their life in the open air on this salubrious soil under that temperate zone working both with head and hands they could not suppose that illness would ever attack them

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: All were indeed wonderfully well. Herbert had already grown two inches in the year. His figure was forming and becoming more manly, and he promised to be an accomplished man, physically as well as morally. Besides he improved himself during the leisure hours which manual occupations left to him; he read the books found in the case; and after the practical lessons which were taught by the very necessity of their position, he found in the engineer for science, and the reporter for languages, masters who were delighted to complete his education.
children.prevalue: All were indeed wonderfully well Herbert had already grown two inches in the year His figure was forming and becoming more manly and he promised to be an accomplished man physically as well as morally Besides he improved himself during the leisure hours which manual occupations left to him he read the books found in the case and after the practical lessons which were taught by the very necessity of their position he found in the engineer for science and the reporter for languages masters who were delighted to complete his education

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The tempest ended about the 9th of March, but the sky remained covered with clouds during the whole of this last summer month. The atmosphere, violently agitated by the electric commotions, could not recover its former purity, and there was almost invariably rain and fog, except for three or four fine days on which several excursions were made. About this time the female onager gave birth to a young one which belonged to the same sex as its mother, and which throve capitally. In the corral, the flock of musmons had also increased, and several lambs already bleated in the sheds, to the great delight of Neb and Herbert, who had each their favorite among these newcomers. An attempt was also made for the domestication of the peccaries, which succeeded well. A sty was constructed under the poultry-yard, and soon contained several young ones in the way to become civilized, that is to say, to become fat under Neb's care. Master Jup, entrusted with carrying them their daily nourishment, leavings from the kitchen, etc., acquitted himself conscientiously of his task. He sometimes amused himself at the expense of his little pensioners by tweaking their tails; but this was mischief, and not wickedness, for these little twisted tails amused him like a plaything, and his instinct was that of a child. One day in this month of March, Pencroft, talking to the engineer, reminded Cyrus Harding of a promise which the latter had not as yet had time to fulfil.
children.prevalue: The tempest ended about the 9th of March but the sky remained covered with clouds during the whole of this last summer month The atmosphere violently agitated by the electric commotions could not recover its former purity and there was almost invariably rain and fog except for three or four fine days on which several excursions were made About this time the female onager gave birth to a young one which belonged to the same sex as its mother and which throve capitally In the corral the flock of musmons had also increased and several lambs already bleated in the sheds to the great delight of Neb and Herbert who had each their favorite among these newcomers An attempt was also made for the domestication of the peccaries which succeeded well A sty was constructed under the poultry yard and soon contained several young ones in the way to become civilized that is to say to become fat under Neb s care Master Jup entrusted with carrying them their daily nourishment leavings from the kitchen etc acquitted himself conscientiously of his task He sometimes amused himself at the expense of his little pensioners by tweaking their tails but this was mischief and not wickedness for these little twisted tails amused him like a plaything and his instinct was that of a child One day in this month of March Pencroft talking to the engineer reminded Cyrus Harding of a promise which the latter had not as yet had time to fulfil

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You once spoke of an apparatus which would take the place of the long ladders at Granite House, captain, said he; won't you make it some day?
children.prevalue: You once spoke of an apparatus which would take the place of the long ladders at Granite House captain said he won t you make it some day

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Nothing will be easier; but is this a really useful thing?
children.prevalue: Nothing will be easier but is this a really useful thing

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Certainly, captain. After we have given ourselves necessaries, let us think a little of luxury. For us it may be luxury, if you like, but for things it is necessary. It isn't very convenient to climb up a long ladder when one is heavily loaded.
children.prevalue: Certainly captain After we have given ourselves necessaries let us think a little of luxury For us it may be luxury if you like but for things it is necessary It isn t very convenient to climb up a long ladder when one is heavily loaded

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, Pencroft, we will try to please you, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Well Pencroft we will try to please you replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But you have no machine at your disposal.
children.prevalue: But you have no machine at your disposal

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: We will make one.
children.prevalue: We will make one

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: A steam machine?
children.prevalue: A steam machine

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No, a water machine.
children.prevalue: No a water machine

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: And, indeed, to work his apparatus there was already a natural force at the disposal of the engineer which could be used without great difficulty. For this, it was enough to augment the flow of the little stream which supplied the interior of Granite House with water. The opening among the stones and grass was then increased, thus producing a strong fall at the bottom of the passage, the overflow from which escaped by the inner well. Below this fall the engineer fixed a cylinder with paddles, which was joined on the exterior with a strong cable rolled on a wheel, supporting a basket. In this way, by means of a long rope reaching to the ground, which enabled them to regulate the motive power, they could rise in the basket to the door of Granite House.
children.prevalue: And indeed to work his apparatus there was already a natural force at the disposal of the engineer which could be used without great difficulty For this it was enough to augment the flow of the little stream which supplied the interior of Granite House with water The opening among the stones and grass was then increased thus producing a strong fall at the bottom of the passage the overflow from which escaped by the inner well Below this fall the engineer fixed a cylinder with paddles which was joined on the exterior with a strong cable rolled on a wheel supporting a basket In this way by means of a long rope reaching to the ground which enabled them to regulate the motive power they could rise in the basket to the door of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It was on the 17th of March that the lift acted for the first time, and gave universal satisfaction. Henceforward all the loads, wood, coal, provisions, and even the settlers themselves, were hoisted by this simple system, which replaced the primitive ladder, and, as may be supposed, no one thought of regretting the change. Top particularly was enchanted with this improvement, for he had not, and never could have possessed Master Jup's skill in climbing ladders, and often it was on Neb's back, or even on that of the orang that he had been obliged to make the ascent to Granite House. About this time, too, Cyrus Harding attempted to manufacture glass, and he at first put the old pottery-kiln to this new use. There were some difficulties to be encountered; but, after several fruitless attempts, he succeeded in setting up a glass manufactory, which Gideon Spilett and Herbert, his usual assistants, did not leave for several days. As to the substances used in the composition of glass, they are simply sand, chalk, and soda, either carbonate or sulphate. Now the beach supplied sand, lime supplied chalk, sea-weeds supplied soda, pyrites supplied sulphuric acid, and the ground supplied coal to heat the kiln to the wished-for temperature. Cyrus Harding thus soon had everything ready for setting to work.
children.prevalue: It was on the 17th of March that the lift acted for the first time and gave universal satisfaction Henceforward all the loads wood coal provisions and even the settlers themselves were hoisted by this simple system which replaced the primitive ladder and as may be supposed no one thought of regretting the change Top particularly was enchanted with this improvement for he had not and never could have possessed Master Jup s skill in climbing ladders and often it was on Neb s back or even on that of the orang that he had been obliged to make the ascent to Granite House About this time too Cyrus Harding attempted to manufacture glass and he at first put the old pottery kiln to this new use There were some difficulties to be encountered but after several fruitless attempts he succeeded in setting up a glass manufactory which Gideon Spilett and Herbert his usual assistants did not leave for several days As to the substances used in the composition of glass they are simply sand chalk and soda either carbonate or sulphate Now the beach supplied sand lime supplied chalk sea weeds supplied soda pyrites supplied sulphuric acid and the ground supplied coal to heat the kiln to the wished for temperature Cyrus Harding thus soon had everything ready for setting to work

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The tool, the manufacture of which presented the most difficulty, was the pipe of the glass-maker, an iron tube, five or six feet long, which collects on one end the material in a state of fusion. But by means of a long, thin piece of iron rolled up like the barrel of a gun, Pencroft succeeded in making a tube soon ready for use.
children.prevalue: The tool the manufacture of which presented the most difficulty was the pipe of the glass maker an iron tube five or six feet long which collects on one end the material in a state of fusion But by means of a long thin piece of iron rolled up like the barrel of a gun Pencroft succeeded in making a tube soon ready for use

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: On the 28th of March the tube was heated. A hundred parts of sand, thirty-five of chalk, forty of sulphate of soda, mixed with two or three parts of powdered coal, composed the substance, which was placed in crucibles. When the high temperature of the oven had reduced it to a liquid, or rather a pasty state, Cyrus Harding collected with the tube a quantity of the paste: he turned it about on a metal plate, previously arranged, so as to give it a form suitable for blowing, then he passed the tube to Herbert, telling him to blow at the other extremity.
children.prevalue: On the 28th of March the tube was heated A hundred parts of sand thirty five of chalk forty of sulphate of soda mixed with two or three parts of powdered coal composed the substance which was placed in crucibles When the high temperature of the oven had reduced it to a liquid or rather a pasty state Cyrus Harding collected with the tube a quantity of the paste he turned it about on a metal plate previously arranged so as to give it a form suitable for blowing then he passed the tube to Herbert telling him to blow at the other extremity

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And Herbert, swelling out his cheeks, blew so much and so well into the tube-taking care to twirl it round at the same time--that his breath dilated the glassy mass. Other quantities of the substance in a state of fusion were added to the first, and in a short time the result was a bubble which measured a foot in diameter. Harding then took the tube out of Herbert's hands, and, giving it a pendulous motion, he ended by lengthening the malleable bubble so as to give it a cylindroconic shape.
children.prevalue: And Herbert swelling out his cheeks blew so much and so well into the tube taking care to twirl it round at the same time that his breath dilated the glassy mass Other quantities of the substance in a state of fusion were added to the first and in a short time the result was a bubble which measured a foot in diameter Harding then took the tube out of Herbert s hands and giving it a pendulous motion he ended by lengthening the malleable bubble so as to give it a cylindroconic shape

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The blowing operation had given a cylinder of glass terminated by two hemispheric caps, which were easily detached by means of a sharp iron dipped in cold water; then, by the same proceeding, this cylinder was cut lengthways, and after having been rendered malleable by a second heating, it was extended on a plate and spread out with a wooden roller.
children.prevalue: The blowing operation had given a cylinder of glass terminated by two hemispheric caps which were easily detached by means of a sharp iron dipped in cold water then by the same proceeding this cylinder was cut lengthways and after having been rendered malleable by a second heating it was extended on a plate and spread out with a wooden roller

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The first pane was thus manufactured, and they had only to perform this operation fifty times to have fifty panes. The windows at Granite House were soon furnished with panes; not very white, perhaps, but still sufficiently transparent.
children.prevalue: The first pane was thus manufactured and they had only to perform this operation fifty times to have fifty panes The windows at Granite House were soon furnished with panes not very white perhaps but still sufficiently transparent

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: As to bottles and tumblers, that was only play. They were satisfied with them, besides, just as they came from the end of the tube. Pencroft had asked to be allowed to blow in his turn, and it was great fun for him; but he blew so hard that his productions took the most ridiculous shapes, which he admired immensely.
children.prevalue: As to bottles and tumblers that was only play They were satisfied with them besides just as they came from the end of the tube Pencroft had asked to be allowed to blow in his turn and it was great fun for him but he blew so hard that his productions took the most ridiculous shapes which he admired immensely

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Herbert, while hunting one day, had entered the forest of the Far West, on the left bank of the Mercy, and, as usual, the lad was asking a thousand questions of the engineer, who answered them heartily. Now, as Harding was not a sportsman, and as, on the other side, Herbert was talking chemistry and natural philosophy, numbers of kangaroos, capybaras, and agouties came within range, which, however, escaped the lad's gun; the consequence was that the day was already advanced, and the two hunters were in danger of having made a useless excursion, when Herbert, stopping, and uttering a cry of joy, exclaimed,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Herbert while hunting one day had entered the forest of the Far West on the left bank of the Mercy and as usual the lad was asking a thousand questions of the engineer who answered them heartily Now as Harding was not a sportsman and as on the other side Herbert was talking chemistry and natural philosophy numbers of kangaroos capybaras and agouties came within range which however escaped the lad s gun the consequence was that the day was already advanced and the two hunters were in danger of having made a useless excursion when Herbert stopping and uttering a cry of joy exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh, Captain Harding, do you see that tree? and he pointed to a shrub, rather than a tree, for it was composed of a single stem, covered with a scaly bark, which bore leaves streaked with little parallel veins.
children.prevalue: Oh Captain Harding do you see that tree and he pointed to a shrub rather than a tree for it was composed of a single stem covered with a scaly bark which bore leaves streaked with little parallel veins

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And what is this tree which resembles a little palm? asked Harding.
children.prevalue: And what is this tree which resembles a little palm asked Harding

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: It is a 'cycas revoluta,' of which I have a picture in our dictionary of Natural History! said Herbert.
children.prevalue: It is a cycas revoluta of which I have a picture in our dictionary of Natural History said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But I can't see any fruit on this shrub! observed his companion.
children.prevalue: But I can t see any fruit on this shrub observed his companion

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: No, captain, replied Herbert; but its stem contains a flour with which nature has provided us all ready ground.
children.prevalue: No captain replied Herbert but its stem contains a flour with which nature has provided us all ready ground

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It is, then, the bread-tree?
children.prevalue: It is then the bread tree

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Yes, the bread-tree.
children.prevalue: Yes the bread tree

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Well, my boy, replied the engineer, this is a valuable discovery, since our wheat harvest is not yet ripe; I hope that you are not mistaken!
children.prevalue: Well my boy replied the engineer this is a valuable discovery since our wheat harvest is not yet ripe I hope that you are not mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Herbert was not mistaken: he broke the stem of a cycas, which was composed of a glandulous tissue, containing a quantity of floury pith, traversed with woody fiber, separated by rings of the same substance, arranged concentrically. With this fecula was mingled a mucilaginous juice of disagreeable flavor, but which it would be easy to get rid of by pressure. This cellular substance was regular flour of a superior quality, extremely nourishing; its exportation was formerly forbidden by the Japanese laws.
children.prevalue: Herbert was not mistaken he broke the stem of a cycas which was composed of a glandulous tissue containing a quantity of floury pith traversed with woody fiber separated by rings of the same substance arranged concentrically With this fecula was mingled a mucilaginous juice of disagreeable flavor but which it would be easy to get rid of by pressure This cellular substance was regular flour of a superior quality extremely nourishing its exportation was formerly forbidden by the Japanese laws

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Herbert, after having examined that part of the Far West where the cycas grew, took their bearings, and returned to Granite House, where they made known their discovery.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Herbert after having examined that part of the Far West where the cycas grew took their bearings and returned to Granite House where they made known their discovery

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The next day the settlers went to collect some, and returned to Granite House with an ample supply of cycas stems. The engineer constructed a press, with which to extract the mucilaginous juice mingled with the fecula, and he obtained a large quantity of flour, which Neb soon transformed into cakes and puddings. This was not quite real wheaten bread, but it was very like it.
children.prevalue: The next day the settlers went to collect some and returned to Granite House with an ample supply of cycas stems The engineer constructed a press with which to extract the mucilaginous juice mingled with the fecula and he obtained a large quantity of flour which Neb soon transformed into cakes and puddings This was not quite real wheaten bread but it was very like it

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Now, too, the onager, the goats, and the sheep in the corral furnished daily the milk necessary to the colony. The cart, or rather a sort of light carriole which had replaced it, made frequent journeys to the corral, and when it was Pencroft's turn to go he took Jup, and let him drive, and Jup, cracking his whip, acquitted himself with his customary intelligence.
children.prevalue: Now too the onager the goats and the sheep in the corral furnished daily the milk necessary to the colony The cart or rather a sort of light carriole which had replaced it made frequent journeys to the corral and when it was Pencroft s turn to go he took Jup and let him drive and Jup cracking his whip acquitted himself with his customary intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Everything prospered, as well in the corral as in Granite House, and certainly the settlers, if it had not been that they were so far from their native land, had no reason to complain. They were so well suited to this life, and were, besides, so accustomed to the island, that they could not have left its hospitable soil without regret!
children.prevalue: Everything prospered as well in the corral as in Granite House and certainly the settlers if it had not been that they were so far from their native land had no reason to complain They were so well suited to this life and were besides so accustomed to the island that they could not have left its hospitable soil without regret

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And yet so deeply is the love of his country implanted in the heart of man, that if a ship had unexpectedly come in sight of the island, the colonists would have made signals, would have attracted her attention, and would have departed!
children.prevalue: And yet so deeply is the love of his country implanted in the heart of man that if a ship had unexpectedly come in sight of the island the colonists would have made signals would have attracted her attention and would have departed

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It was the 1st of April, a Sunday, Easter Day, which Harding and his companions sanctified by rest and prayer. The day was fine, such as an October day in the Northern Hemisphere might be.
children.prevalue: It was the 1st of April a Sunday Easter Day which Harding and his companions sanctified by rest and prayer The day was fine such as an October day in the Northern Hemisphere might be

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: All, towards the evening after dinner, were seated under the veranda on the edge of Prospect Heights, and they were watching the darkness creeping up from the horizon. Some cups of the infusion of elder-berries, which took the place of coffee, had been served by Neb. They were speaking of the island and of its isolated situation in the Pacific, which led Gideon Spilett to say,--

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: My dear Cyrus, have you ever, since you possessed the sextant found in the case, again taken the position of our island?
children.prevalue: My dear Cyrus have you ever since you possessed the sextant found in the case again taken the position of our island

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: No, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: No replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But it would perhaps be a good thing to do it with this instrument, which is more perfect than that which you before used.
children.prevalue: But it would perhaps be a good thing to do it with this instrument which is more perfect than that which you before used

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What is the good? said Pencroft. The island is quite comfortable where it is!
children.prevalue: What is the good said Pencroft The island is quite comfortable where it is

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Well, who knows, returned the reporter, who knows but that we may be much nearer inhabited land than we think?
children.prevalue: Well who knows returned the reporter who knows but that we may be much nearer inhabited land than we think

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: We shall know to-morrow, replied Cyrus Harding, and if it had not been for the occupations which left me no leisure, we should have known it already.
children.prevalue: We shall know to morrow replied Cyrus Harding and if it had not been for the occupations which left me no leisure we should have known it already

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Good! said Pencroft. The captain is too good an observer to be mistaken, and, if it has not moved from its place, the island is just where he put it.
children.prevalue: Good said Pencroft The captain is too good an observer to be mistaken and if it has not moved from its place the island is just where he put it

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: We shall see.
children.prevalue: We shall see

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: On the next day, therefore, by means of the sextant, the engineer made the necessary observations to verify the position which he had already obtained, and this was the result of his operation. His first observation had given him the situation of Lincoln Island,--
children.prevalue: On the next day therefore by means of the sextant the engineer made the necessary observations to verify the position which he had already obtained and this was the result of his operation His first observation had given him the situation of Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: In west longitude: from 150deg. to 155deg.;
children.prevalue: In west longitude from 150deg to 155deg

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: In south latitude: from 30deg. to 35deg.
children.prevalue: In south latitude from 30deg to 35deg

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The second gave exactly:
children.prevalue: The second gave exactly

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: In longitude: 150deg. 30'
children.prevalue: In longitude 150deg 30

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: In south latitude: 34deg. 57'
children.prevalue: In south latitude 34deg 57

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: So then, notwithstanding the imperfection of his apparatus, Cyrus Harding had operated with so much skill that his error did not exceed five degrees.
children.prevalue: So then notwithstanding the imperfection of his apparatus Cyrus Harding had operated with so much skill that his error did not exceed five degrees

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Now, said Gideon Spilett, since we possess an atlas as well as a sextant, let us see, my dear Cyrus, the exact position which Lincoln Island occupies in the Pacific.
children.prevalue: Now said Gideon Spilett since we possess an atlas as well as a sextant let us see my dear Cyrus the exact position which Lincoln Island occupies in the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Herbert fetched the atlas, and the map of the Pacific was opened, and the engineer, compass in hand, prepared to determine their position.
children.prevalue: Herbert fetched the atlas and the map of the Pacific was opened and the engineer compass in hand prepared to determine their position

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Suddenly the compasses stopped, and he exclaimed,
children.prevalue: Suddenly the compasses stopped and he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But an island exists in this part of the Pacific already!
children.prevalue: But an island exists in this part of the Pacific already

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: An island? cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: An island cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: An important island?
children.prevalue: An important island

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: No, an islet lost in the Pacific, and which perhaps has never been visited.
children.prevalue: No an islet lost in the Pacific and which perhaps has never been visited

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Well, we will visit it, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Well we will visit it said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: We?
children.prevalue: We

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Yes, captain. We will build a decked boat, and I will undertake to steer her. At what distance are we from this Tabor Island?
children.prevalue: Yes captain We will build a decked boat and I will undertake to steer her At what distance are we from this Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: About a hundred and fifty miles to the northeast, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: About a hundred and fifty miles to the northeast replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: A hundred and fifty miles! And what's that? returned Pencroft. In forty-eight hours, with a good wind, we should sight it!
children.prevalue: A hundred and fifty miles And what s that returned Pencroft In forty eight hours with a good wind we should sight it

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And, on this reply, it was decided that a vessel should be constructed in time to be launched towards the month of next October, on the return of the fine season.
children.prevalue: And on this reply it was decided that a vessel should be constructed in time to be launched towards the month of next October on the return of the fine season

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When Pencroft had once got a plan in his head, he had no peace till it was executed. Now he wished to visit Tabor Island, and as a boat of a certain size was necessary for this voyage, he determined to build one.
children.prevalue: When Pencroft had once got a plan in his head he had no peace till it was executed Now he wished to visit Tabor Island and as a boat of a certain size was necessary for this voyage he determined to build one

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What wood should he employ? Elm or fir, both of which abounded in the island? They decided for the fir, as being easy to work, but which stands water as well as the elm.
children.prevalue: What wood should he employ Elm or fir both of which abounded in the island They decided for the fir as being easy to work but which stands water as well as the elm

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: These details settled, it was agreed that since the fine season would not return before six months, Cyrus Harding and Pencroft should work alone at the boat. Gideon Spilett and Herbert were to continue to hunt, and neither Neb nor Master Jup, his assistant, were to leave the domestic duties which had devolved upon them.
children.prevalue: These details settled it was agreed that since the fine season would not return before six months Cyrus Harding and Pencroft should work alone at the boat Gideon Spilett and Herbert were to continue to hunt and neither Neb nor Master Jup his assistant were to leave the domestic duties which had devolved upon them

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Directly the trees were chosen, they were felled, stripped of their branches, and sawn into planks as well as sawyers would have been able to do it. A week after, in the recess between the Chimneys and the cliff, a dockyard was prepared, and a keel five-and-thirty feet long, furnished with a stern-post at the stern and a stem at the bows, lay along the sand.
children.prevalue: Directly the trees were chosen they were felled stripped of their branches and sawn into planks as well as sawyers would have been able to do it A week after in the recess between the Chimneys and the cliff a dockyard was prepared and a keel five and thirty feet long furnished with a stern post at the stern and a stem at the bows lay along the sand

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Cyrus Harding was not working in the dark at this new trade. He knew as much about ship-building as about nearly everything else, and he had at first drawn the model of his ship on paper. Besides, he was ably seconded by Pencroft, who, having worked for several years in a dockyard in Brooklyn, knew the practical part of the trade. It was not until after careful calculation and deep thought that the timbers were laid on the keel.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding was not working in the dark at this new trade He knew as much about ship building as about nearly everything else and he had at first drawn the model of his ship on paper Besides he was ably seconded by Pencroft who having worked for several years in a dockyard in Brooklyn knew the practical part of the trade It was not until after careful calculation and deep thought that the timbers were laid on the keel

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Pencroft, as may be believed, was all eagerness to carry out his new enterprise, and would not leave his work for an instant.
children.prevalue: Pencroft as may be believed was all eagerness to carry out his new enterprise and would not leave his work for an instant

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: A single thing had the honor of drawing him, but for one day only, from his dockyard. This was the second wheat-harvest, which was gathered in on the 15th of April. It was as much a success as the first, and yielded the number of grains which had been predicted.
children.prevalue: A single thing had the honor of drawing him but for one day only from his dockyard This was the second wheat harvest which was gathered in on the 15th of April It was as much a success as the first and yielded the number of grains which had been predicted

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Five bushels, captain, said Pencroft, after having scrupulously measured his treasure.
children.prevalue: Five bushels captain said Pencroft after having scrupulously measured his treasure

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Five bushels, replied the engineer; and a hundred and thirty thousand grains a bushel will make six hundred and fifty thousand grains.
children.prevalue: Five bushels replied the engineer and a hundred and thirty thousand grains a bushel will make six hundred and fifty thousand grains

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Well, we will sow them all this time, said the sailor, except a little in reserve.
children.prevalue: Well we will sow them all this time said the sailor except a little in reserve

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, Pencroft, and if the next crop gives a proportionate yield, we shall have four thousand bushels.
children.prevalue: Yes Pencroft and if the next crop gives a proportionate yield we shall have four thousand bushels

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And shall we eat bread?
children.prevalue: And shall we eat bread

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: We shall eat bread.
children.prevalue: We shall eat bread

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But we must have a mill.
children.prevalue: But we must have a mill

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: We will make one.
children.prevalue: We will make one

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The third corn-field was very much larger than the two first, and the soil, prepared with extreme care, received the precious seed. That done, Pencroft returned to his work.
children.prevalue: The third corn field was very much larger than the two first and the soil prepared with extreme care received the precious seed That done Pencroft returned to his work

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: During this time Spilett and Herbert hunted in the neighborhood, and they ventured deep into the still unknown parts of the Far West, their guns loaded with ball, ready for any dangerous emergency. It was a vast thicket of magnificent trees, crowded together as if pressed for room. The exploration of these dense masses of wood was difficult in the extreme, and the reporter never ventured there without the pocket-compass, for the sun scarcely pierced through the thick foliage and it would have been very difficult for them to retrace their way. It naturally happened that game was more rare in those situations where there was hardly sufficient room to move; two or three large herbivorous animals were however killed during the last fortnight of April. These were koalas, specimens of which the settlers had already seen to the north of the lake, and which stupidly allowed themselves to be killed among the thick branches of the trees in which they took refuge. Their skins were brought back to Granite House, and there, by the help of sulphuric acid, they were subjected to a sort of tanning process which rendered them capable of being used.
children.prevalue: During this time Spilett and Herbert hunted in the neighborhood and they ventured deep into the still unknown parts of the Far West their guns loaded with ball ready for any dangerous emergency It was a vast thicket of magnificent trees crowded together as if pressed for room The exploration of these dense masses of wood was difficult in the extreme and the reporter never ventured there without the pocket compass for the sun scarcely pierced through the thick foliage and it would have been very difficult for them to retrace their way It naturally happened that game was more rare in those situations where there was hardly sufficient room to move two or three large herbivorous animals were however killed during the last fortnight of April These were koalas specimens of which the settlers had already seen to the north of the lake and which stupidly allowed themselves to be killed among the thick branches of the trees in which they took refuge Their skins were brought back to Granite House and there by the help of sulphuric acid they were subjected to a sort of tanning process which rendered them capable of being used

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: On the 30th of April, the two sportsmen were in the depth of the Far West, when the reporter, preceding Herbert a few paces, arrived in a sort of clearing, into which the trees more sparsely scattered had permitted a few rays to penetrate. Gideon Spilett was at first surprised at the odor which exhaled from certain plants with straight stalks, round and branchy, bearing grape-like clusters of flowers and very small berries. The reporter broke off one or two of these stalks and returned to the lad, to whom he said,--
children.prevalue: On the 30th of April the two sportsmen were in the depth of the Far West when the reporter preceding Herbert a few paces arrived in a sort of clearing into which the trees more sparsely scattered had permitted a few rays to penetrate Gideon Spilett was at first surprised at the odor which exhaled from certain plants with straight stalks round and branchy bearing grape like clusters of flowers and very small berries The reporter broke off one or two of these stalks and returned to the lad to whom he said

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: What can this be, Herbert?
children.prevalue: What can this be Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Well, Mr. Spilett, said Herbert, this is a treasure which will secure you Pencroft's gratitude forever.
children.prevalue: Well Mr Spilett said Herbert this is a treasure which will secure you Pencroft s gratitude forever

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Is it tobacco?
children.prevalue: Is it tobacco

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes, and though it may not be of the first quality, it is none the less tobacco!
children.prevalue: Yes and though it may not be of the first quality it is none the less tobacco

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Oh, good old Pencroft! Won't he be pleased! But we must not let him smoke it all, he must give us our share.
children.prevalue: Oh good old Pencroft Won t he be pleased But we must not let him smoke it all he must give us our share

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Ah! an idea occurs to me, Mr. Spilett, replied Herbert. Don't let us say anything to Pencroft yet; we will prepare these leaves, and one fine day we will present him with a pipe already filled!
children.prevalue: Ah an idea occurs to me Mr Spilett replied Herbert Don t let us say anything to Pencroft yet we will prepare these leaves and one fine day we will present him with a pipe already filled

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: All right, Herbert, and on that day our worthy companion will have nothing left to wish for in this world.
children.prevalue: All right Herbert and on that day our worthy companion will have nothing left to wish for in this world

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The reporter and the lad secured a good store of the precious plant, and then returned to Granite House, where they smuggled it in with as much precaution as if Pencroft had been the most vigilant and severe of custom-house officers.
children.prevalue: The reporter and the lad secured a good store of the precious plant and then returned to Granite House where they smuggled it in with as much precaution as if Pencroft had been the most vigilant and severe of custom house officers

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Neb were taken into confidence, and the sailor suspected nothing during the whole time, necessarily somewhat long, which was required in order to dry the small leaves, chop them up, and subject them to a certain torrefaction on hot stones. This took two months; but all these manipulations were successfully carried on unknown to Pencroft, for, occupied with the construction of his boat, he only returned to Granite House at the hour of rest.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Neb were taken into confidence and the sailor suspected nothing during the whole time necessarily somewhat long which was required in order to dry the small leaves chop them up and subject them to a certain torrefaction on hot stones This took two months but all these manipulations were successfully carried on unknown to Pencroft for occupied with the construction of his boat he only returned to Granite House at the hour of rest

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: For some days they had observed an enormous animal two or three miles out in the open sea swimming around Lincoln Island. This was a whale of the largest size, which apparently belonged to the southern species, called the Cape Whale.
