children.prevalue: For some days they had observed an enormous animal two or three miles out in the open sea swimming around Lincoln Island This was a whale of the largest size which apparently belonged to the southern species called the Cape Whale

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What a lucky chance it would be if we could capture it! cried the sailor. Ah! if we only had a proper boat and a good harpoon, I would say 'After the beast,' for he would be well worth the trouble of catching!
children.prevalue: What a lucky chance it would be if we could capture it cried the sailor Ah if we only had a proper boat and a good harpoon I would say After the beast for he would be well worth the trouble of catching

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Well, Pencroft, observed Harding, I should much like to watch you handling a harpoon. It would be very interesting.
children.prevalue: Well Pencroft observed Harding I should much like to watch you handling a harpoon It would be very interesting

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I am astonished, said the reporter, to see a whale in this comparatively high latitude.
children.prevalue: I am astonished said the reporter to see a whale in this comparatively high latitude

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Why so, Mr. Spilett? replied Herbert. We are exactly in that part of the Pacific which English and American whalemen call the whale field, and it is here, between New Zealand and South America, that the whales of the Southern Hemisphere are met with in the greatest numbers.
children.prevalue: Why so Mr Spilett replied Herbert We are exactly in that part of the Pacific which English and American whalemen call the whale field and it is here between New Zealand and South America that the whales of the Southern Hemisphere are met with in the greatest numbers

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: And Pencroft returned to his work, not without uttering a sigh of regret, for every sailor is a born fisherman, and if the pleasure of fishing is in exact proportion to the size of the animal, one can judge how a whaler feels in sight of a whale. And if this had only been for pleasure! But they could not help feeling how valuable such a prize would have been to the colony, for the oil, fat, and bones would have been put to many uses.
children.prevalue: And Pencroft returned to his work not without uttering a sigh of regret for every sailor is a born fisherman and if the pleasure of fishing is in exact proportion to the size of the animal one can judge how a whaler feels in sight of a whale And if this had only been for pleasure But they could not help feeling how valuable such a prize would have been to the colony for the oil fat and bones would have been put to many uses

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Now it happened that this whale appeared to have no wish to leave the waters of the island. Therefore, whether from the windows of Granite House, or from Prospect Heights, Herbert and Gideon Spilett, when they were not hunting, or Neb, unless presiding over his fires, never left the telescope, but watched all the animal's movements. The cetacean, having entered far into Union Bay, made rapid furrows across it from Mandible Cape to Claw Cape, propelled by its enormously powerful flukes, on which it supported itself, and making its way through the water at the rate little short of twelve knots. Sometimes also it approached so near to the island that it could be clearly distinguished. It was the southern whale, which is completely black, the head being more depressed than that of the northern whale.
children.prevalue: Now it happened that this whale appeared to have no wish to leave the waters of the island Therefore whether from the windows of Granite House or from Prospect Heights Herbert and Gideon Spilett when they were not hunting or Neb unless presiding over his fires never left the telescope but watched all the animal s movements The cetacean having entered far into Union Bay made rapid furrows across it from Mandible Cape to Claw Cape propelled by its enormously powerful flukes on which it supported itself and making its way through the water at the rate little short of twelve knots Sometimes also it approached so near to the island that it could be clearly distinguished It was the southern whale which is completely black the head being more depressed than that of the northern whale

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: They could also see it throwing up from its air-holes to a great height a cloud of vapor, or of water, for, strange as it may appear, naturalists and whalers are not agreed on this subject. Is it air or is it water which is thus driven out? It is generally admitted to be vapor, which, condensing suddenly by contact with the cold air, falls again as rain.
children.prevalue: They could also see it throwing up from its air holes to a great height a cloud of vapor or of water for strange as it may appear naturalists and whalers are not agreed on this subject Is it air or is it water which is thus driven out It is generally admitted to be vapor which condensing suddenly by contact with the cold air falls again as rain

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: However, the presence of this mammifer preoccupied the colonists. It irritated Pencroft especially, as he could think of nothing else while at work. He ended by longing for it, like a child for a thing which it has been denied. At night he talked about it in his sleep, and certainly if he had had the means of attacking it, if the sloop had been in a fit state to put to sea, he would not have hesitated to set out in pursuit.
children.prevalue: However the presence of this mammifer preoccupied the colonists It irritated Pencroft especially as he could think of nothing else while at work He ended by longing for it like a child for a thing which it has been denied At night he talked about it in his sleep and certainly if he had had the means of attacking it if the sloop had been in a fit state to put to sea he would not have hesitated to set out in pursuit

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: But what the colonists could not do for themselves chance did for them, and on the 3rd of May shouts from Neb, who had stationed himself at the kitchen window, announced that the whale was stranded on the beach of the island.
children.prevalue: But what the colonists could not do for themselves chance did for them and on the 3rd of May shouts from Neb who had stationed himself at the kitchen window announced that the whale was stranded on the beach of the island

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Herbert and Gideon Spilett, who were just about to set out hunting, left their guns, Pencroft threw down his ax, and Harding and Neb joining their companions, all rushed towards the scene of action.
children.prevalue: Herbert and Gideon Spilett who were just about to set out hunting left their guns Pencroft threw down his ax and Harding and Neb joining their companions all rushed towards the scene of action

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The stranding had taken place on the beach of Flotsam Point, three miles from Granite House, and at high tide. It was therefore probable that the cetacean would not be able to extricate itself easily; at any rate it was best to hasten, so as to cut off its retreat if necessary. They ran with pick-axes and iron-tipped poles in their hands, passed over the Mercy bridge, descended the right bank of the river, along the beach, and in less than twenty minutes the settlers were close to the enormous animal, above which flocks of birds already hovered.
children.prevalue: The stranding had taken place on the beach of Flotsam Point three miles from Granite House and at high tide It was therefore probable that the cetacean would not be able to extricate itself easily at any rate it was best to hasten so as to cut off its retreat if necessary They ran with pick axes and iron tipped poles in their hands passed over the Mercy bridge descended the right bank of the river along the beach and in less than twenty minutes the settlers were close to the enormous animal above which flocks of birds already hovered

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: What a monster! cried Neb.
children.prevalue: What a monster cried Neb

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And the exclamation was natural, for it was a southern whale, eighty feet long, a giant of the species, probably not weighing less than a hundred and fifty thousand pounds!
children.prevalue: And the exclamation was natural for it was a southern whale eighty feet long a giant of the species probably not weighing less than a hundred and fifty thousand pounds

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In the meanwhile, the monster thus stranded did not move, nor attempt by struggling to regain the water while the tide was still high.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the monster thus stranded did not move nor attempt by struggling to regain the water while the tide was still high

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It was dead, and a harpoon was sticking out of its left side.
children.prevalue: It was dead and a harpoon was sticking out of its left side

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: There are whalers in these quarters, then? said Gideon Spilett directly.
children.prevalue: There are whalers in these quarters then said Gideon Spilett directly

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh, Mr. Spilett, that doesn't prove anything! replied Pencroft. Whales have been known to go thousands of miles with a harpoon in the side, and this one might even have been struck in the north of the Atlantic and come to die in the south of the Pacific, and it would be nothing astonishing.
children.prevalue: Oh Mr Spilett that doesn t prove anything replied Pencroft Whales have been known to go thousands of miles with a harpoon in the side and this one might even have been struck in the north of the Atlantic and come to die in the south of the Pacific and it would be nothing astonishing

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Pencroft, having torn the harpoon from the animal's side, read this inscription on it:
children.prevalue: Pencroft having torn the harpoon from the animal s side read this inscription on it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: MARIA STELLA, VINEYARD
children.prevalue: MARIA STELLA VINEYARD

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: A vessel from the Vineyard! A ship from my country! he cried. The 'Maria Stella!' A fine whaler, 'pon my word; I know her well! Oh, my friends, a vessel from the Vineyard!--a whaler from the Vineyard!
children.prevalue: A vessel from the Vineyard A ship from my country he cried The Maria Stella A fine whaler pon my word I know her well Oh my friends a vessel from the Vineyard a whaler from the Vineyard

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And the sailor brandishing the harpoon, repeated, not without emotion, the name which he loved so well--the name of his birthplace.
children.prevalue: And the sailor brandishing the harpoon repeated not without emotion the name which he loved so well the name of his birthplace

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: But as it could not be expected that the Maria Stella would come to reclaim the animal harpooned by her, they resolved to begin cutting it up before decomposition should commence. The birds, who had watched this rich prey for several days, had determined to take possession of it without further delay, and it was necessary to drive them off by firing at them repeatedly.
children.prevalue: But as it could not be expected that the Maria Stella would come to reclaim the animal harpooned by her they resolved to begin cutting it up before decomposition should commence The birds who had watched this rich prey for several days had determined to take possession of it without further delay and it was necessary to drive them off by firing at them repeatedly

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The whale was a female, and a large quantity of milk was taken from it, which, according to the opinion of the naturalist Duffenbach, might pass for cow's milk, and, indeed, it differs from it neither in taste, color, nor density.
children.prevalue: The whale was a female and a large quantity of milk was taken from it which according to the opinion of the naturalist Duffenbach might pass for cow s milk and indeed it differs from it neither in taste color nor density

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Pencroft had formerly served on board a whaling-ship, and he could methodically direct the operation of cutting up, a sufficiently disagreeable operation lasting three days, but from which the settlers did not flinch, not even Gideon Spilett, who, as the sailor said, would end by making a real good castaway.
children.prevalue: Pencroft had formerly served on board a whaling ship and he could methodically direct the operation of cutting up a sufficiently disagreeable operation lasting three days but from which the settlers did not flinch not even Gideon Spilett who as the sailor said would end by making a real good castaway

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The blubber, cut in parallel slices of two feet and a half in thickness, then divided into pieces which might weigh about a thousand pounds each, was melted down in large earthen pots brought to the spot, for they did not wish to taint the environs of Granite House, and in this fusion it lost nearly a third of its weight.
children.prevalue: The blubber cut in parallel slices of two feet and a half in thickness then divided into pieces which might weigh about a thousand pounds each was melted down in large earthen pots brought to the spot for they did not wish to taint the environs of Granite House and in this fusion it lost nearly a third of its weight

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But there was an immense quantity of it; the tongue alone yielded six thousand pounds of oil, and the lower lip four thousand. Then, besides the fat, which would insure for a long time a store of stearine and glycerine, there were still the bones, for which a use could doubtless be found, although there were neither umbrellas nor stays used at Granite House. The upper part of the mouth of the cetacean was, indeed, provided on both sides with eight hundred horny blades, very elastic, of a fibrous texture, and fringed at the edge like great combs, at which the teeth, six feet long, served to retain the thousands of animalculae, little fish, and molluscs, on which the whale fed.
children.prevalue: But there was an immense quantity of it the tongue alone yielded six thousand pounds of oil and the lower lip four thousand Then besides the fat which would insure for a long time a store of stearine and glycerine there were still the bones for which a use could doubtless be found although there were neither umbrellas nor stays used at Granite House The upper part of the mouth of the cetacean was indeed provided on both sides with eight hundred horny blades very elastic of a fibrous texture and fringed at the edge like great combs at which the teeth six feet long served to retain the thousands of animalculae little fish and molluscs on which the whale fed

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The operation finished, to the great satisfaction of the operators, the remains of the animal were left to the birds, who would soon make every vestige of it disappear, and their usual daily occupations were resumed by the inmates of Granite House.
children.prevalue: The operation finished to the great satisfaction of the operators the remains of the animal were left to the birds who would soon make every vestige of it disappear and their usual daily occupations were resumed by the inmates of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: However, before returning to the dockyard, Cyrus Harding conceived the idea of fabricating certain machines, which greatly excited the curiosity of his companions. He took a dozen of the whale's bones, cut them into six equal parts, and sharpened their ends.
children.prevalue: However before returning to the dockyard Cyrus Harding conceived the idea of fabricating certain machines which greatly excited the curiosity of his companions He took a dozen of the whale s bones cut them into six equal parts and sharpened their ends

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: This machine is not my own invention, and it is frequently employed by the Aleutian hunters in Russian America. You see these bones, my friends; well, when it freezes, I will bend them, and then wet them with water till they are entirely covered with ice, which will keep them bent, and I will strew them on the snow, having previously covered them with fat. Now, what will happen if a hungry animal swallows one of these baits? Why, the heat of his stomach will melt the ice, and the bone, springing straight, will pierce him with its sharp points.
children.prevalue: This machine is not my own invention and it is frequently employed by the Aleutian hunters in Russian America You see these bones my friends well when it freezes I will bend them and then wet them with water till they are entirely covered with ice which will keep them bent and I will strew them on the snow having previously covered them with fat Now what will happen if a hungry animal swallows one of these baits Why the heat of his stomach will melt the ice and the bone springing straight will pierce him with its sharp points

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Well! I do call that ingenious! said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Well I do call that ingenious said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And it will spare the powder and shot, rejoined Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: And it will spare the powder and shot rejoined Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: That will be better than traps! added Neb.
children.prevalue: That will be better than traps added Neb

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: In the meanwhile the boat-building progressed, and towards the end of the month half the planking was completed. It could already be seen that her shape was excellent, and that she would sail well.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the boat building progressed and towards the end of the month half the planking was completed It could already be seen that her shape was excellent and that she would sail well

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Pencroft worked with unparalleled ardor, and only a sturdy frame could have borne such fatigue; but his companions were preparing in secret a reward for his labors, and on the 31st of May he was to meet with one of the greatest joys of his life.
children.prevalue: Pencroft worked with unparalleled ardor and only a sturdy frame could have borne such fatigue but his companions were preparing in secret a reward for his labors and on the 31st of May he was to meet with one of the greatest joys of his life

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: On that day, after dinner, just as he was about to leave the table, Pencroft felt a hand on his shoulder.
children.prevalue: On that day after dinner just as he was about to leave the table Pencroft felt a hand on his shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It was the hand of Gideon Spilett, who said,--
children.prevalue: It was the hand of Gideon Spilett who said

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: One moment, Master Pencroft, you mustn't sneak off like that! You've forgotten your dessert.
children.prevalue: One moment Master Pencroft you mustn t sneak off like that You ve forgotten your dessert

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Thank you, Mr. Spilett, replied the sailor, I am going back to my work.
children.prevalue: Thank you Mr Spilett replied the sailor I am going back to my work

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Well, a cup of coffee, my friend?
children.prevalue: Well a cup of coffee my friend

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Nothing more.
children.prevalue: Nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: A pipe, then?
children.prevalue: A pipe then

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Pencroft jumped up, and his great good-natured face grew pale when he saw the reporter presenting him with a ready-filled pipe, and Herbert with a glowing coal.
children.prevalue: Pencroft jumped up and his great good natured face grew pale when he saw the reporter presenting him with a ready filled pipe and Herbert with a glowing coal

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The sailor endeavored to speak, but could not get out a word; so, seizing the pipe, he carried it to his lips, then applying the coal, he drew five or six great whiffs. A fragrant blue cloud soon arose, and from its depths a voice was heard repeating excitedly,--
children.prevalue: The sailor endeavored to speak but could not get out a word so seizing the pipe he carried it to his lips then applying the coal he drew five or six great whiffs A fragrant blue cloud soon arose and from its depths a voice was heard repeating excitedly

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Tobacco! real tobacco!
children.prevalue: Tobacco real tobacco

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes, Pencroft, returned Cyrus Harding, and very good tobacco too!
children.prevalue: Yes Pencroft returned Cyrus Harding and very good tobacco too

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: O, divine Providence; sacred Author of all things! cried the sailor. Nothing more is now wanting to our island.
children.prevalue: O divine Providence sacred Author of all things cried the sailor Nothing more is now wanting to our island

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: And Pencroft smoked, and smoked, and smoked.
children.prevalue: And Pencroft smoked and smoked and smoked

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: And who made this discovery? he asked at length. You, Herbert, no doubt?
children.prevalue: And who made this discovery he asked at length You Herbert no doubt

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: No, Pencroft, it was Mr. Spilett.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft it was Mr Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Mr. Spilett! exclaimed the sailor, seizing the reporter, and clasping him to his breast with such a squeeze that he had never felt anything like it before.
children.prevalue: Mr Spilett exclaimed the sailor seizing the reporter and clasping him to his breast with such a squeeze that he had never felt anything like it before

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Oh Pencroft, said Spilett, recovering his breath at last, a truce for one moment. You must share your gratitude with Herbert, who recognized the plant, with Cyrus, who prepared it, and with Neb, who took a great deal of trouble to keep our secret.
children.prevalue: Oh Pencroft said Spilett recovering his breath at last a truce for one moment You must share your gratitude with Herbert who recognized the plant with Cyrus who prepared it and with Neb who took a great deal of trouble to keep our secret

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Well, my friends, I will repay you some day, replied the sailor. Now we are friends for life.
children.prevalue: Well my friends I will repay you some day replied the sailor Now we are friends for life

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Winter arrived with the month of June, which is the December of the northern zones, and the great business was the making of warm and solid clothing.
children.prevalue: Winter arrived with the month of June which is the December of the northern zones and the great business was the making of warm and solid clothing

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The musmons in the corral had been stripped of their wool, and this precious textile material was now to be transformed into stuff.
children.prevalue: The musmons in the corral had been stripped of their wool and this precious textile material was now to be transformed into stuff

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Of course Cyrus Harding, having at his disposal neither carders, combers, polishers, stretchers, twisters, mule-jenny, nor self-acting machine to spin the wool, nor loom to weave it, was obliged to proceed in a simpler way, so as to do without spinning and weaving. And indeed he proposed to make use of the property which the filaments of wool possess when subjected to a powerful pressure of mixing together, and of manufacturing by this simple process the material called felt. This felt could then be obtained by a simple operation which, if it diminished the flexibility of the stuff, increased its power of retaining heat in proportion. Now the wool furnished by the musmons was composed of very short hairs, and was in a good condition to be felted.
children.prevalue: Of course Cyrus Harding having at his disposal neither carders combers polishers stretchers twisters mule jenny nor self acting machine to spin the wool nor loom to weave it was obliged to proceed in a simpler way so as to do without spinning and weaving And indeed he proposed to make use of the property which the filaments of wool possess when subjected to a powerful pressure of mixing together and of manufacturing by this simple process the material called felt This felt could then be obtained by a simple operation which if it diminished the flexibility of the stuff increased its power of retaining heat in proportion Now the wool furnished by the musmons was composed of very short hairs and was in a good condition to be felted

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The engineer, aided by his companions, including Pencroft, who was once more obliged to leave his boat, commenced the preliminary operations, the subject of which was to rid the wool of that fat and oily substance with which it is impregnated, and which is called grease. This cleaning was done in vats filled with water, which was maintained at the temperature of seventy degrees, and in which the wool was soaked for four-and-twenty hours; it was then thoroughly washed in baths of soda, and, when sufficiently dried by pressure, it was in a state to be compressed, that is to say, to produce a solid material, rough, no doubt, and such as would have no value in a manufacturing center of Europe or America, but which would be highly esteemed in the Lincoln Island markets.
children.prevalue: The engineer aided by his companions including Pencroft who was once more obliged to leave his boat commenced the preliminary operations the subject of which was to rid the wool of that fat and oily substance with which it is impregnated and which is called grease This cleaning was done in vats filled with water which was maintained at the temperature of seventy degrees and in which the wool was soaked for four and twenty hours it was then thoroughly washed in baths of soda and when sufficiently dried by pressure it was in a state to be compressed that is to say to produce a solid material rough no doubt and such as would have no value in a manufacturing center of Europe or America but which would be highly esteemed in the Lincoln Island markets

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This sort of material must have been known from the most ancient times, and, in fact, the first woolen stuffs were manufactured by the process which Harding was now about to employ. Where Harding's engineering qualifications now came into play was in the construction of the machine for pressing the wool; for he knew how to turn ingeniously to profit the mechanical force, hitherto unused, which the waterfall on the beach possessed to move a fulling-mill.
children.prevalue: This sort of material must have been known from the most ancient times and in fact the first woolen stuffs were manufactured by the process which Harding was now about to employ Where Harding s engineering qualifications now came into play was in the construction of the machine for pressing the wool for he knew how to turn ingeniously to profit the mechanical force hitherto unused which the waterfall on the beach possessed to move a fulling mill

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Nothing could be more rudimentary. The wool was placed in troughs, and upon it fell in turns heavy wooden mallets; such was the machine in question, and such it had been for centuries until the time when the mallets were replaced by cylinders of compression, and the material was no longer subjected to beating, but to regular rolling.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be more rudimentary The wool was placed in troughs and upon it fell in turns heavy wooden mallets such was the machine in question and such it had been for centuries until the time when the mallets were replaced by cylinders of compression and the material was no longer subjected to beating but to regular rolling

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The operation, ably directed by Cyrus Harding, was a complete success. The wool, previously impregnated with a solution of soap, intended on the one hand to facilitate the interlacing, the compression, and the softening of the wool, and on the other to prevent its diminution by the beating, issued from the mill in the shape of thick felt cloth. The roughnesses with which the staple of wool is naturally filled were so thoroughly entangled and interlaced together that a material was formed equally suitable either for garments or bedclothes. It was certainly neither merino, muslin, cashmere, rep, satin, alpaca, cloth, nor flannel. It was Lincolnian felt, and Lincoln Island possessed yet another manufacture. The colonists had now warm garments and thick bedclothes, and they could without fear await the approach of the winter of 1866-67.
children.prevalue: The operation ably directed by Cyrus Harding was a complete success The wool previously impregnated with a solution of soap intended on the one hand to facilitate the interlacing the compression and the softening of the wool and on the other to prevent its diminution by the beating issued from the mill in the shape of thick felt cloth The roughnesses with which the staple of wool is naturally filled were so thoroughly entangled and interlaced together that a material was formed equally suitable either for garments or bedclothes It was certainly neither merino muslin cashmere rep satin alpaca cloth nor flannel It was Lincolnian felt and Lincoln Island possessed yet another manufacture The colonists had now warm garments and thick bedclothes and they could without fear await the approach of the winter of 1866 67

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The severe cold began to be felt about the 20th of June, and, to his great regret, Pencroft was obliged to suspend his boat-building, which he hoped to finish in time for next spring.
children.prevalue: The severe cold began to be felt about the 20th of June and to his great regret Pencroft was obliged to suspend his boat building which he hoped to finish in time for next spring

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The sailor's great idea was to make a voyage of discovery to Tabor Island, although Harding could not approve of a voyage simply for curiosity's sake, for there was evidently nothing to be found on this desert and almost arid rock. A voyage of a hundred and fifty miles in a comparatively small vessel, over unknown seas, could not but cause him some anxiety. Suppose that their vessel, once out at sea, should be unable to reach Tabor Island, and could not return to Lincoln Island, what would become of her in the midst of the Pacific, so fruitful of disasters?
children.prevalue: The sailor s great idea was to make a voyage of discovery to Tabor Island although Harding could not approve of a voyage simply for curiosity s sake for there was evidently nothing to be found on this desert and almost arid rock A voyage of a hundred and fifty miles in a comparatively small vessel over unknown seas could not but cause him some anxiety Suppose that their vessel once out at sea should be unable to reach Tabor Island and could not return to Lincoln Island what would become of her in the midst of the Pacific so fruitful of disasters

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Harding often talked over this project with Pencroft, and he found him strangely bent upon undertaking this voyage, for which determination he himself could give no sufficient reason.
children.prevalue: Harding often talked over this project with Pencroft and he found him strangely bent upon undertaking this voyage for which determination he himself could give no sufficient reason

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Now, said the engineer one day to him, I must observe, my friend, that after having said so much, in praise of Lincoln Island, after having spoken so often of the sorrow you would feel if you were obliged to forsake it, you are the first to wish to leave it.
children.prevalue: Now said the engineer one day to him I must observe my friend that after having said so much in praise of Lincoln Island after having spoken so often of the sorrow you would feel if you were obliged to forsake it you are the first to wish to leave it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Only to leave it for a few days, replied Pencroft, only for a few days, captain. Time to go and come back, and see what that islet is like!
children.prevalue: Only to leave it for a few days replied Pencroft only for a few days captain Time to go and come back and see what that islet is like

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: But it is not nearly as good as Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: But it is not nearly as good as Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I know that beforehand.
children.prevalue: I know that beforehand

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Then why venture there?
children.prevalue: Then why venture there

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: To know what is going on in Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: To know what is going on in Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But nothing is going on there; nothing could happen there.
children.prevalue: But nothing is going on there nothing could happen there

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Who knows?
children.prevalue: Who knows

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: And if you are caught in a hurricane?
children.prevalue: And if you are caught in a hurricane

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: There is no fear of that in the fine season, replied Pencroft. But, captain, as we must provide against everything, I shall ask your permission to take Herbert only with me on this voyage.
children.prevalue: There is no fear of that in the fine season replied Pencroft But captain as we must provide against everything I shall ask your permission to take Herbert only with me on this voyage

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Pencroft, replied the engineer, placing his hand on the sailor's shoulder, if any misfortune happens to you, or to this lad, whom chance has made our child, do you think we could ever cease to blame ourselves?
children.prevalue: Pencroft replied the engineer placing his hand on the sailor s shoulder if any misfortune happens to you or to this lad whom chance has made our child do you think we could ever cease to blame ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Captain Harding, replied Pencroft, with unshaken confidence, we shall not cause you that sorrow. Besides, we will speak further of this voyage, when the time comes to make it. And I fancy, when you have seen our tight-rigged little craft, when you have observed how she behaves at sea, when we sail round our island, for we will do so together--I fancy, I say, that you will no longer hesitate to let me go. I don't conceal from you that your boat will be a masterpiece.
children.prevalue: Captain Harding replied Pencroft with unshaken confidence we shall not cause you that sorrow Besides we will speak further of this voyage when the time comes to make it And I fancy when you have seen our tight rigged little craft when you have observed how she behaves at sea when we sail round our island for we will do so together I fancy I say that you will no longer hesitate to let me go I don t conceal from you that your boat will be a masterpiece

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Say 'our' boat, at least, Pencroft, replied the engineer, disarmed for the moment. The conversation ended thus, to be resumed later on, without convincing either the sailor or the engineer.
children.prevalue: Say our boat at least Pencroft replied the engineer disarmed for the moment The conversation ended thus to be resumed later on without convincing either the sailor or the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The first snow fell towards the end of the month of June. The corral had previously been largely supplied with stores, so that daily visits to it were not requisite; but it was decided that more than a week should never be allowed to pass without someone going to it.
children.prevalue: The first snow fell towards the end of the month of June The corral had previously been largely supplied with stores so that daily visits to it were not requisite but it was decided that more than a week should never be allowed to pass without someone going to it

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Traps were again set, and the machines manufactured by Harding were tried. The bent whalebones, imprisoned in a case of ice, and covered with a thick outer layer of fat, were placed on the border of the forest at a spot where animals usually passed on their way to the lake.
children.prevalue: Traps were again set and the machines manufactured by Harding were tried The bent whalebones imprisoned in a case of ice and covered with a thick outer layer of fat were placed on the border of the forest at a spot where animals usually passed on their way to the lake

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: To the engineer's great satisfaction, this invention, copied from the Aleutian fishermen, succeeded perfectly. A dozen foxes, a few wild boars, and even a jaguar, were taken in this way, the animals being found dead, their stomachs pierced by the unbent bones.
children.prevalue: To the engineer s great satisfaction this invention copied from the Aleutian fishermen succeeded perfectly A dozen foxes a few wild boars and even a jaguar were taken in this way the animals being found dead their stomachs pierced by the unbent bones

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: An incident must here be related, not only as interesting in itself, but because it was the first attempt made by the colonists to communicate with the rest of mankind.
children.prevalue: An incident must here be related not only as interesting in itself but because it was the first attempt made by the colonists to communicate with the rest of mankind

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Gideon Spilett had already several times pondered whether to throw into the sea a letter enclosed in a bottle, which currents might perhaps carry to an inhabited coast, or to confide it to pigeons.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett had already several times pondered whether to throw into the sea a letter enclosed in a bottle which currents might perhaps carry to an inhabited coast or to confide it to pigeons

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But how could it be seriously hoped that either pigeons or bottles could cross the distance of twelve hundred miles which separated the island from any inhabited land? It would have been pure folly.
children.prevalue: But how could it be seriously hoped that either pigeons or bottles could cross the distance of twelve hundred miles which separated the island from any inhabited land It would have been pure folly

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: But on the 30th of June the capture was effected, not without difficulty, of an albatross, which a shot from Herbert's gun had slightly wounded in the foot. It was a magnificent bird, measuring ten feet from wing to wing, and which could traverse seas as wide as the Pacific.
children.prevalue: But on the 30th of June the capture was effected not without difficulty of an albatross which a shot from Herbert s gun had slightly wounded in the foot It was a magnificent bird measuring ten feet from wing to wing and which could traverse seas as wide as the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Herbert would have liked to keep this superb bird, as its wound would soon heal, and he thought he could tame it; but Spilett explained to him that they should not neglect this opportunity of attempting to communicate by this messenger with the lands of the Pacific; for if the albatross had come from some inhabited region, there was no doubt but that it would return there so soon as it was set free.
children.prevalue: Herbert would have liked to keep this superb bird as its wound would soon heal and he thought he could tame it but Spilett explained to him that they should not neglect this opportunity of attempting to communicate by this messenger with the lands of the Pacific for if the albatross had come from some inhabited region there was no doubt but that it would return there so soon as it was set free

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Perhaps in his heart Gideon Spilett, in whom the journalist sometimes came to the surface, was not sorry to have the opportunity of sending forth to take its chance an exciting article relating the adventures of the settlers in Lincoln Island. What a success for the authorized reporter of the New York Herald, and for the number which should contain the article, if it should ever reach the address of its editor, the Honorable James Bennett!
children.prevalue: Perhaps in his heart Gideon Spilett in whom the journalist sometimes came to the surface was not sorry to have the opportunity of sending forth to take its chance an exciting article relating the adventures of the settlers in Lincoln Island What a success for the authorized reporter of the New York Herald and for the number which should contain the article if it should ever reach the address of its editor the Honorable James Bennett

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Gideon Spilett then wrote out a concise account, which was placed in a strong waterproof bag, with an earnest request to whoever might find it to forward it to the office of the New York Herald. This little bag was fastened to the neck of the albatross, and not to its foot, for these birds are in the habit of resting on the surface of the sea; then liberty was given to this swift courier of the air, and it was not without some emotion that the colonists watched it disappear in the misty west.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett then wrote out a concise account which was placed in a strong waterproof bag with an earnest request to whoever might find it to forward it to the office of the New York Herald This little bag was fastened to the neck of the albatross and not to its foot for these birds are in the habit of resting on the surface of the sea then liberty was given to this swift courier of the air and it was not without some emotion that the colonists watched it disappear in the misty west

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Where is he going to? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Where is he going to asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Towards New Zealand, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: Towards New Zealand replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: A good voyage to you, shouted the sailor, who himself did not expect any great result from this mode of correspondence.
children.prevalue: A good voyage to you shouted the sailor who himself did not expect any great result from this mode of correspondence

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: With the winter, work had been resumed in the interior of Granite House, mending clothes and different occupations, among others making the sails for their vessel, which were cut from the inexhaustible balloon-case.
children.prevalue: With the winter work had been resumed in the interior of Granite House mending clothes and different occupations among others making the sails for their vessel which were cut from the inexhaustible balloon case

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: During the month of July the cold was intense, but there was no lack of either wood or coal. Cyrus Harding had established a second fireplace in the dining-room, and there the long winter evenings were spent. Talking while they worked, reading when the hands remained idle, the time passed with profit to all.
children.prevalue: During the month of July the cold was intense but there was no lack of either wood or coal Cyrus Harding had established a second fireplace in the dining room and there the long winter evenings were spent Talking while they worked reading when the hands remained idle the time passed with profit to all

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: It was real enjoyment to the settlers when in their room, well lighted with candles, well warmed with coal, after a good dinner, elderberry coffee smoking in the cups, the pipes giving forth an odoriferous smoke, they could hear the storm howling without. Their comfort would have been complete, if complete comfort could ever exist for those who are far from their fellow-creatures, and without any means of communication with them. They often talked of their country, of the friends whom they had left, of the grandeur of the American Republic, whose influence could not but increase; and Cyrus Harding, who had been much mixed up with the affairs of the Union, greatly interested his auditors by his recitals, his views, and his prognostics.
children.prevalue: It was real enjoyment to the settlers when in their room well lighted with candles well warmed with coal after a good dinner elderberry coffee smoking in the cups the pipes giving forth an odoriferous smoke they could hear the storm howling without Their comfort would have been complete if complete comfort could ever exist for those who are far from their fellow creatures and without any means of communication with them They often talked of their country of the friends whom they had left of the grandeur of the American Republic whose influence could not but increase and Cyrus Harding who had been much mixed up with the affairs of the Union greatly interested his auditors by his recitals his views and his prognostics

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It chanced one day that Spilett was led to say--
children.prevalue: It chanced one day that Spilett was led to say

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But now, my dear Cyrus, all this industrial and commercial movement to which you predict a continual advance, does it not run the danger of being sooner or later completely stopped?
children.prevalue: But now my dear Cyrus all this industrial and commercial movement to which you predict a continual advance does it not run the danger of being sooner or later completely stopped

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Stopped! And by what?
children.prevalue: Stopped And by what

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: By the want of coal, which may justly be called the most precious of minerals.
children.prevalue: By the want of coal which may justly be called the most precious of minerals

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, the most precious indeed, replied the engineer; and it would seem that nature wished to prove that it was so by making the diamond, which is simply pure carbon crystallized.
children.prevalue: Yes the most precious indeed replied the engineer and it would seem that nature wished to prove that it was so by making the diamond which is simply pure carbon crystallized

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: You don't mean to say, captain, interrupted Pencroft, that we burn diamonds in our stoves in the shape of coal?
children.prevalue: You don t mean to say captain interrupted Pencroft that we burn diamonds in our stoves in the shape of coal

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: No, my friend, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: No my friend replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: However, resumed Gideon Spilett, you do not deny that some day the coal will be entirely consumed?
children.prevalue: However resumed Gideon Spilett you do not deny that some day the coal will be entirely consumed

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Oh! the veins of coal are still considerable, and the hundred thousand miners who annually extract from them a hundred millions of hundredweights have not nearly exhausted them.
children.prevalue: Oh the veins of coal are still considerable and the hundred thousand miners who annually extract from them a hundred millions of hundredweights have not nearly exhausted them

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: With the increasing consumption of coal, replied Gideon Spilett, it can be foreseen that the hundred thousand workmen will soon become two hundred thousand, and that the rate of extraction will be doubled.
children.prevalue: With the increasing consumption of coal replied Gideon Spilett it can be foreseen that the hundred thousand workmen will soon become two hundred thousand and that the rate of extraction will be doubled

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Doubtless; but after the European mines, which will be soon worked more thoroughly with new machines, the American and Australian mines will for a long time yet provide for the consumption in trade.
children.prevalue: Doubtless but after the European mines which will be soon worked more thoroughly with new machines the American and Australian mines will for a long time yet provide for the consumption in trade

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: For how long a time? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: For how long a time asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: For at least two hundred and fifty or three hundred years.
children.prevalue: For at least two hundred and fifty or three hundred years

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: That is reassuring for us, but a bad look-out for our great-grandchildren! observed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: That is reassuring for us but a bad look out for our great grandchildren observed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: They will discover something else, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: They will discover something else said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: It is to be hoped so, answered Spilett, for without coal there would be no machinery, and without machinery there would be no railways, no steamers, no manufactories, nothing of that which is indispensable to modern civilization!
children.prevalue: It is to be hoped so answered Spilett for without coal there would be no machinery and without machinery there would be no railways no steamers no manufactories nothing of that which is indispensable to modern civilization

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: But what will they find? asked Pencroft. Can you guess, captain?
children.prevalue: But what will they find asked Pencroft Can you guess captain

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Nearly, my friend.
children.prevalue: Nearly my friend

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And what will they burn instead of coal?
children.prevalue: And what will they burn instead of coal

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Water, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: Water replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Water! cried Pencroft, water as fuel for steamers and engines! water to heat water!
children.prevalue: Water cried Pencroft water as fuel for steamers and engines water to heat water

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, but water decomposed into its primitive elements, replied Cyrus Harding, and decomposed doubtless, by electricity, which will then have become a powerful and manageable force, for all great discoveries, by some inexplicable laws, appear to agree and become complete at the same time. Yes, my friends, I believe that water will one day be employed as fuel, that hydrogen and oxygen which constitute it, used singly or together, will furnish an inexhaustible source of heat and light, of an intensity of which coal is not capable. Some day the coalrooms of steamers and the tenders of locomotives will, instead of coal, be stored with these two condensed gases, which will burn in the furnaces with enormous calorific power. There is, therefore, nothing to fear. As long as the earth is inhabited it will supply the wants of its inhabitants, and there will be no want of either light or heat as long as the productions of the vegetable, mineral or animal kingdoms do not fail us. I believe, then, that when the deposits of coal are exhausted we shall heat and warm ourselves with water. Water will be the coal of the future.
children.prevalue: Yes but water decomposed into its primitive elements replied Cyrus Harding and decomposed doubtless by electricity which will then have become a powerful and manageable force for all great discoveries by some inexplicable laws appear to agree and become complete at the same time Yes my friends I believe that water will one day be employed as fuel that hydrogen and oxygen which constitute it used singly or together will furnish an inexhaustible source of heat and light of an intensity of which coal is not capable Some day the coalrooms of steamers and the tenders of locomotives will instead of coal be stored with these two condensed gases which will burn in the furnaces with enormous calorific power There is therefore nothing to fear As long as the earth is inhabited it will supply the wants of its inhabitants and there will be no want of either light or heat as long as the productions of the vegetable mineral or animal kingdoms do not fail us I believe then that when the deposits of coal are exhausted we shall heat and warm ourselves with water Water will be the coal of the future

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I should like to see that, observed the sailor.
children.prevalue: I should like to see that observed the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You were born too soon, Pencroft, returned Neb, who only took part in the discussion by these words.
children.prevalue: You were born too soon Pencroft returned Neb who only took part in the discussion by these words

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: However, it was not Neb's speech which interrupted the conversation, but Top's barking, which broke out again with that strange intonation which had before perplexed the engineer. At the same time Top began to run round the mouth of the well, which opened at the extremity of the interior passage.
children.prevalue: However it was not Neb s speech which interrupted the conversation but Top s barking which broke out again with that strange intonation which had before perplexed the engineer At the same time Top began to run round the mouth of the well which opened at the extremity of the interior passage

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: What can Top be barking in that way for? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: What can Top be barking in that way for asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And Jup be growling like that? added Herbert.
children.prevalue: And Jup be growling like that added Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: In fact the orang, joining the dog, gave unequivocal signs of agitation, and, singular to say, the two animals appeared more uneasy than angry.
children.prevalue: In fact the orang joining the dog gave unequivocal signs of agitation and singular to say the two animals appeared more uneasy than angry

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: It is evident, said Gideon Spilett, that this well is in direct communication with the sea, and that some marine animal comes from time to time to breathe at the bottom.
children.prevalue: It is evident said Gideon Spilett that this well is in direct communication with the sea and that some marine animal comes from time to time to breathe at the bottom

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: That's evident, replied the sailor, and there can be no other explanation to give. Quiet there, Top! added Pencroft, turning to the dog, and you, Jup, be off to your room!
children.prevalue: That s evident replied the sailor and there can be no other explanation to give Quiet there Top added Pencroft turning to the dog and you Jup be off to your room

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The ape and the dog were silent. Jup went off to bed, but Top remained in the room, and continued to utter low growls at intervals during the rest of the evening. There was no further talk on the subject, but the incident, however, clouded the brow of the engineer.
children.prevalue: The ape and the dog were silent Jup went off to bed but Top remained in the room and continued to utter low growls at intervals during the rest of the evening There was no further talk on the subject but the incident however clouded the brow of the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: During the remainder of the month of July there was alternate rain and frost. The temperature was not so low as during the preceding winter, and its maximum did not exceed eight degrees Fahrenheit. But although this winter was less cold, it was more troubled by storms and squalls; the sea besides often endangered the safety of the Chimneys. At times it almost seemed as if an under-current raised these monstrous billows which thundered against the wall of Granite House.
children.prevalue: During the remainder of the month of July there was alternate rain and frost The temperature was not so low as during the preceding winter and its maximum did not exceed eight degrees Fahrenheit But although this winter was less cold it was more troubled by storms and squalls the sea besides often endangered the safety of the Chimneys At times it almost seemed as if an under current raised these monstrous billows which thundered against the wall of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: When the settlers, leaning from their windows, gazed on the huge watery masses breaking beneath their eyes, they could not but admire the magnificent spectacle of the ocean in its impotent fury. The waves rebounded in dazzling foam, the beach entirely disapppearing under the raging flood, and the cliff appearing to emerge from the sea itself, the spray rising to a height of more than a hundred feet.
children.prevalue: When the settlers leaning from their windows gazed on the huge watery masses breaking beneath their eyes they could not but admire the magnificent spectacle of the ocean in its impotent fury The waves rebounded in dazzling foam the beach entirely disapppearing under the raging flood and the cliff appearing to emerge from the sea itself the spray rising to a height of more than a hundred feet

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: During these storms it was difficult and even dangerous to venture out, owing to the frequently falling trees; however, the colonists never allowed a week to pass without having paid a visit to the corral. Happily, this enclosure, sheltered by the southeastern spur of Mount Franklin, did not greatly suffer from the violence of the hurricanes, which spared its trees, sheds, and palisades; but the poultry-yard on Prospect Heights, being directly exposed to the gusts of wind from the east, suffered considerable damage. The pigeon-house was twice unroofed and the paling blown down. All this required to be remade more solidly than before, for, as may be clearly seen, Lincoln Island was situated in one of the most dangerous parts of the Pacific. It really appeared as if it formed the central point of vast cyclones, which beat it perpetually as the whip does the top, only here it was the top which was motionless and the whip which moved. During the first week of the month of August the weather became more moderate, and the atmosphere recovered the calm which it appeared to have lost forever. With the calm the cold again became intense, and the thermometer fell to eight degrees Fahrenheit, below zero.
children.prevalue: During these storms it was difficult and even dangerous to venture out owing to the frequently falling trees however the colonists never allowed a week to pass without having paid a visit to the corral Happily this enclosure sheltered by the southeastern spur of Mount Franklin did not greatly suffer from the violence of the hurricanes which spared its trees sheds and palisades but the poultry yard on Prospect Heights being directly exposed to the gusts of wind from the east suffered considerable damage The pigeon house was twice unroofed and the paling blown down All this required to be remade more solidly than before for as may be clearly seen Lincoln Island was situated in one of the most dangerous parts of the Pacific It really appeared as if it formed the central point of vast cyclones which beat it perpetually as the whip does the top only here it was the top which was motionless and the whip which moved During the first week of the month of August the weather became more moderate and the atmosphere recovered the calm which it appeared to have lost forever With the calm the cold again became intense and the thermometer fell to eight degrees Fahrenheit below zero

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: On the 3rd of August an excursion which had been talked of for several days was made into the southeastern part of the island, towards Tadorn Marsh. The hunters were tempted by the aquatic game which took up their winter quarters there. Wild duck, snipe, teal and grebe abounded there, and it was agreed that a day should be devoted to an expedition against these birds.
children.prevalue: On the 3rd of August an excursion which had been talked of for several days was made into the southeastern part of the island towards Tadorn Marsh The hunters were tempted by the aquatic game which took up their winter quarters there Wild duck snipe teal and grebe abounded there and it was agreed that a day should be devoted to an expedition against these birds

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Not only Gideon Spilett and Herbert, but Pencroft and Neb also took part in this excursion. Cyrus Harding alone, alleging some work as an excuse, did not join them, but remained at Granite House.
children.prevalue: Not only Gideon Spilett and Herbert but Pencroft and Neb also took part in this excursion Cyrus Harding alone alleging some work as an excuse did not join them but remained at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The hunters proceeded in the direction of Port Balloon, in order to reach the marsh, after having promised to be back by the evening. Top and Jup accompanied them. As soon as they had passed over the Mercy Bridge, the engineer raised it and returned, intending to put into execution a project for the performance of which he wished to be alone.
children.prevalue: The hunters proceeded in the direction of Port Balloon in order to reach the marsh after having promised to be back by the evening Top and Jup accompanied them As soon as they had passed over the Mercy Bridge the engineer raised it and returned intending to put into execution a project for the performance of which he wished to be alone

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Now this project was to minutely explore the interior well, the mouth of which was on a level with the passage of Granite House, and which communicated with the sea, since it formerly supplied a way to the waters of the lake.
children.prevalue: Now this project was to minutely explore the interior well the mouth of which was on a level with the passage of Granite House and which communicated with the sea since it formerly supplied a way to the waters of the lake

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Why did Top so often run round this opening? Why did he utter such strange barks when a sort of uneasiness seemed to draw him towards this well? Why did Jup join Top in a sort of common anxiety? Had this well branches besides the communication with the sea? Did it spread towards other parts of the island? This is what Cyrus Harding wished to know. He had resolved, therefore, to attempt the exploration of the well during the absence of his companions, and an opportunity for doing so had now presented itself.
children.prevalue: Why did Top so often run round this opening Why did he utter such strange barks when a sort of uneasiness seemed to draw him towards this well Why did Jup join Top in a sort of common anxiety Had this well branches besides the communication with the sea Did it spread towards other parts of the island This is what Cyrus Harding wished to know He had resolved therefore to attempt the exploration of the well during the absence of his companions and an opportunity for doing so had now presented itself

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: It was easy to descend to the bottom of the well by employing the rope ladder which had not been used since the establishment of the lift. The engineer drew the ladder to the hole, the diameter of which measured nearly six feet, and allowed it to unroll itself after having securely fastened its upper extremity. Then, having lighted a lantern, taken a revolver, and placed a cutlass in his belt, he began the descent.
children.prevalue: It was easy to descend to the bottom of the well by employing the rope ladder which had not been used since the establishment of the lift The engineer drew the ladder to the hole the diameter of which measured nearly six feet and allowed it to unroll itself after having securely fastened its upper extremity Then having lighted a lantern taken a revolver and placed a cutlass in his belt he began the descent

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: The sides were everywhere entire; but points of rock jutted out here and there, and by means of these points it would have been quite possible for an active creature to climb to the mouth of the well.
children.prevalue: The sides were everywhere entire but points of rock jutted out here and there and by means of these points it would have been quite possible for an active creature to climb to the mouth of the well

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The engineer remarked this; but although he carefully examined these points by the light of his lantern, he could find no impression, no fracture which could give any reason to suppose that they had either recently or at any former time been used as a staircase. Cyrus Harding descended deeper, throwing the light of his lantern on all sides.
children.prevalue: The engineer remarked this but although he carefully examined these points by the light of his lantern he could find no impression no fracture which could give any reason to suppose that they had either recently or at any former time been used as a staircase Cyrus Harding descended deeper throwing the light of his lantern on all sides

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: He saw nothing suspicious.
children.prevalue: He saw nothing suspicious

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: When the engineer had reached the last rounds he came upon the water, which was then perfectly calm. Neither at its level nor in any other part of the well, did any passage open, which could lead to the interior of the cliff. The wall which Harding struck with the hilt of his cutlass sounded solid. It was compact granite, through which no living being could force a way. To arrive at the bottom of the well and then climb up to its mouth it was necessary to pass through the channel under the rocky subsoil of the beach, which placed it in communication with the sea, and this was only possible for marine animals. As to the question of knowing where this channel ended, at what point of the shore, and at what depth beneath the water, it could not be answered.
children.prevalue: When the engineer had reached the last rounds he came upon the water which was then perfectly calm Neither at its level nor in any other part of the well did any passage open which could lead to the interior of the cliff The wall which Harding struck with the hilt of his cutlass sounded solid It was compact granite through which no living being could force a way To arrive at the bottom of the well and then climb up to its mouth it was necessary to pass through the channel under the rocky subsoil of the beach which placed it in communication with the sea and this was only possible for marine animals As to the question of knowing where this channel ended at what point of the shore and at what depth beneath the water it could not be answered

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Then Cyrus Harding, having ended his survey, re-ascended, drew up the ladder, covered the mouth of the well, and returned thoughtfully to the diningroom, saying to himself,--
children.prevalue: Then Cyrus Harding having ended his survey re ascended drew up the ladder covered the mouth of the well and returned thoughtfully to the diningroom saying to himself

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I have seen nothing, and yet there is something there!
children.prevalue: I have seen nothing and yet there is something there

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In the evening the hunters returned, having enjoyed good sport, and being literally loaded with game; indeed, they had as much as four men could possibly carry. Top wore a necklace of teal and Jup wreaths of snipe round his body.
children.prevalue: In the evening the hunters returned having enjoyed good sport and being literally loaded with game indeed they had as much as four men could possibly carry Top wore a necklace of teal and Jup wreaths of snipe round his body

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Here, master, cried Neb; here's something to employ our time! Preserved and made into pies we shall have a welcome store! But I must have some one to help me. I count on you, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Here master cried Neb here s something to employ our time Preserved and made into pies we shall have a welcome store But I must have some one to help me I count on you Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: No, Neb, replied the sailor; I have the rigging of the vessel to finish and to look after, and you will have to do without me.
children.prevalue: No Neb replied the sailor I have the rigging of the vessel to finish and to look after and you will have to do without me

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: And you, Mr. Herbert?
children.prevalue: And you Mr Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I must go to the corral to-morrow, Neb, replied the lad.
children.prevalue: I must go to the corral to morrow Neb replied the lad

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It will be you then, Mr. Spilett, who will help me?
children.prevalue: It will be you then Mr Spilett who will help me

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: To oblige you, Neb, I will, replied the reporter; but I warn you that if you disclose your recipes to me, I shall publish them.
children.prevalue: To oblige you Neb I will replied the reporter but I warn you that if you disclose your recipes to me I shall publish them

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Whenever you like, Mr. Spilett, replied Neb; whenever you like.
children.prevalue: Whenever you like Mr Spilett replied Neb whenever you like

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And so the next day Gideon Spilett became Neb's assistant and was installed in his culinary laboratory. The engineer had previously made known to him the result of the exploration which he had made the day before, and on this point the reporter shared Harding's opinion, that although he had found nothing, a secret still remained to be discovered!
children.prevalue: And so the next day Gideon Spilett became Neb s assistant and was installed in his culinary laboratory The engineer had previously made known to him the result of the exploration which he had made the day before and on this point the reporter shared Harding s opinion that although he had found nothing a secret still remained to be discovered

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The frost continued for another week, and the settlers did not leave Granite House unless to look after the poultry-yard. The dwelling was filled with appetizing odors, which were emitted from the learned manipulation of Neb and the reporter. But all the results of the chase were not made into preserved provisions; and as the game kept perfectly in the intense cold, wild duck and other fowl were eaten fresh, and declared superior to all other aquatic birds in the known world.
children.prevalue: The frost continued for another week and the settlers did not leave Granite House unless to look after the poultry yard The dwelling was filled with appetizing odors which were emitted from the learned manipulation of Neb and the reporter But all the results of the chase were not made into preserved provisions and as the game kept perfectly in the intense cold wild duck and other fowl were eaten fresh and declared superior to all other aquatic birds in the known world

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: During this week, Pencroft, aided by Herbert, who handled the sailmaker's needle with much skill, worked with such energy that the sails of the vessel were finished. There was no want of cordage. Thanks to the rigging which had been discovered with the case of the balloon, the ropes and cables from the net were all of good quality, and the sailor turned them all to account. To the sails were attached strong bolt ropes, and there still remained enough from which to make the halyards, shrouds, and sheets, etc. The blocks were manufactured by Cyrus Harding under Pencroft's directions by means of the turning lathe. It therefore happened that the rigging was entirely prepared before the vessel was finished. Pencroft also manufactured a flag, that flag so dear to every true American, containing the stars and stripes of their glorious Union. The colors for it were supplied from certain plants used in dyeing, and which were very abundant in the island; only to the thirty-seven stars, representing the thirty-seven States of the Union, which shine on the American flag, the sailor added a thirty-eighth, the star of the State of Lincoln, for he considered his island as already united to the great republic. And, said he, it is so already in heart, if not in deed!
children.prevalue: During this week Pencroft aided by Herbert who handled the sailmaker s needle with much skill worked with such energy that the sails of the vessel were finished There was no want of cordage Thanks to the rigging which had been discovered with the case of the balloon the ropes and cables from the net were all of good quality and the sailor turned them all to account To the sails were attached strong bolt ropes and there still remained enough from which to make the halyards shrouds and sheets etc The blocks were manufactured by Cyrus Harding under Pencroft s directions by means of the turning lathe It therefore happened that the rigging was entirely prepared before the vessel was finished Pencroft also manufactured a flag that flag so dear to every true American containing the stars and stripes of their glorious Union The colors for it were supplied from certain plants used in dyeing and which were very abundant in the island only to the thirty seven stars representing the thirty seven States of the Union which shine on the American flag the sailor added a thirty eighth the star of the State of Lincoln for he considered his island as already united to the great republic And said he it is so already in heart if not in deed

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: In the meantime, the flag was hoisted at the central window of Granite House, and the settlers saluted it with three cheers.
children.prevalue: In the meantime the flag was hoisted at the central window of Granite House and the settlers saluted it with three cheers

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The cold season was now almost at an end, and it appeared as if this second winter was to pass without any unusual occurrence, when on the night of the 11th of August, the plateau of Prospect Heights was menaced with complete destruction.
children.prevalue: The cold season was now almost at an end and it appeared as if this second winter was to pass without any unusual occurrence when on the night of the 11th of August the plateau of Prospect Heights was menaced with complete destruction

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: After a busy day the colonists were sleeping soundly, when towards four o'clock in the morning they were suddenly awakened by Top's barking.
children.prevalue: After a busy day the colonists were sleeping soundly when towards four o clock in the morning they were suddenly awakened by Top s barking

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The dog was not this time barking near the mouth of the well, but at the threshold of the door, at which he was scratching as if he wished to burst it open. Jup was also uttering piercing cries.
children.prevalue: The dog was not this time barking near the mouth of the well but at the threshold of the door at which he was scratching as if he wished to burst it open Jup was also uttering piercing cries

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Hello, Top! cried Neb, who was the first awake. But the dog continued to bark more furiously than ever.
children.prevalue: Hello Top cried Neb who was the first awake But the dog continued to bark more furiously than ever

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What's the matter now? asked Harding.
children.prevalue: What s the matter now asked Harding

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And all dressing in haste rushed to the windows, which they opened.
children.prevalue: And all dressing in haste rushed to the windows which they opened

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Beneath their eyes was spread a sheet of snow which looked gray in the dim light. The settlers could see nothing, but they heard a singular yelping noise away in the darkness. It was evident that the beach had been invaded by a number of animals which could not be seen.
children.prevalue: Beneath their eyes was spread a sheet of snow which looked gray in the dim light The settlers could see nothing but they heard a singular yelping noise away in the darkness It was evident that the beach had been invaded by a number of animals which could not be seen

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What are they? cried Pencroft.
children.prevalue: What are they cried Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Wolves, jaguars, or apes? replied Neb.
children.prevalue: Wolves jaguars or apes replied Neb

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: They have nearly reached the plateau, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: They have nearly reached the plateau said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And our poultry-yard, exclaimed Herbert, and our garden!
children.prevalue: And our poultry yard exclaimed Herbert and our garden

children.name: Paragraph_24
