children.value: Where can they have crossed? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Where can they have crossed asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: They must have crossed the bridge on the shore, replied the engineer, which one of us must have forgotten to close.
children.prevalue: They must have crossed the bridge on the shore replied the engineer which one of us must have forgotten to close

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: True, said Spilett, I remember having left it open.
children.prevalue: True said Spilett I remember having left it open

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A fine job you have made of it, Mr. Spilett, cried the sailor.
children.prevalue: A fine job you have made of it Mr Spilett cried the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: What is done cannot be undone, replied Cyrus Harding. We must consult what it will now be best to do.
children.prevalue: What is done cannot be undone replied Cyrus Harding We must consult what it will now be best to do

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Such were the questions and answers which were rapidly exchanged between Harding and his companions. It was certain that the bridge had been crossed, that the shore had been invaded by animals, and that whatever they might be they could by ascending the left bank of the Mercy reach Prospect Heights. They must therefore be advanced against quickly and fought with if necessary.
children.prevalue: Such were the questions and answers which were rapidly exchanged between Harding and his companions It was certain that the bridge had been crossed that the shore had been invaded by animals and that whatever they might be they could by ascending the left bank of the Mercy reach Prospect Heights They must therefore be advanced against quickly and fought with if necessary

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: But what are these beasts? was asked a second time, as the yelpings were again heard more loudly than before. These yelps made Herbert start, and he remembered having heard them before during his first visit to the sources of the Red Creek.
children.prevalue: But what are these beasts was asked a second time as the yelpings were again heard more loudly than before These yelps made Herbert start and he remembered having heard them before during his first visit to the sources of the Red Creek

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: They are colpeo foxes! he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: They are colpeo foxes he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Forward! shouted the sailor.
children.prevalue: Forward shouted the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: And all arming themselves with hatchets, carbines, and revolvers, threw themselves into the lift and soon set foot on the shore.
children.prevalue: And all arming themselves with hatchets carbines and revolvers threw themselves into the lift and soon set foot on the shore

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Colpeos are dangerous animals when in great numbers and irritated by hunger, nevertheless the colonists did not hesitate to throw themselves into the midst of the troop, and their first shots vividly lighting up the darkness made their assailants draw back.
children.prevalue: Colpeos are dangerous animals when in great numbers and irritated by hunger nevertheless the colonists did not hesitate to throw themselves into the midst of the troop and their first shots vividly lighting up the darkness made their assailants draw back

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The chief thing was to hinder these plunderers from reaching the plateau, for the garden and the poultry-yard would then have been at their mercy, and immense, perhaps irreparable mischief, would inevitably be the result, especially with regard to the corn-field. But as the invasion of the plateau could only be made by the left bank of the Mercy, it was sufficient to oppose the colpeos on the narrow bank between the river and the cliff of granite.
children.prevalue: The chief thing was to hinder these plunderers from reaching the plateau for the garden and the poultry yard would then have been at their mercy and immense perhaps irreparable mischief would inevitably be the result especially with regard to the corn field But as the invasion of the plateau could only be made by the left bank of the Mercy it was sufficient to oppose the colpeos on the narrow bank between the river and the cliff of granite

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: This was plain to all, and, by Cyrus Harding's orders, they reached the spot indicated by him, while the colpeos rushed fiercely through the gloom. Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft and Neb posted themselves in impregnable line. Top, his formidable jaws open, preceded the colonists, and he was followed by Jup, armed with a knotty cudgel, which he brandished like a club.
children.prevalue: This was plain to all and by Cyrus Harding s orders they reached the spot indicated by him while the colpeos rushed fiercely through the gloom Harding Gideon Spilett Herbert Pencroft and Neb posted themselves in impregnable line Top his formidable jaws open preceded the colonists and he was followed by Jup armed with a knotty cudgel which he brandished like a club

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The night was extremely dark, it was only by the flashes from the revolvers as each person fired that they could see their assailants, who were at least a hundred in number, and whose eyes were glowing like hot coals.
children.prevalue: The night was extremely dark it was only by the flashes from the revolvers as each person fired that they could see their assailants who were at least a hundred in number and whose eyes were glowing like hot coals

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: They must not pass! shouted Pencroft.
children.prevalue: They must not pass shouted Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: They shall not pass! returned the engineer.
children.prevalue: They shall not pass returned the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: But if they did not pass it was not for want of having attempted it. Those in the rear pushed on the foremost assailants, and it was an incessant struggle with revolvers and hatchets. Several colpeos already lay dead on the ground, but their number did not appear to diminish, and it might have been supposed that reinforcements were continually arriving over the bridge.
children.prevalue: But if they did not pass it was not for want of having attempted it Those in the rear pushed on the foremost assailants and it was an incessant struggle with revolvers and hatchets Several colpeos already lay dead on the ground but their number did not appear to diminish and it might have been supposed that reinforcements were continually arriving over the bridge

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The colonists were soon obliged to fight at close quarters, not without receiving some wounds, though happily very slight ones. Herbert had, with a shot from his revolver, rescued Neb, on whose back a colpeo had sprung like a tiger cat. Top fought with actual fury, flying at the throats of the foxes and strangling them instantaneously. Jup wielded his weapon valiantly, and it was in vain that they endeavored to keep him in the rear. Endowed doubtless with sight which enabled him to pierce the obscurity, he was always in the thick of the fight uttering from time to time--a sharp hissing sound, which was with him the sign of great rejoicing.
children.prevalue: The colonists were soon obliged to fight at close quarters not without receiving some wounds though happily very slight ones Herbert had with a shot from his revolver rescued Neb on whose back a colpeo had sprung like a tiger cat Top fought with actual fury flying at the throats of the foxes and strangling them instantaneously Jup wielded his weapon valiantly and it was in vain that they endeavored to keep him in the rear Endowed doubtless with sight which enabled him to pierce the obscurity he was always in the thick of the fight uttering from time to time a sharp hissing sound which was with him the sign of great rejoicing

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: At one moment he advanced so far, that by the light from a revolver he was seen surrounded by five or six large colpeos, with whom he was coping with great coolness.
children.prevalue: At one moment he advanced so far that by the light from a revolver he was seen surrounded by five or six large colpeos with whom he was coping with great coolness

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: However, the struggle was ended at last, and victory was on the side of the settlers, but not until they had fought for two long hours! The first signs of the approach of day doubtless determined the retreat of their assailants, who scampered away towards the North, passing over the bridge, which Neb ran immediately to raise. When day had sufficiently lighted up the field of battle, the settlers counted as many as fifty dead bodies scattered about on the shore.
children.prevalue: However the struggle was ended at last and victory was on the side of the settlers but not until they had fought for two long hours The first signs of the approach of day doubtless determined the retreat of their assailants who scampered away towards the North passing over the bridge which Neb ran immediately to raise When day had sufficiently lighted up the field of battle the settlers counted as many as fifty dead bodies scattered about on the shore

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And Jup! cried Pencroft; where is Jup? Jup had disappeared. His friend Neb called him, and for the first time Jup did not reply to his friend's call.
children.prevalue: And Jup cried Pencroft where is Jup Jup had disappeared His friend Neb called him and for the first time Jup did not reply to his friend s call

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Everyone set out in search of Jup, trembling lest he should be found among the slain; they cleared the place of the bodies which stained the snow with their blood. Jup was found in the midst of a heap of colpeos whose broken jaws and crushed bodies showed that they had to do with the terrible club of the intrepid animal.
children.prevalue: Everyone set out in search of Jup trembling lest he should be found among the slain they cleared the place of the bodies which stained the snow with their blood Jup was found in the midst of a heap of colpeos whose broken jaws and crushed bodies showed that they had to do with the terrible club of the intrepid animal

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Poor Jup still held in his hand the stump of his broken cudgel, but deprived of his weapon he had been overpowered by numbers, and his chest was covered with severe wounds.
children.prevalue: Poor Jup still held in his hand the stump of his broken cudgel but deprived of his weapon he had been overpowered by numbers and his chest was covered with severe wounds

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: He is living, cried Neb, who was bending over him.
children.prevalue: He is living cried Neb who was bending over him

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And we will save him, replied the sailor. We will nurse him as if he was one of ourselves.
children.prevalue: And we will save him replied the sailor We will nurse him as if he was one of ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It appeared as if Jup understood, for he leaned his head on Pencroft's shoulder as if to thank him. The sailor was wounded himself, but his wound was insignificant, as were those of his companions; for thanks to their firearms they had been almost always able to keep their assailants at a distance. It was therefore only the orang whose condition was serious.
children.prevalue: It appeared as if Jup understood for he leaned his head on Pencroft s shoulder as if to thank him The sailor was wounded himself but his wound was insignificant as were those of his companions for thanks to their firearms they had been almost always able to keep their assailants at a distance It was therefore only the orang whose condition was serious

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Jup, carried by Neb and Pencroft, was placed in the lift, and only a slight moan now and then escaped his lips. He was gently drawn up to Granite House. There he was laid on a mattress taken from one of the beds, and his wounds were bathed with the greatest care. It did not appear that any vital part had been reached, but Jup was very weak from loss of blood, and a high fever soon set in after his wounds had been dressed. He was laid down, strict diet was imposed, just like a real person, as Neb said, and they made him swallow several cups of a cooling drink, for which the ingredients were supplied from the vegetable medicine chest of Granite House. Jup was at first restless, but his breathing gradually became more regular, and he was left sleeping quietly. From time to time Top, walking on tip-toe, as one might say, came to visit his friend, and seemed to approve of all the care that had been taken of him. One of Jup's hands hung over the side of his bed, and Top licked it with a sympathizing air.
children.prevalue: Jup carried by Neb and Pencroft was placed in the lift and only a slight moan now and then escaped his lips He was gently drawn up to Granite House There he was laid on a mattress taken from one of the beds and his wounds were bathed with the greatest care It did not appear that any vital part had been reached but Jup was very weak from loss of blood and a high fever soon set in after his wounds had been dressed He was laid down strict diet was imposed just like a real person as Neb said and they made him swallow several cups of a cooling drink for which the ingredients were supplied from the vegetable medicine chest of Granite House Jup was at first restless but his breathing gradually became more regular and he was left sleeping quietly From time to time Top walking on tip toe as one might say came to visit his friend and seemed to approve of all the care that had been taken of him One of Jup s hands hung over the side of his bed and Top licked it with a sympathizing air

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: They employed the day in interring the dead, who were dragged to the forest of the Far West, and there buried deep.
children.prevalue: They employed the day in interring the dead who were dragged to the forest of the Far West and there buried deep

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: This attack, which might have had such serious consequences, was a lesson to the settlers, who from this time never went to bed until one of their number had made sure that all the bridges were raised, and that no invasion was possible.
children.prevalue: This attack which might have had such serious consequences was a lesson to the settlers who from this time never went to bed until one of their number had made sure that all the bridges were raised and that no invasion was possible

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: However, Jup, after having given them serious anxiety for several days, began to recover. His constitution brought him through, the fever gradually subsided, and Gideon Spilett, who was a bit of a doctor, pronounced him quite out of danger. On the 16th of August, Jup began to eat. Neb made him nice little sweet dishes, which the invalid devoured with great relish, for if he had a pet failing it was that of being somewhat of a gourmand, and Neb had never done anything to cure him of this fault.
children.prevalue: However Jup after having given them serious anxiety for several days began to recover His constitution brought him through the fever gradually subsided and Gideon Spilett who was a bit of a doctor pronounced him quite out of danger On the 16th of August Jup began to eat Neb made him nice little sweet dishes which the invalid devoured with great relish for if he had a pet failing it was that of being somewhat of a gourmand and Neb had never done anything to cure him of this fault

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What would you have? said he to Gideon Spilett, who sometimes expostulated with him for spoiling the ape. Poor Jup has no other pleasure than that of the palate, and I am only too glad to be able to reward his services in this way!
children.prevalue: What would you have said he to Gideon Spilett who sometimes expostulated with him for spoiling the ape Poor Jup has no other pleasure than that of the palate and I am only too glad to be able to reward his services in this way

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Ten days after taking to his bed, on the 21st of August, Master Jup arose. His wounds were healed, and it was evident that he would not be long in regaining his usual strength and agility. Like all convalescents, he was tremendously hungry, and the reporter allowed him to eat as much as he liked, for he trusted to that instinct, which is too often wanting in reasoning beings, to keep the orang from any excess. Neb was delighted to see his pupil's appetite returning.
children.prevalue: Ten days after taking to his bed on the 21st of August Master Jup arose His wounds were healed and it was evident that he would not be long in regaining his usual strength and agility Like all convalescents he was tremendously hungry and the reporter allowed him to eat as much as he liked for he trusted to that instinct which is too often wanting in reasoning beings to keep the orang from any excess Neb was delighted to see his pupil s appetite returning

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Eat away, my Jup, said he, and don't spare anything; you have shed your blood for us, and it is the least I can do to make you strong again!
children.prevalue: Eat away my Jup said he and don t spare anything you have shed your blood for us and it is the least I can do to make you strong again

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: On the 25th of August Neb's voice was heard calling to his companions.
children.prevalue: On the 25th of August Neb s voice was heard calling to his companions

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Captain, Mr. Spilett, Mr. Herbert, Pencroft, come! come!
children.prevalue: Captain Mr Spilett Mr Herbert Pencroft come come

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The colonists, who were together in the dining-room, rose at Neb's call, who was then in Jup's room.
children.prevalue: The colonists who were together in the dining room rose at Neb s call who was then in Jup s room

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What's the matter? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What s the matter asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Look, replied Neb, with a shout of laughter. And what did they see? Master Jup smoking calmly and seriously, sitting crosslegged like a Turk at the entrance to Granite House!
children.prevalue: Look replied Neb with a shout of laughter And what did they see Master Jup smoking calmly and seriously sitting crosslegged like a Turk at the entrance to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: My pipe, cried Pencroft. He has taken my pipe! Hello, my honest Jup, I make you a present of it! Smoke away, old boy, smoke away!
children.prevalue: My pipe cried Pencroft He has taken my pipe Hello my honest Jup I make you a present of it Smoke away old boy smoke away

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And Jup gravely puffed out clouds of smoke which seemed to give him great satisfaction. Harding did not appear to be much astonished at this incident, and he cited several examples of tame apes, to whom the use of tobacco had become quite familiar.
children.prevalue: And Jup gravely puffed out clouds of smoke which seemed to give him great satisfaction Harding did not appear to be much astonished at this incident and he cited several examples of tame apes to whom the use of tobacco had become quite familiar

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But from this day Master Jup had a pipe of his own, the sailor's ex-pipe, which was hung in his room near his store of tobacco. He filled it himself, lighted it with a glowing coal, and appeared to be the happiest of quadrumana. It may readily be understood that this similarity of tastes of Jup and Pencroft served to tighten the bonds of friendship which already existed between the honest ape and the worthy sailor.
children.prevalue: But from this day Master Jup had a pipe of his own the sailor s ex pipe which was hung in his room near his store of tobacco He filled it himself lighted it with a glowing coal and appeared to be the happiest of quadrumana It may readily be understood that this similarity of tastes of Jup and Pencroft served to tighten the bonds of friendship which already existed between the honest ape and the worthy sailor

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Perhaps he is really a man, said Pencroft sometimes to Neb. Should you be surprised to hear him beginning to speak to us some day?
children.prevalue: Perhaps he is really a man said Pencroft sometimes to Neb Should you be surprised to hear him beginning to speak to us some day

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: My word, no, replied Neb. What astonishes me is that he hasn't spoken to us before, for now he wants nothing but speech!
children.prevalue: My word no replied Neb What astonishes me is that he hasn t spoken to us before for now he wants nothing but speech

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: It would amuse me all the same, resumed the sailor, if some fine day he said to me, 'Suppose we change pipes, Pencroft.'
children.prevalue: It would amuse me all the same resumed the sailor if some fine day he said to me Suppose we change pipes Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Yes, replied Neb, what a pity he was born dumb!
children.prevalue: Yes replied Neb what a pity he was born dumb

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: With the month of September the winter ended, and the works were again eagerly commenced. The building of the vessel advanced rapidly, she was already completely decked over, and all the inside parts of the hull were firmly united with ribs bent by means of steam, which answered all the purposes of a mold.
children.prevalue: With the month of September the winter ended and the works were again eagerly commenced The building of the vessel advanced rapidly she was already completely decked over and all the inside parts of the hull were firmly united with ribs bent by means of steam which answered all the purposes of a mold

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: As there was no want of wood, Pencroft proposed to the engineer to give a double lining to the hull, to insure the strength of the vessel.
children.prevalue: As there was no want of wood Pencroft proposed to the engineer to give a double lining to the hull to insure the strength of the vessel

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Harding, not knowing what the future might have in store for them, approved the sailor's idea of making the craft as strong as possible. The interior and deck of the vessel was entirely finished towards the 15th of September. For calking the seams they made oakum of dry seaweed, which was hammered in between the planks; then these seams were covered with boiling tar, which was obtained in great abundance from the pines in the forest.
children.prevalue: Harding not knowing what the future might have in store for them approved the sailor s idea of making the craft as strong as possible The interior and deck of the vessel was entirely finished towards the 15th of September For calking the seams they made oakum of dry seaweed which was hammered in between the planks then these seams were covered with boiling tar which was obtained in great abundance from the pines in the forest

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The management of the vessel was very simple. She had from the first been ballasted with heavy blocks of granite walled up, in a bed of lime, twelve thousand pounds of which they stowed away.
children.prevalue: The management of the vessel was very simple She had from the first been ballasted with heavy blocks of granite walled up in a bed of lime twelve thousand pounds of which they stowed away

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A deck was placed over this ballast, and the interior was divided into two cabins; two benches extended along them and served also as lockers. The foot of the mast supported the partition which separated the two cabins, which were reached by two hatchways let into the deck.
children.prevalue: A deck was placed over this ballast and the interior was divided into two cabins two benches extended along them and served also as lockers The foot of the mast supported the partition which separated the two cabins which were reached by two hatchways let into the deck

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Pencroft had no trouble in finding a tree suitable for the mast. He chose a straight young fir, with no knots, and which he had only to square at the step, and round off at the top. The ironwork of the mast, the rudder and the hull had been roughly but strongly forged at the Chimneys. Lastly, yards, masts, boom, spars, oars, etc., were all furnished by the first week in October, and it was agreed that a trial trip should be taken round the island, so as to ascertain how the vessel would behave at sea, and how far they might depend upon her.
children.prevalue: Pencroft had no trouble in finding a tree suitable for the mast He chose a straight young fir with no knots and which he had only to square at the step and round off at the top The ironwork of the mast the rudder and the hull had been roughly but strongly forged at the Chimneys Lastly yards masts boom spars oars etc were all furnished by the first week in October and it was agreed that a trial trip should be taken round the island so as to ascertain how the vessel would behave at sea and how far they might depend upon her

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: During all this time the necessary works had not been neglected. The corral was enlarged, for the flock of musmons and goats had been increased by a number of young ones, who had to be housed and fed. The colonists had paid visits also to the oyster bed, the warren, the coal and iron mines, and to the till then unexplored districts of the Far West forest, which abounded in game. Certain indigenous plants were discovered, and those fit for immediate use contributed to vary the vegetable stores of Granite House.
children.prevalue: During all this time the necessary works had not been neglected The corral was enlarged for the flock of musmons and goats had been increased by a number of young ones who had to be housed and fed The colonists had paid visits also to the oyster bed the warren the coal and iron mines and to the till then unexplored districts of the Far West forest which abounded in game Certain indigenous plants were discovered and those fit for immediate use contributed to vary the vegetable stores of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: They were a species of ficoide, some similar to those of the Cape, with eatable fleshy leaves, others bearing seeds containing a sort of flour.
children.prevalue: They were a species of ficoide some similar to those of the Cape with eatable fleshy leaves others bearing seeds containing a sort of flour

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: On the 10th of October the vessel was launched. Pencroft was radiant with joy, the operation was perfectly successful; the boat completely rigged, having been pushed on rollers to the water's edge, was floated by the rising tide, amid the cheers of the colonists, particularly of Pencroft, who showed no modesty on this occasion. Besides his importance was to last beyond the finishing of the vessel, since, after having built her, he was to command her. The grade of captain was bestowed upon him with the approbation of all. To satisfy Captain Pencroft, it was now necessary to give a name to the vessel, and, after many propositions had been discussed, the votes were all in favor of the Bonadventure. As soon as the Bonadventure had been lifted by the rising tide, it was seen that she lay evenly in the water, and would be easily navigated. However, the trial trip was to be made that very day, by an excursion off the coast. The weather was fine, the breeze fresh, and the sea smooth, especially towards the south coast, for the wind was blowing from the northwest.
children.prevalue: On the 10th of October the vessel was launched Pencroft was radiant with joy the operation was perfectly successful the boat completely rigged having been pushed on rollers to the water s edge was floated by the rising tide amid the cheers of the colonists particularly of Pencroft who showed no modesty on this occasion Besides his importance was to last beyond the finishing of the vessel since after having built her he was to command her The grade of captain was bestowed upon him with the approbation of all To satisfy Captain Pencroft it was now necessary to give a name to the vessel and after many propositions had been discussed the votes were all in favor of the Bonadventure As soon as the Bonadventure had been lifted by the rising tide it was seen that she lay evenly in the water and would be easily navigated However the trial trip was to be made that very day by an excursion off the coast The weather was fine the breeze fresh and the sea smooth especially towards the south coast for the wind was blowing from the northwest

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: All hands on board, shouted Pencroft; but breakfast was first necessary, and it was thought best to take provisions on board, in the event of their excursion being prolonged until the evening.
children.prevalue: All hands on board shouted Pencroft but breakfast was first necessary and it was thought best to take provisions on board in the event of their excursion being prolonged until the evening

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Cyrus Harding was equally anxious to try the vessel, the model of which had originated with him, although on the sailor's advice he had altered some parts of it, but he did not share Pencroft's confidence in her, and as the latter had not again spoken of the voyage to Tabor Island, Harding hoped he had given it up. He would have indeed great reluctance in letting two or three of his companions venture so far in so small a boat, which was not of more than fifteen tons' burden.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding was equally anxious to try the vessel the model of which had originated with him although on the sailor s advice he had altered some parts of it but he did not share Pencroft s confidence in her and as the latter had not again spoken of the voyage to Tabor Island Harding hoped he had given it up He would have indeed great reluctance in letting two or three of his companions venture so far in so small a boat which was not of more than fifteen tons burden

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: At half-past ten everybody was on board, even Top and Jup, and Herbert weighed the anchor, which was fast in the sand near the mouth of the Mercy. The sail was hoisted, the Lincolnian flag floated from the masthead, and the Bonadventure, steered by Pencroft, stood out to sea.
children.prevalue: At half past ten everybody was on board even Top and Jup and Herbert weighed the anchor which was fast in the sand near the mouth of the Mercy The sail was hoisted the Lincolnian flag floated from the masthead and the Bonadventure steered by Pencroft stood out to sea

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The wind blowing out of Union Bay she ran before it, and thus showed her owners, much to their satisfaction, that she possessed a remarkably fast pair of heels, according to Pencroft's mode of speaking. After having doubled Flotsam Point and Claw Cape, the captain kept her close hauled, so as to sail along the southern coast of the island, when it was found she sailed admirably within five points of the wind. All hands were enchanted, they had a good vessel, which, in case of need, would be of great service to them, and with fine weather and a fresh breeze the voyage promised to be charming.
children.prevalue: The wind blowing out of Union Bay she ran before it and thus showed her owners much to their satisfaction that she possessed a remarkably fast pair of heels according to Pencroft s mode of speaking After having doubled Flotsam Point and Claw Cape the captain kept her close hauled so as to sail along the southern coast of the island when it was found she sailed admirably within five points of the wind All hands were enchanted they had a good vessel which in case of need would be of great service to them and with fine weather and a fresh breeze the voyage promised to be charming

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Pencroft now stood off the shore, three or four miles across from Port Balloon. The island then appeared in all its extent and under a new aspect, with the varied panorama of its shore from Claw Cape to Reptile End, the forests in which dark firs contrasted with the young foliage of other trees and overlooked the whole, and Mount Franklin whose lofty head was still whitened with snow.
children.prevalue: Pencroft now stood off the shore three or four miles across from Port Balloon The island then appeared in all its extent and under a new aspect with the varied panorama of its shore from Claw Cape to Reptile End the forests in which dark firs contrasted with the young foliage of other trees and overlooked the whole and Mount Franklin whose lofty head was still whitened with snow

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: How beautiful it is! cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: How beautiful it is cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, our island is beautiful and good, replied Pencroft. I love it as I loved my poor mother. It received us poor and destitute, and now what is wanting to us five fellows who fell on it from the sky?
children.prevalue: Yes our island is beautiful and good replied Pencroft I love it as I loved my poor mother It received us poor and destitute and now what is wanting to us five fellows who fell on it from the sky

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Nothing, replied Neb; nothing, captain.
children.prevalue: Nothing replied Neb nothing captain

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: And the two brave men gave three tremendous cheers in honor of their island!
children.prevalue: And the two brave men gave three tremendous cheers in honor of their island

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: During all this time Gideon Spilett, leaning against the mast, sketched the panorama which was developed before his eyes.
children.prevalue: During all this time Gideon Spilett leaning against the mast sketched the panorama which was developed before his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Cyrus Harding gazed on it in silence.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding gazed on it in silence

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Well, Captain Harding, asked Pencroft, what do you think of our vessel?
children.prevalue: Well Captain Harding asked Pencroft what do you think of our vessel

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: She appears to behave well, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: She appears to behave well replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Good! And do you think now that she could undertake a voyage of some extent?
children.prevalue: Good And do you think now that she could undertake a voyage of some extent

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: What voyage, Pencroft?
children.prevalue: What voyage Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: One to Tabor Island, for instance.
children.prevalue: One to Tabor Island for instance

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: My friend, replied Harding, I think that in any pressing emergency we need not hesitate to trust ourselves to the 'Bonadventure' even for a longer voyage; but you know I should see you set off to Tabor Island with great uneasiness, since nothing obliges you to go there.
children.prevalue: My friend replied Harding I think that in any pressing emergency we need not hesitate to trust ourselves to the Bonadventure even for a longer voyage but you know I should see you set off to Tabor Island with great uneasiness since nothing obliges you to go there

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: One likes to know one's neighbors, returned the sailor, who was obstinate in his idea. Tabor Island is our neighbor, and the only one! Politeness requires us to go at least to pay a visit.
children.prevalue: One likes to know one s neighbors returned the sailor who was obstinate in his idea Tabor Island is our neighbor and the only one Politeness requires us to go at least to pay a visit

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: By Jove, said Spilett, our friend Pencroft has become very particular about the proprieties all at once!
children.prevalue: By Jove said Spilett our friend Pencroft has become very particular about the proprieties all at once

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: I am not particular about anything at all, retorted the sailor, who was rather vexed by the engineer's opposition, but who did not wish to cause him anxiety.
children.prevalue: I am not particular about anything at all retorted the sailor who was rather vexed by the engineer s opposition but who did not wish to cause him anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Consider, Pencroft, resumed Harding, you cannot go alone to Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: Consider Pencroft resumed Harding you cannot go alone to Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: One companion will be enough for me.
children.prevalue: One companion will be enough for me

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Even so, replied the engineer, you will risk depriving the colony of Lincoln Island of two settlers out of five.
children.prevalue: Even so replied the engineer you will risk depriving the colony of Lincoln Island of two settlers out of five

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Out of six, answered Pencroft; you forget Jup.
children.prevalue: Out of six answered Pencroft you forget Jup

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Out of seven, added Neb; Top is quite worth another.
children.prevalue: Out of seven added Neb Top is quite worth another

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: There is no risk at all in it, captain, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: There is no risk at all in it captain replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: That is possible, Pencroft; but I repeat it is to expose ourselves uselessly.
children.prevalue: That is possible Pencroft but I repeat it is to expose ourselves uselessly

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: The obstinate sailor did not reply, and let the conversation drop, quite determined to resume it again. But he did not suspect that an incident would come to his aid and change into an act of humanity that which was at first only a doubtful whim.
children.prevalue: The obstinate sailor did not reply and let the conversation drop quite determined to resume it again But he did not suspect that an incident would come to his aid and change into an act of humanity that which was at first only a doubtful whim

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: After standing off the shore the Bonadventure again approached it in the direction of Port Balloon. It was important to ascertain the channels between the sandbanks and reefs, that buoys might be laid down since this little creek was to be the harbor.
children.prevalue: After standing off the shore the Bonadventure again approached it in the direction of Port Balloon It was important to ascertain the channels between the sandbanks and reefs that buoys might be laid down since this little creek was to be the harbor

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: They were not more than half a mile from the coast, and it was necessary to tack to beat against the wind. The Bonadventure was then going at a very moderate rate, as the breeze, partly intercepted by the high land, scarcely swelled her sails, and the sea, smooth as glass, was only rippled now and then by passing gusts.
children.prevalue: They were not more than half a mile from the coast and it was necessary to tack to beat against the wind The Bonadventure was then going at a very moderate rate as the breeze partly intercepted by the high land scarcely swelled her sails and the sea smooth as glass was only rippled now and then by passing gusts

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Herbert had stationed himself in the bows that he might indicate the course to be followed among the channels, when all at once he shouted,--
children.prevalue: Herbert had stationed himself in the bows that he might indicate the course to be followed among the channels when all at once he shouted

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Luff, Pencroft, luff!
children.prevalue: Luff Pencroft luff

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: What's the matter, replied the sailor; a rock?
children.prevalue: What s the matter replied the sailor a rock

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: No--wait, said Herbert; I don't quite see. Luff again--right--now.
children.prevalue: No wait said Herbert I don t quite see Luff again right now

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: So saying, Herbert, leaning over the side, plunged his arm into the water, and pulled it out, exclaiming,--
children.prevalue: So saying Herbert leaning over the side plunged his arm into the water and pulled it out exclaiming

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: A bottle!
children.prevalue: A bottle

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: He held in his hand a corked bottle which he had just seized a few cables' length from the shore.
children.prevalue: He held in his hand a corked bottle which he had just seized a few cables length from the shore

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Cyrus Harding took the bottle. Without uttering a single word he drew the cork, and took from it a damp paper, on which were written these words:--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding took the bottle Without uttering a single word he drew the cork and took from it a damp paper on which were written these words

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Castaway.... Tabor island: 153deg W. long., 37deg 11' S. lat.
children.prevalue: Castaway Tabor island 153deg W long 37deg 11 S lat

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: A castaway! exclaimed Pencroft; left on this Tabor Island not two hundred miles from us! Ah, Captain Harding, you won't now oppose my going.
children.prevalue: A castaway exclaimed Pencroft left on this Tabor Island not two hundred miles from us Ah Captain Harding you won t now oppose my going

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: No, Pencroft, replied Cyrus Harding; and you shall set out as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft replied Cyrus Harding and you shall set out as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: To-morrow?
children.prevalue: To morrow

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: To-morrow!
children.prevalue: To morrow

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The engineer still held in his hand the paper which he had taken from the bottle. He contemplated it for some instants, then resumed,
children.prevalue: The engineer still held in his hand the paper which he had taken from the bottle He contemplated it for some instants then resumed

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: From this document, my friends, from the way in which it is worded, we may conclude this: first, that the castaway on Tabor Island is a man possessing a considerable knowledge of navigation, since he gives the latitude and longitude of the island exactly as we ourselves found it, and to a second of approximation; secondly, that he is either English or American, as the document is written in the English language.
children.prevalue: From this document my friends from the way in which it is worded we may conclude this first that the castaway on Tabor Island is a man possessing a considerable knowledge of navigation since he gives the latitude and longitude of the island exactly as we ourselves found it and to a second of approximation secondly that he is either English or American as the document is written in the English language

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: That is perfectly logical, answered Spilett; and the presence of this castaway explains the arrival of the case on the shores of our island. There must have been a wreck, since there is a castaway. As to the latter, whoever he may be, it is lucky for him that Pencroft thought of building this boat and of trying her this very day, for a day later and this bottle might have been broken on the rocks.
children.prevalue: That is perfectly logical answered Spilett and the presence of this castaway explains the arrival of the case on the shores of our island There must have been a wreck since there is a castaway As to the latter whoever he may be it is lucky for him that Pencroft thought of building this boat and of trying her this very day for a day later and this bottle might have been broken on the rocks

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Indeed, said Herbert, it is a fortunate chance that the 'Bonadventure' passed exactly where the bottle was still floating!
children.prevalue: Indeed said Herbert it is a fortunate chance that the Bonadventure passed exactly where the bottle was still floating

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Does not this appear strange to you? asked Harding of Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Does not this appear strange to you asked Harding of Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It appears fortunate, that's all, answered the sailor. Do you see anything extraordinary in it, captain? The bottle must go somewhere, and why not here as well as anywhere else?
children.prevalue: It appears fortunate that s all answered the sailor Do you see anything extraordinary in it captain The bottle must go somewhere and why not here as well as anywhere else

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Perhaps you are right, Pencroft, replied the engineer; and yet--
children.prevalue: Perhaps you are right Pencroft replied the engineer and yet

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: But, observed Herbert, there's nothing to prove that this bottle has been floating long in the sea.
children.prevalue: But observed Herbert there s nothing to prove that this bottle has been floating long in the sea

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Nothing, replied Gideon Spilett, and the document appears even to have been recently written. What do you think about it, Cyrus?
children.prevalue: Nothing replied Gideon Spilett and the document appears even to have been recently written What do you think about it Cyrus

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: During this conversation Pencroft had not remained inactive. He had put the vessel about, and the Bonadventure, all sails set, was running rapidly towards Claw Cape.
children.prevalue: During this conversation Pencroft had not remained inactive He had put the vessel about and the Bonadventure all sails set was running rapidly towards Claw Cape

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Every one was thinking of the castaway on Tabor Island. Should they be in time to save him? This was a great event in the life of the colonists! They themselves were but castaways, but it was to be feared that another might not have been so fortunate, and their duty was to go to his succor.
children.prevalue: Every one was thinking of the castaway on Tabor Island Should they be in time to save him This was a great event in the life of the colonists They themselves were but castaways but it was to be feared that another might not have been so fortunate and their duty was to go to his succor

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Claw Cape was doubled, and about four o'clock the Bonadventure dropped her anchor at the mouth of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: Claw Cape was doubled and about four o clock the Bonadventure dropped her anchor at the mouth of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: That same evening the arrangements for the new expedition were made. It appeared best that Pencroft and Herbert, who knew how to work the vessel, should undertake the voyage alone. By setting out the next day, the 10th of October, they would arrive on the 13th, for with the present wind it would not take more than forty-eight hours to make this passage of a hundred and fifty miles. One day in the island, three or four to return, they might hope therefore that on the 17th they would again reach Lincoln Island. The weather was fine, the barometer was rising, the wind appeared settled, everything then was in favor of these brave men whom an act of humanity was taking far from their island.
children.prevalue: That same evening the arrangements for the new expedition were made It appeared best that Pencroft and Herbert who knew how to work the vessel should undertake the voyage alone By setting out the next day the 10th of October they would arrive on the 13th for with the present wind it would not take more than forty eight hours to make this passage of a hundred and fifty miles One day in the island three or four to return they might hope therefore that on the 17th they would again reach Lincoln Island The weather was fine the barometer was rising the wind appeared settled everything then was in favor of these brave men whom an act of humanity was taking far from their island

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Thus it had been agreed that Cyrus Harding, Neb, and Gideon Spilett should remain at Granite House, but an objection was raised, and Spilett, who had not forgotten his business as reporter to the New York Herald, having declared that he would go by swimming rather than lose such an opportunity, he was admitted to take a part in the voyage.
children.prevalue: Thus it had been agreed that Cyrus Harding Neb and Gideon Spilett should remain at Granite House but an objection was raised and Spilett who had not forgotten his business as reporter to the New York Herald having declared that he would go by swimming rather than lose such an opportunity he was admitted to take a part in the voyage

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The evening was occupied in transporting on board the Bonadventure, articles of bedding, utensils, arms, ammunition, a compass, provisions for a week; this being rapidly done, the colonists ascended to Granite House.
children.prevalue: The evening was occupied in transporting on board the Bonadventure articles of bedding utensils arms ammunition a compass provisions for a week this being rapidly done the colonists ascended to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The next day, at five o'clock in the morning, the farewells were said, not without some emotion on both sides, and Pencroft setting sail made towards Claw Cape, which had to be doubled in order to proceed to the southwest.
children.prevalue: The next day at five o clock in the morning the farewells were said not without some emotion on both sides and Pencroft setting sail made towards Claw Cape which had to be doubled in order to proceed to the southwest

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The Bonadventure was already a quarter of a mile from the coast when the passengers perceived on the heights of Granite House two men waving their farewells; they were Cyrus Harding and Neb.
children.prevalue: The Bonadventure was already a quarter of a mile from the coast when the passengers perceived on the heights of Granite House two men waving their farewells they were Cyrus Harding and Neb

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Our friends, exclaimed Spilett, this is our first separation in fifteen months.
children.prevalue: Our friends exclaimed Spilett this is our first separation in fifteen months

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Pencroft, the reporter and Herbert waved in return, and Granite House soon disappeared behind the high rocks of the Cape.
children.prevalue: Pencroft the reporter and Herbert waved in return and Granite House soon disappeared behind the high rocks of the Cape

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: During the first part of the day the Bonadventure was still in sight of the southern coast of Lincoln Island, which soon appeared just like a green basket, with Mount Franklin rising from the center. The heights, diminished by distance, did not present an appearance likely to tempt vessels to touch there. Reptile End was passed in about an hour, though at a distance of about ten miles.
children.prevalue: During the first part of the day the Bonadventure was still in sight of the southern coast of Lincoln Island which soon appeared just like a green basket with Mount Franklin rising from the center The heights diminished by distance did not present an appearance likely to tempt vessels to touch there Reptile End was passed in about an hour though at a distance of about ten miles

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: At this distance it was no longer possible to distinguish anything of the Western Coast, which stretched away to the ridges of Mount Franklin, and three hours after the last of Lincoln Island sank below the horizon.
children.prevalue: At this distance it was no longer possible to distinguish anything of the Western Coast which stretched away to the ridges of Mount Franklin and three hours after the last of Lincoln Island sank below the horizon

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The Bonadventure behaved capitally. Bounding over the waves she proceeded rapidly on her course. Pencroft had hoisted the foresail, and steering by the compass followed a rectilinear direction. From time to time Herbert relieved him at the helm, and the lad's hand was so firm that the sailor had not a point to find fault with.
children.prevalue: The Bonadventure behaved capitally Bounding over the waves she proceeded rapidly on her course Pencroft had hoisted the foresail and steering by the compass followed a rectilinear direction From time to time Herbert relieved him at the helm and the lad s hand was so firm that the sailor had not a point to find fault with

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Gideon Spilett chatted sometimes with one, sometimes with the other, if wanted he lent a hand with the ropes, and Captain Pencroft was perfectly satisfied with his crew.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett chatted sometimes with one sometimes with the other if wanted he lent a hand with the ropes and Captain Pencroft was perfectly satisfied with his crew

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: In the evening the crescent moon, which would not be in its first quarter until the 16th, appeared in the twilight and soon set again. The night was dark but starry, and the next day again promised to be fine.
children.prevalue: In the evening the crescent moon which would not be in its first quarter until the 16th appeared in the twilight and soon set again The night was dark but starry and the next day again promised to be fine

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Pencroft prudently lowered the foresail, not wishing to be caught by a sudden gust while carrying too much canvas; it was perhaps an unnecessary precaution on such a calm night, but Pencroft was a prudent sailor and cannot be blamed for it.
children.prevalue: Pencroft prudently lowered the foresail not wishing to be caught by a sudden gust while carrying too much canvas it was perhaps an unnecessary precaution on such a calm night but Pencroft was a prudent sailor and cannot be blamed for it

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The reporter slept part of the night. Pencroft and Herbert took turns for a spell of two hours each at the helm. The sailor trusted Herbert as he would himself, and his confidence was justified by the coolness and judgment of the lad. Pencroft gave him his directions as a commander to his steersman, and Herbert never allowed the Bonadventure to swerve even a point. The night passed quickly, as did the day of the 12th of October. A south-easterly direction was strictly maintained. Unless the Bonadventure fell in with some unknown current she would come exactly within sight of Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: The reporter slept part of the night Pencroft and Herbert took turns for a spell of two hours each at the helm The sailor trusted Herbert as he would himself and his confidence was justified by the coolness and judgment of the lad Pencroft gave him his directions as a commander to his steersman and Herbert never allowed the Bonadventure to swerve even a point The night passed quickly as did the day of the 12th of October A south easterly direction was strictly maintained Unless the Bonadventure fell in with some unknown current she would come exactly within sight of Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: As to the sea over which the vessel was then sailing, it was absolutely deserted. Now and then a great albatross or frigate bird passed within gunshot, and Gideon Spilett wondered if it was to one of them that he had confided his last letter addressed to the New York Herald. These birds were the only beings that appeared to frequent this part of the ocean between Tabor and Lincoln Islands.
children.prevalue: As to the sea over which the vessel was then sailing it was absolutely deserted Now and then a great albatross or frigate bird passed within gunshot and Gideon Spilett wondered if it was to one of them that he had confided his last letter addressed to the New York Herald These birds were the only beings that appeared to frequent this part of the ocean between Tabor and Lincoln Islands

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And yet, observed Herbert, this is the time that whalers usually proceed towards the southern part of the Pacific. Indeed I do not think there could be a more deserted sea than this.
children.prevalue: And yet observed Herbert this is the time that whalers usually proceed towards the southern part of the Pacific Indeed I do not think there could be a more deserted sea than this

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It is not quite so deserted as all that, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It is not quite so deserted as all that replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What do you mean? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What do you mean asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: We are on it. Do you take our vessel for a wreck and us for porpoises?
children.prevalue: We are on it Do you take our vessel for a wreck and us for porpoises

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And Pencroft laughed at his joke.
children.prevalue: And Pencroft laughed at his joke

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: By the evening, according to calculation, it was thought that the Bonadventure had accomplished a distance of a hundred and twenty miles since her departure from Lincoln Island, that is to say in thirty-six hours, which would give her a speed of between three and four knots. The breeze was very slight and might soon drop altogether. However, it was hoped that the next morning by break of day, if the calculation had been correct and the course true, they would sight Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: By the evening according to calculation it was thought that the Bonadventure had accomplished a distance of a hundred and twenty miles since her departure from Lincoln Island that is to say in thirty six hours which would give her a speed of between three and four knots The breeze was very slight and might soon drop altogether However it was hoped that the next morning by break of day if the calculation had been correct and the course true they would sight Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Neither Gideon Spilett, Herbert, nor Pencroft slept that night. In the expectation of the next day they could not but feel some emotion. There was so much uncertainty in their enterprise! Were they near Tabor Island? Was the island still inhabited by the castaway to whose succor they had come? Who was this man? Would not his presence disturb the little colony till then so united? Besides, would he be content to exchange his prison for another? All these questions, which would no doubt be answered the next day, kept them in suspense, and at the dawn of day they all fixed their gaze on the western horizon.
children.prevalue: Neither Gideon Spilett Herbert nor Pencroft slept that night In the expectation of the next day they could not but feel some emotion There was so much uncertainty in their enterprise Were they near Tabor Island Was the island still inhabited by the castaway to whose succor they had come Who was this man Would not his presence disturb the little colony till then so united Besides would he be content to exchange his prison for another All these questions which would no doubt be answered the next day kept them in suspense and at the dawn of day they all fixed their gaze on the western horizon

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Land! shouted Pencroft at about six o'clock in the morning.
children.prevalue: Land shouted Pencroft at about six o clock in the morning

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And it was impossible that Pencroft should be mistaken, it was evident that land was there. Imagine the joy of the little crew of the Bonadventure. In a few hours they would land on the beach of the island!
children.prevalue: And it was impossible that Pencroft should be mistaken it was evident that land was there Imagine the joy of the little crew of the Bonadventure In a few hours they would land on the beach of the island

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The low coast of Tabor Island, scarcely emerging from the sea, was not more than fifteen miles distant.
children.prevalue: The low coast of Tabor Island scarcely emerging from the sea was not more than fifteen miles distant

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The head of the Bonadventure, which was a little to the south of the island, was set directly towards it, and as the sun mounted in the east, its rays fell upon one or two headlands.
children.prevalue: The head of the Bonadventure which was a little to the south of the island was set directly towards it and as the sun mounted in the east its rays fell upon one or two headlands

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This is a much less important isle than Lincoln Island, observed Herbert, and is probably due like ours to some submarine convulsion.
children.prevalue: This is a much less important isle than Lincoln Island observed Herbert and is probably due like ours to some submarine convulsion

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: At eleven o'clock the Bonadventure was not more than two miles off, and Pencroft, while looking for a suitable place at which to land, proceeded very cautiously through the unknown waters. The whole of the island could now be surveyed, and on it could be seen groups of gum and other large trees, of the same species as those growing on Lincoln Island. But the astonishing thing was that no smoke arose to show that the island was inhabited, no signal whatever appeared on the shore!
children.prevalue: At eleven o clock the Bonadventure was not more than two miles off and Pencroft while looking for a suitable place at which to land proceeded very cautiously through the unknown waters The whole of the island could now be surveyed and on it could be seen groups of gum and other large trees of the same species as those growing on Lincoln Island But the astonishing thing was that no smoke arose to show that the island was inhabited no signal whatever appeared on the shore

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And yet the document was clear enough; there was a castaway, and this castaway should have been on the watch.
children.prevalue: And yet the document was clear enough there was a castaway and this castaway should have been on the watch

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: In the meanwhile the Bonadventure entered the winding channels among the reefs, and Pencroft observed every turn with extreme care. He had put Herbert at the helm, posting himself in the bows, inspecting the water, while he held the halliard in his hand, ready to lower the sail at a moment's notice. Gideon Spilett with his glass eagerly scanned the shore, though without perceiving anything.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the Bonadventure entered the winding channels among the reefs and Pencroft observed every turn with extreme care He had put Herbert at the helm posting himself in the bows inspecting the water while he held the halliard in his hand ready to lower the sail at a moment s notice Gideon Spilett with his glass eagerly scanned the shore though without perceiving anything

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: However, at about twelve o'clock the keel of the Bonadventure grated on the bottom. The anchor was let go, the sails furled, and the crew of the little vessel landed.
children.prevalue: However at about twelve o clock the keel of the Bonadventure grated on the bottom The anchor was let go the sails furled and the crew of the little vessel landed

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And there was no reason to doubt that this was Tabor Island, since according to the most recent charts there was no island in this part of the Pacific between New Zealand and the American Coast.
children.prevalue: And there was no reason to doubt that this was Tabor Island since according to the most recent charts there was no island in this part of the Pacific between New Zealand and the American Coast

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The vessel was securely moored, so that there should be no danger of her being carried away by the receding tide; then Pencroft and his companions, well armed, ascended the shore, so as to gain an elevation of about two hundred and fifty or three hundred feet which rose at a distance of half a mile.
children.prevalue: The vessel was securely moored so that there should be no danger of her being carried away by the receding tide then Pencroft and his companions well armed ascended the shore so as to gain an elevation of about two hundred and fifty or three hundred feet which rose at a distance of half a mile

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: From the summit of that hill, said Spilett, we can no doubt obtain a complete view of the island, which will greatly facilitate our search.
children.prevalue: From the summit of that hill said Spilett we can no doubt obtain a complete view of the island which will greatly facilitate our search

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: So as to do here, replied Herbert, that which Captain Harding did the very first thing on Lincoln Island, by climbing Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: So as to do here replied Herbert that which Captain Harding did the very first thing on Lincoln Island by climbing Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Exactly so, answered the reporter, and it is the best plan.
children.prevalue: Exactly so answered the reporter and it is the best plan

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: While thus talking the explorers had advanced along a clearing which terminated at the foot of the hill. Flocks of rock-pigeons and sea-swallows, similar to those of Lincoln Island, fluttered around them. Under the woods which skirted the glade on the left they could hear the bushes rustling and see the grass waving, which indicated the presence of timid animals, but still nothing to show that the island was inhabited.
children.prevalue: While thus talking the explorers had advanced along a clearing which terminated at the foot of the hill Flocks of rock pigeons and sea swallows similar to those of Lincoln Island fluttered around them Under the woods which skirted the glade on the left they could hear the bushes rustling and see the grass waving which indicated the presence of timid animals but still nothing to show that the island was inhabited

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Arrived at the foot of the hill, Pencroft, Spilett, and Herbert climbed it in a few minutes, and gazed anxiously round the horizon.
children.prevalue: Arrived at the foot of the hill Pencroft Spilett and Herbert climbed it in a few minutes and gazed anxiously round the horizon

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: They were on an islet, which did not measure more than six miles in circumference, its shape not much bordered by capes or promontories, bays or creeks, being a lengthened oval. All around, the lonely sea extended to the limits of the horizon. No land nor even a sail was in sight.
children.prevalue: They were on an islet which did not measure more than six miles in circumference its shape not much bordered by capes or promontories bays or creeks being a lengthened oval All around the lonely sea extended to the limits of the horizon No land nor even a sail was in sight

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: This woody islet did not offer the varied aspects of Lincoln Island, arid and wild in one part, but fertile and rich in the other. On the contrary this was a uniform mass of verdure, out of which rose two or three hills of no great height. Obliquely to the oval of the island ran a stream through a wide meadow falling into the sea on the west by a narrow mouth.
children.prevalue: This woody islet did not offer the varied aspects of Lincoln Island arid and wild in one part but fertile and rich in the other On the contrary this was a uniform mass of verdure out of which rose two or three hills of no great height Obliquely to the oval of the island ran a stream through a wide meadow falling into the sea on the west by a narrow mouth

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The domain is limited, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: The domain is limited said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Yes, rejoined Pencroft: It would have been too small for us.
children.prevalue: Yes rejoined Pencroft It would have been too small for us

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And moreover, said the reporter, it appears to be uninhabited.
children.prevalue: And moreover said the reporter it appears to be uninhabited

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Indeed, answered Herbert, nothing here betrays the presence of man.
children.prevalue: Indeed answered Herbert nothing here betrays the presence of man

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Let us go down, said Pencroft, and search.
children.prevalue: Let us go down said Pencroft and search

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The sailor and his two companions returned to the shore, to the place where they had left the Bonadventure.
children.prevalue: The sailor and his two companions returned to the shore to the place where they had left the Bonadventure

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: They had decided to make the tour of the island on foot, before exploring the interior; so that not a spot should escape their investigations. The beach was easy to follow, and only in some places was their way barred by large rocks, which, however, they easily passed round. The explorers proceeded towards the south, disturbing numerous flocks of sea-birds and herds of seals, which threw themselves into the sea as soon as they saw the strangers at a distance.
children.prevalue: They had decided to make the tour of the island on foot before exploring the interior so that not a spot should escape their investigations The beach was easy to follow and only in some places was their way barred by large rocks which however they easily passed round The explorers proceeded towards the south disturbing numerous flocks of sea birds and herds of seals which threw themselves into the sea as soon as they saw the strangers at a distance

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Those beasts yonder, observed the reporter, do not see men for the first time. They fear them, therefore they must know them.
children.prevalue: Those beasts yonder observed the reporter do not see men for the first time They fear them therefore they must know them

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: An hour after their departure they arrived on the southern point of the islet, terminated by a sharp cape, and proceeded towards the north along the western coast, equally formed by sand and rocks, the background bordered with thick woods.
children.prevalue: An hour after their departure they arrived on the southern point of the islet terminated by a sharp cape and proceeded towards the north along the western coast equally formed by sand and rocks the background bordered with thick woods

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: There was not a trace of a habitation in any part, not the print of a human foot on the shore of the island, which after four hours' walking had been gone completely round.
children.prevalue: There was not a trace of a habitation in any part not the print of a human foot on the shore of the island which after four hours walking had been gone completely round

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: It was to say the least very extraordinary, and they were compelled to believe that Tabor Island was not or was no longer inhabited. Perhaps, after all the document was already several months or several years old, and it was possible in this case, either that the castaway had been enabled to return to his country, or that he had died of misery.
children.prevalue: It was to say the least very extraordinary and they were compelled to believe that Tabor Island was not or was no longer inhabited Perhaps after all the document was already several months or several years old and it was possible in this case either that the castaway had been enabled to return to his country or that he had died of misery

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Pencroft, Spilett, and Herbert, forming more or less probable conjectures, dined rapidly on board the Bonadventure so as to be able to continue their excursion until nightfall. This was done at five o'clock in the evening, at which hour they entered the wood.
children.prevalue: Pencroft Spilett and Herbert forming more or less probable conjectures dined rapidly on board the Bonadventure so as to be able to continue their excursion until nightfall This was done at five o clock in the evening at which hour they entered the wood

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Numerous animals fled at their approach, being principally, one might say, only goats and pigs, which were obviously European species.
children.prevalue: Numerous animals fled at their approach being principally one might say only goats and pigs which were obviously European species

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Doubtless some whaler had landed them on the island, where they had rapidly increased. Herbert resolved to catch one or two living, and take them back to Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: Doubtless some whaler had landed them on the island where they had rapidly increased Herbert resolved to catch one or two living and take them back to Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It was no longer doubtful that men at some period or other had visited this islet, and this became still more evident when paths appeared trodden through the forest, felled trees, and everywhere traces of the hand of man; but the trees were becoming rotten, and had been felled many years ago; the marks of the axe were velveted with moss, and the grass grew long and thick on the paths, so that it was difficult to find them.
children.prevalue: It was no longer doubtful that men at some period or other had visited this islet and this became still more evident when paths appeared trodden through the forest felled trees and everywhere traces of the hand of man but the trees were becoming rotten and had been felled many years ago the marks of the axe were velveted with moss and the grass grew long and thick on the paths so that it was difficult to find them

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: But, observed Gideon Spilett, this not only proves that men have landed on the island, but also that they lived on it for some time. Now, who were these men? How many of them remain?
children.prevalue: But observed Gideon Spilett this not only proves that men have landed on the island but also that they lived on it for some time Now who were these men How many of them remain

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The document, said Herbert, only spoke of one castaway.
children.prevalue: The document said Herbert only spoke of one castaway

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Well, if he is still on the island, replied Pencroft, it is impossible but that we shall find him.
children.prevalue: Well if he is still on the island replied Pencroft it is impossible but that we shall find him

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: The exploration was continued. The sailor and his companions naturally followed the route which cut diagonally across the island, and they were thus obliged to follow the stream which flowed towards the sea.
children.prevalue: The exploration was continued The sailor and his companions naturally followed the route which cut diagonally across the island and they were thus obliged to follow the stream which flowed towards the sea

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: If the animals of European origin, if works due to a human hand, showed incontestably that men had already visited the island, several specimens of the vegetable kingdom did not prove it less. In some places, in the midst of clearings, it was evident that the soil had been planted with culinary plants, at probably the same distant period.
children.prevalue: If the animals of European origin if works due to a human hand showed incontestably that men had already visited the island several specimens of the vegetable kingdom did not prove it less In some places in the midst of clearings it was evident that the soil had been planted with culinary plants at probably the same distant period

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: What, then, was Herbert's joy, when he recognized potatoes, chicory, sorrel, carrots, cabbages, and turnips, of which it was sufficient to collect the seed to enrich the soil of Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: What then was Herbert s joy when he recognized potatoes chicory sorrel carrots cabbages and turnips of which it was sufficient to collect the seed to enrich the soil of Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Capital, jolly! exclaimed Pencroft. That will suit Neb as well as us. Even if we do not find the castaway, at least our voyage will not have been useless, and God will have rewarded us.
children.prevalue: Capital jolly exclaimed Pencroft That will suit Neb as well as us Even if we do not find the castaway at least our voyage will not have been useless and God will have rewarded us

children.name: Paragraph_79
