children.value: Doubtless, replied Gideon Spilett, but to see the state in which we find these plantations, it is to be feared that the island has not been inhabited for some time.
children.prevalue: Doubtless replied Gideon Spilett but to see the state in which we find these plantations it is to be feared that the island has not been inhabited for some time

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Indeed, answered Herbert, an inhabitant, whoever he was, could not have neglected such an important culture!
children.prevalue: Indeed answered Herbert an inhabitant whoever he was could not have neglected such an important culture

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Yes, said Pencroft, the castaway has gone.
children.prevalue: Yes said Pencroft the castaway has gone

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: We must suppose so.
children.prevalue: We must suppose so

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: It must then be admitted that the document has already a distant date?
children.prevalue: It must then be admitted that the document has already a distant date

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Evidently.
children.prevalue: Evidently

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: And that the bottle only arrived at Lincoln Island after having floated in the sea a long time.
children.prevalue: And that the bottle only arrived at Lincoln Island after having floated in the sea a long time

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Why not? returned Pencroft. But night is coming on, added he, and I think that it will be best to give up the search for the present.
children.prevalue: Why not returned Pencroft But night is coming on added he and I think that it will be best to give up the search for the present

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Let us go on board, and to-morrow we will begin again, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: Let us go on board and to morrow we will begin again said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: This was the wisest course, and it was about to be followed when Herbert, pointing to a confused mass among the trees, exclaimed,--
children.prevalue: This was the wisest course and it was about to be followed when Herbert pointing to a confused mass among the trees exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: A hut!
children.prevalue: A hut

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: All three immediately ran towards the dwelling. In the twilight it was just possible to see that it was built of planks and covered with a thick tarpaulin.
children.prevalue: All three immediately ran towards the dwelling In the twilight it was just possible to see that it was built of planks and covered with a thick tarpaulin

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: The half-closed door was pushed open by Pencroft, who entered with a rapid step.
children.prevalue: The half closed door was pushed open by Pencroft who entered with a rapid step

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: The hut was empty!
children.prevalue: The hut was empty

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Pencroft, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett remained silent in the midst of the darkness.
children.prevalue: Pencroft Herbert and Gideon Spilett remained silent in the midst of the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Pencroft shouted loudly.
children.prevalue: Pencroft shouted loudly

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: No reply was made.
children.prevalue: No reply was made

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The sailor then struck a light and set fire to a twig. This lighted for a minute a small room, which appeared perfectly empty. At the back was a rude fireplace, with a few cold cinders, supporting an armful of dry wood. Pencroft threw the blazing twig on it, the wood crackled and gave forth a bright light.
children.prevalue: The sailor then struck a light and set fire to a twig This lighted for a minute a small room which appeared perfectly empty At the back was a rude fireplace with a few cold cinders supporting an armful of dry wood Pencroft threw the blazing twig on it the wood crackled and gave forth a bright light

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The sailor and his two companions then perceived a disordered bed, of which the damp and yellow coverlets proved that it had not been used for a long time. In the corner of the fireplace were two kettles, covered with rust, and an overthrown pot. A cupboard, with a few moldy sailor's clothes; on the table a tin plate and a Bible, eaten away by damp; in a corner a few tools, a spade, pickaxe, two fowling-pieces, one of which was broken; on a plank, forming a shelf, stood a barrel of powder, still untouched, a barrel of shot, and several boxes of caps, all thickly covered with dust, accumulated, perhaps, by many long years.
children.prevalue: The sailor and his two companions then perceived a disordered bed of which the damp and yellow coverlets proved that it had not been used for a long time In the corner of the fireplace were two kettles covered with rust and an overthrown pot A cupboard with a few moldy sailor s clothes on the table a tin plate and a Bible eaten away by damp in a corner a few tools a spade pickaxe two fowling pieces one of which was broken on a plank forming a shelf stood a barrel of powder still untouched a barrel of shot and several boxes of caps all thickly covered with dust accumulated perhaps by many long years

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: There is no one here, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: There is no one here said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: No one, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: No one replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It is a long time since this room has been inhabited, observed Herbert.
children.prevalue: It is a long time since this room has been inhabited observed Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Yes, a very long time! answered the reporter.
children.prevalue: Yes a very long time answered the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Mr. Spilett, then said Pencroft, instead of returning on board, I think that it would be well to pass the night in this hut.
children.prevalue: Mr Spilett then said Pencroft instead of returning on board I think that it would be well to pass the night in this hut

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You are right, Pencroft, answered Gideon Spilett, and if its owner returns, well! perhaps he will not be sorry to find the place taken possession of.
children.prevalue: You are right Pencroft answered Gideon Spilett and if its owner returns well perhaps he will not be sorry to find the place taken possession of

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: He will not return, said the sailor, shaking his head.
children.prevalue: He will not return said the sailor shaking his head

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You think that he has quitted the island? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: You think that he has quitted the island asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: If he had quitted the island he would have taken away his weapons and his tools, replied Pencroft. You know the value which castaways set on such articles as these the last remains of a wreck. No! no! repeated the sailor, in a tone of conviction; no, he has not left the island! If he had escaped in a boat made by himself, he would still less have left these indispensable and necessary articles. No! he is on the island!
children.prevalue: If he had quitted the island he would have taken away his weapons and his tools replied Pencroft You know the value which castaways set on such articles as these the last remains of a wreck No no repeated the sailor in a tone of conviction no he has not left the island If he had escaped in a boat made by himself he would still less have left these indispensable and necessary articles No he is on the island

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Living? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: Living asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Living or dead. But if he is dead, I suppose he has not buried himself, and so we shall at least find his remains!
children.prevalue: Living or dead But if he is dead I suppose he has not buried himself and so we shall at least find his remains

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It was then agreed that the night should be passed in the deserted dwelling, and a store of wood found in a corner was sufficient to warm it. The door closed, Pencroft, Herbert and Spilett remained there, seated on a bench, talking little but wondering much. They were in a frame of mind to imagine anything or expect anything. They listened eagerly for sounds outside. The door might have opened suddenly, and a man presented himself to them without their being in the least surprised, notwithstanding all that the hut revealed of abandonment, and they had their hands ready to press the hands of this man, this castaway, this unknown friend, for whom friends were waiting.
children.prevalue: It was then agreed that the night should be passed in the deserted dwelling and a store of wood found in a corner was sufficient to warm it The door closed Pencroft Herbert and Spilett remained there seated on a bench talking little but wondering much They were in a frame of mind to imagine anything or expect anything They listened eagerly for sounds outside The door might have opened suddenly and a man presented himself to them without their being in the least surprised notwithstanding all that the hut revealed of abandonment and they had their hands ready to press the hands of this man this castaway this unknown friend for whom friends were waiting

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: But no voice was heard, the door did not open. The hours thus passed away.
children.prevalue: But no voice was heard the door did not open The hours thus passed away

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: How long the night appeared to the sailor and his companions! Herbert alone slept for two hours, for at his age sleep is a necessity. They were all three anxious to continue their exploration of the day before, and to search the most secret recesses of the islet! The inferences deduced by Pencroft were perfectly reasonable, and it was nearly certain that, as the hut was deserted, and the tools, utensils, and weapons were still there, the owner had succumbed. It was agreed, therefore, that they should search for his remains, and give them at least Christian burial.
children.prevalue: How long the night appeared to the sailor and his companions Herbert alone slept for two hours for at his age sleep is a necessity They were all three anxious to continue their exploration of the day before and to search the most secret recesses of the islet The inferences deduced by Pencroft were perfectly reasonable and it was nearly certain that as the hut was deserted and the tools utensils and weapons were still there the owner had succumbed It was agreed therefore that they should search for his remains and give them at least Christian burial

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Day dawned; Pencroft and his companions immediately proceeded to survey the dwelling. It had certainly been built in a favorable situation, at the back of a little hill, sheltered by five or six magnificent gum-trees. Before its front and through the trees the axe had prepared a wide clearing, which allowed the view to extend to the sea. Beyond a lawn, surrounded by a wooden fence falling to pieces, was the shore, on the left of which was the mouth of the stream.
children.prevalue: Day dawned Pencroft and his companions immediately proceeded to survey the dwelling It had certainly been built in a favorable situation at the back of a little hill sheltered by five or six magnificent gum trees Before its front and through the trees the axe had prepared a wide clearing which allowed the view to extend to the sea Beyond a lawn surrounded by a wooden fence falling to pieces was the shore on the left of which was the mouth of the stream

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The hut had been built of planks, and it was easy to see that these planks had been obtained from the hull or deck of a ship. It was probable that a disabled vessel had been cast on the coast of the island, that one at least of the crew had been saved, and that by means of the wreck this man, having tools at his disposal, had built the dwelling.
children.prevalue: The hut had been built of planks and it was easy to see that these planks had been obtained from the hull or deck of a ship It was probable that a disabled vessel had been cast on the coast of the island that one at least of the crew had been saved and that by means of the wreck this man having tools at his disposal had built the dwelling

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And this became still more evident when Gideon Spilett, after having walked around the hut, saw on a plank, probably one of those which had formed the armor of the wrecked vessel, these letters already half effaced:
children.prevalue: And this became still more evident when Gideon Spilett after having walked around the hut saw on a plank probably one of those which had formed the armor of the wrecked vessel these letters already half effaced

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: BR--TAN--A
children.prevalue: BR TAN A

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Britannia, exclaimed Pencroft, whom the reporter had called; it is a common name for ships, and I could not say if she was English or American!
children.prevalue: Britannia exclaimed Pencroft whom the reporter had called it is a common name for ships and I could not say if she was English or American

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: It matters very little, Pencroft!
children.prevalue: It matters very little Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Very little indeed, answered the sailor, and we will save the survivor of her crew if he is still living, to whatever country he may belong. But before beginning our search again let us go on board the 'Bonadventure'.
children.prevalue: Very little indeed answered the sailor and we will save the survivor of her crew if he is still living to whatever country he may belong But before beginning our search again let us go on board the Bonadventure

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A sort of uneasiness had seized Pencroft upon the subject of his vessel. Should the island be inhabited after all, and should some one have taken possession of her? But he shrugged his shoulders at such an unreasonable supposition. At any rate the sailor was not sorry to go to breakfast on board. The road already trodden was not long, scarcely a mile. They set out on their walk, gazing into the wood and thickets through which goats and pigs fled in hundreds.
children.prevalue: A sort of uneasiness had seized Pencroft upon the subject of his vessel Should the island be inhabited after all and should some one have taken possession of her But he shrugged his shoulders at such an unreasonable supposition At any rate the sailor was not sorry to go to breakfast on board The road already trodden was not long scarcely a mile They set out on their walk gazing into the wood and thickets through which goats and pigs fled in hundreds

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Twenty minutes after leaving the hut Pencroft and his companions reached the western coast of the island, and saw the Bonadventure held fast by her anchor, which was buried deep in the sand.
children.prevalue: Twenty minutes after leaving the hut Pencroft and his companions reached the western coast of the island and saw the Bonadventure held fast by her anchor which was buried deep in the sand

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Pencroft could not restrain a sigh of satisfaction. After all this vessel was his child, and it is the right of fathers to be often uneasy when there is no occasion for it.
children.prevalue: Pencroft could not restrain a sigh of satisfaction After all this vessel was his child and it is the right of fathers to be often uneasy when there is no occasion for it

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: They returned on board, breakfasted, so that it should not be necessary to dine until very late; then the repast being ended, the exploration was continued and conducted with the most minute care. Indeed, it was very probable that the only inhabitant of the island had perished. It was therefore more for the traces of a dead than of a living man that Pencroft and his companions searched. But their searches were vain, and during the half of that day they sought to no purpose among the thickets of trees which covered the islet. There was then scarcely any doubt that, if the castaway was dead, no trace of his body now remained, but that some wild beast had probably devoured it to the last bone.
children.prevalue: They returned on board breakfasted so that it should not be necessary to dine until very late then the repast being ended the exploration was continued and conducted with the most minute care Indeed it was very probable that the only inhabitant of the island had perished It was therefore more for the traces of a dead than of a living man that Pencroft and his companions searched But their searches were vain and during the half of that day they sought to no purpose among the thickets of trees which covered the islet There was then scarcely any doubt that if the castaway was dead no trace of his body now remained but that some wild beast had probably devoured it to the last bone

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: We will set off to-morrow at daybreak, said Pencroft to his two companions, as about two o'clock they were resting for a few minutes under the shade of a clump of firs.
children.prevalue: We will set off to morrow at daybreak said Pencroft to his two companions as about two o clock they were resting for a few minutes under the shade of a clump of firs

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I should think that we might without scruple take the utensils which belonged to the castaway, added Herbert.
children.prevalue: I should think that we might without scruple take the utensils which belonged to the castaway added Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I think so, too, returned Gideon Spilett, and these arms and tools will make up the stores of Granite House. The supply of powder and shot is also most important.
children.prevalue: I think so too returned Gideon Spilett and these arms and tools will make up the stores of Granite House The supply of powder and shot is also most important

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, replied Pencroft, but we must not forget to capture a couple or two of those pigs, of which Lincoln Island is destitute.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Pencroft but we must not forget to capture a couple or two of those pigs of which Lincoln Island is destitute

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Nor to gather those seeds, added Herbert, which will give us all the vegetables of the Old and the New Worlds.
children.prevalue: Nor to gather those seeds added Herbert which will give us all the vegetables of the Old and the New Worlds

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Then perhaps it would be best, said the reporter, to remain a day longer on Tabor Island, so as to collect all that may be useful to us.
children.prevalue: Then perhaps it would be best said the reporter to remain a day longer on Tabor Island so as to collect all that may be useful to us

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, Mr. Spilett, answered Pencroft, I will ask you to set off to-morrow at daybreak. The wind seems to me to be likely to shift to the west, and after having had a fair wind for coming we shall have a fair wind for going back.
children.prevalue: No Mr Spilett answered Pencroft I will ask you to set off to morrow at daybreak The wind seems to me to be likely to shift to the west and after having had a fair wind for coming we shall have a fair wind for going back

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Then do not let us lose time, said Herbert, rising.
children.prevalue: Then do not let us lose time said Herbert rising

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: We won't waste time, returned Pencroft. You, Herbert, go and gather the seeds, which you know better than we do. While you do that, Mr. Spilett and I will go and have a pig hunt, and even without Top I hope we shall manage to catch a few!
children.prevalue: We won t waste time returned Pencroft You Herbert go and gather the seeds which you know better than we do While you do that Mr Spilett and I will go and have a pig hunt and even without Top I hope we shall manage to catch a few

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Herbert accordingly took the path which led towards the cultivated part of the islet, while the sailor and the reporter entered the forest.
children.prevalue: Herbert accordingly took the path which led towards the cultivated part of the islet while the sailor and the reporter entered the forest

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Many specimens of the porcine race fled before them, and these animals, which were singularly active, did not appear to be in a humor to allow themselves to be approached.
children.prevalue: Many specimens of the porcine race fled before them and these animals which were singularly active did not appear to be in a humor to allow themselves to be approached

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: However, after an hour's chase, the hunters had just managed to get hold of a couple lying in a thicket, when cries were heard resounding from the north part of the island, With the cries were mingled terrible yells, in which there was nothing human.
children.prevalue: However after an hour s chase the hunters had just managed to get hold of a couple lying in a thicket when cries were heard resounding from the north part of the island With the cries were mingled terrible yells in which there was nothing human

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Pencroft and Gideon Spilett were at once on their feet, and the pigs by this movement began to run away, at the moment when the sailor was getting ready the rope to bind them.
children.prevalue: Pencroft and Gideon Spilett were at once on their feet and the pigs by this movement began to run away at the moment when the sailor was getting ready the rope to bind them

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: That's Herbert's voice, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: That s Herbert s voice said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Run! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Run exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And the sailor and Spilett immediately ran at full speed towards the spot from whence the cries proceeded.
children.prevalue: And the sailor and Spilett immediately ran at full speed towards the spot from whence the cries proceeded

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: They did well to hasten, for at a turn of the path near a clearing they saw the lad thrown on the ground and in the grasp of a savage being, apparently a gigantic ape, who was about to do him some great harm.
children.prevalue: They did well to hasten for at a turn of the path near a clearing they saw the lad thrown on the ground and in the grasp of a savage being apparently a gigantic ape who was about to do him some great harm

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: To rush on this monster, throw him on the ground in his turn, snatch Herbert from him, then bind him securely, was the work of a minute for Pencroft and Gideon Spilett. The sailor was of Herculean strength, the reporter also very powerful, and in spite of the monster's resistance he was firmly tied so that he could not even move.
children.prevalue: To rush on this monster throw him on the ground in his turn snatch Herbert from him then bind him securely was the work of a minute for Pencroft and Gideon Spilett The sailor was of Herculean strength the reporter also very powerful and in spite of the monster s resistance he was firmly tied so that he could not even move

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You are not hurt, Herbert? asked Spilett.
children.prevalue: You are not hurt Herbert asked Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: No, no!
children.prevalue: No no

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Oh, if this ape had wounded him! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Oh if this ape had wounded him exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But he is not an ape, answered Herbert.
children.prevalue: But he is not an ape answered Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: At these words Pencroft and Gideon Spilett looked at the singular being who lay on the ground. Indeed it was not an ape; it was a human being, a man. But what a man! A savage in all the horrible acceptation of the word, and so much the more frightful that he seemed fallen to the lowest degree of brutishness!
children.prevalue: At these words Pencroft and Gideon Spilett looked at the singular being who lay on the ground Indeed it was not an ape it was a human being a man But what a man A savage in all the horrible acceptation of the word and so much the more frightful that he seemed fallen to the lowest degree of brutishness

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Shaggy hair, untrimmed beard descending to the chest, the body almost naked except a rag round the waist, wild eyes, enormous hands with immensely long nails, skin the color of mahogany, feet as hard as if made of horn, such was the miserable creature who yet had a claim to be called a man. But it might justly be asked if there were yet a soul in this body, or if the brute instinct alone survived in it!
children.prevalue: Shaggy hair untrimmed beard descending to the chest the body almost naked except a rag round the waist wild eyes enormous hands with immensely long nails skin the color of mahogany feet as hard as if made of horn such was the miserable creature who yet had a claim to be called a man But it might justly be asked if there were yet a soul in this body or if the brute instinct alone survived in it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Are you quite sure that this is a man, or that he has ever been one? said Pencroft to the reporter.
children.prevalue: Are you quite sure that this is a man or that he has ever been one said Pencroft to the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Alas! there is no doubt about it, replied Spilett.
children.prevalue: Alas there is no doubt about it replied Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Then this must be the castaway? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: Then this must be the castaway asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Yes, replied Gideon Spilett, but the unfortunate man has no longer anything human about him!
children.prevalue: Yes replied Gideon Spilett but the unfortunate man has no longer anything human about him

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The reporter spoke the truth. It was evident that if the castaway had ever been a civilized being, solitude had made him a savage, or worse, perhaps a regular man of the woods. Hoarse sounds issued from his throat between his teeth, which were sharp as the teeth of a wild beast made to tear raw flesh.
children.prevalue: The reporter spoke the truth It was evident that if the castaway had ever been a civilized being solitude had made him a savage or worse perhaps a regular man of the woods Hoarse sounds issued from his throat between his teeth which were sharp as the teeth of a wild beast made to tear raw flesh

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Memory must have deserted him long before, and for a long time also he had forgotten how to use his gun and tools, and he no longer knew how to make a fire! It could be seen that he was active and powerful, but the physical qualities had been developed in him to the injury of the moral qualities. Gideon Spilett spoke to him. He did not appear to understand or even to hear. And yet on looking into his eyes, the reporter thought he could see that all reason was not extinguished in him. However, the prisoner did not struggle, nor even attempt to break his bonds. Was he overwhelmed by the presence of men whose fellow he had once been? Had he found in some corner of his brain a fleeting remembrance which recalled him to humanity? If free, would he attempt to fly, or would he remain? They could not tell, but they did not make the experiment; and after gazing attentively at the miserable creature,--
children.prevalue: Memory must have deserted him long before and for a long time also he had forgotten how to use his gun and tools and he no longer knew how to make a fire It could be seen that he was active and powerful but the physical qualities had been developed in him to the injury of the moral qualities Gideon Spilett spoke to him He did not appear to understand or even to hear And yet on looking into his eyes the reporter thought he could see that all reason was not extinguished in him However the prisoner did not struggle nor even attempt to break his bonds Was he overwhelmed by the presence of men whose fellow he had once been Had he found in some corner of his brain a fleeting remembrance which recalled him to humanity If free would he attempt to fly or would he remain They could not tell but they did not make the experiment and after gazing attentively at the miserable creature

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Whoever he may be, remarked Gideon Spilett, whoever he may have been, and whatever he may become, it is our duty to take him with us to Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: Whoever he may be remarked Gideon Spilett whoever he may have been and whatever he may become it is our duty to take him with us to Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, yes! replied Herbert, and perhaps with care we may arouse in him some gleam of intelligence.
children.prevalue: Yes yes replied Herbert and perhaps with care we may arouse in him some gleam of intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The soul does not die, said the reporter, and it would be a great satisfaction to rescue one of God's creatures from brutishness.
children.prevalue: The soul does not die said the reporter and it would be a great satisfaction to rescue one of God s creatures from brutishness

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Pencroft shook his head doubtfully.
children.prevalue: Pencroft shook his head doubtfully

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: We must try at any rate, returned the reporter; humanity commands us.
children.prevalue: We must try at any rate returned the reporter humanity commands us

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: It was indeed their duty as Christians and civilized beings. All three felt this, and they well knew that Cyrus Harding would approve of their acting thus.
children.prevalue: It was indeed their duty as Christians and civilized beings All three felt this and they well knew that Cyrus Harding would approve of their acting thus

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Shall we leave him bound? asked the sailor.
children.prevalue: Shall we leave him bound asked the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Perhaps he would walk if his feet were unfastened, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: Perhaps he would walk if his feet were unfastened said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Let us try, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Let us try replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The cords which shackled the prisoner's feet were cut off, but his arms remained securely fastened. He got up by himself and did not manifest any desire to run away. His hard eyes darted a piercing glance at the three men, who walked near him, but nothing denoted that he recollected being their fellow, or at least having been so. A continual hissing sound issued from his lips, his aspect was wild, but he did not attempt to resist.
children.prevalue: The cords which shackled the prisoner s feet were cut off but his arms remained securely fastened He got up by himself and did not manifest any desire to run away His hard eyes darted a piercing glance at the three men who walked near him but nothing denoted that he recollected being their fellow or at least having been so A continual hissing sound issued from his lips his aspect was wild but he did not attempt to resist

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: By the reporter's advice the unfortunate man was taken to the hut. Perhaps the sight of the things that belonged to him would make some impression on him! Perhaps a spark would be sufficient to revive his obscured intellect, to rekindle his dulled soul. The dwelling was not far off. In a few minutes they arrived there, but the prisoner remembered nothing, and it appeared that he had lost consciousness of everything.
children.prevalue: By the reporter s advice the unfortunate man was taken to the hut Perhaps the sight of the things that belonged to him would make some impression on him Perhaps a spark would be sufficient to revive his obscured intellect to rekindle his dulled soul The dwelling was not far off In a few minutes they arrived there but the prisoner remembered nothing and it appeared that he had lost consciousness of everything

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: What could they think of the degree of brutishness into which this miserable being had fallen, unless that his imprisonment on the islet dated from a very distant period and after having arrived there a rational being solitude had reduced him to this condition.
children.prevalue: What could they think of the degree of brutishness into which this miserable being had fallen unless that his imprisonment on the islet dated from a very distant period and after having arrived there a rational being solitude had reduced him to this condition

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The reporter then thought that perhaps the sight of fire would have some effect on him, and in a moment one of those beautiful flames, that attract even animals, blazed up on the hearth. The sight of the flame seemed at first to fix the attention of the unhappy object, but soon he turned away and the look of intelligence faded. Evidently there was nothing to be done, for the time at least, but to take him on board the Bonadventure. This was done, and he remained there in Pencroft's charge.
children.prevalue: The reporter then thought that perhaps the sight of fire would have some effect on him and in a moment one of those beautiful flames that attract even animals blazed up on the hearth The sight of the flame seemed at first to fix the attention of the unhappy object but soon he turned away and the look of intelligence faded Evidently there was nothing to be done for the time at least but to take him on board the Bonadventure This was done and he remained there in Pencroft s charge

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Herbert and Spilett returned to finish their work; and some hours after they came back to the shore, carrying the utensils and guns, a store of vegetables, of seeds, some game, and two couple of pigs.
children.prevalue: Herbert and Spilett returned to finish their work and some hours after they came back to the shore carrying the utensils and guns a store of vegetables of seeds some game and two couple of pigs

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: All was embarked, and the Bonadventure was ready to weigh anchor and sail with the morning tide.
children.prevalue: All was embarked and the Bonadventure was ready to weigh anchor and sail with the morning tide

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The prisoner had been placed in the fore-cabin, where he remained quiet, silent, apparently deaf and dumb.
children.prevalue: The prisoner had been placed in the fore cabin where he remained quiet silent apparently deaf and dumb

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Pencroft offered him something to eat, but he pushed away the cooked meat that was presented to him and which doubtless did not suit him. But on the sailor showing him one of the ducks which Herbert had killed, he pounced on it like a wild beast, and devoured it greedily.
children.prevalue: Pencroft offered him something to eat but he pushed away the cooked meat that was presented to him and which doubtless did not suit him But on the sailor showing him one of the ducks which Herbert had killed he pounced on it like a wild beast and devoured it greedily

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: You think that he will recover his senses? asked Pencroft. It is not impossible that our care will have an effect upon him, for it is solitude that has made him what he is, and from this time forward he will be no longer alone.
children.prevalue: You think that he will recover his senses asked Pencroft It is not impossible that our care will have an effect upon him for it is solitude that has made him what he is and from this time forward he will be no longer alone

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The poor man must no doubt have been in this state for a long time, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: The poor man must no doubt have been in this state for a long time said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Perhaps, answered Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Perhaps answered Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: About what age is he? asked the lad.
children.prevalue: About what age is he asked the lad

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: It is difficult to say, replied the reporter, for it is impossible to see his features under the thick beard which covers his face, but he is no longer young, and I suppose he might be about fifty.
children.prevalue: It is difficult to say replied the reporter for it is impossible to see his features under the thick beard which covers his face but he is no longer young and I suppose he might be about fifty

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Have you noticed, Mr. Spilett, how deeply sunk his eyes are? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: Have you noticed Mr Spilett how deeply sunk his eyes are asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, Herbert, but I must add that they are more human than one could expect from his appearance.
children.prevalue: Yes Herbert but I must add that they are more human than one could expect from his appearance

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: However, we shall see, replied Pencroft, and I am anxious to know what opinion Captain Harding will have of our savage. We went to look for a human creature, and we are bringing back a monster! After all, we did what we could.
children.prevalue: However we shall see replied Pencroft and I am anxious to know what opinion Captain Harding will have of our savage We went to look for a human creature and we are bringing back a monster After all we did what we could

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The night passed, and whether the prisoner slept or not could not be known, but at any rate, although he had been unbound, he did not move. He was like a wild animal, which appears stunned at first by its capture, and becomes wild again afterwards.
children.prevalue: The night passed and whether the prisoner slept or not could not be known but at any rate although he had been unbound he did not move He was like a wild animal which appears stunned at first by its capture and becomes wild again afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: At daybreak the next morning, the 15th of October, the change of weather predicted by Pencroft occurred. The wind having shifted to the northwest favored the return of the Bonadventure, but at the same time it freshened, which might render navigation more difficult.
children.prevalue: At daybreak the next morning the 15th of October the change of weather predicted by Pencroft occurred The wind having shifted to the northwest favored the return of the Bonadventure but at the same time it freshened which might render navigation more difficult

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: At five o'clock in the morning the anchor was weighed. Pencroft took a reef in the mainsail, and steered towards the north-east, so as to sail straight for Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: At five o clock in the morning the anchor was weighed Pencroft took a reef in the mainsail and steered towards the north east so as to sail straight for Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: The first day of the voyage was not marked by any incident. The prisoner remained quiet in the fore-cabin, and as he had been a sailor it appeared that the motion of the vessel might produce on him a salutary reaction. Did some recollection of his former calling return to him? However that might be, he remained tranquil, astonished rather than depressed.
children.prevalue: The first day of the voyage was not marked by any incident The prisoner remained quiet in the fore cabin and as he had been a sailor it appeared that the motion of the vessel might produce on him a salutary reaction Did some recollection of his former calling return to him However that might be he remained tranquil astonished rather than depressed

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The next day the wind increased, blowing more from the north, consequently in a less favorable direction for the Bonadventure. Pencroft was soon obliged to sail close-hauled, and without saying anything about it he began to be uneasy at the state of the sea, which frequently broke over the bows. Certainly, if the wind did not moderate, it would take a longer time to reach Lincoln Island than it had taken to make Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: The next day the wind increased blowing more from the north consequently in a less favorable direction for the Bonadventure Pencroft was soon obliged to sail close hauled and without saying anything about it he began to be uneasy at the state of the sea which frequently broke over the bows Certainly if the wind did not moderate it would take a longer time to reach Lincoln Island than it had taken to make Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Indeed, on the morning of the 17th, the Bonadventure had been forty-eight hours at sea, and nothing showed that she was near the island. It was impossible, besides, to estimate the distance traversed, or to trust to the reckoning for the direction, as the speed had been very irregular.
children.prevalue: Indeed on the morning of the 17th the Bonadventure had been forty eight hours at sea and nothing showed that she was near the island It was impossible besides to estimate the distance traversed or to trust to the reckoning for the direction as the speed had been very irregular

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Twenty-four hours after there was yet no land in sight. The wind was right ahead and the sea very heavy. The sails were close-reefed, and they tacked frequently. On the 18th, a wave swept completely over the Bonadventure; and if the crew had not taken the precaution of lashing themselves to the deck, they would have been carried away.
children.prevalue: Twenty four hours after there was yet no land in sight The wind was right ahead and the sea very heavy The sails were close reefed and they tacked frequently On the 18th a wave swept completely over the Bonadventure and if the crew had not taken the precaution of lashing themselves to the deck they would have been carried away

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: On this occasion Pencroft and his companions, who were occupied with loosing themselves, received unexpected aid from the prisoner, who emerged from the hatchway as if his sailor's instinct had suddenly returned, broke a piece out of the bulwarks with a spar so as to let the water which filled the deck escape. Then the vessel being clear, he descended to his cabin without having uttered a word. Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, greatly astonished, let him proceed.
children.prevalue: On this occasion Pencroft and his companions who were occupied with loosing themselves received unexpected aid from the prisoner who emerged from the hatchway as if his sailor s instinct had suddenly returned broke a piece out of the bulwarks with a spar so as to let the water which filled the deck escape Then the vessel being clear he descended to his cabin without having uttered a word Pencroft Gideon Spilett and Herbert greatly astonished let him proceed

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Their situation was truly serious, and the sailor had reason to fear that he was lost on the wide sea without any possibility of recovering his course.
children.prevalue: Their situation was truly serious and the sailor had reason to fear that he was lost on the wide sea without any possibility of recovering his course

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The night was dark and cold. However, about eleven o'clock, the wind fell, the sea went down, and the speed of the vessel, as she labored less, greatly increased.
children.prevalue: The night was dark and cold However about eleven o clock the wind fell the sea went down and the speed of the vessel as she labored less greatly increased

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Neither Pencroft, Spilett, nor Herbert thought of taking an hour's sleep. They kept a sharp look-out, for either Lincoln Island could not be far distant and would be sighted at daybreak, or the Bonadventure, carried away by currents, had drifted so much that it would be impossible to rectify her course. Pencroft, uneasy to the last degree, yet did not despair, for he had a gallant heart, and grasping the tiller he anxiously endeavored to pierce the darkness which surrounded them.
children.prevalue: Neither Pencroft Spilett nor Herbert thought of taking an hour s sleep They kept a sharp look out for either Lincoln Island could not be far distant and would be sighted at daybreak or the Bonadventure carried away by currents had drifted so much that it would be impossible to rectify her course Pencroft uneasy to the last degree yet did not despair for he had a gallant heart and grasping the tiller he anxiously endeavored to pierce the darkness which surrounded them

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: About two o'clock in the morning he started forward,--
children.prevalue: About two o clock in the morning he started forward

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: A light! a light! he shouted.
children.prevalue: A light a light he shouted

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Indeed, a bright light appeared twenty miles to the northeast. Lincoln Island was there, and this fire, evidently lighted by Cyrus Harding, showed them the course to be followed. Pencroft, who was bearing too much to the north, altered his course and steered towards the fire, which burned brightly above the horizon like a star of the first magnitude.
children.prevalue: Indeed a bright light appeared twenty miles to the northeast Lincoln Island was there and this fire evidently lighted by Cyrus Harding showed them the course to be followed Pencroft who was bearing too much to the north altered his course and steered towards the fire which burned brightly above the horizon like a star of the first magnitude

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next day, the 20th of October, at seven o'clock in the morning, after a voyage of four days, the Bonadventure gently glided up to the beach at the mouth of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: The next day the 20th of October at seven o clock in the morning after a voyage of four days the Bonadventure gently glided up to the beach at the mouth of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Neb, who had become very uneasy at the bad weather and the prolonged absence of their companions, had climbed at daybreak to the plateau of Prospect Heights, and they had at last caught sight of the vessel which had been so long in returning.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Neb who had become very uneasy at the bad weather and the prolonged absence of their companions had climbed at daybreak to the plateau of Prospect Heights and they had at last caught sight of the vessel which had been so long in returning

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: God be praised! there they are! exclaimed Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: God be praised there they are exclaimed Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As to Neb in his joy, he began to dance, to twirl round, clapping his hands and shouting, Oh! my master! A more touching pantomime than the finest discourse.
children.prevalue: As to Neb in his joy he began to dance to twirl round clapping his hands and shouting Oh my master A more touching pantomime than the finest discourse

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The engineer's first idea, on counting the people on the deck of the Bonadventure, was that Pencroft had not found the castaway of Tabor Island, or at any rate that the unfortunate man had refused to leave his island and change one prison for another.
children.prevalue: The engineer s first idea on counting the people on the deck of the Bonadventure was that Pencroft had not found the castaway of Tabor Island or at any rate that the unfortunate man had refused to leave his island and change one prison for another

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Indeed Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert were alone on the deck of the Bonadventure.
children.prevalue: Indeed Pencroft Gideon Spilett and Herbert were alone on the deck of the Bonadventure

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The moment the vessel touched, the engineer and Neb were waiting on the beach, and before the passengers had time to leap on to the sand, Harding said: We have been very uneasy at your delay, my friends! Did you meet with any accident?
children.prevalue: The moment the vessel touched the engineer and Neb were waiting on the beach and before the passengers had time to leap on to the sand Harding said We have been very uneasy at your delay my friends Did you meet with any accident

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: No, replied Gideon Spilett; on the contrary, everything went wonderfully well. We will tell you all about it.
children.prevalue: No replied Gideon Spilett on the contrary everything went wonderfully well We will tell you all about it

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: However, returned the engineer, your search has been unsuccessful, since you are only three, just as you went!
children.prevalue: However returned the engineer your search has been unsuccessful since you are only three just as you went

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Excuse me, captain, replied the sailor, we are four.
children.prevalue: Excuse me captain replied the sailor we are four

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You have found the castaway?
children.prevalue: You have found the castaway

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And you have brought him?
children.prevalue: And you have brought him

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Living?
children.prevalue: Living

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Where is he? Who is he?
children.prevalue: Where is he Who is he

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: He is, replied the reporter, or rather he was a man! There, Cyrus, that is all we can tell you!
children.prevalue: He is replied the reporter or rather he was a man There Cyrus that is all we can tell you

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The engineer was then informed of all that had passed during the voyage, and under what conditions the search had been conducted; how the only dwelling in the island had long been abandoned; how at last a castaway had been captured, who appeared no longer to belong to the human species.
children.prevalue: The engineer was then informed of all that had passed during the voyage and under what conditions the search had been conducted how the only dwelling in the island had long been abandoned how at last a castaway had been captured who appeared no longer to belong to the human species

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: And that's just the point, added Pencroft, I don't know if we have done right to bring him here.
children.prevalue: And that s just the point added Pencroft I don t know if we have done right to bring him here

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Certainly you have, Pencroft, replied the engineer quickly.
children.prevalue: Certainly you have Pencroft replied the engineer quickly

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But the wretched creature has no sense!
children.prevalue: But the wretched creature has no sense

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: That is possible at present, replied Cyrus Harding, but only a few months ago the wretched creature was a man like you and me. And who knows what will become of the survivor of us after a long solitude on this island? It is a great misfortune to be alone, my friends; and it must be believed that solitude can quickly destroy reason, since you have found this poor creature in such a state!
children.prevalue: That is possible at present replied Cyrus Harding but only a few months ago the wretched creature was a man like you and me And who knows what will become of the survivor of us after a long solitude on this island It is a great misfortune to be alone my friends and it must be believed that solitude can quickly destroy reason since you have found this poor creature in such a state

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But, captain, asked Herbert, what leads you to think that the brutishness of the unfortunate man began only a few months back?
children.prevalue: But captain asked Herbert what leads you to think that the brutishness of the unfortunate man began only a few months back

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Because the document we found had been recently written, answered the engineer, and the castaway alone can have written it.
children.prevalue: Because the document we found had been recently written answered the engineer and the castaway alone can have written it

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Always supposing, observed Gideon Spilett, that it had not been written by a companion of this man, since dead.
children.prevalue: Always supposing observed Gideon Spilett that it had not been written by a companion of this man since dead

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: That is impossible, my dear Spilett.
children.prevalue: That is impossible my dear Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Why so? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: Why so asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Because the document would then have spoken of two castaways, replied Harding, and it mentioned only one.
children.prevalue: Because the document would then have spoken of two castaways replied Harding and it mentioned only one

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Herbert then in a few words related the incidents of the voyage, and dwelt on the curious fact of the sort of passing gleam in the prisoner's mind, when for an instant in the height of the storm he had become a sailor.
children.prevalue: Herbert then in a few words related the incidents of the voyage and dwelt on the curious fact of the sort of passing gleam in the prisoner s mind when for an instant in the height of the storm he had become a sailor

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well, Herbert, replied the engineer, you are right to attach great importance to this fact. The unfortunate man cannot be incurable, and despair has made him what he is; but here he will find his fellow-men, and since there is still a soul in him, this soul we shall save!
children.prevalue: Well Herbert replied the engineer you are right to attach great importance to this fact The unfortunate man cannot be incurable and despair has made him what he is but here he will find his fellow men and since there is still a soul in him this soul we shall save

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The castaway of Tabor Island, to the great pity of the engineer and the great astonishment of Neb, was then brought from the cabin which he occupied in the fore part of the Bonadventure; when once on land he manifested a wish to run away.
children.prevalue: The castaway of Tabor Island to the great pity of the engineer and the great astonishment of Neb was then brought from the cabin which he occupied in the fore part of the Bonadventure when once on land he manifested a wish to run away

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But Cyrus Harding approaching, placed his hand on his shoulder with a gesture full of authority, and looked at him with infinite tenderness. Immediately the unhappy man, submitting to a superior will, gradually became calm, his eyes fell, his head bent, and he made no more resistance.
children.prevalue: But Cyrus Harding approaching placed his hand on his shoulder with a gesture full of authority and looked at him with infinite tenderness Immediately the unhappy man submitting to a superior will gradually became calm his eyes fell his head bent and he made no more resistance

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Poor fellow! murmured the engineer.
children.prevalue: Poor fellow murmured the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Cyrus Harding had attentively observed him. To judge by his appearance this miserable being had no longer anything human about him, and yet Harding, as had the reporter already, observed in his look an indefinable trace of intelligence.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding had attentively observed him To judge by his appearance this miserable being had no longer anything human about him and yet Harding as had the reporter already observed in his look an indefinable trace of intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: It was decided that the castaway, or rather the stranger as he was thenceforth termed by his companions, should live in one of the rooms of Granite House, from which, however, he could not escape. He was led there without difficulty, and with careful attention, it might, perhaps, be hoped that some day he would be a companion to the settlers in Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: It was decided that the castaway or rather the stranger as he was thenceforth termed by his companions should live in one of the rooms of Granite House from which however he could not escape He was led there without difficulty and with careful attention it might perhaps be hoped that some day he would be a companion to the settlers in Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Cyrus Harding, during breakfast, which Neb had hastened to prepare, as the reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft were dying of hunger, heard in detail all the incidents which had marked the voyage of exploration to the islet. He agreed with his friends on this point, that the stranger must be either English or American, the name Britannia leading them to suppose this, and, besides, through the bushy beard, and under the shaggy, matted hair, the engineer thought he could recognize the characteristic features of the Anglo-Saxon.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding during breakfast which Neb had hastened to prepare as the reporter Herbert and Pencroft were dying of hunger heard in detail all the incidents which had marked the voyage of exploration to the islet He agreed with his friends on this point that the stranger must be either English or American the name Britannia leading them to suppose this and besides through the bushy beard and under the shaggy matted hair the engineer thought he could recognize the characteristic features of the Anglo Saxon

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: But, by the bye, said Gideon Spilett, addressing Herbert, you never told us how you met this savage, and we know nothing, except that you would have been strangled, if we had not happened to come up in time to help you!
children.prevalue: But by the bye said Gideon Spilett addressing Herbert you never told us how you met this savage and we know nothing except that you would have been strangled if we had not happened to come up in time to help you

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Upon my word, answered Herbert, it is rather difficult to say how it happened. I was, I think, occupied in collecting my plants, when I heard a noise like an avalanche falling from a very tall tree. I scarcely had time to look round. This unfortunate man, who was without doubt concealed in a tree, rushed upon me in less time than I take to tell you about it, and unless Mr. Spilett and Pencroft--
children.prevalue: Upon my word answered Herbert it is rather difficult to say how it happened I was I think occupied in collecting my plants when I heard a noise like an avalanche falling from a very tall tree I scarcely had time to look round This unfortunate man who was without doubt concealed in a tree rushed upon me in less time than I take to tell you about it and unless Mr Spilett and Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: My boy! said Cyrus Harding, you ran a great danger, but, perhaps, without that, the poor creature would have still hidden himself from your search, and we should not have had a new companion.
children.prevalue: My boy said Cyrus Harding you ran a great danger but perhaps without that the poor creature would have still hidden himself from your search and we should not have had a new companion

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: You hope, then, Cyrus, to succeed in reforming the man? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: You hope then Cyrus to succeed in reforming the man asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Yes, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Breakfast over, Harding and his companions left Granite House and returned to the beach. They there occupied themselves in unloading the Bonadventure, and the engineer, having examined the arms and tools, saw nothing which could help them to establish the identity of the stranger.
children.prevalue: Breakfast over Harding and his companions left Granite House and returned to the beach They there occupied themselves in unloading the Bonadventure and the engineer having examined the arms and tools saw nothing which could help them to establish the identity of the stranger

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The capture of pigs, made on the islet, was looked upon as being very profitable to Lincoln Island, and the animals were led to the sty, where they soon became at home.
children.prevalue: The capture of pigs made on the islet was looked upon as being very profitable to Lincoln Island and the animals were led to the sty where they soon became at home

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The two barrels, containing the powder and shot, as well as the box of caps, were very welcome. It was agreed to establish a small powder-magazine, either outside Granite House or in the Upper Cavern, where there would be no fear of explosion. However, the use of pyroxyle was to be continued, for this substance giving excellent results, there was no reason for substituting ordinary powder.
children.prevalue: The two barrels containing the powder and shot as well as the box of caps were very welcome It was agreed to establish a small powder magazine either outside Granite House or in the Upper Cavern where there would be no fear of explosion However the use of pyroxyle was to be continued for this substance giving excellent results there was no reason for substituting ordinary powder

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: When the unloading of the vessel was finished,--
children.prevalue: When the unloading of the vessel was finished

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Captain, said Pencroft, I think it would be prudent to put our 'Bonadventure' in a safe place.
children.prevalue: Captain said Pencroft I think it would be prudent to put our Bonadventure in a safe place

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Is she not safe at the mouth of the Mercy? asked Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Is she not safe at the mouth of the Mercy asked Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, captain, replied the sailor. Half of the time she is stranded on the sand, and that works her. She is a famous craft, you see, and she behaved admirably during the squall which struck us on our return.
children.prevalue: No captain replied the sailor Half of the time she is stranded on the sand and that works her She is a famous craft you see and she behaved admirably during the squall which struck us on our return

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Could she not float in the river?
children.prevalue: Could she not float in the river

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: No doubt, captain, she could; but there is no shelter there, and in the east winds, I think that the 'Bonadventure' would suffer much from the surf.
children.prevalue: No doubt captain she could but there is no shelter there and in the east winds I think that the Bonadventure would suffer much from the surf

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Well, where would you put her, Pencroft?
children.prevalue: Well where would you put her Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: In Port Balloon, replied the sailor. That little creek, shut in by rocks, seems to me to be just the harbor we want.
children.prevalue: In Port Balloon replied the sailor That little creek shut in by rocks seems to me to be just the harbor we want

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Is it not rather far?
children.prevalue: Is it not rather far

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Pooh! it is not more than three miles from Granite House, and we have a fine straight road to take us there!
children.prevalue: Pooh it is not more than three miles from Granite House and we have a fine straight road to take us there

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Do it then, Pencroft, and take your 'Bonadventure' there, replied the engineer, and yet I would rather have her under our more immediate protection. When we have time, we must make a little harbor for her.
children.prevalue: Do it then Pencroft and take your Bonadventure there replied the engineer and yet I would rather have her under our more immediate protection When we have time we must make a little harbor for her

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Famous! exclaimed Pencroft. A harbor with a lighthouse, a pier, and dock! Ah! really with you, captain, everything becomes easy.
children.prevalue: Famous exclaimed Pencroft A harbor with a lighthouse a pier and dock Ah really with you captain everything becomes easy

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Yes, my brave Pencroft, answered the engineer, but on condition, however, that you help me, for you do as much as three men in all our work.
children.prevalue: Yes my brave Pencroft answered the engineer but on condition however that you help me for you do as much as three men in all our work

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Herbert and the sailor then re-embarked on board the Bonadventure, the anchor was weighed, the sail hoisted, and the wind drove her rapidly towards Claw Cape. Two hours after, she was reposing on the tranquil waters of Port Balloon.
children.prevalue: Herbert and the sailor then re embarked on board the Bonadventure the anchor was weighed the sail hoisted and the wind drove her rapidly towards Claw Cape Two hours after she was reposing on the tranquil waters of Port Balloon

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: During the first days passed by the stranger in Granite House, had he already given them reason to think that his savage nature was becoming tamed? Did a brighter light burn in the depths of that obscured mind? In short, was the soul returning to the body?
children.prevalue: During the first days passed by the stranger in Granite House had he already given them reason to think that his savage nature was becoming tamed Did a brighter light burn in the depths of that obscured mind In short was the soul returning to the body

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, to a certainty, and to such a degree, that Cyrus Harding and the reporter wondered if the reason of the unfortunate man had ever been totally extinguished. At first, accustomed to the open air, to the unrestrained liberty which he had enjoyed on Tabor Island, the stranger manifested a sullen fury, and it was feared that he might throw himself onto the beach, out of one of the windows of Granite House. But gradually he became calmer, and more freedom was allowed to his movements.
children.prevalue: Yes to a certainty and to such a degree that Cyrus Harding and the reporter wondered if the reason of the unfortunate man had ever been totally extinguished At first accustomed to the open air to the unrestrained liberty which he had enjoyed on Tabor Island the stranger manifested a sullen fury and it was feared that he might throw himself onto the beach out of one of the windows of Granite House But gradually he became calmer and more freedom was allowed to his movements

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: They had reason to hope, and to hope much. Already, forgetting his carnivorous instincts, the stranger accepted a less bestial nourishment than that on which he fed on the islet, and cooked meat did not produce in him the same sentiment of repulsion which he had showed on board the Bonadventure. Cyrus Harding had profited by a moment when he was sleeping, to cut his hair and matted beard, which formed a sort of mane and gave him such a savage aspect. He had also been clothed more suitably, after having got rid of the rag which covered him. The result was that, thanks to these attentions, the stranger resumed a more human appearance, and it even seemed as if his eyes had become milder. Certainly, when formerly lighted up by intelligence, this man's face must have had a sort of beauty.
children.prevalue: They had reason to hope and to hope much Already forgetting his carnivorous instincts the stranger accepted a less bestial nourishment than that on which he fed on the islet and cooked meat did not produce in him the same sentiment of repulsion which he had showed on board the Bonadventure Cyrus Harding had profited by a moment when he was sleeping to cut his hair and matted beard which formed a sort of mane and gave him such a savage aspect He had also been clothed more suitably after having got rid of the rag which covered him The result was that thanks to these attentions the stranger resumed a more human appearance and it even seemed as if his eyes had become milder Certainly when formerly lighted up by intelligence this man s face must have had a sort of beauty

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Every day, Harding imposed on himself the task of passing some hours in his company. He came and worked near him, and occupied himself in different things, so as to fix his attention. A spark, indeed, would be sufficient to reillumine that soul, a recollection crossing that brain to recall reason. That had been seen, during the storm, on board the Bonadventure! The engineer did not neglect either to speak aloud, so as to penetrate at the same time by the organs of hearing and sight the depths of that torpid intelligence. Sometimes one of his companions, sometimes another, sometimes all joined him. They spoke most often of things belonging to the navy, which must interest a sailor.
children.prevalue: Every day Harding imposed on himself the task of passing some hours in his company He came and worked near him and occupied himself in different things so as to fix his attention A spark indeed would be sufficient to reillumine that soul a recollection crossing that brain to recall reason That had been seen during the storm on board the Bonadventure The engineer did not neglect either to speak aloud so as to penetrate at the same time by the organs of hearing and sight the depths of that torpid intelligence Sometimes one of his companions sometimes another sometimes all joined him They spoke most often of things belonging to the navy which must interest a sailor

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: At times, the stranger gave some slight attention to what was said, and the settlers were soon convinced that he partly understood them. Sometimes the expression of his countenance was deeply sorrowful, a proof that he suffered mentally, for his face could not be mistaken; but he did not speak, although at different times, however, they almost thought that words were about to issue from his lips. At all events, the poor creature was quite quiet and sad!
children.prevalue: At times the stranger gave some slight attention to what was said and the settlers were soon convinced that he partly understood them Sometimes the expression of his countenance was deeply sorrowful a proof that he suffered mentally for his face could not be mistaken but he did not speak although at different times however they almost thought that words were about to issue from his lips At all events the poor creature was quite quiet and sad

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: But was not his calm only apparent? Was not his sadness only the result of his seclusion? Nothing could yet be ascertained. Seeing only certain objects and in a limited space, always in contact with the colonists, to whom he would soon become accustomed, having no desires to satisfy, better fed, better clothed, it was natural that his physical nature should gradually improve; but was he penetrated with the sense of a new life? or rather, to employ a word which would be exactly applicable to him, was he not becoming tamed, like an animal in company with his master? This was an important question, which Cyrus Harding was anxious to answer, and yet he did not wish to treat his invalid roughly! Would he ever be a convalescent?
children.prevalue: But was not his calm only apparent Was not his sadness only the result of his seclusion Nothing could yet be ascertained Seeing only certain objects and in a limited space always in contact with the colonists to whom he would soon become accustomed having no desires to satisfy better fed better clothed it was natural that his physical nature should gradually improve but was he penetrated with the sense of a new life or rather to employ a word which would be exactly applicable to him was he not becoming tamed like an animal in company with his master This was an important question which Cyrus Harding was anxious to answer and yet he did not wish to treat his invalid roughly Would he ever be a convalescent

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: How the engineer observed him every moment! How he was on the watch for his soul, if one may use the expression! How he was ready to grasp it! The settlers followed with real sympathy all the phases of the cure undertaken by Harding. They aided him also in this work of humanity, and all, except perhaps the incredulous Pencroft, soon shared both his hope and his faith.
children.prevalue: How the engineer observed him every moment How he was on the watch for his soul if one may use the expression How he was ready to grasp it The settlers followed with real sympathy all the phases of the cure undertaken by Harding They aided him also in this work of humanity and all except perhaps the incredulous Pencroft soon shared both his hope and his faith

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The calm of the stranger was deep, as has been said, and he even showed a sort of attachment for the engineer, whose influence he evidently felt. Cyrus Harding resolved then to try him, by transporting him to another scene, from that ocean which formerly his eyes had been accustomed to contemplate, to the border of the forest, which might perhaps recall those where so many years of his life had been passed!
children.prevalue: The calm of the stranger was deep as has been said and he even showed a sort of attachment for the engineer whose influence he evidently felt Cyrus Harding resolved then to try him by transporting him to another scene from that ocean which formerly his eyes had been accustomed to contemplate to the border of the forest which might perhaps recall those where so many years of his life had been passed

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: But, said Gideon Spilett, can we hope that he will not escape, if once set at liberty?
children.prevalue: But said Gideon Spilett can we hope that he will not escape if once set at liberty

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The experiment must be tried, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: The experiment must be tried replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well! said Pencroft. When that fellow is outside, and feels the fresh air, he will be off as fast as his legs can carry him!
children.prevalue: Well said Pencroft When that fellow is outside and feels the fresh air he will be off as fast as his legs can carry him

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I do not think so, returned Harding.
children.prevalue: I do not think so returned Harding

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Let us try, said Spilett.
children.prevalue: Let us try said Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: We will try, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: We will try replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: This was on the 30th of October, and consequently the castaway of Tabor Island had been a prisoner in Granite House for nine days. It was warm, and a bright sun darted its rays on the island. Cyrus Harding and Pencroft went to the room occupied by the stranger, who was found lying near the window and gazing at the sky.
children.prevalue: This was on the 30th of October and consequently the castaway of Tabor Island had been a prisoner in Granite House for nine days It was warm and a bright sun darted its rays on the island Cyrus Harding and Pencroft went to the room occupied by the stranger who was found lying near the window and gazing at the sky

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Come, my friend, said the engineer to him.
children.prevalue: Come my friend said the engineer to him

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The stranger rose immediately. His eyes were fixed on Cyrus Harding, and he followed him, while the sailor marched behind them, little confident as to the result of the experiment.
children.prevalue: The stranger rose immediately His eyes were fixed on Cyrus Harding and he followed him while the sailor marched behind them little confident as to the result of the experiment

children.name: Paragraph_77
