children.value: Arrived at the door, Harding and Pencroft made him take his place in the lift, while Neb, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett waited for them before Granite House. The lift descended, and in a few moments all were united on the beach.
children.prevalue: Arrived at the door Harding and Pencroft made him take his place in the lift while Neb Herbert and Gideon Spilett waited for them before Granite House The lift descended and in a few moments all were united on the beach

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The settlers went a short distance from the stranger, so as to leave him at liberty.
children.prevalue: The settlers went a short distance from the stranger so as to leave him at liberty

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: He then made a few steps toward the sea, and his look brightened with extreme animation, but he did not make the slightest attempt to escape. He was gazing at the little waves which, broken by the islet, rippled on the sand.
children.prevalue: He then made a few steps toward the sea and his look brightened with extreme animation but he did not make the slightest attempt to escape He was gazing at the little waves which broken by the islet rippled on the sand

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: This is only the sea, observed Gideon Spilett, and possibly it does not inspire him with any wish to escape!
children.prevalue: This is only the sea observed Gideon Spilett and possibly it does not inspire him with any wish to escape

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Yes, replied Harding, we must take him to the plateau, on the border of the forest. There the experiment will be more conclusive.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Harding we must take him to the plateau on the border of the forest There the experiment will be more conclusive

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Besides, he could not run away, said Neb, since the bridge is raised.
children.prevalue: Besides he could not run away said Neb since the bridge is raised

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh! said Pencroft, that isn't a man to be troubled by a stream like Creek Glycerine! He could cross it directly, at a single bound!
children.prevalue: Oh said Pencroft that isn t a man to be troubled by a stream like Creek Glycerine He could cross it directly at a single bound

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: We shall soon see, Harding contented himself with replying, his eyes not quitting those of his patient.
children.prevalue: We shall soon see Harding contented himself with replying his eyes not quitting those of his patient

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The latter was then led towards the mouth of the Mercy, and all climbing the left bank of the river, reached Prospect Heights.
children.prevalue: The latter was then led towards the mouth of the Mercy and all climbing the left bank of the river reached Prospect Heights

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Arrived at the spot on which grew the first beautiful trees of the forest, their foliage slightly agitated by the breeze, the stranger appeared greedily to drink in the penetrating odor which filled the atmosphere, and a long sigh escaped from his chest.
children.prevalue: Arrived at the spot on which grew the first beautiful trees of the forest their foliage slightly agitated by the breeze the stranger appeared greedily to drink in the penetrating odor which filled the atmosphere and a long sigh escaped from his chest

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The settlers kept behind him, ready to seize him if he made any movement to escape!
children.prevalue: The settlers kept behind him ready to seize him if he made any movement to escape

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And, indeed, the poor creature was on the point of springing into the creek which separated him from the forest, and his legs were bent for an instant as if for a spring, but almost immediately he stepped back, half sank down, and a large tear fell from his eyes.
children.prevalue: And indeed the poor creature was on the point of springing into the creek which separated him from the forest and his legs were bent for an instant as if for a spring but almost immediately he stepped back half sank down and a large tear fell from his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Ah! exclaimed Cyrus Harding, you have become a man again, for you can weep!
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed Cyrus Harding you have become a man again for you can weep

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Yes! the unfortunate man had wept! Some recollection doubtless had flashed across his brain, and to use Cyrus Harding's expression, by those tears he was once more a man.
children.prevalue: Yes the unfortunate man had wept Some recollection doubtless had flashed across his brain and to use Cyrus Harding s expression by those tears he was once more a man

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The colonists left him for some time on the plateau, and withdrew themselves to a short distance, so that he might feel himself free; but he did not think of profiting by this liberty, and Harding soon brought him back to Granite House. Two days after this occurrence, the stranger appeared to wish gradually to mingle with their common life. He evidently heard and understood, but no less evidently was he strangely determined not to speak to the colonists; for one evening, Pencroft, listening at the door of his room, heard these words escape from his lips:--
children.prevalue: The colonists left him for some time on the plateau and withdrew themselves to a short distance so that he might feel himself free but he did not think of profiting by this liberty and Harding soon brought him back to Granite House Two days after this occurrence the stranger appeared to wish gradually to mingle with their common life He evidently heard and understood but no less evidently was he strangely determined not to speak to the colonists for one evening Pencroft listening at the door of his room heard these words escape from his lips

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: No! here! I! never!
children.prevalue: No here I never

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The sailor reported these words to his companions.
children.prevalue: The sailor reported these words to his companions

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: There is some painful mystery there! said Harding.
children.prevalue: There is some painful mystery there said Harding

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The stranger had begun to use the laboring tools, and he worked in the garden. When he stopped in his work, as was often the case, he remained retired within himself, but on the engineer's recommendation, they respected the reserve which he apparently wished to keep. If one of the settlers approached him, he drew back, and his chest heaved with sobs, as if overburdened!
children.prevalue: The stranger had begun to use the laboring tools and he worked in the garden When he stopped in his work as was often the case he remained retired within himself but on the engineer s recommendation they respected the reserve which he apparently wished to keep If one of the settlers approached him he drew back and his chest heaved with sobs as if overburdened

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Was it remorse that overwhelmed him thus? They were compelled to believe so, and Gideon Spilett could not help one day making this observation,--
children.prevalue: Was it remorse that overwhelmed him thus They were compelled to believe so and Gideon Spilett could not help one day making this observation

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: If he does not speak it is because he has, I fear, things too serious to be told!
children.prevalue: If he does not speak it is because he has I fear things too serious to be told

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: They must be patient and wait.
children.prevalue: They must be patient and wait

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: A few days later, on the 3rd of November, the stranger, working on the plateau, had stopped, letting his spade drop to the ground, and Harding, who was observing him from a little distance, saw that tears were again flowing from his eyes. A sort of irresistible pity led him towards the unfortunate man, and he touched his arm lightly.
children.prevalue: A few days later on the 3rd of November the stranger working on the plateau had stopped letting his spade drop to the ground and Harding who was observing him from a little distance saw that tears were again flowing from his eyes A sort of irresistible pity led him towards the unfortunate man and he touched his arm lightly

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: My friend! said he.
children.prevalue: My friend said he

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The stranger tried to avoid his look, and Cyrus Harding having endeavored to take his hand, he drew back quickly.
children.prevalue: The stranger tried to avoid his look and Cyrus Harding having endeavored to take his hand he drew back quickly

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: My friend, said Harding in a firmer voice, look at me, I wish it!
children.prevalue: My friend said Harding in a firmer voice look at me I wish it

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The stranger looked at the engineer, and seemed to be under his power, as a subject under the influence of a mesmerist. He wished to run away. But then his countenance suddenly underwent a transformation. His eyes flashed. Words struggled to escape from his lips. He could no longer contain himself! At last he folded his arms; then, in a hollow voice,--Who are you? he asked Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: The stranger looked at the engineer and seemed to be under his power as a subject under the influence of a mesmerist He wished to run away But then his countenance suddenly underwent a transformation His eyes flashed Words struggled to escape from his lips He could no longer contain himself At last he folded his arms then in a hollow voice Who are you he asked Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Castaways, like you, replied the engineer, whose emotion was deep. We have brought you here, among your fellow-men.
children.prevalue: Castaways like you replied the engineer whose emotion was deep We have brought you here among your fellow men

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: My fellow-men!.... I have none!
children.prevalue: My fellow men I have none

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You are in the midst of friends.
children.prevalue: You are in the midst of friends

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Friends!--for me! friends! exclaimed the stranger, hiding his face in his hands. No--never--leave me! leave me!
children.prevalue: Friends for me friends exclaimed the stranger hiding his face in his hands No never leave me leave me

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Then he rushed to the side of the plateau which overlooked the sea, and remained there a long time motionless.
children.prevalue: Then he rushed to the side of the plateau which overlooked the sea and remained there a long time motionless

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Harding rejoined his companions and related to them what had just happened.
children.prevalue: Harding rejoined his companions and related to them what had just happened

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes! there is some mystery in that man's life, said Gideon Spilett, and it appears as if he had only re-entered society by the path of remorse.
children.prevalue: Yes there is some mystery in that man s life said Gideon Spilett and it appears as if he had only re entered society by the path of remorse

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I don't know what sort of a man we have brought here, said the sailor. He has secrets--
children.prevalue: I don t know what sort of a man we have brought here said the sailor He has secrets

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Which we will respect, interrupted Cyrus Harding quickly. If he has committed any crime, he has most fearfully expiated it, and in our eyes he is absolved.
children.prevalue: Which we will respect interrupted Cyrus Harding quickly If he has committed any crime he has most fearfully expiated it and in our eyes he is absolved

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: For two hours the stranger remained alone on the shore, evidently under the influence of recollections which recalled all his past life--a melancholy life doubtless--and the colonists, without losing sight of him, did not attempt to disturb his solitude. However, after two hours, appearing to have formed a resolution, he came to find Cyrus Harding. His eyes were red with the tears he had shed, but he wept no longer. His countenance expressed deep humility. He appeared anxious, timorous, ashamed, and his eyes were constantly fixed on the ground.
children.prevalue: For two hours the stranger remained alone on the shore evidently under the influence of recollections which recalled all his past life a melancholy life doubtless and the colonists without losing sight of him did not attempt to disturb his solitude However after two hours appearing to have formed a resolution he came to find Cyrus Harding His eyes were red with the tears he had shed but he wept no longer His countenance expressed deep humility He appeared anxious timorous ashamed and his eyes were constantly fixed on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Sir, said he to Harding, your companions and you, are you English?
children.prevalue: Sir said he to Harding your companions and you are you English

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No, answered the engineer, we are Americans.
children.prevalue: No answered the engineer we are Americans

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Ah! said the stranger, and he murmured, I prefer that!
children.prevalue: Ah said the stranger and he murmured I prefer that

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And you, my friend? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: And you my friend asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: English, replied he hastily.
children.prevalue: English replied he hastily

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And as if these few words had been difficult to say, he retreated to the beach, where he walked up and down between the cascade and the mouth of the Mercy, in a state of extreme agitation.
children.prevalue: And as if these few words had been difficult to say he retreated to the beach where he walked up and down between the cascade and the mouth of the Mercy in a state of extreme agitation

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Then, passing one moment close to Herbert, he stopped and in a stifled voice,--
children.prevalue: Then passing one moment close to Herbert he stopped and in a stifled voice

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: What month? he asked.
children.prevalue: What month he asked

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: December, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: December replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What year?
children.prevalue: What year

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Twelve years! twelve years! he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: Twelve years twelve years he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Then he left him abruptly.
children.prevalue: Then he left him abruptly

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Herbert reported to the colonists the questions and answers which had been made.
children.prevalue: Herbert reported to the colonists the questions and answers which had been made

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: This unfortunate man, observed Gideon Spilett, was no longer acquainted with either months or years!
children.prevalue: This unfortunate man observed Gideon Spilett was no longer acquainted with either months or years

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes! added Herbert, and he had been twelve years already on the islet when we found him there!
children.prevalue: Yes added Herbert and he had been twelve years already on the islet when we found him there

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Twelve years! rejoined Harding. Ah! twelve years of solitude, after a wicked life, perhaps, may well impair a man's reason!
children.prevalue: Twelve years rejoined Harding Ah twelve years of solitude after a wicked life perhaps may well impair a man s reason

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I am induced to think, said Pencroft, that this man was not wrecked on Tabor Island, but that in consequence of some crime he was left there.
children.prevalue: I am induced to think said Pencroft that this man was not wrecked on Tabor Island but that in consequence of some crime he was left there

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: You must be right, Pencroft, replied the reporter, and if it is so it is not impossible that those who left him on the island may return to fetch him some day!
children.prevalue: You must be right Pencroft replied the reporter and if it is so it is not impossible that those who left him on the island may return to fetch him some day

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And they will no longer find him, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: And they will no longer find him said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: But then, added Pencroft, they must return, and--
children.prevalue: But then added Pencroft they must return and

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: My friends, said Cyrus Harding, do not let us discuss this question until we know more about it. I believe that the unhappy man has suffered, that he has severely expiated his faults, whatever they may have been, and that the wish to unburden himself stifles him. Do not let us press him to tell us his history! He will tell it to us doubtless, and when we know it, we shall see what course it will be best to follow. He alone besides can tell us, if he has more than a hope, a certainty, of returning some day to his country, but I doubt it!
children.prevalue: My friends said Cyrus Harding do not let us discuss this question until we know more about it I believe that the unhappy man has suffered that he has severely expiated his faults whatever they may have been and that the wish to unburden himself stifles him Do not let us press him to tell us his history He will tell it to us doubtless and when we know it we shall see what course it will be best to follow He alone besides can tell us if he has more than a hope a certainty of returning some day to his country but I doubt it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: And why? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: And why asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Because that, in the event of his being sure of being delivered at a certain time, he would have waited the hour of his deliverance and would not have thrown this document into the sea. No, it is more probable that he was condemned to die on that islet, and that he never expected to see his fellow-creatures again!
children.prevalue: Because that in the event of his being sure of being delivered at a certain time he would have waited the hour of his deliverance and would not have thrown this document into the sea No it is more probable that he was condemned to die on that islet and that he never expected to see his fellow creatures again

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: But, observed the sailor, there is one thing which I cannot explain.
children.prevalue: But observed the sailor there is one thing which I cannot explain

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: If this man had been left for twelve years on Tabor Island, one may well suppose that he had been several years already in the wild state in which we found him!
children.prevalue: If this man had been left for twelve years on Tabor Island one may well suppose that he had been several years already in the wild state in which we found him

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: That is probable, replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: That is probable replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: It must then be many years since he wrote that document!
children.prevalue: It must then be many years since he wrote that document

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: No doubt, and yet the document appears to have been recently written!
children.prevalue: No doubt and yet the document appears to have been recently written

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Besides, how do you know that the bottle which enclosed the document may not have taken several years to come from Tabor Island to Lincoln Island?
children.prevalue: Besides how do you know that the bottle which enclosed the document may not have taken several years to come from Tabor Island to Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: That is not absolutely impossible, replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: That is not absolutely impossible replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Might it not have been a long time already on the coast of the island?
children.prevalue: Might it not have been a long time already on the coast of the island

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: No, answered Pencroft, for it was still floating. We could not even suppose that after it had stayed for any length of time on the shore, it would have been swept off by the sea, for the south coast is all rocks, and it would certainly have been smashed to pieces there!
children.prevalue: No answered Pencroft for it was still floating We could not even suppose that after it had stayed for any length of time on the shore it would have been swept off by the sea for the south coast is all rocks and it would certainly have been smashed to pieces there

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: That is true, rejoined Cyrus Harding thoughtfully.
children.prevalue: That is true rejoined Cyrus Harding thoughtfully

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And then, continued the sailor, if the document was several years old, if it had been shut up in that bottle for several years, it would have been injured by damp. Now, there is nothing of the kind, and it was found in a perfect state of preservation.
children.prevalue: And then continued the sailor if the document was several years old if it had been shut up in that bottle for several years it would have been injured by damp Now there is nothing of the kind and it was found in a perfect state of preservation

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The sailor's reasoning was very just, and pointed out an incomprehensible fact, for the document appeared to have been recently written, when the colonists found it in the bottle. Moreover, it gave the latitude and longitude of Tabor Island correctly, which implied that its author had a more complete knowledge of hydrography than could be expected of a common sailor.
children.prevalue: The sailor s reasoning was very just and pointed out an incomprehensible fact for the document appeared to have been recently written when the colonists found it in the bottle Moreover it gave the latitude and longitude of Tabor Island correctly which implied that its author had a more complete knowledge of hydrography than could be expected of a common sailor

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: There is in this, again, something unaccountable, said the engineer, but we will not urge our companion to speak. When he likes, my friends, then we shall be ready to hear him!
children.prevalue: There is in this again something unaccountable said the engineer but we will not urge our companion to speak When he likes my friends then we shall be ready to hear him

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: During the following days the stranger did not speak a word, and did not once leave the precincts of the plateau. He worked away, without losing a moment, without taking a minute's rest, but always in a retired place. At meal times he never came to Granite House, although invited several times to do so, but contented himself with eating a few raw vegetables. At nightfall he did not return to the room assigned to him, but remained under some clump of trees, or when the weather was bad crouched in some cleft of the rocks. Thus he lived in the same manner as when he had no other shelter than the forests of Tabor Island, and as all persuasion to induce him to improve his life was in vain, the colonists waited patiently. And the time was near, when, as it seemed, almost involuntarily urged by his conscience, a terrible confession escaped him.
children.prevalue: During the following days the stranger did not speak a word and did not once leave the precincts of the plateau He worked away without losing a moment without taking a minute s rest but always in a retired place At meal times he never came to Granite House although invited several times to do so but contented himself with eating a few raw vegetables At nightfall he did not return to the room assigned to him but remained under some clump of trees or when the weather was bad crouched in some cleft of the rocks Thus he lived in the same manner as when he had no other shelter than the forests of Tabor Island and as all persuasion to induce him to improve his life was in vain the colonists waited patiently And the time was near when as it seemed almost involuntarily urged by his conscience a terrible confession escaped him

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: On the 10th of November, about eight o'clock in the evening, as night was coming on, the stranger appeared unexpectedly before the settlers, who were assembled under the veranda. His eyes burned strangely, and he had quite resumed the wild aspect of his worst days.
children.prevalue: On the 10th of November about eight o clock in the evening as night was coming on the stranger appeared unexpectedly before the settlers who were assembled under the veranda His eyes burned strangely and he had quite resumed the wild aspect of his worst days

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions were astounded on seeing that, overcome by some terrible emotion, his teeth chattered like those of a person in a fever. What was the matter with him? Was the sight of his fellow-creatures insupportable to him? Was he weary of this return to a civilized mode of existence? Was he pining for his former savage life? It appeared so, as soon he was heard to express himself in these incoherent sentences:--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions were astounded on seeing that overcome by some terrible emotion his teeth chattered like those of a person in a fever What was the matter with him Was the sight of his fellow creatures insupportable to him Was he weary of this return to a civilized mode of existence Was he pining for his former savage life It appeared so as soon he was heard to express himself in these incoherent sentences

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Why am I here?.... By what right have you dragged me from my islet?.... Do you think there could be any tie between you and me?.... Do you know who I am--what I have done--why I was there--alone? And who told you that I was not abandoned there--that I was not condemned to die there?.... Do you know my past?.... How do you know that I have not stolen, murdered--that I am not a wretch--an accursed being--only fit to live like a wild beast, far from all--speak--do you know it?
children.prevalue: Why am I here By what right have you dragged me from my islet Do you think there could be any tie between you and me Do you know who I am what I have done why I was there alone And who told you that I was not abandoned there that I was not condemned to die there Do you know my past How do you know that I have not stolen murdered that I am not a wretch an accursed being only fit to live like a wild beast far from all speak do you know it

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The colonists listened without interrupting the miserable creature, from whom these broken confessions escaped, as it were, in spite of himself. Harding wishing to calm him, approached him, but he hastily drew back.
children.prevalue: The colonists listened without interrupting the miserable creature from whom these broken confessions escaped as it were in spite of himself Harding wishing to calm him approached him but he hastily drew back

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: No! no! he exclaimed; one word only--am I free?
children.prevalue: No no he exclaimed one word only am I free

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: You are free, answered the engineer.
children.prevalue: You are free answered the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Farewell, then! he cried, and fled like a madman.
children.prevalue: Farewell then he cried and fled like a madman

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Neb, Pencroft, and Herbert ran also towards the edge of the wood--but they returned alone.
children.prevalue: Neb Pencroft and Herbert ran also towards the edge of the wood but they returned alone

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: We must let him alone! said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: We must let him alone said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: He will never come back! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: He will never come back exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: He will come back, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: He will come back replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Many days passed; but Harding--was it a sort of presentiment?--persisted in the fixed idea that sooner or later the unhappy man would return.
children.prevalue: Many days passed but Harding was it a sort of presentiment persisted in the fixed idea that sooner or later the unhappy man would return

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: It is the last revolt of his wild nature, said he, which remorse has touched, and which renewed solitude will terrify.
children.prevalue: It is the last revolt of his wild nature said he which remorse has touched and which renewed solitude will terrify

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: In the meanwhile, works of all sorts were continued, as well on Prospect Heights as at the corral, where Harding intended to build a farm. It is unnecessary to say that the seeds collected by Herbert on Tabor Island had been carefully sown. The plateau thus formed one immense kitchen-garden, well laid out and carefully tended, so that the arms of the settlers were never in want of work. There was always something to be done. As the esculents increased in number, it became necessary to enlarge the simple beds, which threatened to grow into regular fields and replace the meadows. But grass abounded in other parts of the island, and there was no fear of the onagers being obliged to go on short allowance. It was well worth while, besides, to turn Prospect Heights into a kitchen-garden, defended by its deep belt of creeks, and to remove them to the meadows, which had no need of protection against the depredations of quadrumana and quadrapeds.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile works of all sorts were continued as well on Prospect Heights as at the corral where Harding intended to build a farm It is unnecessary to say that the seeds collected by Herbert on Tabor Island had been carefully sown The plateau thus formed one immense kitchen garden well laid out and carefully tended so that the arms of the settlers were never in want of work There was always something to be done As the esculents increased in number it became necessary to enlarge the simple beds which threatened to grow into regular fields and replace the meadows But grass abounded in other parts of the island and there was no fear of the onagers being obliged to go on short allowance It was well worth while besides to turn Prospect Heights into a kitchen garden defended by its deep belt of creeks and to remove them to the meadows which had no need of protection against the depredations of quadrumana and quadrapeds

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: On the 15th of November, the third harvest was gathered in. How wonderfully had the field increased in extent, since eighteen months ago, when the first grain of wheat was sown! The second crop of six hundred thousand grains produced this time four thousand bushels, or five hundred millions of grains!
children.prevalue: On the 15th of November the third harvest was gathered in How wonderfully had the field increased in extent since eighteen months ago when the first grain of wheat was sown The second crop of six hundred thousand grains produced this time four thousand bushels or five hundred millions of grains

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The colony was rich in corn, for ten bushels alone were sufficient for sowing every year to produce an ample crop for the food both of men and beasts. The harvest was completed, and the last fortnight of the month of November was devoted to the work of converting it into food for man. In fact, they had corn, but not flour, and the establishment of a mill was necessary. Cyrus Harding could have utilized the second fall which flowed into the Mercy to establish his motive power, the first being already occupied with moving the felting mill, but, after some consultation, it was decided that a simple windmill should be built on Prospect Heights. The building of this presented no more difficulty than the building of the former, and it was moreover certain that there would be no want of wind on the plateau, exposed as it was to the sea breezes.
children.prevalue: The colony was rich in corn for ten bushels alone were sufficient for sowing every year to produce an ample crop for the food both of men and beasts The harvest was completed and the last fortnight of the month of November was devoted to the work of converting it into food for man In fact they had corn but not flour and the establishment of a mill was necessary Cyrus Harding could have utilized the second fall which flowed into the Mercy to establish his motive power the first being already occupied with moving the felting mill but after some consultation it was decided that a simple windmill should be built on Prospect Heights The building of this presented no more difficulty than the building of the former and it was moreover certain that there would be no want of wind on the plateau exposed as it was to the sea breezes

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Not to mention, said Pencroft, that the windmill will be more lively and will have a good effect in the landscape!
children.prevalue: Not to mention said Pencroft that the windmill will be more lively and will have a good effect in the landscape

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: They set to work by choosing timber for the frame and machinery of the mill. Some large stones, found at the north of the lake, could be easily transformed into millstones, and as to the sails, the inexhaustible case of the balloon furnished the necessary material.
children.prevalue: They set to work by choosing timber for the frame and machinery of the mill Some large stones found at the north of the lake could be easily transformed into millstones and as to the sails the inexhaustible case of the balloon furnished the necessary material

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Cyrus Harding made his model, and the site of the mill was chosen a little to the right of the poultry-yard, near the shore of the lake. The frame was to rest on a pivot supported with strong timbers, so that it could turn with all the machinery it contained according as the wind required it. The work advanced rapidly. Neb and Pencroft had become very skilful carpenters, and had nothing to do but to copy the models provided by the engineer.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding made his model and the site of the mill was chosen a little to the right of the poultry yard near the shore of the lake The frame was to rest on a pivot supported with strong timbers so that it could turn with all the machinery it contained according as the wind required it The work advanced rapidly Neb and Pencroft had become very skilful carpenters and had nothing to do but to copy the models provided by the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Soon a sort of cylindrical box, in shape like a pepper-pot, with a pointed roof, rose on the spot chosen. The four frames which formed the sails had been firmly fixed in the center beam, so as to form a certain angle with it, and secured with iron clamps. As to the different parts of the internal mechanism, the box destined to contain the two millstones, the fixed stone and the moving stone, the hopper, a sort of large square trough, wide at the top, narrow at the bottom, which would allow the grain to fall on the stones, the oscillating spout intended to regulate the passing of the grain, and lastly the bolting machine, which by the operation of sifting, separates the bran from the flour, were made without difficulty. The tools were good, and the work not difficult, for in reality, the machinery of a mill is very simple. This was only a question of time.
children.prevalue: Soon a sort of cylindrical box in shape like a pepper pot with a pointed roof rose on the spot chosen The four frames which formed the sails had been firmly fixed in the center beam so as to form a certain angle with it and secured with iron clamps As to the different parts of the internal mechanism the box destined to contain the two millstones the fixed stone and the moving stone the hopper a sort of large square trough wide at the top narrow at the bottom which would allow the grain to fall on the stones the oscillating spout intended to regulate the passing of the grain and lastly the bolting machine which by the operation of sifting separates the bran from the flour were made without difficulty The tools were good and the work not difficult for in reality the machinery of a mill is very simple This was only a question of time

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Every one had worked at the construction of the mill, and on the 1st of December it was finished. As usual, Pencroft was delighted with his work, and had no doubt that the apparatus was perfect.
children.prevalue: Every one had worked at the construction of the mill and on the 1st of December it was finished As usual Pencroft was delighted with his work and had no doubt that the apparatus was perfect

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Now for a good wind, said he, and we shall grind our first harvest splendidly!
children.prevalue: Now for a good wind said he and we shall grind our first harvest splendidly

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: A good wind, certainly, answered the engineer, but not too much, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: A good wind certainly answered the engineer but not too much Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Pooh! our mill would only go the faster!
children.prevalue: Pooh our mill would only go the faster

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: There is no need for it to go so very fast, replied Cyrus Harding. It is known by experience that the greatest quantity of work is performed by a mill when the number of turns made by the sails in a minute is six times the number of feet traversed by the wind in a second. A moderate breeze, which passes over twenty-four feet to the second, will give sixteen turns to the sails during a minute, and there is no need of more.
children.prevalue: There is no need for it to go so very fast replied Cyrus Harding It is known by experience that the greatest quantity of work is performed by a mill when the number of turns made by the sails in a minute is six times the number of feet traversed by the wind in a second A moderate breeze which passes over twenty four feet to the second will give sixteen turns to the sails during a minute and there is no need of more

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Exactly! cried Herbert, a fine breeze is blowing from the northeast, which will soon do our business for us.
children.prevalue: Exactly cried Herbert a fine breeze is blowing from the northeast which will soon do our business for us

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: There was no reason for delaying the inauguration of the mill, for the settlers were eager to taste the first piece of bread in Lincoln Island. On this morning two or three bushels of wheat were ground, and the next day at breakfast a magnificent loaf, a little heavy perhaps, although raised with yeast, appeared on the table at Granite House. Every one munched away at it with a pleasure which may be easily understood.
children.prevalue: There was no reason for delaying the inauguration of the mill for the settlers were eager to taste the first piece of bread in Lincoln Island On this morning two or three bushels of wheat were ground and the next day at breakfast a magnificent loaf a little heavy perhaps although raised with yeast appeared on the table at Granite House Every one munched away at it with a pleasure which may be easily understood

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: In the meanwhile, the stranger had not reappeared. Several times Gideon Spilett and Herbert searched the forest in the neighborhood of Granite House, without meeting or finding any trace of him. They became seriously uneasy at this prolonged absence. Certainly, the former savage of Tabor island could not be perplexed how to live in the forest, abounding in game, but was it not to be feared that he had resumed his habits, and that this freedom would revive in him his wild instincts? However, Harding, by a sort of presentiment, doubtless, always persisted in saying that the fugitive would return.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the stranger had not reappeared Several times Gideon Spilett and Herbert searched the forest in the neighborhood of Granite House without meeting or finding any trace of him They became seriously uneasy at this prolonged absence Certainly the former savage of Tabor island could not be perplexed how to live in the forest abounding in game but was it not to be feared that he had resumed his habits and that this freedom would revive in him his wild instincts However Harding by a sort of presentiment doubtless always persisted in saying that the fugitive would return

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Yes, he will return! he repeated with a confidence which his companions could not share. When this unfortunate man was on Tabor Island, he knew himself to be alone! Here, he knows that fellow-men are awaiting him! Since he has partially spoken of his past life, the poor penitent will return to tell the whole, and from that day he will belong to us!
children.prevalue: Yes he will return he repeated with a confidence which his companions could not share When this unfortunate man was on Tabor Island he knew himself to be alone Here he knows that fellow men are awaiting him Since he has partially spoken of his past life the poor penitent will return to tell the whole and from that day he will belong to us

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The event justified Cyrus Harding's predictions. On the 3rd of December, Herbert had left the plateau to go and fish on the southern bank of the lake. He was unarmed, and till then had never taken any precautions for defense, as dangerous animals had not shown themselves on that part of the island.
children.prevalue: The event justified Cyrus Harding s predictions On the 3rd of December Herbert had left the plateau to go and fish on the southern bank of the lake He was unarmed and till then had never taken any precautions for defense as dangerous animals had not shown themselves on that part of the island

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Meanwhile, Pencroft and Neb were working in the poultry-yard, while Harding and the reporter were occupied at the Chimneys in making soda, the store of soap being exhausted.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile Pencroft and Neb were working in the poultry yard while Harding and the reporter were occupied at the Chimneys in making soda the store of soap being exhausted

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Suddenly cries resounded,--
children.prevalue: Suddenly cries resounded

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Help! help!
children.prevalue: Help help

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Cyrus Harding and the reporter, being at too great a distance, had not been able to hear the shouts. Pencroft and Neb, leaving the poultry-yard in all haste, rushed towards the lake.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and the reporter being at too great a distance had not been able to hear the shouts Pencroft and Neb leaving the poultry yard in all haste rushed towards the lake

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: But before then, the stranger, whose presence at this place no one had suspected, crossed Creek Glycerine, which separated the plateau from the forest, and bounded up the opposite bank.
children.prevalue: But before then the stranger whose presence at this place no one had suspected crossed Creek Glycerine which separated the plateau from the forest and bounded up the opposite bank

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Herbert was there face to face with a fierce jaguar, similar to the one which had been killed on Reptile End. Suddenly surprised, he was standing with his back against a tree, while the animal gathering itself together was about to spring.
children.prevalue: Herbert was there face to face with a fierce jaguar similar to the one which had been killed on Reptile End Suddenly surprised he was standing with his back against a tree while the animal gathering itself together was about to spring

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: But the stranger, with no other weapon than a knife, rushed on the formidable animal, who turned to meet this new adversary.
children.prevalue: But the stranger with no other weapon than a knife rushed on the formidable animal who turned to meet this new adversary

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The struggle was short. The stranger possessed immense strength and activity. He seized the jaguar's throat with one powerful hand, holding it as in a vise, without heeding the beast's claws which tore his flesh, and with the other he plunged his knife into its heart.
children.prevalue: The struggle was short The stranger possessed immense strength and activity He seized the jaguar s throat with one powerful hand holding it as in a vise without heeding the beast s claws which tore his flesh and with the other he plunged his knife into its heart

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: The jaguar fell. The stranger kicked away the body, and was about to fly at the moment when the settlers arrived on the field of battle, but Herbert, clinging to him, cried,--
children.prevalue: The jaguar fell The stranger kicked away the body and was about to fly at the moment when the settlers arrived on the field of battle but Herbert clinging to him cried

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: No, no! you shall not go!
children.prevalue: No no you shall not go

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Harding advanced towards the stranger, who frowned when he saw him approaching. The blood flowed from his shoulder under his torn shirt, but he took no notice of it.
children.prevalue: Harding advanced towards the stranger who frowned when he saw him approaching The blood flowed from his shoulder under his torn shirt but he took no notice of it

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: My friend, said Cyrus Harding, we have just contracted a debt of gratitude to you. To save our boy you have risked your life!
children.prevalue: My friend said Cyrus Harding we have just contracted a debt of gratitude to you To save our boy you have risked your life

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: My life! murmured the stranger. What is that worth? Less than nothing!
children.prevalue: My life murmured the stranger What is that worth Less than nothing

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: You are wounded?
children.prevalue: You are wounded

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: It is no matter.
children.prevalue: It is no matter

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Will you give me your hand?
children.prevalue: Will you give me your hand

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: And as Herbert endeavored to seize the hand which had just saved him, the stranger folded his arms, his chest heaved, his look darkened, and he appeared to wish to escape, but making a violent effort over himself, and in an abrupt tone,--
children.prevalue: And as Herbert endeavored to seize the hand which had just saved him the stranger folded his arms his chest heaved his look darkened and he appeared to wish to escape but making a violent effort over himself and in an abrupt tone

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Who are you? he asked, and what do you claim to be to me?
children.prevalue: Who are you he asked and what do you claim to be to me

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: It was the colonists' history which he thus demanded, and for the first time. Perhaps this history recounted, he would tell his own.
children.prevalue: It was the colonists history which he thus demanded and for the first time Perhaps this history recounted he would tell his own

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: In a few words Harding related all that had happened since their departure from Richmond; how they had managed, and what resources they now had at their disposal.
children.prevalue: In a few words Harding related all that had happened since their departure from Richmond how they had managed and what resources they now had at their disposal

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: The stranger listened with extreme attention.
children.prevalue: The stranger listened with extreme attention

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Then the engineer told who they all were, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft, Neb, himself, and, he added, that the greatest happiness they had felt since their arrival in Lincoln Island was on the return of the vessel from Tabor Island, when they had been able to include among them a new companion.
children.prevalue: Then the engineer told who they all were Gideon Spilett Herbert Pencroft Neb himself and he added that the greatest happiness they had felt since their arrival in Lincoln Island was on the return of the vessel from Tabor Island when they had been able to include among them a new companion

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: At these words the stranger's face flushed, his head sunk on his breast, and confusion was depicted on his countenance.
children.prevalue: At these words the stranger s face flushed his head sunk on his breast and confusion was depicted on his countenance

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: And now that you know us, added Cyrus Harding, will you give us your hand?
children.prevalue: And now that you know us added Cyrus Harding will you give us your hand

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: No, replied the stranger in a hoarse voice; no! You are honest men! And I--
children.prevalue: No replied the stranger in a hoarse voice no You are honest men And I

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: These last words justified the colonists' presentiment. There had been some mournful past, perhaps expiated in the sight of men, but from which his conscience had not yet absolved him. At any rate the guilty man felt remorse, he repented, and his new friends would have cordially pressed the hand which they sought; but he did not feel himself worthy to extend it to honest men! However, after the scene with the jaguar, he did not return to the forest, and from that day did not go beyond the enclosure of Granite House.
children.prevalue: These last words justified the colonists presentiment There had been some mournful past perhaps expiated in the sight of men but from which his conscience had not yet absolved him At any rate the guilty man felt remorse he repented and his new friends would have cordially pressed the hand which they sought but he did not feel himself worthy to extend it to honest men However after the scene with the jaguar he did not return to the forest and from that day did not go beyond the enclosure of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What was the mystery of his life? Would the stranger one day speak of it? Time alone could show. At any rate, it was agreed that his secret should never be asked from him, and that they would live with him as if they suspected nothing.
children.prevalue: What was the mystery of his life Would the stranger one day speak of it Time alone could show At any rate it was agreed that his secret should never be asked from him and that they would live with him as if they suspected nothing

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: For some days their life continued as before. Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett worked together, sometimes chemists, sometimes experimentalists. The reporter never left the engineer except to hunt with Herbert, for it would not have been prudent to allow the lad to ramble alone in the forest; and it was very necessary to be on their guard. As to Neb and Pencroft, one day at the stables and poultry-yard, another at the corral, without reckoning work in Granite House, they were never in want of employment.
children.prevalue: For some days their life continued as before Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett worked together sometimes chemists sometimes experimentalists The reporter never left the engineer except to hunt with Herbert for it would not have been prudent to allow the lad to ramble alone in the forest and it was very necessary to be on their guard As to Neb and Pencroft one day at the stables and poultry yard another at the corral without reckoning work in Granite House they were never in want of employment

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The stranger worked alone, and he had resumed his usual life, never appearing at meals, sleeping under the trees in the plateau, never mingling with his companions. It really seemed as if the society of those who had saved him was insupportable to him!
children.prevalue: The stranger worked alone and he had resumed his usual life never appearing at meals sleeping under the trees in the plateau never mingling with his companions It really seemed as if the society of those who had saved him was insupportable to him

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But then, observed Pencroft, why did he entreat the help of his fellow-creatures? Why did he throw that paper into the sea?
children.prevalue: But then observed Pencroft why did he entreat the help of his fellow creatures Why did he throw that paper into the sea

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: He will tell us why, invariably replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: He will tell us why invariably replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: When?
children.prevalue: When

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Perhaps sooner than you think, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Perhaps sooner than you think Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And, indeed, the day of confession was near.
children.prevalue: And indeed the day of confession was near

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: On the 10th of December, a week after his return to Granite House, Harding saw the stranger approaching, who, in a calm voice and humble tone, said to him: Sir, I have a request to make of you.
children.prevalue: On the 10th of December a week after his return to Granite House Harding saw the stranger approaching who in a calm voice and humble tone said to him Sir I have a request to make of you

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Speak, answered the engineer, but first let me ask you a question.
children.prevalue: Speak answered the engineer but first let me ask you a question

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: At these words the stranger reddened, and was on the point of withdrawing. Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in the mind of the guilty man, who doubtless feared that the engineer would interrogate him on his past life.
children.prevalue: At these words the stranger reddened and was on the point of withdrawing Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in the mind of the guilty man who doubtless feared that the engineer would interrogate him on his past life

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Harding held him back.
children.prevalue: Harding held him back

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Comrade, said he, we are not only your companions but your friends. I wish you to believe that, and now I will listen to you.
children.prevalue: Comrade said he we are not only your companions but your friends I wish you to believe that and now I will listen to you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The stranger pressed his hand over his eyes. He was seized with a sort of trembling, and remained a few moments without being able to articulate a word.
children.prevalue: The stranger pressed his hand over his eyes He was seized with a sort of trembling and remained a few moments without being able to articulate a word

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Sir, said he at last, I have come to beg you to grant me a favor.
children.prevalue: Sir said he at last I have come to beg you to grant me a favor

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You have, four or five miles from here, a corral for your domesticated animals. These animals need to be taken care of. Will you allow me to live there with them?
children.prevalue: You have four or five miles from here a corral for your domesticated animals These animals need to be taken care of Will you allow me to live there with them

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Cyrus Harding gazed at the unfortunate man for a few moments with a feeling of deep commiseration; then,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding gazed at the unfortunate man for a few moments with a feeling of deep commiseration then

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: My friend, said he, the corral has only stables hardly fit for animals.
children.prevalue: My friend said he the corral has only stables hardly fit for animals

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It will be good enough for me, sir.
children.prevalue: It will be good enough for me sir

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: My friend, answered Harding, we will not constrain you in anything. You wish to live at the corral, so be it. You will, however, be always welcome at Granite House. But since you wish to live at the corral we will make the necessary arrangements for your being comfortably established there.
children.prevalue: My friend answered Harding we will not constrain you in anything You wish to live at the corral so be it You will however be always welcome at Granite House But since you wish to live at the corral we will make the necessary arrangements for your being comfortably established there

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Never mind that, I shall do very well.
children.prevalue: Never mind that I shall do very well

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: My friend, answered Harding, who always intentionally made use of this cordial appellation, you must let us judge what it will be best to do in this respect.
children.prevalue: My friend answered Harding who always intentionally made use of this cordial appellation you must let us judge what it will be best to do in this respect

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Thank you, sir, replied the stranger as he withdrew.
children.prevalue: Thank you sir replied the stranger as he withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The engineer then made known to his companions the proposal which had been made to him, and it was agreed that they should build a wooden house at the corral, which they would make as comfortable as possible.
children.prevalue: The engineer then made known to his companions the proposal which had been made to him and it was agreed that they should build a wooden house at the corral which they would make as comfortable as possible

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: That very day the colonists repaired to the corral with the necessary tools, and a week had not passed before the house was ready to receive its tenant. It was built about twenty feet from the sheds, and from there it was easy to overlook the flock of sheep, which then numbered more than eighty. Some furniture, a bed, table, bench, cupboard, and chest were manufactured, and a gun, ammunition, and tools were carried to the corral.
children.prevalue: That very day the colonists repaired to the corral with the necessary tools and a week had not passed before the house was ready to receive its tenant It was built about twenty feet from the sheds and from there it was easy to overlook the flock of sheep which then numbered more than eighty Some furniture a bed table bench cupboard and chest were manufactured and a gun ammunition and tools were carried to the corral

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The stranger, however, had seen nothing of his new dwelling, and he had allowed the settlers to work there without him, while he occupied himself on the plateau, wishing, doubtless, to put the finishing stroke to his work. Indeed, thanks to him, all the ground was dug up and ready to be sowed when the time came.
children.prevalue: The stranger however had seen nothing of his new dwelling and he had allowed the settlers to work there without him while he occupied himself on the plateau wishing doubtless to put the finishing stroke to his work Indeed thanks to him all the ground was dug up and ready to be sowed when the time came

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: It was on the 20th of December that all the arrangements at the corral were completed. The engineer announced to the stranger that his dwelling was ready to receive him, and the latter replied that he would go and sleep there that very evening.
children.prevalue: It was on the 20th of December that all the arrangements at the corral were completed The engineer announced to the stranger that his dwelling was ready to receive him and the latter replied that he would go and sleep there that very evening

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: On this evening the colonists were gathered in the diningroom of Granite House. It was then eight o'clock, the hour at which their companion was to leave them. Not wishing to trouble him by their presence, and thus imposing on him the necessity of saying farewells which might perhaps be painful to him, they had left him alone and ascended to Granite House.
children.prevalue: On this evening the colonists were gathered in the diningroom of Granite House It was then eight o clock the hour at which their companion was to leave them Not wishing to trouble him by their presence and thus imposing on him the necessity of saying farewells which might perhaps be painful to him they had left him alone and ascended to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Now, they had been talking in the room for a few minutes, when a light knock was heard at the door. Almost immediately the stranger entered, and without any preamble,--
children.prevalue: Now they had been talking in the room for a few minutes when a light knock was heard at the door Almost immediately the stranger entered and without any preamble

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Gentlemen, said he, before I leave you, it is right that you should know my history. I will tell it you.
children.prevalue: Gentlemen said he before I leave you it is right that you should know my history I will tell it you

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: These simple words profoundly impressed Cyrus Harding and his companions. The engineer rose.
children.prevalue: These simple words profoundly impressed Cyrus Harding and his companions The engineer rose

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: We ask you nothing, my friend, said he; it is your right to be silent.
children.prevalue: We ask you nothing my friend said he it is your right to be silent

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It is my duty to speak.
children.prevalue: It is my duty to speak

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Sit down, then.
children.prevalue: Sit down then

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, I will stand.
children.prevalue: No I will stand

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: We are ready to hear you, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: We are ready to hear you replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The stranger remained standing in a corner of the room, a little in the shade. He was bareheaded, his arms folded across his chest, and it was in this posture that in a hoarse voice, speaking like some one who obliges himself to speak, he gave the following recital, which his auditors did not once interrupt:--
children.prevalue: The stranger remained standing in a corner of the room a little in the shade He was bareheaded his arms folded across his chest and it was in this posture that in a hoarse voice speaking like some one who obliges himself to speak he gave the following recital which his auditors did not once interrupt

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: On the 20th of December, 1854, a steam-yacht, belonging to a Scotch nobleman, Lord Glenarvan, anchored off Cape Bernouilli, on the western coast of Australia, in the thirty-seventh parallel. On board this yacht were Lord Glenarvan and his wife, a major in the English army, a French geographer, a young girl, and a young boy. These two last were the children of Captain Grant, whose ship, the 'Britannia,' had been lost, crew and cargo, a year before. The 'Duncan' was commanded by Captain John Mangles, and manned by a crew of fifteen men.
children.prevalue: On the 20th of December 1854 a steam yacht belonging to a Scotch nobleman Lord Glenarvan anchored off Cape Bernouilli on the western coast of Australia in the thirty seventh parallel On board this yacht were Lord Glenarvan and his wife a major in the English army a French geographer a young girl and a young boy These two last were the children of Captain Grant whose ship the Britannia had been lost crew and cargo a year before The Duncan was commanded by Captain John Mangles and manned by a crew of fifteen men

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: This is the reason the yacht at this time lay off the coast of Australia. Six months before, a bottle, enclosing a document written in English, German, and French, had been found in the Irish Sea, and picked up by the 'Duncan.' This document stated in substance that there still existed three survivors from the wreck of the 'Britannia,' that these survivors were Captain Grant and two of his men, and that they had found refuge on some land, of which the document gave the latitude, but of which the longitude, effaced by the sea, was no longer legible.
children.prevalue: This is the reason the yacht at this time lay off the coast of Australia Six months before a bottle enclosing a document written in English German and French had been found in the Irish Sea and picked up by the Duncan This document stated in substance that there still existed three survivors from the wreck of the Britannia that these survivors were Captain Grant and two of his men and that they had found refuge on some land of which the document gave the latitude but of which the longitude effaced by the sea was no longer legible

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: This latitude was 37deg 11' south; therefore, the longitude being unknown, if they followed the thirty-seventh parallel over continents and seas, they would be certain to reach the spot inhabited by Captain Grant and his two companions. The English Admiralty having hesitated to undertake this search, Lord Glenarvan resolved to attempt everything to find the captain. He communicated with Mary and Robert Grant, who joined him. The 'Duncan' yacht was equipped for the distant voyage, in which the nobleman's family and the captain's children wished to take part, and the 'Duncan,' leaving Glasgow, proceeded towards the Atlantic, passed through the Straits of Magellan, and ascended the Pacific as far as Patagonia, where, according to a previous interpretation of the document, they supposed that Captain Grant was a prisoner among the Indians.
children.prevalue: This latitude was 37deg 11 south therefore the longitude being unknown if they followed the thirty seventh parallel over continents and seas they would be certain to reach the spot inhabited by Captain Grant and his two companions The English Admiralty having hesitated to undertake this search Lord Glenarvan resolved to attempt everything to find the captain He communicated with Mary and Robert Grant who joined him The Duncan yacht was equipped for the distant voyage in which the nobleman s family and the captain s children wished to take part and the Duncan leaving Glasgow proceeded towards the Atlantic passed through the Straits of Magellan and ascended the Pacific as far as Patagonia where according to a previous interpretation of the document they supposed that Captain Grant was a prisoner among the Indians

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The 'Duncan' disembarked her passengers on the western coast of Patagonia, and sailed to pick them up again on the eastern coast at Cape Corrientes. Lord Glenarvan traversed Patagonia, following the thirty-seventh parallel, and having found no trace of the captain, he re-embarked on the 13th of November, so as to pursue his search through the Ocean.
children.prevalue: The Duncan disembarked her passengers on the western coast of Patagonia and sailed to pick them up again on the eastern coast at Cape Corrientes Lord Glenarvan traversed Patagonia following the thirty seventh parallel and having found no trace of the captain he re embarked on the 13th of November so as to pursue his search through the Ocean

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: After having unsuccessfully visited the islands of Tristan d'Acunha and Amsterdam, situated in her course, the 'Duncan,' as I have said, arrived at Cape Bernouilli, on the Australian coast, on the 20th of December, 1854.
children.prevalue: After having unsuccessfully visited the islands of Tristan d Acunha and Amsterdam situated in her course the Duncan as I have said arrived at Cape Bernouilli on the Australian coast on the 20th of December 1854

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: It was Lord Glenarvan's intention to traverse Australia as he had traversed America, and he disembarked. A few miles from the coast was established a farm, belonging to an Irishman, who offered hospitality to the travelers. Lord Glenarvan made known to the Irishman the cause which had brought him to these parts, and asked if he knew whether a three-masted English vessel, the 'Britannia,' had been lost less than two years before on the west coast of Australia.
children.prevalue: It was Lord Glenarvan s intention to traverse Australia as he had traversed America and he disembarked A few miles from the coast was established a farm belonging to an Irishman who offered hospitality to the travelers Lord Glenarvan made known to the Irishman the cause which had brought him to these parts and asked if he knew whether a three masted English vessel the Britannia had been lost less than two years before on the west coast of Australia

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The Irishman had never heard of this wreck, but, to the great surprise of the bystanders, one of his servants came forward and said,--
children.prevalue: The Irishman had never heard of this wreck but to the great surprise of the bystanders one of his servants came forward and said

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'My lord, praise and thank God! If Captain Grant is still living, he is living on the Australian shores.'
children.prevalue: My lord praise and thank God If Captain Grant is still living he is living on the Australian shores

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'Who are you?' asked Lord Glenarvan.
children.prevalue: Who are you asked Lord Glenarvan

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'A Scotchman like yourself, my lord,' replied the man; 'I am one of Captain Grant's crew--one of the castaways of the Britannia.'
children.prevalue: A Scotchman like yourself my lord replied the man I am one of Captain Grant s crew one of the castaways of the Britannia

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: This man was called Ayrton. He was, in fact, the boatswain's mate of the 'Britannia,' as his papers showed. But, separated from Captain Grant at the moment when the ship struck upon the rocks, he had till then believed that the captain with all his crew had perished, and that he, Ayrton, was the sole survivor of the 'Britannia.'
children.prevalue: This man was called Ayrton He was in fact the boatswain s mate of the Britannia as his papers showed But separated from Captain Grant at the moment when the ship struck upon the rocks he had till then believed that the captain with all his crew had perished and that he Ayrton was the sole survivor of the Britannia

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'Only,' he added, 'it was not on the west coast, but on the east coast of Australia that the vessel was lost, and if Captain Grant is still living, as his document indicates, he is a prisoner among the natives, and it is on the other coast that he must be looked for.'
children.prevalue: Only he added it was not on the west coast but on the east coast of Australia that the vessel was lost and if Captain Grant is still living as his document indicates he is a prisoner among the natives and it is on the other coast that he must be looked for

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: This man spoke in a frank voice and with a confident look; his words could not be doubted. The Irishman, in whose service he had been for more than a year, answered for his trustworthiness. Lord Glenarvan, therefore, believed in the fidelity of this man and, by his advice, resolved to cross Australia, following the thirty-seventh parallel. Lord Glenarvan, his wife, the two children, the major, the Frenchman, Captain Mangles, and a few sailors composed the little band under the command of Ayrton, while the 'Duncan,' under charge of the mate, Tom Austin, proceeded to Melbourne, there to await Lord Glenarvan's instructions.
children.prevalue: This man spoke in a frank voice and with a confident look his words could not be doubted The Irishman in whose service he had been for more than a year answered for his trustworthiness Lord Glenarvan therefore believed in the fidelity of this man and by his advice resolved to cross Australia following the thirty seventh parallel Lord Glenarvan his wife the two children the major the Frenchman Captain Mangles and a few sailors composed the little band under the command of Ayrton while the Duncan under charge of the mate Tom Austin proceeded to Melbourne there to await Lord Glenarvan s instructions

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: They set out on the 23rd of December, 1854.
children.prevalue: They set out on the 23rd of December 1854

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: It is time to say that Ayrton was a traitor. He was, indeed, the boatswain's mate of the 'Britannia,' but, after some dispute with his captain, he endeavored to incite the crew to mutiny and seize the ship, and Captain Grant had landed him, on the 8th of April, 1852, on the west coast of Australia, and then sailed, leaving him there, as was only just.
children.prevalue: It is time to say that Ayrton was a traitor He was indeed the boatswain s mate of the Britannia but after some dispute with his captain he endeavored to incite the crew to mutiny and seize the ship and Captain Grant had landed him on the 8th of April 1852 on the west coast of Australia and then sailed leaving him there as was only just

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Therefore this wretched man knew nothing of the wreck of the 'Britannia'; he had just heard of it from Glenarvan's account. Since his abandonment, he had become, under the name of Ben Joyce, the leader of the escaped convicts; and if he boldly maintained that the wreck had taken place on the east coast, and led Lord Glenarvan to proceed in that direction, it was that he hoped to separate him from his ship, seize the 'Duncan,' and make the yacht a pirate in the Pacific.
children.prevalue: Therefore this wretched man knew nothing of the wreck of the Britannia he had just heard of it from Glenarvan s account Since his abandonment he had become under the name of Ben Joyce the leader of the escaped convicts and if he boldly maintained that the wreck had taken place on the east coast and led Lord Glenarvan to proceed in that direction it was that he hoped to separate him from his ship seize the Duncan and make the yacht a pirate in the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Here the stranger stopped for a moment. His voice trembled, but he continued,--
children.prevalue: Here the stranger stopped for a moment His voice trembled but he continued

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The expedition set out and proceeded across Australia. It was inevitably unfortunate, since Ayrton, or Ben Joyce, as he may be called, guided it, sometimes preceded, sometimes followed by his band of convicts, who had been told what they had to do.
children.prevalue: The expedition set out and proceeded across Australia It was inevitably unfortunate since Ayrton or Ben Joyce as he may be called guided it sometimes preceded sometimes followed by his band of convicts who had been told what they had to do

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Meanwhile, the 'Duncan' had been sent to Melbourne for repairs. It was necessary, then, to get Lord Glenarvan to order her to leave Melbourne and go to the east coast of Australia, where it would be easy to seize her. After having led the expedition near enough to the coast, in the midst of vast forests with no resources, Ayrton obtained a letter, which he was charged to carry to the mate of the 'Duncan'--a letter which ordered the yacht to repair immediately to the east coast, to Twofold Bay, that is to say a few days' journey from the place where the expedition had stopped. It was there that Ayrton had agreed to meet his accomplices, and two days after gaining possession of the letter, he arrived at Melbourne.
