children.prevalue: Meanwhile the Duncan had been sent to Melbourne for repairs It was necessary then to get Lord Glenarvan to order her to leave Melbourne and go to the east coast of Australia where it would be easy to seize her After having led the expedition near enough to the coast in the midst of vast forests with no resources Ayrton obtained a letter which he was charged to carry to the mate of the Duncan a letter which ordered the yacht to repair immediately to the east coast to Twofold Bay that is to say a few days journey from the place where the expedition had stopped It was there that Ayrton had agreed to meet his accomplices and two days after gaining possession of the letter he arrived at Melbourne

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: So far the villain had succeeded in his wicked design. He would be able to take the 'Duncan' into Twofold Bay, where it would be easy for the convicts to seize her, and her crew massacred, Ben Joyce would become master of the seas. But it pleased God to prevent the accomplishment of these terrible projects.
children.prevalue: So far the villain had succeeded in his wicked design He would be able to take the Duncan into Twofold Bay where it would be easy for the convicts to seize her and her crew massacred Ben Joyce would become master of the seas But it pleased God to prevent the accomplishment of these terrible projects

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Ayrton, arrived at Melbourne, delivered the letter to the mate, Tom Austin, who read it and immediately set sail, but judge of Ayrton's rage and disappointment, when the next day he found that the mate was taking the vessel, not to the east coast of Australia, to Twofold Bay, but to the east coast of New Zealand. He wished to stop him, but Austin showed him the letter!... And indeed, by a providential error of the French geographer, who had written the letter, the east coast of New Zealand was mentioned as the place of destination.
children.prevalue: Ayrton arrived at Melbourne delivered the letter to the mate Tom Austin who read it and immediately set sail but judge of Ayrton s rage and disappointment when the next day he found that the mate was taking the vessel not to the east coast of Australia to Twofold Bay but to the east coast of New Zealand He wished to stop him but Austin showed him the letter And indeed by a providential error of the French geographer who had written the letter the east coast of New Zealand was mentioned as the place of destination

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: All Ayrton's plans were frustrated! He became outrageous. They put him in irons. He was then taken to the coast of New Zealand, not knowing what would become of his accomplices, or what would become of Lord Glenarvan.
children.prevalue: All Ayrton s plans were frustrated He became outrageous They put him in irons He was then taken to the coast of New Zealand not knowing what would become of his accomplices or what would become of Lord Glenarvan

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The 'Duncan' cruised about on this coast until the 3rd of March. On that day Ayrton heard the report of guns. The guns on the 'Duncan' were being fired, and soon Lord Glenarvan and his companions came on board.
children.prevalue: The Duncan cruised about on this coast until the 3rd of March On that day Ayrton heard the report of guns The guns on the Duncan were being fired and soon Lord Glenarvan and his companions came on board

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: This is what had happened.
children.prevalue: This is what had happened

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: After a thousand hardships, a thousand dangers, Lord Glenarvan had accomplished his journey, and arrived on the east coast of Australia, at Twofold Bay. 'No Duncan!' He telegraphed to Melbourne. They answered, Duncan sailed on the 18th instant. Destination unknown.'
children.prevalue: After a thousand hardships a thousand dangers Lord Glenarvan had accomplished his journey and arrived on the east coast of Australia at Twofold Bay No Duncan He telegraphed to Melbourne They answered Duncan sailed on the 18th instant Destination unknown

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Lord Glenarvan could only arrive at one conclusion; that his honest yacht had fallen into the hands of Ben Joyce, and had become a pirate vessel!
children.prevalue: Lord Glenarvan could only arrive at one conclusion that his honest yacht had fallen into the hands of Ben Joyce and had become a pirate vessel

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: However, Lord Glenarvan would not give up. He was a bold and generous man. He embarked in a merchant vessel, sailed to the west coast of New Zealand, traversed it along the thirty-seventh parallel, without finding any trace of Captain Grant; but on the other side, to his great surprise, and by the will of Heaven, he found the 'Duncan,' under command of the mate, who had been waiting for him for five weeks!
children.prevalue: However Lord Glenarvan would not give up He was a bold and generous man He embarked in a merchant vessel sailed to the west coast of New Zealand traversed it along the thirty seventh parallel without finding any trace of Captain Grant but on the other side to his great surprise and by the will of Heaven he found the Duncan under command of the mate who had been waiting for him for five weeks

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: This was on the 3rd of March, 1855. Lord Glenarvan was now on board the 'Duncan,' but Ayrton was there also. He appeared before the nobleman, who wished to extract from him all that the villain knew about Captain Grant. Ayrton refused to speak. Lord Glenarvan then told him, that at the first port they put into, he would be delivered up to the English authorities. Ayrton remained mute.
children.prevalue: This was on the 3rd of March 1855 Lord Glenarvan was now on board the Duncan but Ayrton was there also He appeared before the nobleman who wished to extract from him all that the villain knew about Captain Grant Ayrton refused to speak Lord Glenarvan then told him that at the first port they put into he would be delivered up to the English authorities Ayrton remained mute

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The 'Duncan' continued her voyage along the thirty-seventh parallel. In the meanwhile, Lady Glenarvan undertook to vanquish the resistance of the ruffian.
children.prevalue: The Duncan continued her voyage along the thirty seventh parallel In the meanwhile Lady Glenarvan undertook to vanquish the resistance of the ruffian

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: At last, her influence prevailed, and Ayrton, in exchange for what he could tell, proposed that Lord Glenarvan should leave him on some island in the Pacific, instead of giving him up to the English authorities. Lord Glenarvan, resolving to do anything to obtain information about Captain Grant, consented.
children.prevalue: At last her influence prevailed and Ayrton in exchange for what he could tell proposed that Lord Glenarvan should leave him on some island in the Pacific instead of giving him up to the English authorities Lord Glenarvan resolving to do anything to obtain information about Captain Grant consented

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ayrton then related all his life, and it was certain that he knew nothing from the day on which Captain Grant had landed him on the Australian coast.
children.prevalue: Ayrton then related all his life and it was certain that he knew nothing from the day on which Captain Grant had landed him on the Australian coast

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Nevertheless, Lord Glenarvan kept the promise which he had given. The 'Duncan' continued her voyage and arrived at Tabor Island. It was there that Ayrton was to be landed, and it was there also that, by a veritable miracle, they found Captain Grant and two men, exactly on the thirty-seventh parallel.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless Lord Glenarvan kept the promise which he had given The Duncan continued her voyage and arrived at Tabor Island It was there that Ayrton was to be landed and it was there also that by a veritable miracle they found Captain Grant and two men exactly on the thirty seventh parallel

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The convict, then, went to take their place on this desert islet, and at the moment he left the yacht these words were pronounced by Lord Glenarvan:--
children.prevalue: The convict then went to take their place on this desert islet and at the moment he left the yacht these words were pronounced by Lord Glenarvan

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: 'Here, Ayrton, you will be far from any land, and without any possible communication with your fellow-creatures. You cannot escape from this islet on which the 'Duncan' leaves you. You will be alone, under the eye of a God who reads the depths of the heart, but you will be neither lost nor forgotten, as was Captain Grant. Unworthy as you are to be remembered by men, men will remember you. I know where you are Ayrton, and I know where to find you. I will never forget it!
children.prevalue: Here Ayrton you will be far from any land and without any possible communication with your fellow creatures You cannot escape from this islet on which the Duncan leaves you You will be alone under the eye of a God who reads the depths of the heart but you will be neither lost nor forgotten as was Captain Grant Unworthy as you are to be remembered by men men will remember you I know where you are Ayrton and I know where to find you I will never forget it

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: And the 'Duncan,' making sail, soon disappeared. This was 18th of March, 1855.
children.prevalue: And the Duncan making sail soon disappeared This was 18th of March 1855

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: (The events which have just been briefly related are taken      from a work which some of our readers have no doubt read,      and which is entitled, Captain Grant's children. They will      remark on this occasion, as well as later, some discrepancy      in the dates; but later again, they will understand why the      real dates were not at first given.)
children.prevalue: The events which have just been briefly related are taken from a work which some of our readers have no doubt read and which is entitled Captain Grant s children They will remark on this occasion as well as later some discrepancy in the dates but later again they will understand why the real dates were not at first given

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Ayrton was alone, but he had no want of either ammunition, weapons, tools, or seeds.
children.prevalue: Ayrton was alone but he had no want of either ammunition weapons tools or seeds

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: At his, the convict's disposal, was the house built by honest Captain Grant. He had only to live and expiate in solitude the crimes which he had committed.
children.prevalue: At his the convict s disposal was the house built by honest Captain Grant He had only to live and expiate in solitude the crimes which he had committed

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Gentlemen, he repented, he was ashamed of his crimes and was very miserable! He said to himself, that if men came some day to take him from that islet, he must be worthy to return among them! How he suffered, that wretched man! How he labored to recover himself by work! How he prayed to be reformed by prayer! For two years, three years, this went on, but Ayrton, humbled by solitude, always looking for some ship to appear on the horizon, asking himself if the time of expiation would soon be complete, suffered as none other suffered! Oh! how dreadful was this solitude, to a heart tormented by remorse!
children.prevalue: Gentlemen he repented he was ashamed of his crimes and was very miserable He said to himself that if men came some day to take him from that islet he must be worthy to return among them How he suffered that wretched man How he labored to recover himself by work How he prayed to be reformed by prayer For two years three years this went on but Ayrton humbled by solitude always looking for some ship to appear on the horizon asking himself if the time of expiation would soon be complete suffered as none other suffered Oh how dreadful was this solitude to a heart tormented by remorse

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: But doubtless Heaven had not sufficiently punished this unhappy man, for he felt that he was gradually becoming a savage! He felt that brutishness was gradually gaining on him!
children.prevalue: But doubtless Heaven had not sufficiently punished this unhappy man for he felt that he was gradually becoming a savage He felt that brutishness was gradually gaining on him

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: He could not say if it was after two or three years of solitude, but at last he became the miserable creature you found!
children.prevalue: He could not say if it was after two or three years of solitude but at last he became the miserable creature you found

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: I have no need to tell you, gentlemen, that Ayrton, Ben Joyce, and I, are the same.
children.prevalue: I have no need to tell you gentlemen that Ayrton Ben Joyce and I are the same

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions rose at the end of this account. It is impossible to say how much they were moved! What misery, grief, and despair lay revealed before them!
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions rose at the end of this account It is impossible to say how much they were moved What misery grief and despair lay revealed before them

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Ayrton, said Harding, rising, you have been a great criminal, but Heaven must certainly think that you have expiated your crimes! That has been proved by your having been brought again among your fellow-creatures. Ayrton, you are forgiven! And now you will be our companion?
children.prevalue: Ayrton said Harding rising you have been a great criminal but Heaven must certainly think that you have expiated your crimes That has been proved by your having been brought again among your fellow creatures Ayrton you are forgiven And now you will be our companion

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Ayrton drew back.
children.prevalue: Ayrton drew back

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Here is my hand! said the engineer.
children.prevalue: Here is my hand said the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Ayrton grasped the hand which Harding extended to him, and great tears fell from his eyes.
children.prevalue: Ayrton grasped the hand which Harding extended to him and great tears fell from his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Will you live with us? asked Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Will you live with us asked Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Captain Harding, leave me some time longer, replied Ayrton, leave me alone in the hut in the corral!
children.prevalue: Captain Harding leave me some time longer replied Ayrton leave me alone in the hut in the corral

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: As you like, Ayrton, answered Cyrus Harding. Ayrton was going to withdraw, when the engineer addressed one more question to him:--
children.prevalue: As you like Ayrton answered Cyrus Harding Ayrton was going to withdraw when the engineer addressed one more question to him

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: One word more, my friend. Since it was your intention to live alone, why did you throw into the sea the document which put us on your track?
children.prevalue: One word more my friend Since it was your intention to live alone why did you throw into the sea the document which put us on your track

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: A document? repeated Ayrton, who did not appear to know what he meant.
children.prevalue: A document repeated Ayrton who did not appear to know what he meant

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Yes, the document which we found enclosed in a bottle, giving us the exact position of Tabor Island!
children.prevalue: Yes the document which we found enclosed in a bottle giving us the exact position of Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Ayrton passed his hand over his brow, then after having thought, I never threw any document into the sea! he answered.
children.prevalue: Ayrton passed his hand over his brow then after having thought I never threw any document into the sea he answered

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Never? exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Never exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Never!
children.prevalue: Never

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: And Ayrton, bowing, reached the door and departed.
children.prevalue: And Ayrton bowing reached the door and departed

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Poor man! said Herbert, who had rushed to the door, but returned, having seen Ayrton slide down the rope on the lift and disappear in the darkness.
children.prevalue: Poor man said Herbert who had rushed to the door but returned having seen Ayrton slide down the rope on the lift and disappear in the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: He will come back, said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: He will come back said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Come, now, captain, exclaimed Pencroft, what does that mean? What! wasn't it Ayrton who threw that bottle into the sea? Who was it then?
children.prevalue: Come now captain exclaimed Pencroft what does that mean What wasn t it Ayrton who threw that bottle into the sea Who was it then

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Certainly, if ever a question was necessary to be made, it was that one!
children.prevalue: Certainly if ever a question was necessary to be made it was that one

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It was he, answered Neb, only the unhappy man was half-mad.
children.prevalue: It was he answered Neb only the unhappy man was half mad

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes! said Herbert, and he was no longer conscious of what he was doing.
children.prevalue: Yes said Herbert and he was no longer conscious of what he was doing

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It can only be explained in that way, my friends, replied Harding quickly, and I understand now how Ayrton was able to point out exactly the situation of Tabor Island, since the events which had preceded his being left on the island had made it known to him.
children.prevalue: It can only be explained in that way my friends replied Harding quickly and I understand now how Ayrton was able to point out exactly the situation of Tabor Island since the events which had preceded his being left on the island had made it known to him

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: However, observed Pencroft, if he was not yet a brute when he wrote that document, and if he threw it into the sea seven or eight years ago, how is it that the paper has not been injured by damp?
children.prevalue: However observed Pencroft if he was not yet a brute when he wrote that document and if he threw it into the sea seven or eight years ago how is it that the paper has not been injured by damp

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: That proves, answered Cyrus Harding, that Ayrton was deprived of intelligence at a more recent time than he thinks.
children.prevalue: That proves answered Cyrus Harding that Ayrton was deprived of intelligence at a more recent time than he thinks

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Of course it must be so, replied Pencroft, without that the fact would be unaccountable.
children.prevalue: Of course it must be so replied Pencroft without that the fact would be unaccountable

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Unaccountable indeed, answered the engineer, who did not appear desirous to prolong the conversation.
children.prevalue: Unaccountable indeed answered the engineer who did not appear desirous to prolong the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: But has Ayrton told the truth? asked the sailor.
children.prevalue: But has Ayrton told the truth asked the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, replied the reporter. The story which he has told is true in every point. I remember quite well the account in the newspapers of the yacht expedition undertaken by Lord Glenarvan, and its result.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the reporter The story which he has told is true in every point I remember quite well the account in the newspapers of the yacht expedition undertaken by Lord Glenarvan and its result

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Ayrton has told the truth, added Harding. Do not doubt it, Pencroft, for it was painful to him. People tell the truth when they accuse themselves like that!
children.prevalue: Ayrton has told the truth added Harding Do not doubt it Pencroft for it was painful to him People tell the truth when they accuse themselves like that

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The next day--the 21st of December--the colonists descended to the beach, and having climbed the plateau they found nothing of Ayrton. He had reached his house in the corral during the night and the settlers judged it best not to agitate him by their presence. Time would doubtless perform what sympathy had been unable to accomplish.
children.prevalue: The next day the 21st of December the colonists descended to the beach and having climbed the plateau they found nothing of Ayrton He had reached his house in the corral during the night and the settlers judged it best not to agitate him by their presence Time would doubtless perform what sympathy had been unable to accomplish

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Herbert, Pencroft, and Neb resumed their ordinary occupations. On this day the same work brought Harding and the reporter to the workshop at the Chimneys.
children.prevalue: Herbert Pencroft and Neb resumed their ordinary occupations On this day the same work brought Harding and the reporter to the workshop at the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Do you know, my dear Cyrus, said Gideon Spilett, that the explanation you gave yesterday on the subject of the bottle has not satisfied me at all! How can it be supposed that the unfortunate man was able to write that document and throw the bottle into the sea without having the slightest recollection of it?
children.prevalue: Do you know my dear Cyrus said Gideon Spilett that the explanation you gave yesterday on the subject of the bottle has not satisfied me at all How can it be supposed that the unfortunate man was able to write that document and throw the bottle into the sea without having the slightest recollection of it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Nor was it he who threw it in, my dear Spilett.
children.prevalue: Nor was it he who threw it in my dear Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You think then--
children.prevalue: You think then

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I think nothing, I know nothing! interrupted Cyrus Harding. I am content to rank this incident among those which I have not been able to explain to this day!
children.prevalue: I think nothing I know nothing interrupted Cyrus Harding I am content to rank this incident among those which I have not been able to explain to this day

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Indeed, Cyrus, said Spilett, these things are incredible! Your rescue, the case stranded on the sand, Top's adventure, and lastly this bottle... Shall we never have the answer to these enigmas?
children.prevalue: Indeed Cyrus said Spilett these things are incredible Your rescue the case stranded on the sand Top s adventure and lastly this bottle Shall we never have the answer to these enigmas

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes! replied the engineer quickly, yes, even if I have to penetrate into the bowels of this island!
children.prevalue: Yes replied the engineer quickly yes even if I have to penetrate into the bowels of this island

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Chance will perhaps give us the key to this mystery!
children.prevalue: Chance will perhaps give us the key to this mystery

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Chance! Spilett! I do not believe in chance, any more than I believe in mysteries in this world. There is a reason for everything unaccountable which has happened here, and that reason I shall discover. But in the meantime we must work and observe.
children.prevalue: Chance Spilett I do not believe in chance any more than I believe in mysteries in this world There is a reason for everything unaccountable which has happened here and that reason I shall discover But in the meantime we must work and observe

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The month of January arrived. The year 1867 commenced. The summer occupations were assiduously continued. During the days which followed, Herbert and Spilett having gone in the direction of the corral, ascertained that Ayrton had taken possession of the habitation which had been prepared for him. He busied himself with the numerous flock confided to his care, and spared his companions the trouble of coming every two or three days to visit the corral. Nevertheless, in order not to leave Ayrton in solitude for too long a time, the settlers often paid him a visit.
children.prevalue: The month of January arrived The year 1867 commenced The summer occupations were assiduously continued During the days which followed Herbert and Spilett having gone in the direction of the corral ascertained that Ayrton had taken possession of the habitation which had been prepared for him He busied himself with the numerous flock confided to his care and spared his companions the trouble of coming every two or three days to visit the corral Nevertheless in order not to leave Ayrton in solitude for too long a time the settlers often paid him a visit

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It was not unimportant either, in consequence of some suspicions entertained by the engineer and Gideon Spilett, that this part of the island should be subject to a surveillance of some sort, and that Ayrton, if any incident occurred unexpectedly, should not neglect to inform the inhabitants of Granite House of it.
children.prevalue: It was not unimportant either in consequence of some suspicions entertained by the engineer and Gideon Spilett that this part of the island should be subject to a surveillance of some sort and that Ayrton if any incident occurred unexpectedly should not neglect to inform the inhabitants of Granite House of it

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Nevertheless it might happen that something would occur which it would be necessary to bring rapidly to the engineer's knowledge. Independently of facts bearing on the mystery of Lincoln Island, many others might happen, which would call for the prompt interference of the colonists,--such as the sighting of a vessel, a wreck on the western coast, the possible arrival of pirates, etc.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless it might happen that something would occur which it would be necessary to bring rapidly to the engineer s knowledge Independently of facts bearing on the mystery of Lincoln Island many others might happen which would call for the prompt interference of the colonists such as the sighting of a vessel a wreck on the western coast the possible arrival of pirates etc

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Therefore Cyrus Harding resolved to put the corral in instantaneous communication with Granite House.
children.prevalue: Therefore Cyrus Harding resolved to put the corral in instantaneous communication with Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: It was on the 10th of January that he made known his project to his companions.
children.prevalue: It was on the 10th of January that he made known his project to his companions

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Why! how are you going to manage that, captain? asked Pencroft. Do you by chance happen to think of establishing a telegraph?
children.prevalue: Why how are you going to manage that captain asked Pencroft Do you by chance happen to think of establishing a telegraph

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Exactly so, answered the engineer.
children.prevalue: Exactly so answered the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Electric? cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: Electric cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Electric, replied Cyrus Harding. We have all the necessary materials for making a battery, and the most difficult thing will be to stretch the wires, but by means of a drawplate I think we shall manage it.
children.prevalue: Electric replied Cyrus Harding We have all the necessary materials for making a battery and the most difficult thing will be to stretch the wires but by means of a drawplate I think we shall manage it

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Well, after that, returned the sailor, I shall never despair of seeing ourselves some day rolling along on a railway!
children.prevalue: Well after that returned the sailor I shall never despair of seeing ourselves some day rolling along on a railway

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: They then set to work, beginning with the most difficult thing, for, if they failed in that, it would be useless to manufacture the battery and other accessories.
children.prevalue: They then set to work beginning with the most difficult thing for if they failed in that it would be useless to manufacture the battery and other accessories

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The iron of Lincoln Island, as has been said, was of excellent quality, and consequently very fit for being drawn out. Harding commenced by manufacturing a drawplate, that is to say, a plate of steel, pierced with conical holes of different sizes, which would successively bring the wire to the wished-for tenacity. This piece of steel, after having been tempered, was fixed in as firm a way as possible in a solid framework planted in the ground, only a few feet from the great fall, the motive power of which the engineer intended to utilize. In fact as the fulling-mill was there, although not then in use, its beam moved with extreme power would serve to stretch out the wire by rolling it round itself. It was a delicate operation, and required much care. The iron, prepared previously in long thin rods, the ends of which were sharpened with the file, having been introduced into the largest hole of the drawplate, was drawn out by the beam which wound it round itself, to a length of twenty-five or thirty feet, then unrolled, and the same operation was performed successively through the holes of a less size. Finally, the engineer obtained wires from forty to fifty feet long, which could be easily fastened together and stretched over the distance of five miles, which separated the corral from the bounds of Granite House.
children.prevalue: The iron of Lincoln Island as has been said was of excellent quality and consequently very fit for being drawn out Harding commenced by manufacturing a drawplate that is to say a plate of steel pierced with conical holes of different sizes which would successively bring the wire to the wished for tenacity This piece of steel after having been tempered was fixed in as firm a way as possible in a solid framework planted in the ground only a few feet from the great fall the motive power of which the engineer intended to utilize In fact as the fulling mill was there although not then in use its beam moved with extreme power would serve to stretch out the wire by rolling it round itself It was a delicate operation and required much care The iron prepared previously in long thin rods the ends of which were sharpened with the file having been introduced into the largest hole of the drawplate was drawn out by the beam which wound it round itself to a length of twenty five or thirty feet then unrolled and the same operation was performed successively through the holes of a less size Finally the engineer obtained wires from forty to fifty feet long which could be easily fastened together and stretched over the distance of five miles which separated the corral from the bounds of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: It did not take more than a few days to perform this work, and indeed as soon as the machine had been commenced, Cyrus Harding left his companions to follow the trade of wiredrawers, and occupied himself with manufacturing his battery.
children.prevalue: It did not take more than a few days to perform this work and indeed as soon as the machine had been commenced Cyrus Harding left his companions to follow the trade of wiredrawers and occupied himself with manufacturing his battery

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It was necessary to obtain a battery with a constant current. It is known that the elements of modern batteries are generally composed of retort coal, zinc, and copper. Copper was absolutely wanting to the engineer, who, notwithstanding all his researches, had never been able to find any trace of it in Lincoln Island, and was therefore obliged to do without it. Retort coal, that is to say, the hard graphite which is found in the retorts of gas manufactories, after the coal has been dehydrogenized, could have been obtained, but it would have been necessary to establish a special apparatus, involving great labor. As to zinc, it may be remembered that the case found at Flotsam Point was lined with this metal, which could not be better utilized than for this purpose.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to obtain a battery with a constant current It is known that the elements of modern batteries are generally composed of retort coal zinc and copper Copper was absolutely wanting to the engineer who notwithstanding all his researches had never been able to find any trace of it in Lincoln Island and was therefore obliged to do without it Retort coal that is to say the hard graphite which is found in the retorts of gas manufactories after the coal has been dehydrogenized could have been obtained but it would have been necessary to establish a special apparatus involving great labor As to zinc it may be remembered that the case found at Flotsam Point was lined with this metal which could not be better utilized than for this purpose

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Cyrus Harding, after mature consideration, decided to manufacture a very simple battery, resembling as nearly as possible that invented by Becquerel in 1820, and in which zinc only is employed. The other substances, azotic acid and potash, were all at his disposal.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding after mature consideration decided to manufacture a very simple battery resembling as nearly as possible that invented by Becquerel in 1820 and in which zinc only is employed The other substances azotic acid and potash were all at his disposal

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The way in which the battery was composed was as follows, and the results were to be attained by the reaction of acid and potash on each other. A number of glass bottles were made and filled with azotic acid. The engineer corked them by means of a stopper through which passed a glass tube, bored at its lower extremity, and intended to be plunged into the acid by means of a clay stopper secured by a rag. Into this tube, through its upper extremity, he poured a solution of potash, previously obtained by burning and reducing to ashes various plants, and in this way the acid and potash could act on each other through the clay.
children.prevalue: The way in which the battery was composed was as follows and the results were to be attained by the reaction of acid and potash on each other A number of glass bottles were made and filled with azotic acid The engineer corked them by means of a stopper through which passed a glass tube bored at its lower extremity and intended to be plunged into the acid by means of a clay stopper secured by a rag Into this tube through its upper extremity he poured a solution of potash previously obtained by burning and reducing to ashes various plants and in this way the acid and potash could act on each other through the clay

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Cyrus Harding then took two slips of zinc, one of which was plunged into azotic acid, the other into a solution of potash. A current was immediately produced, which was transmitted from the slip of zinc in the bottle to that in the tube, and the two slips having been connected by a metallic wire the slip in the tube became the positive pole, and that in the bottle the negative pole of the apparatus. Each bottle, therefore, produced as many currents as united would be sufficient to produce all the phenomena of the electric telegraph. Such was the ingenious and very simple apparatus constructed by Cyrus Harding, an apparatus which would allow them to establish a telegraphic communication between Granite House and the corral.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding then took two slips of zinc one of which was plunged into azotic acid the other into a solution of potash A current was immediately produced which was transmitted from the slip of zinc in the bottle to that in the tube and the two slips having been connected by a metallic wire the slip in the tube became the positive pole and that in the bottle the negative pole of the apparatus Each bottle therefore produced as many currents as united would be sufficient to produce all the phenomena of the electric telegraph Such was the ingenious and very simple apparatus constructed by Cyrus Harding an apparatus which would allow them to establish a telegraphic communication between Granite House and the corral

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: On the 6th of February was commenced the planting along the road to the corral, of posts furnished with glass insulators, and intended to support the wire. A few days after, the wire was extended, ready to produce the electric current at a rate of twenty thousand miles a second.
children.prevalue: On the 6th of February was commenced the planting along the road to the corral of posts furnished with glass insulators and intended to support the wire A few days after the wire was extended ready to produce the electric current at a rate of twenty thousand miles a second

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Two batteries had been manufactured, one for Granite House, the other for the corral; for if it was necessary the corral should be able to communicate with Granite House it might also be useful that Granite House should be able to communicate with the corral.
children.prevalue: Two batteries had been manufactured one for Granite House the other for the corral for if it was necessary the corral should be able to communicate with Granite House it might also be useful that Granite House should be able to communicate with the corral

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: As to the receiver and manipulator, they were very simple. At the two stations the wire was wound round a magnet, that is to say, round a piece of soft iron surrounded with a wire. The communication was thus established between the two poles; the current, starting from the positive pole, traversed the wire, passed through the magnet which was temporarily magnetized, and returned through the earth to the negative pole. If the current was interrupted, the magnet immediately became unmagnetized. It was sufficient to place a plate of soft iron before the magnet, which, attracted during the passage of the current, would fall back when the current was interrupted. This movement of the plate thus obtained, Harding could easily fasten to it a needle arranged on a dial, bearing the letters of the alphabet, and in this way communicate from one station to the other.
children.prevalue: As to the receiver and manipulator they were very simple At the two stations the wire was wound round a magnet that is to say round a piece of soft iron surrounded with a wire The communication was thus established between the two poles the current starting from the positive pole traversed the wire passed through the magnet which was temporarily magnetized and returned through the earth to the negative pole If the current was interrupted the magnet immediately became unmagnetized It was sufficient to place a plate of soft iron before the magnet which attracted during the passage of the current would fall back when the current was interrupted This movement of the plate thus obtained Harding could easily fasten to it a needle arranged on a dial bearing the letters of the alphabet and in this way communicate from one station to the other

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: All was completely arranged by the 12th of February. On this day, Harding, having sent the current through the wire, asked if all was going on well at the corral, and received in a few moments a satisfactory reply from Ayrton. Pencroft was wild with joy, and every morning and evening he sent a telegram to the corral, which always received an answer.
children.prevalue: All was completely arranged by the 12th of February On this day Harding having sent the current through the wire asked if all was going on well at the corral and received in a few moments a satisfactory reply from Ayrton Pencroft was wild with joy and every morning and evening he sent a telegram to the corral which always received an answer

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: This mode of communication presented two very real advantages: firstly, because it enabled them to ascertain that Ayrton was at the corral; and secondly, that he was thus not left completely isolated. Besides, Cyrus Harding never allowed a week to pass without going to see him, and Ayrton came from time to time to Granite House, where he always found a cordial welcome.
children.prevalue: This mode of communication presented two very real advantages firstly because it enabled them to ascertain that Ayrton was at the corral and secondly that he was thus not left completely isolated Besides Cyrus Harding never allowed a week to pass without going to see him and Ayrton came from time to time to Granite House where he always found a cordial welcome

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The fine season passed away in the midst of the usual work. The resources of the colony, particularly in vegetables and corn, increased from day to day, and the plants brought from Tabor Island had succeeded perfectly.
children.prevalue: The fine season passed away in the midst of the usual work The resources of the colony particularly in vegetables and corn increased from day to day and the plants brought from Tabor Island had succeeded perfectly

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The plateau of Prospect Heights presented an encouraging aspect. The fourth harvest had been admirable and it may be supposed that no one thought of counting whether the four hundred thousand millions of grains duly appeared in the crop. However, Pencroft had thought of doing so, but Cyrus Harding having told him that even if he managed to count three hundred grains a minute, or nine thousand an hour, it would take him nearly five thousand five-hundred years to finish his task, the honest sailor considered it best to give up the idea.
children.prevalue: The plateau of Prospect Heights presented an encouraging aspect The fourth harvest had been admirable and it may be supposed that no one thought of counting whether the four hundred thousand millions of grains duly appeared in the crop However Pencroft had thought of doing so but Cyrus Harding having told him that even if he managed to count three hundred grains a minute or nine thousand an hour it would take him nearly five thousand five hundred years to finish his task the honest sailor considered it best to give up the idea

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The weather was splendid, the temperature very warm in the day time, but in the evening the sea-breezes tempered the heat of the atmosphere and procured cool nights for the inhabitants of Granite House. There were, however, a few storms, which, although they were not of long duration, swept over Lincoln Island with extraordinary fury. The lightning blazed and the thunder continued to roll for some hours.
children.prevalue: The weather was splendid the temperature very warm in the day time but in the evening the sea breezes tempered the heat of the atmosphere and procured cool nights for the inhabitants of Granite House There were however a few storms which although they were not of long duration swept over Lincoln Island with extraordinary fury The lightning blazed and the thunder continued to roll for some hours

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: At this period the little colony was extremely prosperous.
children.prevalue: At this period the little colony was extremely prosperous

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The tenants of the poultry-yard swarmed, and they lived on the surplus, but it became necessary to reduce the population to a more moderate number. The pigs had already produced young, and it may be understood that their care for these animals absorbed a great part of Neb and Pencroft's time. The onagers, who had two pretty colts, were most often mounted by Gideon Spilett and Herbert, who had become an excellent rider under the reporter's instruction, and they also harnessed them to the cart either for carrying wood and coal to Granite House, or different mineral productions required by the engineer.
children.prevalue: The tenants of the poultry yard swarmed and they lived on the surplus but it became necessary to reduce the population to a more moderate number The pigs had already produced young and it may be understood that their care for these animals absorbed a great part of Neb and Pencroft s time The onagers who had two pretty colts were most often mounted by Gideon Spilett and Herbert who had become an excellent rider under the reporter s instruction and they also harnessed them to the cart either for carrying wood and coal to Granite House or different mineral productions required by the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Several expeditions were made about this time into the depths of the Far West Forests. The explorers could venture there without having anything to fear from the heat, for the sun's rays scarcely penetrated through the thick foliage spreading above their heads. They thus visited all the left bank of the Mercy, along which ran the road from the corral to the mouth of Falls River.
children.prevalue: Several expeditions were made about this time into the depths of the Far West Forests The explorers could venture there without having anything to fear from the heat for the sun s rays scarcely penetrated through the thick foliage spreading above their heads They thus visited all the left bank of the Mercy along which ran the road from the corral to the mouth of Falls River

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But in these excursions the settlers took care to be well armed, for they met with savage wild boars, with which they often had a tussle. They also, during this season, made fierce war against the jaguars. Gideon Spilett had vowed a special hatred against them, and his pupil Herbert seconded him well. Armed as they were, they no longer feared to meet one of those beasts. Herbert's courage was superb, and the reporter's sang-froid astonishing. Already twenty magnificent skins ornamented the dining-room of Granite House, and if this continued, the jaguar race would soon be extinct in the island, the object aimed at by the hunters.
children.prevalue: But in these excursions the settlers took care to be well armed for they met with savage wild boars with which they often had a tussle They also during this season made fierce war against the jaguars Gideon Spilett had vowed a special hatred against them and his pupil Herbert seconded him well Armed as they were they no longer feared to meet one of those beasts Herbert s courage was superb and the reporter s sang froid astonishing Already twenty magnificent skins ornamented the dining room of Granite House and if this continued the jaguar race would soon be extinct in the island the object aimed at by the hunters

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The engineer sometimes took part in the expeditions made to the unknown parts of the island, which he surveyed with great attention. It was for other traces than those of animals that he searched the thickets of the vast forest, but nothing suspicious ever appeared. Neither Top nor Jup, who accompanied him, ever betrayed by their behavior that there was anything strange there, and yet more than once again the dog barked at the mouth of the well, which the engineer had before explored without result.
children.prevalue: The engineer sometimes took part in the expeditions made to the unknown parts of the island which he surveyed with great attention It was for other traces than those of animals that he searched the thickets of the vast forest but nothing suspicious ever appeared Neither Top nor Jup who accompanied him ever betrayed by their behavior that there was anything strange there and yet more than once again the dog barked at the mouth of the well which the engineer had before explored without result

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: At this time Gideon Spilett, aided by Herbert, took several views of the most picturesque parts of the island, by means of the photographic apparatus found in the cases, and of which they had not as yet made any use.
children.prevalue: At this time Gideon Spilett aided by Herbert took several views of the most picturesque parts of the island by means of the photographic apparatus found in the cases and of which they had not as yet made any use

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: This apparatus, provided with a powerful object-glass, was very complete. Substances necessary for the photographic reproduction, collodion for preparing the glass plate, nitrate of silver to render it sensitive, hyposulfate of soda to fix the prints obtained, chloride of ammonium in which to soak the paper destined to give the positive proof, acetate of soda and chloride of gold in which to immerse the paper, nothing was wanting. Even the papers were there, all prepared, and before laying in the printing-frame upon the negatives, it was sufficient to soak them for a few minutes in the solution of nitrate of silver.
children.prevalue: This apparatus provided with a powerful object glass was very complete Substances necessary for the photographic reproduction collodion for preparing the glass plate nitrate of silver to render it sensitive hyposulfate of soda to fix the prints obtained chloride of ammonium in which to soak the paper destined to give the positive proof acetate of soda and chloride of gold in which to immerse the paper nothing was wanting Even the papers were there all prepared and before laying in the printing frame upon the negatives it was sufficient to soak them for a few minutes in the solution of nitrate of silver

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The reporter and his assistant became in a short time very skilful operators, and they obtained fine views of the country, such as the island, taken from Prospect Heights with Mount Franklin in the distance, the mouth of the Mercy, so picturesquely framed in high rocks, the glade and the corral, with the spurs of the mountain in the background, the curious development of Claw Cape, Flotsam Point, etc.
children.prevalue: The reporter and his assistant became in a short time very skilful operators and they obtained fine views of the country such as the island taken from Prospect Heights with Mount Franklin in the distance the mouth of the Mercy so picturesquely framed in high rocks the glade and the corral with the spurs of the mountain in the background the curious development of Claw Cape Flotsam Point etc

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Nor did the photographers forget to take the portraits of all the inhabitants of the island, leaving out no one.
children.prevalue: Nor did the photographers forget to take the portraits of all the inhabitants of the island leaving out no one

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: It multiplies us, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It multiplies us said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And the sailor was enchanted to see his own countenance, faithfully reproduced, ornamenting the walls of Granite House, and he stopped as willingly before this exhibition as he would have done before the richest shop-windows in Broadway.
children.prevalue: And the sailor was enchanted to see his own countenance faithfully reproduced ornamenting the walls of Granite House and he stopped as willingly before this exhibition as he would have done before the richest shop windows in Broadway

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: But it must be acknowledged that the most successful portrait was incontestably that of Master Jup. Master Jup had sat with a gravity not to be described, and his portrait was lifelike!
children.prevalue: But it must be acknowledged that the most successful portrait was incontestably that of Master Jup Master Jup had sat with a gravity not to be described and his portrait was lifelike

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: He looks as if he was just going to grin! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: He looks as if he was just going to grin exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And if Master Jup had not been satisfied, he would have been very difficult to please; but he was quite contented and contemplated his own countenance with a sentimental air which expressed some small amount of conceit.
children.prevalue: And if Master Jup had not been satisfied he would have been very difficult to please but he was quite contented and contemplated his own countenance with a sentimental air which expressed some small amount of conceit

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The summer heat ended with the month of March. The weather was sometimes rainy, but still warm. The month of March, which corresponds to the September of northern latitudes, was not so fine as might have been hoped. Perhaps it announced an early and rigorous winter.
children.prevalue: The summer heat ended with the month of March The weather was sometimes rainy but still warm The month of March which corresponds to the September of northern latitudes was not so fine as might have been hoped Perhaps it announced an early and rigorous winter

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It might have been supposed one morning--the 21 st--that the first snow had already made its appearance. In fact Herbert looking early from one of the windows of Granite House, exclaimed,--
children.prevalue: It might have been supposed one morning the 21 st that the first snow had already made its appearance In fact Herbert looking early from one of the windows of Granite House exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Hallo! the islet is covered with snow!
children.prevalue: Hallo the islet is covered with snow

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Snow at this time? answered the reporter, joining the boy.
children.prevalue: Snow at this time answered the reporter joining the boy

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Their companions were soon beside them, but could only ascertain one thing, that not only the islet but all the beach below Granite House was covered with one uniform sheet of white.
children.prevalue: Their companions were soon beside them but could only ascertain one thing that not only the islet but all the beach below Granite House was covered with one uniform sheet of white

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: It must be snow! said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It must be snow said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Or rather it's very like it! replied Neb.
children.prevalue: Or rather it s very like it replied Neb

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But the thermometer marks fifty-eight degrees! observed Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: But the thermometer marks fifty eight degrees observed Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Cyrus Harding gazed at the sheet of white without saying anything, for he really did not know how to explain this phenomenon, at this time of year and in such a temperature.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding gazed at the sheet of white without saying anything for he really did not know how to explain this phenomenon at this time of year and in such a temperature

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: By Jove! exclaimed Pencroft, all our plants will be frozen!
children.prevalue: By Jove exclaimed Pencroft all our plants will be frozen

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: And the sailor was about to descend, when he was preceded by the nimble Jup, who slid down to the sand.
children.prevalue: And the sailor was about to descend when he was preceded by the nimble Jup who slid down to the sand

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: But the orang had not touched the ground, when the snowy sheet arose and dispersed in the air in such innumerable flakes that the light of the sun was obscured for some minutes.
children.prevalue: But the orang had not touched the ground when the snowy sheet arose and dispersed in the air in such innumerable flakes that the light of the sun was obscured for some minutes

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Birds! cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: Birds cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: They were indeed swarms of sea-birds, with dazzling white plumage. They had perched by thousands on the islet and on the shore, and they disappeared in the distance, leaving the colonists amazed as if they had been present at some transformation scene, in which summer succeeded winter at the touch of a fairy's wand. Unfortunately the change had been so sudden, that neither the reporter nor the lad had been able to bring down one of these birds, of which they could not recognize the species.
children.prevalue: They were indeed swarms of sea birds with dazzling white plumage They had perched by thousands on the islet and on the shore and they disappeared in the distance leaving the colonists amazed as if they had been present at some transformation scene in which summer succeeded winter at the touch of a fairy s wand Unfortunately the change had been so sudden that neither the reporter nor the lad had been able to bring down one of these birds of which they could not recognize the species

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: A few days after came the 26th of March, the day on which, two years before, the castaways from the air had been thrown upon Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: A few days after came the 26th of March the day on which two years before the castaways from the air had been thrown upon Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Two years already! and for two years the colonists had had no communication with their fellow-creatures! They were without news from the civilized world, lost on this island, as completely as if they had been on the most minute star of the celestial hemisphere!
children.prevalue: Two years already and for two years the colonists had had no communication with their fellow creatures They were without news from the civilized world lost on this island as completely as if they had been on the most minute star of the celestial hemisphere

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What was now happening in their country? The picture of their native land was always before their eyes, the land torn by civil war at the time they left it, and which the Southern rebellion was perhaps still staining with blood! It was a great sorrow to them, and they often talked together of these things, without ever doubting however that the cause of the North must triumph, for the honor of the American Confederation.
children.prevalue: What was now happening in their country The picture of their native land was always before their eyes the land torn by civil war at the time they left it and which the Southern rebellion was perhaps still staining with blood It was a great sorrow to them and they often talked together of these things without ever doubting however that the cause of the North must triumph for the honor of the American Confederation

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: During these two years not a vessel had passed in sight of the island; or, at least, not a sail had been seen. It was evident that Lincoln Island was out of the usual track, and also that it was unknown,--as was besides proved by the maps,--for though there was no port, vessels might have visited it for the purpose of renewing their store of water. But the surrounding ocean was deserted as far as the eye could reach, and the colonists must rely on themselves for regaining their native land.
children.prevalue: During these two years not a vessel had passed in sight of the island or at least not a sail had been seen It was evident that Lincoln Island was out of the usual track and also that it was unknown as was besides proved by the maps for though there was no port vessels might have visited it for the purpose of renewing their store of water But the surrounding ocean was deserted as far as the eye could reach and the colonists must rely on themselves for regaining their native land

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: However, one chance of rescue existed, and this chance was discussed one day on the first week of April, when the colonists were gathered together in the dining-room of Granite House.
children.prevalue: However one chance of rescue existed and this chance was discussed one day on the first week of April when the colonists were gathered together in the dining room of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: They had been talking of America, of their native country, which they had so little hope of ever seeing again.
children.prevalue: They had been talking of America of their native country which they had so little hope of ever seeing again

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Decidedly we have only one way, said Spilett, one single way for leaving Lincoln Island, and that is, to build a vessel large enough to sail several hundred miles. It appears to me, that when one has built a boat it is just as easy to build a ship!
children.prevalue: Decidedly we have only one way said Spilett one single way for leaving Lincoln Island and that is to build a vessel large enough to sail several hundred miles It appears to me that when one has built a boat it is just as easy to build a ship

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And in which we might go to the Pomoutous, added Herbert, just as easily as we went to Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: And in which we might go to the Pomoutous added Herbert just as easily as we went to Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I do not say no, replied Pencroft, who had always the casting vote in maritime questions; I do not say no, although it is not exactly the same thing to make a long as a short voyage! If our little craft had been caught in any heavy gale of wind during the voyage to Tabor Island, we should have known that land was at no great distance either way; but twelve hundred miles is a pretty long way, and the nearest land is at least that distance!
children.prevalue: I do not say no replied Pencroft who had always the casting vote in maritime questions I do not say no although it is not exactly the same thing to make a long as a short voyage If our little craft had been caught in any heavy gale of wind during the voyage to Tabor Island we should have known that land was at no great distance either way but twelve hundred miles is a pretty long way and the nearest land is at least that distance

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Would you not, in that case, Pencroft, attempt the adventure? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: Would you not in that case Pencroft attempt the adventure asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I will attempt anything that is desired, Mr. Spilett, answered the sailor, and you know well that I am not a man to flinch!
children.prevalue: I will attempt anything that is desired Mr Spilett answered the sailor and you know well that I am not a man to flinch

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Remember, besides, that we number another sailor amongst us now, remarked Neb.
children.prevalue: Remember besides that we number another sailor amongst us now remarked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Who is that? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Who is that asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Ayrton.
children.prevalue: Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: If he will consent to come, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: If he will consent to come said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Nonsense! returned the reporter; do you think that if Lord Glenarvan's yacht had appeared at Tabor Island, while he was still living there, Ayrton would have refused to depart?
children.prevalue: Nonsense returned the reporter do you think that if Lord Glenarvan s yacht had appeared at Tabor Island while he was still living there Ayrton would have refused to depart

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You forget, my friends, then said Cyrus Harding, that Ayrton was not in possession of his reason during the last years of his stay there. But that is not the question. The point is to know if we may count among our chances of being rescued, the return of the Scotch vessel. Now, Lord Glenarvan promised Ayrton that he would return to take him off from Tabor Island when he considered that his crimes were expiated, and I believe that he will return.
children.prevalue: You forget my friends then said Cyrus Harding that Ayrton was not in possession of his reason during the last years of his stay there But that is not the question The point is to know if we may count among our chances of being rescued the return of the Scotch vessel Now Lord Glenarvan promised Ayrton that he would return to take him off from Tabor Island when he considered that his crimes were expiated and I believe that he will return

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes, said the reporter, and I will add that he will return soon, for it is twelve years since Ayrton was abandoned.
children.prevalue: Yes said the reporter and I will add that he will return soon for it is twelve years since Ayrton was abandoned

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well! answered Pencroft, I agree with you that the nobleman will return, and soon too. But where will he touch? At Tabor Island, and not at Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: Well answered Pencroft I agree with you that the nobleman will return and soon too But where will he touch At Tabor Island and not at Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: That is the more certain, replied Herbert, as Lincoln Island is not even marked on the map.
children.prevalue: That is the more certain replied Herbert as Lincoln Island is not even marked on the map

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Therefore, my friends, said the engineer, we ought to take the necessary precautions for making our presence and that of Ayrton on Lincoln Island known at Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: Therefore my friends said the engineer we ought to take the necessary precautions for making our presence and that of Ayrton on Lincoln Island known at Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Certainly, answered the reporter, and nothing is easier than to place in the hut, which was Captain Grant's and Ayrton's dwelling, a notice which Lord Glenarvan and his crew cannot help finding, giving the position of our island.
children.prevalue: Certainly answered the reporter and nothing is easier than to place in the hut which was Captain Grant s and Ayrton s dwelling a notice which Lord Glenarvan and his crew cannot help finding giving the position of our island

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It is a pity, remarked the sailor, that we forgot to take that precaution on our first visit to Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: It is a pity remarked the sailor that we forgot to take that precaution on our first visit to Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And why should we have done it? asked Herbert. At that time we did not know Ayrton's history; we did not know that any one was likely to come some day to fetch him, and when we did know his history, the season was too advanced to allow us to return then to Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: And why should we have done it asked Herbert At that time we did not know Ayrton s history we did not know that any one was likely to come some day to fetch him and when we did know his history the season was too advanced to allow us to return then to Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yes, replied Harding, it was too late, and we must put off the voyage until next spring.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Harding it was too late and we must put off the voyage until next spring

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But suppose the Scotch yacht comes before that, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: But suppose the Scotch yacht comes before that said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: That is not probable, replied the engineer, for Lord Glenarvan would not choose the winter season to venture into these seas. Either he has already returned to Tabor Island, since Ayrton has been with us, that is to say, during the last five months and has left again; or he will not come till later, and it will be time enough in the first fine October days to go to Tabor Island, and leave a notice there.
children.prevalue: That is not probable replied the engineer for Lord Glenarvan would not choose the winter season to venture into these seas Either he has already returned to Tabor Island since Ayrton has been with us that is to say during the last five months and has left again or he will not come till later and it will be time enough in the first fine October days to go to Tabor Island and leave a notice there

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: We must allow, said Neb, that it will be very unfortunate if the 'Duncan' has returned to these parts only a few months ago!
children.prevalue: We must allow said Neb that it will be very unfortunate if the Duncan has returned to these parts only a few months ago

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I hope that it is not so, replied Cyrus Harding, and that Heaven has not deprived us of the best chance which remains to us.
children.prevalue: I hope that it is not so replied Cyrus Harding and that Heaven has not deprived us of the best chance which remains to us

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I think, observed the reporter, that at any rate we shall know what we have to depend on when we have been to Tabor Island, for if the yacht has returned there, they will necessarily have left some traces of their visit.
children.prevalue: I think observed the reporter that at any rate we shall know what we have to depend on when we have been to Tabor Island for if the yacht has returned there they will necessarily have left some traces of their visit

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: That is evident, answered the engineer. So then, my friends, since we have this chance of returning to our country, we must wait patiently, and if it is taken from us we shall see what will be best to do.
children.prevalue: That is evident answered the engineer So then my friends since we have this chance of returning to our country we must wait patiently and if it is taken from us we shall see what will be best to do

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: At any rate, remarked Pencroft, it is well understood that if we do leave Lincoln Island, it will not be because we were uncomfortable there!
children.prevalue: At any rate remarked Pencroft it is well understood that if we do leave Lincoln Island it will not be because we were uncomfortable there

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: No, Pencroft, replied the engineer, it will be because we are far from all that a man holds dearest in the world, his family, his friends, his native land!
children.prevalue: No Pencroft replied the engineer it will be because we are far from all that a man holds dearest in the world his family his friends his native land

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Matters being thus decided, the building of a vessel large enough to sail either to the Archipelagoes in the north, or to New Zealand in the west, was no longer talked of, and they busied themselves in their accustomed occupations, with a view to wintering a third time in Granite House.
children.prevalue: Matters being thus decided the building of a vessel large enough to sail either to the Archipelagoes in the north or to New Zealand in the west was no longer talked of and they busied themselves in their accustomed occupations with a view to wintering a third time in Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: However, it was agreed that before the stormy weather came on, their little vessel should be employed in making a voyage round the island. A complete survey of the coast had not yet been made, and the colonists had but an imperfect idea of the shore to the west and north, from the mouth of Falls River to the Mandible Capes, as well as of the narrow bay between them, which opened like a shark's jaws.
children.prevalue: However it was agreed that before the stormy weather came on their little vessel should be employed in making a voyage round the island A complete survey of the coast had not yet been made and the colonists had but an imperfect idea of the shore to the west and north from the mouth of Falls River to the Mandible Capes as well as of the narrow bay between them which opened like a shark s jaws

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The plan of this excursion was proposed by Pencroft, and Cyrus Harding fully acquiesced in it, for he himself wished to see this part of his domain.
children.prevalue: The plan of this excursion was proposed by Pencroft and Cyrus Harding fully acquiesced in it for he himself wished to see this part of his domain

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The weather was variable, but the barometer did not fluctuate by sudden movements, and they could therefore count on tolerable weather. However, during the first week of April, after a sudden barometrical fall, a renewed rise was marked by a heavy gale of wind, lasting five or six days; then the needle of the instrument remained stationary at a height of twenty-nine inches and nine-tenths, and the weather appeared propitious for an excursion.
children.prevalue: The weather was variable but the barometer did not fluctuate by sudden movements and they could therefore count on tolerable weather However during the first week of April after a sudden barometrical fall a renewed rise was marked by a heavy gale of wind lasting five or six days then the needle of the instrument remained stationary at a height of twenty nine inches and nine tenths and the weather appeared propitious for an excursion

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The departure was fixed for the 16th of April, and the Bonadventure, anchored in Port Balloon, was provisioned for a voyage which might be of some duration.
children.prevalue: The departure was fixed for the 16th of April and the Bonadventure anchored in Port Balloon was provisioned for a voyage which might be of some duration

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Cyrus Harding informed Ayrton of the projected expedition, and proposed that he should take part in it, but Ayrton preferring to remain on shore, it was decided that he should come to Granite House during the absence of his companions. Master Jup was ordered to keep him company, and made no remonstrance.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding informed Ayrton of the projected expedition and proposed that he should take part in it but Ayrton preferring to remain on shore it was decided that he should come to Granite House during the absence of his companions Master Jup was ordered to keep him company and made no remonstrance

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: On the morning of the 16th of April all the colonists, including Top, embarked. A fine breeze blew from the south-west, and the Bonadventure tacked on leaving Port Balloon so as to reach Reptile End. Of the ninety miles which the perimeter of the island measured, twenty included the south coast between the port and the promontory. The wind being right ahead it was necessary to hug the shore.
children.prevalue: On the morning of the 16th of April all the colonists including Top embarked A fine breeze blew from the south west and the Bonadventure tacked on leaving Port Balloon so as to reach Reptile End Of the ninety miles which the perimeter of the island measured twenty included the south coast between the port and the promontory The wind being right ahead it was necessary to hug the shore

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It took the whole day to reach the promontory, for the vessel on leaving port had only two hours of ebb tide and had therefore to make way for six hours against the flood. It was nightfall before the promontory was doubled.
children.prevalue: It took the whole day to reach the promontory for the vessel on leaving port had only two hours of ebb tide and had therefore to make way for six hours against the flood It was nightfall before the promontory was doubled

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The sailor then proposed to the engineer that they should continue sailing slowly with two reefs in the sail. But Harding preferred to anchor a few cable-lengths from the shore, so as to survey that part of the coast during the day. It was agreed also that as they were anxious for a minute exploration of the coast they should not sail during the night, but would always, when the weather permitted it, be at anchor near the shore.
children.prevalue: The sailor then proposed to the engineer that they should continue sailing slowly with two reefs in the sail But Harding preferred to anchor a few cable lengths from the shore so as to survey that part of the coast during the day It was agreed also that as they were anxious for a minute exploration of the coast they should not sail during the night but would always when the weather permitted it be at anchor near the shore

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The night was passed under the promontory, and the wind having fallen, nothing disturbed the silence. The passengers, with the exception of the sailor, scarcely slept as well on board the Bonadventure as they would have done in their rooms at Granite House, but they did sleep however.
