Pencroft set sail at break of day, and by going on the larboard tack they could keep close to the shore.
children.prevalue: The night was passed under the promontory and the wind having fallen nothing disturbed the silence The passengers with the exception of the sailor scarcely slept as well on board the Bonadventure as they would have done in their rooms at Granite House but they did sleep however Pencroft set sail at break of day and by going on the larboard tack they could keep close to the shore

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The colonists knew this beautiful wooded coast, since they had already explored it on foot, and yet it again excited their admiration. They coasted along as close in as possible, so as to notice everything, avoiding always the trunks of trees which floated here and there. Several times also they anchored, and Gideon Spilett took photographs of the superb scenery.
children.prevalue: The colonists knew this beautiful wooded coast since they had already explored it on foot and yet it again excited their admiration They coasted along as close in as possible so as to notice everything avoiding always the trunks of trees which floated here and there Several times also they anchored and Gideon Spilett took photographs of the superb scenery

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: About noon the Bonadventure arrived at the mouth of Falls River. Beyond, on the left bank, a few scattered trees appeared, and three miles further even these dwindled into solitary groups among the western spurs of the mountain, whose arid ridge sloped down to the shore.
children.prevalue: About noon the Bonadventure arrived at the mouth of Falls River Beyond on the left bank a few scattered trees appeared and three miles further even these dwindled into solitary groups among the western spurs of the mountain whose arid ridge sloped down to the shore

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: What a contrast between the northern and southern part of the coast! In proportion as one was woody and fertile so was the other rugged and barren! It might have been designated as one of those iron coasts, as they are called in some countries, and its wild confusion appeared to indicate that a sudden crystallization had been produced in the yet liquid basalt of some distant geological sea. These stupendous masses would have terrified the settlers if they had been cast at first on this part of the island! They had not been able to perceive the sinister aspect of this shore from the summit of Mount Franklin, for they overlooked it from too great a height, but viewed from the sea it presented a wild appearance which could not perhaps be equaled in any corner of the globe.
children.prevalue: What a contrast between the northern and southern part of the coast In proportion as one was woody and fertile so was the other rugged and barren It might have been designated as one of those iron coasts as they are called in some countries and its wild confusion appeared to indicate that a sudden crystallization had been produced in the yet liquid basalt of some distant geological sea These stupendous masses would have terrified the settlers if they had been cast at first on this part of the island They had not been able to perceive the sinister aspect of this shore from the summit of Mount Franklin for they overlooked it from too great a height but viewed from the sea it presented a wild appearance which could not perhaps be equaled in any corner of the globe

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The Bonadventure sailed along this coast for the distance of half a mile. It was easy to see that it was composed of blocks of all sizes, from twenty to three hundred feet in height, and of all shapes, round like towers, prismatic like steeples, pyramidal like obelisks, conical like factory chimneys. An iceberg of the Polar seas could not have been more capricious in its terrible sublimity! Here, bridges were thrown from one rock to another; there, arches like those of a wave, into the depths of which the eye could not penetrate; in one place, large vaulted excavations presented a monumental aspect; in another, a crowd of columns, spires, and arches, such as no Gothic cathedral ever possessed. Every caprice of nature, still more varied than those of the imagination, appeared on this grand coast, which extended over a length of eight or nine miles.
children.prevalue: The Bonadventure sailed along this coast for the distance of half a mile It was easy to see that it was composed of blocks of all sizes from twenty to three hundred feet in height and of all shapes round like towers prismatic like steeples pyramidal like obelisks conical like factory chimneys An iceberg of the Polar seas could not have been more capricious in its terrible sublimity Here bridges were thrown from one rock to another there arches like those of a wave into the depths of which the eye could not penetrate in one place large vaulted excavations presented a monumental aspect in another a crowd of columns spires and arches such as no Gothic cathedral ever possessed Every caprice of nature still more varied than those of the imagination appeared on this grand coast which extended over a length of eight or nine miles

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions gazed, with a feeling of surprise bordering on stupefaction. But, although they remained silent, Top, not being troubled with feelings of this sort, uttered barks which were repeated by the thousand echoes of the basaltic cliff. The engineer even observed that these barks had something strange in them, like those which the dog had uttered at the mouth of the well in Granite House.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions gazed with a feeling of surprise bordering on stupefaction But although they remained silent Top not being troubled with feelings of this sort uttered barks which were repeated by the thousand echoes of the basaltic cliff The engineer even observed that these barks had something strange in them like those which the dog had uttered at the mouth of the well in Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Let us go close in, said he.
children.prevalue: Let us go close in said he

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And the Bonadventure sailed as near as possible to the rocky shore. Perhaps some cave, which it would be advisable to explore, existed there? But Harding saw nothing, not a cavern, not a cleft which could serve as a retreat to any being whatever, for the foot of the cliff was washed by the surf. Soon Top's barks ceased, and the vessel continued her course at a few cables-length from the coast.
children.prevalue: And the Bonadventure sailed as near as possible to the rocky shore Perhaps some cave which it would be advisable to explore existed there But Harding saw nothing not a cavern not a cleft which could serve as a retreat to any being whatever for the foot of the cliff was washed by the surf Soon Top s barks ceased and the vessel continued her course at a few cables length from the coast

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: In the northwest part of the island the shore became again flat and sandy. A few trees here and there rose above a low, marshy ground, which the colonists had already surveyed, and in violent contrast to the other desert shore, life was again manifested by the presence of myriads of water-fowl. That evening the Bonadventure anchored in a small bay to the north of the island, near the land, such was the depth of water there. The night passed quietly, for the breeze died away with the last light of day, and only rose again with the first streaks of dawn.
children.prevalue: In the northwest part of the island the shore became again flat and sandy A few trees here and there rose above a low marshy ground which the colonists had already surveyed and in violent contrast to the other desert shore life was again manifested by the presence of myriads of water fowl That evening the Bonadventure anchored in a small bay to the north of the island near the land such was the depth of water there The night passed quietly for the breeze died away with the last light of day and only rose again with the first streaks of dawn

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: As it was easy to land, the usual hunters of the colony, that is to say, Herbert and Gideon Spilett, went for a ramble of two hours or so, and returned with several strings of wild duck and snipe. Top had done wonders, and not a bird had been lost, thanks to his zeal and cleverness.
children.prevalue: As it was easy to land the usual hunters of the colony that is to say Herbert and Gideon Spilett went for a ramble of two hours or so and returned with several strings of wild duck and snipe Top had done wonders and not a bird had been lost thanks to his zeal and cleverness

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: At eight o'clock in the morning the Bonadventure set sail, and ran rapidly towards North Mandible Cape, for the wind was right astern and freshening rapidly.
children.prevalue: At eight o clock in the morning the Bonadventure set sail and ran rapidly towards North Mandible Cape for the wind was right astern and freshening rapidly

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: However, observed Pencroft, I should not be surprised if a gale came up from the west. Yesterday the sun set in a very red-looking horizon, and now, this morning, those mares-tails don't forbode anything good.
children.prevalue: However observed Pencroft I should not be surprised if a gale came up from the west Yesterday the sun set in a very red looking horizon and now this morning those mares tails don t forbode anything good

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: These mares-tails are cirrus clouds, scattered in the zenith, their height from the sea being less than five thousand feet. They look like light pieces of cotton wool, and their presence usually announces some sudden change in the weather.
children.prevalue: These mares tails are cirrus clouds scattered in the zenith their height from the sea being less than five thousand feet They look like light pieces of cotton wool and their presence usually announces some sudden change in the weather

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Well, said Harding, let us carry as much sail as possible, and run for shelter into Shark Gulf. I think that the 'Bonadventure' will be safe there.
children.prevalue: Well said Harding let us carry as much sail as possible and run for shelter into Shark Gulf I think that the Bonadventure will be safe there

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Perfectly, replied Pencroft, and besides, the north coast is merely sand, very uninteresting to look at.
children.prevalue: Perfectly replied Pencroft and besides the north coast is merely sand very uninteresting to look at

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I shall not be sorry, resumed the engineer, to pass not only to-night but to-morrow in that bay, which is worth being carefully explored.
children.prevalue: I shall not be sorry resumed the engineer to pass not only to night but to morrow in that bay which is worth being carefully explored

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I think that we shall be obliged to do so, whether we like it or not, answered Pencroft, for the sky looks very threatening towards the west. Dirty weather is coming on!
children.prevalue: I think that we shall be obliged to do so whether we like it or not answered Pencroft for the sky looks very threatening towards the west Dirty weather is coming on

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At any rate we have a favorable wind for reaching Cape Mandible, observed the reporter.
children.prevalue: At any rate we have a favorable wind for reaching Cape Mandible observed the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: A very fine wind, replied the sailor; but we must tack to enter the gulf, and I should like to see my way clear in these unknown quarters.
children.prevalue: A very fine wind replied the sailor but we must tack to enter the gulf and I should like to see my way clear in these unknown quarters

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Quarters which appear to be filled with rocks, added Herbert, if we judge by what we saw on the south coast of Shark Gulf.
children.prevalue: Quarters which appear to be filled with rocks added Herbert if we judge by what we saw on the south coast of Shark Gulf

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Pencroft, said Cyrus Harding, do as you think best, we will leave it to you.
children.prevalue: Pencroft said Cyrus Harding do as you think best we will leave it to you

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Don't make your mind uneasy, captain, replied the sailor, I shall not expose myself needlessly! I would rather a knife were run into my ribs than a sharp rock into those of my 'Bonadventure!'
children.prevalue: Don t make your mind uneasy captain replied the sailor I shall not expose myself needlessly I would rather a knife were run into my ribs than a sharp rock into those of my Bonadventure

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: That which Pencroft called ribs was the part of his vessel under water, and he valued it more than his own skin.
children.prevalue: That which Pencroft called ribs was the part of his vessel under water and he valued it more than his own skin

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: What o'clock is it? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: What o clock is it asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Ten o'clock, replied Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Ten o clock replied Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: And what distance is it to the Cape, captain?
children.prevalue: And what distance is it to the Cape captain

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: About fifteen miles, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: About fifteen miles replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: That's a matter of two hours and a half, said the sailor, and we shall be off the Cape between twelve and one o'clock. Unluckily, the tide will be turning at that moment, and will be ebbing out of the gulf. I am afraid that it will be very difficult to get in, having both wind and tide against us.
children.prevalue: That s a matter of two hours and a half said the sailor and we shall be off the Cape between twelve and one o clock Unluckily the tide will be turning at that moment and will be ebbing out of the gulf I am afraid that it will be very difficult to get in having both wind and tide against us

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And the more so that it is a full moon to-day, remarked Herbert, and these April tides are very strong.
children.prevalue: And the more so that it is a full moon to day remarked Herbert and these April tides are very strong

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Well, Pencroft, asked Harding, can you not anchor off the Cape?
children.prevalue: Well Pencroft asked Harding can you not anchor off the Cape

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Anchor near land, with bad weather coming on! exclaimed the sailor. What are you thinking of, captain? We should run aground, of a certainty!
children.prevalue: Anchor near land with bad weather coming on exclaimed the sailor What are you thinking of captain We should run aground of a certainty

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: What will you do then?
children.prevalue: What will you do then

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I shall try to keep in the offing until the flood, that is to say, till about seven in the evening, and if there is still light enough I will try to enter the gulf; if not, we must stand off and on during the night, and we will enter to-morrow at sunrise.
children.prevalue: I shall try to keep in the offing until the flood that is to say till about seven in the evening and if there is still light enough I will try to enter the gulf if not we must stand off and on during the night and we will enter to morrow at sunrise

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: As I told you, Pencroft, we will leave it to you, answered Harding.
children.prevalue: As I told you Pencroft we will leave it to you answered Harding

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Ah! said Pencroft, if there was only a lighthouse on the coast, it would be much more convenient for sailors.
children.prevalue: Ah said Pencroft if there was only a lighthouse on the coast it would be much more convenient for sailors

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Yes, replied Herbert, and this time we shall have no obliging engineer to light a fire to guide us into port!
children.prevalue: Yes replied Herbert and this time we shall have no obliging engineer to light a fire to guide us into port

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Why, indeed, my dear Cyrus, said Spilett, we have never thanked you; but frankly, without that fire we should never have been able--
children.prevalue: Why indeed my dear Cyrus said Spilett we have never thanked you but frankly without that fire we should never have been able

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: A fire? asked Harding, much astonished at the reporter's words.
children.prevalue: A fire asked Harding much astonished at the reporter s words

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: We mean, captain, answered Pencroft, that on board the 'Bonadventure' we were very anxious during the few hours before our return, and we should have passed to windward of the island, if it had not been for the precaution you took of lighting a fire the night of the 19th of October, on Prospect Heights.
children.prevalue: We mean captain answered Pencroft that on board the Bonadventure we were very anxious during the few hours before our return and we should have passed to windward of the island if it had not been for the precaution you took of lighting a fire the night of the 19th of October on Prospect Heights

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Yes, yes! That was a lucky idea of mine! replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Yes yes That was a lucky idea of mine replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: And this time, continued the sailor, unless the idea occurs to Ayrton, there will be no one to do us that little service!
children.prevalue: And this time continued the sailor unless the idea occurs to Ayrton there will be no one to do us that little service

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: No! No one! answered Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: No No one answered Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: A few minutes after, finding himself alone in the bows of the vessel, with the reporter, the engineer bent down and whispered,--
children.prevalue: A few minutes after finding himself alone in the bows of the vessel with the reporter the engineer bent down and whispered

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: If there is one thing certain in this world, Spilett, it is that I never lighted any fire during the night of the 19th of October, neither on Prospect Heights nor on any other part of the island!
children.prevalue: If there is one thing certain in this world Spilett it is that I never lighted any fire during the night of the 19th of October neither on Prospect Heights nor on any other part of the island

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Things happened as Pencroft had predicted, he being seldom mistaken in his prognostications. The wind rose, and from a fresh breeze it soon increased to a regular gale; that is to say, it acquired a speed of from forty to forty-five miles an hour, before which a ship in the open sea would have run under close-reefed topsails. Now, as it was nearly six o'clock when the Bonadventure reached the gulf, and as at that moment the tide turned, it was impossible to enter. They were therefore compelled to stand off, for even if he had wished to do so, Pencroft could not have gained the mouth of the Mercy. Hoisting the jib to the mainmast by way of a storm-sail, he hove to, putting the head of the vessel towards the land.
children.prevalue: Things happened as Pencroft had predicted he being seldom mistaken in his prognostications The wind rose and from a fresh breeze it soon increased to a regular gale that is to say it acquired a speed of from forty to forty five miles an hour before which a ship in the open sea would have run under close reefed topsails Now as it was nearly six o clock when the Bonadventure reached the gulf and as at that moment the tide turned it was impossible to enter They were therefore compelled to stand off for even if he had wished to do so Pencroft could not have gained the mouth of the Mercy Hoisting the jib to the mainmast by way of a storm sail he hove to putting the head of the vessel towards the land

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Fortunately, although the wind was strong the sea, being sheltered by the land, did not run very high. They had then little to fear from the waves, which always endanger small craft. The Bonadventure would doubtlessly not have capsized, for she was well ballasted, but enormous masses of water falling on the deck might injure her if her timbers could not sustain them. Pencroft, as a good sailor, was prepared for anything. Certainly, he had great confidence in his vessel, but nevertheless he awaited the return of day with some anxiety.
children.prevalue: Fortunately although the wind was strong the sea being sheltered by the land did not run very high They had then little to fear from the waves which always endanger small craft The Bonadventure would doubtlessly not have capsized for she was well ballasted but enormous masses of water falling on the deck might injure her if her timbers could not sustain them Pencroft as a good sailor was prepared for anything Certainly he had great confidence in his vessel but nevertheless he awaited the return of day with some anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: During the night, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett had no opportunity for talking together, and yet the words pronounced in the reporter's ear by the engineer were well worth being discussed, together with the mysterious influence which appeared to reign over Lincoln Island. Gideon Spilett did not cease from pondering over this new and inexplicable incident, the appearance of a fire on the coast of the island. The fire had actually been seen! His companions, Herbert and Pencroft, had seen it with him! The fire had served to signalize the position of the island during that dark night, and they had not doubted that it was lighted by the engineer's hand; and here was Cyrus Harding expressly declaring that he had never done anything of the sort! Spilett resolved to recur to this incident as soon as the Bonadventure returned, and to urge Cyrus Harding to acquaint their companions with these strange facts. Perhaps it would be decided to make in common a complete investigation of every part of Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: During the night Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett had no opportunity for talking together and yet the words pronounced in the reporter s ear by the engineer were well worth being discussed together with the mysterious influence which appeared to reign over Lincoln Island Gideon Spilett did not cease from pondering over this new and inexplicable incident the appearance of a fire on the coast of the island The fire had actually been seen His companions Herbert and Pencroft had seen it with him The fire had served to signalize the position of the island during that dark night and they had not doubted that it was lighted by the engineer s hand and here was Cyrus Harding expressly declaring that he had never done anything of the sort Spilett resolved to recur to this incident as soon as the Bonadventure returned and to urge Cyrus Harding to acquaint their companions with these strange facts Perhaps it would be decided to make in common a complete investigation of every part of Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: However that might be, on this evening no fire was lighted on these yet unknown shores, which formed the entrance to the gulf, and the little vessel stood off during the night.
children.prevalue: However that might be on this evening no fire was lighted on these yet unknown shores which formed the entrance to the gulf and the little vessel stood off during the night

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: When the first streaks of dawn appeared in the western horizon, the wind, which had slightly fallen, shifted two points, and enabled Pencroft to enter the narrow gulf with greater ease. Towards seven o'clock in the morning, the Bonadventure, weathering the North Mandible Cape, entered the strait and glided on to the waters, so strangely enclosed in the frame of lava.
children.prevalue: When the first streaks of dawn appeared in the western horizon the wind which had slightly fallen shifted two points and enabled Pencroft to enter the narrow gulf with greater ease Towards seven o clock in the morning the Bonadventure weathering the North Mandible Cape entered the strait and glided on to the waters so strangely enclosed in the frame of lava

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Well, said Pencroft, this bay would make admirable roads, in which a whole fleet could lie at their ease!
children.prevalue: Well said Pencroft this bay would make admirable roads in which a whole fleet could lie at their ease

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What is especially curious, observed Harding, is that the gulf has been formed by two rivers of lava, thrown out by the volcano, and accumulated by successive eruptions. The result is that the gulf is completely sheltered on all sides, and I believe that even in the stormiest weather, the sea here must be as calm as a lake.
children.prevalue: What is especially curious observed Harding is that the gulf has been formed by two rivers of lava thrown out by the volcano and accumulated by successive eruptions The result is that the gulf is completely sheltered on all sides and I believe that even in the stormiest weather the sea here must be as calm as a lake

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: No doubt, returned the sailor, since the wind has only that narrow entrance between the two capes to get in by, and, besides, the north cape protects that of the south in a way which would make the entrance of gusts very difficult. I declare our 'Bonadventure' could stay here from one end of the year to the other, without even dragging at her anchor!
children.prevalue: No doubt returned the sailor since the wind has only that narrow entrance between the two capes to get in by and besides the north cape protects that of the south in a way which would make the entrance of gusts very difficult I declare our Bonadventure could stay here from one end of the year to the other without even dragging at her anchor

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: It is rather large for her! observed the reporter.
children.prevalue: It is rather large for her observed the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Well! Mr. Spilett, replied the sailor, I agree that it is too large for the 'Bonadventure,' but if the fleets of the Union were in want of a harbor in the Pacific, I don't think they would ever find a better place than this!
children.prevalue: Well Mr Spilett replied the sailor I agree that it is too large for the Bonadventure but if the fleets of the Union were in want of a harbor in the Pacific I don t think they would ever find a better place than this

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: We are in the shark's mouth, remarked Neb, alluding to the form of the gulf.
children.prevalue: We are in the shark s mouth remarked Neb alluding to the form of the gulf

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Right into its mouth, my honest Neb! replied Herbert, but you are not afraid that it will shut upon us, are you?
children.prevalue: Right into its mouth my honest Neb replied Herbert but you are not afraid that it will shut upon us are you

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: No, Mr. Herbert, answered Neb, and yet this gulf here doesn't please me much! It has a wicked look!
children.prevalue: No Mr Herbert answered Neb and yet this gulf here doesn t please me much It has a wicked look

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Hallo! cried Pencroft, here is Neb turning up his nose at my gulf, just as I was thinking of presenting it to America!
children.prevalue: Hallo cried Pencroft here is Neb turning up his nose at my gulf just as I was thinking of presenting it to America

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But, at any rate, is the water deep enough? asked the engineer, for a depth sufficient for the keel of the 'Bonadventure' would not be enough for those of our iron-clads.
children.prevalue: But at any rate is the water deep enough asked the engineer for a depth sufficient for the keel of the Bonadventure would not be enough for those of our iron clads

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: That is easily found out, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: That is easily found out replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And the sailor sounded with a long cord, which served him as a lead-line, and to which was fastened a lump of iron. This cord measured nearly fifty fathoms, and its entire length was unrolled without finding any bottom.
children.prevalue: And the sailor sounded with a long cord which served him as a lead line and to which was fastened a lump of iron This cord measured nearly fifty fathoms and its entire length was unrolled without finding any bottom

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: There, exclaimed Pencroft, our iron-clads can come here after all! They would not run aground!
children.prevalue: There exclaimed Pencroft our iron clads can come here after all They would not run aground

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Indeed, said Gideon Spilett, this gulf is a regular abyss, but, taking into consideration the volcanic origin of the island, it is not astonishing that the sea should offer similar depressions.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Gideon Spilett this gulf is a regular abyss but taking into consideration the volcanic origin of the island it is not astonishing that the sea should offer similar depressions

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: One would say too, observed Herbert, that these cliffs were perfectly perpendicular; and I believe that at their foot, even with a line five or six times longer, Pencroft would not find bottom.
children.prevalue: One would say too observed Herbert that these cliffs were perfectly perpendicular and I believe that at their foot even with a line five or six times longer Pencroft would not find bottom

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: That is all very well, then said the reporter, but I must point out to Pencroft that his harbor is wanting in one very important respect!
children.prevalue: That is all very well then said the reporter but I must point out to Pencroft that his harbor is wanting in one very important respect

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And what is that, Mr. Spilett?
children.prevalue: And what is that Mr Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: An opening, a cutting of some sort, to give access to the interior of the island. I do not see a spot on which we could land. And, in fact, the steep lava cliffs did not afford a single place suitable for landing. They formed an insuperable barrier, recalling, but with more wildness, the fiords of Norway. The Bonadventure, coasting as close as possible along the cliffs, did not discover even a projection which would allow the passengers to leave the deck.
children.prevalue: An opening a cutting of some sort to give access to the interior of the island I do not see a spot on which we could land And in fact the steep lava cliffs did not afford a single place suitable for landing They formed an insuperable barrier recalling but with more wildness the fiords of Norway The Bonadventure coasting as close as possible along the cliffs did not discover even a projection which would allow the passengers to leave the deck

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Pencroft consoled himself by saying that with the help of a mine they could soon open out the cliff when that was necessary, and then, as there was evidently nothing to be done in the gulf, he steered his vessel towards the strait and passed out at about two o'clock in the afternoon.
children.prevalue: Pencroft consoled himself by saying that with the help of a mine they could soon open out the cliff when that was necessary and then as there was evidently nothing to be done in the gulf he steered his vessel towards the strait and passed out at about two o clock in the afternoon

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Ah! said Neb, uttering a sigh of satisfaction.
children.prevalue: Ah said Neb uttering a sigh of satisfaction

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: One might really say that the honest Negro did not feel at his ease in those enormous jaws.
children.prevalue: One might really say that the honest Negro did not feel at his ease in those enormous jaws

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The distance from Mandible Cape to the mouth of the Mercy was not more than eight miles. The head of the Bonadventure was put towards Granite House, and a fair wind filling her sails, she ran rapidly along the coast.
children.prevalue: The distance from Mandible Cape to the mouth of the Mercy was not more than eight miles The head of the Bonadventure was put towards Granite House and a fair wind filling her sails she ran rapidly along the coast

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: To the enormous lava rocks succeeded soon those capricious sand dunes, among which the engineer had been so singularly recovered, and which seabirds frequented in thousands.
children.prevalue: To the enormous lava rocks succeeded soon those capricious sand dunes among which the engineer had been so singularly recovered and which seabirds frequented in thousands

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: About four o'clock, Pencroft leaving the point of the islet on his left, entered the channel which separated it from the coast, and at five o'clock the anchor of the Bonadventure was buried in the sand at the mouth of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: About four o clock Pencroft leaving the point of the islet on his left entered the channel which separated it from the coast and at five o clock the anchor of the Bonadventure was buried in the sand at the mouth of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The colonists had been absent three days from their dwelling. Ayrton was waiting for them on the beach, and Jup came joyously to meet them, giving vent to deep grunts of satisfaction.
children.prevalue: The colonists had been absent three days from their dwelling Ayrton was waiting for them on the beach and Jup came joyously to meet them giving vent to deep grunts of satisfaction

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: A complete exploration of the coast of the island had now been made, and no suspicious appearances had been observed. If any mysterious being resided on it, it could only be under cover of the impenetrable forest of the Serpentine Peninsula, to which the colonists had not yet directed their investigations.
children.prevalue: A complete exploration of the coast of the island had now been made and no suspicious appearances had been observed If any mysterious being resided on it it could only be under cover of the impenetrable forest of the Serpentine Peninsula to which the colonists had not yet directed their investigations

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Gideon Spilett discussed these things with the engineer, and it was agreed that they should direct the attention of their companions to the strange character of certain incidents which had occurred on the island, and of which the last was the most unaccountable.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett discussed these things with the engineer and it was agreed that they should direct the attention of their companions to the strange character of certain incidents which had occurred on the island and of which the last was the most unaccountable

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: However, Harding, returning to the fact of a fire having been kindled on the shore by an unknown hand, could not refrain from repeating for the twentieth time to the reporter,--
children.prevalue: However Harding returning to the fact of a fire having been kindled on the shore by an unknown hand could not refrain from repeating for the twentieth time to the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: But are you quite sure of having seen it? Was it not a partial eruption of the volcano, or perhaps some meteor?
children.prevalue: But are you quite sure of having seen it Was it not a partial eruption of the volcano or perhaps some meteor

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: No, Cyrus, answered the reporter, it was certainly a fire lighted by the hand of man. Besides; question Pencroft and Herbert. They saw it as I saw it myself, and they will confirm my words.
children.prevalue: No Cyrus answered the reporter it was certainly a fire lighted by the hand of man Besides question Pencroft and Herbert They saw it as I saw it myself and they will confirm my words

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: In consequence, therefore, a few days after, on the 25th of April, in the evening, when the settlers were all collected on Prospect Heights, Cyrus Harding began by saying,--
children.prevalue: In consequence therefore a few days after on the 25th of April in the evening when the settlers were all collected on Prospect Heights Cyrus Harding began by saying

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: My friends, I think it my duty to call your attention to certain incidents which have occurred in the island, on the subject of which I shall be happy to have your advice. These incidents are, so to speak, supernatural--
children.prevalue: My friends I think it my duty to call your attention to certain incidents which have occurred in the island on the subject of which I shall be happy to have your advice These incidents are so to speak supernatural

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Supernatural! exclaimed the sailor, emitting a volume of smoke from his mouth. Can it be possible that our island is supernatural?
children.prevalue: Supernatural exclaimed the sailor emitting a volume of smoke from his mouth Can it be possible that our island is supernatural

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No, Pencroft, but mysterious, most certainly, replied the engineer; unless you can explain that which Spilett and I have until now failed to understand.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft but mysterious most certainly replied the engineer unless you can explain that which Spilett and I have until now failed to understand

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Speak away, captain, answered the sailor.
children.prevalue: Speak away captain answered the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Well, have you understood, then said the engineer, how was it that after falling into the sea, I was found a quarter of a mile into the interior of the island, and that, without my having any consciousness of my removal there?
children.prevalue: Well have you understood then said the engineer how was it that after falling into the sea I was found a quarter of a mile into the interior of the island and that without my having any consciousness of my removal there

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Unless, being unconscious-- said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Unless being unconscious said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: That is not admissible, replied the engineer. But to continue. Have you understood how Top was able to discover your retreat five miles from the cave in which I was lying?
children.prevalue: That is not admissible replied the engineer But to continue Have you understood how Top was able to discover your retreat five miles from the cave in which I was lying

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The dog's instinct-- observed Herbert.
children.prevalue: The dog s instinct observed Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Singular instinct! returned the reporter, since notwithstanding the storm of rain and wind which was raging during that night, Top arrived at the Chimneys, dry and without a speck of mud!
children.prevalue: Singular instinct returned the reporter since notwithstanding the storm of rain and wind which was raging during that night Top arrived at the Chimneys dry and without a speck of mud

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Let us continue, resumed the engineer. Have you understood how our dog was so strangely thrown up out of the water of the lake, after his struggle with the dugong?
children.prevalue: Let us continue resumed the engineer Have you understood how our dog was so strangely thrown up out of the water of the lake after his struggle with the dugong

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: No! I confess, not at all, replied Pencroft, and the wound which the dugong had in its side, a wound which seemed to have been made with a sharp instrument; that can't be understood, either.
children.prevalue: No I confess not at all replied Pencroft and the wound which the dugong had in its side a wound which seemed to have been made with a sharp instrument that can t be understood either

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Let us continue again, said Harding. Have you understood, my friends, how that bullet got into the body of the young peccary; how that case happened to be so fortunately stranded, without there being any trace of a wreck; how that bottle containing the document presented itself so opportunely, during our first sea-excursion; how our canoe, having broken its moorings, floated down the current of the Mercy and rejoined us at the very moment we needed it; how after the ape invasion the ladder was so obligingly thrown down from Granite House; and lastly, how the document, which Ayrton asserts was never written by him, fell into our hands?
children.prevalue: Let us continue again said Harding Have you understood my friends how that bullet got into the body of the young peccary how that case happened to be so fortunately stranded without there being any trace of a wreck how that bottle containing the document presented itself so opportunely during our first sea excursion how our canoe having broken its moorings floated down the current of the Mercy and rejoined us at the very moment we needed it how after the ape invasion the ladder was so obligingly thrown down from Granite House and lastly how the document which Ayrton asserts was never written by him fell into our hands

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: As Cyrus Harding thus enumerated, without forgetting one, the singular incidents which had occurred in the island, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft stared at each other, not knowing what to reply, for this succession of incidents, grouped thus for the first time, could not but excite their surprise to the highest degree.
children.prevalue: As Cyrus Harding thus enumerated without forgetting one the singular incidents which had occurred in the island Herbert Neb and Pencroft stared at each other not knowing what to reply for this succession of incidents grouped thus for the first time could not but excite their surprise to the highest degree

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Pon my word, said Pencroft at last, you are right, captain, and it is difficult to explain all these things!
children.prevalue: Pon my word said Pencroft at last you are right captain and it is difficult to explain all these things

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Well, my friends, resumed the engineer, a last fact has just been added to these, and it is no less incomprehensible than the others!
children.prevalue: Well my friends resumed the engineer a last fact has just been added to these and it is no less incomprehensible than the others

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: What is it, captain? asked Herbert quickly.
children.prevalue: What is it captain asked Herbert quickly

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: When you were returning from Tabor Island, Pencroft, continued the engineer, you said that a fire appeared on Lincoln Island?
children.prevalue: When you were returning from Tabor Island Pencroft continued the engineer you said that a fire appeared on Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Certainly, answered the sailor.
children.prevalue: Certainly answered the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And you are quite certain of having seen this fire?
children.prevalue: And you are quite certain of having seen this fire

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: As sure as I see you now.
children.prevalue: As sure as I see you now

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You also, Herbert?
children.prevalue: You also Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Why, captain, cried Herbert, that fire was blazing like a star of the first magnitude!
children.prevalue: Why captain cried Herbert that fire was blazing like a star of the first magnitude

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: But was it not a star? urged the engineer.
children.prevalue: But was it not a star urged the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: No, replied Pencroft, for the sky was covered with thick clouds, and at any rate a star would not have been so low on the horizon. But Mr. Spilett saw it as well as we, and he will confirm our words.
children.prevalue: No replied Pencroft for the sky was covered with thick clouds and at any rate a star would not have been so low on the horizon But Mr Spilett saw it as well as we and he will confirm our words

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I will add, said the reporter, that the fire was very bright, and that it shot up like a sheet of lightning.
children.prevalue: I will add said the reporter that the fire was very bright and that it shot up like a sheet of lightning

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, yes! exactly, added Herbert, and it was certainly placed on the heights of Granite House.
children.prevalue: Yes yes exactly added Herbert and it was certainly placed on the heights of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Well, my friends, replied Cyrus Harding, during the night of the 19th of October, neither Neb nor I lighted any fire on the coast.
children.prevalue: Well my friends replied Cyrus Harding during the night of the 19th of October neither Neb nor I lighted any fire on the coast

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You did not! exclaimed Pencroft, in the height of his astonishment, not being able to finish his sentence.
children.prevalue: You did not exclaimed Pencroft in the height of his astonishment not being able to finish his sentence

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: We did not leave Granite House, answered Cyrus Harding, and if a fire appeared on the coast, it was lighted by another hand than ours!
children.prevalue: We did not leave Granite House answered Cyrus Harding and if a fire appeared on the coast it was lighted by another hand than ours

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb were stupefied. No illusion could be possible, and a fire had actually met their eyes during the night of the 19th of October. Yes! they had to acknowledge it, a mystery existed! An inexplicable influence, evidently favorable to the colonists, but very irritating to their curiosity, was executed always in the nick of time on Lincoln Island. Could there be some being hidden in its profoundest recesses? It was necessary at any cost to ascertain this.
children.prevalue: Pencroft Herbert and Neb were stupefied No illusion could be possible and a fire had actually met their eyes during the night of the 19th of October Yes they had to acknowledge it a mystery existed An inexplicable influence evidently favorable to the colonists but very irritating to their curiosity was executed always in the nick of time on Lincoln Island Could there be some being hidden in its profoundest recesses It was necessary at any cost to ascertain this

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Harding also reminded his companions of the singular behavior of Top and Jup when they prowled round the mouth of the well, which placed Granite House in communication with the sea, and he told them that he had explored the well, without discovering anything suspicious. The final resolve taken, in consequence of this conversation, by all the members of the colony, was that as soon as the fine season returned they would thoroughly search the whole of the island.
children.prevalue: Harding also reminded his companions of the singular behavior of Top and Jup when they prowled round the mouth of the well which placed Granite House in communication with the sea and he told them that he had explored the well without discovering anything suspicious The final resolve taken in consequence of this conversation by all the members of the colony was that as soon as the fine season returned they would thoroughly search the whole of the island

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: But from that day Pencroft appeared to be anxious. He felt as if the island which he had made his own personal property belonged to him entirely no longer, and that he shared it with another master, to whom, willing or not, he felt subject. Neb and he often talked of those unaccountable things, and both, their natures inclining them to the marvelous, were not far from believing that Lincoln Island was under the dominion of some supernatural power.
children.prevalue: But from that day Pencroft appeared to be anxious He felt as if the island which he had made his own personal property belonged to him entirely no longer and that he shared it with another master to whom willing or not he felt subject Neb and he often talked of those unaccountable things and both their natures inclining them to the marvelous were not far from believing that Lincoln Island was under the dominion of some supernatural power

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: In the meanwhile, the bad weather came with the month of May, the November of the northern zones. It appeared that the winter would be severe and forward. The preparations for the winter season were therefore commenced without delay.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the bad weather came with the month of May the November of the northern zones It appeared that the winter would be severe and forward The preparations for the winter season were therefore commenced without delay

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Nevertheless, the colonists were well prepared to meet the winter, however hard it might be. They had plenty of felt clothing, and the musmons, very numerous by this time, had furnished an abundance of wool necessary for the manufacture of this warm material.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless the colonists were well prepared to meet the winter however hard it might be They had plenty of felt clothing and the musmons very numerous by this time had furnished an abundance of wool necessary for the manufacture of this warm material

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It is unnecessary to say that Ayrton had been provided with this comfortable clothing. Cyrus Harding proposed that he should come to spend the bad season with them in Granite House, where he would be better lodged than at the corral, and Ayrton promised to do so, as soon as the last work at the corral was finished. He did this towards the middle of April. From that time Ayrton shared the common life, and made himself useful on all occasions; but still humble and sad, he never took part in the pleasures of his companions.
children.prevalue: It is unnecessary to say that Ayrton had been provided with this comfortable clothing Cyrus Harding proposed that he should come to spend the bad season with them in Granite House where he would be better lodged than at the corral and Ayrton promised to do so as soon as the last work at the corral was finished He did this towards the middle of April From that time Ayrton shared the common life and made himself useful on all occasions but still humble and sad he never took part in the pleasures of his companions

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: For the greater part of this, the third winter which the settlers passed in Lincoln Island, they were confined to Granite House. There were many violent storms and frightful tempests, which appeared to shake the rocks to their very foundations. Immense waves threatened to overwhelm the island, and certainly any vessel anchored near the shore would have been dashed to pieces. Twice, during one of these hurricanes, the Mercy swelled to such a degree as to give reason to fear that the bridges would be swept away, and it was necessary to strengthen those on the shore, which disappeared under the foaming waters, when the sea beat against the beach.
children.prevalue: For the greater part of this the third winter which the settlers passed in Lincoln Island they were confined to Granite House There were many violent storms and frightful tempests which appeared to shake the rocks to their very foundations Immense waves threatened to overwhelm the island and certainly any vessel anchored near the shore would have been dashed to pieces Twice during one of these hurricanes the Mercy swelled to such a degree as to give reason to fear that the bridges would be swept away and it was necessary to strengthen those on the shore which disappeared under the foaming waters when the sea beat against the beach

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: It may well be supposed that such storms, comparable to water-spouts in which were mingled rain and snow, would cause great havoc on the plateau of Prospect Heights. The mill and the poultry-yard particularly suffered. The colonists were often obliged to make immediate repairs, without which the safety of the birds would have been seriously threatened.
children.prevalue: It may well be supposed that such storms comparable to water spouts in which were mingled rain and snow would cause great havoc on the plateau of Prospect Heights The mill and the poultry yard particularly suffered The colonists were often obliged to make immediate repairs without which the safety of the birds would have been seriously threatened

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: During the worst weather, several jaguars and troops of quadrumana ventured to the edge of the plateau, and it was always to be feared that the most active and audacious would, urged by hunger, manage to cross the stream, which besides, when frozen, offered them an easy passage. Plantations and domestic animals would then have been infallibly destroyed, without a constant watch, and it was often necessary to make use of the guns to keep those dangerous visitors at a respectful distance. Occupation was not wanting to the colonists, for without reckoning their out-door cares, they had always a thousand plans for the fitting up of Granite House.
children.prevalue: During the worst weather several jaguars and troops of quadrumana ventured to the edge of the plateau and it was always to be feared that the most active and audacious would urged by hunger manage to cross the stream which besides when frozen offered them an easy passage Plantations and domestic animals would then have been infallibly destroyed without a constant watch and it was often necessary to make use of the guns to keep those dangerous visitors at a respectful distance Occupation was not wanting to the colonists for without reckoning their out door cares they had always a thousand plans for the fitting up of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: They had also some fine sporting excursions, which were made during the frost in the vast Tadorn Marsh. Gideon Spilett and Herbert, aided by Jup and Top, did not miss a shot in the midst of myriads of wild-duck, snipe, teal, and others. The access to these hunting-grounds was easy; besides, whether they reached them by the road to Port Balloon, after having passed the Mercy Bridge, or by turning the rocks from Flotsam Point, the hunters were never distant from Granite House more than two or three miles.
children.prevalue: They had also some fine sporting excursions which were made during the frost in the vast Tadorn Marsh Gideon Spilett and Herbert aided by Jup and Top did not miss a shot in the midst of myriads of wild duck snipe teal and others The access to these hunting grounds was easy besides whether they reached them by the road to Port Balloon after having passed the Mercy Bridge or by turning the rocks from Flotsam Point the hunters were never distant from Granite House more than two or three miles

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Thus passed the four winter months, which were really rigorous, that is to say, June, July, August, and September. But, in short, Granite House did not suffer much from the inclemency of the weather, and it was the same with the corral, which, less exposed than the plateau, and sheltered partly by Mount Franklin, only received the remains of the hurricanes, already broken by the forests and the high rocks of the shore. The damages there were consequently of small importance, and the activity and skill of Ayrton promptly repaired them, when some time in October he returned to pass a few days in the corral.
children.prevalue: Thus passed the four winter months which were really rigorous that is to say June July August and September But in short Granite House did not suffer much from the inclemency of the weather and it was the same with the corral which less exposed than the plateau and sheltered partly by Mount Franklin only received the remains of the hurricanes already broken by the forests and the high rocks of the shore The damages there were consequently of small importance and the activity and skill of Ayrton promptly repaired them when some time in October he returned to pass a few days in the corral

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: During this winter, no fresh inexplicable incident occurred. Nothing strange happened, although Pencroft and Neb were on the watch for the most insignificant facts to which they attached any mysterious cause. Top and Jup themselves no longer growled round the well or gave any signs of uneasiness. It appeared, therefore, as if the series of supernatural incidents was interrupted, although they often talked of them during the evenings in Granite House, and they remained thoroughly resolved that the island should be searched, even in those parts the most difficult to explore. But an event of the highest importance, and of which the consequences might be terrible, momentarily diverted from their projects Cyrus Harding and his companions.
children.prevalue: During this winter no fresh inexplicable incident occurred Nothing strange happened although Pencroft and Neb were on the watch for the most insignificant facts to which they attached any mysterious cause Top and Jup themselves no longer growled round the well or gave any signs of uneasiness It appeared therefore as if the series of supernatural incidents was interrupted although they often talked of them during the evenings in Granite House and they remained thoroughly resolved that the island should be searched even in those parts the most difficult to explore But an event of the highest importance and of which the consequences might be terrible momentarily diverted from their projects Cyrus Harding and his companions

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: It was the month of October. The fine season was swiftly returning. Nature was reviving; and among the evergreen foliage of the coniferae which formed the border of the wood, already appeared the young leaves of the banksias, deodars, and other trees.
children.prevalue: It was the month of October The fine season was swiftly returning Nature was reviving and among the evergreen foliage of the coniferae which formed the border of the wood already appeared the young leaves of the banksias deodars and other trees

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: It may be remembered that Gideon Spilett and Herbert had, at different times, taken photographic views of Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: It may be remembered that Gideon Spilett and Herbert had at different times taken photographic views of Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Now, on the 17th of this month of October, towards three o'clock in the afternoon, Herbert, enticed by the charms of the sky, thought of reproducing Union Bay, which was opposite to Prospect Heights, from Cape Mandible to Claw Cape.
children.prevalue: Now on the 17th of this month of October towards three o clock in the afternoon Herbert enticed by the charms of the sky thought of reproducing Union Bay which was opposite to Prospect Heights from Cape Mandible to Claw Cape

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The horizon was beautifully clear, and the sea, undulating under a soft breeze, was as calm as the waters of a lake, sparkling here and there under the sun's rays.
children.prevalue: The horizon was beautifully clear and the sea undulating under a soft breeze was as calm as the waters of a lake sparkling here and there under the sun s rays

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: The apparatus had been placed at one of the windows of the dining-room at Granite House, and consequently overlooked the shore and the bay. Herbert proceeded as he was accustomed to do, and the negative obtained, he went away to fix it by means of the chemicals deposited in a dark nook of Granite House.
children.prevalue: The apparatus had been placed at one of the windows of the dining room at Granite House and consequently overlooked the shore and the bay Herbert proceeded as he was accustomed to do and the negative obtained he went away to fix it by means of the chemicals deposited in a dark nook of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Returning to the bright light, and examining it well, Herbert perceived on his negative an almost imperceptible little spot on the sea horizon. He endeavored to make it disappear by reiterated washing, but could not accomplish it.
children.prevalue: Returning to the bright light and examining it well Herbert perceived on his negative an almost imperceptible little spot on the sea horizon He endeavored to make it disappear by reiterated washing but could not accomplish it

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: It is a flaw in the glass, he thought.
children.prevalue: It is a flaw in the glass he thought

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: And then he had the curiosity to examine this flaw with a strong magnifier which he unscrewed from one of the telescopes.
children.prevalue: And then he had the curiosity to examine this flaw with a strong magnifier which he unscrewed from one of the telescopes

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: But he had scarcely looked at it, when he uttered a cry, and the glass almost fell from his hands.
children.prevalue: But he had scarcely looked at it when he uttered a cry and the glass almost fell from his hands

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Immediately running to the room in which Cyrus Harding then was, he extended the negative and magnifier towards the engineer, pointing out the little spot.
children.prevalue: Immediately running to the room in which Cyrus Harding then was he extended the negative and magnifier towards the engineer pointing out the little spot

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Harding examined it; then seizing his telescope he rushed to the window.
children.prevalue: Harding examined it then seizing his telescope he rushed to the window

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: The telescope, after having slowly swept the horizon, at last stopped on the looked-for spot, and Cyrus Harding, lowering it, pronounced one word only,--
children.prevalue: The telescope after having slowly swept the horizon at last stopped on the looked for spot and Cyrus Harding lowering it pronounced one word only

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: A vessel!
children.prevalue: A vessel

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: And in fact a vessel was in sight, off Lincoln Island!
children.prevalue: And in fact a vessel was in sight off Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: PART 3
children.prevalue: PART 3

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: THE SECRET OF THE ISLAND
children.prevalue: THE SECRET OF THE ISLAND

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was now two years and a half since the castaways from the balloon had been thrown on Lincoln Island, and during that period there had been no communication between them and their fellow-creatures. Once the reporter had attempted to communicate with the inhabited world by confiding to a bird a letter which contained the secret of their situation, but that was a chance on which it was impossible to reckon seriously. Ayrton, alone, under the circumstances which have been related, had come to join the little colony. Now, suddenly, on this day, the 17th of October, other men had unexpectedly appeared in sight of the island, on that deserted sea!
children.prevalue: It was now two years and a half since the castaways from the balloon had been thrown on Lincoln Island and during that period there had been no communication between them and their fellow creatures Once the reporter had attempted to communicate with the inhabited world by confiding to a bird a letter which contained the secret of their situation but that was a chance on which it was impossible to reckon seriously Ayrton alone under the circumstances which have been related had come to join the little colony Now suddenly on this day the 17th of October other men had unexpectedly appeared in sight of the island on that deserted sea

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There could be no doubt about it! A vessel was there! But would she pass on, or would she put into port? In a few hours the colonists would definitely know what to expect.
children.prevalue: There could be no doubt about it A vessel was there But would she pass on or would she put into port In a few hours the colonists would definitely know what to expect

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Herbert having immediately called Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Neb into the dining-room of Granite House, told them what had happened. Pencroft, seizing the telescope, rapidly swept the horizon, and stopping on the indicated point, that is to say, on that which had made the almost imperceptible spot on the photographic negative,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Herbert having immediately called Gideon Spilett Pencroft and Neb into the dining room of Granite House told them what had happened Pencroft seizing the telescope rapidly swept the horizon and stopping on the indicated point that is to say on that which had made the almost imperceptible spot on the photographic negative

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I'm blessed but it is really a vessel! he exclaimed, in a voice which did not express any great amount of satisfaction.
children.prevalue: I m blessed but it is really a vessel he exclaimed in a voice which did not express any great amount of satisfaction

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Is she coming here? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Is she coming here asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Impossible to say anything yet, answered Pencroft, for her rigging alone is above the horizon, and not a bit of her hull can be seen.
children.prevalue: Impossible to say anything yet answered Pencroft for her rigging alone is above the horizon and not a bit of her hull can be seen

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What is to be done? asked the lad.
children.prevalue: What is to be done asked the lad

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Wait, replied Harding.
children.prevalue: Wait replied Harding

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And for a considerable time the settlers remained silent, given up to all the thoughts, and the emotions, all the fears, all the hopes, which were aroused by this incident--the most important which had occurred since their arrival in Lincoln Island. Certainly, the colonists were not in the situation of castaways abandoned on a sterile islet, constantly contending against a cruel nature for their miserable existence, and incessantly tormented by the longing to return to inhabited countries. Pencroft and Neb, especially, who felt themselves at once so happy and so rich, would not have left their island without regret. They were accustomed, besides, to this new life in the midst of the domain which their intelligence had as it were civilized. But at any rate this ship brought news from the world, perhaps even from their native land. It was bringing fellow-creatures to them, and it may be conceived how deeply their hearts were moved at the sight!
children.prevalue: And for a considerable time the settlers remained silent given up to all the thoughts and the emotions all the fears all the hopes which were aroused by this incident the most important which had occurred since their arrival in Lincoln Island Certainly the colonists were not in the situation of castaways abandoned on a sterile islet constantly contending against a cruel nature for their miserable existence and incessantly tormented by the longing to return to inhabited countries Pencroft and Neb especially who felt themselves at once so happy and so rich would not have left their island without regret They were accustomed besides to this new life in the midst of the domain which their intelligence had as it were civilized But at any rate this ship brought news from the world perhaps even from their native land It was bringing fellow creatures to them and it may be conceived how deeply their hearts were moved at the sight

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: From time to time Pencroft took the glass and rested himself at the window. From thence he very attentively examined the vessel, which was at a distance of twenty miles to the east. The colonists had as yet, therefore, no means of signalizing their presence. A flag would not have been perceived; a gun would not have been heard; a fire would not have been visible. However, it was certain that the island, overtopped by Mount Franklin, could not escape the notice of the vessel's lookout. But why was the ship coming there? Was it simple chance which brought it to that part of the Pacific, where the maps mentioned no land except Tabor Island, which itself was out of the route usually followed by vessels from the Polynesian Archipelagoes, from New Zealand, and from the American coast? To this question, which each one asked himself, a reply was suddenly made by Herbert.
children.prevalue: From time to time Pencroft took the glass and rested himself at the window From thence he very attentively examined the vessel which was at a distance of twenty miles to the east The colonists had as yet therefore no means of signalizing their presence A flag would not have been perceived a gun would not have been heard a fire would not have been visible However it was certain that the island overtopped by Mount Franklin could not escape the notice of the vessel s lookout But why was the ship coming there Was it simple chance which brought it to that part of the Pacific where the maps mentioned no land except Tabor Island which itself was out of the route usually followed by vessels from the Polynesian Archipelagoes from New Zealand and from the American coast To this question which each one asked himself a reply was suddenly made by Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Can it be the 'Duncan'? he cried.
children.prevalue: Can it be the Duncan he cried

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The Duncan, as has been said, was Lord Glenarvan's yacht, which had left Ayrton on the islet, and which was to return there someday to fetch him. Now, the islet was not so far distant from Lincoln Island, but that a vessel, standing for the one, could pass in sight of the other. A hundred and fifty miles only separated them in longitude, and seventy in latitude.
children.prevalue: The Duncan as has been said was Lord Glenarvan s yacht which had left Ayrton on the islet and which was to return there someday to fetch him Now the islet was not so far distant from Lincoln Island but that a vessel standing for the one could pass in sight of the other A hundred and fifty miles only separated them in longitude and seventy in latitude

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: We must tell Ayrton, said Gideon Spilett, and send for him immediately. He alone can say if it is the 'Duncan.'
children.prevalue: We must tell Ayrton said Gideon Spilett and send for him immediately He alone can say if it is the Duncan

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: This was the opinion of all, and the reporter, going to the telegraphic apparatus which placed the corral in communication with Granite House, sent this telegram:--Come with all possible speed.
children.prevalue: This was the opinion of all and the reporter going to the telegraphic apparatus which placed the corral in communication with Granite House sent this telegram Come with all possible speed

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In a few minutes the bell sounded.
children.prevalue: In a few minutes the bell sounded

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I am coming, replied Ayrton.
children.prevalue: I am coming replied Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Then the settlers continued to watch the vessel.
children.prevalue: Then the settlers continued to watch the vessel

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: If it is the 'Duncan,' said Herbert, Ayrton will recognize her without difficulty, since he sailed on board her for some time.
children.prevalue: If it is the Duncan said Herbert Ayrton will recognize her without difficulty since he sailed on board her for some time

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: And if he recognizes her, added Pencroft, it will agitate him exceedingly!
children.prevalue: And if he recognizes her added Pencroft it will agitate him exceedingly

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, answered Cyrus Harding; but now Ayrton is worthy to return on board the 'Duncan,' and pray Heaven that it is indeed Lord Glenarvan's yacht, for I should be suspicious of any other vessel. These are ill-famed seas, and I have always feared a visit from Malay pirates to our island.
children.prevalue: Yes answered Cyrus Harding but now Ayrton is worthy to return on board the Duncan and pray Heaven that it is indeed Lord Glenarvan s yacht for I should be suspicious of any other vessel These are ill famed seas and I have always feared a visit from Malay pirates to our island

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We could defend it,', cried Herbert.
children.prevalue: We could defend it cried Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No doubt, my boy, answered the engineer smiling, but it would be better not to have to defend it.
children.prevalue: No doubt my boy answered the engineer smiling but it would be better not to have to defend it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: A useless observation, said Spilett. Lincoln Island is unknown to navigators, since it is not marked even on the most recent maps. Do you think, Cyrus, that that is a sufficient motive for a ship, finding herself unexpectedly in sight of new land, to try and visit rather than avoid it?
children.prevalue: A useless observation said Spilett Lincoln Island is unknown to navigators since it is not marked even on the most recent maps Do you think Cyrus that that is a sufficient motive for a ship finding herself unexpectedly in sight of new land to try and visit rather than avoid it

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Certainly, replied Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Certainly replied Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I think so too, added the engineer. It may even be said that it is the duty of a captain to come and survey any land or island not yet known, and Lincoln Island is in this position.
children.prevalue: I think so too added the engineer It may even be said that it is the duty of a captain to come and survey any land or island not yet known and Lincoln Island is in this position

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Well, said Pencroft, suppose this vessel comes and anchors there a few cables-lengths from our island, what shall we do?
children.prevalue: Well said Pencroft suppose this vessel comes and anchors there a few cables lengths from our island what shall we do

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: This sudden question remained at first without any reply. But Cyrus Harding, after some moments' thought, replied in the calm tone which was usual to him,--
children.prevalue: This sudden question remained at first without any reply But Cyrus Harding after some moments thought replied in the calm tone which was usual to him

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: What we shall do, my friends? What we ought to do is this:--we will communicate with the ship, we will take our passage on board her, and we will leave our island, after having taken possession of it in the name of the United States. Then we will return with any who may wish to follow us to colonize it definitely, and endow the American Republic with a useful station in this part of the Pacific Ocean!
children.prevalue: What we shall do my friends What we ought to do is this we will communicate with the ship we will take our passage on board her and we will leave our island after having taken possession of it in the name of the United States Then we will return with any who may wish to follow us to colonize it definitely and endow the American Republic with a useful station in this part of the Pacific Ocean

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Hurrah! exclaimed Pencroft, and that will be no small present which we shall make to our country! The colonization is already almost finished; names are given to every part of the island; there is a natural port, fresh water, roads, a telegraph, a dockyard, and manufactories; and there will be nothing to be done but to inscribe Lincoln Island on the maps!
children.prevalue: Hurrah exclaimed Pencroft and that will be no small present which we shall make to our country The colonization is already almost finished names are given to every part of the island there is a natural port fresh water roads a telegraph a dockyard and manufactories and there will be nothing to be done but to inscribe Lincoln Island on the maps

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: But if anyone seizes it in our absence? observed Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: But if anyone seizes it in our absence observed Gideon Spilett
