children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Hang it! cried the sailor. I would rather remain all alone to guard it: and trust to Pencroft, they shouldn't steal it from him, like a watch from the pocket of a swell!
children.prevalue: Hang it cried the sailor I would rather remain all alone to guard it and trust to Pencroft they shouldn t steal it from him like a watch from the pocket of a swell

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: For an hour it was impossible to say with any certainty whether the vessel was or was not standing towards Lincoln Island. She was nearer, but in what direction was she sailing? This Pencroft could not determine. However, as the wind was blowing from the northeast, in all probability the vessel was sailing on the starboard tack. Besides, the wind was favorable for bringing her towards the island, and, the sea being calm, she would not be afraid to approach although the shallows were not marked on the chart.
children.prevalue: For an hour it was impossible to say with any certainty whether the vessel was or was not standing towards Lincoln Island She was nearer but in what direction was she sailing This Pencroft could not determine However as the wind was blowing from the northeast in all probability the vessel was sailing on the starboard tack Besides the wind was favorable for bringing her towards the island and the sea being calm she would not be afraid to approach although the shallows were not marked on the chart

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Towards four o'clock--an hour after he had been sent for--Ayrton arrived at Granite House. He entered the dining-room saying,--
children.prevalue: Towards four o clock an hour after he had been sent for Ayrton arrived at Granite House He entered the dining room saying

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: At your service, gentlemen.
children.prevalue: At your service gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Cyrus Harding gave him his hand, as was his custom to do, and, leading him to the window,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding gave him his hand as was his custom to do and leading him to the window

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Ayrton, said he, we have begged you to come here for an important reason. A ship is in sight of the island.
children.prevalue: Ayrton said he we have begged you to come here for an important reason A ship is in sight of the island

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Ayrton at first paled slightly, and for a moment his eyes became dim; then, leaning out the window, he surveyed the horizon, but could see nothing.
children.prevalue: Ayrton at first paled slightly and for a moment his eyes became dim then leaning out the window he surveyed the horizon but could see nothing

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Take this telescope, said Spilett, and look carefully, Ayrton, for it is possible that this ship may be the 'Duncan' come to these seas for the purpose of taking you home again.
children.prevalue: Take this telescope said Spilett and look carefully Ayrton for it is possible that this ship may be the Duncan come to these seas for the purpose of taking you home again

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The 'Duncan!' murmured Ayrton. Already? This last word escaped Ayrton's lips as if involuntarily, and his head drooped upon his hands.
children.prevalue: The Duncan murmured Ayrton Already This last word escaped Ayrton s lips as if involuntarily and his head drooped upon his hands

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Did not twelve years' solitude on a desert island appear to him a sufficient expiation? Did not the penitent yet feel himself pardoned, either in his own eyes or in the eyes of others?
children.prevalue: Did not twelve years solitude on a desert island appear to him a sufficient expiation Did not the penitent yet feel himself pardoned either in his own eyes or in the eyes of others

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: No, said he, no! it cannot be the 'Duncan'!
children.prevalue: No said he no it cannot be the Duncan

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Look, Ayrton, then said the engineer, for it is necessary that we should know beforehand what to expect.
children.prevalue: Look Ayrton then said the engineer for it is necessary that we should know beforehand what to expect

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Ayrton took the glass and pointed it in the direction indicated. During some minutes he examined the horizon without moving, without uttering a word. Then,--
children.prevalue: Ayrton took the glass and pointed it in the direction indicated During some minutes he examined the horizon without moving without uttering a word Then

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: It is indeed a vessel, said he, but I do not think she is the 'Duncan.'
children.prevalue: It is indeed a vessel said he but I do not think she is the Duncan

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Why do you not think so? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Why do you not think so asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Because the 'Duncan' is a steam-yacht, and I cannot perceive any trace of smoke either above or near that vessel.
children.prevalue: Because the Duncan is a steam yacht and I cannot perceive any trace of smoke either above or near that vessel

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Perhaps she is simply sailing, observed Pencroft. The wind is favorable for the direction which she appears to be taking, and she may be anxious to economize her coal, being so far from land.
children.prevalue: Perhaps she is simply sailing observed Pencroft The wind is favorable for the direction which she appears to be taking and she may be anxious to economize her coal being so far from land

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It is possible that you may be right, Mr. Pencroft, answered Ayrton, and that the vessel has extinguished her fires. We must wait until she is nearer, and then we shall soon know what to expect.
children.prevalue: It is possible that you may be right Mr Pencroft answered Ayrton and that the vessel has extinguished her fires We must wait until she is nearer and then we shall soon know what to expect

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: So saying, Ayrton sat down in a corner of the room and remained silent. The colonists again discussed the strange ship, but Ayrton took no part in the conversation. All were in such a mood that they found it impossible to continue their work. Gideon Spilett and Pencroft were particularly nervous, going, coming, not able to remain still in one place. Herbert felt more curiosity. Neb alone maintained his usual calm manner. Was not his country that where his master was? As to the engineer, he remained plunged in deep thought, and in his heart feared rather than desired the arrival of the ship. In the meanwhile, the vessel was a little nearer the island. With the aid of the glass, it was ascertained that she was a brig, and not one of those Malay proas, which are generally used by the pirates of the Pacific. It was, therefore, reasonable to believe that the engineer's apprehensions would not be justified, and that the presence of this vessel in the vicinity of the island was fraught with no danger.
children.prevalue: So saying Ayrton sat down in a corner of the room and remained silent The colonists again discussed the strange ship but Ayrton took no part in the conversation All were in such a mood that they found it impossible to continue their work Gideon Spilett and Pencroft were particularly nervous going coming not able to remain still in one place Herbert felt more curiosity Neb alone maintained his usual calm manner Was not his country that where his master was As to the engineer he remained plunged in deep thought and in his heart feared rather than desired the arrival of the ship In the meanwhile the vessel was a little nearer the island With the aid of the glass it was ascertained that she was a brig and not one of those Malay proas which are generally used by the pirates of the Pacific It was therefore reasonable to believe that the engineer s apprehensions would not be justified and that the presence of this vessel in the vicinity of the island was fraught with no danger

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Pencroft, after a minute examination, was able positively to affirm that the vessel was rigged as a brig, and that she was standing obliquely towards the coast, on the starboard tack, under her topsails and top-gallant-sails. This was confirmed by Ayrton. But by continuing in this direction she must soon disappear behind Claw Cape, as the wind was from the southwest, and to watch her it would be then necessary to ascend the height of Washington Bay, near Port Balloon--a provoking circumstance, for it was already five o'clock in the evening, and the twilight would soon make any observation extremely difficult.
children.prevalue: Pencroft after a minute examination was able positively to affirm that the vessel was rigged as a brig and that she was standing obliquely towards the coast on the starboard tack under her topsails and top gallant sails This was confirmed by Ayrton But by continuing in this direction she must soon disappear behind Claw Cape as the wind was from the southwest and to watch her it would be then necessary to ascend the height of Washington Bay near Port Balloon a provoking circumstance for it was already five o clock in the evening and the twilight would soon make any observation extremely difficult

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What shall we do when night comes on? asked Gideon Spilett. Shall we light a fire, so as to signal our presence on the coast?
children.prevalue: What shall we do when night comes on asked Gideon Spilett Shall we light a fire so as to signal our presence on the coast

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: This was a serious question, and yet, although the engineer still retained some of his presentiments, it was answered in the affirmative. During the night the ship might disappear and leave for ever, and, this ship gone, would another ever return to the waters of Lincoln Island? Who could foresee what the future would then have in store for the colonists?
children.prevalue: This was a serious question and yet although the engineer still retained some of his presentiments it was answered in the affirmative During the night the ship might disappear and leave for ever and this ship gone would another ever return to the waters of Lincoln Island Who could foresee what the future would then have in store for the colonists

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Yes, said the reporter, we ought to make known to that vessel, whoever she may be, that the island is inhabited. To neglect the opportunity which is offered to us might be to create everlasting regrets.
children.prevalue: Yes said the reporter we ought to make known to that vessel whoever she may be that the island is inhabited To neglect the opportunity which is offered to us might be to create everlasting regrets

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: It was therefore decided that Neb and Pencroft should go to Port Balloon, and that there, at nightfall, they should light an immense fire, the blaze of which would necessarily attract the attention of the brig.
children.prevalue: It was therefore decided that Neb and Pencroft should go to Port Balloon and that there at nightfall they should light an immense fire the blaze of which would necessarily attract the attention of the brig

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But at the moment when Neb and the sailor were preparing to leave Granite House, the vessel suddenly altered her course, and stood directly for Union Bay. The brig was a good sailer, for she approached rapidly. Neb and Pencroft put off their departure, therefore, and the glass was put into Ayrton's hands, that he might ascertain for certain whether the ship was or was not the Duncan. The Scotch yacht was also rigged as a brig. The question was, whether a chimney could be discerned between the two masts of the vessel, which was now at a distance of only five miles.
children.prevalue: But at the moment when Neb and the sailor were preparing to leave Granite House the vessel suddenly altered her course and stood directly for Union Bay The brig was a good sailer for she approached rapidly Neb and Pencroft put off their departure therefore and the glass was put into Ayrton s hands that he might ascertain for certain whether the ship was or was not the Duncan The Scotch yacht was also rigged as a brig The question was whether a chimney could be discerned between the two masts of the vessel which was now at a distance of only five miles

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The horizon was still very clear. The examination was easy, and Ayrton soon let the glass fall again, saying--
children.prevalue: The horizon was still very clear The examination was easy and Ayrton soon let the glass fall again saying

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: It is not the 'Duncan'! It could not be!
children.prevalue: It is not the Duncan It could not be

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Pencroft again brought the brig within the range of the telescope, and could see that she was of between three and four hundred tons burden, wonderfully narrow, well-masted, admirably built, and must be a very rapid sailer. But to what nation did she belong? That was difficult to say.
children.prevalue: Pencroft again brought the brig within the range of the telescope and could see that she was of between three and four hundred tons burden wonderfully narrow well masted admirably built and must be a very rapid sailer But to what nation did she belong That was difficult to say

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And yet, added the sailor, a flag is floating from her peak, but I cannot distinguish the colors of it.
children.prevalue: And yet added the sailor a flag is floating from her peak but I cannot distinguish the colors of it

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: In half an hour we shall be certain about that, answered the reporter. Besides, it is very evident that the intention of the captain of this ship is to land, and, consequently, if not today, to-morrow at the latest, we shall make his acquaintance.
children.prevalue: In half an hour we shall be certain about that answered the reporter Besides it is very evident that the intention of the captain of this ship is to land and consequently if not today to morrow at the latest we shall make his acquaintance

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Never mind! said Pencroft. It is best to know whom we have to deal with, and I shall not be sorry to recognize that fellow's colors!
children.prevalue: Never mind said Pencroft It is best to know whom we have to deal with and I shall not be sorry to recognize that fellow s colors

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And, while thus speaking, the sailor never left the glass. The day began to fade, and with the day the breeze fell also. The brig's ensign hung in folds, and it became more and more difficult to observe it.
children.prevalue: And while thus speaking the sailor never left the glass The day began to fade and with the day the breeze fell also The brig s ensign hung in folds and it became more and more difficult to observe it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: It is not the American flag, said Pencroft from time to time, nor the English, the red of which could be easily seen, nor the French or German colors, nor the white flag of Russia, nor the yellow of Spain. One would say it was all one color. Let's see: in these seas, what do we generally meet with? The Chilean flag?--but that is tri-color. Brazilian?--it is green. Japanese?--it is yellow and black, while this--
children.prevalue: It is not the American flag said Pencroft from time to time nor the English the red of which could be easily seen nor the French or German colors nor the white flag of Russia nor the yellow of Spain One would say it was all one color Let s see in these seas what do we generally meet with The Chilean flag but that is tri color Brazilian it is green Japanese it is yellow and black while this

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: At that moment the breeze blew out the unknown flag. Ayrton seizing the telescope which the sailor had put down, put it to his eye, and in a hoarse voice,--
children.prevalue: At that moment the breeze blew out the unknown flag Ayrton seizing the telescope which the sailor had put down put it to his eye and in a hoarse voice

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The black flag! he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: The black flag he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And indeed the somber bunting was floating from the mast of the brig, and they had now good reason for considering her to be a suspicious vessel!
children.prevalue: And indeed the somber bunting was floating from the mast of the brig and they had now good reason for considering her to be a suspicious vessel

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Had the engineer, then, been right in his presentiments? Was this a pirate vessel? Did she scour the Pacific, competing with the Malay proas which still infest it? For what had she come to look at the shores of Lincoln Island? Was it to them an unknown island, ready to become a magazine for stolen cargoes? Had she come to find on the coast a sheltered port for the winter months? Was the settlers' honest domain destined to be transformed into an infamous refuge--the headquarters of the piracy of the Pacific?
children.prevalue: Had the engineer then been right in his presentiments Was this a pirate vessel Did she scour the Pacific competing with the Malay proas which still infest it For what had she come to look at the shores of Lincoln Island Was it to them an unknown island ready to become a magazine for stolen cargoes Had she come to find on the coast a sheltered port for the winter months Was the settlers honest domain destined to be transformed into an infamous refuge the headquarters of the piracy of the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: All these ideas instinctively presented themselves to the colonists' imaginations. There was no doubt, besides, of the signification which must be attached to the color of the hoisted flag. It was that of pirates! It was that which the Duncan would have carried, had the convicts succeeded in their criminal design! No time was lost before discussing it.
children.prevalue: All these ideas instinctively presented themselves to the colonists imaginations There was no doubt besides of the signification which must be attached to the color of the hoisted flag It was that of pirates It was that which the Duncan would have carried had the convicts succeeded in their criminal design No time was lost before discussing it

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: My friends, said Cyrus Harding, perhaps this vessel only wishes to survey the coast of the island. Perhaps her crew will not land. There is a chance of it. However that may be, we ought to do everything we can to hide our presence here. The windmill on Prospect Heights is too easily seen. Let Ayrton and Neb go and take down the sails. We must also conceal the windows of Granite House with thick branches. All the fires must be extinguished, so that nothing may betray the presence of men on the island.
children.prevalue: My friends said Cyrus Harding perhaps this vessel only wishes to survey the coast of the island Perhaps her crew will not land There is a chance of it However that may be we ought to do everything we can to hide our presence here The windmill on Prospect Heights is too easily seen Let Ayrton and Neb go and take down the sails We must also conceal the windows of Granite House with thick branches All the fires must be extinguished so that nothing may betray the presence of men on the island

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And our vessel? said Herbert.
children.prevalue: And our vessel said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Oh, answered Pencroft, she is sheltered in Port Balloon, and I defy any of those rascals there to find her!
children.prevalue: Oh answered Pencroft she is sheltered in Port Balloon and I defy any of those rascals there to find her

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The engineer's orders were immediately executed. Neb and Ayrton ascended the plateau, and took the necessary precautions to conceal any indication of a settlement. While they were thus occupied, their companions went to the border of Jacamar Wood, and brought back a large quantity of branches and creepers, which would at some distance appear as natural foliage, and thus disguise the windows in the granite cliff. At the same time, the ammunition and guns were placed ready so as to be at hand in case of an unexpected attack.
children.prevalue: The engineer s orders were immediately executed Neb and Ayrton ascended the plateau and took the necessary precautions to conceal any indication of a settlement While they were thus occupied their companions went to the border of Jacamar Wood and brought back a large quantity of branches and creepers which would at some distance appear as natural foliage and thus disguise the windows in the granite cliff At the same time the ammunition and guns were placed ready so as to be at hand in case of an unexpected attack

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: When all these precautions had been taken,--
children.prevalue: When all these precautions had been taken

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: My friends, said Harding, and his voice betrayed some emotion, if the wretches endeavor to seize Lincoln Island, we shall defend it--shall we not?
children.prevalue: My friends said Harding and his voice betrayed some emotion if the wretches endeavor to seize Lincoln Island we shall defend it shall we not

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, Cyrus, replied the reporter, and if necessary we will die to defend it!
children.prevalue: Yes Cyrus replied the reporter and if necessary we will die to defend it

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The engineer extended his hand to his companions, who pressed it warmly. Ayrton remained in his corner, not joining the colonists. Perhaps he, the former convict, still felt himself unworthy to do so!
children.prevalue: The engineer extended his hand to his companions who pressed it warmly Ayrton remained in his corner not joining the colonists Perhaps he the former convict still felt himself unworthy to do so

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in Ayrton's mind, and going to him--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in Ayrton s mind and going to him

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: And you, Ayrton, he asked, what will you do?
children.prevalue: And you Ayrton he asked what will you do

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: My duty, answered Ayrton.
children.prevalue: My duty answered Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: He then took up his station near the window and gazed through the foliage.
children.prevalue: He then took up his station near the window and gazed through the foliage

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: It was now half-past seven. The sun had disappeared twenty minutes ago behind Granite House. Consequently the Eastern horizon was becoming obscured. In the meanwhile the brig continued to advance towards Union Bay. She was now not more than two miles off, and exactly opposite the plateau of Prospect Heights, for after having tacked off Claw Cape, she had drifted towards the north in the current of the rising tide. One might have said that at this distance she had already entered the vast bay, for a straight line drawn from Claw Cape to Cape Mandible would have rested on her starboard quarter.
children.prevalue: It was now half past seven The sun had disappeared twenty minutes ago behind Granite House Consequently the Eastern horizon was becoming obscured In the meanwhile the brig continued to advance towards Union Bay She was now not more than two miles off and exactly opposite the plateau of Prospect Heights for after having tacked off Claw Cape she had drifted towards the north in the current of the rising tide One might have said that at this distance she had already entered the vast bay for a straight line drawn from Claw Cape to Cape Mandible would have rested on her starboard quarter

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Was the brig about to penetrate far into the bay? That was the first question. When once in the bay, would she anchor there? That was the second. Would she not content herself with only surveying the coast, and stand out to sea again without landing her crew? They would know this in an hour. The colonists could do nothing but wait.
children.prevalue: Was the brig about to penetrate far into the bay That was the first question When once in the bay would she anchor there That was the second Would she not content herself with only surveying the coast and stand out to sea again without landing her crew They would know this in an hour The colonists could do nothing but wait

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Cyrus Harding had not seen the suspected vessel hoist the black flag without deep anxiety. Was it not a direct menace against the work which he and his companions had till now conducted so successfully? Had these pirates--for the sailors of the brig could be nothing else--already visited the island, since on approaching it they had hoisted their colors. Had they formerly invaded it, so that certain unaccountable peculiarities might be explained in this way? Did there exist in the as yet unexplored parts some accomplice ready to enter into communication with them?
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding had not seen the suspected vessel hoist the black flag without deep anxiety Was it not a direct menace against the work which he and his companions had till now conducted so successfully Had these pirates for the sailors of the brig could be nothing else already visited the island since on approaching it they had hoisted their colors Had they formerly invaded it so that certain unaccountable peculiarities might be explained in this way Did there exist in the as yet unexplored parts some accomplice ready to enter into communication with them

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: To all these questions which he mentally asked himself, Harding knew not what to reply; but he felt that the safety of the colony could not but be seriously threatened by the arrival of the brig.
children.prevalue: To all these questions which he mentally asked himself Harding knew not what to reply but he felt that the safety of the colony could not but be seriously threatened by the arrival of the brig

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: However, he and his companions were determined to fight to the last gasp. It would have been very important to know if the pirates were numerous and better armed than the colonists. But how was this information to be obtained?
children.prevalue: However he and his companions were determined to fight to the last gasp It would have been very important to know if the pirates were numerous and better armed than the colonists But how was this information to be obtained

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Night fell. The new moon had disappeared. Profound darkness enveloped the island and the sea. No light could pierce through the heavy piles of clouds on the horizon. The wind had died away completely with the twilight. Not a leaf rustled on the trees, not a ripple murmured on the shore. Nothing could be seen of the ship, all her lights being extinguished, and if she was still in sight of the island, her whereabouts could not be discovered.
children.prevalue: Night fell The new moon had disappeared Profound darkness enveloped the island and the sea No light could pierce through the heavy piles of clouds on the horizon The wind had died away completely with the twilight Not a leaf rustled on the trees not a ripple murmured on the shore Nothing could be seen of the ship all her lights being extinguished and if she was still in sight of the island her whereabouts could not be discovered

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Well! who knows? said Pencroft. Perhaps that cursed craft will stand off during the night, and we shall see nothing of her at daybreak.
children.prevalue: Well who knows said Pencroft Perhaps that cursed craft will stand off during the night and we shall see nothing of her at daybreak

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: As if in reply to the sailor's observation, a bright light flashed in the darkness, and a cannon-shot was heard.
children.prevalue: As if in reply to the sailor s observation a bright light flashed in the darkness and a cannon shot was heard

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: The vessel was still there and had guns on board.
children.prevalue: The vessel was still there and had guns on board

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Six seconds elapsed between the flash and the report.
children.prevalue: Six seconds elapsed between the flash and the report

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Therefore the brig was about a mile and a quarter from the coast.
children.prevalue: Therefore the brig was about a mile and a quarter from the coast

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: At the same time, the chains were heard rattling through the hawse-holes.
children.prevalue: At the same time the chains were heard rattling through the hawse holes

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The vessel had just anchored in sight of Granite House!
children.prevalue: The vessel had just anchored in sight of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: There was no longer any doubt as to the pirates' intentions. They had dropped anchor at a short distance from the island, and it was evident that the next day by means of their boats they purposed to land on the beach!
children.prevalue: There was no longer any doubt as to the pirates intentions They had dropped anchor at a short distance from the island and it was evident that the next day by means of their boats they purposed to land on the beach

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions were ready to act, but, determined though they were, they must not forget to be prudent. Perhaps their presence might still be concealed in the event of the pirates contenting themselves with landing on the shore without examining the interior of the island. It might be, indeed, that their only intention was to obtain fresh water from the Mercy, and it was not impossible that the bridge, thrown across a mile and a half from the mouth, and the manufactory at the Chimneys might escape their notice.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions were ready to act but determined though they were they must not forget to be prudent Perhaps their presence might still be concealed in the event of the pirates contenting themselves with landing on the shore without examining the interior of the island It might be indeed that their only intention was to obtain fresh water from the Mercy and it was not impossible that the bridge thrown across a mile and a half from the mouth and the manufactory at the Chimneys might escape their notice

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But why was that flag hoisted at the brig's peak? What was that shot fired for? Pure bravado doubtless, unless it was a sign of the act of taking possession. Harding knew now that the vessel was well armed. And what had the colonists of Lincoln Island to reply to the pirates' guns? A few muskets only.
children.prevalue: But why was that flag hoisted at the brig s peak What was that shot fired for Pure bravado doubtless unless it was a sign of the act of taking possession Harding knew now that the vessel was well armed And what had the colonists of Lincoln Island to reply to the pirates guns A few muskets only

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: However, observed Cyrus Harding, here we are in an impregnable position. The enemy cannot discover the mouth of the outlet, now that it is hidden under reeds and grass, and consequently it would be impossible for them to penetrate into Granite House.
children.prevalue: However observed Cyrus Harding here we are in an impregnable position The enemy cannot discover the mouth of the outlet now that it is hidden under reeds and grass and consequently it would be impossible for them to penetrate into Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But our plantations, our poultry-yard, our corral, all, everything! exclaimed Pencroft, stamping his foot. They may spoil everything, destroy everything in a few hours!
children.prevalue: But our plantations our poultry yard our corral all everything exclaimed Pencroft stamping his foot They may spoil everything destroy everything in a few hours

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Everything, Pencroft, answered Harding, and we have no means of preventing them.
children.prevalue: Everything Pencroft answered Harding and we have no means of preventing them

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Are they numerous? that is the question, said the reporter. If they are not more than a dozen, we shall be able to stop them, but forty, fifty, more perhaps!
children.prevalue: Are they numerous that is the question said the reporter If they are not more than a dozen we shall be able to stop them but forty fifty more perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Captain Harding, then said Ayrton, advancing towards the engineer, will you give me leave?
children.prevalue: Captain Harding then said Ayrton advancing towards the engineer will you give me leave

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: For what, my friend?
children.prevalue: For what my friend

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: To go to that vessel to find out the strength of her crew.
children.prevalue: To go to that vessel to find out the strength of her crew

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But Ayrton-- answered the engineer, hesitating, you will risk your life--
children.prevalue: But Ayrton answered the engineer hesitating you will risk your life

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Why not, sir?
children.prevalue: Why not sir

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: That is more than your duty.
children.prevalue: That is more than your duty

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I have more than my duty to do, replied Ayrton.
children.prevalue: I have more than my duty to do replied Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Will you go to the ship in the boat? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Will you go to the ship in the boat asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: No, sir, but I will swim. A boat would be seen where a man may glide between wind and water.
children.prevalue: No sir but I will swim A boat would be seen where a man may glide between wind and water

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Do you know that the brig is a mile and a quarter from the shore? said Herbert.
children.prevalue: Do you know that the brig is a mile and a quarter from the shore said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I am a good swimmer, Mr. Herbert.
children.prevalue: I am a good swimmer Mr Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I tell you it is risking your life, said the engineer.
children.prevalue: I tell you it is risking your life said the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: That is no matter, answered Ayrton. Captain Harding, I ask this as a favor. Perhaps it will be a means of raising me in my own eyes!
children.prevalue: That is no matter answered Ayrton Captain Harding I ask this as a favor Perhaps it will be a means of raising me in my own eyes

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Go, Ayrton, replied the engineer, who felt sure that a refusal would have deeply wounded the former convict, now become an honest man.
children.prevalue: Go Ayrton replied the engineer who felt sure that a refusal would have deeply wounded the former convict now become an honest man

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I will accompany you, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: I will accompany you said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You mistrust me! said Ayrton quickly.
children.prevalue: You mistrust me said Ayrton quickly

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Then more humbly,--
children.prevalue: Then more humbly

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Alas!
children.prevalue: Alas

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No! no! exclaimed Harding with animation, no, Ayrton, Pencroft does not mistrust you. You interpret his words wrongly.
children.prevalue: No no exclaimed Harding with animation no Ayrton Pencroft does not mistrust you You interpret his words wrongly

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Indeed, returned the sailor, I only propose to accompany Ayrton as far as the islet. It may be, although it is scarcely possible, that one of these villains has landed, and in that case two men will not be too many to hinder him from giving the alarm. I will wait for Ayrton on the islet, and he shall go alone to the vessel, since he has proposed to do so. These things agreed to, Ayrton made preparations for his departure. His plan was bold, but it might succeed, thanks to the darkness of the night. Once arrived at the vessel's side, Ayrton, holding on to the main chains, might reconnoiter the number and perhaps overhear the intentions of the pirates.
children.prevalue: Indeed returned the sailor I only propose to accompany Ayrton as far as the islet It may be although it is scarcely possible that one of these villains has landed and in that case two men will not be too many to hinder him from giving the alarm I will wait for Ayrton on the islet and he shall go alone to the vessel since he has proposed to do so These things agreed to Ayrton made preparations for his departure His plan was bold but it might succeed thanks to the darkness of the night Once arrived at the vessel s side Ayrton holding on to the main chains might reconnoiter the number and perhaps overhear the intentions of the pirates

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Ayrton and Pencroft, followed by their companions, descended to the beach. Ayrton undressed and rubbed himself with grease, so as to suffer less from the temperature of the water, which was still cold. He might, indeed, be obliged to remain in it for several hours.
children.prevalue: Ayrton and Pencroft followed by their companions descended to the beach Ayrton undressed and rubbed himself with grease so as to suffer less from the temperature of the water which was still cold He might indeed be obliged to remain in it for several hours

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Pencroft and Neb, during this time, had gone to fetch the boat, moored a few hundred feet higher up, on the bank of the Mercy, and by the time they returned, Ayrton was ready to start. A coat was thrown over his shoulders, and the settlers all came round him to press his hand.
children.prevalue: Pencroft and Neb during this time had gone to fetch the boat moored a few hundred feet higher up on the bank of the Mercy and by the time they returned Ayrton was ready to start A coat was thrown over his shoulders and the settlers all came round him to press his hand

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Ayrton then shoved off with Pencroft in the boat.
children.prevalue: Ayrton then shoved off with Pencroft in the boat

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: It was half-past ten in the evening when the two adventurers disappeared in the darkness. Their companions returned to wait at the Chimneys.
children.prevalue: It was half past ten in the evening when the two adventurers disappeared in the darkness Their companions returned to wait at the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The channel was easily traversed, and the boat touched the opposite shore of the islet. This was not done without precaution, for fear lest the pirates might be roaming about there. But after a careful survey, it was evident that the islet was deserted. Ayrton then, followed by Pencroft, crossed it with a rapid step, scaring the birds nestled in the holes of the rocks; then, without hesitating, he plunged into the sea, and swam noiselessly in the direction of the ship, in which a few lights had recently appeared, showing her exact situation. As to Pencroft, he crouched down in a cleft of the rock, and awaited the return of his companion.
children.prevalue: The channel was easily traversed and the boat touched the opposite shore of the islet This was not done without precaution for fear lest the pirates might be roaming about there But after a careful survey it was evident that the islet was deserted Ayrton then followed by Pencroft crossed it with a rapid step scaring the birds nestled in the holes of the rocks then without hesitating he plunged into the sea and swam noiselessly in the direction of the ship in which a few lights had recently appeared showing her exact situation As to Pencroft he crouched down in a cleft of the rock and awaited the return of his companion

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: In the meanwhile, Ayrton, swimming with a vigorous stroke, glided through the sheet of water without producing the slightest ripple. His head just emerged above it and his eyes were fixed on the dark hull of the brig, from which the lights were reflected in the water. He thought only of the duty which he had promised to accomplish, and nothing of the danger which he ran, not only on board the ship, but in the sea, often frequented by sharks. The current bore him along and he rapidly receded from the shore.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile Ayrton swimming with a vigorous stroke glided through the sheet of water without producing the slightest ripple His head just emerged above it and his eyes were fixed on the dark hull of the brig from which the lights were reflected in the water He thought only of the duty which he had promised to accomplish and nothing of the danger which he ran not only on board the ship but in the sea often frequented by sharks The current bore him along and he rapidly receded from the shore

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Half an hour afterwards, Ayrton, without having been either seen or heard, arrived at the ship and caught hold of the main-chains. He took breath, then, hoisting himself up, he managed to reach the extremity of the cutwater. There were drying several pairs of sailors' trousers. He put on a pair. Then settling himself firmly, he listened. They were not sleeping on board the brig. On the contrary, they were talking, singing, laughing. And these were the sentences, accompanied with oaths, which principally struck Ayrton:--
children.prevalue: Half an hour afterwards Ayrton without having been either seen or heard arrived at the ship and caught hold of the main chains He took breath then hoisting himself up he managed to reach the extremity of the cutwater There were drying several pairs of sailors trousers He put on a pair Then settling himself firmly he listened They were not sleeping on board the brig On the contrary they were talking singing laughing And these were the sentences accompanied with oaths which principally struck Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Our brig is a famous acquisition.
children.prevalue: Our brig is a famous acquisition

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: She sails well, and merits her name of the 'Speedy.'
children.prevalue: She sails well and merits her name of the Speedy

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: She would show all the navy of Norfolk a clean pair of heels.
children.prevalue: She would show all the navy of Norfolk a clean pair of heels

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Hurrah for her captain!
children.prevalue: Hurrah for her captain

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Hurrah for Bob Harvey!
children.prevalue: Hurrah for Bob Harvey

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: What Ayrton felt when he overheard this fragment of conversation may be understood when it is known that in this Bob Harvey he recognized one of his old Australian companions, a daring sailor, who had continued his criminal career. Bob Harvey had seized, on the shores of Norfolk Island this brig, which was loaded with arms, ammunition, utensils, and tools of all sorts, destined for one of the Sandwich Islands. All his gang had gone on board, and pirates after having been convicts, these wretches, more ferocious than the Malays themselves, scoured the Pacific, destroying vessels, and massacring their crews.
children.prevalue: What Ayrton felt when he overheard this fragment of conversation may be understood when it is known that in this Bob Harvey he recognized one of his old Australian companions a daring sailor who had continued his criminal career Bob Harvey had seized on the shores of Norfolk Island this brig which was loaded with arms ammunition utensils and tools of all sorts destined for one of the Sandwich Islands All his gang had gone on board and pirates after having been convicts these wretches more ferocious than the Malays themselves scoured the Pacific destroying vessels and massacring their crews

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The convicts spoke loudly, they recounted their deeds, drinking deeply at the same time, and this is what Ayrton gathered. The actual crew of the Speedy was composed solely of English prisoners, escaped from Norfolk Island.
children.prevalue: The convicts spoke loudly they recounted their deeds drinking deeply at the same time and this is what Ayrton gathered The actual crew of the Speedy was composed solely of English prisoners escaped from Norfolk Island

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Here it may be well to explain what this island was. In 29deg 2' south latitude, and 165deg 42' east longitude, to the east of Australia, is found a little island, six miles in circumference, overlooked by Mount Pitt, which rises to a height of 1,100 feet above the level of the sea. This is Norfolk Island, once the seat of an establishment in which were lodged the most intractable convicts from the English penitentiaries. They numbered 500, under an iron discipline, threatened with terrible punishments, and were guarded by 150 soldiers, and 150 employed under the orders of the governor. It would be difficult to imagine a collection of greater ruffians. Sometimes,--although very rarely,--notwithstanding the extreme surveillance of which they were the object, many managed to escape, and seizing vessels which they surprised, they infested the Polynesian Archipelagoes.
children.prevalue: Here it may be well to explain what this island was In 29deg 2 south latitude and 165deg 42 east longitude to the east of Australia is found a little island six miles in circumference overlooked by Mount Pitt which rises to a height of 1 100 feet above the level of the sea This is Norfolk Island once the seat of an establishment in which were lodged the most intractable convicts from the English penitentiaries They numbered 500 under an iron discipline threatened with terrible punishments and were guarded by 150 soldiers and 150 employed under the orders of the governor It would be difficult to imagine a collection of greater ruffians Sometimes although very rarely notwithstanding the extreme surveillance of which they were the object many managed to escape and seizing vessels which they surprised they infested the Polynesian Archipelagoes

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Thus had Bob Harvey and his companions done. Thus had Ayrton formerly wished to do. Bob Harvey had seized the brig Speedy, anchored in sight of Norfolk Island; the crew had been massacred; and for a year this ship had scoured the Pacific, under the command of Harvey, now a pirate, and well known to Ayrton!
children.prevalue: Thus had Bob Harvey and his companions done Thus had Ayrton formerly wished to do Bob Harvey had seized the brig Speedy anchored in sight of Norfolk Island the crew had been massacred and for a year this ship had scoured the Pacific under the command of Harvey now a pirate and well known to Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The convicts were, for the most part, assembled under the poop; but a few, stretched on the deck, were talking loudly.
children.prevalue: The convicts were for the most part assembled under the poop but a few stretched on the deck were talking loudly

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The conversation still continued amid shouts and libations. Ayrton learned that chance alone had brought the Speedy in sight of Lincoln Island; Bob Harvey had never yet set foot on it; but, as Cyrus Harding had conjectured, finding this unknown land in his course, its position being marked on no chart, he had formed the project of visiting it, and, if he found it suitable, of making it the brig's headquarters.
children.prevalue: The conversation still continued amid shouts and libations Ayrton learned that chance alone had brought the Speedy in sight of Lincoln Island Bob Harvey had never yet set foot on it but as Cyrus Harding had conjectured finding this unknown land in his course its position being marked on no chart he had formed the project of visiting it and if he found it suitable of making it the brig s headquarters

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: As to the black flag hoisted at the Speedy's peak, and the gun which had been fired, in imitation of men-of-war when they lower their colors, it was pure piratical bravado. It was in no way a signal, and no communication yet existed between the convicts and Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: As to the black flag hoisted at the Speedy s peak and the gun which had been fired in imitation of men of war when they lower their colors it was pure piratical bravado It was in no way a signal and no communication yet existed between the convicts and Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The settlers' domain was now menaced with terrible danger. Evidently the island, with its water, its harbor, its resources of all kinds so increased in value by the colonists, and the concealment afforded by Granite House, could not but be convenient for the convicts; in their hands it would become an excellent place of refuge, and, being unknown, it would assure them, for a long time perhaps, impunity and security. Evidently, also, the lives of the settlers would not be respected, and Bob Harvey and his accomplices' first care would be to massacre them without mercy. Harding and his companions had, therefore, not even the choice of flying and hiding themselves in the island, since the convicts intended to reside there, and since, in the event of the Speedy departing on an expedition, it was probable that some of the crew would remain on shore, so as to settle themselves there. Therefore, it would be necessary to fight, to destroy every one of these scoundrels, unworthy of pity, and against whom any means would be right. So thought Ayrton, and he well knew that Cyrus Harding would be of his way of thinking.
children.prevalue: The settlers domain was now menaced with terrible danger Evidently the island with its water its harbor its resources of all kinds so increased in value by the colonists and the concealment afforded by Granite House could not but be convenient for the convicts in their hands it would become an excellent place of refuge and being unknown it would assure them for a long time perhaps impunity and security Evidently also the lives of the settlers would not be respected and Bob Harvey and his accomplices first care would be to massacre them without mercy Harding and his companions had therefore not even the choice of flying and hiding themselves in the island since the convicts intended to reside there and since in the event of the Speedy departing on an expedition it was probable that some of the crew would remain on shore so as to settle themselves there Therefore it would be necessary to fight to destroy every one of these scoundrels unworthy of pity and against whom any means would be right So thought Ayrton and he well knew that Cyrus Harding would be of his way of thinking

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: But was resistance and, in the last place, victory possible? That would depend on the equipment of the brig, and the number of men which she carried.
children.prevalue: But was resistance and in the last place victory possible That would depend on the equipment of the brig and the number of men which she carried

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: This Ayrton resolved to learn at any cost, and as an hour after his arrival the vociferations had begun to die away, and as a large number of the convicts were already buried in a drunken sleep, Ayrton did not hesitate to venture onto the Speedy's deck, which the extinguished lanterns now left in total darkness. He hoisted himself onto the cutwater, and by the bowsprit arrived at the forecastle. Then, gliding among the convicts stretched here and there, he made the round of the ship, and found that the Speedy carried four guns, which would throw shot of from eight to ten pounds in weight. He found also, on touching them that these guns were breech-loaders. They were therefore, of modern make, easily used, and of terrible effect.
children.prevalue: This Ayrton resolved to learn at any cost and as an hour after his arrival the vociferations had begun to die away and as a large number of the convicts were already buried in a drunken sleep Ayrton did not hesitate to venture onto the Speedy s deck which the extinguished lanterns now left in total darkness He hoisted himself onto the cutwater and by the bowsprit arrived at the forecastle Then gliding among the convicts stretched here and there he made the round of the ship and found that the Speedy carried four guns which would throw shot of from eight to ten pounds in weight He found also on touching them that these guns were breech loaders They were therefore of modern make easily used and of terrible effect

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: As to the men lying on the deck, they were about ten in number, but it was to be supposed that more were sleeping down below. Besides, by listening to them, Ayrton had understood that there were fifty on board. That was a large number for the six settlers of Lincoln Island to contend with! But now, thanks to Ayrton's devotion, Cyrus Harding would not be surprised, he would know the strength of his adversaries, and would make his arrangements accordingly.
children.prevalue: As to the men lying on the deck they were about ten in number but it was to be supposed that more were sleeping down below Besides by listening to them Ayrton had understood that there were fifty on board That was a large number for the six settlers of Lincoln Island to contend with But now thanks to Ayrton s devotion Cyrus Harding would not be surprised he would know the strength of his adversaries and would make his arrangements accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: There was nothing more for Ayrton to do but to return, and render to his companions an account of the mission with which he had charged himself, and he prepared to regain the bows of the brig, so that he might let himself down into the water. But to this man, whose wish was, as he had said, to do more than his duty, there came an heroic thought. This was to sacrifice his own life, but save the island and the colonists. Cyrus Harding evidently could not resist fifty ruffians, all well armed, who, either by penetrating by main force into Granite House, or by starving out the besieged, could obtain from them what they wanted. And then he thought of his preservers--those who had made him again a man, and an honest mm, those to whom he owed all--murdered without pity, their works destroyed, their island turned into a pirates' den! He said to himself that he, Ayrton, was the principal cause of so many disasters, since his old companion, Bob Harvey, had but realized his own plans, and a feeling of horror took possession of him. Then he was seized with an irresistible desire to blow up the brig and with her, all whom she had on board. He would perish in the explosion, but he would have done his duty.
children.prevalue: There was nothing more for Ayrton to do but to return and render to his companions an account of the mission with which he had charged himself and he prepared to regain the bows of the brig so that he might let himself down into the water But to this man whose wish was as he had said to do more than his duty there came an heroic thought This was to sacrifice his own life but save the island and the colonists Cyrus Harding evidently could not resist fifty ruffians all well armed who either by penetrating by main force into Granite House or by starving out the besieged could obtain from them what they wanted And then he thought of his preservers those who had made him again a man and an honest mm those to whom he owed all murdered without pity their works destroyed their island turned into a pirates den He said to himself that he Ayrton was the principal cause of so many disasters since his old companion Bob Harvey had but realized his own plans and a feeling of horror took possession of him Then he was seized with an irresistible desire to blow up the brig and with her all whom she had on board He would perish in the explosion but he would have done his duty

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Ayrton did not hesitate. To reach the powder-room, which is always situated in the after-part of a vessel, was easy. There would be no want of powder in a vessel which followed such a trade, and a spark would be enough to destroy it in an instant.
children.prevalue: Ayrton did not hesitate To reach the powder room which is always situated in the after part of a vessel was easy There would be no want of powder in a vessel which followed such a trade and a spark would be enough to destroy it in an instant

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Ayrton stole carefully along the between-decks, strewn with numerous sleepers, overcome more by drunkenness than sleep. A lantern was lighted at the foot of the mainmast, round which was hung a gun-rack, furnished with weapons of all sorts.
children.prevalue: Ayrton stole carefully along the between decks strewn with numerous sleepers overcome more by drunkenness than sleep A lantern was lighted at the foot of the mainmast round which was hung a gun rack furnished with weapons of all sorts

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Ayrton took a revolver from the rack, and assured himself that it was loaded and primed. Nothing more was needed to accomplish the work of destruction. He then glided towards the stern, so as to arrive under the brig's poop at the powder-magazine.
children.prevalue: Ayrton took a revolver from the rack and assured himself that it was loaded and primed Nothing more was needed to accomplish the work of destruction He then glided towards the stern so as to arrive under the brig s poop at the powder magazine

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: It was difficult to proceed along the dimly lighted deck without stumbling over some half-sleeping convict, who retorted by oaths and kicks. Ayrton was, therefore, more than once obliged to halt. But at last he arrived at the partition dividing the aftercabin, and found the door opening into the magazine itself.
children.prevalue: It was difficult to proceed along the dimly lighted deck without stumbling over some half sleeping convict who retorted by oaths and kicks Ayrton was therefore more than once obliged to halt But at last he arrived at the partition dividing the aftercabin and found the door opening into the magazine itself

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Ayrton, compelled to force it open, set to work. It was a difficult operation to perform without noise, for he had to break a padlock. But under his vigorous hand, the padlock broke, and the door was open.
children.prevalue: Ayrton compelled to force it open set to work It was a difficult operation to perform without noise for he had to break a padlock But under his vigorous hand the padlock broke and the door was open

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: At that moment a hand was laid on Ayrton's shoulder.
children.prevalue: At that moment a hand was laid on Ayrton s shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What are you doing here? asked a tall man, in a harsh voice, who, standing in the shadow, quickly threw the light of a lantern in Ayrton's face.
children.prevalue: What are you doing here asked a tall man in a harsh voice who standing in the shadow quickly threw the light of a lantern in Ayrton s face

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Ayrton drew back. In the rapid flash of the lantern, he had recognized his former accomplice, Bob Harvey, who could not have known him, as he must have thought Ayrton long since dead.
children.prevalue: Ayrton drew back In the rapid flash of the lantern he had recognized his former accomplice Bob Harvey who could not have known him as he must have thought Ayrton long since dead

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What are you doing here? again said Bob Harvey, seizing Ayrton by the waistband.
children.prevalue: What are you doing here again said Bob Harvey seizing Ayrton by the waistband

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: But Ayrton, without replying, wrenched himself from his grasp and attempted to rush into the magazine. A shot fired into the midst of the powder-casks, and all would be over!
children.prevalue: But Ayrton without replying wrenched himself from his grasp and attempted to rush into the magazine A shot fired into the midst of the powder casks and all would be over

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Help, lads! shouted Bob Harvey.
children.prevalue: Help lads shouted Bob Harvey

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: At his shout two or three pirates awoke, jumped up, and, rushing on Ayrton, endeavored to throw him down. He soon extricated himself from their grasp. He fired his revolver, and two of the convicts fell, but a blow from a knife which he could not ward off made a gash in his shoulder.
children.prevalue: At his shout two or three pirates awoke jumped up and rushing on Ayrton endeavored to throw him down He soon extricated himself from their grasp He fired his revolver and two of the convicts fell but a blow from a knife which he could not ward off made a gash in his shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Ayrton perceived that he could no longer hope to carry out his project. Bob Harvey had reclosed the door of the powder-magazine, and a movement on the deck indicated a general awakening of the pirates. Ayrton must reserve himself to fight at the side of Cyrus Harding. There was nothing for him but flight!
children.prevalue: Ayrton perceived that he could no longer hope to carry out his project Bob Harvey had reclosed the door of the powder magazine and a movement on the deck indicated a general awakening of the pirates Ayrton must reserve himself to fight at the side of Cyrus Harding There was nothing for him but flight

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: But was flight still possible? It was doubtful, yet Ayrton resolved to dare everything in order to rejoin his companions.
children.prevalue: But was flight still possible It was doubtful yet Ayrton resolved to dare everything in order to rejoin his companions

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Four barrels of the revolver were still undischarged. Two were fired--one, aimed at Bob Harvey, did not wound him, or at any rate only slightly, and Ayrton, profiting by the momentary retreat of his adversaries, rushed towards the companion-ladder to gain the deck. Passing before the lantern, he smashed it with a blow from the butt of his revolver. A profound darkness ensued, which favored his flight. Two or three pirates, awakened by the noise, were descending the ladder at the same moment.
children.prevalue: Four barrels of the revolver were still undischarged Two were fired one aimed at Bob Harvey did not wound him or at any rate only slightly and Ayrton profiting by the momentary retreat of his adversaries rushed towards the companion ladder to gain the deck Passing before the lantern he smashed it with a blow from the butt of his revolver A profound darkness ensued which favored his flight Two or three pirates awakened by the noise were descending the ladder at the same moment

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: A fifth shot from Ayrton laid one low, and the others drew back, not understanding what was going on. Ayrton was on deck in two bounds, and three seconds later, having discharged his last barrel in the face of a pirate who was about to seize him by the throat, he leaped over the bulwarks into the sea.
children.prevalue: A fifth shot from Ayrton laid one low and the others drew back not understanding what was going on Ayrton was on deck in two bounds and three seconds later having discharged his last barrel in the face of a pirate who was about to seize him by the throat he leaped over the bulwarks into the sea

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Ayrton had not made six strokes before shots were splashing around him like hail.
children.prevalue: Ayrton had not made six strokes before shots were splashing around him like hail

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: What were Pencroft's feelings, sheltered under a rock on the islet! What were those of Harding, the reporter, Herbert, and Neb, crouched in the Chimneys, when they heard the reports on board the brig! They rushed out on to the beach, and, their guns shouldered, they stood ready to repel any attack.
children.prevalue: What were Pencroft s feelings sheltered under a rock on the islet What were those of Harding the reporter Herbert and Neb crouched in the Chimneys when they heard the reports on board the brig They rushed out on to the beach and their guns shouldered they stood ready to repel any attack

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: They had no doubt about it themselves! Ayrton, surprised by the pirates, had been murdered, and, perhaps, the wretches would profit by the night to make a descent on the island!
children.prevalue: They had no doubt about it themselves Ayrton surprised by the pirates had been murdered and perhaps the wretches would profit by the night to make a descent on the island

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Half an hour was passed in terrible anxiety. The firing had ceased, and yet neither Ayrton nor Pencroft had reappeared. Was the islet invaded? Ought they not to fly to the help of Ayrton and Pencroft? But how? The tide being high at that time, rendered the channel impassable. The boat was not there! We may imagine the horrible anxiety which took possession of Harding and his companions!
children.prevalue: Half an hour was passed in terrible anxiety The firing had ceased and yet neither Ayrton nor Pencroft had reappeared Was the islet invaded Ought they not to fly to the help of Ayrton and Pencroft But how The tide being high at that time rendered the channel impassable The boat was not there We may imagine the horrible anxiety which took possession of Harding and his companions

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: At last, towards half-past twelve, a boat, carrying two men, touched the beach. It was Ayrton, slightly wounded in the shoulder, and Pencroft, safe and sound, whom their friends received with open arms.
children.prevalue: At last towards half past twelve a boat carrying two men touched the beach It was Ayrton slightly wounded in the shoulder and Pencroft safe and sound whom their friends received with open arms

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: All immediately took refuge in the Chimneys. There Ayrton recounted all that had passed, even to his plan for blowing up the brig, which he had attempted to put into execution.
children.prevalue: All immediately took refuge in the Chimneys There Ayrton recounted all that had passed even to his plan for blowing up the brig which he had attempted to put into execution

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: All hands were extended to Ayrton, who did not conceal from them that their situation was serious. The pirates had been alarmed. They knew that Lincoln Island was inhabited. They would land upon it in numbers and well armed. They would respect nothing. Should the settlers fall into their hands, they must expect no mercy!
children.prevalue: All hands were extended to Ayrton who did not conceal from them that their situation was serious The pirates had been alarmed They knew that Lincoln Island was inhabited They would land upon it in numbers and well armed They would respect nothing Should the settlers fall into their hands they must expect no mercy

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Well, we shall know how to die! said the reporter.
children.prevalue: Well we shall know how to die said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Let us go in and watch, answered the engineer.
children.prevalue: Let us go in and watch answered the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Have we any chance of escape, captain? asked the sailor.
children.prevalue: Have we any chance of escape captain asked the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Yes Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Hum! six against fifty!
children.prevalue: Hum six against fifty

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Yes! six! without counting--
children.prevalue: Yes six without counting

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Who? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Who asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Cyrus did not reply, but pointed upwards.
children.prevalue: Cyrus did not reply but pointed upwards

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The night passed without incident. The colonists were on the qui vive, and did not leave their post at the Chimneys. The pirates, on their side, did not appear to have made any attempt to land. Since the last shots fired at Ayrton not a report, not even a sound, had betrayed the presence of the brig in the neighborhood of the island. It might have been fancied that she had weighed anchor, thinking that she had to deal with her match, and had left the coast.
children.prevalue: The night passed without incident The colonists were on the qui vive and did not leave their post at the Chimneys The pirates on their side did not appear to have made any attempt to land Since the last shots fired at Ayrton not a report not even a sound had betrayed the presence of the brig in the neighborhood of the island It might have been fancied that she had weighed anchor thinking that she had to deal with her match and had left the coast

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: But it was no such thing, and when day began to dawn the settlers could see a confused mass through the morning mist. It was the Speedy.
children.prevalue: But it was no such thing and when day began to dawn the settlers could see a confused mass through the morning mist It was the Speedy

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: These, my friends, said the engineer, are the arrangements which appear to me best to make before the fog completely clears away. It hides us from the eyes of the pirates, and we can act without attracting their attention. The most important thing is, that the convicts should believe that the inhabitants of the island are numerous, and consequently capable of resisting them. I therefore propose that we divide into three parties. The first of which shall be posted at the Chimneys, the second at the mouth of the Mercy. As to the third, I think it would be best to place it on the islet, so as to prevent, or at all events delay, any attempt at landing. We have the use of two rifles and four muskets. Each of us will be armed, and, as we are amply provided with powder and shot, we need not spare our fire. We have nothing to fear from the muskets nor even from the guns of the brig. What can they do against these rocks? And, as we shall not fire from the windows of Granite House, the pirates will not think of causing irreparable damage by throwing shell against it. What is to be feared is, the necessity of meeting hand-to-hand, since the convicts have numbers on their side. We must therefore try to prevent them from landing, but without discovering ourselves. Therefore, do not economize the ammunition. Fire often, but with a sure aim. We have each eight or ten enemies to kill, and they must be killed!
children.prevalue: These my friends said the engineer are the arrangements which appear to me best to make before the fog completely clears away It hides us from the eyes of the pirates and we can act without attracting their attention The most important thing is that the convicts should believe that the inhabitants of the island are numerous and consequently capable of resisting them I therefore propose that we divide into three parties The first of which shall be posted at the Chimneys the second at the mouth of the Mercy As to the third I think it would be best to place it on the islet so as to prevent or at all events delay any attempt at landing We have the use of two rifles and four muskets Each of us will be armed and as we are amply provided with powder and shot we need not spare our fire We have nothing to fear from the muskets nor even from the guns of the brig What can they do against these rocks And as we shall not fire from the windows of Granite House the pirates will not think of causing irreparable damage by throwing shell against it What is to be feared is the necessity of meeting hand to hand since the convicts have numbers on their side We must therefore try to prevent them from landing but without discovering ourselves Therefore do not economize the ammunition Fire often but with a sure aim We have each eight or ten enemies to kill and they must be killed

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Cyrus Harding had clearly represented their situation, although he spoke in the calmest voice, as if it was a question of directing a piece of work and not ordering a battle. His companions approved these arrangements without even uttering a word. There was nothing more to be done but for each to take his place before the fog should be completely dissipated. Neb and Pencroft immediately ascended to Granite House and brought back a sufficient quantity of ammunition. Gideon Spilett and Ayrton, both very good marksmen, were armed with the two rifles, which carried nearly a mile. The four other muskets were divided among Harding, Neb, Pencroft, and Herbert.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding had clearly represented their situation although he spoke in the calmest voice as if it was a question of directing a piece of work and not ordering a battle His companions approved these arrangements without even uttering a word There was nothing more to be done but for each to take his place before the fog should be completely dissipated Neb and Pencroft immediately ascended to Granite House and brought back a sufficient quantity of ammunition Gideon Spilett and Ayrton both very good marksmen were armed with the two rifles which carried nearly a mile The four other muskets were divided among Harding Neb Pencroft and Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The posts were arranged in the following manner:--
children.prevalue: The posts were arranged in the following manner

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Herbert remained in ambush at the Chimneys, thus commanding the shore to the foot of Granite House.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Herbert remained in ambush at the Chimneys thus commanding the shore to the foot of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Gideon Spilett and Neb crouched among the rocks at the mouth of the Mercy, from which the drawbridges had been raised, so as to prevent any one from crossing in a boat or landing on the opposite shore.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett and Neb crouched among the rocks at the mouth of the Mercy from which the drawbridges had been raised so as to prevent any one from crossing in a boat or landing on the opposite shore

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: As to Ayrton and Pencroft, they shoved off in the boat, and prepared to cross the channel and to take up two separate stations on the islet. In this way, shots being fired from four different points at once, the convicts would be led to believe that the island was both largely peopled and strongly defended.
children.prevalue: As to Ayrton and Pencroft they shoved off in the boat and prepared to cross the channel and to take up two separate stations on the islet In this way shots being fired from four different points at once the convicts would be led to believe that the island was both largely peopled and strongly defended

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: In the event of a landing being effected without their having been able to prevent it, and also if they saw that they were on the point of being cut off by the brig's boat, Ayrton and Pencroft were to return in their boat to the shore and proceed towards the threatened spot.
children.prevalue: In the event of a landing being effected without their having been able to prevent it and also if they saw that they were on the point of being cut off by the brig s boat Ayrton and Pencroft were to return in their boat to the shore and proceed towards the threatened spot

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Before starting to occupy their posts, the colonists for the last time wrung each other's hands.
children.prevalue: Before starting to occupy their posts the colonists for the last time wrung each other s hands

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Pencroft succeeded in controlling himself sufficiently to suppress his emotion when he embraced Herbert, his boy! and then they separated.
children.prevalue: Pencroft succeeded in controlling himself sufficiently to suppress his emotion when he embraced Herbert his boy and then they separated

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: In a few moments Harding and Herbert on one side, the reporter and Neb on the other, had disappeared behind the rocks, and five minutes later Ayrton and Pencroft, having without difficulty crossed the channel, disembarked on the islet and concealed themselves in the clefts of its eastern shore.
children.prevalue: In a few moments Harding and Herbert on one side the reporter and Neb on the other had disappeared behind the rocks and five minutes later Ayrton and Pencroft having without difficulty crossed the channel disembarked on the islet and concealed themselves in the clefts of its eastern shore

children.name: Paragraph_13
