Pencroft, always enthusiastic in his projects, already spoke of constructing a battery to command the channel and the mouth of the river. With four guns, he engaged to prevent any fleet, however powerful it might be, from venturing into the waters of Lincoln Island!
children.prevalue: It may be seen that the arsenal of the colony had gained by the wreck as well as the storerooms of Granite House Pencroft always enthusiastic in his projects already spoke of constructing a battery to command the channel and the mouth of the river With four guns he engaged to prevent any fleet however powerful it might be from venturing into the waters of Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: In the meantime, when nothing remained of the brig but a useless hulk, bad weather came on, which soon finished her. Cyrus Harding had intended to blow her up, so as to collect the remains on the shore, but a strong gale from the northeast and a heavy sea compelled him to economize his powder.
children.prevalue: In the meantime when nothing remained of the brig but a useless hulk bad weather came on which soon finished her Cyrus Harding had intended to blow her up so as to collect the remains on the shore but a strong gale from the northeast and a heavy sea compelled him to economize his powder

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: In fact, on the night of the 23rd, the hull entirely broke up, and some of the wreck was cast up on the beach.
children.prevalue: In fact on the night of the 23rd the hull entirely broke up and some of the wreck was cast up on the beach

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: As to the papers on board, it is useless to say that, although he carefully searched the lockers of the poop, Harding did not discover any trace of them. The pirates had evidently destroyed everything that concerned either the captain or the owners of the Speedy, and, as the name of her port was not painted on her counter, there was nothing which would tell them her nationality. However, by the shape of her boats Ayrton and Pencroft believed that the brig was of English build.
children.prevalue: As to the papers on board it is useless to say that although he carefully searched the lockers of the poop Harding did not discover any trace of them The pirates had evidently destroyed everything that concerned either the captain or the owners of the Speedy and as the name of her port was not painted on her counter there was nothing which would tell them her nationality However by the shape of her boats Ayrton and Pencroft believed that the brig was of English build

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: A week after the castrophe--or, rather, after the fortunate, though inexplicable, event to which the colony owed its preservation--nothing more could be seen of the vessel, even at low tide. The wreck had disappeared, and Granite House was enriched by nearly all it had contained.
children.prevalue: A week after the castrophe or rather after the fortunate though inexplicable event to which the colony owed its preservation nothing more could be seen of the vessel even at low tide The wreck had disappeared and Granite House was enriched by nearly all it had contained

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: However, the mystery which enveloped its strange destruction would doubtless never have been cleared away if, on the 30th of November, Neb, strolling on the beach, had not found a piece of a thick iron cylinder, bearing traces of explosion. The edges of this cylinder were twisted and broken, as if they had been subjected to the action of some explosive substance.
children.prevalue: However the mystery which enveloped its strange destruction would doubtless never have been cleared away if on the 30th of November Neb strolling on the beach had not found a piece of a thick iron cylinder bearing traces of explosion The edges of this cylinder were twisted and broken as if they had been subjected to the action of some explosive substance

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Neb brought this piece of metal to his master, who was then occupied with his companions in the workshop of the Chimneys.
children.prevalue: Neb brought this piece of metal to his master who was then occupied with his companions in the workshop of the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Cyrus Harding examined the cylinder attentively, then, turning to Pencroft,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding examined the cylinder attentively then turning to Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: You persist, my friend, said he, in maintaining that the 'Speedy' was not lost in consequence of a collision?
children.prevalue: You persist my friend said he in maintaining that the Speedy was not lost in consequence of a collision

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Yes, captain, answered the sailor. You know as well as I do that there are no rocks in the channel.
children.prevalue: Yes captain answered the sailor You know as well as I do that there are no rocks in the channel

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: But suppose she had run against this piece of iron? said the engineer, showing the broken cylinder.
children.prevalue: But suppose she had run against this piece of iron said the engineer showing the broken cylinder

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: What, that bit of pipe! exclaimed Pencroft in a tone of perfect incredulity.
children.prevalue: What that bit of pipe exclaimed Pencroft in a tone of perfect incredulity

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: My friends, resumed Harding, you remember that before she foundered the brig rose on the summit of a regular waterspout?
children.prevalue: My friends resumed Harding you remember that before she foundered the brig rose on the summit of a regular waterspout

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Yes, captain, replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: Yes captain replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Well, would you like to know what occasioned that waterspout? It was this, said the engineer, holding up the broken tube.
children.prevalue: Well would you like to know what occasioned that waterspout It was this said the engineer holding up the broken tube

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: That? returned Pencroft.
children.prevalue: That returned Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Yes! This cylinder is all that remains of a torpedo!
children.prevalue: Yes This cylinder is all that remains of a torpedo

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: A torpedo! exclaimed the engineer's companions.
children.prevalue: A torpedo exclaimed the engineer s companions

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: And who put the torpedo there? demanded Pencroft, who did not like to yield.
children.prevalue: And who put the torpedo there demanded Pencroft who did not like to yield

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: All that I can tell you is, that it was not I, answered Cyrus Harding; but it was there, and you have been able to judge of its incomparable power!
children.prevalue: All that I can tell you is that it was not I answered Cyrus Harding but it was there and you have been able to judge of its incomparable power

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: So, then, all was explained by the submarine explosion of this torpedo. Cyrus Harding could not be mistaken, as, during the war of the Union, he had had occasion to try these terrible engines of destruction. It was under the action of this cylinder, charged with some explosive substance, nitro-glycerine, picrate, or some other material of the same nature, that the water of the channel had been raised like a dome, the bottom of the brig crushed in, and she had sunk instantly, the damage done to her hull being so considerable that it was impossible to refloat her. The Speedy had not been able to withstand a torpedo that would have destroyed an ironclad as easily as a fishing-boat!
children.prevalue: So then all was explained by the submarine explosion of this torpedo Cyrus Harding could not be mistaken as during the war of the Union he had had occasion to try these terrible engines of destruction It was under the action of this cylinder charged with some explosive substance nitro glycerine picrate or some other material of the same nature that the water of the channel had been raised like a dome the bottom of the brig crushed in and she had sunk instantly the damage done to her hull being so considerable that it was impossible to refloat her The Speedy had not been able to withstand a torpedo that would have destroyed an ironclad as easily as a fishing boat

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Yes! all was explained, everything--except the presence of the torpedo in the waters of the channel!
children.prevalue: Yes all was explained everything except the presence of the torpedo in the waters of the channel

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: My friends, then, said Cyrus Harding, we can no longer be in doubt as to the presence of a mysterious being, a castaway like us, perhaps, abandoned on our island, and I say this in order that Ayrton may be acquainted with all the strange events which have occurred during these two years. Who this beneficent stranger is, whose intervention has, so fortunately for us, been manifested on many occasions, I cannot imagine. What his object can be in acting thus, in concealing himself after rendering us so many services, I cannot understand: But his services are not the less real, and are of such a nature that only a man possessed of prodigious power, could render them. Ayrton is indebted to him as much as we are, for, if it was the stranger who saved me from the waves after the fall from the balloon, evidently it was he who wrote the document, who placed the bottle in the channel, and who has made known to us the situation of our companion. I will add that it was he who guided that chest, provided with everything we wanted, and stranded it on Flotsam Point; that it was he who lighted that fire on the heights of the island, which permitted you to land; that it was he who fired that bullet found in the body of the peccary; that it was he who plunged that torpedo into the channel, which destroyed the brig; in a word, that all those inexplicable events, for which we could not assign a reason, are due to this mysterious being. Therefore, whoever he may be, whether shipwrecked, or exiled on our island, we shall be ungrateful, if we think ourselves freed from gratitude towards him. We have contracted a debt, and I hope that we shall one day pay it.
children.prevalue: My friends then said Cyrus Harding we can no longer be in doubt as to the presence of a mysterious being a castaway like us perhaps abandoned on our island and I say this in order that Ayrton may be acquainted with all the strange events which have occurred during these two years Who this beneficent stranger is whose intervention has so fortunately for us been manifested on many occasions I cannot imagine What his object can be in acting thus in concealing himself after rendering us so many services I cannot understand But his services are not the less real and are of such a nature that only a man possessed of prodigious power could render them Ayrton is indebted to him as much as we are for if it was the stranger who saved me from the waves after the fall from the balloon evidently it was he who wrote the document who placed the bottle in the channel and who has made known to us the situation of our companion I will add that it was he who guided that chest provided with everything we wanted and stranded it on Flotsam Point that it was he who lighted that fire on the heights of the island which permitted you to land that it was he who fired that bullet found in the body of the peccary that it was he who plunged that torpedo into the channel which destroyed the brig in a word that all those inexplicable events for which we could not assign a reason are due to this mysterious being Therefore whoever he may be whether shipwrecked or exiled on our island we shall be ungrateful if we think ourselves freed from gratitude towards him We have contracted a debt and I hope that we shall one day pay it

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: You are right in speaking thus, my dear Cyrus, replied Gideon Spilett. Yes, there is an almost all-powerful being, hidden in some part of the island, and whose influence has been singularly useful to our colony. I will add that the unknown appears to possess means of action which border on the supernatural, if in the events of practical life the supernatural were recognizable. Is it he who is in secret communication with us by the well in Granite House, and has he thus a knowledge of all our plans? Was it he who threw us that bottle, when the vessel made her first cruise? Was it he who threw Top out of the lake, and killed the dugong? Was it he, who as everything leads us to believe, saved you from the waves, and that under circumstances in which any one else would not have been able to act? If it was he, he possesses a power which renders him master of the elements.
children.prevalue: You are right in speaking thus my dear Cyrus replied Gideon Spilett Yes there is an almost all powerful being hidden in some part of the island and whose influence has been singularly useful to our colony I will add that the unknown appears to possess means of action which border on the supernatural if in the events of practical life the supernatural were recognizable Is it he who is in secret communication with us by the well in Granite House and has he thus a knowledge of all our plans Was it he who threw us that bottle when the vessel made her first cruise Was it he who threw Top out of the lake and killed the dugong Was it he who as everything leads us to believe saved you from the waves and that under circumstances in which any one else would not have been able to act If it was he he possesses a power which renders him master of the elements

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The reporter's reasoning was just, and every one felt it to be so.
children.prevalue: The reporter s reasoning was just and every one felt it to be so

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes, rejoined Cyrus Harding, if the intervention of a human being is not more questionable for us, I agree that he has at his disposal means of action beyond those possessed by humanity. There is a mystery still, but if we discover the man, the mystery will be discovered also. The question, then, is, ought we to respect the incognito of this generous being, or ought we to do everything to find him out? What is your opinion on the matter?
children.prevalue: Yes rejoined Cyrus Harding if the intervention of a human being is not more questionable for us I agree that he has at his disposal means of action beyond those possessed by humanity There is a mystery still but if we discover the man the mystery will be discovered also The question then is ought we to respect the incognito of this generous being or ought we to do everything to find him out What is your opinion on the matter

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: My opinion, said Pencroft, is that, whoever he may be, he is a brave man, and he has my esteem!
children.prevalue: My opinion said Pencroft is that whoever he may be he is a brave man and he has my esteem

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Be it so, answered Harding, but that is not an answer, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Be it so answered Harding but that is not an answer Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Master, then said Neb, my idea is, that we may search as long as we like for this gentleman whom you are talking about, but that we shall not discover him till he pleases.
children.prevalue: Master then said Neb my idea is that we may search as long as we like for this gentleman whom you are talking about but that we shall not discover him till he pleases

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: That's not bad, what you say, Neb, observed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: That s not bad what you say Neb observed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I am of Neb's opinion, said Gideon Spilett, but that is no reason for not attempting the adventure. Whether we find this mysterious being or not, we shall at least have fulfilled our duty towards him.
children.prevalue: I am of Neb s opinion said Gideon Spilett but that is no reason for not attempting the adventure Whether we find this mysterious being or not we shall at least have fulfilled our duty towards him

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And you, my boy, give us your opinion, said the engineer, turning to Herbert.
children.prevalue: And you my boy give us your opinion said the engineer turning to Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oh, cried Herbert, his countenance full of animation, how I should like to thank him, he who saved you first, and who has now saved us!
children.prevalue: Oh cried Herbert his countenance full of animation how I should like to thank him he who saved you first and who has now saved us

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Of course, my boy, replied Pencroft, so would I and all of us. I am not inquisitive, but I would give one of my eyes to see this individual face to face! It seems to me that he must be handsome, tall, strong, with a splendid beard, radiant hair, and that he must be seated on clouds, a great ball in his hands!
children.prevalue: Of course my boy replied Pencroft so would I and all of us I am not inquisitive but I would give one of my eyes to see this individual face to face It seems to me that he must be handsome tall strong with a splendid beard radiant hair and that he must be seated on clouds a great ball in his hands

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But, Pencroft, answered Spilett, you are describing a picture of the Creator.
children.prevalue: But Pencroft answered Spilett you are describing a picture of the Creator

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Possibly, Mr. Spilett, replied the sailor, but that is how I imagine him!
children.prevalue: Possibly Mr Spilett replied the sailor but that is how I imagine him

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And you, Ayrton? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: And you Ayrton asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Captain Harding, replied Ayrton, I can give you no better advice in this matter. Whatever you do will be best; when you wish me to join you in your researches, I am ready to follow you.
children.prevalue: Captain Harding replied Ayrton I can give you no better advice in this matter Whatever you do will be best when you wish me to join you in your researches I am ready to follow you

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I thank you, Ayrton, answered Cyrus Harding, but I should like a more direct answer to the question I put to you. You are our companion; you have already endangered your life several times for us, and you, as well as the rest, ought to be consulted in the matter of any important decision. Speak, therefore.
children.prevalue: I thank you Ayrton answered Cyrus Harding but I should like a more direct answer to the question I put to you You are our companion you have already endangered your life several times for us and you as well as the rest ought to be consulted in the matter of any important decision Speak therefore

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Captain Harding, replied Ayrton, I think that we ought to do everything to discover this unknown benefactor. Perhaps he is alone. Perhaps he is suffering. Perhaps he has a life to be renewed. I, too, as you said, have a debt of gratitude to pay him. It was he, it could be only he who must have come to Tabor Island, who found there the wretch you knew, and who made known to you that there was an unfortunate man there to be saved. Therefore it is, thanks to him, that I have become a man again. No, I will never forget him!
children.prevalue: Captain Harding replied Ayrton I think that we ought to do everything to discover this unknown benefactor Perhaps he is alone Perhaps he is suffering Perhaps he has a life to be renewed I too as you said have a debt of gratitude to pay him It was he it could be only he who must have come to Tabor Island who found there the wretch you knew and who made known to you that there was an unfortunate man there to be saved Therefore it is thanks to him that I have become a man again No I will never forget him

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: That is settled, then, said Cyrus Harding. We will begin our researches as soon as possible. We will not leave a corner of the island unexplored. We will search into its most secret recesses, and will hope that our unknown friend will pardon us in consideration of our intentions!
children.prevalue: That is settled then said Cyrus Harding We will begin our researches as soon as possible We will not leave a corner of the island unexplored We will search into its most secret recesses and will hope that our unknown friend will pardon us in consideration of our intentions

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: For several days the colonists were actively employed in haymaking and the harvest. Before putting their project of exploring the yet unknown parts of the island into execution, they wished to get all possible work finished. It was also the time for collecting the various vegetables from the Tabor Island plants. All was stowed away, and happily there was no want of room in Granite House, in which they might have housed all the treasures of the island. The products of the colony were there, methodically arranged, and in a safe place, as may be believed, sheltered as much from animals as from man.
children.prevalue: For several days the colonists were actively employed in haymaking and the harvest Before putting their project of exploring the yet unknown parts of the island into execution they wished to get all possible work finished It was also the time for collecting the various vegetables from the Tabor Island plants All was stowed away and happily there was no want of room in Granite House in which they might have housed all the treasures of the island The products of the colony were there methodically arranged and in a safe place as may be believed sheltered as much from animals as from man

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: There was no fear of damp in the middle of that thick mass of granite. Many natural excavations situated in the upper passage were enlarged either by pick-axe or mine, and Granite House thus became a general warehouse, containing all the provisions, arms, tools, and spare utensils--in a word, all the stores of the colony.
children.prevalue: There was no fear of damp in the middle of that thick mass of granite Many natural excavations situated in the upper passage were enlarged either by pick axe or mine and Granite House thus became a general warehouse containing all the provisions arms tools and spare utensils in a word all the stores of the colony

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: As to the guns obtained from the brig, they were pretty pieces of ordnance, which, at Pencroft's entreaty, were hoisted by means of tackle and pulleys, right up into Granite House; embrasures were made between the windows, and the shining muzzles of the guns could soon be seen through the granite cliff. From this height they commanded all Union Bay. It was like a little Gibraltar, and any vessel anchored off the islet would inevitably be exposed to the fire of this aerial battery.
children.prevalue: As to the guns obtained from the brig they were pretty pieces of ordnance which at Pencroft s entreaty were hoisted by means of tackle and pulleys right up into Granite House embrasures were made between the windows and the shining muzzles of the guns could soon be seen through the granite cliff From this height they commanded all Union Bay It was like a little Gibraltar and any vessel anchored off the islet would inevitably be exposed to the fire of this aerial battery

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Captain, said Pencroft one day, it was the 8th of November, now that our fortifications are finished, it would be a good thing if we tried the range of our guns.
children.prevalue: Captain said Pencroft one day it was the 8th of November now that our fortifications are finished it would be a good thing if we tried the range of our guns

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Do you think that is useful? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: Do you think that is useful asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: It is more than useful, it is necessary! Without that how are we to know to what distance we can send one of those pretty shot with which we are provided?
children.prevalue: It is more than useful it is necessary Without that how are we to know to what distance we can send one of those pretty shot with which we are provided

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Try them, Pencroft, replied the engineer. However, I think that in making the experiment, we ought to employ, not the ordinary powder, the supply of which, I think, should remain untouched, but the pyroxyle which will never fail us.
children.prevalue: Try them Pencroft replied the engineer However I think that in making the experiment we ought to employ not the ordinary powder the supply of which I think should remain untouched but the pyroxyle which will never fail us

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Can the cannon support the shock of the pyroxyle? asked the reporter, who was not less anxious than Pencroft to try the artillery of Granite House.
children.prevalue: Can the cannon support the shock of the pyroxyle asked the reporter who was not less anxious than Pencroft to try the artillery of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I believe so. However, added the engineer, we will be prudent. The engineer was right in thinking that the guns were of excellent make. Made of forged steel, and breech-loaders, they ought consequently to be able to bear a considerable charge, and also have an enormous range. In fact, as regards practical effect, the transit described by the ball ought to be as extended as possible, and this tension could only be obtained under the condition that the projectile should be impelled with a very great initial velocity.
children.prevalue: I believe so However added the engineer we will be prudent The engineer was right in thinking that the guns were of excellent make Made of forged steel and breech loaders they ought consequently to be able to bear a considerable charge and also have an enormous range In fact as regards practical effect the transit described by the ball ought to be as extended as possible and this tension could only be obtained under the condition that the projectile should be impelled with a very great initial velocity

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Now, said Harding to his companions, the initial velocity is in proportion to the quantity of powder used. In the fabrication of these pieces, everything depends on employing a metal with the highest possible power of resistance, and steel is incontestably that metal of all others which resists the best. I have, therefore, reason to believe that our guns will bear without risk the expansion of the pyroxyle gas, and will give excellent results.
children.prevalue: Now said Harding to his companions the initial velocity is in proportion to the quantity of powder used In the fabrication of these pieces everything depends on employing a metal with the highest possible power of resistance and steel is incontestably that metal of all others which resists the best I have therefore reason to believe that our guns will bear without risk the expansion of the pyroxyle gas and will give excellent results

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: We shall be a great deal more certain of that when we have tried them! answered Pencroft.
children.prevalue: We shall be a great deal more certain of that when we have tried them answered Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It is unnecessary to say that the four cannons were in perfect order. Since they had been taken from the water, the sailor had bestowed great care upon them. How many hours he had spent, in rubbing, greasing, and polishing them, and in cleaning the mechanism! And now the pieces were as brilliant as if they had been on board a frigate of the United States Navy.
children.prevalue: It is unnecessary to say that the four cannons were in perfect order Since they had been taken from the water the sailor had bestowed great care upon them How many hours he had spent in rubbing greasing and polishing them and in cleaning the mechanism And now the pieces were as brilliant as if they had been on board a frigate of the United States Navy

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: On this day, therefore, in presence of all the members of the colony, including Master Jup and Top, the four cannon were successively tried. They were charged with pyroxyle, taking into consideration its explosive power, which, as has been said, is four times that of ordinary powder: the projectile to be fired was cylindroconic.
children.prevalue: On this day therefore in presence of all the members of the colony including Master Jup and Top the four cannon were successively tried They were charged with pyroxyle taking into consideration its explosive power which as has been said is four times that of ordinary powder the projectile to be fired was cylindroconic

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Pencroft, holding the end of the quick-match, stood ready to fire.
children.prevalue: Pencroft holding the end of the quick match stood ready to fire

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: At Harding's signal, he fired. The shot, passing over the islet, fell into the sea at a distance which could not be calculated with exactitude.
children.prevalue: At Harding s signal he fired The shot passing over the islet fell into the sea at a distance which could not be calculated with exactitude

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The second gun was pointed at the rocks at the end of Flotsam Point, and the shot striking a sharp rock nearly three miles from Granite House, made it fly into splinters. It was Herbert who had pointed this gun and fired it, and very proud he was of his first shot. Pencroft only was prouder than he! Such a shot, the honor of which belonged to his dear boy.
children.prevalue: The second gun was pointed at the rocks at the end of Flotsam Point and the shot striking a sharp rock nearly three miles from Granite House made it fly into splinters It was Herbert who had pointed this gun and fired it and very proud he was of his first shot Pencroft only was prouder than he Such a shot the honor of which belonged to his dear boy

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The third shot, aimed this time at the downs forming the upper side of Union Bay, struck the sand at a distance of four miles, then having ricocheted: was lost in the sea in a cloud of spray.
children.prevalue: The third shot aimed this time at the downs forming the upper side of Union Bay struck the sand at a distance of four miles then having ricocheted was lost in the sea in a cloud of spray

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: For the fourth piece Cyrus Harding slightly increased the charge, so as to try its extreme range. Then, all standing aside for fear of its bursting, the match was lighted by means of a long cord.
children.prevalue: For the fourth piece Cyrus Harding slightly increased the charge so as to try its extreme range Then all standing aside for fear of its bursting the match was lighted by means of a long cord

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: A tremendous report was heard, but the piece had held good, and the colonists rushing to the windows, saw the shot graze the rocks of Mandible Cape, nearly five miles from Granite House, and disappear in Shark Gulf.
children.prevalue: A tremendous report was heard but the piece had held good and the colonists rushing to the windows saw the shot graze the rocks of Mandible Cape nearly five miles from Granite House and disappear in Shark Gulf

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Well, captain, exclaimed Pencroft, whose cheers might have rivaled the reports themselves, what do you say of our battery? All the pirates in the Pacific have only to present themselves before Granite House! Not one can land there now without our permission!
children.prevalue: Well captain exclaimed Pencroft whose cheers might have rivaled the reports themselves what do you say of our battery All the pirates in the Pacific have only to present themselves before Granite House Not one can land there now without our permission

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Believe me, Pencroft, replied the engineer, it would be better not to have to make the experiment.
children.prevalue: Believe me Pencroft replied the engineer it would be better not to have to make the experiment

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Well, said the sailor, what ought to be done with regard to those six villains who are roaming about the island? Are we to leave them to overrun our forests, our fields, our plantations? These pirates are regular jaguars, and it seems to me we ought not to hesitate to treat them as such! What do you think, Ayrton? added Pencroft, turning to his companion.
children.prevalue: Well said the sailor what ought to be done with regard to those six villains who are roaming about the island Are we to leave them to overrun our forests our fields our plantations These pirates are regular jaguars and it seems to me we ought not to hesitate to treat them as such What do you think Ayrton added Pencroft turning to his companion

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Ayrton hesitated at first to reply, and Cyrus Harding regretted that Pencroft had so thoughtlessly put this question. And he was much moved when Ayrton replied in a humble tone,--
children.prevalue: Ayrton hesitated at first to reply and Cyrus Harding regretted that Pencroft had so thoughtlessly put this question And he was much moved when Ayrton replied in a humble tone

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I have been one of those jaguars, Mr. Pencroft. I have no right to speak.
children.prevalue: I have been one of those jaguars Mr Pencroft I have no right to speak

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And with a slow step he walked away.
children.prevalue: And with a slow step he walked away

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Pencroft understood.
children.prevalue: Pencroft understood

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What a brute I am! he exclaimed. Poor Ayrton! He has as much right to speak here as any one!
children.prevalue: What a brute I am he exclaimed Poor Ayrton He has as much right to speak here as any one

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, said Gideon Spilett, but his reserve does him honor, and it is right to respect the feeling which he has about his sad past.
children.prevalue: Yes said Gideon Spilett but his reserve does him honor and it is right to respect the feeling which he has about his sad past

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Certainly, Mr. Spilett, answered the sailor, and there is no fear of my doing so again. I would rather bite my tongue off than cause Ayrton any pain! But to return to the question. It seems to me that these ruffians have no right to any pity, and that we ought to rid the island of them as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: Certainly Mr Spilett answered the sailor and there is no fear of my doing so again I would rather bite my tongue off than cause Ayrton any pain But to return to the question It seems to me that these ruffians have no right to any pity and that we ought to rid the island of them as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Is that your opinion, Pencroft? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: Is that your opinion Pencroft asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Quite my opinion.
children.prevalue: Quite my opinion

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: And before hunting them mercilessly, you would not wait until they had committed some fresh act of hostility against us?
children.prevalue: And before hunting them mercilessly you would not wait until they had committed some fresh act of hostility against us

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Isn't what they have done already enough? asked Pencroft, who did not understand these scruples.
children.prevalue: Isn t what they have done already enough asked Pencroft who did not understand these scruples

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: They may adopt other sentiments! said Harding, and perhaps repent.
children.prevalue: They may adopt other sentiments said Harding and perhaps repent

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: They repent! exclaimed the sailor, shrugging his shoulders.
children.prevalue: They repent exclaimed the sailor shrugging his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Pencroft, think of Ayrton! said Herbert, taking the sailor's hand. He became an honest man again!
children.prevalue: Pencroft think of Ayrton said Herbert taking the sailor s hand He became an honest man again

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Pencroft looked at his companions one after the other. He had never thought of his proposal being met with any objection. His rough nature could not allow that they ought to come to terms with the rascals who had landed on the island with Bob Harvey's accomplices, the murderers of the crew of the Speedy, and he looked upon them as wild beasts which ought to be destroyed without delay and without remorse.
children.prevalue: Pencroft looked at his companions one after the other He had never thought of his proposal being met with any objection His rough nature could not allow that they ought to come to terms with the rascals who had landed on the island with Bob Harvey s accomplices the murderers of the crew of the Speedy and he looked upon them as wild beasts which ought to be destroyed without delay and without remorse

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Come! said be. Everybody is against me! You wish to be generous to those villains! Very well; I hope we mayn't repent it!
children.prevalue: Come said be Everybody is against me You wish to be generous to those villains Very well I hope we mayn t repent it

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What danger shall we run, said Herbert, if we take care to be always on our guard?
children.prevalue: What danger shall we run said Herbert if we take care to be always on our guard

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Hum! observed the reporter, who had not given any decided opinion. They are six and well armed. If they each lay hid in a corner, and each fired at one of us, they would soon be masters of the colony!
children.prevalue: Hum observed the reporter who had not given any decided opinion They are six and well armed If they each lay hid in a corner and each fired at one of us they would soon be masters of the colony

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Why have they not done so? said Herbert. No doubt because it was not their interest to do it. Besides, we are six also.
children.prevalue: Why have they not done so said Herbert No doubt because it was not their interest to do it Besides we are six also

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Well, well! replied Pencroft, whom no reasoning could have convinced. Let us leave these good people to do what they like, and don't think anything more about them!
children.prevalue: Well well replied Pencroft whom no reasoning could have convinced Let us leave these good people to do what they like and don t think anything more about them

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Come, Pencroft, said Neb, don't make yourself out so bad as all that! Suppose one of these unfortunate men were here before you, within good range of your guns, you would not fire.
children.prevalue: Come Pencroft said Neb don t make yourself out so bad as all that Suppose one of these unfortunate men were here before you within good range of your guns you would not fire

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I would fire on him as I would on a mad dog, Neb, replied Pencroft coldly.
children.prevalue: I would fire on him as I would on a mad dog Neb replied Pencroft coldly

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Pencroft, said the engineer, you have always shown much deference to my advice; will you, in this matter, yield to me?
children.prevalue: Pencroft said the engineer you have always shown much deference to my advice will you in this matter yield to me

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I will do as you please, Captain Harding, answered the sailor, who was not at all convinced.
children.prevalue: I will do as you please Captain Harding answered the sailor who was not at all convinced

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Very well, wait, and we will not attack them unless we are attacked first.
children.prevalue: Very well wait and we will not attack them unless we are attacked first

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Thus their behavior towards the pirates was agreed upon, although Pencroft augured nothing good from it. They were not to attack them, but were to be on their guard. After all, the island was large and fertile. If any sentiment of honesty yet remained in the bottom of their hearts, these wretches might perhaps be reclaimed. Was it not their interest in the situation in which they found themselves to begin a new life? At any rate, for humanity's sake alone, it would be right to wait. The colonists would no longer as before, be able to go and come without fear. Hitherto they had only wild beasts to guard against, and now six convicts of the worst description, perhaps, were roaming over their island. It was serious, certainly, and to less brave men, it would have been security lost! No matter! At present, the colonists had reason on their side against Pencroft. Would they be right in the future? That remained to be seen.
children.prevalue: Thus their behavior towards the pirates was agreed upon although Pencroft augured nothing good from it They were not to attack them but were to be on their guard After all the island was large and fertile If any sentiment of honesty yet remained in the bottom of their hearts these wretches might perhaps be reclaimed Was it not their interest in the situation in which they found themselves to begin a new life At any rate for humanity s sake alone it would be right to wait The colonists would no longer as before be able to go and come without fear Hitherto they had only wild beasts to guard against and now six convicts of the worst description perhaps were roaming over their island It was serious certainly and to less brave men it would have been security lost No matter At present the colonists had reason on their side against Pencroft Would they be right in the future That remained to be seen

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: However, the chief business of the colonists was to make that complete exploration of the island which had been decided upon, and which would have two objects: to discover the mysterious being whose existence was now indisputable, and at the same time to find out what had become of the pirates, what retreat they had chosen, what sort of life they were leading, and what was to be feared from them. Cyrus Harding wished to set out without delay; but as the expedition would be of some days duration, it appeared best to load the cart with different materials and tools in order to facilitate the organization of the encampments. One of the onagers, however, having hurt its leg, could not be harnessed at present, and a few days' rest was necessary. The departure was, therefore, put off for a week, until the 20th of November. The month of November in this latitude corresponds to the month of May in the northern zones. It was, therefore, the fine season. The sun was entering the tropic of Capricorn, and gave the longest days in the year. The time was, therefore, very favorable for the projected expedition, which, if it did not accomplish its principal object, would at any rate be fruitful in discoveries, especially of natural productions, since Harding proposed to explore those dense forests of the Far West, which stretched to the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula.
children.prevalue: However the chief business of the colonists was to make that complete exploration of the island which had been decided upon and which would have two objects to discover the mysterious being whose existence was now indisputable and at the same time to find out what had become of the pirates what retreat they had chosen what sort of life they were leading and what was to be feared from them Cyrus Harding wished to set out without delay but as the expedition would be of some days duration it appeared best to load the cart with different materials and tools in order to facilitate the organization of the encampments One of the onagers however having hurt its leg could not be harnessed at present and a few days rest was necessary The departure was therefore put off for a week until the 20th of November The month of November in this latitude corresponds to the month of May in the northern zones It was therefore the fine season The sun was entering the tropic of Capricorn and gave the longest days in the year The time was therefore very favorable for the projected expedition which if it did not accomplish its principal object would at any rate be fruitful in discoveries especially of natural productions since Harding proposed to explore those dense forests of the Far West which stretched to the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: During the nine days which preceded their departure, it was agreed that the work on Prospect Heights should be finished off.
children.prevalue: During the nine days which preceded their departure it was agreed that the work on Prospect Heights should be finished off

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Moreover, it was necessary for Ayrton to return to the corral, where the domesticated animals required his care. It was decided that he should spend two days there, and return to Granite House after having liberally supplied the stables.
children.prevalue: Moreover it was necessary for Ayrton to return to the corral where the domesticated animals required his care It was decided that he should spend two days there and return to Granite House after having liberally supplied the stables

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As he was about to start, Harding asked him if he would not like one of them to accompany him, observing that the island was less safe than formerly. Ayrton replied that this was unnecessary, as he was enough for the work, and that besides he apprehended no danger. If anything occurred at the corral, or in the neighborhood, he could instantly warn the colonists by sending a telegram to Granite House.
children.prevalue: As he was about to start Harding asked him if he would not like one of them to accompany him observing that the island was less safe than formerly Ayrton replied that this was unnecessary as he was enough for the work and that besides he apprehended no danger If anything occurred at the corral or in the neighborhood he could instantly warn the colonists by sending a telegram to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Ayrton departed at dawn on the 9th, taking the cart drawn by one onager, and two hours after, the electric wire announced that he had found all in order at the corral.
children.prevalue: Ayrton departed at dawn on the 9th taking the cart drawn by one onager and two hours after the electric wire announced that he had found all in order at the corral

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: During these two days Harding busied himself in executing a project which would completely guard Granite House against any surprise. It was necessary to completely conceal the opening of the old outlet, which was already walled up and partly hidden under grass and plants, at the southern angle of Lake Grant. Nothing was easier, since if the level of the lake was raised two or three feet, the opening would be quite beneath it. Now, to raise this level they had only to establish a dam at the two openings made by the lake, and by which were fed Creek Glycerine and Falls River.
children.prevalue: During these two days Harding busied himself in executing a project which would completely guard Granite House against any surprise It was necessary to completely conceal the opening of the old outlet which was already walled up and partly hidden under grass and plants at the southern angle of Lake Grant Nothing was easier since if the level of the lake was raised two or three feet the opening would be quite beneath it Now to raise this level they had only to establish a dam at the two openings made by the lake and by which were fed Creek Glycerine and Falls River

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The colonists worked with a will, and the two dams which besides did not exceed eight feet in width by three in height, were rapidly erected by means of well-cemented blocks of stone.
children.prevalue: The colonists worked with a will and the two dams which besides did not exceed eight feet in width by three in height were rapidly erected by means of well cemented blocks of stone

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: This work finished, it would have been impossible to guess that at that part of the lake, there existed a subterranean passage through which the overflow of the lake formerly escaped.
children.prevalue: This work finished it would have been impossible to guess that at that part of the lake there existed a subterranean passage through which the overflow of the lake formerly escaped

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Of course the little stream which fed the reservoir of Granite House and worked the lift, had been carefully preserved, and the water could not fail. The lift once raised, this sure and comfortable retreat would be safe from any surprise.
children.prevalue: Of course the little stream which fed the reservoir of Granite House and worked the lift had been carefully preserved and the water could not fail The lift once raised this sure and comfortable retreat would be safe from any surprise

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: This work had been so quickly done, that Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert found time to make an expedition to Port Balloon, The sailor was very anxious to know if the little creek in which the Bonadventure was moored, had been visited by the convicts.
children.prevalue: This work had been so quickly done that Pencroft Gideon Spilett and Herbert found time to make an expedition to Port Balloon The sailor was very anxious to know if the little creek in which the Bonadventure was moored had been visited by the convicts

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: These gentlemen, he observed, landed on the south coast, and if they followed the shore, it is to be feared that they may have discovered the little harbor, and in that case, I wouldn't give half-a-dollar for our 'Bonadventure.'
children.prevalue: These gentlemen he observed landed on the south coast and if they followed the shore it is to be feared that they may have discovered the little harbor and in that case I wouldn t give half a dollar for our Bonadventure

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Pencroft's apprehensions were not without foundation, and a visit to Port Balloon appeared to be very desirable. The sailor and his companions set off on the 10th of November, after dinner, well armed. Pencroft, ostentatiously slipping two bullets into each barrel of his rifle, shook his head in a way which betokened nothing good to any one who approached too near him, whether man or beast, as he said. Gideon Spilett and Herbert also took their guns, and about three o'clock all three left Granite House.
children.prevalue: Pencroft s apprehensions were not without foundation and a visit to Port Balloon appeared to be very desirable The sailor and his companions set off on the 10th of November after dinner well armed Pencroft ostentatiously slipping two bullets into each barrel of his rifle shook his head in a way which betokened nothing good to any one who approached too near him whether man or beast as he said Gideon Spilett and Herbert also took their guns and about three o clock all three left Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Neb accompanied them to the turn of the Mercy, and after they had crossed, he raised the bridge. It was agreed that a gunshot should announce the colonists' return, and that at the signal Neb should return and reestablish the communication between the two banks of the river.
children.prevalue: Neb accompanied them to the turn of the Mercy and after they had crossed he raised the bridge It was agreed that a gunshot should announce the colonists return and that at the signal Neb should return and reestablish the communication between the two banks of the river

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The little band advanced directly along the road which led to the southern coast of the island. This was only a distance of three miles and a half, but Gideon Spilett and his companions took two hours to traverse it. They examined all the border of the road, the thick forest, as well as Tabor Marsh. They found no trace of the fugitives who, no doubt, not having yet discovered the number of the colonists, or the means of defense which they had at their disposal, had gained the less accessible parts of the island.
children.prevalue: The little band advanced directly along the road which led to the southern coast of the island This was only a distance of three miles and a half but Gideon Spilett and his companions took two hours to traverse it They examined all the border of the road the thick forest as well as Tabor Marsh They found no trace of the fugitives who no doubt not having yet discovered the number of the colonists or the means of defense which they had at their disposal had gained the less accessible parts of the island

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Arrived at Port Balloon, Pencroft saw with extreme satisfaction that the Bonadventure was tranquilly floating in the narrow creek. However, Port Balloon was so well hidden among high rocks, that it could scarcely be discovered either from the land or the sea.
children.prevalue: Arrived at Port Balloon Pencroft saw with extreme satisfaction that the Bonadventure was tranquilly floating in the narrow creek However Port Balloon was so well hidden among high rocks that it could scarcely be discovered either from the land or the sea

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Come, said Pencroft, the blackguards have not been there yet. Long grass suits reptiles best, and evidently we shall find them in the Far West.
children.prevalue: Come said Pencroft the blackguards have not been there yet Long grass suits reptiles best and evidently we shall find them in the Far West

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And it's very lucky, for if they had found the 'Bonadventure', added Herbert, they would have gone off in her, and we should have been prevented from returning to Tabor Island.
children.prevalue: And it s very lucky for if they had found the Bonadventure added Herbert they would have gone off in her and we should have been prevented from returning to Tabor Island

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Indeed, remarked the reporter, it will be important to take a document there which will make known the situation of Lincoln Island, and Ayrton's new residence, in case the Scotch yacht returns to fetch him.
children.prevalue: Indeed remarked the reporter it will be important to take a document there which will make known the situation of Lincoln Island and Ayrton s new residence in case the Scotch yacht returns to fetch him

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Well, the 'Bonadventure' is always there, Mr. Spilett, answered the sailor. She and her crew are ready to start at a moment's notice!
children.prevalue: Well the Bonadventure is always there Mr Spilett answered the sailor She and her crew are ready to start at a moment s notice

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I think, Pencroft, that that is a thing to be done after our exploration of the island is finished. It is possible after all that the stranger, if we manage to find him, may know as much about Tabor Island as about Lincoln Island. Do not forget that he is certainly the author of the document, and he may, perhaps, know how far we may count on the return of the yacht!
children.prevalue: I think Pencroft that that is a thing to be done after our exploration of the island is finished It is possible after all that the stranger if we manage to find him may know as much about Tabor Island as about Lincoln Island Do not forget that he is certainly the author of the document and he may perhaps know how far we may count on the return of the yacht

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But! exclaimed Pencroft, who in the world can he be? The fellow knows us and we know nothing about him! If he is a simple castaway, why should he conceal himself! We are honest men, I suppose, and the society of honest men isn't unpleasant to any one. Did he come here voluntarily? Can he leave the island if he likes? Is he here still? Will he remain any longer?
children.prevalue: But exclaimed Pencroft who in the world can he be The fellow knows us and we know nothing about him If he is a simple castaway why should he conceal himself We are honest men I suppose and the society of honest men isn t unpleasant to any one Did he come here voluntarily Can he leave the island if he likes Is he here still Will he remain any longer

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Chatting thus, Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert got on board and looked about the deck of the Bonadventure. All at once, the sailor having examined the bitts to which the cable of the anchor was secured,--
children.prevalue: Chatting thus Pencroft Gideon Spilett and Herbert got on board and looked about the deck of the Bonadventure All at once the sailor having examined the bitts to which the cable of the anchor was secured

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Hallo, he cried, this is queer!
children.prevalue: Hallo he cried this is queer

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What is the matter, Pencroft? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What is the matter Pencroft asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The matter is, that it was not I who made this knot!
children.prevalue: The matter is that it was not I who made this knot

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And Pencroft showed a rope which fastened the cable to the bitt itself.
children.prevalue: And Pencroft showed a rope which fastened the cable to the bitt itself

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: What, it was not you? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: What it was not you asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: No! I can swear to it. This is a reef knot, and I always make a running bowline.
children.prevalue: No I can swear to it This is a reef knot and I always make a running bowline

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: You must be mistaken, Pencroft.
children.prevalue: You must be mistaken Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I am not mistaken! declared the sailor. My hand does it so naturally, and one's hand is never mistaken!
children.prevalue: I am not mistaken declared the sailor My hand does it so naturally and one s hand is never mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Then can the convicts have been on board? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: Then can the convicts have been on board asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I know nothing about that, answered Pencroft, but what is certain, is that some one has weighed the 'Bonadventure's' anchor and dropped it again! And look here, here is another proof! The cable of the anchor has been run out, and its service is no longer at the hawse-hole. I repeat that some one has been using our vessel!
children.prevalue: I know nothing about that answered Pencroft but what is certain is that some one has weighed the Bonadventure s anchor and dropped it again And look here here is another proof The cable of the anchor has been run out and its service is no longer at the hawse hole I repeat that some one has been using our vessel

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But if the convicts had used her, they would have pillaged her, or rather gone off with her.
children.prevalue: But if the convicts had used her they would have pillaged her or rather gone off with her

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Gone off! where to--to Tabor Island? replied Pencroft. Do you think, they would risk themselves in a boat of such small tonnage?
children.prevalue: Gone off where to to Tabor Island replied Pencroft Do you think they would risk themselves in a boat of such small tonnage

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: We must, besides, be sure that they know of the islet, rejoined the reporter.
children.prevalue: We must besides be sure that they know of the islet rejoined the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: However that may be, said the sailor, as sure as my name is Bonadventure Pencroft, of the Vineyard, our 'Bonadventure' has sailed without us!
children.prevalue: However that may be said the sailor as sure as my name is Bonadventure Pencroft of the Vineyard our Bonadventure has sailed without us

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The sailor was positive that neither Gideon Spilett nor Herbert could dispute his statement. It was evident that the vessel had been moved, more or less, since Pencroft had brought her to Port Balloon. As to the sailor, he had not the slightest doubt that the anchor had been raised and then dropped again. Now, what was the use of these two maneuvers, unless the vessel had been employed in some expedition?
children.prevalue: The sailor was positive that neither Gideon Spilett nor Herbert could dispute his statement It was evident that the vessel had been moved more or less since Pencroft had brought her to Port Balloon As to the sailor he had not the slightest doubt that the anchor had been raised and then dropped again Now what was the use of these two maneuvers unless the vessel had been employed in some expedition

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: But how was it we did not see the 'Bonadventure' pass in the sight of the island? observed the reporter, who was anxious to bring forward every possible objection.
children.prevalue: But how was it we did not see the Bonadventure pass in the sight of the island observed the reporter who was anxious to bring forward every possible objection

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Why, Mr. Spilett, replied the sailor, they would only have to start in the night with a good breeze, and they would be out of sight of the island in two hours.
children.prevalue: Why Mr Spilett replied the sailor they would only have to start in the night with a good breeze and they would be out of sight of the island in two hours

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, resumed Gideon Spilett, I ask again, what object could the convicts have had in using the 'Bonadventure,' and why, after they had made use of her, should they have brought her back to port?
children.prevalue: Well resumed Gideon Spilett I ask again what object could the convicts have had in using the Bonadventure and why after they had made use of her should they have brought her back to port

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Why, Mr. Spilett, replied the sailor, we must put that among the unaccountable things, and not think anything more about it. The chief thing is that the 'Bonadventure' was there, and she is there now. Only, unfortunately, if the convicts take her a second time, we shall very likely not find her again in her place!
children.prevalue: Why Mr Spilett replied the sailor we must put that among the unaccountable things and not think anything more about it The chief thing is that the Bonadventure was there and she is there now Only unfortunately if the convicts take her a second time we shall very likely not find her again in her place

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Then, Pencroft, said Herbert, would it not be wisest to bring the 'Bonadventure' off to Granite House?
children.prevalue: Then Pencroft said Herbert would it not be wisest to bring the Bonadventure off to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes and no, answered Pencroft, or rather no. The mouth of the Mercy is a bad place for a vessel, and the sea is heavy there.
children.prevalue: Yes and no answered Pencroft or rather no The mouth of the Mercy is a bad place for a vessel and the sea is heavy there

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But by hauling her up on the sand, to the foot of the Chimneys?
children.prevalue: But by hauling her up on the sand to the foot of the Chimneys

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Perhaps yes, replied Pencroft. At any rate, since we must leave Granite House for a long expedition, I think the 'Bonadventure' will be safer here during our absence, and we shall do best to leave her here until the island is rid of these blackguards.
children.prevalue: Perhaps yes replied Pencroft At any rate since we must leave Granite House for a long expedition I think the Bonadventure will be safer here during our absence and we shall do best to leave her here until the island is rid of these blackguards

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: That is exactly my opinion, said the reporter. At any rate in the event of bad weather, she will not be exposed here as she would be at the mouth of the Mercy.
children.prevalue: That is exactly my opinion said the reporter At any rate in the event of bad weather she will not be exposed here as she would be at the mouth of the Mercy

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But suppose the convicts pay her another visit, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: But suppose the convicts pay her another visit said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Well, my boy, replied Pencroft, not finding her here, they would not be long in finding her on the sands of Granite House, and, during our absence, nothing could hinder them from seizing her! I agree, therefore, with Mr. Spilett, that she must be left in Port Balloon. But, if on our return we have not rid the island of those rascals, it will be prudent to bring our boat to Granite House, until the time when we need not fear any unpleasant visits.
children.prevalue: Well my boy replied Pencroft not finding her here they would not be long in finding her on the sands of Granite House and during our absence nothing could hinder them from seizing her I agree therefore with Mr Spilett that she must be left in Port Balloon But if on our return we have not rid the island of those rascals it will be prudent to bring our boat to Granite House until the time when we need not fear any unpleasant visits

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: That's settled. Let us be off, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: That s settled Let us be off said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Pencroft, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett, on their return to Granite House, told the engineer all that had passed, and the latter approved of their arrangements both for the present and the future. He also promised the sailor that he would study that part of the channel situated between the islet and the coast, so as to ascertain if it would not be possible to make an artificial harbor there by means of dams. In this way, the Bonadventure would be always within reach, under the eyes of the colonists, and if necessary, under lock and key.
children.prevalue: Pencroft Herbert and Gideon Spilett on their return to Granite House told the engineer all that had passed and the latter approved of their arrangements both for the present and the future He also promised the sailor that he would study that part of the channel situated between the islet and the coast so as to ascertain if it would not be possible to make an artificial harbor there by means of dams In this way the Bonadventure would be always within reach under the eyes of the colonists and if necessary under lock and key

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: That evening a telegram was sent to Ayrton, requesting him to bring from the corral a couple of goats, which Neb wished to acclimatize to the plateau. Singularly enough, Ayrton did not acknowledge the receipt of the despatch, as he was accustomed to do. This could not but astonish the engineer. But it might be that Ayrton was not at that moment in the corral, or even that he was on his way back to Granite House. In fact, two days had already passed since his departure, and it had been decided that on the evening of the 10th or at the latest the morning of the 11th, he should return. The colonists waited, therefore, for Ayrton to appear on Prospect Heights. Neb and Herbert even watched at the bridge so as to be ready to lower it the moment their companion presented himself.
children.prevalue: That evening a telegram was sent to Ayrton requesting him to bring from the corral a couple of goats which Neb wished to acclimatize to the plateau Singularly enough Ayrton did not acknowledge the receipt of the despatch as he was accustomed to do This could not but astonish the engineer But it might be that Ayrton was not at that moment in the corral or even that he was on his way back to Granite House In fact two days had already passed since his departure and it had been decided that on the evening of the 10th or at the latest the morning of the 11th he should return The colonists waited therefore for Ayrton to appear on Prospect Heights Neb and Herbert even watched at the bridge so as to be ready to lower it the moment their companion presented himself

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But up to ten in the evening, there were no signs of Ayrton. It was, therefore, judged best to send a fresh despatch, requiring an immediate reply.
children.prevalue: But up to ten in the evening there were no signs of Ayrton It was therefore judged best to send a fresh despatch requiring an immediate reply

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The bell of the telegraph at Granite House remained mute.
children.prevalue: The bell of the telegraph at Granite House remained mute

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The colonists' uneasiness was great. What had happened? Was Ayrton no longer at the corral, or if he was still there, had he no longer control over his movements? Could they go to the corral in this dark night?
children.prevalue: The colonists uneasiness was great What had happened Was Ayrton no longer at the corral or if he was still there had he no longer control over his movements Could they go to the corral in this dark night

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: They consulted. Some wished to go, the others to remain.
children.prevalue: They consulted Some wished to go the others to remain

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: But, said Herbert, perhaps some accident has happened to the telegraphic apparatus, so that it works no longer?
children.prevalue: But said Herbert perhaps some accident has happened to the telegraphic apparatus so that it works no longer

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: That may be, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: That may be said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Wait till to-morrow, replied Cyrus Harding. It is possible, indeed, that Ayrton has not received our despatch, or even that we have not received his.
children.prevalue: Wait till to morrow replied Cyrus Harding It is possible indeed that Ayrton has not received our despatch or even that we have not received his

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: They waited, of course not without some anxiety.
children.prevalue: They waited of course not without some anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: At dawn of day, the 11th of November, Harding again sent the electric current along the wire and received no reply.
children.prevalue: At dawn of day the 11th of November Harding again sent the electric current along the wire and received no reply

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: He tried again: the same result.
children.prevalue: He tried again the same result

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Off to the corral, said he.
children.prevalue: Off to the corral said he

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And well armed! added Pencroft.
children.prevalue: And well armed added Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It was immediately decided that Granite House should not be left alone and that Neb should remain there. After having accompanied his friends to Creek Glycerine, he raised the bridge; and waiting behind a tree he watched for the return of either his companions or Ayrton.
children.prevalue: It was immediately decided that Granite House should not be left alone and that Neb should remain there After having accompanied his friends to Creek Glycerine he raised the bridge and waiting behind a tree he watched for the return of either his companions or Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: In the event of the pirates presenting themselves and attempting to force the passage, he was to endeavor to stop them by firing on them, and as a last resource he was to take refuge in Granite House, where, the lift once raised, he would be in safety.
children.prevalue: In the event of the pirates presenting themselves and attempting to force the passage he was to endeavor to stop them by firing on them and as a last resource he was to take refuge in Granite House where the lift once raised he would be in safety

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft were to repair to the corral, and if they did not find Ayrton, search the neighboring woods.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett Herbert and Pencroft were to repair to the corral and if they did not find Ayrton search the neighboring woods

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: At six o'clock in the morning, the engineer and his three companions had passed Creek Glycerine, and Neb posted himself behind a small mound crowned by several dragon trees, on the left bank of the stream.
children.prevalue: At six o clock in the morning the engineer and his three companions had passed Creek Glycerine and Neb posted himself behind a small mound crowned by several dragon trees on the left bank of the stream

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The colonists, after leaving the plateau of Prospect Heights, immediately took the road to the corral. They shouldered their guns, ready to fire on the slightest hostile demonstration. The two rifles and the two guns had been loaded with ball.
children.prevalue: The colonists after leaving the plateau of Prospect Heights immediately took the road to the corral They shouldered their guns ready to fire on the slightest hostile demonstration The two rifles and the two guns had been loaded with ball

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The wood was thick on each side of the road and might easily have concealed the convicts, who owing to their weapons would have been really formidable.
children.prevalue: The wood was thick on each side of the road and might easily have concealed the convicts who owing to their weapons would have been really formidable

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The colonists walked rapidly and in silence. Top preceded them, sometimes running on the road, sometimes taking a ramble into the wood, but always quiet and not appearing to fear anything unusual. And they could be sure that the faithful dog would not allow them to be surprised, but would bark at the least appearance of danger.
children.prevalue: The colonists walked rapidly and in silence Top preceded them sometimes running on the road sometimes taking a ramble into the wood but always quiet and not appearing to fear anything unusual And they could be sure that the faithful dog would not allow them to be surprised but would bark at the least appearance of danger

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions followed beside the road the wire which connected the corral with Granite House. After walking for nearly two miles, they had not as yet discovered any explanation of the difficulty. The posts were in good order, the wire regularly extended. However, at that moment the engineer observed that the wire appeared to be slack, and on arriving at post No. 74, Herbert, who was in advance stopped, exclaiming,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions followed beside the road the wire which connected the corral with Granite House After walking for nearly two miles they had not as yet discovered any explanation of the difficulty The posts were in good order the wire regularly extended However at that moment the engineer observed that the wire appeared to be slack and on arriving at post No 74 Herbert who was in advance stopped exclaiming

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The wire is broken!
children.prevalue: The wire is broken

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: His companions hurried forward and arrived at the spot where the lad was standing. The post was rooted up and lying across the path. The unexpected explanation of the difficulty was here, and it was evident that the despatches from Granite House had not been received at the corral, nor those from the corral at Granite House.
children.prevalue: His companions hurried forward and arrived at the spot where the lad was standing The post was rooted up and lying across the path The unexpected explanation of the difficulty was here and it was evident that the despatches from Granite House had not been received at the corral nor those from the corral at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: It wasn't the wind that blew down this post, observed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It wasn t the wind that blew down this post observed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: No, replied Gideon Spilett. The earth has been dug up round its foot, and it has been torn up by the hand of man.
children.prevalue: No replied Gideon Spilett The earth has been dug up round its foot and it has been torn up by the hand of man

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Besides, the wire is broken, added Herbert, showing that the wire had been snapped.
children.prevalue: Besides the wire is broken added Herbert showing that the wire had been snapped

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Is the fracture recent? asked Harding.
