children.prevalue: Is the fracture recent asked Harding

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes, answered Herbert, it has certainly been done quite lately.
children.prevalue: Yes answered Herbert it has certainly been done quite lately

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: To the corral! to the corral! exclaimed the sailor.
children.prevalue: To the corral to the corral exclaimed the sailor

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: The colonists were now half way between Granite House and the corral, having still two miles and a half to go. They pressed forward with redoubled speed.
children.prevalue: The colonists were now half way between Granite House and the corral having still two miles and a half to go They pressed forward with redoubled speed

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Indeed, it was to be feared that some serious accident had occurred in the corral. No doubt, Ayrton might have sent a telegram which had not arrived, but this was not the reason why his companions were so uneasy, for, a more unaccountable circumstance, Ayrton, who had promised to return the evening before, had not reappeared. In short, it was not without a motive that all communication had been stopped between the corral and Granite House, and who but the convicts could have any interest in interrupting this communication?
children.prevalue: Indeed it was to be feared that some serious accident had occurred in the corral No doubt Ayrton might have sent a telegram which had not arrived but this was not the reason why his companions were so uneasy for a more unaccountable circumstance Ayrton who had promised to return the evening before had not reappeared In short it was not without a motive that all communication had been stopped between the corral and Granite House and who but the convicts could have any interest in interrupting this communication

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: The settlers hastened on, their hearts oppressed with anxiety. They were sincerely attached to their new companion. Were they to find him struck down by the hands of those of whom he was formerly the leader?
children.prevalue: The settlers hastened on their hearts oppressed with anxiety They were sincerely attached to their new companion Were they to find him struck down by the hands of those of whom he was formerly the leader

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Soon they arrived at the place where the road led along the side of the little stream which flowed from the Red Creek and watered the meadows of the corral. They then moderated their pace so that they should not be out of breath at the moment when a struggle might be necessary. Their guns were in their hands ready cocked. The forest was watched on every side. Top uttered sullen groans which were rather ominous.
children.prevalue: Soon they arrived at the place where the road led along the side of the little stream which flowed from the Red Creek and watered the meadows of the corral They then moderated their pace so that they should not be out of breath at the moment when a struggle might be necessary Their guns were in their hands ready cocked The forest was watched on every side Top uttered sullen groans which were rather ominous

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: At last the palisade appeared through the trees. No trace of any damage could be seen. The gate was shut as usual. Deep silence reigned in the corral. Neither the accustomed bleating of the sheep nor Ayrton's voice could be heard.
children.prevalue: At last the palisade appeared through the trees No trace of any damage could be seen The gate was shut as usual Deep silence reigned in the corral Neither the accustomed bleating of the sheep nor Ayrton s voice could be heard

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Let us enter, said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Let us enter said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: And the engineer advanced, while his companions, keeping watch about twenty paces behind him, were ready to fire at a moment's notice.
children.prevalue: And the engineer advanced while his companions keeping watch about twenty paces behind him were ready to fire at a moment s notice

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Harding raised the inner latch of the gate and was about to push it back, when Top barked loudly. A report sounded and was responded to by a cry of pain.
children.prevalue: Harding raised the inner latch of the gate and was about to push it back when Top barked loudly A report sounded and was responded to by a cry of pain

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Herbert, struck by a bullet, lay stretched on the ground.
children.prevalue: Herbert struck by a bullet lay stretched on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At Herbert's cry, Pencroft, letting his gun fall, rushed towards him.
children.prevalue: At Herbert s cry Pencroft letting his gun fall rushed towards him

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: They have killed him! he cried. My boy! They have killed him!
children.prevalue: They have killed him he cried My boy They have killed him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett ran to Herbert.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett ran to Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The reporter listened to ascertain if the poor lad's heart was still beating.
children.prevalue: The reporter listened to ascertain if the poor lad s heart was still beating

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He lives, said he, but he must be carried--
children.prevalue: He lives said he but he must be carried

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: To Granite House? that is impossible! replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: To Granite House that is impossible replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Into the corral, then! said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Into the corral then said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: In a moment, said Harding.
children.prevalue: In a moment said Harding

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And he ran round the left corner of the palisade. There he found a convict, who aiming at him, sent a ball through his hat. In a few seconds, before he had even time to fire his second barrel, he fell, struck to the heart by Harding's dagger, more sure even than his gun.
children.prevalue: And he ran round the left corner of the palisade There he found a convict who aiming at him sent a ball through his hat In a few seconds before he had even time to fire his second barrel he fell struck to the heart by Harding s dagger more sure even than his gun

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: During this time, Gideon Spilett and the sailor hoisted themselves over the palisade, leaped into the enclosure, threw down the props which supported the inner door, ran into the empty house, and soon, poor Herbert was lying on Ayrton's bed. In a few moments, Harding was by his side.
children.prevalue: During this time Gideon Spilett and the sailor hoisted themselves over the palisade leaped into the enclosure threw down the props which supported the inner door ran into the empty house and soon poor Herbert was lying on Ayrton s bed In a few moments Harding was by his side

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: On seeing Herbert senseless, the sailor's grief was terrible.
children.prevalue: On seeing Herbert senseless the sailor s grief was terrible

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: He sobbed, he cried, he tried to beat his head against the wall.
children.prevalue: He sobbed he cried he tried to beat his head against the wall

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Neither the engineer nor the reporter could calm him. They themselves were choked with emotion. They could not speak.
children.prevalue: Neither the engineer nor the reporter could calm him They themselves were choked with emotion They could not speak

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: However, they knew that it depended on them to rescue from death the poor boy who was suffering beneath their eyes. Gideon Spilett had not passed through the many incidents by which his life had been checkered without acquiring some slight knowledge of medicine. He knew a little of everything, and several times he had been obliged to attend to wounds produced either by a sword-bayonet or shot. Assisted by Cyrus Harding, he proceeded to render the aid Herbert required.
children.prevalue: However they knew that it depended on them to rescue from death the poor boy who was suffering beneath their eyes Gideon Spilett had not passed through the many incidents by which his life had been checkered without acquiring some slight knowledge of medicine He knew a little of everything and several times he had been obliged to attend to wounds produced either by a sword bayonet or shot Assisted by Cyrus Harding he proceeded to render the aid Herbert required

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The reporter was immediately struck by the complete stupor in which Herbert lay, a stupor owing either to the hemorrhage, or to the shock, the ball having struck a bone with sufficient force to produce a violent concussion.
children.prevalue: The reporter was immediately struck by the complete stupor in which Herbert lay a stupor owing either to the hemorrhage or to the shock the ball having struck a bone with sufficient force to produce a violent concussion

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Herbert was deadly pale, and his pulse so feeble that Spilett only felt it beat at long intervals, as if it was on the point of stopping.
children.prevalue: Herbert was deadly pale and his pulse so feeble that Spilett only felt it beat at long intervals as if it was on the point of stopping

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: These symptoms were very serious.
children.prevalue: These symptoms were very serious

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Herbert's chest was laid bare, and the blood having been stanched with handkerchiefs, it was bathed with cold water.
children.prevalue: Herbert s chest was laid bare and the blood having been stanched with handkerchiefs it was bathed with cold water

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The contusion, or rather the contused wound appeared,--an oval below the chest between the third and fourth ribs. It was there that Herbert had been hit by the bullet.
children.prevalue: The contusion or rather the contused wound appeared an oval below the chest between the third and fourth ribs It was there that Herbert had been hit by the bullet

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett then turned the poor boy over; as they did so, he uttered a moan so feeble that they almost thought it was his last sigh.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett then turned the poor boy over as they did so he uttered a moan so feeble that they almost thought it was his last sigh

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Herberts back was covered with blood from another contused wound, by which the ball had immediately escaped.
children.prevalue: Herberts back was covered with blood from another contused wound by which the ball had immediately escaped

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: God be praised! said the reporter, the ball is not in the body, and we shall not have to extract it.
children.prevalue: God be praised said the reporter the ball is not in the body and we shall not have to extract it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But the heart? asked Harding.
children.prevalue: But the heart asked Harding

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The heart has not been touched; if it had been, Herbert would be dead!
children.prevalue: The heart has not been touched if it had been Herbert would be dead

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Dead! exclaimed Pencroft, with a groan.
children.prevalue: Dead exclaimed Pencroft with a groan

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The sailor had only heard the last words uttered by the reporter.
children.prevalue: The sailor had only heard the last words uttered by the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: No, Pencroft, replied Cyrus Harding, no! He is not dead. His pulse still beats. He has even uttered a moan. But for your boy's sake, calm yourself. We have need of all our self-possession.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft replied Cyrus Harding no He is not dead His pulse still beats He has even uttered a moan But for your boy s sake calm yourself We have need of all our self possession

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Do not make us lose it, my friend.
children.prevalue: Do not make us lose it my friend

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Pencroft was silent, but a reaction set in, and great tears rolled down his cheeks.
children.prevalue: Pencroft was silent but a reaction set in and great tears rolled down his cheeks

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: In the meanwhile, Gideon Spilett endeavored to collect his ideas, and proceed methodically. After his examination he had no doubt that the ball, entering in front, between the seventh and eighth ribs, had issued behind between the third and fourth. But what mischief had the ball committed in its passage? What important organs had been reached? A professional surgeon would have had difficulty in determining this at once, and still more so the reporter.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile Gideon Spilett endeavored to collect his ideas and proceed methodically After his examination he had no doubt that the ball entering in front between the seventh and eighth ribs had issued behind between the third and fourth But what mischief had the ball committed in its passage What important organs had been reached A professional surgeon would have had difficulty in determining this at once and still more so the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: However, he knew one thing, this was that he would have to prevent the inflammatory strangulation of the injured parts, then to contend with the local inflammation and fever which would result from the wound, perhaps mortal! Now, what styptics, what antiphlogistics ought to be employed? By what means could inflammation be prevented?
children.prevalue: However he knew one thing this was that he would have to prevent the inflammatory strangulation of the injured parts then to contend with the local inflammation and fever which would result from the wound perhaps mortal Now what styptics what antiphlogistics ought to be employed By what means could inflammation be prevented

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: At any rate, the most important thing was that the two wounds should be dressed without delay. It did not appear necessary to Gideon Spilett that a fresh flow of blood should be caused by bathing them in tepid water, and compressing their lips. The hemorrhage had been very abundant, and Herbert was already too much enfeebled by the loss of blood.
children.prevalue: At any rate the most important thing was that the two wounds should be dressed without delay It did not appear necessary to Gideon Spilett that a fresh flow of blood should be caused by bathing them in tepid water and compressing their lips The hemorrhage had been very abundant and Herbert was already too much enfeebled by the loss of blood

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The reporter, therefore, thought it best to simply bathe the two wounds with cold water.
children.prevalue: The reporter therefore thought it best to simply bathe the two wounds with cold water

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Herbert was placed on his left side, and was maintained in that position.
children.prevalue: Herbert was placed on his left side and was maintained in that position

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: He must not be moved. said Gideon Spilett. He is in the most favorable position for the wounds in his back and chest to suppurate easily, and absolute rest is necessary.
children.prevalue: He must not be moved said Gideon Spilett He is in the most favorable position for the wounds in his back and chest to suppurate easily and absolute rest is necessary

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What! can't we carry him to Granite House? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: What can t we carry him to Granite House asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, Pencroft, replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I'll pay the villains off! cried the sailor, shaking his fist in a menacing manner.
children.prevalue: I ll pay the villains off cried the sailor shaking his fist in a menacing manner

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Pencroft! said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Pencroft said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Gideon Spilett had resumed his examination of the wounded boy. Herbert was still so frightfully pale, that the reporter felt anxious.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett had resumed his examination of the wounded boy Herbert was still so frightfully pale that the reporter felt anxious

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Cyrus, said he, I am not a surgeon. I am in terrible perplexity. You must aid me with your advice, your experience!
children.prevalue: Cyrus said he I am not a surgeon I am in terrible perplexity You must aid me with your advice your experience

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Take courage, my friend, answered the engineer, pressing the reporter's hand. Judge coolly. Think only of this: Herbert must be saved!
children.prevalue: Take courage my friend answered the engineer pressing the reporter s hand Judge coolly Think only of this Herbert must be saved

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: These words restored to Gideon Spilett that self-possession which he had lost in a moment of discouragement on feeling his great responsibility. He seated himself close to the bed. Cyrus Harding stood near. Pencroft had torn up his shirt, and was mechanically making lint.
children.prevalue: These words restored to Gideon Spilett that self possession which he had lost in a moment of discouragement on feeling his great responsibility He seated himself close to the bed Cyrus Harding stood near Pencroft had torn up his shirt and was mechanically making lint

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Spilett then explained to Cyrus Harding that he thought he ought first of all to stop the hemorrhage, but not close the two wounds, or cause their immediate cicatrization, for there had been internal perforation, and the suppuration must not be allowed to accumulate in the chest.
children.prevalue: Spilett then explained to Cyrus Harding that he thought he ought first of all to stop the hemorrhage but not close the two wounds or cause their immediate cicatrization for there had been internal perforation and the suppuration must not be allowed to accumulate in the chest

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Harding approved entirely, and it was decided that the two wounds should be dressed without attempting to close them by immediate coaptation.
children.prevalue: Harding approved entirely and it was decided that the two wounds should be dressed without attempting to close them by immediate coaptation

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And now did the colonists possess an efficacious agent to act against the inflammation which might occur?
children.prevalue: And now did the colonists possess an efficacious agent to act against the inflammation which might occur

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Yes. They had one, for nature had generously lavished it. They had cold water, that is to say, the most powerful sedative that can be employed against inflammation of wounds, the most efficacious therapeutic agent in grave cases, and the one which is now adopted by all physicians. Cold water has, moreover, the advantage of leaving the wound in absolute rest, and preserving it from all premature dressing, a considerable advantage, since it has been found by experience that contact with the air is dangerous during the first days.
children.prevalue: Yes They had one for nature had generously lavished it They had cold water that is to say the most powerful sedative that can be employed against inflammation of wounds the most efficacious therapeutic agent in grave cases and the one which is now adopted by all physicians Cold water has moreover the advantage of leaving the wound in absolute rest and preserving it from all premature dressing a considerable advantage since it has been found by experience that contact with the air is dangerous during the first days

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Gideon Spilett and Cyrus Harding reasoned thus with their simple good sense, and they acted as the best surgeon would have done. Compresses of linen were applied to poor Herbert's two wounds, and were kept constantly wet with cold water.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett and Cyrus Harding reasoned thus with their simple good sense and they acted as the best surgeon would have done Compresses of linen were applied to poor Herbert s two wounds and were kept constantly wet with cold water

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The sailor had at first lighted a fire in the hut, which was not wanting in things necessary for life. Maple sugar, medicinal plants, the same which the lad had gathered on the banks of Lake Grant, enabled them to make some refreshing drinks, which they gave him without his taking any notice of it. His fever was extremely high, and all that day and night passed without his becoming conscious.
children.prevalue: The sailor had at first lighted a fire in the hut which was not wanting in things necessary for life Maple sugar medicinal plants the same which the lad had gathered on the banks of Lake Grant enabled them to make some refreshing drinks which they gave him without his taking any notice of it His fever was extremely high and all that day and night passed without his becoming conscious

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Herbert's life hung on a thread, and this thread might break at any moment. The next day, the 12th of November, the hopes of Harding and his companions slightly revived. Herbert had come out of his long stupor. He opened his eyes, he recognized Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and Pencroft. He uttered two or three words. He did not know what had happened. They told him, and Spilett begged him to remain perfectly still, telling him that his life was not in danger, and that his wounds would heal in a few days. However, Herbert scarcely suffered at all, and the cold water with which they were constantly bathed, prevented any inflammation of the wounds. The suppuration was established in a regular way, the fever did not increase, and it might now be hoped that this terrible wound would not involve any catastrophe. Pencroft felt the swelling of his heart gradually subside. He was like a sister of mercy, like a mother by the bed of her child.
children.prevalue: Herbert s life hung on a thread and this thread might break at any moment The next day the 12th of November the hopes of Harding and his companions slightly revived Herbert had come out of his long stupor He opened his eyes he recognized Cyrus Harding the reporter and Pencroft He uttered two or three words He did not know what had happened They told him and Spilett begged him to remain perfectly still telling him that his life was not in danger and that his wounds would heal in a few days However Herbert scarcely suffered at all and the cold water with which they were constantly bathed prevented any inflammation of the wounds The suppuration was established in a regular way the fever did not increase and it might now be hoped that this terrible wound would not involve any catastrophe Pencroft felt the swelling of his heart gradually subside He was like a sister of mercy like a mother by the bed of her child

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Herbert dozed again, but his sleep appeared more natural.
children.prevalue: Herbert dozed again but his sleep appeared more natural

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Tell me again that you hope, Mr. Spilett, said Pencroft. Tell me again that you will save Herbert!
children.prevalue: Tell me again that you hope Mr Spilett said Pencroft Tell me again that you will save Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Yes, we will save him! replied the reporter. The wound is serious, and, perhaps, even the ball has traversed the lungs, but the perforation of this organ is not fatal.
children.prevalue: Yes we will save him replied the reporter The wound is serious and perhaps even the ball has traversed the lungs but the perforation of this organ is not fatal

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: God bless you! answered Pencroft.
children.prevalue: God bless you answered Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: As may be believed, during the four-and-twenty hours they had been in the corral, the colonists had no other thought than that of nursing Herbert. They did not think either of the danger which threatened them should the convicts return, or of the precautions to be taken for the future.
children.prevalue: As may be believed during the four and twenty hours they had been in the corral the colonists had no other thought than that of nursing Herbert They did not think either of the danger which threatened them should the convicts return or of the precautions to be taken for the future

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: But on this day, while Pencroft watched by the sick-bed, Cyrus Harding and the reporter consulted as to what it would be best to do.
children.prevalue: But on this day while Pencroft watched by the sick bed Cyrus Harding and the reporter consulted as to what it would be best to do

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: First of all they examined the corral. There was not a trace of Ayrton. Had the unhappy man been dragged away by his former accomplices? Had he resisted, and been overcome in the struggle? This last supposition was only too probable. Gideon Spilett, at the moment he scaled the palisade, had clearly seen some one of the convicts running along the southern spur of Mount Franklin, towards whom Top had sprung. It was one of those whose object had been so completely defeated by the rocks at the mouth of the Mercy. Besides, the one killed by Harding, and whose body was found outside the enclosure, of course belonged to Bob Harvey's crew.
children.prevalue: First of all they examined the corral There was not a trace of Ayrton Had the unhappy man been dragged away by his former accomplices Had he resisted and been overcome in the struggle This last supposition was only too probable Gideon Spilett at the moment he scaled the palisade had clearly seen some one of the convicts running along the southern spur of Mount Franklin towards whom Top had sprung It was one of those whose object had been so completely defeated by the rocks at the mouth of the Mercy Besides the one killed by Harding and whose body was found outside the enclosure of course belonged to Bob Harvey s crew

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: As to the corral, it had not suffered any damage. The gates were closed, and the animals had not been able to disperse in the forest. Nor could they see traces of any struggle, any devastation, either in the hut, or in the palisade. The ammunition only, with which Ayrton had been supplied, had disappeared with him.
children.prevalue: As to the corral it had not suffered any damage The gates were closed and the animals had not been able to disperse in the forest Nor could they see traces of any struggle any devastation either in the hut or in the palisade The ammunition only with which Ayrton had been supplied had disappeared with him

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The unhappy man has been surprised, said Harding, and as he was a man to defend himself, he must have been overpowered.
children.prevalue: The unhappy man has been surprised said Harding and as he was a man to defend himself he must have been overpowered

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Yes, that is to be feared! said the reporter. Then, doubtless, the convicts installed themselves in the corral where they found plenty of everything, and only fled when they saw us coming. It is very evident, too, that at this moment Ayrton, whether living or dead, is not here!
children.prevalue: Yes that is to be feared said the reporter Then doubtless the convicts installed themselves in the corral where they found plenty of everything and only fled when they saw us coming It is very evident too that at this moment Ayrton whether living or dead is not here

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: We shall have to beat the forest, said the engineer, and rid the island of these wretches. Pencroft's presentiments were not mistaken, when he wished to hunt them as wild beasts. That would have spared us all these misfortunes!
children.prevalue: We shall have to beat the forest said the engineer and rid the island of these wretches Pencroft s presentiments were not mistaken when he wished to hunt them as wild beasts That would have spared us all these misfortunes

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, answered the reporter, but now we have the right to be merciless!
children.prevalue: Yes answered the reporter but now we have the right to be merciless

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: At any rate, said the engineer, we are obliged to wait some time, and to remain at the corral until we can carry Herbert without danger to Granite House.
children.prevalue: At any rate said the engineer we are obliged to wait some time and to remain at the corral until we can carry Herbert without danger to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But Neb? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: But Neb asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Neb is in safety.
children.prevalue: Neb is in safety

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: But if, uneasy at our absence, he would venture to come?
children.prevalue: But if uneasy at our absence he would venture to come

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: He must not come! returned Cyrus Harding quickly. He would be murdered on the road!
children.prevalue: He must not come returned Cyrus Harding quickly He would be murdered on the road

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: It is very probable, however, that he will attempt to rejoin us!
children.prevalue: It is very probable however that he will attempt to rejoin us

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Ah, if the telegraph still acted, he might be warned! But that is impossible now! As to leaving Pencroft and Herbert here alone, we could not do it! Well, I will go alone to Granite House.
children.prevalue: Ah if the telegraph still acted he might be warned But that is impossible now As to leaving Pencroft and Herbert here alone we could not do it Well I will go alone to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: No, no! Cyrus, answered the reporter, you must not expose yourself! Your courage would be of no avail. The villains are evidently watching the corral, they are hidden in the thick woods which surround it, and if you go we shall soon have to regret two misfortunes instead of one!
children.prevalue: No no Cyrus answered the reporter you must not expose yourself Your courage would be of no avail The villains are evidently watching the corral they are hidden in the thick woods which surround it and if you go we shall soon have to regret two misfortunes instead of one

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But Neb? repeated the engineer. It is now four-and-twenty hours since he has had any news of us! He will be sure to come!
children.prevalue: But Neb repeated the engineer It is now four and twenty hours since he has had any news of us He will be sure to come

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: And as he will be less on his guard than we should be ourselves, added Spilett, he will be killed!
children.prevalue: And as he will be less on his guard than we should be ourselves added Spilett he will be killed

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Is there really no way of warning him?
children.prevalue: Is there really no way of warning him

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: While the engineer thought, his eyes fell on Top, who, going backwards and forwards seemed to say,--
children.prevalue: While the engineer thought his eyes fell on Top who going backwards and forwards seemed to say

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Am not I here?
children.prevalue: Am not I here

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Top! exclaimed Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Top exclaimed Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The animal sprang at his master's call.
children.prevalue: The animal sprang at his master s call

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes, Top will go, said the reporter, who had understood the engineer.
children.prevalue: Yes Top will go said the reporter who had understood the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Top can go where we cannot! He will carry to Granite House the news of the corral, and he will bring back to us that from Granite House!
children.prevalue: Top can go where we cannot He will carry to Granite House the news of the corral and he will bring back to us that from Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Quick! said Harding. Quick!
children.prevalue: Quick said Harding Quick

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Spilett rapidly tore a leaf from his note-book, and wrote these words:--
children.prevalue: Spilett rapidly tore a leaf from his note book and wrote these words

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Herbert wounded. We are at the corral. Be on your guard. Do not leave Granite House. Have the convicts appeared in the neighborhood? Reply by Top.
children.prevalue: Herbert wounded We are at the corral Be on your guard Do not leave Granite House Have the convicts appeared in the neighborhood Reply by Top

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: This laconic note contained all that Neb ought to know, and at the same time asked all that the colonists wished to know. It was folded and fastened to Top's collar in a conspicuous position.
children.prevalue: This laconic note contained all that Neb ought to know and at the same time asked all that the colonists wished to know It was folded and fastened to Top s collar in a conspicuous position

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Top, my dog, said the engineer, caressing the animal, Neb, Top! Neb! Go, go!
children.prevalue: Top my dog said the engineer caressing the animal Neb Top Neb Go go

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Top bounded at these words. He understood, he knew what was expected of him. The road to the corral was familiar to him. In less than an hour he could clear it, and it might be hoped that where neither Cyrus Harding nor the reporter could have ventured without danger, Top, running among the grass or in the wood, would pass unperceived.
children.prevalue: Top bounded at these words He understood he knew what was expected of him The road to the corral was familiar to him In less than an hour he could clear it and it might be hoped that where neither Cyrus Harding nor the reporter could have ventured without danger Top running among the grass or in the wood would pass unperceived

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The engineer went to the gate of the corral and opened it.
children.prevalue: The engineer went to the gate of the corral and opened it

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Neb, Top! Neb! repeated the engineer, again pointing in the direction of Granite House.
children.prevalue: Neb Top Neb repeated the engineer again pointing in the direction of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Top sprang forwards, then almost immediately disappeared.
children.prevalue: Top sprang forwards then almost immediately disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: He will get there! said the reporter.
children.prevalue: He will get there said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Yes, and he will come back, the faithful animal!
children.prevalue: Yes and he will come back the faithful animal

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What o'clock is it? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: What o clock is it asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Ten.
children.prevalue: Ten

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: In an hour he may be here. We will watch for his return.
children.prevalue: In an hour he may be here We will watch for his return

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: The gate of the corral was closed. The engineer and the reporter re-entered the house. Herbert was still in a sleep. Pencroft kept the compresses always wet. Spilett, seeing there was nothing he could do at that moment, busied himself in preparing some nourishment, while attentively watching that part of the enclosure against the hill, at which an attack might be expected.
children.prevalue: The gate of the corral was closed The engineer and the reporter re entered the house Herbert was still in a sleep Pencroft kept the compresses always wet Spilett seeing there was nothing he could do at that moment busied himself in preparing some nourishment while attentively watching that part of the enclosure against the hill at which an attack might be expected

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The settlers awaited Top's return with much anxiety. A little before eleven o'clock, Cyrus Harding and the reporter, rifle in hand, were behind the gate, ready to open it at the first bark of their dog.
children.prevalue: The settlers awaited Top s return with much anxiety A little before eleven o clock Cyrus Harding and the reporter rifle in hand were behind the gate ready to open it at the first bark of their dog

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: They did not doubt that if Top had arrived safely at Granite House, Neb would have sent him back immediately.
children.prevalue: They did not doubt that if Top had arrived safely at Granite House Neb would have sent him back immediately

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: They had both been there for about ten minutes, when a report was heard, followed by repeated barks.
children.prevalue: They had both been there for about ten minutes when a report was heard followed by repeated barks

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: The engineer opened the gate, and seeing smoke a hundred feet off in the wood, he fired in that direction.
children.prevalue: The engineer opened the gate and seeing smoke a hundred feet off in the wood he fired in that direction

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Almost immediately Top bounded into the corral, and the gate was quickly shut.
children.prevalue: Almost immediately Top bounded into the corral and the gate was quickly shut

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Top, Top! exclaimed the engineer, taking the dog's great honest head between his hands.
children.prevalue: Top Top exclaimed the engineer taking the dog s great honest head between his hands

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: A note was fastened to his neck, and Cyrus Harding read these words, traced in Neb's large writing:--No pirates in the neighborhood of Granite House. I will not stir. Poor Mr. Herbert!
children.prevalue: A note was fastened to his neck and Cyrus Harding read these words traced in Neb s large writing No pirates in the neighborhood of Granite House I will not stir Poor Mr Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: So the convicts were still there, watching the corral, and determined to kill the settlers one after the other. There was nothing to be done but to treat them as wild beasts. But great precautions must be taken, for just now the wretches had the advantage on their side, seeing, and not being seen, being able to surprise by the suddenness of their attack, yet not to be surprised themselves. Harding made arrangements, therefore, for living in the corral, of which the provisions would last for a tolerable length of time. Ayrton's house had been provided with all that was necessary for existence, and the convicts, scared by the arrival of the settlers, had not had time to pillage it. It was probable, as Gideon Spilett observed, that things had occurred as follows:
children.prevalue: So the convicts were still there watching the corral and determined to kill the settlers one after the other There was nothing to be done but to treat them as wild beasts But great precautions must be taken for just now the wretches had the advantage on their side seeing and not being seen being able to surprise by the suddenness of their attack yet not to be surprised themselves Harding made arrangements therefore for living in the corral of which the provisions would last for a tolerable length of time Ayrton s house had been provided with all that was necessary for existence and the convicts scared by the arrival of the settlers had not had time to pillage it It was probable as Gideon Spilett observed that things had occurred as follows

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The six convicts, disembarking on the island, had followed the southern shore, and after having traversed the double shore of the Serpentine Peninsula, not being inclined to venture into the Far West woods, they had reached the mouth of Falls River. From this point, by following the right bank of the watercourse, they would arrive at the spurs of Mount Franklin, among which they would naturally seek a retreat, and they could not have been long in discovering the corral, then uninhabited. There they had regularly installed themselves, awaiting the moment to put their abominable schemes into execution. Ayrton's arrival had surprised them, but they had managed to overpower the unfortunate man, and--the rest may be easily imagined!
children.prevalue: The six convicts disembarking on the island had followed the southern shore and after having traversed the double shore of the Serpentine Peninsula not being inclined to venture into the Far West woods they had reached the mouth of Falls River From this point by following the right bank of the watercourse they would arrive at the spurs of Mount Franklin among which they would naturally seek a retreat and they could not have been long in discovering the corral then uninhabited There they had regularly installed themselves awaiting the moment to put their abominable schemes into execution Ayrton s arrival had surprised them but they had managed to overpower the unfortunate man and the rest may be easily imagined

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Now, the convicts,--reduced to five, it is true, but well armed,--were roaming the woods, and to venture there was to expose themselves to their attacks, which could be neither guarded against nor prevented.
children.prevalue: Now the convicts reduced to five it is true but well armed were roaming the woods and to venture there was to expose themselves to their attacks which could be neither guarded against nor prevented

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Wait! There is nothing else to be done! repeated Cyrus Harding. When Herbert is cured, we can organize a general battle of the island, and have satisfaction of these convicts. That will be the object of our grand expedition at the same time--
children.prevalue: Wait There is nothing else to be done repeated Cyrus Harding When Herbert is cured we can organize a general battle of the island and have satisfaction of these convicts That will be the object of our grand expedition at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: As the search for our mysterious protector, added Gideon Spilett, finishing the engineer's sentence. And it must be acknowledged, my dear Cyrus, that this time his protection was wanting at the very moment when it was most necessary to us!
children.prevalue: As the search for our mysterious protector added Gideon Spilett finishing the engineer s sentence And it must be acknowledged my dear Cyrus that this time his protection was wanting at the very moment when it was most necessary to us

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Who knows? replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: Who knows replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What do you mean? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What do you mean asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: That we are not at the end of our trouble yet, my dear Spilett, and that his powerful intervention may have another opportunity of exercising itself. But that is not the question now. Herbert's life before everything.
children.prevalue: That we are not at the end of our trouble yet my dear Spilett and that his powerful intervention may have another opportunity of exercising itself But that is not the question now Herbert s life before everything

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: This was the colonists' saddest thought. Several days passed, and the poor boy's state was happily no worse. Cold water, always kept at a suitable temperature, had completely prevented the inflammation of the wounds. It even seemed to the reporter that this water, being slightly sulphurous,--which was explained by the neighborhood of the volcano, had a more direct action on the healing. The suppuration was much less abundant, and thanks to the incessant care by which he was surrounded!--Herbert returned to life, and his fever abated. He was besides subjected to a severe diet, and consequently his weakness was and would be extreme; but there was no want of refreshing drinks, and absolute rest was of the greatest benefit to him. Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft had become very skilful in dressing the lad's wounds. All the linen in the house had been sacrificed. Herbert's wounds, covered with compresses and lint, were pressed neither too much nor too little, so as to cause their cicatrization without effecting any inflammatory reaction. The reporter used extreme care in the dressing, knowing well the importance of it, and repeating to his companions that which most surgeons willingly admit, that it is perhaps rarer to see a dressing well done than an operation well performed.
children.prevalue: This was the colonists saddest thought Several days passed and the poor boy s state was happily no worse Cold water always kept at a suitable temperature had completely prevented the inflammation of the wounds It even seemed to the reporter that this water being slightly sulphurous which was explained by the neighborhood of the volcano had a more direct action on the healing The suppuration was much less abundant and thanks to the incessant care by which he was surrounded Herbert returned to life and his fever abated He was besides subjected to a severe diet and consequently his weakness was and would be extreme but there was no want of refreshing drinks and absolute rest was of the greatest benefit to him Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett and Pencroft had become very skilful in dressing the lad s wounds All the linen in the house had been sacrificed Herbert s wounds covered with compresses and lint were pressed neither too much nor too little so as to cause their cicatrization without effecting any inflammatory reaction The reporter used extreme care in the dressing knowing well the importance of it and repeating to his companions that which most surgeons willingly admit that it is perhaps rarer to see a dressing well done than an operation well performed

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In ten days, on the 22nd of November, Herbert was considerably better. He had begun to take some nourishment.
children.prevalue: In ten days on the 22nd of November Herbert was considerably better He had begun to take some nourishment

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The color was returning to his cheeks, and his bright eyes smiled at his nurses. He talked a little, notwithstanding Pencroft's efforts, who talked incessantly to prevent him from beginning to speak, and told him the most improbable stories. Herbert had questioned him on the subject of Ayrton, whom he was astonished not to see near him, thinking that he was at the corral. But the sailor, not wishing to distress Herbert, contented himself by replying that Ayrton had rejoined Neb, so as to defend Granite House.
children.prevalue: The color was returning to his cheeks and his bright eyes smiled at his nurses He talked a little notwithstanding Pencroft s efforts who talked incessantly to prevent him from beginning to speak and told him the most improbable stories Herbert had questioned him on the subject of Ayrton whom he was astonished not to see near him thinking that he was at the corral But the sailor not wishing to distress Herbert contented himself by replying that Ayrton had rejoined Neb so as to defend Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Humph! said Pencroft, these pirates! they are gentlemen who have no right to any consideration! And the captain wanted to win them by kindness! I'll send them some kindness, but in the shape of a good bullet!
children.prevalue: Humph said Pencroft these pirates they are gentlemen who have no right to any consideration And the captain wanted to win them by kindness I ll send them some kindness but in the shape of a good bullet

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And have they not been seen again? asked Herbert.
children.prevalue: And have they not been seen again asked Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: No, my boy, answered the sailor, but we shall find them, and when you are cured we shall see if the cowards who strike us from behind will dare to meet us face to face!
children.prevalue: No my boy answered the sailor but we shall find them and when you are cured we shall see if the cowards who strike us from behind will dare to meet us face to face

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I am still very weak, my poor Pencroft!
children.prevalue: I am still very weak my poor Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well! your strength will return gradually! What's a ball through the chest? Nothing but a joke! I've seen many, and I don't think much of them!
children.prevalue: Well your strength will return gradually What s a ball through the chest Nothing but a joke I ve seen many and I don t think much of them

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: At last things appeared to be going on well, and if no complication occurred, Herbert's recovery might be regarded as certain. But what would have been the condition of the colonists if his state had been aggravated,--if, for example, the ball had remained in his body, if his arm or his leg had had to be amputated?
children.prevalue: At last things appeared to be going on well and if no complication occurred Herbert s recovery might be regarded as certain But what would have been the condition of the colonists if his state had been aggravated if for example the ball had remained in his body if his arm or his leg had had to be amputated

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: No, said Spilett more than once, I have never thought of such a contingency without shuddering!
children.prevalue: No said Spilett more than once I have never thought of such a contingency without shuddering

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: And yet, if it had been necessary to operate, said Harding one day to him, you would not have hesitated?
children.prevalue: And yet if it had been necessary to operate said Harding one day to him you would not have hesitated

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: No, Cyrus! said Gideon Spilett, but thank God that we have been spared this complication!
children.prevalue: No Cyrus said Gideon Spilett but thank God that we have been spared this complication

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: As in so many other conjectures, the colonists had appealed to the logic of that simple good sense of which they had made use so often, and once more, thanks to their general knowledge, it had succeeded! But might not a time come when all their science would be at fault? They were alone on the island. Now, men in all states of society are necessary to each other. Cyrus Harding knew this well, and sometimes he asked if some circumstance might not occur which they would be powerless to surmount. It appeared to him besides, that he and his companions, till then so fortunate, had entered into an unlucky period. During the two years and a half which had elapsed since their escape from Richmond, it might be said that they had had everything their own way. The island had abundantly supplied them with minerals, vegetables, animals, and as Nature had constantly loaded them, their science had known how to take advantage of what she offered them.
children.prevalue: As in so many other conjectures the colonists had appealed to the logic of that simple good sense of which they had made use so often and once more thanks to their general knowledge it had succeeded But might not a time come when all their science would be at fault They were alone on the island Now men in all states of society are necessary to each other Cyrus Harding knew this well and sometimes he asked if some circumstance might not occur which they would be powerless to surmount It appeared to him besides that he and his companions till then so fortunate had entered into an unlucky period During the two years and a half which had elapsed since their escape from Richmond it might be said that they had had everything their own way The island had abundantly supplied them with minerals vegetables animals and as Nature had constantly loaded them their science had known how to take advantage of what she offered them

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The wellbeing of the colony was therefore complete. Moreover, in certain occurrences an inexplicable influence had come to their aid!... But all that could only be for a time.
children.prevalue: The wellbeing of the colony was therefore complete Moreover in certain occurrences an inexplicable influence had come to their aid But all that could only be for a time

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: In short, Cyrus Harding believed that fortune had turned against them.
children.prevalue: In short Cyrus Harding believed that fortune had turned against them

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: In fact, the convicts' ship had appeared in the waters of the island, and if the pirates had been, so to speak, miraculously destroyed, six of them, at least, had escaped the catastrophe. They had disembarked on the island, and it was almost impossible to get at the five who survived. Ayrton had no doubt been murdered by these wretches, who possessed firearms, and at the first use that they had made of them, Herbert had fallen, wounded almost mortally. Were these the first blows aimed by adverse fortune at the colonists? This was often asked by Harding. This was often repeated by the reporter; and it appeared to him also that the intervention, so strange, yet so efficacious, which till then had served them so well, had now failed them. Had this mysterious being, whatever he was, whose existence could not be denied, abandoned the island? Had he in his turn succumbed?
children.prevalue: In fact the convicts ship had appeared in the waters of the island and if the pirates had been so to speak miraculously destroyed six of them at least had escaped the catastrophe They had disembarked on the island and it was almost impossible to get at the five who survived Ayrton had no doubt been murdered by these wretches who possessed firearms and at the first use that they had made of them Herbert had fallen wounded almost mortally Were these the first blows aimed by adverse fortune at the colonists This was often asked by Harding This was often repeated by the reporter and it appeared to him also that the intervention so strange yet so efficacious which till then had served them so well had now failed them Had this mysterious being whatever he was whose existence could not be denied abandoned the island Had he in his turn succumbed

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: No reply was possible to these questions. But it must not be imagined that because Harding and his companions spoke of these things, they were men to despair. Far from that. They looked their situation in the face, they analyzed the chances, they prepared themselves for any event, they stood firm and straight before the future, and if adversity was at last to strike them, it would find in them men prepared to struggle against it.
children.prevalue: No reply was possible to these questions But it must not be imagined that because Harding and his companions spoke of these things they were men to despair Far from that They looked their situation in the face they analyzed the chances they prepared themselves for any event they stood firm and straight before the future and if adversity was at last to strike them it would find in them men prepared to struggle against it

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The convalescence of the young invalid was regularly progressing. One thing only was now to be desired, that his state would allow him to be brought to Granite House. However well built and supplied the corral house was, it could not be so comfortable as the healthy granite dwelling. Besides, it did not offer the same security, and its tenants, notwithstanding their watchfulness, were here always in fear of some shot from the convicts. There, on the contrary, in the middle of that impregnable and inaccessible cliff, they would have nothing to fear, and any attack on their persons would certainly fail. They therefore waited impatiently for the moment when Herbert might be moved without danger from his wound, and they were determined to make this move, although the communication through Jacamar Wood was very difficult.
children.prevalue: The convalescence of the young invalid was regularly progressing One thing only was now to be desired that his state would allow him to be brought to Granite House However well built and supplied the corral house was it could not be so comfortable as the healthy granite dwelling Besides it did not offer the same security and its tenants notwithstanding their watchfulness were here always in fear of some shot from the convicts There on the contrary in the middle of that impregnable and inaccessible cliff they would have nothing to fear and any attack on their persons would certainly fail They therefore waited impatiently for the moment when Herbert might be moved without danger from his wound and they were determined to make this move although the communication through Jacamar Wood was very difficult

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: They had no news from Neb, but were not uneasy on that account. The courageous Negro, well entrenched in the depths of Granite House, would not allow himself to be surprised. Top had not been sent again to him, as it appeared useless to expose the faithful dog to some shot which might deprive the settlers of their most useful auxiliary.
children.prevalue: They had no news from Neb but were not uneasy on that account The courageous Negro well entrenched in the depths of Granite House would not allow himself to be surprised Top had not been sent again to him as it appeared useless to expose the faithful dog to some shot which might deprive the settlers of their most useful auxiliary

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: They waited, therefore, although they were anxious to be reunited at Granite House. It pained the engineer to see his forces divided, for it gave great advantage to the pirates. Since Ayrton's disappearance they were only four against five, for Herbert could not yet be counted, and this was not the least care of the brave boy, who well understood the trouble of which he was the cause.
children.prevalue: They waited therefore although they were anxious to be reunited at Granite House It pained the engineer to see his forces divided for it gave great advantage to the pirates Since Ayrton s disappearance they were only four against five for Herbert could not yet be counted and this was not the least care of the brave boy who well understood the trouble of which he was the cause

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The question of knowing how, in their condition, they were to act against the pirates, was thoroughly discussed on the 29th of November by Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft, at a moment when Herbert was asleep and could not hear them.
children.prevalue: The question of knowing how in their condition they were to act against the pirates was thoroughly discussed on the 29th of November by Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett and Pencroft at a moment when Herbert was asleep and could not hear them

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: My friends, said the reporter, after they had talked of Neb and of the impossibility of communicating with him, I think,--like you, that to venture on the road to the corral would be to risk receiving a gunshot without being able to return it. But do you not think that the best thing to be done now is to openly give chase to these wretches?
children.prevalue: My friends said the reporter after they had talked of Neb and of the impossibility of communicating with him I think like you that to venture on the road to the corral would be to risk receiving a gunshot without being able to return it But do you not think that the best thing to be done now is to openly give chase to these wretches

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: That is just what I was thinking, answered Pencroft. I believe we're not fellows to be afraid of a bullet, and as for me, if Captain Harding approves, I'm ready to dash into the forest! Why, hang it, one man is equal to another!
children.prevalue: That is just what I was thinking answered Pencroft I believe we re not fellows to be afraid of a bullet and as for me if Captain Harding approves I m ready to dash into the forest Why hang it one man is equal to another

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But is he equal to five? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: But is he equal to five asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I will join Pencroft, said the reporter, and both of us, well-armed and accompanied by Top--
children.prevalue: I will join Pencroft said the reporter and both of us well armed and accompanied by Top

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: My dear Spilett, and you, Pencroft, answered Harding, let us reason coolly. If the convicts were hid in one spot of the island, if we knew that spot, and had only to dislodge them, I would undertake a direct attack; but is there not occasion to fear, on the contrary, that they are sure to fire the first shot?
children.prevalue: My dear Spilett and you Pencroft answered Harding let us reason coolly If the convicts were hid in one spot of the island if we knew that spot and had only to dislodge them I would undertake a direct attack but is there not occasion to fear on the contrary that they are sure to fire the first shot

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Well, captain, cried Pencroft, a bullet does not always reach its mark.
children.prevalue: Well captain cried Pencroft a bullet does not always reach its mark

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: That which struck Herbert did not miss, Pencroft, replied the engineer. Besides, observe that if both of you left the corral I should remain here alone to defend it. Do you imagine that the convicts will not see you leave it, that they will not allow you to enter the forest, and that they will not attack it during your absence, knowing that there is no one here but a wounded boy and a man?
children.prevalue: That which struck Herbert did not miss Pencroft replied the engineer Besides observe that if both of you left the corral I should remain here alone to defend it Do you imagine that the convicts will not see you leave it that they will not allow you to enter the forest and that they will not attack it during your absence knowing that there is no one here but a wounded boy and a man

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You are right, captain, replied Pencroft, his chest swelling with sullen anger. You are right; they will do all they can to retake the corral, which they know to be well stored; and alone you could not hold it against them.
children.prevalue: You are right captain replied Pencroft his chest swelling with sullen anger You are right they will do all they can to retake the corral which they know to be well stored and alone you could not hold it against them

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oh, if we were only at Granite House!
children.prevalue: Oh if we were only at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: If we were at Granite House, answered the engineer, the case would be very different. There I should not be afraid to leave Herbert with one, while the other three went to search the forests of the island. But we are at the corral, and it is best to stay here until we can leave it together.
children.prevalue: If we were at Granite House answered the engineer the case would be very different There I should not be afraid to leave Herbert with one while the other three went to search the forests of the island But we are at the corral and it is best to stay here until we can leave it together

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Cyrus Harding's reasoning was unanswerable, and his companions understood it well.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding s reasoning was unanswerable and his companions understood it well

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: If only Ayrton was still one of us! said Gideon Spilett. Poor fellow! his return to social life will have been but of short duration.
children.prevalue: If only Ayrton was still one of us said Gideon Spilett Poor fellow his return to social life will have been but of short duration

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: If he is dead, added Pencroft, in a peculiar tone.
children.prevalue: If he is dead added Pencroft in a peculiar tone

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Do you hope, then, Pencroft, that the villains have spared him? asked Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Do you hope then Pencroft that the villains have spared him asked Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes, if they had any interest in doing so.
children.prevalue: Yes if they had any interest in doing so

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What! you suppose that Ayrton finding his old companions, forgetting all that he owes us--
children.prevalue: What you suppose that Ayrton finding his old companions forgetting all that he owes us

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Who knows? answered the sailor, who did not hazard this shameful supposition without hesitating.
children.prevalue: Who knows answered the sailor who did not hazard this shameful supposition without hesitating

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Pencroft, said Harding, taking the sailor's arm, that is a wicked idea of yours, and you will distress me much if you persist in speaking thus. I will answer for Ayrton's fidelity.
children.prevalue: Pencroft said Harding taking the sailor s arm that is a wicked idea of yours and you will distress me much if you persist in speaking thus I will answer for Ayrton s fidelity

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And I also, added the reporter quickly.
children.prevalue: And I also added the reporter quickly

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yes, yes, captain, I was wrong, replied Pencroft; it was a wicked idea indeed that I had, and nothing justifies it. But what can I do? I'm not in my senses. This imprisonment in the corral wearies me horribly, and I have never felt so excited as I do now.
children.prevalue: Yes yes captain I was wrong replied Pencroft it was a wicked idea indeed that I had and nothing justifies it But what can I do I m not in my senses This imprisonment in the corral wearies me horribly and I have never felt so excited as I do now

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Be patient, Pencroft, replied the engineer. How long will it be, my dear Spilett, before you think Herbert may be carried to Granite House?
children.prevalue: Be patient Pencroft replied the engineer How long will it be my dear Spilett before you think Herbert may be carried to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: That is difficult to say, Cyrus, answered the reporter, for any imprudence might involve terrible consequences. But his convalescence is progressing, and if he continues to gain strength, in eight days from now--well, we shall see.
children.prevalue: That is difficult to say Cyrus answered the reporter for any imprudence might involve terrible consequences But his convalescence is progressing and if he continues to gain strength in eight days from now well we shall see

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Eight days! That would put off the return to Granite House until the first days of December. At this time two months of spring had already passed. The weather was fine, and the heat began to be great. The forests of the island were in full leaf, and the time was approaching when the usual crops ought to be gathered. The return to the plateau of Prospect Heights would, therefore, be followed by extensive agricultural labors, interrupted only by the projected expedition through the island.
children.prevalue: Eight days That would put off the return to Granite House until the first days of December At this time two months of spring had already passed The weather was fine and the heat began to be great The forests of the island were in full leaf and the time was approaching when the usual crops ought to be gathered The return to the plateau of Prospect Heights would therefore be followed by extensive agricultural labors interrupted only by the projected expedition through the island

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It can, therefore, be well understood how injurious this seclusion in the corral must have been to the colonists.
children.prevalue: It can therefore be well understood how injurious this seclusion in the corral must have been to the colonists

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But if they were compelled to bow before necessity, they did not do so without impatience.
children.prevalue: But if they were compelled to bow before necessity they did not do so without impatience

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Once or twice the reporter ventured out into the road and made the tour of the palisade. Top accompanied him, and Gideon Spilett, his gun cocked, was ready for any emergency.
children.prevalue: Once or twice the reporter ventured out into the road and made the tour of the palisade Top accompanied him and Gideon Spilett his gun cocked was ready for any emergency

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: He met with no misadventure and found no suspicious traces. His dog would have warned him of any danger, and, as Top did not bark, it might be concluded that there was nothing to fear at the moment at least, and that the convicts were occupied in another part of the island.
children.prevalue: He met with no misadventure and found no suspicious traces His dog would have warned him of any danger and as Top did not bark it might be concluded that there was nothing to fear at the moment at least and that the convicts were occupied in another part of the island

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: However, on his second sortie, on the 27th of November, Gideon Spilett, who had ventured a quarter of a mile into the woods, towards the south of the mountain, remarked that Top scented something. The dog had no longer his unconcerned manner; he went backwards and forwards, ferreting among the grass and bushes as if his smell had revealed some suspicious object to him.
children.prevalue: However on his second sortie on the 27th of November Gideon Spilett who had ventured a quarter of a mile into the woods towards the south of the mountain remarked that Top scented something The dog had no longer his unconcerned manner he went backwards and forwards ferreting among the grass and bushes as if his smell had revealed some suspicious object to him

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Gideon Spilett followed Top, encouraged him, excited him by his voice, while keeping a sharp look-out, his gun ready to fire, and sheltering himself behind the trees. It was not probable that Top scented the presence of man, for in that case, he would have announced it by half-uttered, sullen, angry barks. Now, as he did not growl, it was because danger was neither near nor approaching.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett followed Top encouraged him excited him by his voice while keeping a sharp look out his gun ready to fire and sheltering himself behind the trees It was not probable that Top scented the presence of man for in that case he would have announced it by half uttered sullen angry barks Now as he did not growl it was because danger was neither near nor approaching

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Nearly five minutes passed thus, Top rummaging, the reporter following him prudently when, all at once, the dog rushed towards a thick bush, and drew out a rag.
children.prevalue: Nearly five minutes passed thus Top rummaging the reporter following him prudently when all at once the dog rushed towards a thick bush and drew out a rag

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It was a piece of cloth, stained and torn, which Spilett immediately brought back to the corral. There it was examined by the colonists, who found that it was a fragment of Ayrton's waistcoat, a piece of that felt, manufactured solely by the Granite House factory.
children.prevalue: It was a piece of cloth stained and torn which Spilett immediately brought back to the corral There it was examined by the colonists who found that it was a fragment of Ayrton s waistcoat a piece of that felt manufactured solely by the Granite House factory

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: You see, Pencroft, observed Harding, there has been resistance on the part of the unfortunate Ayrton. The convicts have dragged him away in spite of himself! Do you still doubt his honesty?
children.prevalue: You see Pencroft observed Harding there has been resistance on the part of the unfortunate Ayrton The convicts have dragged him away in spite of himself Do you still doubt his honesty

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, captain, answered the sailor, and I repented of my suspicion a long time ago! But it seems to me that something may be learned from the incident.
children.prevalue: No captain answered the sailor and I repented of my suspicion a long time ago But it seems to me that something may be learned from the incident

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: What is that? asked the reporter.
children.prevalue: What is that asked the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: It is that Ayrton was not killed at the corral! That they dragged him away living, since he has resisted. Therefore, perhaps, he is still living!
children.prevalue: It is that Ayrton was not killed at the corral That they dragged him away living since he has resisted Therefore perhaps he is still living

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Perhaps, indeed, replied the engineer, who remained thoughtful.
children.prevalue: Perhaps indeed replied the engineer who remained thoughtful

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: This was a hope, to which Ayrton's companions could still hold. Indeed, they had before believed that, surprised in the corral, Ayrton had fallen by a bullet, as Herbert had fallen. But if the convicts had not killed him at first, if they had brought him living to another part of the island, might it not be admitted that he was still their prisoner? Perhaps, even, one of them had found in Ayrton his old Australian companion Ben Joyce, the chief of the escaped convicts. And who knows but that they had conceived the impossible hope of bringing back Ayrton to themselves? He would have been very useful to them, if they had been able to make him turn traitor!
children.prevalue: This was a hope to which Ayrton s companions could still hold Indeed they had before believed that surprised in the corral Ayrton had fallen by a bullet as Herbert had fallen But if the convicts had not killed him at first if they had brought him living to another part of the island might it not be admitted that he was still their prisoner Perhaps even one of them had found in Ayrton his old Australian companion Ben Joyce the chief of the escaped convicts And who knows but that they had conceived the impossible hope of bringing back Ayrton to themselves He would have been very useful to them if they had been able to make him turn traitor

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: This incident was, therefore, favorably interpreted at the corral, and it no longer appeared impossible that they should find Ayrton again. On his side, if he was only a prisoner, Ayrton would no doubt do all he could to escape from the hands of the villains, and this would be a powerful aid to the settlers!
children.prevalue: This incident was therefore favorably interpreted at the corral and it no longer appeared impossible that they should find Ayrton again On his side if he was only a prisoner Ayrton would no doubt do all he could to escape from the hands of the villains and this would be a powerful aid to the settlers

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: At any rate, observed Gideon Spilett, if happily Ayrton did manage to escape, he would go directly to Granite House, for he could not know of the attempted assassination of which Herbert has been a victim, and consequently would never think of our being imprisoned in the corral.
children.prevalue: At any rate observed Gideon Spilett if happily Ayrton did manage to escape he would go directly to Granite House for he could not know of the attempted assassination of which Herbert has been a victim and consequently would never think of our being imprisoned in the corral

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Oh! I wish that he was there, at Granite House! cried Pencroft, and that we were there, too! For, although the rascals can do nothing to our house, they may plunder the plateau, our plantations, our poultry-yard!
children.prevalue: Oh I wish that he was there at Granite House cried Pencroft and that we were there too For although the rascals can do nothing to our house they may plunder the plateau our plantations our poultry yard

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Pencroft had become a thorough farmer, heartily attached to his crops. But it must be said that Herbert was more anxious than any to return to Granite House, for he knew how much the presence of the settlers was needed there.
