children.value: Like true settlers, the colonists spared the largest and most beautiful trees, which would besides have cost immense labor to fell, and the small ones only were sacrificed, but the result was that the road took a very winding direction, and lengthened itself by numerous detours.
children.prevalue: Like true settlers the colonists spared the largest and most beautiful trees which would besides have cost immense labor to fell and the small ones only were sacrificed but the result was that the road took a very winding direction and lengthened itself by numerous detours

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: During the day Herbert discovered several new specimens not before met with in the island, such as the tree-fern, with its leaves spread out like the waters of a fountain, locust-trees, on the long pods of which the onagers browsed greedily, and which supplied a sweet pulp of excellent flavor. There, too, the colonists again found groups of magnificent kauries, their cylindrical trunks, crowded with a cone of verdure, rising to a height of two hundred feet. These were the tree-kings of New Zealand, as celebrated as the cedars of Lebanon.
children.prevalue: During the day Herbert discovered several new specimens not before met with in the island such as the tree fern with its leaves spread out like the waters of a fountain locust trees on the long pods of which the onagers browsed greedily and which supplied a sweet pulp of excellent flavor There too the colonists again found groups of magnificent kauries their cylindrical trunks crowded with a cone of verdure rising to a height of two hundred feet These were the tree kings of New Zealand as celebrated as the cedars of Lebanon

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: As to the fauna, there was no addition to those species already known to the hunters. Nevertheless, they saw, though unable to get near them, a couple of those large birds peculiar to Australia, a sort of cassowary, called emu, five feet in height, and with brown plumage, which belong to the tribe of waders. Top darted after them as fast as his four legs could carry him, but the emus distanced him with ease, so prodigious was their speed.
children.prevalue: As to the fauna there was no addition to those species already known to the hunters Nevertheless they saw though unable to get near them a couple of those large birds peculiar to Australia a sort of cassowary called emu five feet in height and with brown plumage which belong to the tribe of waders Top darted after them as fast as his four legs could carry him but the emus distanced him with ease so prodigious was their speed

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: As to the traces left by the convicts, a few more were discovered. Some footprints found near an apparently recently extinguished fire were attentively examined by the settlers. By measuring them one after the other, according to their length and breadth, the marks of five men's feet were easily distinguished. The five convicts had evidently camped on this spot; but,--and this was the object of so minute an examination,--a sixth footprint could not be discovered, which in that case would have been that of Ayrton.
children.prevalue: As to the traces left by the convicts a few more were discovered Some footprints found near an apparently recently extinguished fire were attentively examined by the settlers By measuring them one after the other according to their length and breadth the marks of five men s feet were easily distinguished The five convicts had evidently camped on this spot but and this was the object of so minute an examination a sixth footprint could not be discovered which in that case would have been that of Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Ayrton was not with them! said Herbert.
children.prevalue: Ayrton was not with them said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, answered Pencroft, and if he was not with them, it was because the wretches had already murdered him! but then these rascals have not a den to which they may be tracked like tigers!
children.prevalue: No answered Pencroft and if he was not with them it was because the wretches had already murdered him but then these rascals have not a den to which they may be tracked like tigers

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: No, replied the reporter, it is more probable that they wander at random, and it is their interest to rove about until the time when they will be masters of the island!
children.prevalue: No replied the reporter it is more probable that they wander at random and it is their interest to rove about until the time when they will be masters of the island

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The masters of the island! exclaimed the sailor; the masters of the island!... he repeated, and his voice was choked, as if his throat was seized in an iron grasp. Then in a calmer tone, Do you know, Captain Harding, said he, what the ball is which I have rammed into my gun?
children.prevalue: The masters of the island exclaimed the sailor the masters of the island he repeated and his voice was choked as if his throat was seized in an iron grasp Then in a calmer tone Do you know Captain Harding said he what the ball is which I have rammed into my gun

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: No, Pencroft!
children.prevalue: No Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: It is the ball that went through Herbert's chest, and I promise you it won't miss its mark!
children.prevalue: It is the ball that went through Herbert s chest and I promise you it won t miss its mark

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But this just retaliation would not bring Ayrton back to life, and from the examination of the footprints left in the ground, they must, alas! conclude that all hopes of ever seeing him again must be abandoned.
children.prevalue: But this just retaliation would not bring Ayrton back to life and from the examination of the footprints left in the ground they must alas conclude that all hopes of ever seeing him again must be abandoned

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: That evening they encamped fourteen miles from Granite House, and Cyrus Harding calculated that they could not be more than five miles from Reptile Point.
children.prevalue: That evening they encamped fourteen miles from Granite House and Cyrus Harding calculated that they could not be more than five miles from Reptile Point

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And indeed, the next day the extremity of the peninsula was reached, and the whole length of the forest had been traversed; but there was nothing to indicate the retreat in which the convicts had taken refuge, nor that, no less secret, which sheltered the mysterious unknown.
children.prevalue: And indeed the next day the extremity of the peninsula was reached and the whole length of the forest had been traversed but there was nothing to indicate the retreat in which the convicts had taken refuge nor that no less secret which sheltered the mysterious unknown

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next day, the 18th of February, was devoted to the exploration of all that wooded region forming the shore from Reptile End to Falls River. The colonists were able to search this forest thoroughly, for, as it was comprised between the two shores of the Serpentine Peninsula, it was only from three to four miles in breadth. The trees, both by their height and their thick foliage, bore witness to the vegetative power of the soil, more astonishing here than in any other part of the island. One might have said that a corner from the virgin forests of America or Africa had been transported into this temperate zone. This led them to conclude that the superb vegetation found a heat in this soil, damp in its upper layer, but warmed in the interior by volcanic fires, which could not belong to a temperate climate. The most frequently occurring trees were knaries and eucalypti of gigantic dimensions.
children.prevalue: The next day the 18th of February was devoted to the exploration of all that wooded region forming the shore from Reptile End to Falls River The colonists were able to search this forest thoroughly for as it was comprised between the two shores of the Serpentine Peninsula it was only from three to four miles in breadth The trees both by their height and their thick foliage bore witness to the vegetative power of the soil more astonishing here than in any other part of the island One might have said that a corner from the virgin forests of America or Africa had been transported into this temperate zone This led them to conclude that the superb vegetation found a heat in this soil damp in its upper layer but warmed in the interior by volcanic fires which could not belong to a temperate climate The most frequently occurring trees were knaries and eucalypti of gigantic dimensions

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: But the colonists' object was not simply to admire the magnificent vegetation. They knew already that in this respect Lincoln Island would have been worthy to take the first rank in the Canary group, to which the first name given was that of the Happy Isles. Now, alas! their island no longer belonged to them entirely; others had taken possession of it, miscreants polluted its shores, and they must be destroyed to the last man.
children.prevalue: But the colonists object was not simply to admire the magnificent vegetation They knew already that in this respect Lincoln Island would have been worthy to take the first rank in the Canary group to which the first name given was that of the Happy Isles Now alas their island no longer belonged to them entirely others had taken possession of it miscreants polluted its shores and they must be destroyed to the last man

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: No traces were found on the western coast, although they were carefully sought for. No more footprints, no more broken branches, no more deserted camps.
children.prevalue: No traces were found on the western coast although they were carefully sought for No more footprints no more broken branches no more deserted camps

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: This does not surprise me, said Cyrus Harding to his companions. The convicts first landed on the island in the neighborhood of Flotsam Point, and they immediately plunged into the Far West forests, after crossing Tadorn Marsh. They then followed almost the same route that we took on leaving Granite House. This explains the traces we found in the wood. But, arriving on the shore, the convicts saw at once that they would discover no suitable retreat there, and it was then that, going northwards again, they came upon the corral.
children.prevalue: This does not surprise me said Cyrus Harding to his companions The convicts first landed on the island in the neighborhood of Flotsam Point and they immediately plunged into the Far West forests after crossing Tadorn Marsh They then followed almost the same route that we took on leaving Granite House This explains the traces we found in the wood But arriving on the shore the convicts saw at once that they would discover no suitable retreat there and it was then that going northwards again they came upon the corral

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Where they have perhaps returned, said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Where they have perhaps returned said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I do not think so, answered the engineer, for they would naturally suppose that our researches would be in that direction. The corral is only a storehouse to them, and not a definitive encampment.
children.prevalue: I do not think so answered the engineer for they would naturally suppose that our researches would be in that direction The corral is only a storehouse to them and not a definitive encampment

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I am of Cyrus' opinion, said the reporter, and I think that it is among the spurs of Mount Franklin that the convicts will have made their lair.
children.prevalue: I am of Cyrus opinion said the reporter and I think that it is among the spurs of Mount Franklin that the convicts will have made their lair

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Then, captain, straight to the corral! cried Pencroft. We must finish them off, and till now we have only lost time!
children.prevalue: Then captain straight to the corral cried Pencroft We must finish them off and till now we have only lost time

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No, my friend, replied the engineer; you forget that we have a reason for wishing to know if the forests of the Far West do not contain some habitation. Our exploration has a double object, Pencroft. If, on the one hand, we have to chastise crime, we have, on the other, an act of gratitude to perform.
children.prevalue: No my friend replied the engineer you forget that we have a reason for wishing to know if the forests of the Far West do not contain some habitation Our exploration has a double object Pencroft If on the one hand we have to chastise crime we have on the other an act of gratitude to perform

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: That was well said, captain, replied the sailor, but, all the same, it is my opinion that we shall not find the gentleman until he pleases.
children.prevalue: That was well said captain replied the sailor but all the same it is my opinion that we shall not find the gentleman until he pleases

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: And truly Pencroft only expressed the opinion of all. It was probable that the stranger's retreat was not less mysterious than was he himself.
children.prevalue: And truly Pencroft only expressed the opinion of all It was probable that the stranger s retreat was not less mysterious than was he himself

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That evening the cart halted at the mouth of Falls River. The camp was organized as usual, and the customary precautions were taken for the night. Herbert, become again the healthy and vigorous lad he was before his illness, derived great benefit from this life in the open air, between the sea breezes and the vivifying air from the forests. His place was no longer in the cart, but at the head of the troop.
children.prevalue: That evening the cart halted at the mouth of Falls River The camp was organized as usual and the customary precautions were taken for the night Herbert become again the healthy and vigorous lad he was before his illness derived great benefit from this life in the open air between the sea breezes and the vivifying air from the forests His place was no longer in the cart but at the head of the troop

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The next day, the 19th of February, the colonists, leaving the shore, where, beyond the mouth, basalts of every shape were so picturesquely piled up, ascended the river by its left bank. The road had been already partly cleared in their former excursions made from the corral to the west coast. The settlers were now about six miles from Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: The next day the 19th of February the colonists leaving the shore where beyond the mouth basalts of every shape were so picturesquely piled up ascended the river by its left bank The road had been already partly cleared in their former excursions made from the corral to the west coast The settlers were now about six miles from Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The engineer's plan was this:--To minutely survey the valley forming the bed of the river, and to cautiously approach the neighborhood of the corral; if the corral was occupied, to seize it by force; if it was not, to entrench themselves there and make it the center of the operations which had for their object the exploration of Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: The engineer s plan was this To minutely survey the valley forming the bed of the river and to cautiously approach the neighborhood of the corral if the corral was occupied to seize it by force if it was not to entrench themselves there and make it the center of the operations which had for their object the exploration of Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: This plan was unanimously approved by the colonists, for they were impatient to regain entire possession of their island.
children.prevalue: This plan was unanimously approved by the colonists for they were impatient to regain entire possession of their island

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: They made their way then along the narrow valley separating two of the largest spurs of Mount Franklin. The trees, crowded on the river's bank, became rare on the upper slopes of the mountain. The ground was hilly and rough, very suitable for ambushes, and over which they did not venture without extreme precaution. Top and Jup skirmished on the flanks, springing right and left through the thick brushwood, and emulating each other in intelligence and activity. But nothing showed that the banks of the stream had been recently frequented--nothing announced either the presence or the proximity of the convicts. Towards five in the evening the cart stopped nearly 600 feet from the palisade. A semicircular screen of trees still hid it.
children.prevalue: They made their way then along the narrow valley separating two of the largest spurs of Mount Franklin The trees crowded on the river s bank became rare on the upper slopes of the mountain The ground was hilly and rough very suitable for ambushes and over which they did not venture without extreme precaution Top and Jup skirmished on the flanks springing right and left through the thick brushwood and emulating each other in intelligence and activity But nothing showed that the banks of the stream had been recently frequented nothing announced either the presence or the proximity of the convicts Towards five in the evening the cart stopped nearly 600 feet from the palisade A semicircular screen of trees still hid it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It was necessary to reconnoiter the corral, in order to ascertain if it was occupied. To go there openly, in broad daylight, when the convicts were probably in ambush, would be to expose themselves, as poor Herbert had done, to the firearms of the ruffians. It was better, then, to wait until night came on.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to reconnoiter the corral in order to ascertain if it was occupied To go there openly in broad daylight when the convicts were probably in ambush would be to expose themselves as poor Herbert had done to the firearms of the ruffians It was better then to wait until night came on

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: However, Gideon Spilett wished without further delay to reconnoiter the approaches to the corral, and Pencroft, who was quite out of patience, volunteered to accompany him.
children.prevalue: However Gideon Spilett wished without further delay to reconnoiter the approaches to the corral and Pencroft who was quite out of patience volunteered to accompany him

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No, my friends, said the engineer, wait till night. I will not allow one of you to expose himself in open day.
children.prevalue: No my friends said the engineer wait till night I will not allow one of you to expose himself in open day

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: But, captain-- answered the sailor, little disposed to obey.
children.prevalue: But captain answered the sailor little disposed to obey

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I beg of you, Pencroft, said the engineer.
children.prevalue: I beg of you Pencroft said the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Very well! replied the sailor, who vented his anger in another way, by bestowing on the convicts the worst names in his maritime vocabulary.
children.prevalue: Very well replied the sailor who vented his anger in another way by bestowing on the convicts the worst names in his maritime vocabulary

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The colonists remained, therefore, near the cart, and carefully watched the neighboring parts of the forest.
children.prevalue: The colonists remained therefore near the cart and carefully watched the neighboring parts of the forest

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Three hours passed thus. The wind had fallen, and absolute silence reigned under the great trees. The snapping of the smallest twig, a footstep on the dry leaves, the gliding of a body among the grass, would have been heard without difficulty. All was quiet. Besides, Top, lying on the grass, his head stretched out on his paws, gave no sign of uneasiness. At eight o'clock the day appeared far enough advanced for the reconnaissance to be made under favorable conditions. Gideon Spilett declared himself ready to set out accompanied by Pencroft. Cyrus Harding consented. Top and Jup were to remain with the engineer, Herbert, and Neb, for a bark or a cry at a wrong moment would give the alarm.
children.prevalue: Three hours passed thus The wind had fallen and absolute silence reigned under the great trees The snapping of the smallest twig a footstep on the dry leaves the gliding of a body among the grass would have been heard without difficulty All was quiet Besides Top lying on the grass his head stretched out on his paws gave no sign of uneasiness At eight o clock the day appeared far enough advanced for the reconnaissance to be made under favorable conditions Gideon Spilett declared himself ready to set out accompanied by Pencroft Cyrus Harding consented Top and Jup were to remain with the engineer Herbert and Neb for a bark or a cry at a wrong moment would give the alarm

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Do not be imprudent, said Harding to the reporter and Pencroft, you have not to gain possession of the corral, but only to find out whether it is occupied or not.
children.prevalue: Do not be imprudent said Harding to the reporter and Pencroft you have not to gain possession of the corral but only to find out whether it is occupied or not

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: All right, answered Pencroft.
children.prevalue: All right answered Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And the two departed.
children.prevalue: And the two departed

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Under the trees, thanks to the thickness of their foliage, the obscurity rendered any object invisible beyond a radius of from thirty to forty feet. The reporter and Pencroft, halting at any suspicious sound, advanced with great caution.
children.prevalue: Under the trees thanks to the thickness of their foliage the obscurity rendered any object invisible beyond a radius of from thirty to forty feet The reporter and Pencroft halting at any suspicious sound advanced with great caution

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: They walked a little distance apart from each other so as to offer a less mark for a shot. And, to tell the truth, they expected every moment to hear a report. Five minutes after leaving the cart, Gideon Spilett and Pencroft arrived at the edge of the wood before the clearing beyond which rose the palisade.
children.prevalue: They walked a little distance apart from each other so as to offer a less mark for a shot And to tell the truth they expected every moment to hear a report Five minutes after leaving the cart Gideon Spilett and Pencroft arrived at the edge of the wood before the clearing beyond which rose the palisade

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: They stopped. A few straggling beams still fell on the field clear of trees. Thirty feet distant was the gate of the corral, which appeared to be closed. This thirty feet, which it was necessary to cross from the wood to the palisade, constituted the dangerous zone, to borrow a ballistic term: in fact, one or more bullets fired from behind the palisade might knock over any one who ventured on to this zone. Gideon Spilett and the sailor were not men to draw back, but they knew that any imprudence on their part, of which they would be the first victims, would fall afterwards on their companions. If they themselves were killed, what would become of Harding, Neb, and Herbert?
children.prevalue: They stopped A few straggling beams still fell on the field clear of trees Thirty feet distant was the gate of the corral which appeared to be closed This thirty feet which it was necessary to cross from the wood to the palisade constituted the dangerous zone to borrow a ballistic term in fact one or more bullets fired from behind the palisade might knock over any one who ventured on to this zone Gideon Spilett and the sailor were not men to draw back but they knew that any imprudence on their part of which they would be the first victims would fall afterwards on their companions If they themselves were killed what would become of Harding Neb and Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But Pencroft, excited at feeling himself so near the corral where he supposed the convicts had taken refuge, was about to press forward, when the reporter held him back with a grasp of iron.
children.prevalue: But Pencroft excited at feeling himself so near the corral where he supposed the convicts had taken refuge was about to press forward when the reporter held him back with a grasp of iron

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: In a few minutes it will be quite dark, whispered Spilett in the sailor's ear, then will be the time to act.
children.prevalue: In a few minutes it will be quite dark whispered Spilett in the sailor s ear then will be the time to act

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Pencroft, convulsively clasping the butt-end of his gun, restrained his energies, and waited, swearing to himself.
children.prevalue: Pencroft convulsively clasping the butt end of his gun restrained his energies and waited swearing to himself

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Soon the last of the twilight faded away. Darkness, which seemed as if it issued from the dense forest, covered the clearing. Mount Franklin rose like an enormous screen before the western horizon, and night spread rapidly over all, as it does in regions of low latitudes. Now was the time.
children.prevalue: Soon the last of the twilight faded away Darkness which seemed as if it issued from the dense forest covered the clearing Mount Franklin rose like an enormous screen before the western horizon and night spread rapidly over all as it does in regions of low latitudes Now was the time

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The reporter and Pencroft, since posting themselves on the edge of the wood, had not once lost sight of the palisade. The corral appeared to be absolutely deserted. The top of the palisade formed a line, a little darker than the surrounding shadow, and nothing disturbed its distinctness. Nevertheless, if the convicts were there, they must have posted one of their number to guard against any surprise.
children.prevalue: The reporter and Pencroft since posting themselves on the edge of the wood had not once lost sight of the palisade The corral appeared to be absolutely deserted The top of the palisade formed a line a little darker than the surrounding shadow and nothing disturbed its distinctness Nevertheless if the convicts were there they must have posted one of their number to guard against any surprise

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Spilett grasped his companion's hand, and both crept towards the corral, their guns ready to fire.
children.prevalue: Spilett grasped his companion s hand and both crept towards the corral their guns ready to fire

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: They reached the gate without the darkness being illuminated by a single ray of light.
children.prevalue: They reached the gate without the darkness being illuminated by a single ray of light

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Pencroft tried to push open the gate, which, as the reporter and he had supposed, was closed. However, the sailor was able to ascertain that the outer bars had not been put up. It might, then, be concluded that the convicts were there in the corral, and that very probably they had fastened the gate in such a way that it could not be forced open.
children.prevalue: Pencroft tried to push open the gate which as the reporter and he had supposed was closed However the sailor was able to ascertain that the outer bars had not been put up It might then be concluded that the convicts were there in the corral and that very probably they had fastened the gate in such a way that it could not be forced open

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Gideon Spilett and Pencroft listened.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett and Pencroft listened

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Not a sound could be heard inside the palisade. The musmons and the goats, sleeping no doubt in their huts, in no way disturbed the calm of night.
children.prevalue: Not a sound could be heard inside the palisade The musmons and the goats sleeping no doubt in their huts in no way disturbed the calm of night

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The reporter and the sailor hearing nothing, asked themselves whether they had not better scale the palisades and penetrate into the corral. This would have been contrary to Cyrus Harding's instructions.
children.prevalue: The reporter and the sailor hearing nothing asked themselves whether they had not better scale the palisades and penetrate into the corral This would have been contrary to Cyrus Harding s instructions

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: It is true that the enterprise might succeed, but it might also fail. Now, if the convicts were suspecting nothing, if they knew nothing of the expedition against them, if, lastly, there now existed a chance of surprising them, ought this chance to be lost by inconsiderately attempting to cross the palisades?
children.prevalue: It is true that the enterprise might succeed but it might also fail Now if the convicts were suspecting nothing if they knew nothing of the expedition against them if lastly there now existed a chance of surprising them ought this chance to be lost by inconsiderately attempting to cross the palisades

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This was not the reporter's opinion. He thought it better to wait until all the settlers were collected together before attempting to penetrate into the corral. One thing was certain, that it was possible to reach the palisade without being seen, and also that it did not appear to be guarded. This point settled, there was nothing to be done but to return to the cart, where they would consult.
children.prevalue: This was not the reporter s opinion He thought it better to wait until all the settlers were collected together before attempting to penetrate into the corral One thing was certain that it was possible to reach the palisade without being seen and also that it did not appear to be guarded This point settled there was nothing to be done but to return to the cart where they would consult

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Pencroft probably agreed with this decision, for he followed the reporter without making any objection when the latter turned back to the wood.
children.prevalue: Pencroft probably agreed with this decision for he followed the reporter without making any objection when the latter turned back to the wood

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: In a few minutes the engineer was made acquainted with the state of affairs.
children.prevalue: In a few minutes the engineer was made acquainted with the state of affairs

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Well, said he, after a little thought, I now have reason to believe that the convicts are not in the corral.
children.prevalue: Well said he after a little thought I now have reason to believe that the convicts are not in the corral

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: We shall soon know, said Pencroft, when we have scaled the palisade.
children.prevalue: We shall soon know said Pencroft when we have scaled the palisade

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: To the corral, my friends! said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: To the corral my friends said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Shall we leave the cart in the wood? asked Neb.
children.prevalue: Shall we leave the cart in the wood asked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: No, replied the engineer, it is our wagon of ammunition and provisions, and, if necessary, it would serve as an entrenchment.
children.prevalue: No replied the engineer it is our wagon of ammunition and provisions and if necessary it would serve as an entrenchment

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Forward, then! said Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: Forward then said Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The cart emerged from the wood and began to roll noiselessly towards the palisade. The darkness was now profound, the silence as complete as when Pencroft and the reporter crept over the ground. The thick grass completely muffled their footsteps. The colonists held themselves ready to fire. Jup, at Pencroft's orders, kept behind. Neb led Top in a leash, to prevent him from bounding forward.
children.prevalue: The cart emerged from the wood and began to roll noiselessly towards the palisade The darkness was now profound the silence as complete as when Pencroft and the reporter crept over the ground The thick grass completely muffled their footsteps The colonists held themselves ready to fire Jup at Pencroft s orders kept behind Neb led Top in a leash to prevent him from bounding forward

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The clearing soon came in sight. It was deserted. Without hesitating, the little band moved towards the palisade. In a short space of time the dangerous zone was passed. Neb remained at the onagers' heads to hold them. The engineer, the reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft, proceeded to the door, in order to ascertain if it was barricaded inside. It was open!
children.prevalue: The clearing soon came in sight It was deserted Without hesitating the little band moved towards the palisade In a short space of time the dangerous zone was passed Neb remained at the onagers heads to hold them The engineer the reporter Herbert and Pencroft proceeded to the door in order to ascertain if it was barricaded inside It was open

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What do you say now? asked the engineer, turning to the sailor and Spilett.
children.prevalue: What do you say now asked the engineer turning to the sailor and Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Both were stupefied.
children.prevalue: Both were stupefied

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I can swear, said Pencroft, that this gate was shut just now!
children.prevalue: I can swear said Pencroft that this gate was shut just now

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The colonists now hesitated. Were the convicts in the corral when Pencroft and the reporter made their reconnaissance? It could not be doubted, as the gate then closed could only have been opened by them. Were they still there, or had one of their number just gone out?
children.prevalue: The colonists now hesitated Were the convicts in the corral when Pencroft and the reporter made their reconnaissance It could not be doubted as the gate then closed could only have been opened by them Were they still there or had one of their number just gone out

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: All these questions presented themselves simultaneously to the minds of the colonists, but how could they be answered?
children.prevalue: All these questions presented themselves simultaneously to the minds of the colonists but how could they be answered

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At that moment, Herbert, who had advanced a few steps into the enclosure, drew back hurriedly, and seized Harding's hand.
children.prevalue: At that moment Herbert who had advanced a few steps into the enclosure drew back hurriedly and seized Harding s hand

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What's the matter? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: What s the matter asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: A light!
children.prevalue: A light

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: In the house?
children.prevalue: In the house

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Yes!
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: All five advanced and indeed, through the window fronting them, they saw glimmering a feeble light. Cyrus Harding made up his mind rapidly. It is our only chance, said he to his companions, of finding the convicts collected in this house, suspecting nothing! They are in our power! Forward! The colonists crossed through the enclosure, holding their guns ready in their hands. The cart had been left outside under the charge of Jup and Top, who had been prudently tied to it.
children.prevalue: All five advanced and indeed through the window fronting them they saw glimmering a feeble light Cyrus Harding made up his mind rapidly It is our only chance said he to his companions of finding the convicts collected in this house suspecting nothing They are in our power Forward The colonists crossed through the enclosure holding their guns ready in their hands The cart had been left outside under the charge of Jup and Top who had been prudently tied to it

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, and Gideon Spilett on one side, Herbert and Neb on the other, going along by the palisade, surveyed the absolutely dark and deserted corral.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding Pencroft and Gideon Spilett on one side Herbert and Neb on the other going along by the palisade surveyed the absolutely dark and deserted corral

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: In a few moments they were near the closed door of the house.
children.prevalue: In a few moments they were near the closed door of the house

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Harding signed to his companions not to stir, and approached the window, then feebly lighted by the inner light.
children.prevalue: Harding signed to his companions not to stir and approached the window then feebly lighted by the inner light

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: He gazed into the apartment.
children.prevalue: He gazed into the apartment

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: On the table burned a lantern. Near the table was the bed formerly used by Ayrton.
children.prevalue: On the table burned a lantern Near the table was the bed formerly used by Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: On the bed lay the body of a man.
children.prevalue: On the bed lay the body of a man

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Suddenly Cyrus Harding drew back, and in a hoarse voice,--Ayrton! he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: Suddenly Cyrus Harding drew back and in a hoarse voice Ayrton he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Immediately the door was forced rather than opened, and the colonists rushed into the room.
children.prevalue: Immediately the door was forced rather than opened and the colonists rushed into the room

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Ayrton appeared to be asleep. His countenance showed that he had long and cruelly suffered. On his wrists and ankles could be seen great bruises.
children.prevalue: Ayrton appeared to be asleep His countenance showed that he had long and cruelly suffered On his wrists and ankles could be seen great bruises

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Harding bent over him.
children.prevalue: Harding bent over him

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Ayrton! cried the engineer, seizing the arm of the man whom he had just found again under such unexpected circumstances.
children.prevalue: Ayrton cried the engineer seizing the arm of the man whom he had just found again under such unexpected circumstances

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: At this exclamation Ayrton opened his eyes, and, gazing at Harding, then at the others,--
children.prevalue: At this exclamation Ayrton opened his eyes and gazing at Harding then at the others

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: You! he cried, you?
children.prevalue: You he cried you

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Ayrton! Ayrton! repeated Harding.
children.prevalue: Ayrton Ayrton repeated Harding

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Where am I?
children.prevalue: Where am I

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: In the house in the corral!
children.prevalue: In the house in the corral

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Alone?
children.prevalue: Alone

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Yes!
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: But they will come back! cried Ayrton. Defend yourselves! defend yourselves!
children.prevalue: But they will come back cried Ayrton Defend yourselves defend yourselves

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: And he fell back exhausted.
children.prevalue: And he fell back exhausted

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Spilett, exclaimed the engineer, we may be attacked at any moment. Bring the cart into the corral. Then, barricade the door, and all come back here.
children.prevalue: Spilett exclaimed the engineer we may be attacked at any moment Bring the cart into the corral Then barricade the door and all come back here

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Pencroft, Neb, and the reporter hastened to execute the engineer's orders. There was not a moment to be lost. Perhaps even now the cart was in the hands of the convicts!
children.prevalue: Pencroft Neb and the reporter hastened to execute the engineer s orders There was not a moment to be lost Perhaps even now the cart was in the hands of the convicts

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: In a moment the reporter and his two companions had crossed the corral and reached the gate of the palisade behind which Top was heard growling sullenly.
children.prevalue: In a moment the reporter and his two companions had crossed the corral and reached the gate of the palisade behind which Top was heard growling sullenly

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The engineer, leaving Ayrton for an instant, came out ready to fire. Herbert was at his side. Both surveyed the crest of the spur overlooking the corral. If the convicts were lying in ambush there, they might knock the settlers over one after the other.
children.prevalue: The engineer leaving Ayrton for an instant came out ready to fire Herbert was at his side Both surveyed the crest of the spur overlooking the corral If the convicts were lying in ambush there they might knock the settlers over one after the other

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: At that moment the moon appeared in the east, above the black curtain of the forest, and a white sheet of light spread over the interior of the enclosure. The corral, with its clumps of trees, the little stream which watered it, its wide carpet of grass, was suddenly illuminated. From the side of the mountain, the house and a part of the palisade stood out white in the moonlight. On the opposite side towards the door, the enclosure remained dark. A black mass soon appeared. This was the cart entering the circle of light, and Cyrus Harding could hear the noise made by the door, as his companions shut it and fastened the interior bars.
children.prevalue: At that moment the moon appeared in the east above the black curtain of the forest and a white sheet of light spread over the interior of the enclosure The corral with its clumps of trees the little stream which watered it its wide carpet of grass was suddenly illuminated From the side of the mountain the house and a part of the palisade stood out white in the moonlight On the opposite side towards the door the enclosure remained dark A black mass soon appeared This was the cart entering the circle of light and Cyrus Harding could hear the noise made by the door as his companions shut it and fastened the interior bars

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: But, at that moment, Top, breaking loose, began to bark furiously and rush to the back of the corral, to the right of the house.
children.prevalue: But at that moment Top breaking loose began to bark furiously and rush to the back of the corral to the right of the house

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Be ready to fire, my friends! cried Harding.
children.prevalue: Be ready to fire my friends cried Harding

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: The colonists raised their pieces and waited the moment to fire.
children.prevalue: The colonists raised their pieces and waited the moment to fire

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Top still barked, and Jup, running towards the dog, uttered shrill cries.
children.prevalue: Top still barked and Jup running towards the dog uttered shrill cries

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: The colonists followed him, and reached the borders of the little stream, shaded by large trees. And there, in the bright moonlight, what did they see? Five corpses, stretched on the bank!
children.prevalue: The colonists followed him and reached the borders of the little stream shaded by large trees And there in the bright moonlight what did they see Five corpses stretched on the bank

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: They were those of the convicts who, four months previously, had landed on Lincoln Island!
children.prevalue: They were those of the convicts who four months previously had landed on Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: How had it happened? who had killed the convicts? Was it Ayrton? No, for a moment before he was dreading their return.
children.prevalue: How had it happened who had killed the convicts Was it Ayrton No for a moment before he was dreading their return

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: But Ayrton was now in a profound stupor, from which it was no longer possible to rouse him. After uttering those few words he had again become unconscious, and had fallen back motionless on the bed.
children.prevalue: But Ayrton was now in a profound stupor from which it was no longer possible to rouse him After uttering those few words he had again become unconscious and had fallen back motionless on the bed

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The colonists, a prey to a thousand confused thoughts, under the influence of violent excitement, waited all night, without leaving Ayrton's house, or returning to the spot where lay the bodies of the convicts. It was very probable that Ayrton would not be able to throw any light on the circumstances under which the bodies had been found, since he himself was not aware that he was in the corral. But at any rate he would be in a position to give an account of what had taken place before this terrible execution. The next day Ayrton awoke from his torpor, and his companions cordially manifested all the joy they felt, on seeing him again, almost safe and sound, after a hundred and four days separation.
children.prevalue: The colonists a prey to a thousand confused thoughts under the influence of violent excitement waited all night without leaving Ayrton s house or returning to the spot where lay the bodies of the convicts It was very probable that Ayrton would not be able to throw any light on the circumstances under which the bodies had been found since he himself was not aware that he was in the corral But at any rate he would be in a position to give an account of what had taken place before this terrible execution The next day Ayrton awoke from his torpor and his companions cordially manifested all the joy they felt on seeing him again almost safe and sound after a hundred and four days separation

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Ayrton then in a few words recounted what had happened, or, at least, as much as he knew.
children.prevalue: Ayrton then in a few words recounted what had happened or at least as much as he knew

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The day after his arrival at the corral, on the 10th of last November, at nightfall, he was surprised by the convicts, who had scaled the palisade. They bound and gagged him; then he was led to a dark cavern, at the foot of Mount Franklin, where the convicts had taken refuge.
children.prevalue: The day after his arrival at the corral on the 10th of last November at nightfall he was surprised by the convicts who had scaled the palisade They bound and gagged him then he was led to a dark cavern at the foot of Mount Franklin where the convicts had taken refuge

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: His death had been decided upon, and the next day the convicts were about to kill him, when one of them recognized him and called him by the name which he bore in Australia. The wretches had no scruples as to murdering Ayrton! They spared Ben Joyce!
children.prevalue: His death had been decided upon and the next day the convicts were about to kill him when one of them recognized him and called him by the name which he bore in Australia The wretches had no scruples as to murdering Ayrton They spared Ben Joyce

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But from that moment Ayrton was exposed to the importunities of his former accomplices. They wished him to join them again, and relied upon his aid to enable them to gain possession of Granite House, to penetrate into that hitherto inaccessible dwelling, and to become masters of the island, after murdering the colonists!
children.prevalue: But from that moment Ayrton was exposed to the importunities of his former accomplices They wished him to join them again and relied upon his aid to enable them to gain possession of Granite House to penetrate into that hitherto inaccessible dwelling and to become masters of the island after murdering the colonists

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Ayrton remained firm. The once convict, now repentant and pardoned, would rather die than betray his companions. Ayrton--bound, gagged, and closely watched--lived in this cave for four months.
children.prevalue: Ayrton remained firm The once convict now repentant and pardoned would rather die than betray his companions Ayrton bound gagged and closely watched lived in this cave for four months

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Nevertheless the convicts had discovered the corral a short time after their arrival in the island, and since then they had subsisted on Ayrton's stores, but did not live at the corral.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless the convicts had discovered the corral a short time after their arrival in the island and since then they had subsisted on Ayrton s stores but did not live at the corral

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: On the 11th of November, two of the villains, surprised by the colonists' arrival, fired at Herbert, and one of them returned, boasting of having killed one of the inhabitants of the island; but he returned alone. His companion, as is known, fell by Cyrus Harding's dagger.
children.prevalue: On the 11th of November two of the villains surprised by the colonists arrival fired at Herbert and one of them returned boasting of having killed one of the inhabitants of the island but he returned alone His companion as is known fell by Cyrus Harding s dagger

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ayrton's anxiety and despair may be imagined when he learned the news of Herbert's death. The settlers were now only four, and, as it seemed, at the mercy of the convicts. After this event, and during all the time that the colonists, detained by Herbert's illness, remained in the corral, the pirates did not leave their cavern, and even after they had pillaged the plateau of Prospect Heights, they did not think it prudent to abandon it.
children.prevalue: Ayrton s anxiety and despair may be imagined when he learned the news of Herbert s death The settlers were now only four and as it seemed at the mercy of the convicts After this event and during all the time that the colonists detained by Herbert s illness remained in the corral the pirates did not leave their cavern and even after they had pillaged the plateau of Prospect Heights they did not think it prudent to abandon it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The ill-treatment inflicted on Ayrton was now redoubled. His hands and feet still bore the bloody marks of the cords which bound him day and night. Every moment he expected to be put to death, nor did it appear possible that he could escape.
children.prevalue: The ill treatment inflicted on Ayrton was now redoubled His hands and feet still bore the bloody marks of the cords which bound him day and night Every moment he expected to be put to death nor did it appear possible that he could escape

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Matters remained thus until the third week of February. The convicts, still watching for a favorable opportunity, rarely quitted their retreat, and only made a few hunting excursions, either to the interior of the island, or the south coast.
children.prevalue: Matters remained thus until the third week of February The convicts still watching for a favorable opportunity rarely quitted their retreat and only made a few hunting excursions either to the interior of the island or the south coast

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Ayrton had no further news of his friends, and relinquished all hope of ever seeing them again. At last, the unfortunate man, weakened by ill-treatment, fell into a prostration so profound that sight and hearing failed him. From that moment, that is to say, since the last two days, he could give no information whatever of what had occurred.
children.prevalue: Ayrton had no further news of his friends and relinquished all hope of ever seeing them again At last the unfortunate man weakened by ill treatment fell into a prostration so profound that sight and hearing failed him From that moment that is to say since the last two days he could give no information whatever of what had occurred

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But, Captain Harding, he added, since I was imprisoned in that cavern, how is it that I find myself in the corral?
children.prevalue: But Captain Harding he added since I was imprisoned in that cavern how is it that I find myself in the corral

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: How is it that the convicts are lying yonder dead, in the middle of the enclosure? answered the engineer.
children.prevalue: How is it that the convicts are lying yonder dead in the middle of the enclosure answered the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Dead! cried Ayrton, half rising from his bed, notwithstanding his weakness.
children.prevalue: Dead cried Ayrton half rising from his bed notwithstanding his weakness

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: His companions supported him. He wished to get up, and with their assistance he did so. They then proceeded together towards the little stream.
children.prevalue: His companions supported him He wished to get up and with their assistance he did so They then proceeded together towards the little stream

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It was now broad daylight.
children.prevalue: It was now broad daylight

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: There, on the bank, in the position in which they had been stricken by death in its most instantaneous form, lay the corpses of the five convicts!
children.prevalue: There on the bank in the position in which they had been stricken by death in its most instantaneous form lay the corpses of the five convicts

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Ayrton was astounded. Harding and his companions looked at him without uttering a word. On a sign from the engineer, Neb and Pencroft examined the bodies, already stiffened by the cold.
children.prevalue: Ayrton was astounded Harding and his companions looked at him without uttering a word On a sign from the engineer Neb and Pencroft examined the bodies already stiffened by the cold

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: They bore no apparent trace of any wound.
children.prevalue: They bore no apparent trace of any wound

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Only, after carefully examining them, Pencroft found on the forehead of one, on the chest of another, on the back of this one, on the shoulder of that, a little red spot, a sort of scarcely visible bruise, the cause of which it was impossible to conjecture.
children.prevalue: Only after carefully examining them Pencroft found on the forehead of one on the chest of another on the back of this one on the shoulder of that a little red spot a sort of scarcely visible bruise the cause of which it was impossible to conjecture

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It is there that they have been struck! said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: It is there that they have been struck said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But with what weapon? cried the reporter.
children.prevalue: But with what weapon cried the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: A weapon, lightning-like in its effects, and of which we have not the secret!
children.prevalue: A weapon lightning like in its effects and of which we have not the secret

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And who has struck the blow? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: And who has struck the blow asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The avenging power of the island, replied Harding, he who brought you here, Ayrton, whose influence has once more manifested itself, who does for us all that which we cannot do for ourselves, and who, his will accomplished, conceals himself from us.
children.prevalue: The avenging power of the island replied Harding he who brought you here Ayrton whose influence has once more manifested itself who does for us all that which we cannot do for ourselves and who his will accomplished conceals himself from us

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Let us make search for him, then! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Let us make search for him then exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, we will search for him, answered Harding, but we shall not discover this powerful being who performs such wonders, until he pleases to call us to him!
children.prevalue: Yes we will search for him answered Harding but we shall not discover this powerful being who performs such wonders until he pleases to call us to him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: This invisible protection, which rendered their own action unavailing, both irritated and piqued the engineer. The relative inferiority which it proved was of a nature to wound a haughty spirit. A generosity evinced in such a manner as to elude all tokens of gratitude, implied a sort of disdain for those on whom the obligation was conferred, which in Cyrus Harding's eyes marred, in some degree, the worth of the benefit.
children.prevalue: This invisible protection which rendered their own action unavailing both irritated and piqued the engineer The relative inferiority which it proved was of a nature to wound a haughty spirit A generosity evinced in such a manner as to elude all tokens of gratitude implied a sort of disdain for those on whom the obligation was conferred which in Cyrus Harding s eyes marred in some degree the worth of the benefit

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Let us search, he resumed, and God grant that we may some day be permitted to prove to this haughty protector that he has not to deal with ungrateful people! What would I not give could we repay him, by rendering him in our turn, although at the price of our lives, some signal service!
children.prevalue: Let us search he resumed and God grant that we may some day be permitted to prove to this haughty protector that he has not to deal with ungrateful people What would I not give could we repay him by rendering him in our turn although at the price of our lives some signal service

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: From this day, the thoughts of the inhabitants of Lincoln Island were solely occupied with the intended search. Everything incited them to discover the answer to this enigma, an answer which would only be the name of a man endowed with a truly inexplicable, and in some degree superhuman power.
children.prevalue: From this day the thoughts of the inhabitants of Lincoln Island were solely occupied with the intended search Everything incited them to discover the answer to this enigma an answer which would only be the name of a man endowed with a truly inexplicable and in some degree superhuman power

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: In a few minutes, the settlers re-entered the house, where their influence soon restored to Ayrton his moral and physical energy. Neb and Pencroft carried the corpses of the convicts into the forest, some distance from the corral, and buried them deep in the ground.
children.prevalue: In a few minutes the settlers re entered the house where their influence soon restored to Ayrton his moral and physical energy Neb and Pencroft carried the corpses of the convicts into the forest some distance from the corral and buried them deep in the ground

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Ayrton was then made acquainted with the facts which had occurred during his seclusion. He learned Herbert's adventures, and through what various trials the colonists had passed. As to the settlers, they had despaired of ever seeing Ayrton again, and had been convinced that the convicts had ruthlessly murdered him.
children.prevalue: Ayrton was then made acquainted with the facts which had occurred during his seclusion He learned Herbert s adventures and through what various trials the colonists had passed As to the settlers they had despaired of ever seeing Ayrton again and had been convinced that the convicts had ruthlessly murdered him

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And now, said Cyrus Harding, as he ended his recital, a duty remains for us to perform. Half of our task is accomplished, but although the convicts are no longer to be feared, it is not owing to ourselves that we are once more masters of the island.
children.prevalue: And now said Cyrus Harding as he ended his recital a duty remains for us to perform Half of our task is accomplished but although the convicts are no longer to be feared it is not owing to ourselves that we are once more masters of the island

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well! answered Gideon Spilett, let us search all this labyrinth of the spurs of Mount Franklin. We will not leave a hollow, not a hole unexplored! Ah! if ever a reporter found himself face to face with a mystery, it is I who now speak to you, my friends!
children.prevalue: Well answered Gideon Spilett let us search all this labyrinth of the spurs of Mount Franklin We will not leave a hollow not a hole unexplored Ah if ever a reporter found himself face to face with a mystery it is I who now speak to you my friends

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And we will not return to Granite House until we have found our benefactor, said Herbert.
children.prevalue: And we will not return to Granite House until we have found our benefactor said Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Yes, said the engineer, we will do all that it is humanly possible to do, but I repeat we shall not find him until he himself permits us.
children.prevalue: Yes said the engineer we will do all that it is humanly possible to do but I repeat we shall not find him until he himself permits us

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Shall we stay at the corral? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Shall we stay at the corral asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: We shall stay here, answered Harding. Provisions are abundant, and we are here in the very center of the circle we have to explore. Besides, if necessary, the cart will take us rapidly to Granite House.
children.prevalue: We shall stay here answered Harding Provisions are abundant and we are here in the very center of the circle we have to explore Besides if necessary the cart will take us rapidly to Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Good! answered the sailor. Only I have a remark to make.
children.prevalue: Good answered the sailor Only I have a remark to make

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Here is the fine season getting on, and we must not forget that we have a voyage to make.
children.prevalue: Here is the fine season getting on and we must not forget that we have a voyage to make

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: A voyage? said Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: A voyage said Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, to Tabor Island, answered Pencroft. It is necessary to carry a notice there to point out the position of our island and say that Ayrton is here in case the Scotch yacht should come to take him off. Who knows if it is not already too late?
children.prevalue: Yes to Tabor Island answered Pencroft It is necessary to carry a notice there to point out the position of our island and say that Ayrton is here in case the Scotch yacht should come to take him off Who knows if it is not already too late

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But, Pencroft, asked Ayrton, how do you intend to make this voyage?
children.prevalue: But Pencroft asked Ayrton how do you intend to make this voyage

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: In the 'Bonadventure.'
children.prevalue: In the Bonadventure

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The 'Bonadventure!' exclaimed Ayrton. She no longer exists.
children.prevalue: The Bonadventure exclaimed Ayrton She no longer exists

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: My 'Bonadventure' exists no longer! shouted Pencroft, bounding from his seat.
children.prevalue: My Bonadventure exists no longer shouted Pencroft bounding from his seat

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: No, answered Ayrton. The convicts discovered her in her little harbor only eight days ago, they put to sea in her--
children.prevalue: No answered Ayrton The convicts discovered her in her little harbor only eight days ago they put to sea in her

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: And? said Pencroft, his heart beating.
children.prevalue: And said Pencroft his heart beating

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: And not having Bob Harvey to steer her, they ran on the rocks, and the vessel went to pieces.
children.prevalue: And not having Bob Harvey to steer her they ran on the rocks and the vessel went to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Oh, the villains, the cutthroats, the infamous scoundrels! exclaimed Pencroft.
children.prevalue: Oh the villains the cutthroats the infamous scoundrels exclaimed Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Pencroft, said Herbert, taking the sailor's hand, we will build another 'Bonadventure'--a larger one. We have all the ironwork--all the rigging of the brig at our disposal.
children.prevalue: Pencroft said Herbert taking the sailor s hand we will build another Bonadventure a larger one We have all the ironwork all the rigging of the brig at our disposal

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: But do you know, returned Pencroft, that it will take at least five or six months to build a vessel of from thirty to forty tons?
children.prevalue: But do you know returned Pencroft that it will take at least five or six months to build a vessel of from thirty to forty tons

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: We can take our time, said the reporter, and we must give up the voyage to Tabor Island for this year.
children.prevalue: We can take our time said the reporter and we must give up the voyage to Tabor Island for this year

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Oh, my 'Bonadventure!' my poor 'Bonadventure!' cried Pencroft, almost broken-hearted at the destruction of the vessel of which he was so proud.
children.prevalue: Oh my Bonadventure my poor Bonadventure cried Pencroft almost broken hearted at the destruction of the vessel of which he was so proud

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The loss of the Bonadventure was certainly a thing to be lamented by the colonists, and it was agreed that this loss should be repaired as soon as possible. This settled, they now occupied themselves with bringing their researches to bear on the most secret parts of the island.
children.prevalue: The loss of the Bonadventure was certainly a thing to be lamented by the colonists and it was agreed that this loss should be repaired as soon as possible This settled they now occupied themselves with bringing their researches to bear on the most secret parts of the island

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The exploration was commenced at daybreak on the 19th of February, and lasted an entire week. The base of the mountain, with its spurs and their numberless ramifications, formed a labyrinth of valleys and elevations. It was evident that there, in the depths of these narrow gorges, perhaps even in the interior of Mount Franklin itself, was the proper place to pursue their researches. No part of the island could have been more suitable to conceal a dwelling whose occupant wished to remain unknown. But so irregular was the formation of the valleys that Cyrus Harding was obliged to conduct the exploration in a strictly methodical manner.
children.prevalue: The exploration was commenced at daybreak on the 19th of February and lasted an entire week The base of the mountain with its spurs and their numberless ramifications formed a labyrinth of valleys and elevations It was evident that there in the depths of these narrow gorges perhaps even in the interior of Mount Franklin itself was the proper place to pursue their researches No part of the island could have been more suitable to conceal a dwelling whose occupant wished to remain unknown But so irregular was the formation of the valleys that Cyrus Harding was obliged to conduct the exploration in a strictly methodical manner

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The colonists first visited the valley opening to the south of the volcano, and which first received the waters of Falls River. There Ayrton showed them the cavern where the convicts had taken refuge, and in which he had been imprisoned until his removal to the corral. This cavern was just as Ayrton had left it. They found there a considerable quantity of ammunition and provisions, conveyed thither by the convicts in order to form a reserve.
children.prevalue: The colonists first visited the valley opening to the south of the volcano and which first received the waters of Falls River There Ayrton showed them the cavern where the convicts had taken refuge and in which he had been imprisoned until his removal to the corral This cavern was just as Ayrton had left it They found there a considerable quantity of ammunition and provisions conveyed thither by the convicts in order to form a reserve

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The whole of the valley bordering on the cave, shaded by fir and other trees, was thoroughly explored, and on turning the point of the southwestern spur, the colonists entered a narrower gorge similar to the picturesque columns of basalt on the coast. Here the trees were fewer. Stones took the place of grass. Goats and musmons gambolled among the rocks. Here began the barren part of the island. It could already be seen that, of the numerous valleys branching off at the base of Mount Franklin, three only were wooded and rich in pasturage like that of the corral, which bordered on the west on the Falls River valley, and on the east on the Red Creek valley. These two streams, which lower down became rivers by the absorption of several tributaries, were formed by all the springs of the mountain and thus caused the fertility of its southern part. As to the Mercy, it was more directly fed from ample springs concealed under the cover of Jacamar Wood, and it was by springs of this nature, spreading in a thousand streamlets, that the soil of the Serpentine Peninsula was watered.
children.prevalue: The whole of the valley bordering on the cave shaded by fir and other trees was thoroughly explored and on turning the point of the southwestern spur the colonists entered a narrower gorge similar to the picturesque columns of basalt on the coast Here the trees were fewer Stones took the place of grass Goats and musmons gambolled among the rocks Here began the barren part of the island It could already be seen that of the numerous valleys branching off at the base of Mount Franklin three only were wooded and rich in pasturage like that of the corral which bordered on the west on the Falls River valley and on the east on the Red Creek valley These two streams which lower down became rivers by the absorption of several tributaries were formed by all the springs of the mountain and thus caused the fertility of its southern part As to the Mercy it was more directly fed from ample springs concealed under the cover of Jacamar Wood and it was by springs of this nature spreading in a thousand streamlets that the soil of the Serpentine Peninsula was watered

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Now, of these three well-watered valleys, either might have served as a retreat to some solitary who would have found there everything necessary for life. But the settlers had already explored them, and in no part had they discovered the presence of man.
children.prevalue: Now of these three well watered valleys either might have served as a retreat to some solitary who would have found there everything necessary for life But the settlers had already explored them and in no part had they discovered the presence of man

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Was it then in the depths of those barren gorges, in the midst of the piles of rock, in the rugged northern ravines, among the streams of lava, that this dwelling and its occupant would be found?
children.prevalue: Was it then in the depths of those barren gorges in the midst of the piles of rock in the rugged northern ravines among the streams of lava that this dwelling and its occupant would be found

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The northern part of Mount Franklin was at its base composed solely of two valleys, wide, not very deep, without any appearance of vegetation, strewn with masses of rock, paved with lava, and varied with great blocks of mineral. This region required a long and careful exploration. It contained a thousand cavities, comfortless no doubt, but perfectly concealed and difficult of access.
children.prevalue: The northern part of Mount Franklin was at its base composed solely of two valleys wide not very deep without any appearance of vegetation strewn with masses of rock paved with lava and varied with great blocks of mineral This region required a long and careful exploration It contained a thousand cavities comfortless no doubt but perfectly concealed and difficult of access

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The colonists even visited dark tunnels, dating from the volcanic period, still black from the passage of the fire, and penetrated into the depths of the mountain. They traversed these somber galleries, waving lighted torches; they examined the smallest excavations; they sounded the shallowest depths, but all was dark and silent. It did not appear that the foot of man had ever before trodden these ancient passages, or that his arm had ever displaced one of these blocks, which remained as the volcano had cast them up above the waters, at the time of the submersion of the island.
children.prevalue: The colonists even visited dark tunnels dating from the volcanic period still black from the passage of the fire and penetrated into the depths of the mountain They traversed these somber galleries waving lighted torches they examined the smallest excavations they sounded the shallowest depths but all was dark and silent It did not appear that the foot of man had ever before trodden these ancient passages or that his arm had ever displaced one of these blocks which remained as the volcano had cast them up above the waters at the time of the submersion of the island

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: However, although these passages appeared to be absolutely deserted, and the obscurity was complete, Cyrus Harding was obliged to confess that absolute silence did not reign there.
children.prevalue: However although these passages appeared to be absolutely deserted and the obscurity was complete Cyrus Harding was obliged to confess that absolute silence did not reign there

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: On arriving at the end of one of these gloomy caverns, extending several hundred feet into the interior of the mountain, he was surprised to hear a deep rumbling noise, increased in intensity by the sonorousness of the rocks.
children.prevalue: On arriving at the end of one of these gloomy caverns extending several hundred feet into the interior of the mountain he was surprised to hear a deep rumbling noise increased in intensity by the sonorousness of the rocks

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Gideon Spilett, who accompanied him, also heard these distant mutterings, which indicated a revivification of the subterranean fires. Several times both listened, and they agreed that some chemical process was taking place in the bowels of the earth.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett who accompanied him also heard these distant mutterings which indicated a revivification of the subterranean fires Several times both listened and they agreed that some chemical process was taking place in the bowels of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Then the volcano is not totally extinct? said the reporter.
children.prevalue: Then the volcano is not totally extinct said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It is possible that since our exploration of the crater, replied Cyrus Harding, some change has occurred. Any volcano, although considered extinct, may evidently again burst forth.
children.prevalue: It is possible that since our exploration of the crater replied Cyrus Harding some change has occurred Any volcano although considered extinct may evidently again burst forth

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: But if an eruption of Mount Franklin occurred, asked Spilett, would there not be some danger to Lincoln Island?
children.prevalue: But if an eruption of Mount Franklin occurred asked Spilett would there not be some danger to Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I do not think so, answered the reporter. The crater, that is to say, the safety-valve, exists, and the overflow of smoke and lava, would escape, as it did formerly, by this customary outlet.
