children.prevalue: I do not think so answered the reporter The crater that is to say the safety valve exists and the overflow of smoke and lava would escape as it did formerly by this customary outlet

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Unless the lava opened a new way for itself towards the fertile parts of the island!
children.prevalue: Unless the lava opened a new way for itself towards the fertile parts of the island

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: And why, my dear Spilett, answered Cyrus Harding, should it not follow the road naturally traced out for it?
children.prevalue: And why my dear Spilett answered Cyrus Harding should it not follow the road naturally traced out for it

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Well, volcanoes are capricious, returned the reporter.
children.prevalue: Well volcanoes are capricious returned the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Notice, answered the engineer, that the inclination of Mount Franklin favors the flow of water towards the valleys which we are exploring just now. To turn aside this flow, an earthquake would be necessary to change the mountain's center of gravity.
children.prevalue: Notice answered the engineer that the inclination of Mount Franklin favors the flow of water towards the valleys which we are exploring just now To turn aside this flow an earthquake would be necessary to change the mountain s center of gravity

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But an earthquake is always to be feared at these times, observed Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: But an earthquake is always to be feared at these times observed Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Always, replied the engineer, especially when the subterranean forces begin to awake, as they risk meeting with some obstruction, after a long rest. Thus, my dear Spilett, an eruption would be a serious thing for us, and it would be better that the volcano should not have the slightest desire to wake up. But we could not prevent it, could we? At any rate, even if it should occur, I do not think Prospect Heights would be seriously threatened. Between them and the mountain, the ground is considerably depressed, and if the lava should ever take a course towards the lake, it would be cast on the downs and the neighboring parts of Shark Gulf.
children.prevalue: Always replied the engineer especially when the subterranean forces begin to awake as they risk meeting with some obstruction after a long rest Thus my dear Spilett an eruption would be a serious thing for us and it would be better that the volcano should not have the slightest desire to wake up But we could not prevent it could we At any rate even if it should occur I do not think Prospect Heights would be seriously threatened Between them and the mountain the ground is considerably depressed and if the lava should ever take a course towards the lake it would be cast on the downs and the neighboring parts of Shark Gulf

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: We have not yet seen any smoke at the top of the mountain, to indicate an approaching eruption, said Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: We have not yet seen any smoke at the top of the mountain to indicate an approaching eruption said Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: No, answered Harding, not a vapor escapes from the crater, for it was only yesterday that I attentively surveyed the summit. But it is probable that at the lower part of the chimney, time may have accumulated rocks, cinders, hardened lava, and that this valve of which I spoke, may at any time become overcharged. But at the first serious effort, every obstacle will disappear, and you may be certain, my dear Spilett, that neither the island, which is the boiler, nor the volcano, which is the chimney, will burst under the pressure of gas. Nevertheless, I repeat, it would be better that there should not be an eruption.
children.prevalue: No answered Harding not a vapor escapes from the crater for it was only yesterday that I attentively surveyed the summit But it is probable that at the lower part of the chimney time may have accumulated rocks cinders hardened lava and that this valve of which I spoke may at any time become overcharged But at the first serious effort every obstacle will disappear and you may be certain my dear Spilett that neither the island which is the boiler nor the volcano which is the chimney will burst under the pressure of gas Nevertheless I repeat it would be better that there should not be an eruption

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: And yet we are not mistaken, remarked the reporter. Mutterings can be distinctly heard in the very bowels of the volcano!
children.prevalue: And yet we are not mistaken remarked the reporter Mutterings can be distinctly heard in the very bowels of the volcano

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: You are right, said the engineer, again listening attentively. There can be no doubt of it. A commotion is going on there, of which we can neither estimate the importance nor the ultimate result.
children.prevalue: You are right said the engineer again listening attentively There can be no doubt of it A commotion is going on there of which we can neither estimate the importance nor the ultimate result

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Spilett, on coming out, rejoined their companions, to whom they made known the state of affairs.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Spilett on coming out rejoined their companions to whom they made known the state of affairs

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Very well! cried Pencroft, The volcano wants to play his pranks! Let him try, if he likes! He will find his master!
children.prevalue: Very well cried Pencroft The volcano wants to play his pranks Let him try if he likes He will find his master

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Who? asked Neb.
children.prevalue: Who asked Neb

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Our good genius, Neb, our good genius, who will shut his mouth for him, if he so much as pretends to open it!
children.prevalue: Our good genius Neb our good genius who will shut his mouth for him if he so much as pretends to open it

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: As may be seen, the sailor's confidence in the tutelary deity of his island was absolute, and, certainly, the occult power, manifested until now in so many inexplicable ways, appeared to be unlimited; but also it knew how to escape the colonists' most minute researches, for, in spite of all their efforts, in spite of the more than zeal,--the obstinacy,--with which they carried on their exploration, the retreat of the mysterious being could not be discovered.
children.prevalue: As may be seen the sailor s confidence in the tutelary deity of his island was absolute and certainly the occult power manifested until now in so many inexplicable ways appeared to be unlimited but also it knew how to escape the colonists most minute researches for in spite of all their efforts in spite of the more than zeal the obstinacy with which they carried on their exploration the retreat of the mysterious being could not be discovered

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: From the 19th to the 20th of February the circle of investigation was extended to all the northern region of Lincoln Island, whose most secret nooks were explored. The colonists even went the length of tapping every rock. The search was extended to the extreme verge of the mountain. It was explored thus to the very summit of the truncated cone terminating the first row of rocks, then to the upper ridge of the enormous hat, at the bottom of which opened the crater.
children.prevalue: From the 19th to the 20th of February the circle of investigation was extended to all the northern region of Lincoln Island whose most secret nooks were explored The colonists even went the length of tapping every rock The search was extended to the extreme verge of the mountain It was explored thus to the very summit of the truncated cone terminating the first row of rocks then to the upper ridge of the enormous hat at the bottom of which opened the crater

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: They did more; they visited the gulf, now extinct, but in whose depths the rumbling could be distinctly heard. However, no sign of smoke or vapor, no heating of the rock, indicated an approaching eruption. But neither there, nor in any other part of Mount Franklin, did the colonists find any traces of him of whom they were in search.
children.prevalue: They did more they visited the gulf now extinct but in whose depths the rumbling could be distinctly heard However no sign of smoke or vapor no heating of the rock indicated an approaching eruption But neither there nor in any other part of Mount Franklin did the colonists find any traces of him of whom they were in search

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Their investigations were then directed to the downs. They carefully examined the high lava-cliffs of Shark Gulf from the base to the crest, although it was extremely difficult to reach even the level of the gulf. No one!--nothing!
children.prevalue: Their investigations were then directed to the downs They carefully examined the high lava cliffs of Shark Gulf from the base to the crest although it was extremely difficult to reach even the level of the gulf No one nothing

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Indeed, in these three words was summed up so much fatigue uselessly expended, so much energy producing no results, that somewhat of anger mingled with the discomfiture of Cyrus Harding and his companions.
children.prevalue: Indeed in these three words was summed up so much fatigue uselessly expended so much energy producing no results that somewhat of anger mingled with the discomfiture of Cyrus Harding and his companions

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: It was now time to think of returning, for these researches could not be prolonged indefinitely. The colonists were certainly right in believing that the mysterious being did not reside on the surface of the island, and the wildest fancies haunted their excited imaginations. Pencroft and Neb, particularly, were not contented with the mystery, but allowed their imaginations to wander into the domain of the supernatural.
children.prevalue: It was now time to think of returning for these researches could not be prolonged indefinitely The colonists were certainly right in believing that the mysterious being did not reside on the surface of the island and the wildest fancies haunted their excited imaginations Pencroft and Neb particularly were not contented with the mystery but allowed their imaginations to wander into the domain of the supernatural

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: On the 25th of February the colonists re-entered Granite House, and by means of the double cord, carried by an arrow to the threshold of the door, they re-established communication between their habitation and the ground.
children.prevalue: On the 25th of February the colonists re entered Granite House and by means of the double cord carried by an arrow to the threshold of the door they re established communication between their habitation and the ground

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: A month later they commemorated, on the 25th of March, the third anniversary of their arrival on Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: A month later they commemorated on the 25th of March the third anniversary of their arrival on Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Three years had passed away since the escape of the prisoners from Richmond, and how often during those three years had they spoken of their country, always present in their thoughts!
children.prevalue: Three years had passed away since the escape of the prisoners from Richmond and how often during those three years had they spoken of their country always present in their thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: They had no doubt that the civil war was at an end, and to them it appeared impossible that the just cause of the North had not triumphed. But what had been the incidents of this terrible war? How much blood had it not cost? How many of their friends must have fallen in the struggle? They often spoke of these things, without as yet being able to foresee the day when they would be permitted once more to see their country. To return thither, were it but for a few days, to renew the social link with the inhabited world, to establish a communication between their native land and their island, then to pass the longest, perhaps the best, portion of their existence in this colony, founded by them, and which would then be dependent on their country, was this a dream impossible to realize?
children.prevalue: They had no doubt that the civil war was at an end and to them it appeared impossible that the just cause of the North had not triumphed But what had been the incidents of this terrible war How much blood had it not cost How many of their friends must have fallen in the struggle They often spoke of these things without as yet being able to foresee the day when they would be permitted once more to see their country To return thither were it but for a few days to renew the social link with the inhabited world to establish a communication between their native land and their island then to pass the longest perhaps the best portion of their existence in this colony founded by them and which would then be dependent on their country was this a dream impossible to realize

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: There were only two ways of accomplishing it--either a ship must appear off Lincoln Island, or the colonists must themselves build a vessel strong enough to sail to the nearest land.
children.prevalue: There were only two ways of accomplishing it either a ship must appear off Lincoln Island or the colonists must themselves build a vessel strong enough to sail to the nearest land

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Unless, said Pencroft, our good genius, himself provides us with the means of returning to our country.
children.prevalue: Unless said Pencroft our good genius himself provides us with the means of returning to our country

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And, really, had any one told Pencroft and Neb that a ship of 300 tons was waiting for them in Shark Gulf or at Port Balloon, they would not even have made a gesture of surprise. In their state of mind nothing appeared improbable.
children.prevalue: And really had any one told Pencroft and Neb that a ship of 300 tons was waiting for them in Shark Gulf or at Port Balloon they would not even have made a gesture of surprise In their state of mind nothing appeared improbable

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But Cyrus Harding, less confident, advised them to confine themselves to fact, and more especially so with regard to the building of a vessel--a really urgent work, since it was for the purpose of depositing, as soon as possible, at Tabor Island a document indicating Ayrton's new residence.
children.prevalue: But Cyrus Harding less confident advised them to confine themselves to fact and more especially so with regard to the building of a vessel a really urgent work since it was for the purpose of depositing as soon as possible at Tabor Island a document indicating Ayrton s new residence

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: As the Bonadventure no longer existed, six months at least would be required for the construction of a new vessel. Now winter was approaching, and the voyage would not be made before the following spring.
children.prevalue: As the Bonadventure no longer existed six months at least would be required for the construction of a new vessel Now winter was approaching and the voyage would not be made before the following spring

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: We have time to get everything ready for the fine season, remarked the engineer, who was consulting with Pencroft about these matters. I think, therefore, my friend, that since we have to rebuild our vessel it will be best to give her larger dimensions. The arrival of the Scotch yacht at Tabor Island is very uncertain. It may even be that, having arrived several months ago, she has again sailed after having vainly searched for some trace of Ayrton. Will it not then be best to build a ship which, if necessary, could take us either to the Polynesian Archipelago or to New Zealand? What do you think?
children.prevalue: We have time to get everything ready for the fine season remarked the engineer who was consulting with Pencroft about these matters I think therefore my friend that since we have to rebuild our vessel it will be best to give her larger dimensions The arrival of the Scotch yacht at Tabor Island is very uncertain It may even be that having arrived several months ago she has again sailed after having vainly searched for some trace of Ayrton Will it not then be best to build a ship which if necessary could take us either to the Polynesian Archipelago or to New Zealand What do you think

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I think, captain, answered the sailor; I think that you are as capable of building a large vessel as a small one. Neither the wood nor the tools are wanting. It is only a question of time.
children.prevalue: I think captain answered the sailor I think that you are as capable of building a large vessel as a small one Neither the wood nor the tools are wanting It is only a question of time

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And how many months would be required to build a vessel of from 250 to 300 tons? asked Harding.
children.prevalue: And how many months would be required to build a vessel of from 250 to 300 tons asked Harding

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Seven or eight months at least, replied Pencroft. But it must not be forgotten that winter is drawing near, and that in severe frost wood is difficult to work. We must calculate on several weeks delay, and if our vessel is ready by next November we may think ourselves very lucky.
children.prevalue: Seven or eight months at least replied Pencroft But it must not be forgotten that winter is drawing near and that in severe frost wood is difficult to work We must calculate on several weeks delay and if our vessel is ready by next November we may think ourselves very lucky

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Well, replied Cyrus Harding, that will be exactly the most favorable time for undertaking a voyage of any importance, either to Tabor Island or to a more distant land.
children.prevalue: Well replied Cyrus Harding that will be exactly the most favorable time for undertaking a voyage of any importance either to Tabor Island or to a more distant land

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: So it will, captain, answered the sailor. Make out your plans then; the workmen are ready, and I imagine that Ayrton can lend us a good helping hand.
children.prevalue: So it will captain answered the sailor Make out your plans then the workmen are ready and I imagine that Ayrton can lend us a good helping hand

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The colonists, having been consulted, approved the engineer's plan, and it was, indeed, the best thing to be done. It is true that the construction of a ship of from two to three hundred tons would be great labor, but the colonists had confidence in themselves, justified by their previous success.
children.prevalue: The colonists having been consulted approved the engineer s plan and it was indeed the best thing to be done It is true that the construction of a ship of from two to three hundred tons would be great labor but the colonists had confidence in themselves justified by their previous success

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Cyrus Harding then busied himself in drawing the plan of the vessel and making the model. During this time his companions employed themselves in felling and carting trees to furnish the ribs, timbers, and planks. The forest of the Far West supplied the best oaks and elms. They took advantage of the opening already made on their last excursion to form a practicable road, which they named the Far West Road, and the trees were carried to the Chimneys, where the dockyard was established. As to the road in question, the choice of trees had rendered its direction somewhat capricious, but at the same time it facilitated the access to a large part of the Serpentine Peninsula.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding then busied himself in drawing the plan of the vessel and making the model During this time his companions employed themselves in felling and carting trees to furnish the ribs timbers and planks The forest of the Far West supplied the best oaks and elms They took advantage of the opening already made on their last excursion to form a practicable road which they named the Far West Road and the trees were carried to the Chimneys where the dockyard was established As to the road in question the choice of trees had rendered its direction somewhat capricious but at the same time it facilitated the access to a large part of the Serpentine Peninsula

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It was important that the trees should be quickly felled and cut up, for they could not be used while yet green, and some time was necessary to allow them to get seasoned. The carpenters, therefore, worked vigorously during the month of April, which was troubled only by a few equinoctial gales of some violence. Master Jup aided them dexterously, either by climbing to the top of a tree to fasten the ropes or by lending his stout shoulders to carry the lopped trunks.
children.prevalue: It was important that the trees should be quickly felled and cut up for they could not be used while yet green and some time was necessary to allow them to get seasoned The carpenters therefore worked vigorously during the month of April which was troubled only by a few equinoctial gales of some violence Master Jup aided them dexterously either by climbing to the top of a tree to fasten the ropes or by lending his stout shoulders to carry the lopped trunks

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: All this timber was piled up under a large shed, built near the Chimneys, and there awaited the time for use.
children.prevalue: All this timber was piled up under a large shed built near the Chimneys and there awaited the time for use

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The month of April was tolerably fine, as October often is in the northern zone. At the same time other work was actively continued, and soon all trace of devastation disappeared from the plateau of Prospect Heights. The mill was rebuilt, and new buildings rose in the poultry-yard. It had appeared necessary to enlarge their dimensions, for the feathered population had increased considerably. The stable now contained five onagers, four of which were well broken, and allowed themselves to be either driven or ridden, and a little colt. The colony now possessed a plow, to which the onagers were yoked like regular Yorkshire or Kentucky oxen. The colonists divided their work, and their arms never tired. Then who could have enjoyed better health than these workers, and what good humor enlivened the evenings in Granite House as they formed a thousand plans for the future!
children.prevalue: The month of April was tolerably fine as October often is in the northern zone At the same time other work was actively continued and soon all trace of devastation disappeared from the plateau of Prospect Heights The mill was rebuilt and new buildings rose in the poultry yard It had appeared necessary to enlarge their dimensions for the feathered population had increased considerably The stable now contained five onagers four of which were well broken and allowed themselves to be either driven or ridden and a little colt The colony now possessed a plow to which the onagers were yoked like regular Yorkshire or Kentucky oxen The colonists divided their work and their arms never tired Then who could have enjoyed better health than these workers and what good humor enlivened the evenings in Granite House as they formed a thousand plans for the future

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: As a matter of course Ayrton shared the common lot in every respect, and there was no longer any talk of his going to live at the corral. Nevertheless he was still sad and reserved, and joined more in the work than in the pleasures of his companions. But he was a valuable workman at need--strong, skilful, ingenious, intelligent. He was esteemed and loved by all, and he could not be ignorant of it.
children.prevalue: As a matter of course Ayrton shared the common lot in every respect and there was no longer any talk of his going to live at the corral Nevertheless he was still sad and reserved and joined more in the work than in the pleasures of his companions But he was a valuable workman at need strong skilful ingenious intelligent He was esteemed and loved by all and he could not be ignorant of it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: In the meanwhile the corral was not abandoned. Every other day one of the settlers, driving the cart or mounted on an onager, went to look after the flock of musmons and goats and bring back the supply of milk required by Neb. These excursions at the same time afforded opportunities for hunting. Therefore Herbert and Gideon Spilett, with Top in front, traversed more often than their companions the road to the corral, and with the capital guns which they carried, capybaras, agouties, kangaroos, and wild pigs for large game, ducks, grouse, jacamars, and snipe for small game, were never wanting in the house. The produce of the warren, of the oyster-bed, several turtles which were taken, excellent salmon which came up the Mercy, vegetables from the plateau, wild fruit from the forest, were riches upon riches, and Neb, the head cook, could scarcely by himself store them away.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the corral was not abandoned Every other day one of the settlers driving the cart or mounted on an onager went to look after the flock of musmons and goats and bring back the supply of milk required by Neb These excursions at the same time afforded opportunities for hunting Therefore Herbert and Gideon Spilett with Top in front traversed more often than their companions the road to the corral and with the capital guns which they carried capybaras agouties kangaroos and wild pigs for large game ducks grouse jacamars and snipe for small game were never wanting in the house The produce of the warren of the oyster bed several turtles which were taken excellent salmon which came up the Mercy vegetables from the plateau wild fruit from the forest were riches upon riches and Neb the head cook could scarcely by himself store them away

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The telegraphic wire between the corral and Granite House had of course been repaired, and it was worked whenever one or other of the settlers was at the corral and found it necessary to spend the night there. Besides, the island was safe now and no attacks were to be feared, at any rate from men.
children.prevalue: The telegraphic wire between the corral and Granite House had of course been repaired and it was worked whenever one or other of the settlers was at the corral and found it necessary to spend the night there Besides the island was safe now and no attacks were to be feared at any rate from men

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: However, that which had happened might happen again. A descent of pirates, or even of escaped convicts, was always to be feared. It was possible that companions or accomplices of Bob Harvey had been in the secret of his plans, and might be tempted to imitate him. The colonists, therefore, were careful to observe the sea around the island, and every day their telescope covered the horizon enclosed by Union and Washington Bays. When they went to the corral they examined the sea to the west with no less attention, and by climbing the spur their gaze extended over a large section of the western horizon.
children.prevalue: However that which had happened might happen again A descent of pirates or even of escaped convicts was always to be feared It was possible that companions or accomplices of Bob Harvey had been in the secret of his plans and might be tempted to imitate him The colonists therefore were careful to observe the sea around the island and every day their telescope covered the horizon enclosed by Union and Washington Bays When they went to the corral they examined the sea to the west with no less attention and by climbing the spur their gaze extended over a large section of the western horizon

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Nothing suspicious was discerned, but still it was necessary for them to be on their guard.
children.prevalue: Nothing suspicious was discerned but still it was necessary for them to be on their guard

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The engineer one evening imparted to his friends a plan which he had conceived for fortifying the corral. It appeared prudent to him to heighten the palisade and to flank it with a sort of blockhouse, which, if necessary, the settlers could hold against the enemy. Granite House might, by its very position, be considered impregnable; therefore the corral with its buildings, its stores, and the animals it contained, would always be the object of pirates, whoever they were, who might land on the island, and should the colonists be obliged to shut themselves up there they ought also to be able to defend themselves without any disadvantage. This was a project which might be left for consideration, and they were, besides, obliged to put off its execution until the next spring.
children.prevalue: The engineer one evening imparted to his friends a plan which he had conceived for fortifying the corral It appeared prudent to him to heighten the palisade and to flank it with a sort of blockhouse which if necessary the settlers could hold against the enemy Granite House might by its very position be considered impregnable therefore the corral with its buildings its stores and the animals it contained would always be the object of pirates whoever they were who might land on the island and should the colonists be obliged to shut themselves up there they ought also to be able to defend themselves without any disadvantage This was a project which might be left for consideration and they were besides obliged to put off its execution until the next spring

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: About the 15th of May the keel of the new vessel lay along the dockyard, and soon the stem and stern-post, mortised at each of its extremities, rose almost perpendicularly. The keel, of good oak, measured 110 feet in length, this allowing a width of five-and-twenty feet to the midship beam. But this was all the carpenters could do before the arrival of the frosts and bad weather. During the following week they fixed the first of the stern timbers, but were then obliged to suspend work.
children.prevalue: About the 15th of May the keel of the new vessel lay along the dockyard and soon the stem and stern post mortised at each of its extremities rose almost perpendicularly The keel of good oak measured 110 feet in length this allowing a width of five and twenty feet to the midship beam But this was all the carpenters could do before the arrival of the frosts and bad weather During the following week they fixed the first of the stern timbers but were then obliged to suspend work

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: During the last days of the month the weather was extremely bad. The wind blew from the east, sometimes with the violence of a tempest. The engineer was somewhat uneasy on account of the dockyard shed--which besides, he could not have established in any other place near to Granite House--for the islet only imperfectly sheltered the shore from the fury of the open sea, and in great storms the waves beat against the very foot of the granite cliff.
children.prevalue: During the last days of the month the weather was extremely bad The wind blew from the east sometimes with the violence of a tempest The engineer was somewhat uneasy on account of the dockyard shed which besides he could not have established in any other place near to Granite House for the islet only imperfectly sheltered the shore from the fury of the open sea and in great storms the waves beat against the very foot of the granite cliff

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: But, very fortunately, these fears were not realized. The wind shifted to the southeast, and there the beach of Granite House was completely covered by Flotsam Point.
children.prevalue: But very fortunately these fears were not realized The wind shifted to the southeast and there the beach of Granite House was completely covered by Flotsam Point

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Pencroft and Ayrton, the most zealous workmen at the new vessel, pursued their labor as long as they could. They were not men to mind the wind tearing at their hair, nor the rain wetting them to the skin, and a blow from a hammer is worth just as much in bad as in fine weather. But when a severe frost succeeded this wet period, the wood, its fibers acquiring the hardness of iron, became extremely difficult to work, and about the 10th of June shipbuilding was obliged to be entirely discontinued.
children.prevalue: Pencroft and Ayrton the most zealous workmen at the new vessel pursued their labor as long as they could They were not men to mind the wind tearing at their hair nor the rain wetting them to the skin and a blow from a hammer is worth just as much in bad as in fine weather But when a severe frost succeeded this wet period the wood its fibers acquiring the hardness of iron became extremely difficult to work and about the 10th of June shipbuilding was obliged to be entirely discontinued

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions had not omitted to observe how severe was the temperature during the winters of Lincoln Island. The cold was comparable to that experienced in the States of New England, situated at almost the same distance from the equator. In the northern hemisphere, or at any rate in the part occupied by British America and the north of the United States, this phenomenon is explained by the flat conformation of the territories bordering on the pole, and on which there is no intumescence of the soil to oppose any obstacle to the north winds; here, in Lincoln Island, this explanation would not suffice.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions had not omitted to observe how severe was the temperature during the winters of Lincoln Island The cold was comparable to that experienced in the States of New England situated at almost the same distance from the equator In the northern hemisphere or at any rate in the part occupied by British America and the north of the United States this phenomenon is explained by the flat conformation of the territories bordering on the pole and on which there is no intumescence of the soil to oppose any obstacle to the north winds here in Lincoln Island this explanation would not suffice

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: It has even been observed, remarked Harding one day to his companions, that in equal latitudes the islands and coast regions are less tried by the cold than inland countries. I have often heard it asserted that the winters of Lombardy, for example, are not less rigorous than those of Scotland, which results from the sea restoring during the winter the heat which it received during the summer. Islands are, therefore, in a better situation for benefiting by this restitution.
children.prevalue: It has even been observed remarked Harding one day to his companions that in equal latitudes the islands and coast regions are less tried by the cold than inland countries I have often heard it asserted that the winters of Lombardy for example are not less rigorous than those of Scotland which results from the sea restoring during the winter the heat which it received during the summer Islands are therefore in a better situation for benefiting by this restitution

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But then, Captain Harding, asked Herbert, why does Lincoln Island appear to escape the common law?
children.prevalue: But then Captain Harding asked Herbert why does Lincoln Island appear to escape the common law

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: That is difficult to explain, answered the engineer. However, I should be disposed to conjecture that this peculiarity results from the situation of the island in the Southern Hemisphere, which, as you know, my boy, is colder than the Northern Hemisphere.
children.prevalue: That is difficult to explain answered the engineer However I should be disposed to conjecture that this peculiarity results from the situation of the island in the Southern Hemisphere which as you know my boy is colder than the Northern Hemisphere

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, said Herbert, and icebergs are met with in lower latitudes in the south than in the north of the Pacific.
children.prevalue: Yes said Herbert and icebergs are met with in lower latitudes in the south than in the north of the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: That is true, remarked Pencroft, and when I have been serving on board whalers I have seen icebergs off Cape Horn.
children.prevalue: That is true remarked Pencroft and when I have been serving on board whalers I have seen icebergs off Cape Horn

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The severe cold experienced in Lincoln Island, said Gideon Spilett, may then perhaps be explained by the presence of floes or icebergs comparatively near to Lincoln Island.
children.prevalue: The severe cold experienced in Lincoln Island said Gideon Spilett may then perhaps be explained by the presence of floes or icebergs comparatively near to Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Your opinion is very admissible indeed, my dear Spilett, answered Cyrus Harding, and it is evidently to the proximity of icebergs that we owe our rigorous winters. I would draw your attention also to an entirely physical cause, which renders the Southern colder than the Northern Hemisphere. In fact, since the sun is nearer to this hemisphere during the summer, it is necessarily more distant during the winter. This explains then the excess of temperature in the two seasons, for, if we find the winters very cold in Lincoln Island, we must not forget that the summers here, on the contrary, are very hot.
children.prevalue: Your opinion is very admissible indeed my dear Spilett answered Cyrus Harding and it is evidently to the proximity of icebergs that we owe our rigorous winters I would draw your attention also to an entirely physical cause which renders the Southern colder than the Northern Hemisphere In fact since the sun is nearer to this hemisphere during the summer it is necessarily more distant during the winter This explains then the excess of temperature in the two seasons for if we find the winters very cold in Lincoln Island we must not forget that the summers here on the contrary are very hot

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: But why, if you please, captain, asked Pencroft, knitting his brows, why should our hemisphere, as you say, be so badly divided? It isn't just, that!
children.prevalue: But why if you please captain asked Pencroft knitting his brows why should our hemisphere as you say be so badly divided It isn t just that

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Friend Pencroft, answered the engineer, laughing, whether just or not, we must submit to it, and here lies the reason for this peculiarity. The earth does not describe a circle around the sun, but an ellipse, as it must by the laws of rational mechanics. Now, the earth occupies one of the foci of the ellipse, and so at one point in its course is at its apogee, that is, at its farthest from the sun, and at another point it is at its perigee, or nearest to the sun. Now it happens that it is during the winter of the southern countries that it is at its most distant point from the sun, and consequently, in a situation for those regions to feel the greatest cold. Nothing can be done to prevent that, and men, Pencroft, however learned they may be, can never change anything of the cosmographical order established by God Himself.
children.prevalue: Friend Pencroft answered the engineer laughing whether just or not we must submit to it and here lies the reason for this peculiarity The earth does not describe a circle around the sun but an ellipse as it must by the laws of rational mechanics Now the earth occupies one of the foci of the ellipse and so at one point in its course is at its apogee that is at its farthest from the sun and at another point it is at its perigee or nearest to the sun Now it happens that it is during the winter of the southern countries that it is at its most distant point from the sun and consequently in a situation for those regions to feel the greatest cold Nothing can be done to prevent that and men Pencroft however learned they may be can never change anything of the cosmographical order established by God Himself

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And yet, added Pencroft, the world is very learned. What a big book, captain, might be made with all that is known!
children.prevalue: And yet added Pencroft the world is very learned What a big book captain might be made with all that is known

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And what a much bigger book still with all that is not known! answered Harding.
children.prevalue: And what a much bigger book still with all that is not known answered Harding

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: At last, for one reason or another, the month of June brought the cold with its accustomed intensity, and the settlers were often confined to Granite House. Ah! how wearisome this imprisonment was to them, and more particularly to Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: At last for one reason or another the month of June brought the cold with its accustomed intensity and the settlers were often confined to Granite House Ah how wearisome this imprisonment was to them and more particularly to Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Look here, said he to Neb one day, I would give you by notarial deed all the estates which will come to me some day, if you were a good enough fellow to go, no matter where, and subscribe to some newspaper for me! Decidedly the thing that is most essential to my happiness is the knowing every morning what has happened the day before in other places than this!
children.prevalue: Look here said he to Neb one day I would give you by notarial deed all the estates which will come to me some day if you were a good enough fellow to go no matter where and subscribe to some newspaper for me Decidedly the thing that is most essential to my happiness is the knowing every morning what has happened the day before in other places than this

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Neb began to laugh.
children.prevalue: Neb began to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'Pon my word, he replied, the only thing I think about is my daily work!
children.prevalue: Pon my word he replied the only thing I think about is my daily work

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The truth was that indoors as well as out there was no want of work.
children.prevalue: The truth was that indoors as well as out there was no want of work

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The colony of Lincoln Island was now at its highest point of prosperity, achieved by three years of continued hard work. The destruction of the brig had been a new source of riches. Without speaking of the complete rig which would serve for the vessel now on the stocks, utensils and tools of all sorts, weapons and ammunition, clothes and instruments, were now piled in the storerooms of Granite House. It had not even been necessary to resort again to the manufacture of the coarse felt materials. Though the colonists had suffered from cold during their first winter, the bad season might now come without their having any reason to dread its severity. Linen was plentiful also, and besides, they kept it with extreme care. From chloride of sodium, which is nothing else than sea salt, Cyrus Harding easily extracted the soda and chlorine. The soda, which it was easy to change into carbonate of soda, and the chlorine, of which he made chloride of lime, were employed for various domestic purposes, and especially in bleaching linen. Besides, they did not wash more than four times a year, as was done by families in the olden times, and it may be added, that Pencroft and Gideon Spilett, while waiting for the postman to bring him his newspaper, distinguished themselves as washermen.
children.prevalue: The colony of Lincoln Island was now at its highest point of prosperity achieved by three years of continued hard work The destruction of the brig had been a new source of riches Without speaking of the complete rig which would serve for the vessel now on the stocks utensils and tools of all sorts weapons and ammunition clothes and instruments were now piled in the storerooms of Granite House It had not even been necessary to resort again to the manufacture of the coarse felt materials Though the colonists had suffered from cold during their first winter the bad season might now come without their having any reason to dread its severity Linen was plentiful also and besides they kept it with extreme care From chloride of sodium which is nothing else than sea salt Cyrus Harding easily extracted the soda and chlorine The soda which it was easy to change into carbonate of soda and the chlorine of which he made chloride of lime were employed for various domestic purposes and especially in bleaching linen Besides they did not wash more than four times a year as was done by families in the olden times and it may be added that Pencroft and Gideon Spilett while waiting for the postman to bring him his newspaper distinguished themselves as washermen

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: So passed the winter months, June, July, and August. They were severe, and the average observations of the thermometer did not give more than eight degrees of Fahrenheit. It was therefore lower in temperature than the preceding winter. But then, what splendid fires blazed continually on the hearths of Granite House, the smoke marking the granite wall with long, zebra-like streaks! Fuel was not spared, as it grew naturally a few steps from them. Besides, the chips of the wood destined for the construction of the ship enabled them to economize the coal, which required more trouble to transport.
children.prevalue: So passed the winter months June July and August They were severe and the average observations of the thermometer did not give more than eight degrees of Fahrenheit It was therefore lower in temperature than the preceding winter But then what splendid fires blazed continually on the hearths of Granite House the smoke marking the granite wall with long zebra like streaks Fuel was not spared as it grew naturally a few steps from them Besides the chips of the wood destined for the construction of the ship enabled them to economize the coal which required more trouble to transport

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Men and animals were all well. Master Jup was a little chilly, it must be confessed. This was perhaps his only weakness, and it was necessary to make him a well-padded dressing-gown. But what a servant he was, clever, zealous, indefatigable, not indiscreet, not talkative, and he might have been with reason proposed as a model for all his biped brothers in the Old and New Worlds!
children.prevalue: Men and animals were all well Master Jup was a little chilly it must be confessed This was perhaps his only weakness and it was necessary to make him a well padded dressing gown But what a servant he was clever zealous indefatigable not indiscreet not talkative and he might have been with reason proposed as a model for all his biped brothers in the Old and New Worlds

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: As for that, said Pencroft, when one has four hands at one's service, of course one's work ought to be done so much the better!
children.prevalue: As for that said Pencroft when one has four hands at one s service of course one s work ought to be done so much the better

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And indeed the intelligent creature did it well.
children.prevalue: And indeed the intelligent creature did it well

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: During the seven months which had passed since the last researches made round the mountain, and during the month of September, which brought back fine weather, nothing was heard of the genius of the island. His power was not manifested in any way. It is true that it would have been superfluous, for no incident occurred to put the colonists to any painful trial.
children.prevalue: During the seven months which had passed since the last researches made round the mountain and during the month of September which brought back fine weather nothing was heard of the genius of the island His power was not manifested in any way It is true that it would have been superfluous for no incident occurred to put the colonists to any painful trial

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Cyrus Harding even observed that if by chance the communication between the unknown and the tenants of Granite House had ever been established through the granite, and if Top's instinct had as it were felt it, there was no further sign of it during this period. The dog's growling had entirely ceased, as well as the uneasiness of the orang. The two friends--for they were such--no longer prowled round the opening of the inner well, nor did they bark or whine in that singular way which from the first the engineer had noticed. But could he be sure that this was all that was to be said about this enigma, and that he should never arrive at a solution? Could he be certain that some conjuncture would not occur which would bring the mysterious personage on the scene? who could tell what the future might have in reserve?
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding even observed that if by chance the communication between the unknown and the tenants of Granite House had ever been established through the granite and if Top s instinct had as it were felt it there was no further sign of it during this period The dog s growling had entirely ceased as well as the uneasiness of the orang The two friends for they were such no longer prowled round the opening of the inner well nor did they bark or whine in that singular way which from the first the engineer had noticed But could he be sure that this was all that was to be said about this enigma and that he should never arrive at a solution Could he be certain that some conjuncture would not occur which would bring the mysterious personage on the scene who could tell what the future might have in reserve

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: At last the winter was ended, but an event, the consequences of which might be serious occurred in the first days of the returning spring.
children.prevalue: At last the winter was ended but an event the consequences of which might be serious occurred in the first days of the returning spring

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: On the 7th of September, Cyrus Harding, having observed the crater, saw smoke curling round the summit of the mountain, its first vapors rising in the air.
children.prevalue: On the 7th of September Cyrus Harding having observed the crater saw smoke curling round the summit of the mountain its first vapors rising in the air

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The colonists, warned by the engineer, left their work and gazed in silence at the summit of Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: The colonists warned by the engineer left their work and gazed in silence at the summit of Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The volcano had awoke, and the vapor had penetrated the mineral layer heaped at the bottom of the crater. But would the subterranean fires provoke any violent eruption? This was an event which could not be foreseen. However, even while admitting the possibility of an eruption, it was not probable that the whole of Lincoln Island would suffer from it. The flow of volcanic matter is not always disastrous, and the island had already undergone this trial, as was shown by the streams of lava hardened on the northern slopes of the mountain. Besides, from the shape of the crater--the opening broken in the upper edge--the matter would be thrown to the side opposite the fertile regions of the island.
children.prevalue: The volcano had awoke and the vapor had penetrated the mineral layer heaped at the bottom of the crater But would the subterranean fires provoke any violent eruption This was an event which could not be foreseen However even while admitting the possibility of an eruption it was not probable that the whole of Lincoln Island would suffer from it The flow of volcanic matter is not always disastrous and the island had already undergone this trial as was shown by the streams of lava hardened on the northern slopes of the mountain Besides from the shape of the crater the opening broken in the upper edge the matter would be thrown to the side opposite the fertile regions of the island

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: However, the past did not necessarily answer for the future. Often, at the summit of volcanoes, the old craters close and new ones open. This had occurred in the two hemispheres--at Etna, Popocatepetl, at Orizabaand on the eve of an eruption there is everything to be feared. In fact, an earthquake--a phenomenon which often accompanies volcanic eruption--is enough to change the interior arrangement of a mountain, and to open new outlets for the burning lava.
children.prevalue: However the past did not necessarily answer for the future Often at the summit of volcanoes the old craters close and new ones open This had occurred in the two hemispheres at Etna Popocatepetl at Orizabaand on the eve of an eruption there is everything to be feared In fact an earthquake a phenomenon which often accompanies volcanic eruption is enough to change the interior arrangement of a mountain and to open new outlets for the burning lava

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Cyrus Harding explained these things to his companions, and, without exaggerating the state of things, he told them all the pros and cons. After all, they could not prevent it. It did not appear likely that Granite House would be threatened unless the ground was shaken by an earthquake. But the corral would be in great danger should a new crater open in the southern side of Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding explained these things to his companions and without exaggerating the state of things he told them all the pros and cons After all they could not prevent it It did not appear likely that Granite House would be threatened unless the ground was shaken by an earthquake But the corral would be in great danger should a new crater open in the southern side of Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: From that day the smoke never disappeared from the top of the mountain, and it could even be perceived that it increased in height and thickness, without any flame mingling in its heavy volumes. The phenomenon was still concentrated in the lower part of the central crater.
children.prevalue: From that day the smoke never disappeared from the top of the mountain and it could even be perceived that it increased in height and thickness without any flame mingling in its heavy volumes The phenomenon was still concentrated in the lower part of the central crater

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: However, with the fine days work had been continued. The building of the vessel was hastened as much as possible, and, by means of the waterfall on the shore, Cyrus Harding managed to establish an hydraulic sawmill, which rapidly cut up the trunks of trees into planks and joists. The mechanism of this apparatus was as simple as those used in the rustic sawmills of Norway. A first horizontal movement to move the piece of wood, a second vertical movement to move the saw--this was all that was wanted; and the engineer succeeded by means of a wheel, two cylinders, and pulleys properly arranged. Towards the end of the month of September the skeleton of the vessel, which was to be rigged as a schooner, lay in the dockyard. The ribs were almost entirely completed, and, all the timbers having been sustained by a provisional band, the shape of the vessel could already be seen. The schooner, sharp in the bows, very slender in the after-part, would evidently be suitable for a long voyage, if wanted; but laying the planking would still take a considerable time. Very fortunately, the iron work of the pirate brig had been saved after the explosion. From the planks and injured ribs Pencroft and Ayrton had extracted the bolts and a large quantity of copper nails. It was so much work saved for the smiths, but the carpenters had much to do.
children.prevalue: However with the fine days work had been continued The building of the vessel was hastened as much as possible and by means of the waterfall on the shore Cyrus Harding managed to establish an hydraulic sawmill which rapidly cut up the trunks of trees into planks and joists The mechanism of this apparatus was as simple as those used in the rustic sawmills of Norway A first horizontal movement to move the piece of wood a second vertical movement to move the saw this was all that was wanted and the engineer succeeded by means of a wheel two cylinders and pulleys properly arranged Towards the end of the month of September the skeleton of the vessel which was to be rigged as a schooner lay in the dockyard The ribs were almost entirely completed and all the timbers having been sustained by a provisional band the shape of the vessel could already be seen The schooner sharp in the bows very slender in the after part would evidently be suitable for a long voyage if wanted but laying the planking would still take a considerable time Very fortunately the iron work of the pirate brig had been saved after the explosion From the planks and injured ribs Pencroft and Ayrton had extracted the bolts and a large quantity of copper nails It was so much work saved for the smiths but the carpenters had much to do

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Shipbuilding was interrupted for a week for the harvest, the haymaking, and the gathering in of the different crops on the plateau. This work finished, every moment was devoted to finishing the schooner. When night came the workmen were really quite exhausted. So as not to lose any time they had changed the hours for their meals; they dined at twelve o'clock, and only had their supper when daylight failed them. They then ascended to Granite House, when they were always ready to go to bed.
children.prevalue: Shipbuilding was interrupted for a week for the harvest the haymaking and the gathering in of the different crops on the plateau This work finished every moment was devoted to finishing the schooner When night came the workmen were really quite exhausted So as not to lose any time they had changed the hours for their meals they dined at twelve o clock and only had their supper when daylight failed them They then ascended to Granite House when they were always ready to go to bed

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Sometimes, however, when the conversation bore on some interesting subject the hour for sleep was delayed for a time. The colonists then spoke of the future, and talked willingly of the changes which a voyage in the schooner to inhabited lands would make in their situation. But always, in the midst of these plans, prevailed the thought of a subsequent return to Lincoln Island. Never would they abandon this colony, founded with so much labor and with such success, and to which a communication with America would afford a fresh impetus. Pencroft and Neb especially hoped to end their days there.
children.prevalue: Sometimes however when the conversation bore on some interesting subject the hour for sleep was delayed for a time The colonists then spoke of the future and talked willingly of the changes which a voyage in the schooner to inhabited lands would make in their situation But always in the midst of these plans prevailed the thought of a subsequent return to Lincoln Island Never would they abandon this colony founded with so much labor and with such success and to which a communication with America would afford a fresh impetus Pencroft and Neb especially hoped to end their days there

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Herbert, said the sailor, you will never abandon Lincoln Island?
children.prevalue: Herbert said the sailor you will never abandon Lincoln Island

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Never, Pencroft, and especially if you make up your mind to stay there.
children.prevalue: Never Pencroft and especially if you make up your mind to stay there

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: That was made up long ago, my boy, answered Pencroft. I shall expect you. You will bring me your wife and children, and I shall make jolly chaps of your youngsters!
children.prevalue: That was made up long ago my boy answered Pencroft I shall expect you You will bring me your wife and children and I shall make jolly chaps of your youngsters

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That's agreed, replied Herbert, laughing and blushing at the same time.
children.prevalue: That s agreed replied Herbert laughing and blushing at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And you, Captain Harding, resumed Pencroft enthusiastically, you will be still the governor of the island! Ah, how many inhabitants could it support? Ten thousand at least!
children.prevalue: And you Captain Harding resumed Pencroft enthusiastically you will be still the governor of the island Ah how many inhabitants could it support Ten thousand at least

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: They talked in this way, allowing Pencroft to run on, and at last the reporter actually started a newspaper--the New Lincoln Herald!
children.prevalue: They talked in this way allowing Pencroft to run on and at last the reporter actually started a newspaper the New Lincoln Herald

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: So is man's heart. The desire to perform a work which will endure, which will survive him, is the origin of his superiority over all other living creatures here below. It is this which has established his dominion, and this it is which justifies it, over all the world.
children.prevalue: So is man s heart The desire to perform a work which will endure which will survive him is the origin of his superiority over all other living creatures here below It is this which has established his dominion and this it is which justifies it over all the world

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: After that, who knows if Jup and Top had not themselves their little dream of the future.
children.prevalue: After that who knows if Jup and Top had not themselves their little dream of the future

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ayrton silently said to himself that he would like to see Lord Glenarvan again and show himself to all restored.
children.prevalue: Ayrton silently said to himself that he would like to see Lord Glenarvan again and show himself to all restored

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: One evening, on the 15th of October, the conversation was prolonged later than usual. It was nine o'clock. Already, long badly concealed yawns gave warning of the hour of rest, and Pencroft was proceeding towards his bed, when the electric bell, placed in the dining-room, suddenly rang.
children.prevalue: One evening on the 15th of October the conversation was prolonged later than usual It was nine o clock Already long badly concealed yawns gave warning of the hour of rest and Pencroft was proceeding towards his bed when the electric bell placed in the dining room suddenly rang

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: All were there, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Ayrton, Pencroft, Neb. Therefore none of the colonists were at the corral.
children.prevalue: All were there Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett Herbert Ayrton Pencroft Neb Therefore none of the colonists were at the corral

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Cyrus Harding rose. His companions stared at each other, scarcely believing their ears.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding rose His companions stared at each other scarcely believing their ears

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What does that mean? cried Neb. Was it the devil who rang it?
children.prevalue: What does that mean cried Neb Was it the devil who rang it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No one answered.
children.prevalue: No one answered

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The weather is stormy, observed Herbert. Might not its influence of electricity--
children.prevalue: The weather is stormy observed Herbert Might not its influence of electricity

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Herbert did not finish his phrase. The engineer, towards whom all eyes were turned, shook his head negatively.
children.prevalue: Herbert did not finish his phrase The engineer towards whom all eyes were turned shook his head negatively

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: We must wait, said Gideon Spilett. If it is a signal, whoever it may be who has made it, he will renew it.
children.prevalue: We must wait said Gideon Spilett If it is a signal whoever it may be who has made it he will renew it

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But who do you think it is? cried Neb.
children.prevalue: But who do you think it is cried Neb

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Who? answered Pencroft, but he--
children.prevalue: Who answered Pencroft but he

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The sailor's sentence was cut short by a new tinkle of the bell.
children.prevalue: The sailor s sentence was cut short by a new tinkle of the bell

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Harding went to the apparatus, and sent this question to the corral:--
children.prevalue: Harding went to the apparatus and sent this question to the corral

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What do you want?
children.prevalue: What do you want

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: A few moments later the needle, moving on the alphabetic dial, gave this reply to the tenants of Granite House:--
children.prevalue: A few moments later the needle moving on the alphabetic dial gave this reply to the tenants of Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Come to the corral immediately.
children.prevalue: Come to the corral immediately

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: At last! exclaimed Harding.
children.prevalue: At last exclaimed Harding

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes! At last! The mystery was about to be unveiled. The colonists' fatigue had disappeared before the tremendous interest which was about to urge them to the corral, and all wish for rest had ceased. Without having uttered a word, in a few moments they had left Granite House, and were standing on the beach. Jup and Top alone were left behind. They could do without them.
children.prevalue: Yes At last The mystery was about to be unveiled The colonists fatigue had disappeared before the tremendous interest which was about to urge them to the corral and all wish for rest had ceased Without having uttered a word in a few moments they had left Granite House and were standing on the beach Jup and Top alone were left behind They could do without them

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The night was black. The new moon had disappeared at the same time as the sun. As Herbert had observed, great stormy clouds formed a lowering and heavy vault, preventing any star rays. A few lightning flashes, reflections from a distant storm, illuminated the horizon.
children.prevalue: The night was black The new moon had disappeared at the same time as the sun As Herbert had observed great stormy clouds formed a lowering and heavy vault preventing any star rays A few lightning flashes reflections from a distant storm illuminated the horizon

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: It was possible that a few hours later the thunder would roll over the island itself. The night was very threatening.
children.prevalue: It was possible that a few hours later the thunder would roll over the island itself The night was very threatening

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: But however deep the darkness was, it would not prevent them from finding the familiar road to the corral.
children.prevalue: But however deep the darkness was it would not prevent them from finding the familiar road to the corral

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: They ascended the left bank of the Mercy, reached the plateau, passed the bridge over Creek Glycerine, and advanced through the forest.
children.prevalue: They ascended the left bank of the Mercy reached the plateau passed the bridge over Creek Glycerine and advanced through the forest

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: They walked at a good pace, a prey to the liveliest emotions. There was no doubt but that they were now going to learn the long-searched-for answer to the enigma, the name of that mysterious being, so deeply concerned in their life, so generous in his influence, so powerful in his action! Must not this stranger have indeed mingled with their existence, have known the smallest details, have heard all that was said in Granite House, to have been able always to act in the very nick of time?
children.prevalue: They walked at a good pace a prey to the liveliest emotions There was no doubt but that they were now going to learn the long searched for answer to the enigma the name of that mysterious being so deeply concerned in their life so generous in his influence so powerful in his action Must not this stranger have indeed mingled with their existence have known the smallest details have heard all that was said in Granite House to have been able always to act in the very nick of time

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Every one, wrapped up in his own reflections, pressed forward. Under the arch of trees the darkness was such that even the edge of the road could not be seen. Not a sound in the forest. Both animals and birds, influenced by the heaviness of the atmosphere, remained motionless and silent. Not a breath disturbed the leaves. The footsteps of the colonists alone resounded on the hardened ground.
children.prevalue: Every one wrapped up in his own reflections pressed forward Under the arch of trees the darkness was such that even the edge of the road could not be seen Not a sound in the forest Both animals and birds influenced by the heaviness of the atmosphere remained motionless and silent Not a breath disturbed the leaves The footsteps of the colonists alone resounded on the hardened ground

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: During the first quarter of an hour the silence was only interrupted by this remark from Pencroft:--
children.prevalue: During the first quarter of an hour the silence was only interrupted by this remark from Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: We ought to have brought a torch.
children.prevalue: We ought to have brought a torch

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And by this reply from the engineer:--
children.prevalue: And by this reply from the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: We shall find one at the corral.
children.prevalue: We shall find one at the corral

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Harding and his companions had left Granite House at twelve minutes past nine. At forty-seven minutes past nine they had traversed three out of the five miles which separated the mouth of the Mercy from the corral.
children.prevalue: Harding and his companions had left Granite House at twelve minutes past nine At forty seven minutes past nine they had traversed three out of the five miles which separated the mouth of the Mercy from the corral

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: At that moment sheets of lightning spread over the island and illumined the dark trees. The flashes dazzled and almost blinded them. Evidently the storm would not be long in bursting forth.
children.prevalue: At that moment sheets of lightning spread over the island and illumined the dark trees The flashes dazzled and almost blinded them Evidently the storm would not be long in bursting forth

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The flashes gradually became brighter and more rapid. Distant thunder growled in the sky. The atmosphere was stifling.
children.prevalue: The flashes gradually became brighter and more rapid Distant thunder growled in the sky The atmosphere was stifling

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The colonists proceeded as if they were urged onwards by some irresistible force.
children.prevalue: The colonists proceeded as if they were urged onwards by some irresistible force

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: At ten o'clock a vivid flash showed them the palisade, and as they reached the gate the storm burst forth with tremendous fury.
children.prevalue: At ten o clock a vivid flash showed them the palisade and as they reached the gate the storm burst forth with tremendous fury

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: In a minute the corral was crossed, and Harding stood before the hut.
children.prevalue: In a minute the corral was crossed and Harding stood before the hut

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Probably the house was occupied by the stranger, since it was from thence that the telegram had been sent. However, no light shone through the window.
children.prevalue: Probably the house was occupied by the stranger since it was from thence that the telegram had been sent However no light shone through the window

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The engineer knocked at the door.
children.prevalue: The engineer knocked at the door

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: No answer.
children.prevalue: No answer

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Cyrus Harding opened the door, and the settlers entered the room, which was perfectly dark. A light was struck by Neb, and in a few moments the lantern was lighted and the light thrown into every corner of the room.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding opened the door and the settlers entered the room which was perfectly dark A light was struck by Neb and in a few moments the lantern was lighted and the light thrown into every corner of the room

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: There was no one there. Everything was in the state in which it had been left.
children.prevalue: There was no one there Everything was in the state in which it had been left

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Have we been deceived by an illusion? murmured Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Have we been deceived by an illusion murmured Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No! that was not possible! The telegram had clearly said,--
children.prevalue: No that was not possible The telegram had clearly said

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Come to the corral immediately.
children.prevalue: Come to the corral immediately

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: They approached the table specially devoted to the use of the wire. Everything was in order--the pile on the box containing it, as well as all the apparatus.
children.prevalue: They approached the table specially devoted to the use of the wire Everything was in order the pile on the box containing it as well as all the apparatus

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Who came here the last time? asked the engineer.
children.prevalue: Who came here the last time asked the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I did, captain, answered Ayrton.
children.prevalue: I did captain answered Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And that was--
children.prevalue: And that was

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Four days ago.
children.prevalue: Four days ago

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Ah! a note! cried Herbert, pointing to a paper lying on the table.
children.prevalue: Ah a note cried Herbert pointing to a paper lying on the table

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: On this paper were written these words in English:--
children.prevalue: On this paper were written these words in English

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Follow the new wire.
children.prevalue: Follow the new wire

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Forward! cried Harding, who understood that the despatch had not been sent from the corral, but from the mysterious retreat, communicating directly with Granite House by means of a supplementary wire joined to the old one.
children.prevalue: Forward cried Harding who understood that the despatch had not been sent from the corral but from the mysterious retreat communicating directly with Granite House by means of a supplementary wire joined to the old one

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Neb took the lighted lantern, and all left the corral. The storm then burst forth with tremendous violence. The interval between each lightning-flash and each thunder-clap diminished rapidly. The summit of the volcano, with its plume of vapor, could be seen by occasional flashes.
children.prevalue: Neb took the lighted lantern and all left the corral The storm then burst forth with tremendous violence The interval between each lightning flash and each thunder clap diminished rapidly The summit of the volcano with its plume of vapor could be seen by occasional flashes

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: There was no telegraphic communication in any part of the corral between the house and the palisade; but the engineer, running straight to the first post, saw by the light of a flash a new wire hanging from the isolator to the ground.
children.prevalue: There was no telegraphic communication in any part of the corral between the house and the palisade but the engineer running straight to the first post saw by the light of a flash a new wire hanging from the isolator to the ground

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: There it is! said he.
children.prevalue: There it is said he

children.name: Paragraph_71
