children.value: This wire lay along the ground, and was surrounded with an isolating substance like a submarine cable, so as to assure the free transmission of the current. It appeared to pass through the wood and the southern spurs of the mountain, and consequently it ran towards the west.
children.prevalue: This wire lay along the ground and was surrounded with an isolating substance like a submarine cable so as to assure the free transmission of the current It appeared to pass through the wood and the southern spurs of the mountain and consequently it ran towards the west

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Follow it! said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Follow it said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And the settlers immediately pressed forward, guided by the wire.
children.prevalue: And the settlers immediately pressed forward guided by the wire

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The thunder continued to roar with such violence that not a word could be heard. However, there was no occasion for speaking, but to get forward as fast as possible.
children.prevalue: The thunder continued to roar with such violence that not a word could be heard However there was no occasion for speaking but to get forward as fast as possible

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions then climbed the spur rising between the corral valley and that of Falls River, which they crossed at its narrowest part. The wire, sometimes stretched over the lower branches of the trees, sometimes lying on the ground, guided them surely. The engineer had supposed that the wire would perhaps stop at the bottom of the valley, and that the stranger's retreat would be there.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions then climbed the spur rising between the corral valley and that of Falls River which they crossed at its narrowest part The wire sometimes stretched over the lower branches of the trees sometimes lying on the ground guided them surely The engineer had supposed that the wire would perhaps stop at the bottom of the valley and that the stranger s retreat would be there

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Nothing of the sort. They were obliged to ascend the south-western spur, and re-descend on that arid plateau terminated by the strangely-wild basalt cliff. From time to time one of the colonists stooped down and felt for the wire with his hands; but there was now no doubt that the wire was running directly towards the sea. There, to a certainty, in the depths of those rocks, was the dwelling so long sought for in vain.
children.prevalue: Nothing of the sort They were obliged to ascend the south western spur and re descend on that arid plateau terminated by the strangely wild basalt cliff From time to time one of the colonists stooped down and felt for the wire with his hands but there was now no doubt that the wire was running directly towards the sea There to a certainty in the depths of those rocks was the dwelling so long sought for in vain

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The sky was literally on fire. Flash succeeded flash. Several struck the summit of the volcano in the midst of the thick smoke. It appeared there as if the mountain was vomiting flame. At a few minutes to eleven the colonists arrived on the high cliff overlooking the ocean to the west. The wind had risen. The surf roared 500 feet below.
children.prevalue: The sky was literally on fire Flash succeeded flash Several struck the summit of the volcano in the midst of the thick smoke It appeared there as if the mountain was vomiting flame At a few minutes to eleven the colonists arrived on the high cliff overlooking the ocean to the west The wind had risen The surf roared 500 feet below

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Harding calculated that they had gone a mile and a half from the corral.
children.prevalue: Harding calculated that they had gone a mile and a half from the corral

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: At this point the wire entered among the rocks, following the steep side of a narrow ravine. The settlers followed it at the risk of occasioning a fall of the slightly-balanced rocks, and being dashed into the sea. The descent was extremely perilous, but they did not think of the danger; they were no longer masters of themselves, and an irresistible attraction drew them towards this mysterious place as the magnet draws iron.
children.prevalue: At this point the wire entered among the rocks following the steep side of a narrow ravine The settlers followed it at the risk of occasioning a fall of the slightly balanced rocks and being dashed into the sea The descent was extremely perilous but they did not think of the danger they were no longer masters of themselves and an irresistible attraction drew them towards this mysterious place as the magnet draws iron

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Thus they almost unconsciously descended this ravine, which even in broad daylight would have been considered impracticable.
children.prevalue: Thus they almost unconsciously descended this ravine which even in broad daylight would have been considered impracticable

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The stones rolled and sparkled like fiery balls when they crossed through the gleams of light. Harding was first--Ayrton last. On they went, step by step. Now they slid over the slippery rock; then they struggled to their feet and scrambled on.
children.prevalue: The stones rolled and sparkled like fiery balls when they crossed through the gleams of light Harding was first Ayrton last On they went step by step Now they slid over the slippery rock then they struggled to their feet and scrambled on

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: At last the wire touched the rocks on the beach. The colonists had reached the bottom of the basalt cliff.
children.prevalue: At last the wire touched the rocks on the beach The colonists had reached the bottom of the basalt cliff

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: There appeared a narrow ridge, running horizontally and parallel with the sea. The settlers followed the wire along it. They had not gone a hundred paces when the ridge by a moderate incline sloped down to the level of the sea.
children.prevalue: There appeared a narrow ridge running horizontally and parallel with the sea The settlers followed the wire along it They had not gone a hundred paces when the ridge by a moderate incline sloped down to the level of the sea

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: The engineer seized the wire and found that it disappeared beneath the waves.
children.prevalue: The engineer seized the wire and found that it disappeared beneath the waves

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: His companions were stupefied.
children.prevalue: His companions were stupefied

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: A cry of disappointment, almost a cry of despair, escaped them! Must they then plunge beneath the water and seek there for some submarine cavern? In their excited state they would not have hesitated to do it.
children.prevalue: A cry of disappointment almost a cry of despair escaped them Must they then plunge beneath the water and seek there for some submarine cavern In their excited state they would not have hesitated to do it

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The engineer stopped them.
children.prevalue: The engineer stopped them

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: He led his companions to a hollow in the rocks, and there--
children.prevalue: He led his companions to a hollow in the rocks and there

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: We must wait, said he. The tide is high. At low water the way will be open.
children.prevalue: We must wait said he The tide is high At low water the way will be open

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: But what can make you think- asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: But what can make you think asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: He would not have called us if the means had been wanting to enable us to reach him!
children.prevalue: He would not have called us if the means had been wanting to enable us to reach him

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Cyrus Harding spoke in a tone of such thorough conviction that no objection was raised. His remark, besides, was logical. It was quite possible that an opening, practicable at low water, though hidden now by the high tide, opened at the foot of the cliff.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding spoke in a tone of such thorough conviction that no objection was raised His remark besides was logical It was quite possible that an opening practicable at low water though hidden now by the high tide opened at the foot of the cliff

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: There was some time to wait. The colonists remained silently crouching in a deep hollow. Rain now began to fall in torrents. The thunder was re-echoed among the rocks with a grand sonorousness.
children.prevalue: There was some time to wait The colonists remained silently crouching in a deep hollow Rain now began to fall in torrents The thunder was re echoed among the rocks with a grand sonorousness

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: The colonists' emotion was great. A thousand strange and extraordinary ideas crossed their brains, and they expected some grand and superhuman apparition, which alone could come up to the notion they had formed of the mysterious genius of the island.
children.prevalue: The colonists emotion was great A thousand strange and extraordinary ideas crossed their brains and they expected some grand and superhuman apparition which alone could come up to the notion they had formed of the mysterious genius of the island

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: At midnight, Harding carrying the lantern, descended to the beach to reconnoiter.
children.prevalue: At midnight Harding carrying the lantern descended to the beach to reconnoiter

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: The engineer was not mistaken. The beginning of an immense excavation could be seen under the water. There the wire, bending at a right angle, entered the yawning gulf.
children.prevalue: The engineer was not mistaken The beginning of an immense excavation could be seen under the water There the wire bending at a right angle entered the yawning gulf

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Cyrus Harding returned to his companions, and said simply,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding returned to his companions and said simply

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: In an hour the opening will be practicable.
children.prevalue: In an hour the opening will be practicable

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: It is there, then? said Pencroft.
children.prevalue: It is there then said Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Did you doubt it? returned Harding.
children.prevalue: Did you doubt it returned Harding

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: But this cavern must be filled with water to a certain height, observed Herbert.
children.prevalue: But this cavern must be filled with water to a certain height observed Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Either the cavern will be completely dry, replied Harding, and in that case we can traverse it on foot, or it will not be dry, and some means of transport will be put at our disposal.
children.prevalue: Either the cavern will be completely dry replied Harding and in that case we can traverse it on foot or it will not be dry and some means of transport will be put at our disposal

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: An hour passed. All climbed down through the rain to the level of the sea. There was now eight feet of the opening above the water. It was like the arch of a bridge, under which rushed the foaming water.
children.prevalue: An hour passed All climbed down through the rain to the level of the sea There was now eight feet of the opening above the water It was like the arch of a bridge under which rushed the foaming water

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Leaning forward, the engineer saw a black object floating on the water. He drew it towards him. It was a boat, moored to some interior projection of the cave. This boat was iron-plated. Two oars lay at the bottom.
children.prevalue: Leaning forward the engineer saw a black object floating on the water He drew it towards him It was a boat moored to some interior projection of the cave This boat was iron plated Two oars lay at the bottom

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Jump in! said Harding.
children.prevalue: Jump in said Harding

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: In a moment the settlers were in the boat. Neb and Ayrton took the oars, Pencroft the rudder. Cyrus Harding in the bows, with the lantern, lighted the way.
children.prevalue: In a moment the settlers were in the boat Neb and Ayrton took the oars Pencroft the rudder Cyrus Harding in the bows with the lantern lighted the way

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: The elliptical roof, under which the boat at first passed, suddenly rose; but the darkness was too deep, and the light of the lantern too slight, for either the extent, length, height, or depth of the cave to be ascertained. Solemn silence reigned in this basaltic cavern. Not a sound could penetrate into it, even the thunder peals could not pierce its thick sides.
children.prevalue: The elliptical roof under which the boat at first passed suddenly rose but the darkness was too deep and the light of the lantern too slight for either the extent length height or depth of the cave to be ascertained Solemn silence reigned in this basaltic cavern Not a sound could penetrate into it even the thunder peals could not pierce its thick sides

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Such immense caves exist in various parts of the world, natural crypts dating from the geological epoch of the globe. Some are filled by the sea; others contain entire lakes in their sides. Such is Fingal's Cave, in the island of Staffa, one of the Hebrides; such are the caves of Morgat, in the bay of Douarnenez, in Brittany, the caves of Bonifacio, in Corsica, those of Lyse-Fjord, in Norway; such are the immense Mammoth caverns in Kentucky, 500 feet in height, and more than twenty miles in length! In many parts of the globe, nature has excavated these caverns, and preserved them for the admiration of man.
children.prevalue: Such immense caves exist in various parts of the world natural crypts dating from the geological epoch of the globe Some are filled by the sea others contain entire lakes in their sides Such is Fingal s Cave in the island of Staffa one of the Hebrides such are the caves of Morgat in the bay of Douarnenez in Brittany the caves of Bonifacio in Corsica those of Lyse Fjord in Norway such are the immense Mammoth caverns in Kentucky 500 feet in height and more than twenty miles in length In many parts of the globe nature has excavated these caverns and preserved them for the admiration of man

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Did the cavern which the settlers were now exploring extend to the center of the island? For a quarter of an hour the boat had been advancing, making detours, indicated to Pencroft by the engineer in short sentences, when all at once,--
children.prevalue: Did the cavern which the settlers were now exploring extend to the center of the island For a quarter of an hour the boat had been advancing making detours indicated to Pencroft by the engineer in short sentences when all at once

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: More to the right! he commanded.
children.prevalue: More to the right he commanded

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: The boat, altering its course, came up alongside the right wall. The engineer wished to see if the wire still ran along the side.
children.prevalue: The boat altering its course came up alongside the right wall The engineer wished to see if the wire still ran along the side

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: The wire was there fastened to the rock.
children.prevalue: The wire was there fastened to the rock

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Forward! said Harding.
children.prevalue: Forward said Harding

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: And the two oars, plunging into the dark waters, urged the boat onwards.
children.prevalue: And the two oars plunging into the dark waters urged the boat onwards

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: On they went for another quarter of an hour, and a distance of half-a-mile must have been cleared from the mouth of the cave, when Harding's voice was again heard.
children.prevalue: On they went for another quarter of an hour and a distance of half a mile must have been cleared from the mouth of the cave when Harding s voice was again heard

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Stop! said he.
children.prevalue: Stop said he

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: The boat stopped, and the colonists perceived a bright light illuminating the vast cavern, so deeply excavated in the bowels of the island, of which nothing had ever led them to suspect the existence.
children.prevalue: The boat stopped and the colonists perceived a bright light illuminating the vast cavern so deeply excavated in the bowels of the island of which nothing had ever led them to suspect the existence

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: At a height of a hundred feet rose the vaulted roof, supported on basalt shafts. Irregular arches, strange moldings, appeared on the columns erected by nature in thousands from the first epochs of the formation of the globe. The basalt pillars, fitted one into the other, measured from forty to fifty feet in height, and the water, calm in spite of the tumult outside, washed their base. The brilliant focus of light, pointed out by the engineer, touched every point of rocks, and flooded the walls with light.
children.prevalue: At a height of a hundred feet rose the vaulted roof supported on basalt shafts Irregular arches strange moldings appeared on the columns erected by nature in thousands from the first epochs of the formation of the globe The basalt pillars fitted one into the other measured from forty to fifty feet in height and the water calm in spite of the tumult outside washed their base The brilliant focus of light pointed out by the engineer touched every point of rocks and flooded the walls with light

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: By reflection the water reproduced the brilliant sparkles, so that the boat appeared to be floating between two glittering zones. They could not be mistaken in the nature of the irradiation thrown from the glowing nucleus, whose clear rays were shattered by all the angles, all the projections of the cavern. This light proceeded from an electric source, and its white color betrayed its origin. It was the sun of this cave, and it filled it entirely.
children.prevalue: By reflection the water reproduced the brilliant sparkles so that the boat appeared to be floating between two glittering zones They could not be mistaken in the nature of the irradiation thrown from the glowing nucleus whose clear rays were shattered by all the angles all the projections of the cavern This light proceeded from an electric source and its white color betrayed its origin It was the sun of this cave and it filled it entirely

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: At a sign from Cyrus Harding the oars again plunged into the water, causing a regular shower of gems, and the boat was urged forward towards the light, which was now not more than half a cable's length distant.
children.prevalue: At a sign from Cyrus Harding the oars again plunged into the water causing a regular shower of gems and the boat was urged forward towards the light which was now not more than half a cable s length distant

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: At this place the breadth of the sheet of water measured nearly 350 feet, and beyond the dazzling center could be seen an enormous basaltic wall, blocking up any issue on that side. The cavern widened here considerably, the sea forming a little lake. But the roof, the side walls, the end cliff, all the prisms, all the peaks, were flooded with the electric fluid, so that the brilliancy belonged to them, and as if the light issued from them.
children.prevalue: At this place the breadth of the sheet of water measured nearly 350 feet and beyond the dazzling center could be seen an enormous basaltic wall blocking up any issue on that side The cavern widened here considerably the sea forming a little lake But the roof the side walls the end cliff all the prisms all the peaks were flooded with the electric fluid so that the brilliancy belonged to them and as if the light issued from them

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: In the center of the lake a long cigar-shaped object floated on the surface of the water, silent, motionless. The brilliancy which issued from it escaped from its sides as from two kilns heated to a white heat. This apparatus, similar in shape to an enormous whale, was about 250 feet long, and rose about ten or twelve above the water.
children.prevalue: In the center of the lake a long cigar shaped object floated on the surface of the water silent motionless The brilliancy which issued from it escaped from its sides as from two kilns heated to a white heat This apparatus similar in shape to an enormous whale was about 250 feet long and rose about ten or twelve above the water

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: The boat slowly approached it, Cyrus Harding stood up in the bows. He gazed, a prey to violent excitement. Then, all at once, seizing the reporter's arm,--
children.prevalue: The boat slowly approached it Cyrus Harding stood up in the bows He gazed a prey to violent excitement Then all at once seizing the reporter s arm

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: It is he! It can only be he! he cried, he!--
children.prevalue: It is he It can only be he he cried he

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Then, falling back on the seat, he murmured a name which Gideon Spilett alone could hear.
children.prevalue: Then falling back on the seat he murmured a name which Gideon Spilett alone could hear

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: The reporter evidently knew this name, for it had a wonderful effect upon him, and he answered in a hoarse voice,--
children.prevalue: The reporter evidently knew this name for it had a wonderful effect upon him and he answered in a hoarse voice

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: He! an outlawed man!
children.prevalue: He an outlawed man

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: He! said Harding.
children.prevalue: He said Harding

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: At the engineer's command the boat approached this singular floating apparatus. The boat touched the left side, from which escaped a ray of light through a thick glass.
children.prevalue: At the engineer s command the boat approached this singular floating apparatus The boat touched the left side from which escaped a ray of light through a thick glass

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Harding and his companions mounted on the platform. An open hatchway was there. All darted down the opening.
children.prevalue: Harding and his companions mounted on the platform An open hatchway was there All darted down the opening

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: At the bottom of the ladder was a deck, lighted by electricity. At the end of this deck was a door, which Harding opened.
children.prevalue: At the bottom of the ladder was a deck lighted by electricity At the end of this deck was a door which Harding opened

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: A richly-ornamented room, quickly traversed by the colonists, was joined to a library, over which a luminous ceiling shed a flood of light.
children.prevalue: A richly ornamented room quickly traversed by the colonists was joined to a library over which a luminous ceiling shed a flood of light

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: At the end of the library a large door, also shut, was opened by the engineer.
children.prevalue: At the end of the library a large door also shut was opened by the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: An immense saloon--a sort of museum, in which were heaped up, with all the treasures of the mineral world, works of art, marvels of industry--appeared before the eyes of the colonists, who almost thought themselves suddenly transported into a land of enchantment.
children.prevalue: An immense saloon a sort of museum in which were heaped up with all the treasures of the mineral world works of art marvels of industry appeared before the eyes of the colonists who almost thought themselves suddenly transported into a land of enchantment

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Stretched on a rich sofa they saw a man, who did not appear to notice their presence.
children.prevalue: Stretched on a rich sofa they saw a man who did not appear to notice their presence

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Then Harding raised his voice, and to the extreme surprise of his companions, he uttered these words,--
children.prevalue: Then Harding raised his voice and to the extreme surprise of his companions he uttered these words

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Captain Nemo, you asked for us! We are here.--
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo you asked for us We are here

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At these words the reclining figure rose, and the electric light fell upon his countenance; a magnificent head, the forehead high, the glance commanding, beard white, hair abundant and falling over the shoulders.
children.prevalue: At these words the reclining figure rose and the electric light fell upon his countenance a magnificent head the forehead high the glance commanding beard white hair abundant and falling over the shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: His hand rested upon the cushion of the divan from which he had just risen. He appeared perfectly calm. It was evident that his strength had been gradually undermined by illness, but his voice seemed yet powerful, as he said in English, and in a tone which evinced extreme surprise,--
children.prevalue: His hand rested upon the cushion of the divan from which he had just risen He appeared perfectly calm It was evident that his strength had been gradually undermined by illness but his voice seemed yet powerful as he said in English and in a tone which evinced extreme surprise

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Sir, I have no name.
children.prevalue: Sir I have no name

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Nevertheless, I know you! replied Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless I know you replied Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Captain Nemo fixed his penetrating gaze upon the engineer, as though he were about to annihilate him.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo fixed his penetrating gaze upon the engineer as though he were about to annihilate him

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Then, falling back amid the pillows of the divan,--
children.prevalue: Then falling back amid the pillows of the divan

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: After all, what matters now? he murmured; I am dying!
children.prevalue: After all what matters now he murmured I am dying

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Cyrus Harding drew near the captain, and Gideon Spilett took his hand--it was of a feverish heat. Ayrton, Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb stood respectfully apart in an angle of the magnificent saloon, whose atmosphere was saturated with the electric fluid.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding drew near the captain and Gideon Spilett took his hand it was of a feverish heat Ayrton Pencroft Herbert and Neb stood respectfully apart in an angle of the magnificent saloon whose atmosphere was saturated with the electric fluid

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Meanwhile Captain Nemo withdrew his hand, and motioned the engineer and the reporter to be seated.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile Captain Nemo withdrew his hand and motioned the engineer and the reporter to be seated

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: All regarded him with profound emotion. Before them they beheld that being whom they had styled the genius of the island, the powerful protector whose intervention, in so many circumstances, had been so efficacious, the benefactor to whom they owed such a debt of gratitude! Their eyes beheld a man only, and a man at the point of death, where Pencroft and Neb had expected to find an almost supernatural being!
children.prevalue: All regarded him with profound emotion Before them they beheld that being whom they had styled the genius of the island the powerful protector whose intervention in so many circumstances had been so efficacious the benefactor to whom they owed such a debt of gratitude Their eyes beheld a man only and a man at the point of death where Pencroft and Neb had expected to find an almost supernatural being

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But how happened it that Cyrus Harding had recognized Captain Nemo? why had the latter so suddenly risen on hearing this name uttered, a name which he had believed known to none?--
children.prevalue: But how happened it that Cyrus Harding had recognized Captain Nemo why had the latter so suddenly risen on hearing this name uttered a name which he had believed known to none

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The captain had resumed his position on the divan, and leaning on his arm, he regarded the engineer, seated near him.
children.prevalue: The captain had resumed his position on the divan and leaning on his arm he regarded the engineer seated near him

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You know the name I formerly bore, sir? he asked.
children.prevalue: You know the name I formerly bore sir he asked

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I do, answered Cyrus Harding, and also that of this wonderful submarine vessel--
children.prevalue: I do answered Cyrus Harding and also that of this wonderful submarine vessel

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The 'Nautilus'? said the captain, with a faint smile.
children.prevalue: The Nautilus said the captain with a faint smile

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The 'Nautilus.'
children.prevalue: The Nautilus

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But do you--do you know who I am?
children.prevalue: But do you do you know who I am

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I do.
children.prevalue: I do

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It is nevertheless many years since I have held any communication with the inhabited world; three long years have I passed in the depth of the sea, the only place where I have found liberty! Who then can have betrayed my secret?
children.prevalue: It is nevertheless many years since I have held any communication with the inhabited world three long years have I passed in the depth of the sea the only place where I have found liberty Who then can have betrayed my secret

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: A man who was bound to you by no tie, Captain Nemo, and who, consequently, cannot be accused of treachery.
children.prevalue: A man who was bound to you by no tie Captain Nemo and who consequently cannot be accused of treachery

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The Frenchman who was cast on board my vessel by chance sixteen years since?
children.prevalue: The Frenchman who was cast on board my vessel by chance sixteen years since

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The same.
children.prevalue: The same

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: He and his two companions did not then perish in the maelstrom, in the midst of which the 'Nautilus' was struggling?
children.prevalue: He and his two companions did not then perish in the maelstrom in the midst of which the Nautilus was struggling

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: They escaped, and a book has appeared under the title of 'Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,' which contains your history.
children.prevalue: They escaped and a book has appeared under the title of Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea which contains your history

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The history of a few months only of my life! interrupted the captain impetuously.
children.prevalue: The history of a few months only of my life interrupted the captain impetuously

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It is true, answered Cyrus Harding, but a few months of that strange life have sufficed to make you known.
children.prevalue: It is true answered Cyrus Harding but a few months of that strange life have sufficed to make you known

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: As a great criminal, doubtless! said Captain Nemo, a haughty smile curling his lips. Yes, a rebel, perhaps an outlaw against humanity!
children.prevalue: As a great criminal doubtless said Captain Nemo a haughty smile curling his lips Yes a rebel perhaps an outlaw against humanity

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The engineer was silent.
children.prevalue: The engineer was silent

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Well, sir?
children.prevalue: Well sir

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: It is not for me to judge you, Captain Nemo, answered Cyrus Harding, at any rate as regards your past life. I am, with the rest of the world, ignorant of the motives which induced you to adopt this strange mode of existence, and I cannot judge of effects without knowing their causes; but what I do know is, that a beneficent hand has constantly protected us since our arrival on Lincoln Island, that we all owe our lives to a good, generous, and powerful being, and that this being so powerful, good and generous, Captain Nemo, is yourself!
children.prevalue: It is not for me to judge you Captain Nemo answered Cyrus Harding at any rate as regards your past life I am with the rest of the world ignorant of the motives which induced you to adopt this strange mode of existence and I cannot judge of effects without knowing their causes but what I do know is that a beneficent hand has constantly protected us since our arrival on Lincoln Island that we all owe our lives to a good generous and powerful being and that this being so powerful good and generous Captain Nemo is yourself

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: It is I, answered the captain simply.
children.prevalue: It is I answered the captain simply

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The engineer and the reporter rose. Their companions had drawn near, and the gratitude with which their hearts were charged was about to express itself in their gestures and words.
children.prevalue: The engineer and the reporter rose Their companions had drawn near and the gratitude with which their hearts were charged was about to express itself in their gestures and words

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Captain Nemo stopped them by a sign, and in a voice which betrayed more emotion than he doubtless intended to show.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo stopped them by a sign and in a voice which betrayed more emotion than he doubtless intended to show

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Wait till you have heard all, he said.
children.prevalue: Wait till you have heard all he said

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And the captain, in a few concise sentences, ran over the events of his life.
children.prevalue: And the captain in a few concise sentences ran over the events of his life

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: His narrative was short, yet he was obliged to summon up his whole remaining energy to arrive at the end. He was evidently contending against extreme weakness. Several times Cyrus Harding entreated him to repose for a while, but he shook his head as a man to whom the morrow may never come, and when the reporter offered his assistance,--
children.prevalue: His narrative was short yet he was obliged to summon up his whole remaining energy to arrive at the end He was evidently contending against extreme weakness Several times Cyrus Harding entreated him to repose for a while but he shook his head as a man to whom the morrow may never come and when the reporter offered his assistance

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: It is useless, he said; my hours are numbered.
children.prevalue: It is useless he said my hours are numbered

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Captain Nemo was an Indian, the Prince Dakkar, son of a rajah of the then independent territory of Bundelkund. His father sent him, when ten years of age, to Europe, in order that he might receive an education in all respects complete, and in the hopes that by his talents and knowledge he might one day take a leading part in raising his long degraded and heathen country to a level with the nations of Europe.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo was an Indian the Prince Dakkar son of a rajah of the then independent territory of Bundelkund His father sent him when ten years of age to Europe in order that he might receive an education in all respects complete and in the hopes that by his talents and knowledge he might one day take a leading part in raising his long degraded and heathen country to a level with the nations of Europe

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: From the age of ten years to that of thirty Prince Dakkar, endowed by Nature with her richest gifts of intellect, accumulated knowledge of every kind, and in science, literature, and art his researches were extensive and profound.
children.prevalue: From the age of ten years to that of thirty Prince Dakkar endowed by Nature with her richest gifts of intellect accumulated knowledge of every kind and in science literature and art his researches were extensive and profound

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: He traveled over the whole of Europe. His rank and fortune caused him to be everywhere sought after; but the pleasures of the world had for him no attractions. Though young and possessed of every personal advantage, he was ever grave--somber even--devoured by an unquenchable thirst for knowledge, and cherishing in the recesses of his heart the hope that he might become a great and powerful ruler of a free and enlightened people.
children.prevalue: He traveled over the whole of Europe His rank and fortune caused him to be everywhere sought after but the pleasures of the world had for him no attractions Though young and possessed of every personal advantage he was ever grave somber even devoured by an unquenchable thirst for knowledge and cherishing in the recesses of his heart the hope that he might become a great and powerful ruler of a free and enlightened people

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Still, for long the love of science triumphed over all other feelings. He became an artist deeply impressed by the marvels of art, a philosopher to whom no one of the higher sciences was unknown, a statesman versed in the policy of European courts. To the eyes of those who observed him superficially he might have passed for one of those cosmopolitans, curious of knowledge, but disdaining action; one of those opulent travelers, haughty and cynical, who move incessantly from place to place, and are of no country.
children.prevalue: Still for long the love of science triumphed over all other feelings He became an artist deeply impressed by the marvels of art a philosopher to whom no one of the higher sciences was unknown a statesman versed in the policy of European courts To the eyes of those who observed him superficially he might have passed for one of those cosmopolitans curious of knowledge but disdaining action one of those opulent travelers haughty and cynical who move incessantly from place to place and are of no country

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The history of Captain Nemo has, in fact, been published under the title of Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea. Here, therefore, will apply the observation already made as to the adventures of Ayrton with regard to the discrepancy of dates. Readers should therefore refer to the note already published on this point.
children.prevalue: The history of Captain Nemo has in fact been published under the title of Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea Here therefore will apply the observation already made as to the adventures of Ayrton with regard to the discrepancy of dates Readers should therefore refer to the note already published on this point

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This artist, this philosopher, this man was, however, still cherishing the hope instilled into him from his earliest days.
children.prevalue: This artist this philosopher this man was however still cherishing the hope instilled into him from his earliest days

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Prince Dakkar returned to Bundelkund in the year 1849. He married a noble Indian lady, who was imbued with an ambition not less ardent than that by which he was inspired. Two children were born to them, whom they tenderly loved. But domestic happiness did not prevent him from seeking to carry out the object at which he aimed. He waited an opportunity. At length, as he vainly fancied, it presented itself.
children.prevalue: Prince Dakkar returned to Bundelkund in the year 1849 He married a noble Indian lady who was imbued with an ambition not less ardent than that by which he was inspired Two children were born to them whom they tenderly loved But domestic happiness did not prevent him from seeking to carry out the object at which he aimed He waited an opportunity At length as he vainly fancied it presented itself

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Instigated by princes equally ambitious and less sagacious and more unscrupulous than he was, the people of India were persuaded that they might successfully rise against their English rulers, who had brought them out of a state of anarchy and constant warfare and misery, and had established peace and prosperity in their country. Their ignorance and gross superstition made them the facile tools of their designing chiefs.
children.prevalue: Instigated by princes equally ambitious and less sagacious and more unscrupulous than he was the people of India were persuaded that they might successfully rise against their English rulers who had brought them out of a state of anarchy and constant warfare and misery and had established peace and prosperity in their country Their ignorance and gross superstition made them the facile tools of their designing chiefs

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: In 1857 the great sepoy revolt broke out. Prince Dakkar, under the belief that he should thereby have the opportunity of attaining the object of his long-cherished ambition, was easily drawn into it. He forthwith devoted his talents and wealth to the service of this cause. He aided it in person; he fought in the front ranks; he risked his life equally with the humblest of the wretched and misguided fanatics; he was ten times wounded in twenty engagements, seeking death but finding it not, but at length the sanguinary rebels were utterly defeated, and the atrocious mutiny was brought to an end.
children.prevalue: In 1857 the great sepoy revolt broke out Prince Dakkar under the belief that he should thereby have the opportunity of attaining the object of his long cherished ambition was easily drawn into it He forthwith devoted his talents and wealth to the service of this cause He aided it in person he fought in the front ranks he risked his life equally with the humblest of the wretched and misguided fanatics he was ten times wounded in twenty engagements seeking death but finding it not but at length the sanguinary rebels were utterly defeated and the atrocious mutiny was brought to an end

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Never before had the British power in India been exposed to such danger, and if, as they had hoped, the sepoys had received assistance from without, the influence and supremacy in Asia of the United Kingdom would have been a thing of the past.
children.prevalue: Never before had the British power in India been exposed to such danger and if as they had hoped the sepoys had received assistance from without the influence and supremacy in Asia of the United Kingdom would have been a thing of the past

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The name of Prince Dakkar was at that time well known. He had fought openly and without concealment. A price was set upon his head, but he managed to escape from his pursuers.
children.prevalue: The name of Prince Dakkar was at that time well known He had fought openly and without concealment A price was set upon his head but he managed to escape from his pursuers

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Civilization never recedes; the law of necessity ever forces it onwards. The sepoys were vanquished, and the land of the rajahs of old fell again under the rule of England.
children.prevalue: Civilization never recedes the law of necessity ever forces it onwards The sepoys were vanquished and the land of the rajahs of old fell again under the rule of England

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Prince Dakkar, unable to find that death he courted, returned to the mountain fastnesses of Bundelkund. There, alone in the world, overcome by disappointment at the destruction of all his vain hopes, a prey to profound disgust for all human beings, filled with hatred of the civilized world, he realized the wreck of his fortune, assembled some score of his most faithful companions, and one day disappeared, leaving no trace behind.
children.prevalue: Prince Dakkar unable to find that death he courted returned to the mountain fastnesses of Bundelkund There alone in the world overcome by disappointment at the destruction of all his vain hopes a prey to profound disgust for all human beings filled with hatred of the civilized world he realized the wreck of his fortune assembled some score of his most faithful companions and one day disappeared leaving no trace behind

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Where, then, did he seek that liberty denied him upon the inhabited earth? Under the waves, in the depths of the ocean, where none could follow.
children.prevalue: Where then did he seek that liberty denied him upon the inhabited earth Under the waves in the depths of the ocean where none could follow

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The warrior became the man of science. Upon a deserted island of the Pacific he established his dockyard, and there a submarine vessel was constructed from his designs. By methods which will at some future day be revealed he had rendered subservient the illimitable forces of electricity, which, extracted from inexhaustible sources, was employed for all the requirements of his floating equipage, as a moving, lighting, and heating agent. The sea, with its countless treasures, its myriads of fish, its numberless wrecks, its enormous mammalia, and not only all that nature supplied, but also all that man had lost in its depths, sufficed for every want of the prince and his crew--and thus was his most ardent desire accomplished, never again to hold communication with the earth. He named his submarine vessel the Nautilus, called himself simply Captain Nemo, and disappeared beneath the seas.
children.prevalue: The warrior became the man of science Upon a deserted island of the Pacific he established his dockyard and there a submarine vessel was constructed from his designs By methods which will at some future day be revealed he had rendered subservient the illimitable forces of electricity which extracted from inexhaustible sources was employed for all the requirements of his floating equipage as a moving lighting and heating agent The sea with its countless treasures its myriads of fish its numberless wrecks its enormous mammalia and not only all that nature supplied but also all that man had lost in its depths sufficed for every want of the prince and his crew and thus was his most ardent desire accomplished never again to hold communication with the earth He named his submarine vessel the Nautilus called himself simply Captain Nemo and disappeared beneath the seas

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: During many years this strange being visited every ocean, from pole to pole. Outcast of the inhabited earth in these unknown worlds he gathered incalculable treasures. The millions lost in the Bay of Vigo, in 1702, by the galleons of Spain, furnished him with a mine of inexhaustible riches which he devoted always, anonymously, in favor of those nations who fought for the independence of their country.
children.prevalue: During many years this strange being visited every ocean from pole to pole Outcast of the inhabited earth in these unknown worlds he gathered incalculable treasures The millions lost in the Bay of Vigo in 1702 by the galleons of Spain furnished him with a mine of inexhaustible riches which he devoted always anonymously in favor of those nations who fought for the independence of their country

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: (This refers to the resurrection of the Candiotes, who were, in    fact, largely assisted by Captain Nemo.)
children.prevalue: This refers to the resurrection of the Candiotes who were in fact largely assisted by Captain Nemo

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: For long, however, he had held no communication with his fellow-creatures, when, during the night of the 6th of November, 1866, three men were cast on board his vessel. They were a French professor, his servant, and a Canadian fisherman. These three men had been hurled overboard by a collision which had taken place between the Nautilus and the United States frigate Abraham Lincoln, which had chased her.
children.prevalue: For long however he had held no communication with his fellow creatures when during the night of the 6th of November 1866 three men were cast on board his vessel They were a French professor his servant and a Canadian fisherman These three men had been hurled overboard by a collision which had taken place between the Nautilus and the United States frigate Abraham Lincoln which had chased her

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Captain Nemo learned from this professor that the Nautilus, taken now for a gigantic mammal of the whale species, now for a submarine vessel carrying a crew of pirates, was sought for in every sea.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo learned from this professor that the Nautilus taken now for a gigantic mammal of the whale species now for a submarine vessel carrying a crew of pirates was sought for in every sea

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: He might have returned these three men to the ocean, from whence chance had brought them in contact with his mysterious existence. Instead of doing this he kept them prisoners, and during seven months they were enabled to behold all the wonders of a voyage of twenty thousand leagues under the sea.
children.prevalue: He might have returned these three men to the ocean from whence chance had brought them in contact with his mysterious existence Instead of doing this he kept them prisoners and during seven months they were enabled to behold all the wonders of a voyage of twenty thousand leagues under the sea

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: One day, the 22nd of June, 1867, these three men, who knew nothing of the past history of Captain Nemo, succeeded in escaping in one of the Nautilus's boats. But as at this time the Nautilus was drawn into the vortex of the maelstrom, off the coast of Norway, the captain naturally believed that the fugitives, engulfed in that frightful whirlpool, found their death at the bottom of the abyss. He was unaware that the Frenchman and his two companions had been miraculously cast on shore, that the fishermen of the Lofoten Islands had rendered them assistance, and that the professor, on his return to France, had published that work in which seven months of the strange and eventful navigation of the Nautilus were narrated and exposed to the curiosity of the public.
children.prevalue: One day the 22nd of June 1867 these three men who knew nothing of the past history of Captain Nemo succeeded in escaping in one of the Nautilus s boats But as at this time the Nautilus was drawn into the vortex of the maelstrom off the coast of Norway the captain naturally believed that the fugitives engulfed in that frightful whirlpool found their death at the bottom of the abyss He was unaware that the Frenchman and his two companions had been miraculously cast on shore that the fishermen of the Lofoten Islands had rendered them assistance and that the professor on his return to France had published that work in which seven months of the strange and eventful navigation of the Nautilus were narrated and exposed to the curiosity of the public

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: For a long time after this, Captain Nemo continued to live thus, traversing every sea. But one by one his companions died, and found their last resting-place in their cemetery of coral, in the bed of the Pacific. At last Captain Nemo remained the solitary survivor of all those who had taken refuge with him in the depths of the ocean.
children.prevalue: For a long time after this Captain Nemo continued to live thus traversing every sea But one by one his companions died and found their last resting place in their cemetery of coral in the bed of the Pacific At last Captain Nemo remained the solitary survivor of all those who had taken refuge with him in the depths of the ocean

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: He was now sixty years of age. Although alone, he succeeded in navigating the Nautilus towards one of those submarine caverns which had sometimes served him as a harbor.
children.prevalue: He was now sixty years of age Although alone he succeeded in navigating the Nautilus towards one of those submarine caverns which had sometimes served him as a harbor

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: One of these ports was hollowed beneath Lincoln Island, and at this moment furnished an asylum to the Nautilus.
children.prevalue: One of these ports was hollowed beneath Lincoln Island and at this moment furnished an asylum to the Nautilus

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The captain had now remained there six years, navigating the ocean no longer, but awaiting death, and that moment when he should rejoin his former companions, when by chance he observed the descent of the balloon which carried the prisoners of the Confederates. Clad in his diving dress he was walking beneath the water at a few cables' length from the shore of the island, when the engineer had been thrown into the sea. Moved by a feeling of compassion the captain saved Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: The captain had now remained there six years navigating the ocean no longer but awaiting death and that moment when he should rejoin his former companions when by chance he observed the descent of the balloon which carried the prisoners of the Confederates Clad in his diving dress he was walking beneath the water at a few cables length from the shore of the island when the engineer had been thrown into the sea Moved by a feeling of compassion the captain saved Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: His first impulse was to fly from the vicinity of the five castaways; but his harbor refuge was closed, for in consequence of an elevation of the basalt, produced by the influence of volcanic action, he could no longer pass through the entrance of the vault. Though there was sufficient depth of water to allow a light craft to pass the bar, there was not enough for the Nautilus, whose draught of water was considerable.
children.prevalue: His first impulse was to fly from the vicinity of the five castaways but his harbor refuge was closed for in consequence of an elevation of the basalt produced by the influence of volcanic action he could no longer pass through the entrance of the vault Though there was sufficient depth of water to allow a light craft to pass the bar there was not enough for the Nautilus whose draught of water was considerable

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Captain Nemo was compelled, therefore, to remain. He observed these men thrown without resources upon a desert island, but had no wish to be himself discovered by them. By degrees he became interested in their efforts when he saw them honest, energetic, and bound to each other by the ties of friendship. As if despite his wishes, he penetrated all the secrets of their existence. By means of the diving dress he could easily reach the well in the interior of Granite House, and climbing by the projections of rock to its upper orifice he heard the colonists as they recounted the past, and studied the present and future. He learned from them the tremendous conflict of America with America itself, for the abolition of slavery. Yes, these men were worthy to reconcile Captain Nemo with that humanity which they represented so nobly in the island.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo was compelled therefore to remain He observed these men thrown without resources upon a desert island but had no wish to be himself discovered by them By degrees he became interested in their efforts when he saw them honest energetic and bound to each other by the ties of friendship As if despite his wishes he penetrated all the secrets of their existence By means of the diving dress he could easily reach the well in the interior of Granite House and climbing by the projections of rock to its upper orifice he heard the colonists as they recounted the past and studied the present and future He learned from them the tremendous conflict of America with America itself for the abolition of slavery Yes these men were worthy to reconcile Captain Nemo with that humanity which they represented so nobly in the island

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Captain Nemo had saved Cyrus Harding. It was he also who had brought back the dog to the Chimneys, who rescued Top from the waters of the lake, who caused to fall at Flotsam Point the case containing so many things useful to the colonists, who conveyed the canoe back into the stream of the Mercy, who cast the cord from the top of Granite House at the time of the attack by the baboons, who made known the presence of Ayrton upon Tabor Island, by means of the document enclosed in the bottle, who caused the explosion of the brig by the shock of a torpedo placed at the bottom of the canal, who saved Herbert from certain death by bringing the sulphate of quinine; and finally, it was he who had killed the convicts with the electric balls, of which he possessed the secret, and which he employed in the chase of submarine creatures. Thus were explained so many apparently supernatural occurrences, and which all proved the generosity and power of the captain.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo had saved Cyrus Harding It was he also who had brought back the dog to the Chimneys who rescued Top from the waters of the lake who caused to fall at Flotsam Point the case containing so many things useful to the colonists who conveyed the canoe back into the stream of the Mercy who cast the cord from the top of Granite House at the time of the attack by the baboons who made known the presence of Ayrton upon Tabor Island by means of the document enclosed in the bottle who caused the explosion of the brig by the shock of a torpedo placed at the bottom of the canal who saved Herbert from certain death by bringing the sulphate of quinine and finally it was he who had killed the convicts with the electric balls of which he possessed the secret and which he employed in the chase of submarine creatures Thus were explained so many apparently supernatural occurrences and which all proved the generosity and power of the captain

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Nevertheless, this noble misanthrope longed to benefit his proteges still further. There yet remained much useful advice to give them, and, his heart being softened by the approach of death, he invited, as we are aware, the colonists of Granite House to visit the Nautilus, by means of a wire which connected it with the corral. Possibly he would not have done this had he been aware that Cyrus Harding was sufficiently acquainted with his history to address him by the name of Nemo.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless this noble misanthrope longed to benefit his proteges still further There yet remained much useful advice to give them and his heart being softened by the approach of death he invited as we are aware the colonists of Granite House to visit the Nautilus by means of a wire which connected it with the corral Possibly he would not have done this had he been aware that Cyrus Harding was sufficiently acquainted with his history to address him by the name of Nemo

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The captain concluded the narrative of his life. Cyrus Harding then spoke; he recalled all the incidents which had exercised so beneficent an influence upon the colony, and in the names of his companions and himself thanked the generous being to whom they owed so much.
children.prevalue: The captain concluded the narrative of his life Cyrus Harding then spoke he recalled all the incidents which had exercised so beneficent an influence upon the colony and in the names of his companions and himself thanked the generous being to whom they owed so much

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: But Captain Nemo paid little attention; his mind appeared to be absorbed by one idea, and without taking the proffered hand of the engineer,--
children.prevalue: But Captain Nemo paid little attention his mind appeared to be absorbed by one idea and without taking the proffered hand of the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Now, sir, said he, now that you know my history, your judgment!
children.prevalue: Now sir said he now that you know my history your judgment

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: In saying this, the captain evidently alluded to an important incident witnessed by the three strangers thrown on board his vessel, and which the French professor had related in his work, causing a profound and terrible sensation. Some days previous to the flight of the professor and his two companions, the Nautilus, being chased by a frigate in the north of the Atlantic had hurled herself as a ram upon this frigate, and sunk her without mercy.
children.prevalue: In saying this the captain evidently alluded to an important incident witnessed by the three strangers thrown on board his vessel and which the French professor had related in his work causing a profound and terrible sensation Some days previous to the flight of the professor and his two companions the Nautilus being chased by a frigate in the north of the Atlantic had hurled herself as a ram upon this frigate and sunk her without mercy

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Cyrus Harding understood the captain's allusion, and was silent.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding understood the captain s allusion and was silent

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: It was an enemy's frigate, exclaimed Captain Nemo, transformed for an instant into the Prince Dakkar, an enemy's frigate! It was she who attacked me--I was in a narrow and shallow bay--the frigate barred my way--and I sank her!
children.prevalue: It was an enemy s frigate exclaimed Captain Nemo transformed for an instant into the Prince Dakkar an enemy s frigate It was she who attacked me I was in a narrow and shallow bay the frigate barred my way and I sank her

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A few moments of silence ensued; then the captain demanded,--
children.prevalue: A few moments of silence ensued then the captain demanded

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: What think you of my life, gentlemen?
children.prevalue: What think you of my life gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Cyrus Harding extended his hand to the ci-devant prince and replied gravely, Sir, your error was in supposing that the past can be resuscitated, and in contending against inevitable progress. It is one of those errors which some admire, others blame; which God alone can judge. He who is mistaken in an action which he sincerely believes to be right may be an enemy, but retains our esteem. Your error is one that we may admire, and your name has nothing to fear from the judgment of history, which does not condemn heroic folly, but its results.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding extended his hand to the ci devant prince and replied gravely Sir your error was in supposing that the past can be resuscitated and in contending against inevitable progress It is one of those errors which some admire others blame which God alone can judge He who is mistaken in an action which he sincerely believes to be right may be an enemy but retains our esteem Your error is one that we may admire and your name has nothing to fear from the judgment of history which does not condemn heroic folly but its results

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The old man's breast swelled with emotion, and raising his hand to heaven,--
children.prevalue: The old man s breast swelled with emotion and raising his hand to heaven

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Was I wrong, or in the right? he murmured.
children.prevalue: Was I wrong or in the right he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Cyrus Harding replied, All great actions return to God, from whom they are derived. Captain Nemo, we, whom you have succored, shall ever mourn your loss.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding replied All great actions return to God from whom they are derived Captain Nemo we whom you have succored shall ever mourn your loss

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Herbert, who had drawn near the captain, fell on his knees and kissed his hand.
children.prevalue: Herbert who had drawn near the captain fell on his knees and kissed his hand

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: A tear glistened in the eyes of the dying man. My child, he said, may God bless you!
children.prevalue: A tear glistened in the eyes of the dying man My child he said may God bless you

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Day had returned. No ray of light penetrated into the profundity of the cavern. It being high-water, the entrance was closed by the sea. But the artificial light, which escaped in long streams from the skylights of the Nautilus was as vivid as before, and the sheet of water shone around the floating vessel.
children.prevalue: Day had returned No ray of light penetrated into the profundity of the cavern It being high water the entrance was closed by the sea But the artificial light which escaped in long streams from the skylights of the Nautilus was as vivid as before and the sheet of water shone around the floating vessel

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: An extreme exhaustion now overcame Captain Nemo, who had fallen back upon the divan. It was useless to contemplate removing him to Granite House, for he had expressed his wish to remain in the midst of those marvels of the Nautilus which millions could not have purchased, and to wait there for that death which was swiftly approaching.
children.prevalue: An extreme exhaustion now overcame Captain Nemo who had fallen back upon the divan It was useless to contemplate removing him to Granite House for he had expressed his wish to remain in the midst of those marvels of the Nautilus which millions could not have purchased and to wait there for that death which was swiftly approaching

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: During a long interval of prostration, which rendered him almost unconscious, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett attentively observed the condition of the dying man. It was apparent that his strength was gradually diminishing. That frame, once so robust, was now but the fragile tenement of a departing soul. All of life was concentrated in the heart and head.
children.prevalue: During a long interval of prostration which rendered him almost unconscious Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett attentively observed the condition of the dying man It was apparent that his strength was gradually diminishing That frame once so robust was now but the fragile tenement of a departing soul All of life was concentrated in the heart and head

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The engineer and reporter consulted in whispers. Was it possible to render any aid to the dying man? Might his life, if not saved, be prolonged for some days? He himself had said that no remedy could avail, and he awaited with tranquillity that death which had for him no terrors.
children.prevalue: The engineer and reporter consulted in whispers Was it possible to render any aid to the dying man Might his life if not saved be prolonged for some days He himself had said that no remedy could avail and he awaited with tranquillity that death which had for him no terrors

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: We can do nothing, said Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: We can do nothing said Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But of what is he dying? asked Pencroft.
children.prevalue: But of what is he dying asked Pencroft

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Life is simply fading out, replied the reporter.
children.prevalue: Life is simply fading out replied the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Nevertheless, said the sailor, if we move him into the open air, and the light of the sun, he might perhaps recover.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless said the sailor if we move him into the open air and the light of the sun he might perhaps recover

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No, Pencroft, answered the engineer, it is useless to attempt it. Besides, Captain Nemo would never consent to leave his vessel. He has lived for a dozen years on board the 'Nautilus,' and on board the 'Nautilus' he desires to die.
children.prevalue: No Pencroft answered the engineer it is useless to attempt it Besides Captain Nemo would never consent to leave his vessel He has lived for a dozen years on board the Nautilus and on board the Nautilus he desires to die

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Without doubt Captain Nemo heard Cyrus Harding's reply, for he raised himself slightly, and in a voice more feeble, but always intelligible,--
children.prevalue: Without doubt Captain Nemo heard Cyrus Harding s reply for he raised himself slightly and in a voice more feeble but always intelligible

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You are right, sir, he said. I shall die here--it is my wish; and therefore I have a request to make of you.
children.prevalue: You are right sir he said I shall die here it is my wish and therefore I have a request to make of you

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions had drawn near the divan, and now arranged the cushions in such a manner as to better support the dying man.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions had drawn near the divan and now arranged the cushions in such a manner as to better support the dying man

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: They saw his eyes wander over all the marvels of this saloon, lighted by the electric rays which fell from the arabesques of the luminous ceiling. He surveyed, one after the other, the pictures hanging from the splendid tapestries of the partitions, the chef-d'oeuvres of the Italian, Flemish, French, and Spanish masters; the statues of marble and bronze on their pedestals; the magnificent organ, leaning against the after-partition; the aquarium, in which bloomed the most wonderful productions of the sea--marine plants, zoophytes, chaplets of pearls of inestimable value; and, finally, his eyes rested on this device, inscribed over the pediment of the museum--the motto of the Nautilus--
children.prevalue: They saw his eyes wander over all the marvels of this saloon lighted by the electric rays which fell from the arabesques of the luminous ceiling He surveyed one after the other the pictures hanging from the splendid tapestries of the partitions the chef d oeuvres of the Italian Flemish French and Spanish masters the statues of marble and bronze on their pedestals the magnificent organ leaning against the after partition the aquarium in which bloomed the most wonderful productions of the sea marine plants zoophytes chaplets of pearls of inestimable value and finally his eyes rested on this device inscribed over the pediment of the museum the motto of the Nautilus

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Mobilis in mobile.
children.prevalue: Mobilis in mobile

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: His glance seemed to rest fondly for the last time on these masterpieces of art and of nature, to which he had limited his horizon during a sojourn of so many years in the abysses of the seas.
children.prevalue: His glance seemed to rest fondly for the last time on these masterpieces of art and of nature to which he had limited his horizon during a sojourn of so many years in the abysses of the seas

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Cyrus Harding respected the captain's silence, and waited till he should speak.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding respected the captain s silence and waited till he should speak

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: After some minutes, during which, doubtless, he passed in review his whole life, Captain Nemo turned to the colonists and said,
children.prevalue: After some minutes during which doubtless he passed in review his whole life Captain Nemo turned to the colonists and said

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You consider yourselves, gentlemen, under some obligations to me?
children.prevalue: You consider yourselves gentlemen under some obligations to me

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Captain, believe us that we would give our lives to prolong yours.
children.prevalue: Captain believe us that we would give our lives to prolong yours

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Promise, then, continued Captain Nemo, to carry out my last wishes, and I shall be repaid for all I have done for you.
children.prevalue: Promise then continued Captain Nemo to carry out my last wishes and I shall be repaid for all I have done for you

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We promise, said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: We promise said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And by this promise he bound both himself and his companions.
children.prevalue: And by this promise he bound both himself and his companions

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Gentlemen, resumed the captain, to-morrow I shall be dead.
children.prevalue: Gentlemen resumed the captain to morrow I shall be dead

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Herbert was about to utter an exclamation, but a sign from the captain arrested him.
children.prevalue: Herbert was about to utter an exclamation but a sign from the captain arrested him

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: To-morrow I shall die, and I desire no other tomb than the 'Nautilus.' It is my grave! All my friends repose in the depths of the ocean; their resting-place shall be mine.
children.prevalue: To morrow I shall die and I desire no other tomb than the Nautilus It is my grave All my friends repose in the depths of the ocean their resting place shall be mine

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: These words were received with profound silence.
children.prevalue: These words were received with profound silence

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Pay attention to my wishes, he continued. The 'Nautilus' is imprisoned in this grotto, the entrance of which is blocked up; but, although egress is impossible, the vessel may at least sink in the abyss, and there bury my remains.
children.prevalue: Pay attention to my wishes he continued The Nautilus is imprisoned in this grotto the entrance of which is blocked up but although egress is impossible the vessel may at least sink in the abyss and there bury my remains

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The colonists listened reverently to the words of the dying man.
children.prevalue: The colonists listened reverently to the words of the dying man

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: To-morrow, after my death, Mr. Harding, continued the captain, yourself and companions will leave the 'Nautilus,' for all the treasures it contains must perish with me. One token alone will remain with you of Prince Dakkar, with whose history you are now acquainted. That coffer yonder contains diamonds of the value of many millions, most of them mementoes of the time when, husband and father, I thought happiness possible for me, and a collection of pearls gathered by my friends and myself in the depths of the ocean. Of this treasure at a future day, you may make good use. In the hands of such men as yourself and your comrades, Captain Harding, money will never be a source of danger. From on high I shall still participate in your enterprises, and I fear not but that they will prosper.
children.prevalue: To morrow after my death Mr Harding continued the captain yourself and companions will leave the Nautilus for all the treasures it contains must perish with me One token alone will remain with you of Prince Dakkar with whose history you are now acquainted That coffer yonder contains diamonds of the value of many millions most of them mementoes of the time when husband and father I thought happiness possible for me and a collection of pearls gathered by my friends and myself in the depths of the ocean Of this treasure at a future day you may make good use In the hands of such men as yourself and your comrades Captain Harding money will never be a source of danger From on high I shall still participate in your enterprises and I fear not but that they will prosper

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: After a few moments' repose, necessitated by his extreme weakness, Captain Nemo continued,--
children.prevalue: After a few moments repose necessitated by his extreme weakness Captain Nemo continued

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: To-morrow you will take the coffer, you will leave the saloon, of which you will close the door; then you will ascend on to the deck of the 'Nautilus,' and you will lower the mainhatch so as entirely to close the vessel.
children.prevalue: To morrow you will take the coffer you will leave the saloon of which you will close the door then you will ascend on to the deck of the Nautilus and you will lower the mainhatch so as entirely to close the vessel

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: It shall be done, captain, answered Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: It shall be done captain answered Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Good.
