You will then embark in the canoe which brought you hither; but, before leaving the 'Nautilus,' go to the stern and there open two large stop-cocks which you will find upon the water-line. The water will penetrate into the reservoirs, and the 'Nautilus' will gradually sink beneath the water to repose at the bottom of the abyss.
children.prevalue: Good You will then embark in the canoe which brought you hither but before leaving the Nautilus go to the stern and there open two large stop cocks which you will find upon the water line The water will penetrate into the reservoirs and the Nautilus will gradually sink beneath the water to repose at the bottom of the abyss

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And comprehending a gesture of Cyrus Harding, the captain added,--
children.prevalue: And comprehending a gesture of Cyrus Harding the captain added

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Fear nothing! You will but bury a corpse!
children.prevalue: Fear nothing You will but bury a corpse

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions ventured to offer any observation to Captain Nemo. He had expressed his last wishes, and they had nothing to do but to conform to them.
children.prevalue: Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions ventured to offer any observation to Captain Nemo He had expressed his last wishes and they had nothing to do but to conform to them

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I have your promise, gentlemen? added Captain Nemo.
children.prevalue: I have your promise gentlemen added Captain Nemo

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: You have, captain, replied the engineer.
children.prevalue: You have captain replied the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The captain thanked the colonists by a sign, and requested them to leave him for some hours. Gideon Spilett wished to remain near him, in the event of a crisis coming on, but the dying man refused, saying, I shall live until to-morrow, sir.
children.prevalue: The captain thanked the colonists by a sign and requested them to leave him for some hours Gideon Spilett wished to remain near him in the event of a crisis coming on but the dying man refused saying I shall live until to morrow sir

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: All left the saloon, passed through the library and the dining-room, and arrived forward, in the machine-room where the electrical apparatus was established, which supplied not only heat and light, but the mechanical power of the Nautilus.
children.prevalue: All left the saloon passed through the library and the dining room and arrived forward in the machine room where the electrical apparatus was established which supplied not only heat and light but the mechanical power of the Nautilus

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The Nautilus was a masterpiece containing masterpieces within itself, and the engineer was struck with astonishment.
children.prevalue: The Nautilus was a masterpiece containing masterpieces within itself and the engineer was struck with astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The colonists mounted the platform, which rose seven or eight feet above the water. There they beheld a thick glass lenticular covering, which protected a kind of large eye, from which flashed forth light. Behind this eye was apparently a cabin containing the wheels of the rudder, and in which was stationed the helmsman, when he navigated the Nautilus over the bed of the ocean, which the electric rays would evidently light up to a considerable distance.
children.prevalue: The colonists mounted the platform which rose seven or eight feet above the water There they beheld a thick glass lenticular covering which protected a kind of large eye from which flashed forth light Behind this eye was apparently a cabin containing the wheels of the rudder and in which was stationed the helmsman when he navigated the Nautilus over the bed of the ocean which the electric rays would evidently light up to a considerable distance

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions remained for a time silent, for they were vividly impressed by what they had just seen and heard, and their hearts were deeply touched by the thought that he whose arm had so often aided them, the protector whom they had known but a few hours, was at the point of death.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions remained for a time silent for they were vividly impressed by what they had just seen and heard and their hearts were deeply touched by the thought that he whose arm had so often aided them the protector whom they had known but a few hours was at the point of death

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Whatever might be the judgment pronounced by posterity upon the events of this, so to speak, extra-human existence, the character of Prince Dakkar would ever remain as one of those whose memory time can never efface.
children.prevalue: Whatever might be the judgment pronounced by posterity upon the events of this so to speak extra human existence the character of Prince Dakkar would ever remain as one of those whose memory time can never efface

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: What a man! said Pencroft. Is it possible that he can have lived at the bottom of the sea? And it seems to me that perhaps he has not found peace there any more than elsewhere!
children.prevalue: What a man said Pencroft Is it possible that he can have lived at the bottom of the sea And it seems to me that perhaps he has not found peace there any more than elsewhere

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The 'Nautilus,' observed Ayrton, might have enabled us to leave Lincoln Island and reach some inhabited country.
children.prevalue: The Nautilus observed Ayrton might have enabled us to leave Lincoln Island and reach some inhabited country

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Good Heavens! exclaimed Pencroft, I for one would never risk myself in such a craft. To sail on the seas, good, but under the seas, never!
children.prevalue: Good Heavens exclaimed Pencroft I for one would never risk myself in such a craft To sail on the seas good but under the seas never

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I believe, Pencroft, answered the reporter, that the navigation of a submarine vessel such as the 'Nautilus' ought to be very easy, and that we should soon become accustomed to it. There would be no storms, no lee-shore to fear. At some feet beneath the surface the waters of the ocean are as calm as those of a lake.
children.prevalue: I believe Pencroft answered the reporter that the navigation of a submarine vessel such as the Nautilus ought to be very easy and that we should soon become accustomed to it There would be no storms no lee shore to fear At some feet beneath the surface the waters of the ocean are as calm as those of a lake

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: That may be, replied the sailor, but I prefer a gale of wind on board a well-found craft. A vessel is built to sail on the sea, and not beneath it.
children.prevalue: That may be replied the sailor but I prefer a gale of wind on board a well found craft A vessel is built to sail on the sea and not beneath it

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: My friends, said the engineer, it is useless, at any rate as regards the 'Nautilus,' to discuss the question of submarine vessels. The 'Nautilus' is not ours, and we have not the right to dispose of it. Moreover, we could in no case avail ourselves of it. Independently of the fact that it would be impossible to get it out of this cavern, whose entrance is now closed by the uprising of the basaltic rocks, Captain Nemo's wish is that it shall be buried with him. His wish is our law, and we will fulfil it.
children.prevalue: My friends said the engineer it is useless at any rate as regards the Nautilus to discuss the question of submarine vessels The Nautilus is not ours and we have not the right to dispose of it Moreover we could in no case avail ourselves of it Independently of the fact that it would be impossible to get it out of this cavern whose entrance is now closed by the uprising of the basaltic rocks Captain Nemo s wish is that it shall be buried with him His wish is our law and we will fulfil it

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: After a somewhat prolonged conversation, Cyrus Harding and his companions again descended to the interior of the Nautilus. There they took some refreshment and returned to the saloon.
children.prevalue: After a somewhat prolonged conversation Cyrus Harding and his companions again descended to the interior of the Nautilus There they took some refreshment and returned to the saloon

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Captain Nemo had somewhat rallied from the prostration which had overcome him, and his eyes shone with their wonted fire. A faint smile even curled his lips.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo had somewhat rallied from the prostration which had overcome him and his eyes shone with their wonted fire A faint smile even curled his lips

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The colonists drew around him.
children.prevalue: The colonists drew around him

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Gentlemen, said the captain, you are brave and honest men. You have devoted yourselves to the common weal. Often have I observed your conduct. I have esteemed you--I esteem you still! Your hand, Mr. Harding.
children.prevalue: Gentlemen said the captain you are brave and honest men You have devoted yourselves to the common weal Often have I observed your conduct I have esteemed you I esteem you still Your hand Mr Harding

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Cyrus Harding gave his hand to the captain, who clasped it affectionately.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding gave his hand to the captain who clasped it affectionately

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: It is well! he murmured.
children.prevalue: It is well he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: He resumed,--
children.prevalue: He resumed

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: But enough of myself. I have to speak concerning yourselves, and this Lincoln Island, upon which you have taken refuge. You now desire to leave it?
children.prevalue: But enough of myself I have to speak concerning yourselves and this Lincoln Island upon which you have taken refuge You now desire to leave it

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: To return, captain! answered Pencroft quickly.
children.prevalue: To return captain answered Pencroft quickly

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: To return, Pencroft? said the captain, with a smile. I know, it is true, your love for this island. You have helped to make it what it now is, and it seems to you a paradise!
children.prevalue: To return Pencroft said the captain with a smile I know it is true your love for this island You have helped to make it what it now is and it seems to you a paradise

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Our project, captain, interposed Cyrus Harding, is to annex it to the United States, and to establish for our shipping a port so fortunately situated in this part of the Pacific.
children.prevalue: Our project captain interposed Cyrus Harding is to annex it to the United States and to establish for our shipping a port so fortunately situated in this part of the Pacific

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Your thoughts are with your country, gentlemen, continued the captain; your toils are for her prosperity and glory. You are right. One's native land!--there should one live! there die! And I die far from all I loved!
children.prevalue: Your thoughts are with your country gentlemen continued the captain your toils are for her prosperity and glory You are right One s native land there should one live there die And I die far from all I loved

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You have some last wish to transmit, said the engineer with emotion, some souvenir to send to those friends you have left in the mountains of India?
children.prevalue: You have some last wish to transmit said the engineer with emotion some souvenir to send to those friends you have left in the mountains of India

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: No, Captain Harding; no friends remain to me! I am the last of my race, and to all whom I have known I have long been as are the dead.--But to return to yourselves. Solitude, isolation, are painful things, and beyond human endurance. I die of having thought it possible to live alone! You should, therefore, dare all in the attempt to leave Lincoln Island, and see once more the land of your birth. I am aware that those wretches have destroyed the vessel you have built.
children.prevalue: No Captain Harding no friends remain to me I am the last of my race and to all whom I have known I have long been as are the dead But to return to yourselves Solitude isolation are painful things and beyond human endurance I die of having thought it possible to live alone You should therefore dare all in the attempt to leave Lincoln Island and see once more the land of your birth I am aware that those wretches have destroyed the vessel you have built

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: We propose to construct a vessel, said Gideon Spilett, sufficiently large to convey us to the nearest land; but if we should succeed, sooner or later we shall return to Lincoln Island. We are attached to it by too many recollections ever to forget it.
children.prevalue: We propose to construct a vessel said Gideon Spilett sufficiently large to convey us to the nearest land but if we should succeed sooner or later we shall return to Lincoln Island We are attached to it by too many recollections ever to forget it

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: It is here that we have known Captain Nemo, said Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: It is here that we have known Captain Nemo said Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: It is here only that we can make our home! added Herbert.
children.prevalue: It is here only that we can make our home added Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: And here shall I sleep the sleep of eternity, if-- replied the captain.
children.prevalue: And here shall I sleep the sleep of eternity if replied the captain

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: He paused for a moment, and, instead of completing the sentence, said simply,--
children.prevalue: He paused for a moment and instead of completing the sentence said simply

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Mr. Harding, I wish to speak with you--alone!
children.prevalue: Mr Harding I wish to speak with you alone

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The engineer's companions, respecting the wish, retired.
children.prevalue: The engineer s companions respecting the wish retired

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Cyrus Harding remained but a few minutes alone with Captain Nemo, and soon recalled his companions; but he said nothing to them of the private matters which the dying man had confided to him.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding remained but a few minutes alone with Captain Nemo and soon recalled his companions but he said nothing to them of the private matters which the dying man had confided to him

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Gideon Spilett now watched the captain with extreme care. It was evident that he was no longer sustained by his moral energy, which had lost the power of reaction against his physical weakness.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett now watched the captain with extreme care It was evident that he was no longer sustained by his moral energy which had lost the power of reaction against his physical weakness

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The day closed without change. The colonists did not quit the Nautilus for a moment. Night arrived, although it was impossible to distinguish it from day in the cavern.
children.prevalue: The day closed without change The colonists did not quit the Nautilus for a moment Night arrived although it was impossible to distinguish it from day in the cavern

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Captain Nemo suffered no pain, but he was visibly sinking. His noble features, paled by the approach of death, were perfectly calm. Inaudible words escaped at intervals from his lips, bearing upon various incidents of his checkered career. Life was evidently ebbing slowly and his extremities were already cold.
children.prevalue: Captain Nemo suffered no pain but he was visibly sinking His noble features paled by the approach of death were perfectly calm Inaudible words escaped at intervals from his lips bearing upon various incidents of his checkered career Life was evidently ebbing slowly and his extremities were already cold

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Once or twice more he spoke to the colonists who stood around him, and smiled on them with that last smile which continues after death.
children.prevalue: Once or twice more he spoke to the colonists who stood around him and smiled on them with that last smile which continues after death

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: At length, shortly after midnight, Captain Nemo by a supreme effort succeeded in folding his arms across his breast, as if wishing in that attitude to compose himself for death.
children.prevalue: At length shortly after midnight Captain Nemo by a supreme effort succeeded in folding his arms across his breast as if wishing in that attitude to compose himself for death

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: By one o'clock his glance alone showed signs of life. A dying light gleamed in those eyes once so brilliant. Then, murmuring the words, God and my country! he quietly expired.
children.prevalue: By one o clock his glance alone showed signs of life A dying light gleamed in those eyes once so brilliant Then murmuring the words God and my country he quietly expired

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Cyrus Harding, bending low closed the eyes of him who had once been the Prince Dakkar, and was now not even Captain Nemo.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding bending low closed the eyes of him who had once been the Prince Dakkar and was now not even Captain Nemo

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Herbert and Pencroft sobbed aloud. Tears fell from Ayrton's eyes. Neb was on his knees by the reporter's side, motionless as a statue.
children.prevalue: Herbert and Pencroft sobbed aloud Tears fell from Ayrton s eyes Neb was on his knees by the reporter s side motionless as a statue

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Then Cyrus Harding, extending his hand over the forehead of the dead, said solemnly, May his soul be with God! Turning to his friends, he added, Let us pray for him whom we have lost!
children.prevalue: Then Cyrus Harding extending his hand over the forehead of the dead said solemnly May his soul be with God Turning to his friends he added Let us pray for him whom we have lost

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Some hours later the colonists fulfilled the promise made to the captain by carrying out his dying wishes.
children.prevalue: Some hours later the colonists fulfilled the promise made to the captain by carrying out his dying wishes

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions quitted the Nautilus, taking with them the only memento left them by their benefactor, the coffer which contained wealth amounting to millions.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions quitted the Nautilus taking with them the only memento left them by their benefactor the coffer which contained wealth amounting to millions

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: The marvelous saloon, still flooded with light, had been carefully closed. The iron door leading on deck was then securely fastened in such a manner as to prevent even a drop of water from penetrating to the interior of the Nautilus.
children.prevalue: The marvelous saloon still flooded with light had been carefully closed The iron door leading on deck was then securely fastened in such a manner as to prevent even a drop of water from penetrating to the interior of the Nautilus

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The colonists then descended into the canoe, which was moored to the side of the submarine vessel.
children.prevalue: The colonists then descended into the canoe which was moored to the side of the submarine vessel

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The canoe was now brought around to the stern. There, at the water-line, were two large stop-cocks communicating with the reservoirs employed in the submersion of the vessel.
children.prevalue: The canoe was now brought around to the stern There at the water line were two large stop cocks communicating with the reservoirs employed in the submersion of the vessel

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The stop-cocks were opened, the reservoirs filled, and the Nautilus, slowly sinking, disappeared beneath the surface of the lake.
children.prevalue: The stop cocks were opened the reservoirs filled and the Nautilus slowly sinking disappeared beneath the surface of the lake

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: But the colonists were yet able to follow its descent through the waves. The powerful light it gave forth lighted up the translucent water, while the cavern became gradually obscure. At length this vast effusion of electric light faded away, and soon after the Nautilus, now the tomb of Captain Nemo, reposed in its ocean bed.
children.prevalue: But the colonists were yet able to follow its descent through the waves The powerful light it gave forth lighted up the translucent water while the cavern became gradually obscure At length this vast effusion of electric light faded away and soon after the Nautilus now the tomb of Captain Nemo reposed in its ocean bed

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At break of day the colonists regained in silence the entrance of the cavern, to which they gave the name of Dakkar Grotto, in memory of Captain Nemo. It was now low-water, and they passed without difficulty under the arcade, washed on the right by the sea.
children.prevalue: At break of day the colonists regained in silence the entrance of the cavern to which they gave the name of Dakkar Grotto in memory of Captain Nemo It was now low water and they passed without difficulty under the arcade washed on the right by the sea

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The canoe was left here, carefully protected from the waves. As additional precaution, Pencroft, Neb, and Ayrton drew it up on a little beach which bordered one of the sides of the grotto, in a spot where it could run no risk of harm.
children.prevalue: The canoe was left here carefully protected from the waves As additional precaution Pencroft Neb and Ayrton drew it up on a little beach which bordered one of the sides of the grotto in a spot where it could run no risk of harm

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The storm had ceased during the night. The last low mutterings of the thunder died away in the west. Rain fell no longer, but the sky was yet obscured by clouds. On the whole, this month of October, the first of the southern spring, was not ushered in by satisfactory tokens, and the wind had a tendency to shift from one point of the compass to another, which rendered it impossible to count upon settled weather.
children.prevalue: The storm had ceased during the night The last low mutterings of the thunder died away in the west Rain fell no longer but the sky was yet obscured by clouds On the whole this month of October the first of the southern spring was not ushered in by satisfactory tokens and the wind had a tendency to shift from one point of the compass to another which rendered it impossible to count upon settled weather

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Cyrus Harding and his companions, on leaving Dakkar Grotto, had taken the road to the corral. On their way Neb and Herbert were careful to preserve the wire which had been laid down by the captain between the corral and the grotto, and which might at a future time be of service.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and his companions on leaving Dakkar Grotto had taken the road to the corral On their way Neb and Herbert were careful to preserve the wire which had been laid down by the captain between the corral and the grotto and which might at a future time be of service

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The colonists spoke but little on the road. The various incidents of the night of October 15th had left a profound impression on their minds. The unknown being whose influence had so effectually protected them, the man whom their imagination had endowed with supernatural powers, Captain Nemo, was no more. His Nautilus and he were buried in the depths of the abyss. To each one of them their existence seemed even more isolated than before. They had been accustomed to count upon the intervention of that power which existed no longer, and Gideon Spilett, and even Cyrus Harding, could not escape this impression. Thus they maintained a profound silence during their journey to the corral.
children.prevalue: The colonists spoke but little on the road The various incidents of the night of October 15th had left a profound impression on their minds The unknown being whose influence had so effectually protected them the man whom their imagination had endowed with supernatural powers Captain Nemo was no more His Nautilus and he were buried in the depths of the abyss To each one of them their existence seemed even more isolated than before They had been accustomed to count upon the intervention of that power which existed no longer and Gideon Spilett and even Cyrus Harding could not escape this impression Thus they maintained a profound silence during their journey to the corral

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Towards nine in the morning the colonists arrived at Granite House.
children.prevalue: Towards nine in the morning the colonists arrived at Granite House

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It had been agreed that the construction of the vessel should be actively pushed forward, and Cyrus Harding more than ever devoted his time and labor to this object. It was impossible to divine what future lay before them. Evidently the advantage to the colonists would be great of having at their disposal a substantial vessel, capable of keeping the sea even in heavy weather, and large enough to attempt, in case of need, a voyage of some duration. Even if, when their vessel should be completed, the colonists should not resolve to leave Lincoln Island as yet, in order to gain either one of the Polynesian Archipelagoes of the Pacific or the shores of New Zealand, they might at least, sooner or later, proceed to Tabor Island, to leave there the notice relating to Ayrton. This was a precaution rendered indispensable by the possibility of the Scotch yacht reappearing in those seas, and it was of the highest importance that nothing should be neglected on this point.
children.prevalue: It had been agreed that the construction of the vessel should be actively pushed forward and Cyrus Harding more than ever devoted his time and labor to this object It was impossible to divine what future lay before them Evidently the advantage to the colonists would be great of having at their disposal a substantial vessel capable of keeping the sea even in heavy weather and large enough to attempt in case of need a voyage of some duration Even if when their vessel should be completed the colonists should not resolve to leave Lincoln Island as yet in order to gain either one of the Polynesian Archipelagoes of the Pacific or the shores of New Zealand they might at least sooner or later proceed to Tabor Island to leave there the notice relating to Ayrton This was a precaution rendered indispensable by the possibility of the Scotch yacht reappearing in those seas and it was of the highest importance that nothing should be neglected on this point

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The works were then resumed. Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, and Ayrton, assisted by Neb, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, except when unavoidably called off by other necessary occupations, worked without cessation. It was important that the new vessel should be ready in five months--that is to say, by the beginning of March--if they wished to visit Tabor Island before the equinoctial gales rendered the voyage impracticable. Therefore the carpenters lost not a moment. Moreover, it was unnecessary to manufacture rigging, that of the Speedy having been saved entire, so that the hull only of the vessel needed to be constructed.
children.prevalue: The works were then resumed Cyrus Harding Pencroft and Ayrton assisted by Neb Gideon Spilett and Herbert except when unavoidably called off by other necessary occupations worked without cessation It was important that the new vessel should be ready in five months that is to say by the beginning of March if they wished to visit Tabor Island before the equinoctial gales rendered the voyage impracticable Therefore the carpenters lost not a moment Moreover it was unnecessary to manufacture rigging that of the Speedy having been saved entire so that the hull only of the vessel needed to be constructed

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The end of the year 1868 found them occupied by these important labors, to the exclusion of almost all others. At the expiration of two months and a half the ribs had been set up and the first planks adjusted. It was already evident that the plans made by Cyrus Harding were admirable, and that the vessel would behave well at sea.
children.prevalue: The end of the year 1868 found them occupied by these important labors to the exclusion of almost all others At the expiration of two months and a half the ribs had been set up and the first planks adjusted It was already evident that the plans made by Cyrus Harding were admirable and that the vessel would behave well at sea

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Pencroft brought to the task a devouring energy, and would even grumble when one or the other abandoned the carpenter's axe for the gun of the hunter. It was nevertheless necessary to keep up the stores of Granite House, in view of the approaching winter. But this did not satisfy Pencroft. The brave, honest sailor was not content when the workmen were not at the dockyard. When this happened he grumbled vigorously, and, by way of venting his feelings, did the work of six men.
children.prevalue: Pencroft brought to the task a devouring energy and would even grumble when one or the other abandoned the carpenter s axe for the gun of the hunter It was nevertheless necessary to keep up the stores of Granite House in view of the approaching winter But this did not satisfy Pencroft The brave honest sailor was not content when the workmen were not at the dockyard When this happened he grumbled vigorously and by way of venting his feelings did the work of six men

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The weather was very unfavorable during the whole of the summer season. For some days the heat was overpowering, and the atmosphere, saturated with electricity, was only cleared by violent storms. It was rarely that the distant growling of the thunder could not be heard, like a low but incessant murmur, such as is produced in the equatorial regions of the globe.
children.prevalue: The weather was very unfavorable during the whole of the summer season For some days the heat was overpowering and the atmosphere saturated with electricity was only cleared by violent storms It was rarely that the distant growling of the thunder could not be heard like a low but incessant murmur such as is produced in the equatorial regions of the globe

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The 1st of January, 1869, was signalized by a storm of extreme violence, and the thunder burst several times over the island. Large trees were struck by the electric fluid and shattered, and among others one of those gigantic nettle-trees which had shaded the poultry-yard at the southern extremity of the lake. Had this meteor any relation to the phenomena going on in the bowels of the earth? Was there any connection between the commotion of the atmosphere and that of the interior of the earth? Cyrus Harding was inclined to think that such was the case, for the development of these storms was attended by the renewal of volcanic symptoms.
children.prevalue: The 1st of January 1869 was signalized by a storm of extreme violence and the thunder burst several times over the island Large trees were struck by the electric fluid and shattered and among others one of those gigantic nettle trees which had shaded the poultry yard at the southern extremity of the lake Had this meteor any relation to the phenomena going on in the bowels of the earth Was there any connection between the commotion of the atmosphere and that of the interior of the earth Cyrus Harding was inclined to think that such was the case for the development of these storms was attended by the renewal of volcanic symptoms

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It was on the 3rd of January that Herbert, having ascended at daybreak to the plateau of Prospect Heights to harness one of the onagers, perceived an enormous hat-shaped cloud rolling from the summit of the volcano.
children.prevalue: It was on the 3rd of January that Herbert having ascended at daybreak to the plateau of Prospect Heights to harness one of the onagers perceived an enormous hat shaped cloud rolling from the summit of the volcano

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Herbert immediately apprised the colonists, who at once joined him in watching the summit of Mount Franklin.
children.prevalue: Herbert immediately apprised the colonists who at once joined him in watching the summit of Mount Franklin

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Ah! exclaimed Pencroft, those are not vapors this time! It seems to me that the giant is not content with breathing; he must smoke!
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed Pencroft those are not vapors this time It seems to me that the giant is not content with breathing he must smoke

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: This figure of speech employed by the sailor exactly expressed the changes going on at the mouth of the volcano. Already for three months had the crater emitted vapors more or less dense, but which were as yet produced only by an internal ebullition of mineral substances. But now the vapors were replaced by a thick smoke, rising in the form of a grayish column, more than three hundred feet in width at its base, and which spread like an immense mushroom to a height of from seven to eight hundred feet above the summit of the mountain.
children.prevalue: This figure of speech employed by the sailor exactly expressed the changes going on at the mouth of the volcano Already for three months had the crater emitted vapors more or less dense but which were as yet produced only by an internal ebullition of mineral substances But now the vapors were replaced by a thick smoke rising in the form of a grayish column more than three hundred feet in width at its base and which spread like an immense mushroom to a height of from seven to eight hundred feet above the summit of the mountain

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The fire is in the chimney, observed Gideon Spilett.
children.prevalue: The fire is in the chimney observed Gideon Spilett

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And we can't put it out! replied Herbert.
children.prevalue: And we can t put it out replied Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The volcano ought to be swept, observed Neb, who spoke as if perfectly serious.
children.prevalue: The volcano ought to be swept observed Neb who spoke as if perfectly serious

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Well said, Neb! cried Pencroft, with a shout of laughter; and you'll undertake the job, no doubt?
children.prevalue: Well said Neb cried Pencroft with a shout of laughter and you ll undertake the job no doubt

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Cyrus Harding attentively observed the dense smoke emitted by Mount Franklin, and even listened, as if expecting to hear some distant muttering. Then, turning towards his companions, from whom he had gone somewhat apart, he said,--
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding attentively observed the dense smoke emitted by Mount Franklin and even listened as if expecting to hear some distant muttering Then turning towards his companions from whom he had gone somewhat apart he said

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The truth is, my friends, we must not conceal from ourselves that an important change is going forward. The volcanic substances are no longer in a state of ebullition, they have caught fire, and we are undoubtedly menaced by an approaching eruption.
children.prevalue: The truth is my friends we must not conceal from ourselves that an important change is going forward The volcanic substances are no longer in a state of ebullition they have caught fire and we are undoubtedly menaced by an approaching eruption

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well, captain, said Pencroft, we shall witness the eruption; and if it is a good one, we'll applaud it. I don't see that we need concern ourselves further about the matter.
children.prevalue: Well captain said Pencroft we shall witness the eruption and if it is a good one we ll applaud it I don t see that we need concern ourselves further about the matter

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It may be so, replied Cyrus Harding, for the ancient track of the lava is still open; and thanks to this, the crater has hitherto overflowed towards the north. And yet--
children.prevalue: It may be so replied Cyrus Harding for the ancient track of the lava is still open and thanks to this the crater has hitherto overflowed towards the north And yet

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And yet, as we can derive no advantage from an eruption, it might be better it should not take place, said the reporter.
children.prevalue: And yet as we can derive no advantage from an eruption it might be better it should not take place said the reporter

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Who knows? answered the sailor. Perhaps there may be some valuable substance in this volcano, which it will spout forth, and which we may turn to good account!
children.prevalue: Who knows answered the sailor Perhaps there may be some valuable substance in this volcano which it will spout forth and which we may turn to good account

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Cyrus Harding shook his head with the air of a man who augured no good from the phenomenon whose development had been so sudden. He did not regard so lightly as Pencroft the results of an eruption. If the lava, in consequence of the position of the crater, did not directly menace the wooded and cultivated parts of the island, other complications might present themselves. In fact, eruptions are not unfrequently accompanied by earthquakes; and an island of the nature of Lincoln Island, formed of substances so varied, basalt on one side, granite on the other, lava on the north, rich soil on the south, substances which consequently could not be firmly attached to each other, would be exposed to the risk of disintegration. Although, therefore, the spreading of the volcanic matter might not constitute a serious danger, any movement of the terrestrial structure which should shake the island might entail the gravest consequences.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding shook his head with the air of a man who augured no good from the phenomenon whose development had been so sudden He did not regard so lightly as Pencroft the results of an eruption If the lava in consequence of the position of the crater did not directly menace the wooded and cultivated parts of the island other complications might present themselves In fact eruptions are not unfrequently accompanied by earthquakes and an island of the nature of Lincoln Island formed of substances so varied basalt on one side granite on the other lava on the north rich soil on the south substances which consequently could not be firmly attached to each other would be exposed to the risk of disintegration Although therefore the spreading of the volcanic matter might not constitute a serious danger any movement of the terrestrial structure which should shake the island might entail the gravest consequences

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It seems to me, said Ayrton, who had reclined so as to place his ear to the ground, it seems to me that I can hear a dull, rumbling sound, like that of a wagon loaded with bars of iron.
children.prevalue: It seems to me said Ayrton who had reclined so as to place his ear to the ground it seems to me that I can hear a dull rumbling sound like that of a wagon loaded with bars of iron

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The colonists listened with the greatest attention, and were convinced that Ayrton was not mistaken. The rumbling was mingled with a subterranean roar, which formed a sort of rinforzando, and died slowly away, as if some violent storm had passed through the profundities of the globe. But no explosion properly so termed, could be heard. It might therefore be concluded that the vapors and smoke found a free passage through the central shaft; and that the safety-valve being sufficiently large, no convulsion would be produced, no explosion was to be apprehended.
children.prevalue: The colonists listened with the greatest attention and were convinced that Ayrton was not mistaken The rumbling was mingled with a subterranean roar which formed a sort of rinforzando and died slowly away as if some violent storm had passed through the profundities of the globe But no explosion properly so termed could be heard It might therefore be concluded that the vapors and smoke found a free passage through the central shaft and that the safety valve being sufficiently large no convulsion would be produced no explosion was to be apprehended

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Well, then! said Pencroft, are we not going back to work? Let Mount Franklin smoke, groan, bellow, or spout forth fire and flame as much as it pleases, that is no reason why we should be idle! Come, Ayrton, Neb, Herbert, Captain Harding, Mr. Spilett, every one of us must turn to at our work to-day! We are going to place the keelson, and a dozen pair of hands would not be too many. Before two months I want our new 'Bonadventure'--for we shall keep the old name, shall we not?--to float on the waters of Port Balloon! Therefore there is not an hour to lose!
children.prevalue: Well then said Pencroft are we not going back to work Let Mount Franklin smoke groan bellow or spout forth fire and flame as much as it pleases that is no reason why we should be idle Come Ayrton Neb Herbert Captain Harding Mr Spilett every one of us must turn to at our work to day We are going to place the keelson and a dozen pair of hands would not be too many Before two months I want our new Bonadventure for we shall keep the old name shall we not to float on the waters of Port Balloon Therefore there is not an hour to lose

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: All the colonists, their services thus requisitioned by Pencroft, descended to the dockyard, and proceeded to place the keelson, a thick mass of wood which forms the lower portion of a ship and unites firmly the timbers of the hull. It was an arduous undertaking, in which all took part.
children.prevalue: All the colonists their services thus requisitioned by Pencroft descended to the dockyard and proceeded to place the keelson a thick mass of wood which forms the lower portion of a ship and unites firmly the timbers of the hull It was an arduous undertaking in which all took part

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: They continued their labors during the whole of this day, the 3rd of January, without thinking further of the volcano, which could not, besides, be seen from the shore of Granite House. But once or twice, large shadows, veiling the sun, which described its diurnal arc through an extremely clear sky, indicated that a thick cloud of smoke passed between its disc and the island. The wind, blowing on the shore, carried all these vapors to the westward. Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett remarked these somber appearances, and from time to time discussed the evident progress of the volcanic phenomena, but their work went on without interruption. It was, besides, of the first importance from every point of view, that the vessel should be finished with the least possible delay. In presence of the eventualities which might arise, the safety of the colonists would be to a great extent secured by their ship. Who could tell that it might not prove some day their only refuge?
children.prevalue: They continued their labors during the whole of this day the 3rd of January without thinking further of the volcano which could not besides be seen from the shore of Granite House But once or twice large shadows veiling the sun which described its diurnal arc through an extremely clear sky indicated that a thick cloud of smoke passed between its disc and the island The wind blowing on the shore carried all these vapors to the westward Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett remarked these somber appearances and from time to time discussed the evident progress of the volcanic phenomena but their work went on without interruption It was besides of the first importance from every point of view that the vessel should be finished with the least possible delay In presence of the eventualities which might arise the safety of the colonists would be to a great extent secured by their ship Who could tell that it might not prove some day their only refuge

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: In the evening, after supper, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert again ascended the plateau of Prospect Heights. It was already dark, and the obscurity would permit them to ascertain if flames or incandescent matter thrown up by the volcano were mingled with the vapor and smoke accumulated at the mouth of the crater.
children.prevalue: In the evening after supper Cyrus Harding Gideon Spilett and Herbert again ascended the plateau of Prospect Heights It was already dark and the obscurity would permit them to ascertain if flames or incandescent matter thrown up by the volcano were mingled with the vapor and smoke accumulated at the mouth of the crater

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The crater is on fire! said Herbert, who, more active than his companion, first reached the plateau.
children.prevalue: The crater is on fire said Herbert who more active than his companion first reached the plateau

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Mount Franklin, distant about six miles, now appeared like a gigantic torch, around the summit of which turned fuliginous flames. So much smoke, and possibly scoriae and cinders were mingled with them, that their light gleamed but faintly amid the gloom of the night. But a kind of lurid brilliancy spread over the island, against which stood out confusedly the wooded masses of the heights. Immense whirlwinds of vapor obscured the sky, through which glimmered a few stars.
children.prevalue: Mount Franklin distant about six miles now appeared like a gigantic torch around the summit of which turned fuliginous flames So much smoke and possibly scoriae and cinders were mingled with them that their light gleamed but faintly amid the gloom of the night But a kind of lurid brilliancy spread over the island against which stood out confusedly the wooded masses of the heights Immense whirlwinds of vapor obscured the sky through which glimmered a few stars

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The change is rapid! said the engineer.
children.prevalue: The change is rapid said the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: That is not surprising, answered the reporter. The reawakening of the volcano already dates back some time. You may remember, Cyrus, that the first vapors appeared about the time we searched the sides of the mountain to discover Captain Nemo's retreat. It was, if I mistake not, about the 15th of October.
children.prevalue: That is not surprising answered the reporter The reawakening of the volcano already dates back some time You may remember Cyrus that the first vapors appeared about the time we searched the sides of the mountain to discover Captain Nemo s retreat It was if I mistake not about the 15th of October

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes, replied Herbert, two months and a half ago!
children.prevalue: Yes replied Herbert two months and a half ago

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The subterranean fires have therefore been smoldering for ten weeks, resumed Gideon Spilett, and it is not to be wondered at that they now break out with such violence!
children.prevalue: The subterranean fires have therefore been smoldering for ten weeks resumed Gideon Spilett and it is not to be wondered at that they now break out with such violence

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Do not you feel a certain vibration of the soil? asked Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Do not you feel a certain vibration of the soil asked Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Yes, replied Gideon Spilett, but there is a great difference between that and an earthquake.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Gideon Spilett but there is a great difference between that and an earthquake

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I do not affirm that we are menaced with an earthquake, answered Cyrus Harding, may God preserve us from that! No; these vibrations are due to the effervescence of the central fire. The crust of the earth is simply the shell of a boiler, and you know that such a shell, under the pressure of steam, vibrates like a sonorous plate. It is this effect which is being produced at this moment.
children.prevalue: I do not affirm that we are menaced with an earthquake answered Cyrus Harding may God preserve us from that No these vibrations are due to the effervescence of the central fire The crust of the earth is simply the shell of a boiler and you know that such a shell under the pressure of steam vibrates like a sonorous plate It is this effect which is being produced at this moment

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What magnificent flames! exclaimed Herbert.
children.prevalue: What magnificent flames exclaimed Herbert

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: At this instant a kind of bouquet of flames shot forth from the crater, the brilliancy of which was visible even through the vapors. Thousands of luminous sheets and barbed tongues of fire were cast in various directions. Some, extending beyond the dome of smoke, dissipated it, leaving behind an incandescent powder. This was accompanied by successive explosions, resembling the discharge of a battery of machine-guns.
children.prevalue: At this instant a kind of bouquet of flames shot forth from the crater the brilliancy of which was visible even through the vapors Thousands of luminous sheets and barbed tongues of fire were cast in various directions Some extending beyond the dome of smoke dissipated it leaving behind an incandescent powder This was accompanied by successive explosions resembling the discharge of a battery of machine guns

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and Herbert, after spending an hour on the plateau of Prospect Heights, again descended to the beach, and returned to Granite House. The engineer was thoughtful and preoccupied, so much so, indeed, that Gideon Spilett inquired if he apprehended any immediate danger, of which the eruption might directly or indirectly be the cause.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding the reporter and Herbert after spending an hour on the plateau of Prospect Heights again descended to the beach and returned to Granite House The engineer was thoughtful and preoccupied so much so indeed that Gideon Spilett inquired if he apprehended any immediate danger of which the eruption might directly or indirectly be the cause

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, and no, answered Cyrus Harding.
children.prevalue: Yes and no answered Cyrus Harding

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Nevertheless, continued the reporter, would not the greatest misfortune which could happen to us be an earthquake which would overturn the island? Now, I do not suppose that this is to be feared, since the vapors and lava have found a free outlet.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless continued the reporter would not the greatest misfortune which could happen to us be an earthquake which would overturn the island Now I do not suppose that this is to be feared since the vapors and lava have found a free outlet

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: True, replied Cyrus Harding, and I do not fear an earthquake in the sense in which the term is commonly applied to convulsions of the soil provoked by the expansion of subterranean gases. But other causes may produce great disasters.
children.prevalue: True replied Cyrus Harding and I do not fear an earthquake in the sense in which the term is commonly applied to convulsions of the soil provoked by the expansion of subterranean gases But other causes may produce great disasters

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: How so, my dear Cyrus?'
children.prevalue: How so my dear Cyrus

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I am not certain. I must consider. I must visit the mountain. In a few days I shall learn more on this point.
children.prevalue: I am not certain I must consider I must visit the mountain In a few days I shall learn more on this point

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Gideon Spilett said no more, and soon, in spite of the explosions of the volcano, whose intensity increased, and which were repeated by the echoes of the island, the inhabitants of Granite House were sleeping soundly.
children.prevalue: Gideon Spilett said no more and soon in spite of the explosions of the volcano whose intensity increased and which were repeated by the echoes of the island the inhabitants of Granite House were sleeping soundly

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Three days passed by--the 4th, 5th, and 6th of January. The construction of the vessel was diligently continued, and without offering further explanations the engineer pushed forward the work with all his energy. Mount Franklin was now hooded by a somber cloud of sinister aspect, and, amid the flames, vomiting forth incandescent rocks, some of which fell back into the crater itself. This caused Pencroft, who would only look at the matter in the light of a joke, to exclaim,--
children.prevalue: Three days passed by the 4th 5th and 6th of January The construction of the vessel was diligently continued and without offering further explanations the engineer pushed forward the work with all his energy Mount Franklin was now hooded by a somber cloud of sinister aspect and amid the flames vomiting forth incandescent rocks some of which fell back into the crater itself This caused Pencroft who would only look at the matter in the light of a joke to exclaim

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Ah! the giant is playing at cup and ball; he is a conjurer.
children.prevalue: Ah the giant is playing at cup and ball he is a conjurer

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: In fact, the substances thrown up fell back again in to the abyss, and it did not seem that the lava, though swollen by the internal pressure, had yet risen to the orifice of the crater. At any rate, the opening on the northeast, which was partly visible, poured out no torrent upon the northern slope of the mountain.
children.prevalue: In fact the substances thrown up fell back again in to the abyss and it did not seem that the lava though swollen by the internal pressure had yet risen to the orifice of the crater At any rate the opening on the northeast which was partly visible poured out no torrent upon the northern slope of the mountain

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Nevertheless, however pressing was the construction of the vessel, other duties demanded the presence of the colonists on various portions of the island. Before everything it was necessary to go to the corral, where the flocks of musmons and goats were enclosed, and replenish the provision of forage for those animals. It was accordingly arranged that Ayrton should proceed thither the next day, the 7th of January; and as he was sufficient for the task, to which he was accustomed, Pencroft and the rest were somewhat surprised on hearing the engineer say to Ayrton--
children.prevalue: Nevertheless however pressing was the construction of the vessel other duties demanded the presence of the colonists on various portions of the island Before everything it was necessary to go to the corral where the flocks of musmons and goats were enclosed and replenish the provision of forage for those animals It was accordingly arranged that Ayrton should proceed thither the next day the 7th of January and as he was sufficient for the task to which he was accustomed Pencroft and the rest were somewhat surprised on hearing the engineer say to Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: As you are going to-morrow to the corral I will accompany you.
children.prevalue: As you are going to morrow to the corral I will accompany you

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: But, Captain Harding, exclaimed the sailor, our working days will not be many, and if you go also we shall be two pair of hands short!
children.prevalue: But Captain Harding exclaimed the sailor our working days will not be many and if you go also we shall be two pair of hands short

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: We shall return to-morrow, replied Cyrus Harding, but it is necessary that I should go to the corral. I must learn how the eruption is progressing.
children.prevalue: We shall return to morrow replied Cyrus Harding but it is necessary that I should go to the corral I must learn how the eruption is progressing

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The eruption! always the eruption! answered Pencroft, with an air of discontent. An important thing, truly, this eruption! I trouble myself very little about it.
children.prevalue: The eruption always the eruption answered Pencroft with an air of discontent An important thing truly this eruption I trouble myself very little about it

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Whatever might be the sailor's opinion, the expedition projected by the engineer was settled for the next day. Herbert wished to accompany Cyrus Harding, but he would not vex Pencroft by his absence.
children.prevalue: Whatever might be the sailor s opinion the expedition projected by the engineer was settled for the next day Herbert wished to accompany Cyrus Harding but he would not vex Pencroft by his absence

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The next day, at dawn, Cyrus Harding and Ayrton, mounting the cart drawn by two onagers, took the road to the corral and set off at a round trot.
children.prevalue: The next day at dawn Cyrus Harding and Ayrton mounting the cart drawn by two onagers took the road to the corral and set off at a round trot

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Above the forest were passing large clouds, to which the crater of Mount Franklin incessantly added fuliginous matter. These clouds, which rolled heavily in the air, were evidently composed of heterogeneous substances. It was not alone from the volcano that they derived their strange opacity and weight. Scoriae, in a state of dust, like powdered pumice-stone, and grayish ashes as small as the finest feculae, were held in suspension in the midst of their thick folds. These ashes are so fine that they have been observed in the air for whole months. After the eruption of 1783 in Iceland for upwards of a year the atmosphere was thus charged with volcanic dust through which the rays of the sun were only with difficulty discernible.
children.prevalue: Above the forest were passing large clouds to which the crater of Mount Franklin incessantly added fuliginous matter These clouds which rolled heavily in the air were evidently composed of heterogeneous substances It was not alone from the volcano that they derived their strange opacity and weight Scoriae in a state of dust like powdered pumice stone and grayish ashes as small as the finest feculae were held in suspension in the midst of their thick folds These ashes are so fine that they have been observed in the air for whole months After the eruption of 1783 in Iceland for upwards of a year the atmosphere was thus charged with volcanic dust through which the rays of the sun were only with difficulty discernible

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But more often this pulverized matter falls, and this happened on the present occasion. Cyrus Harding and Ayrton had scarcely reached the corral when a sort of black snow like fine gunpowder fell, and instantly changed the appearance of the soil. Trees, meadows, all disappeared beneath a covering several inches in depth. But, very fortunately, the wind blew from the northeast, and the greater part of the cloud dissolved itself over the sea.
children.prevalue: But more often this pulverized matter falls and this happened on the present occasion Cyrus Harding and Ayrton had scarcely reached the corral when a sort of black snow like fine gunpowder fell and instantly changed the appearance of the soil Trees meadows all disappeared beneath a covering several inches in depth But very fortunately the wind blew from the northeast and the greater part of the cloud dissolved itself over the sea

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: This is very singular, Captain Harding, said Ayrton.
children.prevalue: This is very singular Captain Harding said Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It is very serious, replied the engineer. This powdered pumice-stone, all this mineral dust, proves how grave is the convulsion going forward in the lower depths of the volcano.
children.prevalue: It is very serious replied the engineer This powdered pumice stone all this mineral dust proves how grave is the convulsion going forward in the lower depths of the volcano

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: But can nothing be done?
children.prevalue: But can nothing be done

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Nothing, except to note the progress of the phenomenon. Do you, therefore, Ayrton, occupy yourself with the necessary work at the corral. In the meantime I will ascend just beyond the source of Red Creek and examine the condition of the mountain upon its northern aspect. Then--
children.prevalue: Nothing except to note the progress of the phenomenon Do you therefore Ayrton occupy yourself with the necessary work at the corral In the meantime I will ascend just beyond the source of Red Creek and examine the condition of the mountain upon its northern aspect Then

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Well, Captain Harding?
children.prevalue: Well Captain Harding

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Then we will pay a visit to Dakkar Grotto. I wish to inspect it. At any rate I will come back for you in two hours.
children.prevalue: Then we will pay a visit to Dakkar Grotto I wish to inspect it At any rate I will come back for you in two hours

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ayrton then proceeded to enter the corral, and, while awaiting the engineer's return, busied himself with the musmons and goats which seemed to feel a certain uneasiness in presence of these first signs of an eruption.
children.prevalue: Ayrton then proceeded to enter the corral and while awaiting the engineer s return busied himself with the musmons and goats which seemed to feel a certain uneasiness in presence of these first signs of an eruption

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Meanwhile Cyrus Harding ascended the crest of the eastern spur, passed Red Creek, and arrived at the spot where he and his companions had discovered a sulphurous spring at the time of their first exploration.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile Cyrus Harding ascended the crest of the eastern spur passed Red Creek and arrived at the spot where he and his companions had discovered a sulphurous spring at the time of their first exploration

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: How changed was everything! Instead of a single column of smoke he counted thirteen, forced through the soil as if violently propelled by some piston. It was evident that the crust of the earth was subjected in this part of the globe to a frightful pressure. The atmosphere was saturated with gases and carbonic acid, mingled with aqueous vapors. Cyrus Harding felt the volcanic tufa with which the plain was strewn, and which was but pulverized cinders hardened into solid blocks by time, tremble beneath him, but he could discover no traces of fresh lava.
children.prevalue: How changed was everything Instead of a single column of smoke he counted thirteen forced through the soil as if violently propelled by some piston It was evident that the crust of the earth was subjected in this part of the globe to a frightful pressure The atmosphere was saturated with gases and carbonic acid mingled with aqueous vapors Cyrus Harding felt the volcanic tufa with which the plain was strewn and which was but pulverized cinders hardened into solid blocks by time tremble beneath him but he could discover no traces of fresh lava

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The engineer became more assured of this when he observed all the northern part of Mount Franklin. Pillars of smoke and flame escaped from the crater; a hail of scoriae fell on the ground; but no current of lava burst from the mouth of the volcano, which proved that the volcanic matter had not yet attained the level of the superior orifice of the central shaft.
children.prevalue: The engineer became more assured of this when he observed all the northern part of Mount Franklin Pillars of smoke and flame escaped from the crater a hail of scoriae fell on the ground but no current of lava burst from the mouth of the volcano which proved that the volcanic matter had not yet attained the level of the superior orifice of the central shaft

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: But I would prefer that it were so, said Cyrus Harding to himself. At any rate, I should then know that the lava had followed its accustomed track. Who can say that it may not take a new course? But the danger does not consist in that! Captain Nemo foresaw it clearly! No, the danger does not lie there!
children.prevalue: But I would prefer that it were so said Cyrus Harding to himself At any rate I should then know that the lava had followed its accustomed track Who can say that it may not take a new course But the danger does not consist in that Captain Nemo foresaw it clearly No the danger does not lie there

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Cyrus Harding advanced towards the enormous causeway whose prolongation enclosed the narrow Shark Gulf. He could now sufficiently examine on this side the ancient channels of the lava. There was no doubt in his mind that the most recent eruption had occurred at a far-distant epoch.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding advanced towards the enormous causeway whose prolongation enclosed the narrow Shark Gulf He could now sufficiently examine on this side the ancient channels of the lava There was no doubt in his mind that the most recent eruption had occurred at a far distant epoch

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: He then returned by the same way, listening attentively to the subterranean mutterings which rolled like long-continued thunder, interrupted by deafening explosions. At nine in the morning he reached the corral.
children.prevalue: He then returned by the same way listening attentively to the subterranean mutterings which rolled like long continued thunder interrupted by deafening explosions At nine in the morning he reached the corral

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Ayrton awaited him.
children.prevalue: Ayrton awaited him

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The animals are cared for, Captain Harding, said Ayrton.
children.prevalue: The animals are cared for Captain Harding said Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Good, Ayrton.
children.prevalue: Good Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: They seem uneasy, Captain Harding.
children.prevalue: They seem uneasy Captain Harding

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Yes, instinct speaks through them, and instinct is never deceived.
children.prevalue: Yes instinct speaks through them and instinct is never deceived

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Are you ready?
children.prevalue: Are you ready

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Take a lamp, Ayrton, answered the engineer; we will start at once.
children.prevalue: Take a lamp Ayrton answered the engineer we will start at once

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Ayrton did as desired. The onagers, unharnessed, roamed in the corral. The gate was secured on the outside, and Cyrus Harding, preceding Ayrton, took the narrow path which led westward to the shore.
children.prevalue: Ayrton did as desired The onagers unharnessed roamed in the corral The gate was secured on the outside and Cyrus Harding preceding Ayrton took the narrow path which led westward to the shore

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The soil they walked upon was choked with the pulverized matter fallen from the cloud. No quadruped appeared in the woods. Even the birds had fled. Sometimes a passing breeze raised the covering of ashes, and the two colonists, enveloped in a whirlwind of dust, lost sight of each other. They were then careful to cover their eyes and mouths with handkerchiefs, for they ran the risk of being blinded and suffocated.
children.prevalue: The soil they walked upon was choked with the pulverized matter fallen from the cloud No quadruped appeared in the woods Even the birds had fled Sometimes a passing breeze raised the covering of ashes and the two colonists enveloped in a whirlwind of dust lost sight of each other They were then careful to cover their eyes and mouths with handkerchiefs for they ran the risk of being blinded and suffocated

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: It was impossible for Cyrus Harding and Ayrton, with these impediments, to make rapid progress. Moreover, the atmosphere was close, as if the oxygen had been partly burned up, and had become unfit for respiration. At every hundred paces they were obliged to stop to take breath. It was therefore past ten o'clock when the engineer and his companion reached the crest of the enormous mass of rocks of basalt and porphyry which composed the northwest coast of the island.
children.prevalue: It was impossible for Cyrus Harding and Ayrton with these impediments to make rapid progress Moreover the atmosphere was close as if the oxygen had been partly burned up and had become unfit for respiration At every hundred paces they were obliged to stop to take breath It was therefore past ten o clock when the engineer and his companion reached the crest of the enormous mass of rocks of basalt and porphyry which composed the northwest coast of the island

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Ayrton and Cyrus Harding commenced the descent of this abrupt declivity, following almost step for step the difficult path which, during that stormy night, had led them to Dakkar Grotto. In open day the descent was less perilous, and, besides, the bed of ashes which covered the polished surface of the rock enabled them to make their footing more secure.
children.prevalue: Ayrton and Cyrus Harding commenced the descent of this abrupt declivity following almost step for step the difficult path which during that stormy night had led them to Dakkar Grotto In open day the descent was less perilous and besides the bed of ashes which covered the polished surface of the rock enabled them to make their footing more secure

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The ridge at the end of the shore, about forty feet in height, was soon reached. Cyrus Harding recollected that this elevation gradually sloped towards the level of the sea. Although the tide was at present low, no beach could be seen, and the waves, thickened by the volcanic dust, beat upon the basaltic rocks.
children.prevalue: The ridge at the end of the shore about forty feet in height was soon reached Cyrus Harding recollected that this elevation gradually sloped towards the level of the sea Although the tide was at present low no beach could be seen and the waves thickened by the volcanic dust beat upon the basaltic rocks

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Cyrus Harding and Ayrton found without difficulty the entrance to Dakkar Grotto, and paused for a moment at the last rock before it.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding and Ayrton found without difficulty the entrance to Dakkar Grotto and paused for a moment at the last rock before it

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The iron boat should be there, said the engineer.
children.prevalue: The iron boat should be there said the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: It is here, Captain Harding, replied Ayrton, drawing towards him the fragile craft, which was protected by the arch of the vault.
children.prevalue: It is here Captain Harding replied Ayrton drawing towards him the fragile craft which was protected by the arch of the vault

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: On board, Ayrton!
children.prevalue: On board Ayrton

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The two colonists stepped into the boat. A slight undulation of the waves carried it farther under the low arch of the crypt, and there Ayrton, with the aid of flint and steel, lighted the lamp. He then took the oars, and the lamp having been placed in the bow of the boat, so that its rays fell before them, Cyrus Harding took the helm and steered through the shades of the grotto.
children.prevalue: The two colonists stepped into the boat A slight undulation of the waves carried it farther under the low arch of the crypt and there Ayrton with the aid of flint and steel lighted the lamp He then took the oars and the lamp having been placed in the bow of the boat so that its rays fell before them Cyrus Harding took the helm and steered through the shades of the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: The Nautilus was there no longer to illuminate the cavern with its electric light. Possibly it might not yet be extinguished, but no ray escaped from the depths of the abyss in which reposed all that was mortal of Captain Nemo.
children.prevalue: The Nautilus was there no longer to illuminate the cavern with its electric light Possibly it might not yet be extinguished but no ray escaped from the depths of the abyss in which reposed all that was mortal of Captain Nemo

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The light afforded by the lamp, although feeble, nevertheless enabled the engineer to advance slowly, following the wall of the cavern. A deathlike silence reigned under the vaulted roof, or at least in the anterior portion, for soon Cyrus Harding distinctly heard the rumbling which proceeded from the bowels of the mountain.
children.prevalue: The light afforded by the lamp although feeble nevertheless enabled the engineer to advance slowly following the wall of the cavern A deathlike silence reigned under the vaulted roof or at least in the anterior portion for soon Cyrus Harding distinctly heard the rumbling which proceeded from the bowels of the mountain

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: That comes from the volcano, he said.
children.prevalue: That comes from the volcano he said

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Besides these sounds, the presence of chemical combinations was soon betrayed by their powerful odor, and the engineer and his companion were almost suffocated by sulphurous vapors.
children.prevalue: Besides these sounds the presence of chemical combinations was soon betrayed by their powerful odor and the engineer and his companion were almost suffocated by sulphurous vapors

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: This is what Captain Nemo feared, murmured Cyrus Harding, changing countenance. We must go to the end, notwithstanding.
children.prevalue: This is what Captain Nemo feared murmured Cyrus Harding changing countenance We must go to the end notwithstanding

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Forward! replied Ayrton, bending to his oars and directing the boat towards the head of the cavern.
children.prevalue: Forward replied Ayrton bending to his oars and directing the boat towards the head of the cavern

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Twenty-five minutes after entering the mouth of the grotto the boat reached the extreme end.
children.prevalue: Twenty five minutes after entering the mouth of the grotto the boat reached the extreme end

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Cyrus Harding then, standing up, cast the light of the lamp upon the walls of the cavern which separated it from the central shaft of the volcano. What was the thickness of this wall? It might be ten feet or a hundred feet--it was impossible to say. But the subterranean sounds were too perceptible to allow of the supposition that it was of any great thickness.
children.prevalue: Cyrus Harding then standing up cast the light of the lamp upon the walls of the cavern which separated it from the central shaft of the volcano What was the thickness of this wall It might be ten feet or a hundred feet it was impossible to say But the subterranean sounds were too perceptible to allow of the supposition that it was of any great thickness

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: The engineer, after having explored the wall at a certain height horizontally, fastened the lamp to the end of an oar, and again surveyed the basaltic wall at a greater elevation.
children.prevalue: The engineer after having explored the wall at a certain height horizontally fastened the lamp to the end of an oar and again surveyed the basaltic wall at a greater elevation

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: There, through scarcely visible clefts and joinings, escaped a pungent vapor, which infected the atmosphere of the cavern. The wall was broken by large cracks, some of which extended to within two or three feet of the water's edge.
children.prevalue: There through scarcely visible clefts and joinings escaped a pungent vapor which infected the atmosphere of the cavern The wall was broken by large cracks some of which extended to within two or three feet of the water s edge

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Cyrus Harding thought for a brief space. Then he said in a low voice,--
